**Annotations and Commentary on the *True Classic of Southern Florescence*, Scroll One**
**Guo Xiang of Henan, Commentator**
**Cheng Xuanying of the Western Florescence School, Tang Dynasty, Subcommentator**

**Inner Chapters – "Free and Easy Wandering" (First)**

**[Commentary]**
Though small and great differ, when released into the realm of self-attainment, things follow their nature, affairs match their capacities, and each abides in its proper measure—free and easy wandering is one. How could victory or defeat arise between them?

**In the Northern Darkness there is a fish, its name is Kun.**
The greatness of Kun—no one knows how many thousand *li* it spans.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Darkness" (*ming*) is like "sea," taken for its vast and boundless obscurity, hence called "darkness." Dongfang Shuo’s *Record of the Ten Continents* states: "The Dark Sea has no wind, yet its waves rise a hundred *zhang*." Within this immense sea dwells this great fish, intended to illustrate the spontaneity of things’ natures, thus placed at the chapter’s head. The *Mysteries Within Records* says: "In the east there is a great fish; a traveler takes a day to pass its head, seven days to pass its tail. When it spawns for three days, the azure sea turns red." Thus we know great things arise in great places—why only the Northern Darkness? It transforms into a bird, its name is Peng.

**[Commentary]**
The reality of Peng and Kun, I have not yet fathomed. Master Zhuang’s grand intent lies in free and easy wandering, non-action and self-attainment. Thus he exhausts the extremes of small and great to clarify the suitability of inherent nature. Those of far-reaching vision should grasp its convergence and let go of its lodging—there is no need to quibble over every detail with the living. As long as it does not harm the great purport, all may be passed over.

**[Subcommentary]**
The four seasons race like wind, the three luminaries course like lightning—thus one may bear mountains and cast off the old, or hoist valleys and hasten toward the new. Therefore, the transformation of fish into bird serves to illuminate the grand principle of change. The Peng’s back—who knows how many thousand *li* it spans? Roused to flight, its wings hang like clouds suspended from the sky.

**[Subcommentary]**
The fish is described in terms of its vastness to show how its head and tail defy comprehension; the bird is spoken of in terms of its back to suggest that its length is beyond measure. Thus the text below states, “None have known its full extent.” Beating its wings in fury, its feathers bristle with vigor—now it seeks to strike the wind, now it prepares to cleave the water. Then it severs the clouds; its back bears the azure sky. Soaring and wheeling, it grazes the thunder and the Milky Way, riding the yin to cast its shadow, like a cloud descending from the edge of heaven.

This bird, when the sea stirs, will migrate to the Southern Darkness. The Southern Darkness is the Celestial Pond.

**[Commentary]**
No mere dark sea could bear its body; no less than ninety thousand *li* could support its wings. Is this mere love of the marvelous? It is simply that great things must arise in great places, and great places must give rise to such great things—this is the inherent pattern of nature, free from error. Why trouble the mind over such matters?

**[Subcommentary]**
*Yun* means “to turn.” *Shi* refers to this Peng-bird. Its form is so massive that without the sea’s turning motion, it could not ascend—all this is inevitable, not a matter of preference. Moreover, as its form undergoes transformation, so too does its nature. Once a fish, it swam in the Northern Sea; now a bird, it soars toward the Southern Darkness. Though its rise and fall differ in kind, its ease is one. This is like life and death, gathering and dispersal—whatever it encounters is fitting. Through ten thousand transformations, it has never ceased to be itself.

The reason for the fish’s transformation into a bird, moving from north to south, lies in this: the bird is a creature of the void, and the south is the direction of the Morning Star; the fish is a creature of stagnation, and the north holds the land of deep obscurity. The intent is to show the turning toward light and away from darkness, the casting off of stagnation in pursuit of progress. Thus the fish and bird of north and south are presented as the path of the Way.

The great sea and vast rivers originate from the workings of creation, not from human hands—hence it is called the Celestial Pond.

*The Record of Qi Xie* is a chronicle of marvels. It states: When the Peng migrates to the Southern Darkness, it strikes the water for three thousand *li*, then beats against the whirlwind to ascend ninety thousand *li*.

**[Commentary]**
With wings so vast, it cannot take flight easily—only by striking the whirlwind can it rise, and only at ninety thousand *li* can it fully sustain itself. Given such wings, how could it rise sluggishly, only to descend after a few *ren*? All this is inevitable, not a matter of preference.

It departs with the winds of the sixth month.

**[Commentary]**
The great bird departs for half a year before resting at the Celestial Pond; the small bird flies for half a morning before alighting on the elm or sandalwood. Though their capacities differ, their fulfillment of nature is one.

**[Subcommentary]**
Qi Xie is the name of a person. It may also refer to the title of a book—there exists in the state of Qi a record called *Xie* that chronicles strange events. *Ji* means “to strike,” *bo* means “to contend,” and *fuyao* is a whirlwind. The book compiled by Qi Xie records many marvels, and Master Zhuang cites it as evidence to confirm that his account is not baseless.

When the great Peng sets out for the Southern Darkness, it cannot rise sluggishly. Thus it strikes its wings, stirring three thousand *li* of water, and travels along the surface before it can leave the sea. Then, spiraling and circling, it beats its wings in fury, riding the wind’s force to ascend. After traversing ninety thousand *li* and half a year’s time, it arrives at last, its ambition fulfilled, and speaks of resting. It seeks only what suffices—how could it be a matter of preference?

The wild horses, the dust motes—all living things are blown aloft by one another’s breath.

**[Commentary]**
These are what the Peng relies upon to fly. The “wild horses” are wandering *qi*.

**[Subcommentary]**
The *Erya* states: “Beyond the city is the outskirts, beyond the outskirts is the pasture, beyond the pasture is the wilds.” Here, it refers to the time of spring, when the yang *qi* stirs. Gazing into the marshes, one sees *qi* like galloping horses—hence the term “wild horses.” Dust is raised earth; the finest dust is called motes. Between heaven and earth, the breath of living things blows one another aloft, enabling the Peng’s flight.

The four kinds of life, the ten thousand forms—all differ in shape and nature, each requiring different supports. Thus the Peng beats its wings that span the sky, riding the wind in ease; the cicada and fledgling dove stretch their small wings, alighting on the elm or sandalwood in contentment. All act in accord with their nature, receiving it from creation. They harbor no preference for far or near, nor do they concern themselves with pride or humility. Those who embody this spirit—why should they speak of longing or aspiration?

Is the deep blue of heaven its true color? Or is it so distant that it has no end? When the Peng looks down, it sees only as we do.

**[Commentary]**
Gazing at the deep blue of heaven, we cannot know whether it is truly heaven’s color or merely its boundless distance. When the Peng looks down from above, it is as when we look up from below. Thus it halts and plans its journey south.

**[Subcommentary]**
Looking up at the vault of heaven, it seems immeasurably distant. The azure expanse stretches endlessly—is this truly heaven’s color? Yet when the Peng soars in the middle reaches, its view of the earth below is no different from our view of heaven above. Just as we cannot discern heaven’s true color, the Peng cannot know the earth’s distance. It seeks only what suffices to sustain itself and flies toward the Southern Darkness. The Peng’s calculations end here.

Moreover, when water does not accumulate to sufficient depth, it lacks the power to bear a great boat. Pour a cup of water onto a hollow in the hall, and a mustard seed may serve as a boat; but place the cup there, and it will stick fast—water is shallow, and the boat too large.

**[Commentary]**
All this illustrates why the Peng soars so high: its wings are vast. What is small in substance requires no great support, so what is great in substance cannot be sustained by what is small. Thus, principle has its ultimate measure, things have their fixed limits, and each suffices for its task—all achieve their end alike. If one loses the master of forgetting life and pursues it beyond what is fitting, if one’s affairs exceed one’s strength and one’s movements do not match one’s nature, then even riding the wings of heaven, one cannot escape exhaustion, and the flight of lesser creatures cannot avoid distress.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Moreover* is a provisional term, a phrase of passing mention. *Coupled with* marks the beginning, the start of an argument. *Accumulate* means to gather; *depth* means profound. A *cup* is a small vessel. *Hollow* refers to a sunken or depressed place in the hall’s floor. *Mustard seed* is a grass. *Stick fast* means to adhere. This begins the analogy.

If one overturns a cup of water into a hollow in the hall’s floor, a mustard leaf may float upon it without hindrance; but if one uses the cup itself as a boat, it will not move. Why? The water is shallow and the boat too large, so it clings to the earth and does not advance. Thus, a great boat requires deep water, while a tiny mustard seed needs no mighty current—if size and circumstance are fitting, all things wander freely.

When wind does not accumulate to sufficient depth, it lacks the power to bear great wings. Thus, at ninety thousand *li*, the wind lies beneath it.

**[Subcommentary]**
This completes the analogy. If water is not deep, a great boat cannot float; if wind is not lofty, great wings cannot ascend the heavens. Thus, the small bird flies for half a morning, darting among the mulberry and elm; the great Peng, at ninety thousand *li*, is borne aloft by the whirling wind beneath it. Only then does it ride the wind; only with the blue sky at its back and no obstacle to block its way does it then set its course southward.

**[Commentary]**
That it now sets its course southward is not because it delights in height or yearns for distance, but because without accumulated wind, the path is not open. This is the Peng’s wandering.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Ride* means to rely upon. *Obstacle* means to block; *path* means to obstruct. At first, it depends on the whirlwind to ascend; only with wind amassed beneath it can it take flight. Then, with the sky above and the wind’s spine below, it soars through the heavens, journeying for six months before it rests. Nets and snares cannot reach it, arrows and traps do not touch it—where could misfortune of blockage or ruin befall it? Truly, with resources and needs in harmony, it attains its rightful place, wandering to the Southern Sea—is this not fitting?

The cicada and the turtledove laugh at it, saying: “We dart up and fly, striking the mulberry and sandalwood; sometimes we do not reach our goal and fall to the earth—what need is there to travel ninety thousand *li* to the south?”

**[Commentary]**
If one is content with one’s nature, then even the great Peng has no cause to value itself above the small bird, nor does the small bird envy the heavenly pond—its joy and fulfillment are complete. Thus, though great and small differ, their wandering is one.

**[Subcommentary]**
The *cicada* is an insect that emerges in the seventh or eighth month, purple-green in color, also called *zhaoliao*. The *turtledove* is the magpie dove, the same as today’s spotted dove. *Dart* describes swift movement. *Strike* means to alight or dart. *Sandalwood* is a type of hardwood. *Fall* means to descend, to draw near, or to reach an end. *What need* asks why. *Travel* means to go.

The cicada and turtledove, hearing of the Peng’s vastness and how it relies on wind and water to fly so high, mock its great size and toil, delighting in their own smallness and ease. They leap no higher than a few yards, darting among the mulberry and sandalwood; when weary, they do not reach the next grove but rest upon the earth before rising again. Wandering as their nature suits them, they find joy in this—why endure a six-month journey, ninety thousand *li* of arduous travel, to reach the south? Those who, in their smallness, laugh at what is great, who boast and strive yet do not wander freely—such have never been.

Those who travel to the misty wilds take three meals and return with bellies still full; those who journey a hundred *li* spend the night grinding grain; those who go a thousand *li* gather provisions for three months.

**[Commentary]**
The farther one travels, the more provisions one must gather. Thus, the greater the wings, the thicker the accumulated *qi*.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Travel* means to go. *Misty wilds* describes the color of the countryside, hazy and indistinct from afar. *Full* describes a sated belly. Going to the countryside, one returns after three meals, the journey being short, the belly still full. A journey of a hundred *li* is somewhat farther, so one grinds grain to prepare for an overnight stay. Traveling a thousand *li*, the road is long, so one gathers three months’ provisions to suffice for the journey. As Guo’s commentary says: “The farther one travels, the more provisions one must gather; thus, the greater the wings, the thicker the accumulated *qi*.”

What do these two creatures know?

**[Commentary]**
The two creatures are the Peng and the cicada. The great is set against the small to show that their aims are equal. Why are their aims different? Is it because they knowingly choose difference? All simply follow what they do not know and act naturally. Acting naturally means not acting at all—this is the great meaning of wandering.

**[Subcommentary]**
Guo’s commentary says: “The two creatures are the Peng and the cicada; the great is set against the small to show that their aims are equal.” Though the great Peng rides the wind for ninety thousand *li* and the small bird darts among the mulberry and sandalwood, though their distances differ, each follows its nature. Neither knows the length of its journey; each takes what suffices and sustains itself. The heavenly mechanism unfolds of itself—none know how.

Since there is no intent toward high or low, how could there be feeling for superiority or inferiority? The attainment of wandering lies precisely here.

As for calling the Peng a "creature," the *Greater Dai Ritual* states: "In the east are three hundred sixty scaled creatures, with the winged dragon as their chief; in the south are three hundred sixty feathered creatures, with the phoenix as their chief; in the west are three hundred sixty furred creatures, with the qilin as their chief; in the north are three hundred sixty shelled creatures, with the spirit turtle as their chief; in the center are three hundred sixty naked creatures, with the sage as their chief." Speaking broadly, the Peng is thus called a creature.

Lesser knowledge does not reach greater knowledge; shorter years do not reach longer years.

**[Commentary]**
Each thing has its nature, and each nature has its limit—all are like years and knowledge. How could they be within the reach of aspiration? From this point through the passage on Liezi, examples of long and short years and knowledge are cited, each trusting in its own measure, none sufficient to overturn another. Only then is the person without dependence brought forth—who forgets others and forgets self, obscures these manifold differences, and while all attain their own Way, remains without merit or fame. Thus, one who unites small and great is one without small or great; if there were small and great, then even the great Peng and the marsh wren, the minister and the wind-rider, would alike be burdened by things. One who equalizes life and death is one without life or death; if there were life and death, then even the great *zhuang* tree and the mayfly, Pengzu and the morning mushroom, would be equally cut short. Therefore, advancing to the state without small or great is to be without limit; obscuring the distinction between non-life and non-death is to be without end. If wandering is bound to a particular realm, then even if released to roam, it will have its limit and remain dependent.

**[Subcommentary]**
Things receive qi differently and are endowed with distinct portions: some knowledge is bright, some dim; some years are short, some long. Thus, the morning mushroom, the *mingling* tree, the minister, and Rongzi are all like years and knowledge—how could they be within the reach of aspiration? Therefore, the natures of things differ and cannot be forcibly imitated.

How do we know this is so?

**[Subcommentary]**
*Xi* means "what"; *ran* means "thus." How do we know that years and knowledge do not reach one another to such an extreme degree? The question is posed hypothetically, and the answer follows.

The morning mushroom does not know the dark and the dawn; the mayfly does not know spring and autumn—these are short years.

**[Subcommentary]**
This answers the previous question. The morning mushroom grows when rain lingers, steaming upon dung and soil; it lives in damp shade and dies when exposed to sunlight. It is also called "dog fungus," born at dawn and dead by dusk, hence the name "morning mushroom." The last day of the month is called *hui* (dark); the first day is called *shuo* (dawn). If it encounters shade, it withers in days and never spans a full month, thus it does not know the dark and the dawn. The mayfly is the summer cicada, born on wheat stalks (also called "wheat joints"), living in summer and dying in autumn, thus it does not know spring and autumn. The mushroom lives from dawn to dusk; the cicada grows in summer and perishes in autumn—both have brief lifespans, hence they are called "short years."

South of Chu there is the *mingling* tree, which takes five hundred years as its spring and five hundred years as its autumn. In high antiquity there was the great *zhuang* tree, which takes eight thousand years as its spring and eight thousand years as its autumn.

**[Subcommentary]**
Both the *mingling* and the *zhuang* are names of trees, with leafing as spring and shedding as autumn. The *mingling* grows south of Chu, taking two thousand years as one year. "High antiquity" refers to the time of Fuxi. The great *zhuang* tree grew in high antiquity, taking thirty-two thousand years as one year. The *mingling* blooms after five hundred years; the *zhuang* sheds leaves after eight thousand years—both have prolonged springs and autumns, hence they are called "long years."

Yet Pengzu alone is renowned for his longevity today. For the common people to compare themselves to him is truly lamentable.

**[Commentary]**
The disparity in years and knowledge is so vast that to compare oneself to the masses is also lamentable. Yet the masses do not lament this because each nature has its limit. If one knows this limit, then even the slightest difference cannot be surpassed—what in the world is there to lament? Things never desire to be small because of greatness, nor do they envy greatness because of smallness. Since the distinction between small and great is fixed by nature and not within the reach of envy or desire, the burden of envy and desire can be severed. Sorrow arises from burden; when burden is severed, sorrow departs. When sorrow departs and nature and life are not at peace, such a thing has never existed.

**[Subcommentary]**
Pengzu’s surname was Qian, his given name Keng, and he was a great-grandson of Emperor Zhuanxu. Skilled in nurturing his nature and regulating the cauldron, he presented pheasant soup to Yao, who enfeoffed him at Pengcheng. His Way was worthy of being an ancestor, hence he was called Pengzu. He lived through the Xia and Shang dynasties into the Zhou, reaching eight hundred years of age. *Te* means "alone"—his long life made his name uniquely renowned. Yet for common people to compare themselves to Pengzu is deeply sorrowful. They do not grieve because Pengzu’s nature was endowed with long life, unlike their own kind, so they set it beyond words and dare not sigh in sorrow. Thus, life has its limits. Not only is Pengzu’s longevity beyond reach by even the slightest measure, but in this, the *zhuang* tree and the mushroom, Pengzu and the ephemeral, are all equal—each abides in its portion, and nature and life are at peace.

Tang’s question to Ji is also like this.

**[Commentary]**
Tang’s question to Ji likewise states that each thing has its limit; when left to itself, it flourishes. Thus, Zhuangzi regarded the question as correct.

**[Subcommentary]**
Tang was a descendant of Di Ku and a scion of Xie, with the surname Zi, the given name Lü, and the courtesy name Tianyi. His mother, Fudu, saw a white vapor piercing the moon and conceived Tang. His appearance was full below and open above, and he stood nine feet tall.

In Xia, he served as a feudal lord, possessing sagely virtue, and the lords submitted to him. When he encountered Jie’s lawlessness, he was imprisoned in the Summer Terrace. Later released, he joined the feudal lords in an alliance at Jingbo, convened with Jie at the ruins of Kunwu, and fought a great battle on the plains of Mingtiao, where Jie fled to Nanchao. After Tang overthrew Jie, he offered the realm to Wu Guang, who refused. Tang then ascended the throne, establishing his capital at Bo, later renamed Shang—the founding sovereign of Yin.

Ji was a worthy of Tang’s time, also called Tang’s erudite. *Liezi* refers to him as Xia Ge; "Ge" and "Ji" are phonetically similar, likely a scribal error. As Ji was a worthy, Tang treated him as a teacher. Thus, Tang questioned Ji about the supreme Dao, inquiring into the nature of things: though their natures differ, each has its inherent portion. Following their natural course and abiding in spontaneity, one lets them be. Tang’s earnest inquiry delved deeply into profound subtleties, and Zhuangzi affirmed its correctness, hence saying it was so.

Beyond the barren north lies the Dark Sea, a celestial lake. There dwells a fish, its width spanning thousands of *li*, its length unknown—its name is Kun.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Length" here means extent. The earth’s vegetation is likened to hair; the northernmost lands, frozen and desolate, bear no grass or trees, hence called "barren." The Kun fish spans thousands in width, its length unmeasured—thus its vastness is evident. Yet the Kun and Peng were already described earlier. Their reappearance here serves to confirm: the prior citation of *Qi Xie* established authority, while this reference to *Liezi* further verifies its truth, reinforcing the point with meticulous care.

There is also a bird, named Peng, its back like Mount Tai, its wings like clouds hanging from the sky. It beats the whirling winds, ascending ninety thousand *li*, piercing the clouds, bearing the blue heavens, then turning southward.

**[Subcommentary]**
The Peng’s back is vast as the sacred peaks; its spiraling winds twist like ram’s horns. Soaring to the azure vault, it cleaves the clouds, its mighty wings driving it toward the southern sea. Thus, in *Yu Tang’s Questions*, Liezi remarks: "Who in the world knows of such a creature?" Yu the Great saw it, Bo Yi named it, and Yi Jian recorded it.

Yet it merely heads south to the Dark Sea. The quail laughs at it, saying: "Where does it think it’s going? I leap and flutter, rising no more than a few yards before descending, wheeling among the mugwort and wormwood—this is the utmost of flight! Where does *it* think it’s going?" This is the distinction between small and great.

**[Commentary]**
Each attains perfection by fulfilling its nature, and the utmost by exhausting its own capacity. Earlier, it was said that the two creatures differ in wings, hence their destinations diverge—one soars over the celestial pond, the other fulfills its aspirations among the elm and sandalwood. Each is content with its form and sufficient unto itself, unaware of why it is so. Now, the distinction between small and great is spoken of again: each possesses its natural endowment, neither attainable through striving nor envied for its difference. Thus, all rest in their inherent nature, untroubled by disparity, and so the passage is reiterated.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Qie* means "then," or serves as a grammatical particle. *Chi* is a small marsh. *Zhe* is the sparrow. Eight *chi* make one *ren*. *Aoxiang* means "to frolic." The crane and sparrow, small birds, roam freely in the marsh, leaping and bounding within the mugwort and wormwood, deriding the journey of ninety thousand *li* and delighting in their flight of a few *ren*. This illustrates the distinction between the natures of small and great, and the principle that each is sufficient in its own way. Thus, those who "use their knowledge to serve in one office, compare their conduct to one village, align their virtue with one ruler, or win the trust of one state"—their self-regard is no different.

**[Commentary]**
This is like the bird content within its own domain.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Gu* connects to the preceding passage, while *fu* introduces what follows. A *guo* is one of the five ranks of states; a *xiang* comprises twelve thousand five hundred households. Some possess the wisdom and skill to govern an office; some have renowned reputations, esteemed throughout their village; some embody vast virtue, fit to face south as a ruler, pacifying a state and securing its people. These three differ in their allotted roles and vary in excellence, yet in their sufficiency, they are not unequal. Their self-assessment is like the bird content within its own domain. Yet Song Rongzi still laughs at them.

**[Commentary]**
Unable to equalize, he thus laughs.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Zi* is an honorific for one of virtue; his surname is Rong, and he is from Song. *Youran* means "thus." Though Rongzi can forget being, he cannot yet relinquish non-being, hence his laughter. Those bound to office and rank, and even those of empty indifference, harbor such derision, for they perceive the lack of equality. Earlier, the small mocked the great to show that the great do not boast; now, the great mocks the small, so the small do not aspire. Those who do not rest in their nature and destiny have not yet heard this principle. "When the whole world praises him, he is not spurred; when the whole world condemns him, he is not disheartened."

**[Commentary]**
He examines and attains self-sufficiency.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Ju* means "all." *Quan* means "to encourage." *Ju* means "to grieve or despair." Rongzi follows his nature and embraces the Dao, transcending the common with clarity. Were the world to praise him, he would not be stirred to greater effort; were all the land to slander him, he would not be cast into despair—he examines and attains self-sufficiency. "He is certain of the division between inner and outer."

**[Commentary]**
Inner is the self; outer is things.

**[Subcommentary]**
Rongzi knows that what is within is not the self, and what is without is not things. He relinquishes both inner and outer, forgetting both self and things, thus he is certain of the division between inner and outer without confusion. "He distinguishes the realm of honor and disgrace."

**[Commentary]**
Honor is for oneself; disgrace is for others.

**[Subcommentary]**
He forgets encouragement and discouragement in praise and blame, merging success and failure in honor and disgrace. Thus, he reflects inwardly with clarity of mind, discerning the subtleties of the external realm with profound insight. No longer does he regard inner as self and outer as things, nor honor himself and disgrace others. "This is the limit."

**[Commentary]**
He cannot surpass this.

**[Subcommentary]**
"斯" means "this"; "已" means "to cease." Does Song Rong’s wisdom and virtue cease at this point? Yet in his engagement with the world, he is not restless.

**[Commentary]**
Content with himself, he is thus indifferent to the world.

**[Subcommentary]**
"数数" means "eagerly striving." Song Rong, following his nature, remains empty and tranquil, advancing straightforwardly with the principle, never employing his intellect to seek or his mind to pursue the Dao. Dwelling beyond the self and things, he is not restless. Nevertheless, there is still something he has not established.

**[Commentary]**
He can only affirm himself; he has not yet reached the state of "nothing is not permissible."

**[Subcommentary]**
"树" means "to establish." Rongzi grasps the manifest to verify the hidden, yet remains mired in partiality and stagnation. Thus, in the mind of non-dependence, he has not established the realm of carefree wandering, and his wisdom is still deficient.

Now, Liezi rides the wind and travels, soaring lightly and skillfully.

**[Commentary]**
"泠然" describes a light and wondrous manner.

**[Subcommentary]**
His surname is Lie, given name Yukou, a native of Zheng. A contemporary of Duke Zhuang of Zheng, he studied under Master Huqiu Zilin and authored eight scrolls. Having attained the Dao of wind immortality, he rides the wind in travel, ascending lightly—hence his skill is praised. After fifteen days, he returns.

**[Commentary]**
If one still depends on something, then even riding the wind, one cannot circumnavigate in a single moment.

**[Subcommentary]**
"旬" means ten days. Having attained the wind immortal’s Dao, he roams the world, returning home every fifteen days. Yet he cannot ride all things without exception, so he cannot act in a single moment.

In his attainment of fortune, he is not restless.

**[Commentary]**
He naturally rides the wind; he does not eagerly seek it.

**[Subcommentary]**
"致" means "to attain." Lie Yukou’s attainment of the fortune of wind immortality arises from his indifference to heat and cold, his empty mind following its course—it is not a matter of striving with intent or eagerly pursuing. This clarifies the essentials of the Dao: the essence lies in forgetting the mind. If one employs and exhausts intellect and thought, one strays far from it. Though he avoids walking, he still depends on something.

**[Commentary]**
Without wind, he cannot travel—this is necessarily dependence. Only one who rides all things without exception is without dependence.

**[Subcommentary]**
Riding the wind and ascending lightly, though he avoids walking, he cannot advance without wind—he still requires something to depend on. From officials downward through Song Rong and Lie Yukou, though their wisdom and virtue differ in excellence, none have thoroughly forgotten, and all remain in dependence. Only by following the nature of the myriad things, wandering the paths of transformation, and achieving all without exception can one fully realize the wondrous attainment of carefree wandering.

If one rides the inherent principle of Heaven and Earth and harnesses the transformations of the six qi to wander boundlessly—what does such a one depend on?

**[Commentary]**
"Heaven and Earth" is the collective name for the myriad things. Heaven and Earth take the myriad things as their body, and the myriad things in turn take spontaneity as their inherent principle. Spontaneity is that which is not contrived yet arises naturally. Thus, the great Peng’s ability to soar high, the sparrow’s ability to fly low, the great tree’s ability to grow tall, and the morning mushroom’s ability to be short—all these are what spontaneity enables, not what contrivance enables. Not contrived yet naturally able—this is the inherent principle. Thus, to ride the inherent principle of Heaven and Earth is to follow the nature of the myriad things; to harness the transformations of the six qi is to wander the paths of change. Proceeding thus, where could there be any limit? Whatever one encounters, one rides—what, then, would one depend on?

This is the freedom of those of utmost virtue who mystically unite self and other. If there is dependence, then even the lightness and wonder of Liezi would still be unable to travel without wind—only when he obtains what he depends on can he be free, let alone the great Peng. Only those who merge with things and follow great transformation can be without dependence and ever-pervading—how could this be merely self-pervading? Moreover, by following those who depend, one ensures they do not lose what they depend on; when what they depend on is not lost, they become one with the great pervasion. Thus, I cannot equate the dependent and the non-dependent; but as for each resting in its nature, the heavenly mechanism unfolding of itself, receiving without awareness—these I cannot distinguish. For even the non-dependent are not sufficient to distinguish themselves from the dependent, let alone the great and small among the dependent.

[Commentary] "Heaven and Earth" is the collective name for the myriad things. "The myriad things" is another name for spontaneity. As for the six qi, Ji Yi said: dawn’s morning glow, midday’s pure yang, sunset’s flying springs, midnight’s vast dampness—these are the six qi of Heaven and Earth. Du Yu said: the six qi are yin, yang, wind, rain, darkness, and brightness. Zhi Daolin said: the six qi are Heaven, Earth, and the four seasons; *bian* means transformation. *Wu hu*, what does one depend on?

The non-dependent sage, emptying the heart-mind and embodying the Dao, thus can ride the inherent principle of the Two Modes, follow the spontaneity of the myriad things, harness the six qi to wander freely, and blend with all spirits in transformation. If one is without things yet does not follow, where could one not pervade? Clearly seeing through to the limitless, what would one depend on?

Thus it is said: the perfected person is without self—
[Annotation] Without self, thus following things; following things, one reaches the utmost.

the spirit person is without achievement—
[Annotation] Things have never declined from arising naturally, yet they rejoice in relying on acupuncture and stone needles—thus when principle reaches its limit, they perish. Now, following without aiding, one becomes one with the utmost principle—thus without achievement.

the sage is without fame.
[Annotation] The sage is merely the name for things attaining their nature; it is insufficient to name how they attain it.

[Commentary] "Perfected" speaks of their essence, "spirit" of their function, "sage" of their name. Thus, in speaking of essence, one says "perfected"; of function, "spirit"; of name, "sage"—in reality, they are one. Reaching the ultimate of numinous power, they are called "perfected"; being unfathomable as yin and yang, they are called "spirit"; rightly naming the hundred things, they are called "sage." Above one person, these three exist—desiring to display their differing functions and names, they are distinguished as three persons. These three persons are those who earlier rode the inherent principle of Heaven and Earth and harnessed the transformations of the six qi. Desiring to conclude this person’s non-dependent virtue and manifest their essence and function, one speaks in reverse, thus saying:

Yao offered the world to Xu You, saying: "When the sun and moon have risen, yet the torch still does not cease—is it not difficult for it to shine? When the season has descended, yet one still irrigates—is it not laborious for it to moisten?"

[Commentary] Yao was the son of Emperor Ku, surnamed Yi Qi, style Fangxun. His mother, Qingdu, conceived him after sensing a red dragon. He was ten feet tall, broad above and full below, with eight-colored eyebrows and feet treading the stars of the Dipper. He possessed sagely virtue. At fifteen, he served the Lord of Tang; at twenty-one, he succeeded his brother to the imperial throne, establishing his capital at Pingyang, and was called Lord of Taotang. After seventy-two years on the throne, he abdicated to Shun. He died at 128 and was buried in Yangcheng, posthumously named Yao. According to the rules of posthumous naming, "Yao" means "winged goodness transmitting sagacity," referring to his merit in transmitting the throne to Shun.

Xu You was a recluse, surnamed Xu, named You, style Zhongwu, from Yangcheng in Yingchuan. He lived in seclusion on Mount Ji, studied under Nie Que, ate from the mountains, and drank from the river. Yao, knowing his worth, offered him the imperial throne. Xu You, hearing this, went to the river to wash his ears. When Chaofu came to water his calf, he led it away, saying: "It would pollute my water." After his death, Yao had his tomb sealed and posthumously named him Lord of Ji—he was Yao’s teacher.

"When the sun and moon have risen, yet the torch still does not cease—is it not difficult for it to shine? When the season has descended, yet one still irrigates—is it not laborious for it to moisten?"

[Commentary] "Jiao fire" refers to torch fire, a small flame. In the time of Shennong, rain fell once every fifteen days, called "timely rain." Moreover, with the sun and moon illuminating all, why rely on the light of torches? With timely rain soaking the earth, why labor over irrigation? Yao, in his humility and deference, yielded to others and withdrew himself—these words serve to extol Zhongwu. "If the Master were to stand as ruler, the world would be well-ordered, yet I still occupy his place. I see myself as lacking. I beg to yield the world to him."

[Commentary] "Well-ordered" means properly governed. "Occupy" means to preside. "Yield" means to offer. As Yao took Xu You as his teacher, he addressed him as "Master." If Zhongwu were to ascend the throne, the realm would surely attain great peace, yet I still hold sway as its lord. Seeing myself as insufficient, I ask to relinquish the imperial position to a worthy man.

Xu You said: "You govern the world, and the world is already well-ordered."

[Annotation] He who can bring order to the world does not govern it. Thus, Yao ordered it by not governing, not by governing to order it. Now that Xu You clearly sees it is already well-ordered, there is nothing for him to replace. Yet the order truly comes from Yao, hence the words "you govern it." One should forget the words and seek the meaning they convey. Some, however, claim: "He who governs to order it is Yao; he who does not govern yet enables Yao to order it is Xu You." This is far from the truth. Order arises from non-governance, action emerges from non-action. Yao’s sufficiency requires no borrowing from Xu You. To suggest that only by withdrawing into mountain forests can one be called "non-acting" is the very reason why the teachings of Zhuangzi and Laozi are rejected by those in power. Those who remain bound to the realm of action without returning—this is the source of such errors.

[Commentary] "Well-ordered" means governed. "Already" means fully. Yao governed the world for so long that it reached peace, with all under heaven tranquil. Why trouble me with such excessive words? Yet in Zhuangzi’s text, Yao is belittled while Xu You is exalted, while Guo Xiang’s commentary disparages Xu You and praises Yao—why? To show that the sagely Yao and the worthy Zhongwu, though both great, follow different paths, separated by a vast distance. Thus, Yao, bearing the weight of the world, lost it, while Xu You, untouched by custom, stood alone on a high mountain. Their differing fates are clear. Zhuangzi, invoking the theme of abdication, spoke of torch fires; Guo Xiang, discerning the heart of non-reliance, expounded on non-governance. This may be called delving into subtleties and uncovering hidden truths, aligning text with meaning. One should seek its intent, not quibble over details.

"Yet I would still replace you—would I do so for the sake of a name? A name is but the guest of reality. Would I seek to be a guest?"

[Annotation] He who takes responsibility for himself, in harmony with things, is without opposition to them. Thus, Yao was without opposition to the world, and Xu You stood as an equal to Qi and Xie. How can this be said? He who merges with things cannot be separated from them. Therefore, with a mind free and responses mysterious, he follows only what moves him, drifting like an untethered boat, unconcerned with east or west. Thus, he acts without sharing with the people, and rules without becoming the world’s lord. To rule in this way is like heaven’s natural height—this is the true virtue of a ruler. If one stands alone atop a high mountain, not out of human sentiment for self-preservation but to uphold a partial view, how can this be exclusive? He is but one among the common folk, an outer minister to Yao. To treat an outer minister as an inner lord is to bear the name of ruler without its reality.

[Commentary] Xu You, aloof on Mount Ji, wandering by the Ying River, spurned fame and profit, despising the filth of reputation. Yet Yao, earnest in his entreaties, still hoped Xu You would replace him. If Xu You ascended the throne, he would gain the name of emperor. Yet reality gives rise to name, and name follows reality. Reality is inner and primary; name is outer and secondary. To abandon the primary for the secondary, to lose the inner in pursuit of the outer—this is not the aspiration of a recluse, hence his words: "Would I seek to be a guest?"

The wren nests in the deep forest, yet needs no more than a single branch; the mole drinks from the river, yet takes no more than its fill.

[Annotation] Each nature has its limit. If that limit is satisfied, the rest of the world’s wealth is superfluous.

[Commentary] The *jiaoliao* is the wren, a clever bird, also called the "female artisan" or "peach insect," skilled at nesting in dense thickets. The *yan shu* is a creature the size of an ox, black in color, with cloven hooves, three claws on each foot, ears like an elephant’s, and a white-tipped tail, fond of drinking from rivers. The bird nests beyond a single branch without needing a vast forest; the beast drinks beyond its fill without requiring a boundless expanse.

Moreover, Xu You found contentment in humble thatch and lotus roots, spurning the golden gates; he delighted in coarse fare, scorning the finest delicacies. "Return and rest, my lord—I have no use for the realm."

[Annotation] All things are equally without use, yet Yao alone possessed it. This shows that those who embrace openness know no bounds, and so the world delights in exalting them without weariness.

[Commentary] *Yu* means "I." Xu You, with his few desires and pure tranquility, declined Yao’s abdication, saying to Yao: "You should swiftly return to the imperial carriage, go back to the Purple Palace, and let the words of abdication be at rest. The honor of the Four Seas is of no use to me; what would I do with the nobility of the Nine-Five?" Though the kitchen servant may not tend the kitchen, the invocator and officiant do not overstep their bounds to take his place at the wine vessel and meat platter.

[Annotation] The kitchen servant, the invocator, and the officiant each abide in their proper office. Birds, beasts, and the myriad things each find sufficiency in what they receive. Emperor Yao and Xu You each remain at peace with their lot—this is the ultimate truth of the world. When each attains their truth, what more is there to do? They find contentment in themselves. Thus, though the conduct of Yao and Xu differed, in their freedom they were one.

[Commentary] The *paoren* is the one who oversees the kitchen, equivalent to today’s imperial caterer. The *shi* is the spirit tablet in the ancestral temple; the *zhu* is today’s Grand Invocator of the Court of Sacrifices. Holding the ritual tablets, they invoke before the *shi*, hence the term *shizhu*. The *zun* is a wine vessel; the *zu* is a meat platter. The kitchen servant, invocator, and officiant each have their appointed roles. Even if the chef were negligent and refused to prepare the meal, the invocator and officiant would never overstep their bounds, abandon their vessels, and take up the knife to cook. Just so, when Emperor Yao abdicated and did not govern the realm, Xu You did not leave his mountain forest to ascend the throne. Thus the annotation says: "Emperor Yao and Xu You each remained at peace with what they had."

Jian Wu asked Lian Shu: "I heard words from Jie Yu—"

[Commentary] Jian Wu and Lian Shu were both men of the Dao in ancient times. Jie Yu was surnamed Lu, named Tong, styled Jie Yu, a worthy recluse of Chu who lived at the same time as Confucius. Feigning madness and refusing office, he devoted himself to farming. When the King of Chu, knowing his worth, offered him a hundred *yi* of gold and two teams of four horses, he declined. Then, shouldering his belongings with his wife following behind, he wandered among mountains and seas, and none knew where he ended his days. Jian Wu, finding Jie Yu’s words unbounded and without measure, asked Lian Shu to clarify their meaning. "I heard words from Jie Yu" means he heard Jie Yu’s speech. Zhuangzi cited these three worthies to illustrate Yao’s singular sagacity; the content of what he heard is set forth below.

"—vast and without limit, sweeping onward without return. I was alarmed by his words, as though the Milky Way stretched endlessly without bound."

[Commentary] What he heard from Jie Yu was grand yet without proper measure, advancing in a single direction with no trace of return. I secretly heard it with shock and dread, like gazing at the celestial river, lofty and distant, its source and flow utterly unfathomable.

"They were wildly divergent, far from human sentiment."

[Commentary] *Jingting* means "excessive," also describing a direct advance without regard. Jie Yu’s words did not align with the common, often exceeding bounds and defying worldly norms—hence his grand speech did not accord with reason.

Lian Shu said: "What did his words say?"

"On the distant Mount Gushe, there dwells a spirit-like person—skin like ice and snow, supple and graceful as a maiden."

[Annotation] These are but figurative words. The "spirit-like person" is what we now call the sage. Though the sage may sit in the halls of state, his heart remains no different than if he dwelt in the mountains and forests. How could the world recognize this? They see only his imperial yellow canopy and jade-encrusted girdle, and think these suffice to bind his heart; they see him traverse mountains and rivers, sharing in the people’s labors, and think these suffice to weary his spirit. How could they know that the most perfect remains unharmed? Now, by speaking of one of royal virtue and placing him on this mountain, we illuminate how the world fails to recognize him—thus we set him beyond the farthest borders and relegate him beyond sight and sound. As for the maiden? She is not inwardly wounded by outward things.

[Commentary] *Miao* means "distant." The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* states: Mount Gushe lies beyond the encircling sea, where a spirit-like sage dwells, gathering responses to the world. When the moment calls for bows and courtesy, he becomes a Yao or Shun; when the moment calls for shield and spear, he becomes a Tang or Wu.

Graceful and yielding—this is softness. The *chü-tzu* is an unmarried maiden. To speak of the sage is to show how movement and stillness respond as one, how emptiness and being illuminate together. Though he dwells in the halls of state, he is no different from one in the mountains and forests. He harmonizes his light with the dust, abiding in defilement yet undefiled. Ice and snow are chosen for their purity and cold; gracefulness is likened to gentleness and harmony; the *chü-tzu* is not harmed by things; Mount Gushe speaks of its remoteness. This clarifies the fullness of Yao’s virtue—profound, dark, and wondrous—thus placing him beyond the farthest borders, relegating him beyond sight and sound. Yet this is but a parable; how could there truly be a Mount Gushe? One ought to forget words and seek what they point to. This is the very passage where Jian Wu, deluded by his former understanding, responds to Lian Shu.

He eats no grain, drinking the wind and sipping the dew.
*[Annotation]* Though all consume the five grains, only the spirit-person is not made by them, for the spirit-person is uniquely endowed with the wondrous qi of nature.
*[Commentary]* The five grains are millet, sorghum, hemp, beans, and wheat. The spirit-like sage, descending to respond to things, is born with pure and essential numinosity, endowed with the finest qi of yin and yang. Though he relies on things for sustenance, he is not made by the five grains; though he cleaves to wind and dew for clarity and emptiness, he is not altered by the four seasons.

He rides the clouds and qi, drives flying dragons, and roams beyond the four seas.
*[Commentary]* His wisdom illuminates with numinous penetration, his original heart follows things—thus he rides the clouds and qi. Swift without haste, ever-changing yet constant—thus he drives flying dragons. Borne upon the ten thousand things yet transcending the six directions—thus he advances beyond the four seas.

His spirit congeals, so that things are free from blight and pestilence, and the year’s harvest ripens. Yet I deem this mad and do not believe it.
*[Annotation]* One who embodies spirit, abides in numinosity, and exhausts the subtleties of principle—though silent and still within the quiet chamber—is mystically one with the farthest reaches of the four seas. Thus he rides the Two Modes and drives the Six Qi, harmonizing with the multitude of beings and taming the ten thousand things. If he were not in accord with things, he would ride the floating clouds; if he were not borne by form, he would drive flying dragons. Forgetting the self and attaining the self, though seemingly indifferent and without reliance, sitting in forgetfulness and walking in forgetfulness, acting in forgetfulness—thus his movements are like dragging a withered tree, his stillness like a heap of dead ashes. Hence it is said his spirit congeals. When his spirit congeals, what does not congeal attains the self. Yet the world judges by what it sees—how could it ever believe this?
*[Commentary]* *Congeals* means still. *Blight and pestilence* mean illness and disease. *The year’s harvest ripens* means a good year. The sage’s form is like a withered tree, his heart like dead ashes, his essence pervading the moment, movement and stillness both wondrous. His congealed illumination flows unimpeded, his empty mind benefits things. Thus the four seasons follow their order, the five grains flourish, people are free from calamity, and things are free from untimely death. Such is the sage’s power in the world. Yet Jian Wu, failing to grasp these profound words, deems them mad and does not believe.

Lian Shu said: Indeed. The blind have no part in the sight of patterns, the deaf no part in the sound of bells and drums. Is it only the body that has deafness and blindness? Knowledge, too, has them.
*[Annotation]* Not knowing the ultimate subtlety of profound words and deeming them mad and unbelievable—this is the deafness and blindness of knowledge.
*[Commentary]* The blind have eyes like drumskin, dark and sealed. The deaf suffer from an affliction of the ears. The blind have ruined eye-faculties. Sight and hearing are the common conditions of beings with form. Yet the blind and deaf cannot be shown sights and sounds. Likewise, the profound words of the wondrous Dao are known only by those of suspended understanding. The deluded and confused, however, remain unenlightened their whole lives, for their wisdom is obstructed and blind. Is this affliction unique to the body? From here onward is Lian Shu’s reply to Jian Wu.

These words are like a maiden in her chamber.
*[Annotation]* These words of Jie Yu are naturally sought by things, yet those whose knowledge is deaf and blind deem them impossible.
*[Commentary]* *These* is a pointing word. *A maiden in her chamber* is a young, unmarried woman. These words of Jie Yu are like a graceful and pure maiden, sought by the noble man, yet those whose knowledge is deaf and blind say such a thing is impossible.

This person, this power—who would exhaust themselves with the world’s affairs, laboring over governance?
*[Annotation]* The sage’s heart encompasses the ultimate convergence of the Two Modes and exhausts the wondrous numbers of the ten thousand things. Thus he embodies transformation and harmonizes change, with nothing beyond his reach, uniting the ten thousand things without their being otherwise. The world, in its chaos, seeks him, yet he has no mind. If he had no mind, how could he not respond to the world? Yet one who embodies the profound and exhausts the wondrous—though he harmonizes the natures of the ten thousand things and shapes the transformations of the world to achieve the renown of Yao and Shun—always does so by not-doing. Who would exhaust themselves with laborious thoughts and toilsome governance, making affairs their affair, and only then succeed?
*[Commentary]* *This* is an exclamatory particle. *Uniting* means blending as one. *Seeks* means to request. *Who* means no one. *This person* praises Yao as a sage; *this power* extols Yao’s great virtue. The sage’s power accords with the Two Modes, his Dao levels the myriad kinds, blending the ten thousand things and mastering the hundred spirits. When the world is decadent and the people in chaos, they seek the great sage to govern and pacify. Yet like an empty boat or a suspended mirror, he responds without intent. Who would weary their form and exhaust their wisdom, managing the realm, making affairs their affair, and only then succeed?

Thus *Laozi* states: "Act without acting, manage without managing," and further declares: "To take the world, one must always act without acting; when one acts with acting, it is insufficient to take the world."

This person—nothing harms them.
*[Annotation]* One who rests in what harms them cannot be harmed; when harm cannot harm, then things do not harm them.

Great floods reach the heavens yet do not drown them; great droughts melt metal and stone, scorch mountains and earth, yet do not burn them.
*[Annotation]* Without going and without resting, wherever they are is fitting. Death and life hold no change for them—how much less drowning or burning?

Thus the perfected person does not cling to calamity and disaster, not by avoiding them, but by advancing straight through principle, naturally meeting with good fortune.
*[Commentary]* *Stabilized* means to reach. One who penetrates life and death knows no death and no life; one who is fitting with water and fire is neither drowned nor burned. Even if the Yang-nine disaster melts metal or the Hundred-six calamity floods the heavens, chaos arises from others—what does it matter to them? Thus *Guo’s Annotation* says: "Death and life hold no change for them—how much less drowning or burning?"

Their dust and grime, their husks and chaff, are what would mold and cast into Yao and Shun. Who would take things as their affair?
*[Annotation]* Yao and Shun are but names of worldly affairs; one who acts for a name is not the name. Thus Yao and Shun—are they merely Yao and Shun? No! Their hexagrams hold the reality of spirit-like persons. What we call Yao and Shun are but the dust and grime, the husks and chaff of their names.
*[Commentary]* *Scattered* becomes dust, *greasy* becomes grime; *unripe grain* is husk, *grain husk* is chaff—all coarse things. *Melting metal* is casting, *molding clay* is pottery. *Yi’s model*: "Wings of goodness transmit sageliness" is Yao; "transforming sageliness into radiant brightness" is Shun. Yao’s root reaches the ultimate, wondrously transcending form and name, blending and advancing with the dust—things savor his power, so he establishes the name *Yi* to manifest his sagely body. Yet names are crude models, no different from husks; *Yi* is a worldly affair, what separates it from dust? Thus, flatterers and deceivers falsely forge that dust and grime into Yao, use these husks and chaff to craft Shun. How could they know the wondrous body cannot be spoken? This is why no one would take things as their affair.

The people of Song carried ceremonial caps to Yue, but the Yue people, with shorn hair and tattooed bodies, had no use for them.
*[Commentary]* This begins the analogy. *Carried* means to trade. Yue, bordering rivers and lakes, shaves its hair and tattoos its body to avoid the harm of dragons. *Zhangfu* is the name of a cap. Thus Confucius, born in Lu, wore robes with wide sleeves; raised in Song, he wore the *zhangfu* cap. Song was the descendant of Weizi; Yue was the lineage of Taibo. The two states traded and interacted, making *zhangfu* a commodity. Yet *zhangfu* is meant to adorn the head, requiring hair to hold the cap—Yue people, with shorn hair and tattooed bodies, rendered the commodity useless. Just as glory and splendor are inherently clinging, wealth and nobility arise from arrogance and pride. Yao, embodying the Dao and penetrating forgetfulness, could thus have no use for the world. Thus *Guo’s Annotation* says: "Yao’s having no use for governing the world is like the Yue people having no use for *zhangfu*."

Yao governed the people of the world and harmonized the governance of the seas within, yet when he went to see the Four Masters on the distant Guye Mountain, north of the Fen River, he suddenly lost his world.
*[Annotation]* Yao’s having no use for governing the world is like the Yue people having no use for *zhangfu*. Yet one who abandons the world is truly revered by the world. Though the world reveres Yao, Yao never possessed the world. Thus he lost it in a daze, having long roamed his mind in the boundless dark, though seated atop the ten thousand things, he had never ceased to be free and unfettered. The Four Masters are but figurative speech, clarifying that Yao is not confined to being Yao. Yao is truly dark and obscure—his emergence is Yao. Viewing obscurity from emergence, inner and outer are different realms—this is no wonder. The world only sees Yao as Yao, how could they recognize his obscurity? Thus, seeking the Four Masters beyond the seas while fixing Yao to what is seen, and then claiming those who flow with things lose their freedom, misses the truth. For one who follows the farthest reaches knows that compliance is nearer, and the highest convergence is lower. If one rigidly exalts uniqueness as supreme and does not level with worldly entanglements, they are but a mountain-valley scholar, not one who transcends dependency—how could they speak of the ultimate or wander the boundless?
*[Commentary]* *Governed* means to order and manage; *governance* refers to moral instruction.

This is a combined metaphor. The Fen River originates in Taiyuan and flows westward into the Yellow River. North of the water is called *yang*—today’s Pingyang County in Jinzhou lies north of the Fen River, where Yao once established his capital. *Baoran* signifies stillness and solitude, a term for profound remoteness. *Sang* means forgetting, denoting the act of relinquishment and dissolution. As for the Four Masters, they represent the Four Virtues: first, the root; second, compliance; third, neither root nor emergence; fourth, neither non-root nor emergence. It speaks of Yao turning inward to illuminate the source of the mind, penetratingly beholding the realm of the Dao, transcending these four distinctions—hence it is said he went to meet the Four Masters.

The sage has no fixed mind; responding only when moved, he thus orders and harmonizes the myriad states, bringing peace to the nine lands. Though he concentrates his spirit upon the Four Masters, sitting in solemn repose north of the Fen, governing the ten thousand affairs, he remains *baoran*, having forgotten the world. This is the convergence of root and emergence, of substance and function, the dual illumination of emptiness and being, the simultaneity of movement and stillness. Thus, the Maiden Peak of Guye is no different from the northern bank of the Fen, and how could mountain forests be distinct from the imperial palace? Yet the world equalizes only what it sees—when has it ever trusted this truth?

Yet Ma Biao’s reduction of the Four Masters to Nie Que fails to grasp the profound principle, while Liu Zhang’s transposition of the Fen River to Mount She only compounds confusion in immediate matters. The present explication diverges somewhat from these views.

Thus, Guo Xiang’s commentary states: “The Four Masters are but figurative expressions, revealing that Yao was not confined to ‘Yao’—the world sees only Yao’s emergence, how could it recognize his true reality?”

Master Hui said to Master Zhuang: “The King of Wei bestowed upon me seeds of a great gourd. (Annotation: His surname was Hui, given name Shi, a native of Song. He served as Prime Minister of Liang. *Wei* here refers to King Hui of Liang, who originally ruled from Anyi under the state name Wei. Later, pressed by the might of Qin, he relocated to Daliang and renamed his state Liang, usurping the title of king.) Master Hui raised this metaphor of the great gourd to satirize Master Zhuang’s writings—though their purport is vast, they fail to address practical affairs, hence this exchange to provoke further discourse.

“I planted them, and when they bore fruit, it held five *dan*. When I used it to contain water or broth, its fragility prevented it from supporting its own weight. (Annotation: *Shu* means to cultivate. *Shi* refers to the fruit. Having obtained the gourd seeds, Master Hui planted them until they matured, yielding fruit so large it could hold five *dan*. Yet when used to contain liquids, its hollow brittleness rendered it unable to bear its own weight.) When I split it to make ladles, its shallowness left nothing to hold. Though it was resplendently vast, I deemed it useless and smashed it. (Annotation: *Pou* means to split. *Piao* is a ladle. *Huluo* describes its flatness. *Yangran* denotes its vast emptiness. *Pou* means to shatter. Used to hold water, its brittleness made it unsustainable; split into ladles, its shallowness could contain little. Deemed utterly useless, it was broken and discarded.) This mocks Master Zhuang’s words for failing to address the exigencies of the age—like this gourd, they ought to be cast aside.”

Master Zhuang replied: “You are indeed inept at putting great things to use. There was a man of Song skilled in making an ointment that prevented chapping of the hands. For generations, his family made their living by washing silk floss in water. (Annotation: This ointment kept hands from cracking, allowing them to constantly soak floss in water. *Hong* means to float; *you*, to drift. *Huang* refers to silk floss. *Shishi* means for years. In the depths of winter, the man of Song waded into water to wash floss, his fingers cracking like tortoise shells. Thus, his family passed down this ointment through generations, ensuring their hands remained unchapped and their livelihood of washing floss in water endured without decline. Alternate reading: *pi* means to prepare; *tong*, to continue.)”

The client, having heard of this, offered to buy the formula for a hundred *jin* of gold. (Annotation: A *jin* of gold refers to a gold ingot measuring one *cun* in size and weighing one *jin*.) A visitor from another state happened to learn of it and sought to purchase the remedy for chapped hands, offering a hundred *jin* of gold. The family gathered to deliberate, saying: “For generations, we have washed silk floss and earned no more than a few *jin* of gold. Now, in a single morning, we can sell this skill for a hundred *jin*—let us give it to him.” (Annotation: *Chang* means to sell. The price being so high, the family conferred. For generations, they had floated and washed floss, reaping meager profit, but selling the remedy in one stroke would bring vast wealth. With one voice, they agreed to the sale.)

The client obtained it and presented it to the King of Wu. When Yue posed a threat, the King of Wu appointed him as a general. In winter, he engaged the Yue forces in a naval battle, decisively defeating them, and was enfeoffed with land in reward. (Annotation: Wu and Yue were northern neighbors, their lands bordering rivers and seas, their weapons clashing like hills. In winter, the soldiers’ hands often cracked. The client, endowed with heroic talent and natural intelligence, having acquired the formula, persuaded the King of Wu. When Yue’s troops invaded Wu, the king made him a general. Relying on this renowned remedy, his soldiers’ hands did not chap. The moment banners were raised, the Yue forces fell into disarray. Achieving such a great victory, he returned in triumph, his merit and service duly recognized, and was granted a fief of thatched earth.)

The same remedy prevented chapped hands, yet one man used it to gain a fief, while another remained content with washing silk floss—such is the difference in how it was employed. (Annotation: *Huo* means indeterminate. The formula was equally effective, but its users differed in skill, so the traveler gained a marquisate while the Song man used it for washing floss. This illustrates the disparity in their application.)

“Now, you have a gourd of five *shi* capacity—why not hollow it out to make a great flotation vessel and drift upon the rivers and lakes? Instead, you fret that it is too large to hold anything. Truly, your mind is as tangled as the *peng* grass.” (Annotation: *Peng* refers to one who lacks direct understanding. This chapter shows that all things have their proper use; if one finds the right application, how can one not attain freedom?)

(Annotation: *Ju* means to bind with ropes. A *zun* is a vessel lacquered like a wine cup, secured with cords, used to cross rivers and lakes—what the southerners call a “waist boat.” *Peng* is the name of a grass that curls and does not grow straight. *Fu* is an exclamatory particle. A great gourd, floating upon rivers and lakes, can serve as a boat to prevent drowning; the profound teachings, when put into practice, can ferry the lost across the world. Yet Master Hui, his mind as tangled as *peng* grass, fails to grasp the subtle principle and instead raises frivolous objections, mocking Zhuangzi’s writings. To misuse things so is deeply regrettable.)

Master Hui said to Master Zhuang: “I have a great tree—people call it the *bo*. (Annotation: The *bo* is a type of lacquer tree, foul-smelling when bruised, a worthless wood. Names in the world are often empty and false; though people call it *bo*, its true nature remains uncertain.) Its trunk is swollen and gnarled, unfit for the carpenter’s line, and its branches are twisted, failing to meet the compass or square. Planted by the roadside, no carpenter would even glance at it. (Annotation: *Yongzhong* means knotted and misshapen; *juanqu*, crooked and unstraight. The compass draws circles, the square measures right angles. The *bo* tree, being useless, has a trunk so gnarled that no line can be applied, and branches so twisted that no compass or square can correct them. Planted by the road, carpenters would not deign to look at it.) Now, your words are grand but of no use—just as the crowd shuns them. (Annotation: Just as the tree is gnarled and useless, ignored by carpenters, so too are your words vast but impractical, rejected by all. This is the analogy.)”

Zhuangzi said: Have you alone not seen the wildcat? It crouches low, lying in wait for the roaming prey; leaping east and west, heedless of high or low; it is caught in the trap’s snare and dies in the hunter’s net.

Now, have you not seen the weasel capturing mice? It lowers its body, lying in ambush for the careless rodent, bounding this way and that, undeterred by uneven ground; yet it is ensnared by the trap’s mechanism and perishes in the net—all for being deluded by petty gain, never considering the greater consequence. This is no different from those who bow and scrape, clutching at the skirts of the sage, feigning nature and distorting truth to seize fleeting advantage. Though they may prosper for a time, they later face ruin—and Shang Yang, Su Qin, and Zhang Yi are just such cases. How is this unlike the weasel that dies in the hunter’s net?

Consider the yak: vast as a cloud trailing across the sky. This creature is great indeed, yet it cannot catch a mouse.

Just as Zhuangzi’s words teach: one who does not fawn upon the vulgar can govern the state and cultivate the self, enduring long and abiding in permanence.

Now, you possess a great tree, yet lament its lack of utility. Why not plant it in the land of *wuheyou*—the boundless wilds? (The *wuheyou* means "nothing possessed," for in that vast and unpeopled expanse, whatever exists is as if it were not, hence the name *wuheyou*.) There, you may wander freely at its side or recline in ease beneath its shade. (The term *panghuang* denotes unconstrained movement, while *xiaoyao* signifies self-contentment—different words expressing the same idea, each lending its own elegance.) This useless tree, with its lush branches and luxuriant leaves, casts a sweeping shade that blocks the sun and welcomes the wind. Travelers passing by linger to rest, pacing to and fro or leaning against its trunk, lying down beneath its boughs. This, too, mirrors Zhuangzi’s teaching: by embracing emptiness and simplicity, one may roam at will and nurture one’s nature, offering shelter to all living beings.

It will not be felled by axes, nor harmed by any thing. Since it has no use, how can it suffer hardship? (For things great and small alike, if they stray from their proper measure, the principles of benefit and harm become the same. But when each is used according to its nature, all things attain freedom.) The tree’s gnarled and twisted form renders it unfit for timber, and no carpenter spares it a glance. The axe will never touch it, so how could the calamity of premature felling befall it? Thus, it fulfills its natural lifespan and exhausts its allotted years. In its uselessness, where lies its hardship? This, again, reflects Zhuangzi’s teaching: by deviating from convention and aligning with the Dao, one may preserve one’s integrity and safeguard one’s true nature—neither cut short by the world’s paths nor ever mired in life’s struggles.

#43 Wang Xiaoyu, following the context below, adds the character "clumsy" (*zhuo*) above "and" (*er*).
#44 The *Quewu* cites the Wen Ruhai edition, where "hardship" (*kun ku*) is rendered as "destitution" (*qiong kun*).

**Preface to the *Nanhua True Scripture***
*By Guo Xiang of Henan, styled Zixuan*

Zhuangzi may be said to have known the root. Thus, he never concealed his unbridled words—utterances that, though vast as the cycles of heaven and earth, respond uniquely to the moment. For if a response does not meet the occasion, even if it aligns with the primordial use, it remains ineffective; and if words do not address the affairs of things, even if lofty, they will not circulate. Compared to those who remain still until compelled to act, Zhuangzi’s approach is fundamentally distinct. This is what it means to know the primordial mind.

When the mind is primordial, it responds to stimuli as they arise, adapting to the times, its words ever measured. Thus, it embodies transformation, flowing through the ages to merge with things—how could it ever contrive opposition, encountering the singular to wander in discourse beyond the bounds of convention? This is why his work, though not canonical, stands as the crown of the Hundred Schools.

Yet while Zhuangzi may not have fully embodied it, his words reach the utmost. They unify the order of heaven and earth, sequence the natures of the myriad things, penetrate the changes of life and death, and illuminate the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship. Above, he knows the Creator and the primordial absence of things; below, he knows how things arise of themselves. His words are vast and expansive, his meaning profound and wondrous. The Way in its perfection is subtle and refined; serene and unconstrained, it is free yet not dissolute.

Thus, he says: not knowing where righteousness leads, one may act wildly yet tread the great square; chewing one’s food, one rejoices in simplicity; drumming one’s belly, one wanders in boundless vastness. Supreme benevolence reaches the absence of partiality; filial piety and kindness culminate in mutual forgetting. Ritual and music revert to innate ability; loyalty and trust emerge from the radiance of heaven. Using this radiance, one’s uncarved simplicity naturally takes form. Therefore, the sacred vessel transforms alone in the mysterious darkness, its source deep and its flow enduring.

Thus, wherever its long waves ripple, wherever its lofty winds fan, it harmonizes with the fittingness of things and accords with the people’s wishes. It broadens the narrow, unties the entangled, and though its liberating work is not yet applied, arrogance and ostentation scatter of themselves. Reading his book, one feels transcendent, as if already attaining the fitting, crossing Kunlun, traversing the great void, and wandering the courts of the indistinct and joyous. Even the greedy and the restless, if they but briefly grasp its lingering fragrance, taste its overflowing stream, or glimpse its echoes and shadows, may yet feel the expansive joy of forgetting form and self-attainment—how much more those who delve into its distant depths and savor its eternal years? Thus, it stretches far and clear, departing from the dust of the world to return to the ultimate darkness.

---

**Preface to the *Commentary on the Nanhua True Scripture***
*By Master Cheng Xuanying of Xihua, Tang Dynasty*

Zhuangzi’s work expounds the deep roots of virtue and power, elucidates the wondrous purport of the profound mystery, unfolds the primordial uncarved simplicity, and clarifies the office of solitary transformation. It restrains the Nine Schools, encompasses the Hundred Masters, and is indeed the supreme teaching within the realm—truly the subtle words beyond forms.

He was surnamed Zhuang, named Zhou, styled Zixiu, born in Meng County of Suiyang in the state of Song. His teacher was Master Sang of Chang, and he received the title "Immortal of Nanhua." At the beginning of the Warring States period, during the decline of the late Zhou, he lamented the meager karma of the people and grieved the erosion of virtue and power. Thus, with fervent resolve, he composed this discourse.

His words are vast and erudite, his meaning deep and far-reaching—beyond the comprehension of lesser scholars, unfathomable to shallow minds. The term *zi* ("Master") is an honorific for the virtuous; in ancient times, teachers were called *zi*. It is also the title of this book—not merely the collective name for the three Inner Chapters, but a general designation for the Hundred Schools.

The *Inner Chapters* are so named because "inner" stands in contrast to "outer," and "chapters" refers to the arrangement of bamboo slips. In ancient times, bamboo was treated to make slips, bound with leather thongs; when slips were bound into chapters, it was like today’s pages forming a scroll. Thus, the *Yuan Kai* states: great matters are recorded on *ce* (long slips), while minor matters use *du* (short slips). The *Inner Chapters* discuss the root of principle, while the *Outer Chapters* address its peripheral affairs. Though affairs may be manifest, they are not understood without principle; though principle is subtle, it is not revealed without affairs. To first clarify the wondrous principle, the *Inner Chapters* are placed first.

The principles in the *Inner Chapters* are profound, so each chapter is given a separate title outside the text. Guo Xiang’s commentary appears directly beneath these titles, as in *Free and Easy Wandering* and *The Equality of Things*. From the *Outer Chapters* onward, titles are taken from the first two characters of each chapter, as in *Webbed Toes* and *Horses’ Hooves*.

Regarding *Free and Easy Wandering*, interpretations have varied across the ages. Here, I broadly outline the main threads, presenting three explanations:

The first: Gu Tongbai says: *Xiao* means "to dissolve"; *yao* means "distant." Dissolving the burdens of deliberate action, one perceives the principle of non-action. Wandering thus, it is called *xiaoyao*.

The second: Zhi Daolin says: One treats things as things yet is not treated as a thing by them, so one is free (*xiaoran*) without reliance on others. The mysterious response is swift without haste, so one is far-reaching (*yaoran*) without limit. Wandering the world thus, it is called *xiaoyao you* (Free and Easy Wandering).

The third: Mu Ye says: *Xiaoyao* is the name for being uninhibited and self-content. When utmost virtue fills one within, one is not bound by the times; responding to things with forgetfulness, where does one not penetrate? Wandering the world thus, it is called *xiaoyao you*.

The *Inner Chapters* clarify the root of principle; the *Outer Chapters* discuss its proximate affairs; the *Miscellaneous Chapters* intermingle principle and affairs. Though the *Inner Chapters* clarify the root of principle, they do not exclude its peripheral affairs; though the *Outer Chapters* discuss proximate affairs, they contain wondrous principles. The division of teachings into chapters is based on what is most discussed.

Thus, *Free and Easy Wandering* is placed first: it speaks of those who attain the Way—whose wisdom and virtue are bright and keen, whose achievements are always fitting, and who wander freely among things. Therefore, it is named *Free and Easy Wandering*.

The unattached sage, like a mirror reflecting the moment, having clarified the two wisdoms of provisional and real, thus achieves great equality amid the ten thousand conditions—therefore *Equalizing Things* follows next.

Having pointed to the hooves of horses and the heavens-and-earth, merging with the myriad things, with a spirit serene and still, one may grasp the arts of nurturing life—therefore *Nurturing Life* is placed next in order.

Having forgotten both good and evil, with conditions and wisdom both wondrous, following transformations and yielding to change, one may dwell amid the affairs of the human world—therefore *The World of Men* follows next.

With inner virtue complete, one may then extend it outward to engage with things, rising and falling with them, achieving profound harmony within and without—therefore *The Sign of Full Virtue* follows next.

Like still water or flowing reflection, engaging with things without fixed intent, forgetting virtue and forgetting form, attaining the utmost union of inner and outer, one may craft and perfect the myriad beings—therefore *The Great Master* follows next.

The true sages of old, knowing Heaven and knowing man, sharing the work of creation, at once quiescent and responsive, thus guided and governed the multitude—therefore *Responding to Emperors and Kings* follows next.
