*[Commentary]* Only one who skillfully relinquishes the two extremes and abides in the single center can preserve the body and fulfill the Way of life. Externally, one can filially nurture parents and perfectly accord with human relations; internally, one can safeguard the spirit and fulfill one’s heavenly mandate.

Cook Ding carved an ox for Lord Wenhui. Where his hand touched, where his shoulder leaned, where his foot trod, where his knee pressed—*shū*! *xiàng*!—the blade sounded *luò*!
*[Commentary]* Cook Ding refers to the kitchen servant, the one who prepares meals today. Alternatively, Ding is his name. Lord Wenhui is Lord Hui of Liang. *Carved* means to butcher. *Qí* means to thrust with the lower horn. The text says that Cook Ding, skilled at butchering oxen, saw their natural patterns. Thus, with his hand he grasped, with his shoulder he leaned, with his foot he trod, with his knee he pressed, causing flesh and skin to separate. *Shē*! *xiàng*!—the sounds responded. Advancing the phoenix knife, *luò*!—the great carving was complete. This is an allegory of Cook Ding to illustrate the flourishing of nurturing life.

Every sound was in tune, harmonizing with the dance of *Sanglin* and matching the rhythm of *Jingshou*.
*[Annotation]* His actions, following convenience and applying skill, were all effortlessly masterful. So perfect was his accord with principle that he both followed the ox’s patterns and matched the musical notes.
*[Commentary]* *Sanglin* is the name of a Shang Tang dance. *Jingshou* is the name of a chapter of the *Xianchi* music, the music of Yao. Cook Ding’s spirit was at ease, and he masterfully followed the ox’s patterns. Then, the sounds of his carving harmonized with elegant tones, so that his music matched *Sanglin* and his rhythm accorded with *Jingshou*.

Lord Wenhui said, "Ah! Excellent! How has your skill reached such heights?"

The exclamation "Ah!" is an expression of admiration. Having witnessed Cook Ding apply his skill with such ease, produce harmonious rhythms, and align so perfectly with the musical compositions, Lord Wenhui praised how his mastery had reached such heights.

Cook Ding set down his knife and replied, "What your servant delights in is the Dao, which surpasses mere skill."

*[Annotation]* He merely lodged the principle within his skill—what he truly delighted in was not the skill itself.

*[Commentary]* Setting aside his ornate blade, he answered by expounding the Dao of nurturing life, thus elevating his craft to present to his lord. Another interpretation: "surpasses" means "goes beyond." What he delights in is the Dao of nurturing life, which transcends the skill of butchering an ox.

"When I first began butchering oxen, all I saw was the ox itself."

*[Annotation]* He had yet to perceive the patterns within.

*[Commentary]* At the outset of learning his trade, he had not yet discerned the underlying principles, so all he beheld was the ox. This is akin to one who first embarks on nurturing life, unable to perceive the true realm, and thus encounters obstacles at every turn.

"After three years, I no longer saw the ox as a whole."

*[Annotation]* He now saw only the patterns within.

*[Commentary]* Having wielded the knife for some time, he frequently perceived the spaces between the patterns, so that upon glimpsing the ox, he already knew how to render it empty. This is like one who has cultivated the Dao for many days, whose wisdom gradually brightens, seeing all worldly phenomena as illusory.

"Now, I encounter it with my spirit rather than with my eyes."

*[Annotation]* He merges with and meets the principle.

*[Commentary]* "Encounter" means "to meet." For nineteen years, he has harmonized with the subtle numbers of yin and yang, guiding his spirit to unite with the principle—how could he rely on his eyes to see? This is like one who has mastered the Dao, whose profound accord with the ultimate transcends the need to engage the senses to grasp the dust of the world.

"My senses cease, and my spirit moves as it wills."

*[Annotation]* The faculties of perception are stilled, and the mind flows freely in accord with the principle.

*[Commentary]* "Faculties" refer to the governing senses—such as the eyes, which perceive form, or the ears, which perceive sound. Having encountered the ox with his spirit and no longer relying on his eyes, all such governing senses are stilled. His mind moves as it wills, flowing in accord with the principle. The same holds true for one who skillfully nurtures life.

"I follow the natural patterns." *[Annotation]* Without arbitrary severance.

The skill lies in following the inherent excellence of natural patterns, never arbitrarily severing to harm the ox. Likewise, the subtle Dao of nurturing life adheres to the bounds of nature, never demanding premature death from the living.

"Strike at the great gaps,"
*[Annotation]* At the junctures, strike to part them.
*[Commentary]* At the points where adjacent parts meet, apply force to separate them, causing sinews and bones to diverge. This is like one who studies the Dao, at the junctures of life and death or poverty and prosperity, employing mindful observation to attain liberation.

"Guide through the great cavities,"
*[Annotation]* Where joints open into hollows, guide the blade to keep them distinct.
*[Commentary]* *Qiào* means hollow. At the hollows between bones and joints, thrust and guide the blade to maintain separation. This is like the practitioner who, with the emptiness of resources, guides the fullness of being.

"Proceed from what is inherently so."
*[Annotation]* The blade is never applied arbitrarily.
*[Commentary]* Only after finding the gaps to strike does one wield the knife, just as one relies on what the eyes see and ears hear, never applying the blade arbitrarily.

"Never once has it encountered the tangles of flesh or the snares of sinew,"
*[Annotation]* The marvel of the skill lies in constantly moving the blade through emptiness, never once meeting even the slightest obstruction.
"how much less the great bones?"
*[Annotation]* *Wèi* refers to the largest joints, where the blade would bind.
*[Commentary]* *Kěn yíng* refers to where flesh adheres to bone; *wèi*, to the great bones. The marvel of the skill lies in moving the blade through emptiness, never once encountering even the slightest obstruction—how much less the great bones? Likewise, in nurturing life and wielding wisdom, one subtly embodies true emptiness; even minor delusions do not stain the mind, so how could gross dust burden one’s virtue?

"A good butcher changes his knife once a year—because he cuts."
*[Annotation]* He does not cleave along the natural divisions.
*[Commentary]* Even a skilled butcher, failing to cleave along the natural divisions, must replace his knife after a year. How much more so for one who has not yet embodied the true Dao, grasping at emptiness while clinging to being, whose mind is easily swayed?

"A mediocre butcher changes his knife every month—because he hacks."
*[Annotation]* He strikes bone and breaks the blade.
*[Commentary]* How much more so for the coarse and unrefined, whose spirit is obstructed and dull, encountering every circumstance as an obstacle, thereby harming wisdom and injuring the spirit?

"For nineteen years, my blade has remained in use, having dissected thousands of oxen, yet its edge is as if newly whetted from the grindstone."
*[Annotation]* *Xíng* refers to a whetstone.
*[Commentary]* *Xíng* is a sharpening stone. Nine is the number of yang; ten, the number of yin.

Thus, nineteen years represent the ultimate subtlety of yin and yang. For this reason, after nineteen years and thousands of oxen dissected, moving through emptiness and traversing the void without dulling the blade’s edge, his knife remains as keen as if freshly whetted. How much more so for one who nurtures life well, whose wisdom penetrates emptiness and being, who harmonizes his light with the world and exhausts the mysteries of yin and yang? Though myriad transformations unfold, he ever renews his virtue; though he traverses ten thousand realms, he remains serene and undisturbed.

Those joints possess spaces, while the blade’s edge has no thickness. With no thickness entering into spaces, how vast is the room for the blade to move! *[Commentary]* The ox’s bones and joints naturally contain gaps, while the blade’s edge is sharp and thin, possessing no thickness. Using a blade without thickness to enter the ox’s gaps, the movement of the knife is thus expansive, leaving ample room. How much more so for the adept who nurtures life, the one who embodies the Dao, who wields the wondrous wisdom of forgetting the utmost and roams the boundless realm of things? Thus, he arranges and adapts with ease, ever at leisure, while realm and wisdom merge, neither one nor different. Therefore, after nineteen years, the blade’s edge remains as if newly sharpened. *[Commentary]* Reiterating the preceding text to conclude its meaning.

Yet whenever I encounter the dense clusters, I perceive the difficulty. *[Annotation]* "Dense clusters" refers to where sinews and bones intertwine. I pause in caution, my gaze fixed, *[Annotation]* No longer directing my eyes elsewhere. my movements slow. *[Annotation]* My hand moves deliberately. *[Commentary]* Where the joints and bones are densely entangled is called a "cluster." Though the blade moves through emptiness and I skillfully discern its retreat, whenever I reach these tangled knots, I cannot but attend to the challenge with care, remaining vigilant and deliberate, my focus unwavering and my hand unhurried. How much more so for one who embodies the Dao: though he comprehends the illusory nature of all things, when realm and wisdom intersect, he must remain cautious and deliberate, lest he lightly taint the roots and dust, disturbing the tranquility.

With the slightest effort, the ox falls apart, *[Annotation]* When the proper method is found, little force is needed. like earth crumbling to the ground. *[Annotation]* The dismemberment occurs without the knife’s advance, as if soil scattering. *[Commentary]* *Dié* (谍) is pronounced with a hundred inflections. *Diéran* refers to the sound of bones and flesh separating. The movement of the phoenix knife is exquisitely subtle, guided by Heaven’s principle, so the task is effortless—like earth scattering to the ground, leaving no trace. How much more so when wielding spirit and wisdom, illuminating the finest subtleties, traversing the dusty realm without the slightest obstruction, where realm and wisdom merge and subject and object dissolve?

Standing with the knife raised, I look around, filled with satisfaction. *[Annotation]* This describes a leisurely and self-contented demeanor. *[Commentary]* Having completed the task of dissecting the ox, I stand at ease, holding the phoenix knife, lingering in contemplation. Then, with an air of refined detachment, I survey the four directions, my spirit full and my heart brimming with self-assurance. The principle of nurturing life is likewise. I then wipe the knife clean and store it away. *[Annotation]* To clean the knife and put it away. *[Commentary]* Preserving it well, I wipe and sheath it. How much more so for one who skillfully nurtures life: he shines without dazzling.

Prince Wenhui said: "Excellent! From the words of Cook Ding, I have learned how to nurture life." *[Annotation]* Since the knife can be nurtured, so too can life. *[Commentary]* Marquis Wen heard Cook Ding’s words and awakened to the Dao of nurturing life. Delighted by its spiritual wonder, he exclaimed, "Excellent!"

Gongwen Xuan saw the Right Minister and was startled, asking: "Who is this man? Why is he limping?" *[Annotation]* *Jie* refers to a partial amputation. *[Commentary]* Gongwen was his surname, Xuan his given name, a man of Song. "Right Minister" was his official title. *Jie* means amputation. Gongwen, seeing the Right Minister’s missing foot, was startled and asked how he came to be so maimed—what offense had he committed to suffer such a loss? Was it fate, or was it man?" *[Annotation]* What cannot be helped is fate; what violates one’s knowledge is man. *[Commentary]* Was this decreed by Heaven, or did he lack a foot from birth? Or was it due to human affairs that he suffered this mutilation? Was this Gongwen’s question?

The reply came: "It is Heaven, not man. Heaven’s creation made him solitary." *[Annotation]* To be partially amputated is called "solitary." If one’s knowledge is limited to a single household and cannot preserve both feet, then knowledge is powerless to help. If the Right Minister’s knowledge sought to keep both feet whole, his spirit would be inwardly exhausted and his body outwardly ruined—how could it be merely a partial amputation? *[Commentary]* The clarity of wisdom and the wholeness of form are both bestowed by Heaven, not a matter of human affairs. Even if he had violated royal law and suffered this mutilation, it would still be due to Heaven’s creation of his stubborn ignorance, insufficient to protect himself. To attribute the loss of his foot to human action while ignoring Heaven’s role in shaping his wisdom is to recognize that having or lacking is a matter of fate.

"Man’s appearance is likewise bestowed."

[Annotation] "Having both feet to walk" is called *having both*. One who possesses such an appearance does not doubt that it is a matter of fate. From this we know that it is Heaven’s doing, not man’s.

[Annotation] Since *having both* is a matter of fate, we know that *lacking one* is likewise not of my own doing. Thus, one who understands the nature of life does not strive for what life cannot achieve; one who understands the nature of fate does not contend with what fate cannot alter—one simply preserves what is natural.

[Subcommentary] *Having both* means sharing. All people’s appearances, including having two feet to walk, are bestowed by the Creator. Thus we know that if one foot suffers this mutilation, it is likewise nothing but fate. This clarifies that success or failure, adversity or prosperity, foolishness or wisdom, wholeness or impairment—all are determined by hidden omens, not by human skill or clumsiness. Only those who grasp this principle can preserve life in its fullness.

The marsh pheasant takes ten steps to peck, a hundred steps to drink, yet does not seek to be fed in a cage.

[Annotation] *Seek* means to pursue; *cage* is what confines the pheasant. To move freely between Heaven and Earth, to roam in the realm of self-contentment—this is the sublime art of nurturing life. Why then seek to enter a cage and submit to domestication?

[Subcommentary] *Seek* means to pursue; *cage* refers to the pheasant’s pen. The marsh pheasant, following its wild nature, drinks and pecks at will, roaming freely and unfettered. How could it desire to enter a cage and be tamed? This is like one who nurtures life, dwelling in serene seclusion, finding joy only in the rustling of the forest—how could they envy worldly glory?

[Another interpretation:] The *ze* resembles a pheasant but is not one; the *ze* has a long tail while the pheasant’s is short—this refers to the *ze-pheasant*.

Though its spirit reigns supreme, it is not *good*.

[Annotation] One who begins with contentment and never ceases to be content has forgotten contentment. The pheasant’s spirit reigns supreme, its will and qi overflowing with ease, freely roaming the clear and boundless wilds. Suddenly, it does not recognize *good* as good.

[Subcommentary] The pheasant dwells in the mountains and marshes, drinking and pecking at will, its spirit reigning supreme, its will and qi brimming with joy. At such moments, it suddenly does not recognize *good* as good. Only when confined to a cage, its nature and emotions unfulfilled, does it reflect on the past and find it exceedingly carefree. If even a bird is thus, how much more so for humans? This illustrates that supreme contentment forgets contentment, and supreme goodness forgets goodness.

When Lao Dan died, Qin Shi mourned him, wailing three times before departing.

[Annotation] Where others mourn, he mourns; where others wail, he wails.

[Subcommentary] Lao Jun is Laozi, surnamed Li, named Er, styled Boyang, and also known as Lao Dan—a great sage born in Ku County of Chen State. During the reign of King Ping of Zhou, he left the Zhou court, crossed the western desert, and journeyed to the land of the barbarians. Though no records of his life appear in the inner and outer classics, this text alone speaks of his death, intending to show that the principles of life and death are ultimately one, and that the Way of the sage is equal in all things. This is but a parable of Zhuangzi’s, for Lao Jun is the ancestor of the Great Dao, the origin of Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things—how could he have life and death? Thus, he borrows this tale to illustrate that even sages undergo life and death, clarifying the principle of life and death. Lao Jun’s descent, life, and ascent to Heaven are fully recorded in the *Twelve Classics*, but they are not elaborated here.

Qin Shi, surnamed Qin and named Shi, was a scholar of the Dao, though his origins are unknown. Upon Laozi’s death, he mourned him, wailing three times before departing. Though he lowered himself to act as an ordinary mourner, his duty fulfilled, he left.

The disciple said: "Was he not your friend?"
*(Note: Surprised that he did not merely stand by the door to observe the transformation but instead wailed three times.)*
*(Commentary: Qin Shi and Lord Lao both wandered beyond the world. To wail and mourn—could this be called lofty? Thus, the disciple, startled and doubtful, asked if he was not a friend.)*

He replied: "Yes."
*(Commentary: "Yes" means "it is so." Qin Shi answered the disciple, saying he was a friend from beyond the world.)*

The disciple asked: "Then is it proper to mourn him in this way?"
*(Commentary: For one beyond the world to perform the rites of the mundane, wailing and mourning thus—is this reasonable? Not yet understanding the harmony of light, he pressed further with this question.)*

He replied: "Yes."
*(Note: The perfected one is without emotion; he merely joined the crowd in wailing. Thus, it is permissible.)*
*(Commentary: "Yes" means "it is permissible." Profound stillness and responsiveness are inwardly and outwardly in perfect accord, so it is fitting.)*

"At first, I thought he was one of your followers, but now I see he is not.
When I entered to offer my condolences, I saw elders weeping for him as if for a son, and the young weeping for him as if for a mother.
Those who gathered must have been moved by words not sought, by weeping not contrived."
*(Note: He suspected they had bestowed favors before the fact, not abiding in principle, thus leading to such excessive attachment.)*
*(Commentary: "Sought" means "deliberately pursued." "Those" refers to the crowd. The sage, with an empty heart, responds to the feelings of all things. Pitying the multitudes and grieving for the people, he expounds the Dao without waiting to be asked. Thus, when he died, the people gathered, wailing and mourning as if for a parent or child. This is the clinging of ordinary emotions, the delusion of life and death, stirred by the sage’s kindness to such sorrow. Judging by this, I knew they were not Lord Lao’s disciples.)*

"This is fleeing from Heaven and doubling one’s emotions, forgetting what one has received."
*(Note: The nature one receives from Heaven has its own proper measure; it cannot be escaped, nor can it be added to.)*
*(Commentary: "This" refers to those who wept. "Doubling" means "adding." To flee from one’s natural endowment and amplify worldly emotions, mistakenly seeing death as something to grieve—this is to forget the measure one has received.)*

"The ancients called this the punishment of fleeing from Heaven."
*(Note: To be so deeply moved by things as to exceed what is proper is to flee from Heaven. Racing into the realm of sorrow and joy, though no physical punishment is applied, one’s nature and emotions are already exhausted—is this not a punishment?)*
*(Commentary: To flee from Heaven’s principle and amplify worldly emotions, to be consumed by sorrow and joy, to torment the heart and spirit as if by flogging—is this not a punishment? The enlightened of old spoke thus.)*

"To come is the Master’s time;
*(Note: Time arises of itself.)*
to go is the Master’s compliance.
*(Note: Death is the natural principle.)*
*(Commentary: "The Master" refers to Lord Lao. Qin Shi, knowing Lord Lao was a great sage who profoundly understood the source, said that his timely birth was in accord with the moment, and his tranquil departure was in compliance with principle, returning to the true.)*

"Abiding in time and complying with principle, neither sorrow nor joy can enter.
*(Note: Sorrow and joy arise from loss and gain. Now, the one who is spiritually attuned and harmonized with change is at peace in every moment, in every circumstance. Mysteriously one with the transformations of creation, there is nowhere that is not oneself—what gain or loss, what life or death could there be? Thus, following what one has received, sorrow and joy have no place to intervene.)*
*(Commentary: Content with life, one does not resent living; compliant with death, one does not abhor dying. In the myriad changes, nothing is not oneself. Wherever one goes, one is at ease—thus sorrow and joy have no place in the heart.)*

"The ancients called this the celestial release."
*(Note: To take the bound as "suspended" is to see the unbound as "released." Released, the emotions of life and destiny are attained. This is the essence of nurturing life.)*
*(Commentary: "Celestial" means "Heaven." To be bound by life and death is to be suspended; to be free of life and death is to be released. For one whom life and death cannot bind, whom sorrow and joy cannot enter—the sages of remote antiquity called this the natural release. Yet Lord Lao, the great sage, was one with life and death—how could he flee from the punishment of fleeing Heaven or rush into sorrow and joy? Master Xuan’s note here misses the mark by far. If so, what does it mean to abide in time and comply with principle, to attain the celestial release? The argument turns back on itself. Thus, the punishment of fleeing Heaven belongs to those who grieve excessively, not to Lord Lao.)*

"When the finger is exhausted in pointing to the firewood, the fire is transmitted.
*(Note: "Exhausted" means "ended"; "firewood" refers to the preceding fuel. When the finger points to the principle of the preceding firewood, the fire is transmitted and does not expire. When the heart abides in the midst of nurturing, life continues without end. This clarifies that nurturing life is the very means by which life is sustained.)*
*(Commentary: "Exhausted" means "ended." "Firewood" means "fuel." "Pointing" means "preceding." When one kindles a fire, using the preceding fuel, one who fully understands the principle of kindling will ensure that even as the preceding fuel is consumed, the following fuel continues it, passing the flame from one to the next so that the fire does not expire. This is like one who skillfully nurtures life, flowing with change, moving with things, renewing oneself without attachment—nothing is not oneself, so life continues without end.)*

"One does not know its end.
*(Note: Time does not return, the present does not pause—thus, for a person’s life, each breath is a single attainment. The last breath is not the present breath; thus, by nurturing, life continues.)*

The preceding fire is not the subsequent fire, thus the fire is transmitted through the fuel, and as the fire is transmitted, life continues—this arises from nurturing to its utmost. How could the world know that as one ends, another is born?

*(Commentary: The deluded and forgetful, bound by their emotions and attachments, how could they know that the new is ever-unceasing, thought after thought flowing onward? Yesterday’s self is already exhausted in today, and today’s self is reborn in what follows. Formerly, this chapter was divided into seven sections to clarify its meaning, but upon examining its textual flow, such division proved overly cumbersome. Now, I have merged "For Goodness" with the first section and "Pointing to Exhaustion" with "Lord Lao," consolidating the whole into five chapters, leaving no room for doubt or ambiguity.)*

*The Zhuangzi: Annotated Explanations, Scroll Four—Concluded*

*(Textual Notes: #1 The Zhao Advisor’s edition reads "其" instead of "而." #2 The original reads "宜," emended to "冥" following the Siku Quanshu and Zhejiang Bureau editions. #3 Guo Qingfan’s cited text emends "改" to "宰." #4 Guo Qingfan’s cited text adds the character "刀" after "奏." #5 The Zhao edition includes the character "全" before "牛." #6 Guo Qingfan’s cited text reads "照" instead of "扇." #7 The Zhao edition reads "理顺" instead of "顺理." #8 Wang Xiaoyu emends "蹴" to "就" based on the commentary. #9 Guo Qingfan’s cited text reads "分别" instead of "刀然." #10 The *Quewu* edition, citing the Ruhai and Liu Deyi versions, adds "不知其死也" after "解." #11 Guo Qingfan’s cited text emends "美" to "善." #12 The character "者" appears erroneous; following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the context, it should read "诸." #13 Guo Qingfan’s cited text reads "斯" instead of "其." #14 The *Quewu* edition, citing the Ruhai version, reads "至" instead of "其." #15 Guo Qingfan’s cited text reads "锌" instead of "锋." #16 The Zhao edition does not repeat "火传.")*

*The Zhuangzi: Annotated Explanations, Scroll Five*
*Annotations by Guo Xiang of Henan*

The Tang-era Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary
*Inner Chapters, "In the Human World" (Chapter Four)*

To dwell among people is to be inseparable from them. Yet the vicissitudes of human affairs vary across ages, and only those who are without fixed intent and do not impose their own will can adapt to change as it arises without bearing its burdens.

Yan Hui sought out Confucius and requested leave to travel.
**[Subcommentary]** His surname was Yan, given name Hui, courtesy name Ziyuan, a native of Lu. Among Confucius’ three thousand disciples, he was one of the foremost, admitted to the inner chamber across the four categories of instruction. As for Zhongni: his surname was Kong, given name Qiu, courtesy name Zhongni, also a native of Lu, a descendant of the Yin sovereign Tang. Born in the declining Zhou era, he possessed sagely virtue and was the teacher of Yan Hui. The roots of their deeds lie in the Confucian tradition, but since this is an explication of the *Zhuangzi*, our intent lies in the profound and subtle. Thus, we shall not belabor the details here.

Yet the threads of human affairs are tangled and fraught with difficulty. To engage with others for their benefit is a principle not easily mastered. Therefore, the text invokes Yan and Kong to reveal the method of transformation and guidance, entrusting these sages to clarify the safeguarding of the fasting of the mind.

The sagely Kong and the worthy Yan—
Confucius asked, “Where are you bound?”
**[Subcommentary]** *Xi* means “what”; *zhi* means “to go.” The question inquires where Yan Hui intends to travel.
Yan Hui replied, “I will go to Wei.”
**[Subcommentary]** Wei was the capital of King Zhou of Yin and later the fief of Kang Shu. Today, it corresponds to Weizhou in Jijun. Here, Yan answers Confucius’ question regarding his destination.
Confucius asked, “What will you do there?”
**[Subcommentary]** What purpose does he have in going to the state of Wei? The question presses Yan Hui further on the intent behind his journey.
Yan Hui replied, “I have heard that the Lord of Wei is in his prime, yet his conduct is willful.”
**[Annotation]** He does not share the desires of his people.
**[Subcommentary]** The Lord of Wei refers to Ji Zha, son of Duke Ling. Dissolute and reckless, he indulged in excess without regard for the Dao. Though young and vigorous, his might was fearsome; his actions were violent and defied the will of the people. Yan Hui recounts what he has heard to answer his master.

The ruler treats his state with recklessness.
**[Annotation]** One who governs others must act with caution, for a single outburst of anger may leave corpses strewn and blood flowing, while a moment of pleasure may fill the roads with carriages and caps. Thus, the use of a state by its ruler must never be taken lightly.
**[Subcommentary]** The people are the foundation of the state; when the foundation is secure, the state enjoys peace. If one fails to cherish and value the common folk, instead treating their use with contempt, how can the state avoid collapse?

And yet he fails to see his own faults.
**[Annotation]** None dare admonish him.
**[Subcommentary]** His strength suffices to reject counsel, his eloquence to gloss over wrongs. Thus, the hundred officials swallow their words in fear, and though his faults abound, none dare reproach him.

He treats the lives of his people as of little worth,
**[Annotation]** He treats them as expendable in matters of life and death.
**[Subcommentary]** Unmoved by stillness or motion, complacent in his ease, he recklessly deploys his people, casting them into the jaws of death.

The dead are measured by the state as if they were reeds in the marsh,
**[Annotation]** When the entire state is driven to death, their number defies reckoning—they are regarded as mere grass and weeds.
**[Subcommentary]** *Jiao* refers to grass and weeds. Whether through ceaseless campaigns or crushing taxes, the dead are beyond counting. To speak of their number is to measure them by the state itself, for their multitude is too vast to tally in haste. Indulging only himself, he neglects the hundred clans, viewing his people as no more than reeds in a swamp.

The people have nowhere to turn.
**[Annotation]** They have no refuge.
**[Subcommentary]** With a ruler devoid of the Way and ministers suffering famine, they not only find themselves helpless but also have nowhere to flee.

I once heard the Master say: “Flee a well-governed state; go to a disordered one—where there are many illnesses, there is work for a physician.” I wish to apply the principle I have heard, hoping that the state may yet find some relief.
**[Subcommentary]** *Shu* means “to hope,” *ji* means “near.”

"Recovery" means healing. In a well-governed state, peace and tranquility prevail without need of correction or support; but in a disordered land, isolated and imperiled, one must apply tested remedies. Yan now proposes to transform Wei, and so I recount what I once heard, reflecting on the teachings he received, hoping he may draw near to the good Way. Like a physician’s gate where many are cured of illness, so too can a worthy scholar rescue from peril—yet for the malady of wanton excess, there is no recovery.

Confucius said: “Hmph. You will likely go and meet punishment.”
**[Annotation]** His Way is insufficient to save or bring rest.
**[Subcommentary]** *Hmph* is the sound of mocking laughter. *You* means “you.” *Likely* means “near.” Confucius scoffs at his shallow presumption, for he is unfit to transform others. If you go to Wei, you will surely suffer execution.

The Way does not tolerate admixture.
**[Annotation]** It must be rightly embodied in the proper person.
Admixture leads to multiplicity, multiplicity to disorder, disorder to distress, and distress cannot be remedied.
**[Annotation]** If the proper person is not found, even a hundred physicians attending the patient will only deepen doubt and fail to bring a single cure.
**[Subcommentary]** The numinous Way resides in purity alone. If it is adulterated, affairs multiply; multiplicity breeds confusion in the heart, and confusion gives rise to distress. When medicine and malady clash, both patient and healer are exhausted. If one cannot even establish oneself, how can one save others? The perfected of old first stabilized themselves before stabilizing others.
**[Annotation]** Only with the requisite capacity can one engage with the world.
**[Subcommentary]** *Zhu* means “in.” *Cun* means “to establish.” The supremely virtuous of antiquity, advancing with empty minds into the world, first secured their own Way before rescuing others. There has never been one whose own self was unestablished who could yet engage with things. This is cited from the ancients as a mirror and warning. If what is established in oneself remains unsettled, how can one presume to reach the conduct of a violent ruler?
**[Annotation]** One who does not respond to things with an empty mind but expends thought in reckless confrontation shows that what is established in oneself is not yet settled.
Only by externalizing knowledge to nurture the true, entrusting subtlety to the talents of the many, ascribing merit to things while quieting cares and distancing the self, can one then attain the conduct of a violent ruler.
**[Subcommentary]** Only one who responds to affairs with an empty mind, forgets knowledge to nurture the true, entrusts rightness to the many, and ascribes merit to the myriad things may then enter the human realm, adapt to its currents, and act to transform it. Now Yan Hui’s self-cultivation is not yet secure; right and wrong, joy and anger surge within his breast. What leisure has he to rush to Wei and admonish a violent ruler? This course is not yet viable.

Moreover, do you know whence virtue is swept away and knowledge arises?"

Virtue is swept away by fame, and knowledge arises from contention.
**[Annotation]** The reason virtue flows away and dissipates is the pride taken in fame; the reason knowledge spreads recklessly is the struggle to be deemed good. Even if one were as ruined as Jie, what they cherish and cling to is nothing but the name of goodness.

**[Subcommentary]** Do you even know the source from which virtue is swept away and knowledge arises? Virtue flows away and loses its truth because of pride in fame; knowledge spreads recklessly and exceeds its bounds because of contention over goodness. Only one who forgets both good and evil, relinquishing both name and reality, can ensure that the myriad virtues do not dissipate and that ultimate knowledge does not arise. Fame is that by which people clash; knowledge is the instrument of contention. These two are instruments of misfortune and cannot be fully enacted.

**[Annotation]** Fame and knowledge are what the world employs. Yet when fame arises, people clash; when knowledge is used, contention flourishes. Only by relinquishing fame and knowledge can conduct be fully realized.

**[Subcommentary]** To take pride in fame is to invite mutual harm; to display knowledge is to spark contention on the path. Thus, these two are both instruments of calamity and cannot be enacted in the world. Moreover, though virtue is profound and trustworthiness evident, one has not yet reached the qi of others; though one’s reputation is renowned and free of contention, one has not yet reached the hearts of others.

**[Subcommentary]** *Qiang* means "truly." Suppose one’s virtue is pure and profound, one’s conduct truly steadfast, one’s reputation fragrant and renowned, and one does not contend with others—yet the ruler of Wei, by nature stubborn and foolish, cruel and lacking discernment, neither grasps Yan Hui’s qi nor recognizes his intent to rectify. To forcefully present the language of benevolence and righteousness, the inked line of the carpenter’s square, before such a violent ruler is to impose one’s beauty where others despise it.

**[Annotation]** To offer a night-shining pearl to another is rarely met without a hand on the sword, for they do not comprehend it. Yan Hui’s virtue and trustworthiness, along with his reputation free of contention, are things the ruler of Wei does not grasp. To forcefully apply the measuring line of the Seven Virtues to him would lead him to believe that Yan Hui seeks to destroy others to establish himself. Thus, the perfected person does not exert their will to order the world but responds to things with an empty mind. Sincerity and trustworthiness manifest in heaven and earth; non-contention flows freely among the myriad things. Only then do the myriad things return to embrace them, heaven and earth do not oppose them, their virtuous voice issues forth and the world resonates in harmony, their illustrious conduct shines and the six directions all respond. Only then can one endure cold and heat, traverse order and chaos, without ever encountering the reverse scales.

**[Subcommentary]** The language of the carpenter’s square refers to the sagely wisdom of the Five Virtues. The ruler of Wei does not grasp Yan Hui’s inner virtue, yet he forcefully deploys the conduct of benevolence and righteousness before a violent ruler. The fine words of former kings he presents will only incur the ruler’s resentment and aversion—thus, it cannot be done. This is called "the old man." Where there is an old man, people will surely turn against the shoots.

**[Annotation]** If one’s words are not trusted and received, others will assume they are contending for fame and thus turn to harm them.

**[Subcommentary]** *Ming* means "to name." The ruler of Wei does not grasp your heart and will assume you seek to harm him. Once suspicion arises, you will be met with opposition and harm. You would be perilously close to becoming a target for others. Moreover, if one merely delights in the worthy and despises the unworthy, what need is there to seek something different?

**[Annotation]** If one can delight in the worthy and despise the foolish, heeding righteousness and submitting to it, then one is already a enlightened ruler. If one is an enlightened ruler, then one does not need worthy ministers—your going would not be particularly remarkable. If this is not the case, going would only bring harm. Thus, to go with intention is to find no path that is viable; to respond without intention is to have blessings come of their own accord—then there is no path that is not viable.

**[Subcommentary]** *Dai* means "near"; *fu* means "to deceive." If you go to Wei, you will be near peril and destruction, harmed by the violent ruler—this is deeply deceptive. Moreover, if the ruler of Wei could delight in worthy men and despise the unworthy, then his court would be filled with gentlemen, petty men would be cast aside, and he would already have loyal ministers—what need would he have for you? In going to him, how would you be different from others? Since you would be no different, your departure would be of no benefit. If you remain utterly silent, the king and duke will surely exploit their position to vie for victory.

**[Annotation]** You must remain utterly silent; if you speak, the king and duke will exploit their lordly authority to compete for victory, using clever words to adorn their wrongdoing.

**[Subcommentary]** *Zhao* means "speech." *Wang gong* refers to the ruler of Wei. If you go to Wei, you should remain silent; if you offer admonitions, you will suffer humiliation. Moreover, the ruler of Wei relies on the power of a thousand chariots and the might of the five ranks, adorning his wrongs and rejecting remonstrance, sharpening his cleverness and eloquence. Overcome with fear, how would you have the leisure to rectify him? His eyes will be dazzled,

**[Annotation]** His words are so clever and quick that they dazzle the eyes.

**[Subcommentary]** *Ying* means "to dazzle." Though the ruler of Wei is dissolute and violent, he is exceedingly clever and eloquent. Relying on the authority of a ruler, he oppresses and tramples loyal remonstrators, so that Yan Hui’s heart fills with terror and his eyes become dazzled. His countenance will be leveled,

**[Annotation]** He will no longer be able to distinguish himself from others.

Though one may have a refined heart, one dare not display distinction, and one’s countenance becomes meek and compliant, harmonizing with the other in peace.

The mouth will be occupied with self-preservation,
**[Annotation]** There is no leisure for self-explanation.
**[Subcommentary]** As the lord of Wei holds high rank and awe-inspiring majesty, Yan fears disaster may befall him and is beset by a hundred anxieties. Thus, his tongue is wholly engaged in self-preservation, leaving no moment of respite.

The bearing will manifest compliance,
**[Subcommentary]** *Xing* means "to appear." Fearing calamity, he yields in outward submission, striking his cheeks and bending his fists, his form and demeanor revealing such compliance.

The heart will even come to embrace it.
**[Annotation]** He will then set aside his own convictions to follow the other.
**[Subcommentary]** Not only does his outward form comply, but his inner heart also aligns, unable to advance goodness and instead furthering the other’s wrongdoing. Thus, it is like using fire to fight fire, or water to fight water—what is called "increasing the excess."

**[Annotation]** Such efforts fail to remedy the situation and instead only serve to amplify the other’s dominance.
**[Subcommentary]** *Yi* means "to employ." Employing fire to fight fire only intensifies the blaze; employing water to fight water only worsens the waves. Thus, Yanzi’s conduct merely abets the lord of Wei’s tyranny, failing to correct or admonish him—truly an "increase of excess." Compliance at the outset knows no end,

**[Annotation]** Clinging to the usual and refusing to change.
If, in peril, one offers earnest words without first establishing trust, one will surely die before the violent ruler.
**[Annotation]** Without trust, even earnestness brings harm.
**[Subcommentary]** Your earnest and sincere counsel, if not first trusted, will—though offered with utmost loyalty—only result in execution before the brutal ruler. Moreover, in ancient times, Jie killed Guan Longfeng, and Zhou killed Prince Bigan. Both were men who cultivated their conduct to serve the people beneath the pivot of governance, yet they defied their superiors.

**[Annotation]** Taking on the ruler’s burdens while below—Bigan’s case was not his proper duty.

The *yù* method: a ruler who slays many people and plunders the people is called Jie; one who ruins righteousness and harms goodness is called Zhou. Guan was his surname, Longfeng his courtesy name—a worthy minister of Jie of Xia, who, though utterly sincere, met with beheading. Bigan, a paternal uncle of Zhou of Yin, who remonstrated in loyalty, had his heart cut out. *Yǎnbàn* means to nurture and foster. *Fú* means to defy or oppose.

These two men, both excellent ministers of ancient times, cultivated and adorned their persons, practiced loyalty and integrity in secret, and from their position as subjects, took on the burdens of the ruler’s people. Though the ministers possessed virtue, the rulers were without the Way; defying their rulers, both suffered execution and disgrace. Citing the past to prove the present, they serve as a mirror and warning. From this, we know that Yan Hui’s attempt to transform Wei could not succeed. Thus, its ruler, seizing upon their cultivation, cast them aside—these were men who coveted reputation.

**[Annotation]** He did not wish for his ministers to gain a reputation surpassing his own.

**[Subcommentary]** *Jǐ* means to cast down, to ensnare, to poison. Jie of Xia and Zhou of Yin, rulers without the Way, failed to measure themselves and still demanded praise and renown. Thus, they seized upon the cultivation of worthy ministers and wantonly poisoned them. Their intent lay in contending for fame and profit, and so they came to this end.

In ancient times, Yao attacked Congzhi and Xu’ao, and Yu attacked Youhu. Their states became desolate ruins, their persons met with execution and punishment. Their use of arms did not cease, their pursuit of substance knew no end. These were all men who sought fame and substance—have you alone not heard of this?

**[Annotation]** Brutal rulers not only seek to indulge their desires but also pursue fame; it is only that what they seek is not by the proper Way.

**[Subcommentary]** The two rulers Yao and Yu have already been explained above. Congzhi, Xu’ao, and Youhu are all names of states. Youhu is present-day Huo County in Yongzhou. A dwelling without people is called a ruin; a ghost without descendants is called a wraith. These three rulers were all without the Way, fond of waging war and invading other states. Not only did they demand substantial profit, but they also sought empty fame, so that their territories became barren wastes, their people exterminated, their persons met with execution, and their ancestral temples overthrown. The pursuit of fame and substance led to this extremity—this is known to all, past and present; have you alone not heard of it?

Fame and substance are things even the sages cannot overcome—how much less can one such as you?

**[Annotation]** Rulers who crave reputation and indulge their desires, even if they were Yao or Yu, could not be transformed; thus, they assembled armies to attack them. How then could you, Yanzi, go empty-handed to transform them with the Way?

**[Subcommentary]** Ordinary men and violent kings, who demand profit and seek fame, even the sage-kings Yao and Yu could not win over with virtue and instead raised armies to punish their crimes and eliminate their evil. How much less could Yanzi, a common man, go empty-handed to transform them? There is no doubt that this is impossible.

Nevertheless, if you must have some means, try telling it to me.

**[Subcommentary]** *Cháng* means to attempt. Though your transformative guidance may not yet be expansive, since you wish to go, you must have some basis. Try setting forth your intent and telling it to me.

Yan Hui said: Upright yet empty—

**[Annotation]** To rectify one’s form and empty one’s mind.

**[Subcommentary]** To rectify one’s form is to fulfill the reverence of a subject; to empty one’s mind and thoughts is to exhaust the sincerity of remediation.

Having received your lofty command, how dare I be confused about the means?

Earnest and single-minded—

**[Annotation]** To be yielding yet unwavering.

**[Subcommentary]** To exert one’s body and mind, to devote oneself wholly to the state, to speak and act with loyalty and sincerity, never deviating in the slightest.

—would this suffice?

**[Subcommentary]** Following these two principles, could this be put into practice or not?

The Master said: How could it? How could it suffice?

**[Annotation]** This means it is not yet sufficient.

**[Subcommentary]** *Wū è* means "in what way." In what way could it suffice? It means it is not yet sufficient.

For one whose yang is full to the utmost and widely displayed—

**[Annotation]** The ruler of Wei’s overbearing yang nature is replete within and greatly manifested without—this is the height of strength and arrogance.

**[Subcommentary]** *Yáng* means firm and fierce. *Chōng* means full; *kǒng*, extreme. The ruler of Wei’s firm and fierce nature fills his heart, and his violence is extreme, manifesting outwardly.

Whose colors are unsettled—

**[Annotation]** His joy and anger are without constancy.

**[Subcommentary]** When things go his way, he is pleased; when they do not, he rages. His spirit, countenance, and qi show no fixed standard.

Such a one as even ordinary people dare not oppose—

**[Annotation]** None dare go against him.

**[Subcommentary]** His nature is violent and cruel, his might and ferocity constant. Even skilled knights and worthy men cannot oppose him.

And who, seizing upon what moves others, seeks to indulge his own heart—

**[Annotation]** One so stubborn and overbearing that when others move him with pleasing matters, he tramples and humiliates them, seeking ease and self-indulgence to satisfy his extravagant desires.

**[Subcommentary]** *Àn* means to suppress. *Róngyǔ* means to be unrestrained. When others move him with good and pleasing remonstrances, the ruler seizes upon their loyal admonitions and suppresses them, seeking pleasure and indulgence to satisfy his dissolute and reckless intentions.

Is said to be one whose daily accumulating virtue does not take shape—how much less could great virtue do so?

**[Annotation]** This means that even a little is too much; there is no way to make him yield.

**[Subcommentary]** The Marquis of Wei has been without the Way for a long time. Even the virtue that accumulates day by day cannot take shape—how much less could the vast and luminous standards of the sage be hoped for?

He will cling to his ways and not be transformed—

**[Annotation]** Thus, he holds to his original intent.

**[Subcommentary]** He adorns his wrongs and agrees with his lord, cannot follow others like flowing water, clings to his original mind—who would change from evil to good?

Outwardly compliant yet inwardly uncritical—how could this possibly suffice?

**[Annotation]** Outwardly compliant yet inwardly uncritical is just what was meant earlier by "upright yet empty" and "earnest and single-minded." This is insufficient to transform him.

**[Subcommentary]** Outwardly, he bows and scrapes to fulfill utmost reverence; inwardly, he submits without daring to criticize.

To propose this for practice—what benefit could there be? The Way of transforming Wei—how could it possibly be spoken of? This is but to reject the earlier "upright yet empty" Wei as unfit for implementation.

Yet if I am inwardly straight but outwardly bent, achieving and ascending to comparison—

**[Annotation]** Yan Hui further speaks of these three principles.

**[Subcommentary]** Having been reproved for the two matters previously set forth, he now offers three principles, hoping they may prove fitting. Here he states the topics; below, he explains their meaning—this is Yan Hui, deluded about himself, questioning Confucius.

"Inwardly straight" means to follow Heaven as one’s companion. To follow Heaven as one’s companion is to know that the Son of Heaven and oneself are both children of Heaven. Should one alone take one’s words as kindling for others’ approval when they are good, or as kindling when they are not?

**[Annotation]** All things, noble or base, share the same source of life. Thus, whether good or not good, one entrusts them to impartial judgment—seeking nothing from others.

**[Subcommentary]** Below, he explains the meaning. 析 means "to seek."

"To say 'inwardly straight' is to maintain a plain and honest heart, joining with the natural principle as one’s kindred. Knowing that the emperor and I both receive our nature from Heaven, one can forget distinctions of noble and base between ruler and subject, dismiss considerations of good and evil in honor and disgrace, and refrain from priding oneself on avoiding wrong or seeking goodness in others. This is emptiness of mind, and it may accord with principle. If so, others will call one a child—this is what it means to join with Heaven as one’s kindred.

**[Annotation]** Following Heaven’s principle, one extends one’s nature and destiny like an infant’s straightforward advance.

**[Subcommentary]** *Ran* means "in this way." *Tongzi* means "infant." If, as described, one extends principle and advances directly, acting like an infant, one is called a child. This completes the previous meaning, and so it is called joining with Heaven as one’s kindred.

"To be 'outwardly compliant' is to join with others as one’s kindred. Raising the chin and bending the fists—these are the rites of a minister. Everyone does them; how dare I not? To do what others do is to incur no fault from them.

**[Subcommentary]** To bend one’s outward form and follow the ways of the world is to join with human relationships as one’s kindred. Raising the hands, touching the chin, bending the knees, bowing the body, lowering and lifting in obeisance—these are the rites of a minister. Yet to harmonize with the dust and grime, adapting to the rise and fall of things, is what everyone does; how could I alone refuse? Thus, doing what others do, one incurs no resentment or blame. This is what it means to join with others as one’s kindred.

**[Annotation]** Outwardly bending one’s form, one follows what human affairs require.

**[Subcommentary]** This completes the above.

"To 'achieve and compare above' is to join with the ancients as one’s kindred.

**[Annotation]** Achieving in the present and comparing with the ancients.

**[Subcommentary]** The affairs of loyal remonstrance are achieved in the present, while the principle of ruler and minister is compared with the ancients. Thus, one joins with the loyal ministers of antiquity, such as Bi Gan and others—this is its meaning. Though one’s words may instruct, they contain reproof in reality.

**[Annotation]** Though it is common instruction, it truly carries the intent of admonition.

**[Subcommentary]** *Zhe* means "reproof." The words of warning, though appearing as instruction, in their intent truly contain a heart of admonition. This has existed since ancient times; it is not something I alone have initiated today. If so, though one is straightforward, one will not be harmed.

**[Annotation]** Entrusting straightness to the ancients, there is nothing by which to harm me.

**[Subcommentary]** If the way of loyal remonstrance has existed since antiquity, and I am now sincere and straightforward, I may also be fortunate enough to avoid trouble. This is what it means to join with the ancients as one’s kindred.

**[Subcommentary]** This completes the previous point.

"Is this acceptable?"

**[Subcommentary]** Presenting these three principles, one does not yet know whether they are acceptable.

Confucius said: "Alas, how can it be? Too much governance, with laws but no coherence.

**[Annotation]** When principle admits no duality, yet one imposes three principles to govern, it does not merge with the matter.

**[Subcommentary]** *Die* means "coherence," "accord." If laws accord with principle, one need not multiply them; to impose three principles is excessively cumbersome. It does not accord with principle and brings no peace or ease—how could it be acceptable? Yet, though rigid, it is also without fault.

**[Annotation]** Though not grand, it also incurs no blame.

**[Subcommentary]** Proposing these three principles, though crude, since they have not yet been put into practice, one may also be fortunate enough to avoid blame. Nevertheless, this is all it is; how can it reach transformation?

**[Annotation]** There is no fault, but there is also no transformation.

**[Subcommentary]** *Hu* means "how." Yan Hui’s transformation of Wei consists only of these methods, sufficient for self-cultivation but not for saving the age—how can it reach transformation? Another explanation: If one stops and does not act, it may accord with principle, but if one goes to Wei, one will surely encounter danger. It is still to follow one’s own mind.

**[Annotation]** Carrying three principles to that place is not to be without mind and entrust it to the world.

**[Subcommentary]** The sage empties himself, responding to the times without mind, like a bright mirror or an empty valley. Now Yan Hui prepares teachings in advance, deliberating whether they may be acceptable—since he is not yet indifferent and detached, it is clear he follows his own mind.

Yan Hui said: "I have nothing further to advance. I venture to ask for its method."

**[Subcommentary]** Yan Hui’s three courses were exhausted in a single morning. The way to transform Wei admits no further advance; he asks the sage teacher, hoping to hear the wondrous method.

Confucius said: "Fast! I will tell you. To have and act upon it—is that easy?

**[Annotation]** To have the mind and act upon it is truly not easy.

**[Subcommentary]** Yan Hui earnestly requests, and the Master speaks of the fasting of the mind. If one can empty and forget, I will tell you. But to have the mind and seek the mysterious Dao is truly not easy.

"To consider it easy is not fitting for the vast sky.

**[Annotation]** To take having and acting as easy is not seen as fitting.

**[Subcommentary]** The *Erya* says: In summer, the sky is *haotian*. It speaks of its vast and expansive qi. To act with the mind of having and consider the Dao easy is not fitting under the vast sky. It is not fitting to have the mind in the fasting of the mind."

Yan Hui said: "My family is poor. For months now, I have not drunk wine or eaten meat. If this is so, can it be considered fasting?"

**[Subcommentary]** *Ru* means "to eat." *Hun* means "pungent vegetables." *Zhai* means "to fast," signifying that both mind and conduct are unstained by the dust of others. Yan Hui’s family is poor; the Confucian histories record this clearly. Without wine to drink or meat to eat, subsisting on a bamboo basket of grain and a gourd of vegetables, this has gone on for months. He asks whether this can be considered fasting.

Confucius said: "This is the fasting for sacrifice, not the fasting of the mind."

The Master [Confucius] replied: "This is the fasting for offering sacrifices to spirits and ancestors, the method of purification practiced among the common folk—it is not what is meant by the fasting of the mind."

Yan Hui said: "May I ask about the fasting of the mind?"

**[Subcommentary]** Earlier, he spoke of his family’s poverty, which required him to perform sacrificial rites. Now he asks for instruction in the method of the fasting of the mind.

Zhongni [Confucius] said: "Unify your will.
**[Annotation]** Abandon all distractions and rely solely on the singular.
**[Subcommentary]** Unify your mind and will, leaving no room for distractions. Enter stillness and emptiness, forgetting all, and obscurely align with solitary transformation. What follows is the Master’s answer to Yan Hui, broadly expounding the method of the fasting of the mind.

Do not listen with the ears but listen with the mind.
**[Subcommentary]** Let the ear-root remain empty and still, not clinging to sounds. Turn inward to listen to the soundless, concentrating the spirit in the mind’s abode.

Do not listen with the mind but listen with qi.
**[Subcommentary]** The mind possesses awareness, which still gives rise to conditions; qi is without thought or deliberation, empty and yielding, responsive to things. Thus, abandon the mind’s awareness and embrace this emptiness and yielding. Through repeated relinquishment, one gradually ascends to the mysterious and wondrous.

Listening stops at the ears.
**[Subcommentary]** Not clinging to the dust of sound, listening ceases at the mind. This explains "do not listen with the ears."

The mind stops at alignment.
**[Subcommentary]** *Fu* means "to align." When the mind arises in conditions, it must align with external objects. Strive to make it still and empty, so it no longer aligns with external things. This explains "do not listen with the mind."

Qi is that which is empty and awaits things.
**[Annotation]** Abandon the ears and eyes, discard the mind’s intentions, and entrust oneself to the self-attainment of qi’s nature—this is emptiness awaiting things.
**[Subcommentary]** Like qi, which is soft, weak, and empty, the mind must be still and forgetful to respond to things. This explains "listen with qi."

Only the Dao gathers in emptiness. Emptiness is the fasting of the mind.
**[Annotation]** Empty the mind, and the supreme Dao will gather within.
**[Subcommentary]** Only the true Dao gathers in the empty mind. Thus, the empty mind is the wondrous Dao of the fasting of the mind.

Yan Hui said: "Before I received this teaching, I was truly myself, Yan Hui.
**[Annotation]** Without the fasting of the mind, one remains attached to the self.
**[Subcommentary]** Without examining the teaching of the fasting of the mind, one still harbors a bounded and obstructed mind. Unable to break the body and forget the self, one still regards Yan Hui as truly existing.

Now that I have received this teaching, there has never been a Yan Hui.
**[Annotation]** Having received the teaching of the fasting of the mind, one is without self.
**[Subcommentary]** Having received the Master’s teaching and been guided to empty the mind, one can thoroughly forget both self and others, so that there has never been a Yan Hui.

Can this be called emptiness?"
The Master said: "It is complete."

"I tell you: You may enter and wander within its bounds, but do not be moved by its name.
**[Annotation]** The realm where the mind is released and self-attained—one should rest in reality.
**[Subcommentary]** The Master speaks of the essentials of transformation and spiritual wandering. Be cautious not to grasp its pivot. Rather, wander within its bounds, concealing your traces and silencing your name, so as not to be moved by fame or wisdom. *Fan* means "bounds."

If you enter, then sing; if you do not enter, then stop.
**[Annotation]** Like the notes of music, response arises without intention—this is called "singing." To respond without intention is to follow the other, not to force a response.
**[Subcommentary]** If your counsel is heeded by the ruler, then you may sing to guide and save him. If your advice is not received, then seal your lips and forget words. To insist on displaying loyalty and integrity will surely invite disaster.

No gate, no governance.
**[Annotation]** Let things be as they are—this is "no gate." Entrust the world to its natural peace—this is "no governance." *Du* means "to govern."
**[Subcommentary]** *Du* means "to govern." Like water or a mirror, respond with an empty mind, not acting in advance.

Dwell in the one and lodge in the inevitable.
**[Annotation]** The inevitable is what is necessarily so in principle. Abide in the dwelling of utmost oneness and meet the alignment of necessity.
**[Subcommentary]** *Zhai* means "dwelling." Abide in the Dao of utmost oneness, responding without ceasing, where stimulus and response obscurely align, without prior calculation.

Then you are near.
**[Annotation]** The principle is exhausted here.
**[Subcommentary]** *Ji* means "near exhaustion." The principle of responding to things is exhausted here.

To sever nearness is easy; to walk without treading the earth is difficult.
**[Annotation]** Not acting is easy; to act without treading the earth is impossible. Non-action is easy; to act without harming one’s nature is unattainable.
**[Subcommentary]** To sit still and sever all paths is not difficult in principle; to walk without treading the earth is thus not easy. Likewise, non-action and emptiness make response easy; deliberate action and thought make engagement with things difficult. The principle is clear, and thus this analogy is apt.

To be employed by man is easy to deceive; to be employed by Heaven is difficult to deceive.
**[Annotation]** What the eyes and ears perceive is coarse, so it is easy to deceive. The response of the natural is subtle, so it is difficult to deceive. Those who lose little of the real lose little of their wholeness; those who lose much of the real lose much of their wholeness. The recompense for loss and gain has never failed to match its measure. To attempt to defy Heaven and act falsely—is this not delusion?
**[Subcommentary]** Human emotions and employments are shallow and superficial, so they are easy to deceive. The natural order’s governance is profound and subtle, so it is difficult to falsify. Thus, in human affairs, one must follow one’s nature and act with sincerity.

I have heard of flying with wings, but never of flying without wings. I have heard of knowing with knowledge, but never of knowing without knowledge.
**[Annotation]** Every undertaking requires its proper tools. Without the dwelling of utmost emptiness, there is no way to achieve the reality of transforming things."

**[Subcommentary]** Just as a bird without six feathers cannot soar through the void, so too can one without dual wisdom not engage with the world. Behold that emptiness: in a vacant chamber, whiteness arises.
**[Annotation]** To regard being as non-being—this is the vacant chamber. When the chamber is empty, pure whiteness alone emerges.

**[Subcommentary]** *Pān* means observation. *Bǐ* refers to the preceding realm. *Quē* means emptiness. Observing the ten thousand existences, all are empty and quiescent; thus one can exhaust the chamber of the heart, return the illumination to the true source, and wisdom and clarity arise in accordance with use. *White* is the Dao.

"Auspiciousness rests, rests."
**[Annotation]** That which auspiciousness gathers is utmost emptiness and utmost stillness.
**[Subcommentary]** *Jí* refers to felicitous and virtuous affairs. *Xiáng* refers to propitious omens. *Zhǐ* refers to the wisdom of concentration and stillness. Auspicious and virtuous fortune rests in the concentrated and still heart; the concentrated and still heart can likewise bring forth auspicious and virtuous responses.

"If one does not rest where one ought, this is called sitting in motion."
**[Annotation]** If one does not rest where one should, nor meet the ultimate, this is to respond as if seated while galloping without cease. Thus, before external enemies arrive, one is already exhausted within—how then can one transform things?
**[Subcommentary]** If one cannot make one’s form like withered wood and one’s heart like dead ashes, then though one’s demeanor may be upright and composed, the spirit gallops—this is called sitting in form while the heart races.

"When one follows the ears and eyes to communicate inwardly yet remains external to the heart’s knowing, spirits will come to dwell—how much more so humans?"
**[Annotation]** If one closes the ears and eyes to attain what comes naturally, the function of the heart’s knowing is externalized. Thus, if one fully entrusts to nature and communicates directly, there is nowhere one does not merge with the obscure. Even the reproach of ghosts and spirits is absent—how much more the burdens of the human realm?
**[Subcommentary]** *Xùn* means to cause. If one can make the senses communicate inwardly without being ensnared by external objects, and the spirit is tranquil while the will remains external to the heart’s knowing, then one externally abandons form and internally forgets wisdom. With the body collected and the senses subdued, the mind emptied to receive things, spirits obscurely attach and dwell—is this not fitting? Human relationships turn and look up in reverence, naturally submitting—this is as it should be.

Thus, the *Outer Chapters* say: "Without ghosts to reproach, there are no humans to criticize." This is the transformation of the ten thousand things, the pivot of Yu and Shun, the lifelong practice of Fuxi and Jihuang—how much more those who are scattered and ordinary?
**[Annotation]** There is no thing, noble or base, that does not rely on the heart’s knowing and the ears and eyes to communicate. Thus, what the world calls knowing—does one know in order to know? What it calls seeing—does one see in order to see? If knowing and seeing could be obtained by desire, then could one desire worthiness to become worthy, or act as a sage to become a sage? Certainly not. Yet the world does not know that knowing knows itself, and so desires to act as knowing to know; it does not see that seeing sees itself, and so desires to act as seeing to see. Not knowing that life lives itself, it would act to live. Thus, seeing the eyes, one seeks the brightness of Li Zhu; hearing the ears, one demands the acuity of Shi Kuang. The heart and spirit gallop within, the ears and eyes are exhausted without. The body is not at ease, and one does not merge with things. Not merging, how can one harmonize with the changes of the human realm or respond to the rhythms of the ages? There has never been such a case.

**[Subcommentary]** *Shì* is a demonstrative, a term of reference, pointing to the previous methods of fasting the heart. These can transform the ten thousand things and nurture all living beings. Fuxi, who tamed oxen and rode horses, was called Fuxi, surnamed Feng, and titled Tai Hao. *Jǐhuáng* refers to the sovereigns before the Three August Ones, who ruled without writing. This Way of fasting the heart was the guiding principle by which Yu and Shun responded to things, and Fuxi and Jihuang practiced it throughout their lives. How much more should the common and scattered people of the world follow this path if they wish to transform things?

When Ye Gong Zi Gao was about to be sent as an envoy to Qi, he asked Confucius: "The king’s charge to me is most weighty."
**[Annotation]** He considers the mission weighty, for he desires something.
**[Subcommentary]** The great-grandson of King Zhuang of Chu, Yin Chengzi, was named Zhu Liang, styled Zi Gao, and enfeoffed at Ye, where he usurped the title of Duke. The king—though in reality a viscount during the Spring and Autumn period—usurped the title of king. Qi was the descendant of the Grand Duke of the Jiang clan, whose ancestor was one of the Four Mountains of Yu. Some were enfeoffed at Lü, hence the Grand Duke was called Lü Wang. King Wu of Zhou enfeoffed the Grand Duke at Yingqiu, establishing the state of Qi. The two states of Qi and Chu maintained friendly relations, with envoys bearing gifts coming and going without cease. Sometimes they sought aid in emergencies, or requested troops to punish offenses. The matters were not trivial, and the trust placed in them was great. Thus, Zhu Liang was anxious and sought counsel from Confucius.

"The Qi envoys awaiting an audience are treated with great reverence but not urgency."
**[Annotation]** He fears that one may merely display reverence outwardly without promptly responding to their requests.
**[Subcommentary]** The Qi envoys came and went abruptly, without sincerity. When it came to receiving the Chu envoys, they were treated with great ceremony, but the matters they requested were not promptly granted. Given the weight of the mission, Zhu Liang harbored this concern.

"The charge is so weighty that I tremble."
**[Subcommentary]** Even a commoner’s resolve cannot be shaken—how much less a feudal lord? Considering this, he was greatly fearful and trembling.

"You once told me: 'In all affairs, whether great or small, few do not become fearful if not guided by the Dao.'"
**[Annotation]** In affairs, whether great or small, few do not become fearful if not guided by the Dao. This is what Confucius once told Zhu Liang.
**[Subcommentary]** *Zǐ* refers to Confucius.

The term *guǎ* ("few") signifies scarcity. Now, in managing the threads of affairs, the complexities are indeed manifold. Though matters may differ in scale, none do not find their fear and comfort in success. Thus, Zhu Liang invoked what he had once received to awaken later insight. If affairs do not succeed, there will surely be the peril of human norms.
**[Annotation]** Those who fear failure do so because failure invites wrath. This is something even the King of Chu cannot escape.
**[Subcommentary]** If emotions clash and affairs do not come to fruition, there will be the moral order of human relations and the anxiety of punishment.

If affairs succeed, there will surely be the peril of yin and yang.
**[Annotation]** Though the external vexation may depart, joy and fear still wage war in the breast, having already congealed ice and embers within the five viscera.
**[Subcommentary]** Joy expands the yang; sorrow contracts the yin. Once affairs succeed, the heart’s true feelings are satisfied, transforming past sorrow into present joy. Joy and fear intermingle in one heart, yin and yang clash fiercely in the five viscera—ice and embers gather, how can there be rest?

Only those with virtue can remain free from peril, whether affairs succeed or fail.
**[Annotation]** Only those with virtue can entrust success or failure to others without disturbance to the heart.
**[Subcommentary]** To remain unmoved in the spirit by gain or loss, to leave success or failure to the path ahead, and not to be burdened by sorrow or joy—this belongs only to those of great virtue.

"My meals consist of coarse fare, not refined; my kitchen has no one seeking coolness."
**[Annotation]** Facing the fire without thought of cold illustrates the frugality of his provisions.
**[Subcommentary]** *Zāng* means "refined"; *qīng* means "cool." Bearing a grave charge, his heart filled with dread, he partook of coarse sustenance, having no leisure for fine delicacies. His provisions were meager, and his kitchen staff did not wish to think of cold—yet the fire was not large, and there was no heat to avoid.

"Now, I receive my charge at court in the morning and drink ice by evening—is it inner heat that afflicts me?"
**[Annotation]** Though his provisions were meager, his inner heat drove him to drink ice, for he truly feared the difficulty of the task, not the allure of fine food.
**[Subcommentary]** Zhu Liang received his commission at dawn and drank ice by dusk, clearly showing his dread and sorrow, his inner heart scorched with anxiety. His earnest inquiry into the Dao illuminated this state of mind.

"I have not yet reached the truth of the matter, yet I already suffer the peril of yin and yang. If the affair does not succeed, there will surely be the peril of human norms. These are the two anxieties."
**[Annotation]** Before the affair is settled, one only fears it will not succeed. If it truly fails, fear will lodge within while the net of punishment ensnares without.
**[Subcommentary]** When the outcome of a matter is undecided and success or failure unknown, yet sorrow and joy already reside in the heart—this is the peril of yin and yang. If affairs go awry and do not come to fruition, there will be the Way of the minister and the reach of the penal net. With these two anxieties, where can one escape fault?

"As a minister, I am unworthy of this task. You must have something to tell me."
**[Subcommentary]** Unworthy as a minister, overstepping my station, my position is high but my virtue shallow—I am unfit for this task. Since you are a sage, your nature encompasses all things, and you have the means—pray, enlighten me."

Confucius said: "Under heaven, there are two great precepts: the first is fate; the second is righteousness."
**[Subcommentary]** *Jiè* means "precept." Within the realm, teachings and laws are myriad, but none are more essential than these two. Their meanings are elaborated below.

"Your love for your parents is fate—it cannot be untied from the heart."
**[Annotation]** Naturally bound and fixed, it cannot be untied.
**[Subcommentary]** The filial son serves his parents with utmost love and respect. This nature and fate arise from heaven, following the heart’s true course—thus it cannot be untied.

"A minister’s service to his lord is righteousness—there is no place under heaven where one is not the lord’s subject, nowhere to escape within the bounds of heaven and earth."
**[Annotation]** When a thousand gather, if not one is master, disorder leads to dissolution. Thus, many worthy men cannot mean many lords, and no worthy men cannot mean no lord—this is the Way of heaven and man, the utmost propriety.
**[Subcommentary]** The principle of lord and minister is inherently so. Thus, the loyal minister serves his lord, dying to fulfill his duty—this is the convergence of duty, not a matter of heavenly nature. Yet though the six directions are vast, there is no lordless state. If one bears guilt, where can one escape fault? Thus, one accepts the charge and departs, without hesitation in advance or retreat.

These are called the great precepts.
**[Annotation]** If the lord could be escaped and parents untied, they would not be precepts.
**[Subcommentary]** This concludes the meaning of the great precepts regarding lord and parent.

"Thus, one who serves his parents does not choose a place to settle them—this is the utmost filial piety."
**[Subcommentary]** The filial son, in serving his parents, seeks only their comfort. Whether seeking office or emolument, he does not choose high or low, finding contentment wherever he is—this is true utmost filial piety.

"One who serves his lord does not choose his tasks to settle in them—this is the height of loyalty."
**[Subcommentary]** The loyal minister serves his lord with unwavering devotion, undeterred by peril or ease, accepting his lot as fate. How can he pick and choose between advantage and harm before acting? One who can do so is the paragon of loyal ministers.

"One who serves his own heart does not alter joy or sorrow before events—knowing the inevitable and accepting it as fate, this is the utmost virtue."
**[Annotation]** Knowing the inevitable is fate and accepting it, there is neither sorrow nor joy—how can one alter or impose them? Thus, obscurely taking what one encounters as fate and not engaging the heart in its midst, merging indistinguishably with what is most fitting and having no joy or sorrow within—though serving others, one is ever at ease, let alone with lord or parent.
**[Subcommentary]** The man of the Dao who settles his own heart and mind perceives no difference between adversity and prosperity, understanding that gain and loss are one. Thus, he traverses the realms of sorrow and joy without altering his course, knowing that success and failure are inevitable—how can human sentiment control them?

Thus, to settle the heart and follow fate without contravening the principles of Heaven—unless one is a perfected person of profound virtue, who could equal this? For those who serve as ministers or children, there are inevitably circumstances beyond their control. In acting according to the circumstances while forgetting the self,

**[Annotation]** Affairs have their inevitable course, and principle is inherently constant. Thus, yielding to them brings order to affairs, and when affairs are ordered, the self is never lost—why then trouble the heart over the existence of the self?

**[Subcommentary]** When ministers and children serve their lords and parents, they must inevitably give their lives and exhaust their sincerity. When affairs arise, they act without hesitation or choice, forgetting the self to attend to duty—this is only fitting. If it cannot be avoided, one must submit to fate. How could there be leisure to delight in life and shrink from death? In this, the Master’s conduct is exemplary.

**[Annotation]** Principle admits of no obstruction, so one should simply proceed directly with what one encounters. If one’s commitment to the Dao is not steadfast and delight or aversion remain in the heart, if one cannot advance together with what is most fitting while scheming for life and fearing death, one will never see one’s affairs brought to completion.

**[Subcommentary]** Since one is acting on behalf of others, there is no room for delight or aversion. Receiving the lord’s command, one must only act with equanimity—how could there be time to scheme for life and fear death?

Confucius then requested to add what he had heard: In all dealings, when close, one must yield to one another in good faith,

**[Annotation]** Those who are near can interact directly, so their trust is verified by mutual yielding and submission.

when distant, one must be loyal in speech,

**[Annotation]** From afar, intentions are conveyed through words.

**[Subcommentary]** In interactions with those nearby, one yields in accordance with natural feeling; with those far away, one relies on words to express loyalty. This is Confucius citing what he has heard to admonish Zilu. Words must sometimes be transmitted.
