Now, transmitting words of mutual delight or mutual anger is the most difficult task under Heaven.

**[Annotation]** When words express delight or anger, if they exceed what is fitting, the transmitter must ensure neither side loses the mean—thus it is not easy.

**[Subcommentary]** Conveying intentions through messengers, sending someone to transmit them, with both sides sometimes pleased, sometimes angry—this is no easy task for the intermediary. For when both are pleased, there will surely be excessive praise; when both are angry, there will surely be excessive slander.

**[Annotation]** *Yi* (溢) means "to exceed." Words of delight or anger often exceed what is appropriate.

**[Subcommentary]** *Yi* means "to exceed." When two people mutually praise or revile, if they follow their emotions, their words of praise or blame will necessarily go too far.

All such excesses are false,

**[Annotation]** Suspecting the words are not truly theirs, it seems the transmitter has fabricated them.

**[Subcommentary]** *Lei* means "to resemble." Words that exceed what is fitting are not truly real; when the listener doubts them, it seems the messenger has falsely constructed them.

and when false, they are not trusted,

**[Annotation]** *Mo* means to be filled with doubt.

**[Subcommentary]** *Mo* describes a state of doubt. Since it seems the transmitter has fabricated them, distrust arises, and the listener is filled with doubt.

and when not trusted, the transmitter incurs misfortune.

**[Annotation]** Transmitting excessive words seems like fabrication. When the recipient doubts them, the transmitter is arbitrarily blamed for exaggerating or diminishing.

**[Subcommentary]** When the recipient grows doubtful and distrustful, misfortune befalls the messenger.

Thus, the *Fayan* says: Transmit the constant feelings, do not transmit excessive words, and you will be close to preservation.

**[Annotation]** Though you hear momentary excessive words, do not transmit them. You must convey the constant feelings and ensure their sincerity—then you will be close to preservation.

**[Subcommentary]** In dealing with others as an intermediary, the task is truly difficult. One must first examine the constant feelings and ensure the host and guest meet at the mean, not transmitting momentary delight or anger to cause discord in their words. One who can do this will be close to preserving themselves. The Master cites the model words of the former sages as a guide for future conduct.

Moreover, those who compete in skill and strength begin with yang—

**[Annotation]** Originally sharing playful delight.

—yet invariably end in yin—

**[Annotation]** As the desire to prevail intensifies, harm toward the other arises in secret.

**[Subcommentary]** Yang is joy; yin is anger. When testing strength in play, there is no lack of cunning. At first, the mood is one of lighthearted caution; but by the end, the heart breeds resentment and wrath, and the urge to dominate covertly gives rise to harm. Such is the way of joy and anger in the world—this example of competing in strength serves as an analogy.

When excess reaches its height, strange craft abounds—

**[Annotation]** No longer following reason.

**[Subcommentary]** When anger and the thirst for victory grow extreme, the mind overflows with cunning and deceit, a hundred stratagems unfolding.

Those who drink wine according to ritual begin with order—

**[Annotation]** Distinctions of honor and humility are observed, and toasts proceed in proper sequence.

—yet invariably end in chaos—

**[Annotation]** Drunkenness and indulgence run rampant.

**[Subcommentary]** Order is principle. When host and guest exchange cups, there is an inherent pattern; yet once caps are askew, hierarchy dissolves. All things begin in correctness and end in disorder—this example of drinking wine serves as an analogy.

When excess reaches its height, strange pleasures abound—

**[Annotation]** Dissipation and abandon know no bounds.

**[Subcommentary]** Once the feast grows wild, indulgence knows no limit: songs are sung again and again, dances spun without end, all restraint cast aside. In every way, the strange and extraordinary abound—how boundless the revelry!

In all matters, it is ever thus: they begin in sincerity and invariably end in baseness.

Its beginning is ever simple; its end must be vast.

**[Annotation]** For complexity arises from simplicity, and affairs begin in subtlety—this is the inevitable course of things.

**[Subcommentary]** Even in trifling matters and common affairs, it is ever thus: all things begin in sincerity and end in baseness; they start with small steps and conclude in great magnitude. Thus complexity arises from simplicity, and affairs begin in subtlety. This serves as a combined analogy.

Words are like wind and waves; actions bring true loss or gain.

**[Annotation]** Words are like wind and waves, and thus acting upon them leads to the loss of truth.

**[Subcommentary]** Just as water stirs into waves at the touch of wind, so too does the heart stir with joy or anger at the touch of words. Therefore, to act upon such wind-and-wave words is to lose hold of true principle. For wind and waves are easily stirred, and the loss of truth easily brings peril.

**[Annotation]** Thus, if one leaves wind and waves unacted upon, truth remains unlost. When affairs rest upon their true nature, peril may be stilled and turmoil settled.

**[Subcommentary]** Wind churns water into waves, making them easily agitated—just as words that stray from truth readily bring danger. Thus, anger arises without cause, through artful speech and biased words.

**[Annotation]** Anger arises from no other source; it is always born of artful words that exceed truth and biased speech that misses the mark.

**[Subcommentary]** The stirring of anger has no other cause—it is ever the result of false, artful words, biased speech, and flattering deceit.

When a beast is cornered, it does not choose its cries; its breath grows stifled, and from this, a fierce heart arises.

**[Annotation]** Like a wild beast driven into a corner, when its will is desperate and its strength spent, it does not utter harmonious sounds, nor does its breath flow smoothly. Instead, it bristles with sudden fury, and both beast and pursuer grow vicious in their confrontation.

**[Subcommentary]** When a wild beast is pressed into a desperate corner, its life hanging by a thread, it howls without regard for sound; its breath becomes stifled, its heart grows diseased, and in a sudden burst of rage, it lunges to bite its pursuer. This serves as another analogy.

When scrutiny becomes too exacting, unworthy thoughts inevitably arise in response—yet one remains unaware of it.

**[Annotation]** When one is broad and accommodating, others naturally gather. But when scrutiny becomes too precise, a stingy and petty heart arises without one’s awareness.

The great person lets things unfold freely in the realm of self-attainment, neither begrudging another’s ability nor exhausting another’s joy. Thus, the bonds of the four seas may be preserved whole.

**[Subcommentary]** When one presses too closely and exacts too much, unworthy thoughts naturally arise in response, for things follow their own principles. Thus, haste loses one’s lordly bearing, while generosity wins the multitude.

If one remains unaware of this, who can foresee where it will end?

**[Annotation]** If one does not perceive this, how can one know where fortune or misfortune will lead?

**[Subcommentary]** Impatience repels others, and such actions summon their own consequences—yet one remains unaware. If unworthy thoughts arise in response, who can foresee the calamity that may follow?

Thus, the *Fa Yan* says: Do not alter commands.

**[Annotation]** Transmit their true substance.

**[Subcommentary]** When carrying out a ruler’s command, convey its true meaning; do not alter it on a whim according to one’s own joy or anger.

Do not urge completion.

**[Annotation]** Let it come to fruition on its own.

**[Subcommentary]** State the ruler’s command plainly and let matters take their course; do not press or cajole to force its completion.

To exceed the proper measure is to add needlessly.

**[Annotation]** Adding is not to let things be as they are.

**[Subcommentary]** Abide by Heaven’s mandate, follow one’s nature, and act in accord with feeling—do not embellish with words beyond the original measure.

Altering commands and urging completion endanger affairs.

**[Annotation]** This brings affairs to peril.

**[Subcommentary]** To change a ruler’s command or force its completion is to place the matter in grave danger.

What is beautifully accomplished endures; what is badly accomplished cannot be undone.

**[Annotation]** Beautiful accomplishment comes from allowing things to transform in their own time—like planting, which cannot be rushed to fruition in a single morning.

**[Subcommentary]** What the heart deems beautiful comes to fulfillment naturally, without urging—thus it endures.

**[Annotation]** What one finds repugnant yet forces to completion will soon bring regret.

**[Subcommentary]** What the heart finds repugnant, if forced to completion, will not last long before remorse follows.

Can one not be cautious?

**[Subcommentary]** In navigating the world and carrying out commands, one should heed the cautionary words of the sages.

Moreover, to ride things with a wandering heart,

**[Annotation]** To entrust one’s intent to things.

**[Subcommentary]** The one who embodies solitary transformation moves freely among people, riding things with a wandering heart and following the world with an empty mind—what peril could there be?

To entrust oneself to what cannot be otherwise in nurturing the center—this is perfection.

**[Annotation]** To follow what is inevitably so is to fully embody the mark of the mean; this is the highest way of engaging with things.

**[Subcommentary]** What cannot be otherwise is the inevitable course of principle. To entrust oneself to such inevitability in nurturing the center is to reach the ultimate truth and the most wondrous way of responding to things.

What need is there to contrive a response?

**[Annotation]** One should simply follow the true nature of what is to be repaid—why contrive intentions in the matter?

**[Subcommentary]** Follow one’s own nature, act in accord with principle—why preemptively devise calculations to contrive a response?

It is better to deliver the command faithfully. This is the difficult part.

**[Annotation]** To deliver the command directly is easiest, yet one’s own joy and anger intervene in the heart—this is why it is difficult.

**[Subcommentary]** To deliver directly, following one’s nature and entrusting to Heaven’s command, is simplicity itself—how could it be difficult? Yet when it speaks of "this being the difficult part," it means that it is not truly difficult.

When Yan He was about to become tutor to the crown prince of Duke Ling of Wei,
**[Subcommentary]** His surname was Yan, given name He, a worthy man of Lu. The crown prince was cruel and harsh. Yan He traveled from Lu to Wei, intending to serve as the prince’s tutor.

he asked Lian Boyu:
**[Subcommentary]** His surname was Lian, given name Huan, courtesy name Boyu, a worthy minister of Wei. The prince’s virtue was as harsh as Heaven’s wrath, delighting in slaughter. Since he was a man of Wei, the text says, "There is a man here." As he was to become tutor to the heir apparent, he sought counsel from this wise man.

"If I deal with him without method, I endanger the state; if I deal with him by method, I endanger myself."
**[Annotation]** The nature of petty men is such that if you guide them by rules, they resent you; if you indulge them without restraint, they throw the state into chaos.
**[Subcommentary]** *Fang* means "method." His nature was fierce and stubborn, devoid of benevolence and righteousness. If you imposed methods upon him, his resentment would endanger you; if you indulged him without restraint, his excesses would ruin the state.

"His knowledge suffices only to perceive others’ faults, not the cause of those faults."
**[Annotation]** He does not recognize that the people’s faults arise from himself, so he blames the people and does not reform.
**[Subcommentary]** With no virtue of his own to reform, he metes out extreme punishments for the people’s crimes. He sees only the commoners’ transgressions, not that the faults originate in himself. Since he knows that, like wind bending grass, blame lies with the ruler, what then is to be done?

Lian Boyu said: "Excellent question! Be on guard, be cautious, and rectify yourself first.
**[Annotation]** To repeatedly reflect and adjust is how one rectifies the self.
**[Subcommentary]** *Jie* means "to warn." One must not act carelessly. Be vigilant in guiding the crown prince, avoid provoking him, walk the upright path, and adapt to circumstances. First, praise his ability to ask; later, show him the method.

In form, do not oppose; in heart, do not resist.
**[Annotation]** In form, do not act contrary; in heart, harmonize without conformity.
**[Subcommentary]** In conduct, follow and do not violate the rites of ruler and minister. In wisdom, harmonize and blend, adapting to all matters.

Yet these two have their limits.
**[Subcommentary]** The two methods above are but rough outlines. They are not yet perfect, for they still entail encumbrances.

Do not let form lead to compliance,
**[Annotation]** *Jiu* means "to follow in form"; *ru* means "to fully conform."
**[Subcommentary]** As Guo’s commentary says: *Jiu* means "to follow in form"; *ru* means "to fully conform."

nor let harmony lead to display.
**[Annotation]** *He* means "to aid with righteousness"; *chu* means "to show off one’s merits."
**[Subcommentary]** In heart, harmonize and guide with skillful means, attributing success to the crown prince without displaying one’s own ability—this is not "display."

If form follows and fully complies, you will fall, perish, collapse, or stumble.
**[Annotation]** If you fully conform, you fail to support what is endangered, perishing with him. Thus, one should model oneself on Heaven and Earth, differing only in minor ways.
**[Subcommentary]** *Dian* means "to overturn"; *mie*, "to extinguish"; *beng*, "to crumble"; *jue*, "to fail." If in form you follow and fully conform to his evil, you fail to support what is endangered, so that the state will be overthrown, extinguished, crumbled to dust, and ruined along with him.

If the heart harmonizes and displays itself, you will become a reputation, a name, an omen, a calamity.
**[Annotation]** If you display yourself, you will incur the reputation of bearing shame. If you aid his wrongdoing, he will resent your superiority and falsely accuse you of harboring evil.
**[Subcommentary]** To turn against things is to become an omen. *Nie* means "disaster." Though you harmonize and blend like dust, if you display your wisdom and fail to conceal your brilliance, you will gain a reputation for equaling him. He will resent your superiority and falsely accuse you of harboring evil, seeking to harm you through schemes.

If he acts like an infant, act like an infant with him; if he acts without boundaries, act without boundaries with him; if he acts without limits, act without limits with him. Guide him thus, and you will enter without flaw.
**[Annotation]** Do not set up minor distinctions to provoke his scales.
**[Subcommentary]** *Ding* means "to evaluate"; *qi*, "to divide"; *yu*, "to share." To engage with the world is inherently difficult. One cannot fully conform nor entirely oppose. Whether he acts like a foolish infant, or like a wild field without boundaries, or indulges in excessive demands and violent slaughter, guide him with virtue and align him with ritual. One who grasps this path enters the way without encumbrance.

Do you not know the mantis? It brandished its arms to block the chariot’s wheels, unaware that it was unequal to the task—yet this was the beauty of its ability.
**[Annotation]** The mantis’s brandishing of its arms is not without beauty; it is simply no match for the chariot’s wheels. Now, to know there is no alternative and still forcibly take on the task is like the mantis brandishing its arms.

**[Subcommentary]** The *tangluo* is an insect bearing axe-like forelegs. When the mantis raises its arms in fury to block the wheel-tracks of a grand chariot, though it relies on the beauty and excellence of its own ability, it still cannot fulfill its intended task. This is like Yan He, who sought to match his own talents against the power of the heir apparent—how is this different from the mantis raising its arms to block the chariot’s wheels? Be warned, be cautious. To accumulate and boast of your own abilities in order to challenge such a one is perilous indeed.

**[Annotation]** To amass your talents and vaunt your own excellence in order to provoke this man is a path to danger.

**[Subcommentary]** *Ji* means "to store up"; *er* means "you"; *ji* means "danger." Having become tutor to the heir apparent, you ought to be vigilant. Yet now you hoard your talents, pride yourself on your own excellence, and provoke his authority—this will surely lead to your ruin.

Do you not know the man who rears tigers? He dares not feed it living creatures, for fear of its killing rage.

**[Annotation]** He fears that the act of killing will provoke its fury.

**[Subcommentary]** Do you understand the method of raising tigers? One must not offer living swine or sheep to a fierce beast, lest the act of killing stir its wrath. Nor does one dare give it whole carcasses, for fear of its tearing rage.

**[Annotation]** If the tiger must gnaw and divide the meat itself, the effort will incite its fury.

**[Subcommentary]** Even when offering dead prey, one must first portion it out. If the tiger must tear it apart itself, the exertion may provoke its anger. One must time its hunger and satiety, and understand the causes of its rage.

**[Annotation]** To know what provokes its anger and act accordingly.

**[Subcommentary]** By knowing the rhythms of its hunger and fullness, and grasping the patterns of its joy and fury, one aligns with the principles of things—how could danger then arise? Though tigers and humans are of different kinds, the tiger fawns upon its keeper when treated with compliance. Thus, those it kills are those who act in opposition.

**[Annotation]** When one follows the natural order, even creatures of different kinds grow affectionate; when one violates it, even the closest kin turn to violence.

**[Subcommentary]** Compliance brings delight and tameness, so that even tigers and wolves may be domesticated. Opposition brings slaughter, so that even the closest kin take up arms against one another. The way of nurturing oneself is the same; the method of engaging with things is no different.

Now, the lover of horses uses a basket to collect its dung and a conch shell to gather its urine.

**[Annotation]** Dung and urine are the basest of things, yet he stores them in precious vessels—this is the height of love for his horse.

**[Subcommentary]** *Shen* refers to a large clam. The man who cherishes his horse’s dung does so out of a desire to honor it. Though excrement and urine are the basest of things, he uses a great clam to contain them, so bound is he by his attachment.

Then, when a swarm of mosquitoes or horseflies alight upon the horse,

**[Annotation]** They cluster upon the horse in great numbers.

and he strikes them at the wrong moment,

**[Annotation]** Though he means to relieve the horse’s distress, he startles it by acting unexpectedly.

the horse breaks its bit, shatters its bridle, and smashes its chest.

**[Annotation]** Caught off guard, the horse is so startled that it comes to this.

**[Subcommentary]** *Pu* means "to gather"; *pi* means "to strike"; *xian* means "the bit."

When mosquitoes and insects gather upon the horse, the master, cherishing it so deeply, impulsively strikes at them, intending to remove the harm. Yet lacking proper timing, he startles the horse unawares, causing it to bolt in sudden terror. Thus the horse snaps its bit, shatters its bridle, and tramples its master, crushing his chest and smashing his skull. Where attachment runs deepest, loss follows—can one not be cautious?

**[Annotation]** His intent was to relieve the horse’s distress, but acting rashly, he brought about destruction, losing the very object of his care. Thus in all worldly dealings, one must be mindful of the interplay between resistance and compliance.

**[Subcommentary]** *Loss* here means *forfeiture*. His attachment was fixed upon the horse, yet in destroying it, he lost what he loved. In human affairs, the same principle applies: when responses to circumstances are misaligned, disaster strikes. The lesson of the horse and its master demands the utmost care.

Carpenter Shi traveled to Qi and came to Qu Yuan, where he saw a *li* tree standing by the earth-altar.

**[Subcommentary]** *Zhi* means "to go." *Qu Yuan* is the name of a mountain, its paths winding like those west of Mount Song, where the road is called *Bao Yuan*—this is of the same kind. *Li* is the name of a tree; *she* is the earth deity. The altar is a mound of earth for sacrifices, called *she* because it "spews forth" (*tu*) all things, hence the name. *Jiang* is a general term for craftsmen, while *Shi* is the given name of this particular master. Traveling from Lu to Qi, he passed through the winding roads and saw this extraordinary tree, gnarled and useless. This illustrates that in navigating human affairs, one must recognize the use in what seems useless. Its girth could shade an ox, its circumference bound by a hundred spans.

**[Subcommentary]** *Xu* means "to bind." This *li* tree by the earth-altar was exceptionally tall, its branches and leaves casting shade enough to cover a thousand oxen. When measured with a rope, its girth spanned a hundred feet. The *Zhuangzi* text from the Jiangnan region often speaks of it shading an ox, omitting the "thousand" character—this version appears to be in error. For the tree at Shangqiu could shelter a thousand chariots, so how could the one at Qu Yuan shade only a single ox? By this comparison, the version with "thousands" is correct.

Its height towered a thousand *ren* before branches appeared, while along its sides grew a dozen or so trunks large enough to make boats.

**[Subcommentary]** A *ren* is seven feet. This tree rose straight and towering over seventy feet before sprouting branches, blocking the sun and brushing the clouds. The trunks suitable for boats numbered in the dozens. Such was its form.

Spectators thronged like a marketplace, yet the master carpenter paid it no heed, continuing on his way without pause.

**[Subcommentary]** *Chuo* means "to stop." The tree was extraordinarily large, drawing crowds of onlookers. Only Carpenter Shi, recognizing its worthlessness, passed by without a glance.

The disciple, weary of gazing, ran to catch up with Carpenter Shi and said: "Since I took up the axe and followed you, Master, I have never seen timber so magnificent. Yet you refuse to look, walking on without pause—why?"

**[Subcommentary]** The disciple marveled at the tree’s extraordinary grandeur and stood transfixed in admiration. Proud of his long apprenticeship, he had never seen wood so wondrously vast—yet the master carpenter paid it no heed. Catching up, he could not help but ask.

"Enough," said Carpenter Shi. "Say no more."

**[Subcommentary]** *Yi* means "to stop." Carpenter Shi knew the great tree was useless, unfit for worldly purposes. Fearing his disciple’s words would be wasteful, he rebuked him and commanded silence.

"It is a *scattered tree*—if made into a boat, it would sink; if made into a coffin or outer casket, it would rot swiftly.

**[Subcommentary]** The tree’s wood is heavy: as a boat, it would sink; near earth, it decays quickly. A loose-grained tree, it lives out its natural years—useless timber, left to idleness.

If made into vessels, it would break easily.

**[Subcommentary]** Among human artifacts, durability is prized. This wood, brittle and porous, would surely shatter early.

If made into doors, it would ooze sap; if made into beams, it would be worm-eaten.

**[Subcommentary]** *Ye* means the exudation of resin. *Du* refers to internal rot. As doors, it would seep sap; as beams, it would be infested and unstable.

It is a *useless tree*, good for nothing—yet this is why it has attained such longevity."

**[Commentary]** Not counted among the useful, it is called a *scattered tree*.

**[Subcommentary]** Loose-grained and brittle, it is indeed useless timber, unfit for any purpose—thus spared an early demise.

That night, Carpenter Shi dreamed the tree appeared to him, saying: "To what would you compare me? Would you liken me to the *patterned trees*?"

**[Commentary]** All useful timber is called *patterned trees*.

**[Subcommentary]** *Wu hu* means "to what." *Ruo* means "you." *Yu* means "me."

The useful trees are called *patterned trees*. Carpenter Shi returned and retired to sleep, whereupon the *li* tree appeared to him in a dream and asked: "With what would you compare me? Would you liken me to a *scattered tree* of no use, or to a *patterned tree* of fine grain and utility? Consider the wild pear, the chestnut, the orange, the pomelo, and the melon gourds—*[Subcommentary]* Those that grow on trees are called *fruits*, such as the wild pear and its kind; those that grow on the ground are called *vegetables*, such as melons and gourds. Would you compare me to these? In truth, once they ripen, they are stripped and humiliated; their great branches break, their small branches are torn. This is because their very usefulness brings suffering to their lives, so they do not fulfill their natural span but perish midway, struck down by the common world. All things are thus. *[Commentary]* All things harm themselves through their own usefulness. *[Subcommentary]* Such fruits and gourds, though their flavors are sweet, once their seeds and flesh ripen, are stripped and cast down—whereupon their great branches snap and their small branches are torn. Is this not because their delicious flavors bring suffering to their lives? The words of ruin and disgrace refer precisely to this. Though they sprout in spring and fall in autumn, fulfilling their natural span, they are battered midway and called *prematurely cut down*. Yet they, lacking awareness, and all worldly things besides, harm and cut short their lives through their usefulness. Thus this concludes: none are not so. *Shi* means "to strike."

As for me, I have long sought to be of no use—nearly dying in the process—until now, when I have attained it. *[Commentary]* Many have looked askance at me, but only now has Carpenter Shi understood. This is my great usefulness. *[Commentary]* To accumulate uselessness is to achieve the great usefulness of sustaining life. *[Subcommentary]* Being of no use, I have thus preserved my life. The *li* tree has sought this for a long time. Yet clumsy craftsmen, mistaking me for a *patterned tree*, have repeatedly come to inspect me, intending to fell me, fearing only the axe that would cut short my life. Now, meeting a master craftsman who recognizes my uselessness, I have at last preserved my life—this is my great usefulness. *Ji* means "nearly." Had I been useful, could I have grown so great? *[Commentary]* If useful, I would have long since been felled. *[Subcommentary]* Had I been a *patterned tree* of some use, I would long since have been hacked down, cut short by axes—how could I have grown so large and lived so long?

Moreover, you and I are both things—how could we truly know one another? *[Subcommentary]* You and I are both creatures of the same creation—how could things ever truly know one another? *Nai he zai* is an interrogative phrase. And you, a *scattered man* nearly dead, what could you know of a *scattered tree*? *[Commentary]* This is said in jest to Carpenter Shi. *[Subcommentary]* Carpenter Shi calls me a *scattered tree* for my uselessness, while the *li* tree calls him a *scattered man* for his misplaced skill. You flaunt your talents in the common world, and so verge on premature ruin; I, through my scattered uselessness, have preserved my life. You are a *scattered man* on the brink of death—how could you know I am a *scattered tree*? This is spoken in a dream to tease Carpenter Shi.

Carpenter Shi awoke and interpreted his dream. *[Subcommentary]* *Zhen* means "to divine." Awakening, Carpenter Shi pondered the dream and divined its meaning, then told his disciples. His disciples asked: "If its purpose is to be of no use, why then does it serve as a shrine tree?" *[Commentary]* They still suspect it takes pride in being a shrine tree rather than simply seeking to be of no use. *[Subcommentary]* The *li* tree’s intent is to be of no use, thereby preserving its life—so why does it serve as a shrine tree to glorify itself? The disciples did not understand, hence this question. He replied: "Hush."

"If you remain silent—it merely lodges there by chance.
*[Commentary]* The shrine spirit comes to lodge of its own accord; this tree does not seek to become a shrine.
*[Subcommentary]* *If* means "you." *That* refers to the shrine. You must be discreet and not speak carelessly. The shrine spirit comes to lodge of its own accord—it has nothing to do with this tree’s seeking to become a shrine.

It takes this as those who do not know it reviling it.
*[Commentary]* This tree regards the shrine as failing to recognize its true nature, thus bringing disgrace and harm—how could this be an honor?
*[Subcommentary]* *Reviling* means "disgrace." The shrine spirit, not understanding that this tree values uselessness as its true use—cherishing the preservation of its life—comes to lodge here arbitrarily, deeply offending it. Far from being an honor, this is a humiliation.

If it were not a shrine tree, how much more would it be so?
*[Commentary]* Since it inherently values uselessness as its use, even if it were not a shrine tree, it would still avoid the harm of being felled.
*[Subcommentary]* This tree, being scattered and unfit for use, thus preserves its life. Even if it were not a shrine tree, would it ever come close to the harm of being felled?

Moreover, what it preserves differs from the multitude.
*[Commentary]* It preserves itself by not preserving, while the multitude preserves itself by preserving.
*[Subcommentary]* The scattered tree preserves its life through uselessness, while the so-called "useful" trees perish young due to their talents—this is how they differ.

Yet you praise it in the name of *yi*—is this not far off the mark?
*[Commentary]* Benefiting others, sustaining things, and restraining people from wrongdoing—these are the *yi* of the shrine. But the useless one, serene and inactive, allows all talents to function on their own. Each finds its proper place without interference—this is how the useless preserves itself. You praise it in the name of the shrine’s *yi*, yet you are not even close.
*[Subcommentary]* The scattered tree, endowed by nature with worthlessness, relies on its uselessness to preserve its life. Yet the shrine spirit lodges here, turning this into a disgrace, and now you further praise it in the name of *yi*—how much farther from the truth could you be?

Nanbo Ziqi was wandering in Shangqiu when he saw an extraordinary tree. A thousand four-horse chariots could shelter beneath its shade, resting in the cool of its rustling leaves.
*[Commentary]* Its branches cast shade enough to shelter a thousand chariots.
*[Subcommentary]* *Bo* means "elder." His Way was so revered that he could lead all things, hence he was called *Bo*—this was Nan Guo Zi Qin. Shangqiu was a place in the region of Liang and Song. A *si* is a team of four horses. *Su* means "shade." Zi Qin, traveling through the land of Song, passed by Shangqiu and saw a great tree unlike any other. Its trunk was tall and sturdy, its branches and leaves luxuriant, casting a vast shade where countless chariots and horses could take shelter.

Zi Qin said: "What tree is this? It must possess extraordinary qualities."
*[Subcommentary]* Zi Qin, seeing this tree, did not recognize its name but suspected it had some exceptional ability, hence his astonishment.

Looking up at its slender branches, he saw they were gnarled and crooked, unfit for beams or rafters. Looking down at its great roots, he saw they were split and twisted like a turning axle, unfit for coffins or outer caskets.
*[Subcommentary]* *Split like an axle* means the wood turns like a wheel’s hub, referring to its twisted grain. A coffin encloses the body entirely—*guan* means "complete." An outer casket encloses the coffin entirely."

The timber for beams and pillars must be straight—crookedness renders it useless; coffins and outer caskets require solidity—splitting and scattering undermine their strength. If one chews its leaves, the mouth festers and becomes injured; if one smells them, it induces a raving intoxication that persists for three days without cease.
*[Subcommentary]* Chewing the leaves with the tongue causes the lips and mouth to fester and injure; inhaling their scent through the nose brings unending stupor. *Xing* refers to the sickness of drunkenness.

Zi Qin said: "This tree is truly one of no use, yet it has grown to such immense size."
*[Subcommentary]* Its entire body being without utility may be called the great talent of preserving life whole; its utter uselessness to all is precisely the wondrous function of aiding others. Thus it escapes the axe’s early doom and shelters a thousand chariots in its shade.

Ah, the spirit-like person—it is by this very uselessness!
*[Annotation]* The Celestial King is "without talent" among the hundred officials, so the hundred officials manage their affairs: the clear-sighted see for him, the keen-eared hear for him, the wise plan for him, the brave contend for him. What does Heaven do? It remains darkly silent, that is all.

Yet when the multitude of useful trees do not lose their proper place, it is precisely the useless tree upon which they most depend. Thus the world delights in exalting it without weariness, riding upon the ten thousand things without harming them.

*[Subcommentary]* The perfected person is spirit-like, so profound that yin and yang cannot fathom him; he merges with the human realm, blending his light so that it does not shine. Thus his roots run deep and his stem is firm, achieving long life and enduring vision. Like a boat or a ship, he shelters the myriad things, shading the black-haired people. Compare him to the sacred mulberry: though it stands apart from common timber, it is by this very uselessness that the spirit-like person is praised. The so-called "useless" is truly the greatest of talents.

In Song there was a place called Jing-shi, where catalpa, cypress, and mulberry grew in abundance.
*[Subcommentary]* Jing-shi is a place name. In the state of Song, there was a region called Ju-shi where these three trees—catalpa, cypress, and mulberry—all grew straight and tall, fit for timber. This briefly illustrates how fine timber meets an early end by the axe, contrasting with the scattered trees of no use that preserve their lives whole.

Those with trunks the span of two hands or one were felled by those seeking switches to discipline monkeys;
*[Subcommentary]* "Two hands" refers to a double span, "one hand" to a single span. Monkeys here mean macaques. "Switches" refers to roots or branches, also meaning to break. Trees of this size, their timber not large, were cut into rods to strike mischievous monkeys.

Those three or four spans in girth were felled by those seeking beams for lofty halls or fine names;
*[Subcommentary]* "Beams" refer to roof ridges, also to small boats. "Lofty names" mean honor and renown. Trees of three or four spans in girth, their timber somewhat larger, were taken by those seeking glory, high roofs, or fine boats.

Those seven or eight spans in girth were felled by the households of nobles and wealthy merchants seeking planks for coffins.
*[Subcommentary]* "Planks" refer to coffin boards. Also, a coffin made from a single side of a tree, not joined, is called a "single-side plank." Trees of seven or eight spans in girth, their timber very large, were cut down by the wealthy and merchant families seeking large boards for coffins.

Thus they did not complete their Heaven-appointed years but met an untimely end midway by the axe—this is the calamity of being useful.
*[Annotation]* Those with utility cannot avoid being prized.
*[Subcommentary]* Because they are useful, they do not fulfill their natural lifespan but perish midway at the hands of craftsmen. All this is the harm that comes from their utility.

Therefore, for expiatory rites, oxen with white foreheads, pigs with upturned snouts, and men with hemorrhoids were not taken to the river.
*[Annotation]* Shamans and invocators, when performing expiations, would first carefully select their words and offerings before daring to proceed.
*[Subcommentary]* "Forehead" refers to the brow; "upturned" means raised. Hemorrhoids are a disease of lower leakage. Shamans and invocators, when presenting straw dogs for sacrifices or selecting cattle and pigs for expiations, must choose pure and unblemished animals, demonstrating utmost sincerity as if the spirits were present, hoping to move the ghosts and gods. Yet here were pigs with upturned snouts and broken foreheads, calves with white foreheads that could not be rejected, and men with filthy hemorrhoid diseases—these three, being unclean, could not be taken to the sacred river for offerings. In ancient times, people were sent into the river to sacrifice to the River Earl; when Ximen Bao served as magistrate of Ye, he put an end to this practice—this is an example of such rites. The shamans and invocators knew this well:
*[Annotation]* The shamans and invocators also knew that the useless remain whole.
Thus they deemed them inauspicious. Yet this is precisely how the spirit-like person achieves the greatest auspiciousness.
*[Annotation]* Preserving life whole is what the world calls auspicious. Shamans and invocators, deeming the useless inauspicious and refusing to use them, do not realize that it is by this very inauspiciousness that life is preserved whole—this is the greatest auspiciousness. The spirit-like person, without fixed intent, follows the flow of things. Thus what the world calls the greatest auspiciousness, the spirit-like person does not reject.
*[Subcommentary]* Women are called shamans, men are called invocators. Invocators are those who hold tablets and recite sacrificial texts. "Auspicious" means good. When shamans, invocators, and scribes perform expiations, they know these three—white-foreheaded oxen, upturned-snouted pigs, and men with hemorrhoids—are unfit for offerings and discard them as inauspicious. Yet the spirit-like person, attuned to the transformations of nature, knows that the useless and valueless preserve life whole. Thus the talk of white foreheads, upturned snouts, and hemorrhoids as inauspicious is merely the narrow view of lesser shamans—how could it be the comprehensive wisdom of the great? Therefore, it is precisely those without complete utility whom the spirit-like person deems most auspicious and good.

There was one called *Zhi Li Shu*, whose chin was hidden in his navel, whose shoulders rose above his head,
*[Subcommentary]* His limbs were disjointed, his body misshapen, so that his cheeks were hidden between his navel, and his shoulders rose above his head. His appearance was so deformed that he was named *Zhi Li* (Disjointed).
his crown pointed to the sky, his five organs atop his back, his thighs pressed against his ribs.
*[Subcommentary]* "Crown" describes how his hair stood upright. The five organs refer to the viscera. The viscera are located in the back of a person, and in ancient times, topknots were worn near the back of the head. Now, *Zhi Li*’s deformities caused him to bend backward, so that his viscera and topknot faced upward, while his thighs and calves were drawn up against his ribs.

By sewing and washing, he could feed himself;
*[Subcommentary]* "Sewing" refers to mending clothes; "washing" to laundering. He earned his living through menial labor to sustain himself.
by sifting chaff and winnowing grain, he could feed ten.
*[Subcommentary]* "Chaff" refers to small winnowing baskets. "Grain" means rice. He swept the marketplace, sifted chaff, winnowed dust, and sorted grain. Another interpretation: "Sifting chaff" refers to casting divination stalks, and "winnowing grain" to discerning the fine from the coarse in divination. Whether sweeping the market to support his family or selling divination to sustain himself, his earnings could feed ten people.

When rulers conscript warriors, the Hunchback thrusts his arms among them;
*[Annotation]* Relying on his uselessness, he does not flee into hiding.
*[Subcommentary]* When borderlands are troubled and brave men are sought, the crippled and infirm, unfit for campaign, remain fearless, thrusting their arms about as they wander—secure in their uselessness, they do not hide.

When rulers impose great corvées, the Hunchback, citing his chronic ailment, is exempt from labor;
*[Annotation]* Unfit for service, he is not assigned tasks.
*[Subcommentary]* When the state undertakes major forced labor, he, being afflicted with madness, is not made to fulfill its work quotas.

When rulers distribute grain to the ailing, he receives three *zhong* and ten bundles of firewood.
*[Annotation]* Though exempt from labor, he accepts gifts.
*[Subcommentary]* Six *dan* and four *dou* make one *zhong*. The ruler, pitying widows and orphans, showing compassion for the poor and sick, grants more to those whose bodies are severely deformed.

Thus, the Master Guo observes: exempt from labor, he accepts gifts.
One whose form is deformed may yet nourish himself and live out his natural years—how much more so one whose virtue is deformed?

*[Annotation]* The spiritual person is of no use to things, yet things each attain their own use, ascribing merit and fame to the multitude. In harmony with things and without advancement, they avoid the harms of the human realm, abiding in the substance of constant beauty. This is what it means to deform one’s virtue.
*[Subcommentary]* To deform one’s form is to forget form; to deform one’s virtue is to forget virtue. Yet even one whose body is deformed and crippled merely forgets form, for they are no sage and thus cannot forget virtue.

To forget virtue is to comprehend all things with wisdom yet return wisdom to folly, to illuminate the Three Luminaries yet restore illumination to obscurity. Thus, one may achieve success without claiming it, act without reliance, ascribe merit and fame to the multitude of beings, and merge with things without assertion—this is to forget virtue.
One who forgets form may yet nourish the body and live out their years, avoiding the harms of the human realm—how much more so one who forgets virtue? The disparity in their depth and excellence is such that they cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

Thus, one who deforms their virtue—surely this is the sage.
When Confucius traveled to Chu, Jie Yu, the Madman of Chu, wandered to his gate and sang:
*"O phoenix! O phoenix! How has virtue so declined?"*

*[Annotation]* One should follow the times and proceed directly, fulfilling what is fitting in the moment.
The rise and fall of the world are too subtle to perceive, hence the question: *How has it so declined?*
*[Subcommentary]* *How* means *in what manner*. *Declined* means *to reach*. When Confucius journeyed from Lu to Chu, he lodged at an inn. There was a worthy man of Chu, surnamed Lu, named Tong, styled Jie Yu, who knew of Confucius’s travels and sang to mock him:
*"O phoenix! O phoenix!"*—thus lamenting the sage, likening him to the auspicious bird that appears when the Dao prevails. When the Dao exists, it manifests; when it does not, it withdraws. How could one harbor such sagely virtue yet travel to a realm of decline and disorder?

*"Future ages cannot be awaited; past ages cannot be pursued."*
*[Annotation]* One should hasten to fulfill what is fitting in the present moment.
*[Subcommentary]* The ages to come, with rulers who embrace the Dao and might be served, are as fleeting as a galloping horse—thus, they cannot be awaited. The ages past, with sage-kings like Yao and Shun, have long since transformed—thus, they cannot be sought. One should hasten to fulfill what is fitting in the present, without straining to look ahead or behind.

*"When the world has the Dao, the sage achieves; when the world lacks the Dao, the sage survives."*
*[Annotation]* Entrusting oneself to what is so, principle naturally achieves or survives. Neither achievement nor survival is of my doing—how could order or chaos alter one’s resolve? Order seeks achievement, thus one may relinquish achievement without failure; chaos seeks survival, thus one may forget survival without perishing.
*[Subcommentary]* In an enlightened ruler’s reign, a time of brilliance, the sage expands the Dao and establishes teaching, bringing achievement to the world. When encountering a benighted ruler, an age of desolation, one may only preserve life and avoid harm, concealing brilliance and obscuring traces.

*"In this present age, one barely escapes punishment."*
*[Annotation]* Without looking ahead or behind, one fully meets the demands of the present moment, merging obscurely with the times to attain perfect harmony, thus escaping punishment.
*[Subcommentary]* *Present* means *current*. Now, in this age of ruin and the declining Zhou, with cautious conduct and guarded speech, one barely escapes execution—yet to grasp the reins and respond to summons is surely delusional. These are Jie Yu’s words, mocking Confucius.

*"Fortune is lighter than a feather, yet none know how to bear it;*
*[Annotation]* Feet can walk yet are left idle; hands can grasp yet are left unburdened. One listens to what the ears hear, sees what the eyes see, knows to stop at what they do not know, and acts only within their capacity. Using what is naturally used, doing what is naturally done, indulging one’s nature without the slightest encumbrance from what lies beyond—this is the utmost ease of non-action. Yet no one whose nature and destiny remain unfulfilled through non-action has ever existed; and if nature and destiny are fulfilled, it cannot but be fortune. Thus, fortune is simply what was earlier called fulfillment—it is not borrowed from things, so how could it bear the weight of a goose feather?

To move in accordance with one’s nature, never exceeding its bounds, is the utmost ease in the world. To lift what lifts itself, to bear what bears itself, is the utmost lightness in the world. Yet knowing with boundless knowledge harms one’s nature, and the heart, swayed by likes and dislikes, scatters one’s authenticity. Thus, people abandon this utmost ease of non-action to pursue the utmost difficulty of action, discard this utmost lightness of self-lifting to take up the utmost burden of bearing others—this is the common folly of the world.

*"Misfortune is heavier than the earth, yet none know how to avoid it."*
*[Annotation]* To lift what lies within one’s nature, even if bearing ten thousand *jun*, one does not feel its weight; to entrust oneself to external things, even if the burden is no more than a *zhu*, one may yet be unequal to it. To act from within is fortune—thus, fortune is supremely light.

To act from without is misfortune—thus, misfortune is supremely heavy. Yet misfortune, though heavier than the earth, none know how to avoid: this is the world’s great delusion.

*[Annotation]* Now, seeing and hearing, knowing and ability, each have their limits. To abide within one’s limits is to preserve life; to seek beyond them is to court early death. Preserving life is thus fortune, while early death is misfortune. Yet the fortune that lies within one’s limits is lighter than a goose feather, and those who vie for honor and gain do not know it is borne within themselves. The misfortune that lies beyond one’s limits is heavier than the earth, yet the deluded, clinging fast, do not know to shun it from themselves. This is the common affliction of the vulgar world—thus, the text invokes Confucius and Lu to reveal its burden.

*"Enough! Enough! Meet others with virtue.
Danger! Danger! Trace the line and follow it."*

*[Annotation]* To trace a line upon the ground and bid others follow it is to make plain what lies near; to possess oneself and stand above things is to be at odds with them. Thus, the great person does not illumine me to dazzle others but lets others find their own illumination; does not impose me upon others but lets each attain their own fulfillment. Thereby, they pervade and unite the ten thousand things, mysteriously merging self and other, and in silent oneness with all under Heaven, inner and outer share the same fortune.

*[Annotation]* *Yi* means to cease; *dai* means peril.

Confucius was born at the end of the declining Zhou, in an age of decadence and decline. Clinging to sagely advancement, he traveled through the states responding to summons, yet repeatedly faced rejection and slander. Thus, the repeated cry of "Enough! Enough!"—better to cease and not act at all. If one employs the Five Virtues to govern the people, imposing oneself upon others, it will only lead to peril and ruin. It is like drawing lines upon the ground and making others run along them—wasted effort with no hope of concealment. To impose oneself upon things follows the same principle.

"Lost brightness! Lost brightness! Do not harm my path."
*[Annotation]* "Lost brightness" means the absence of outward display. Abiding in solitude without being swayed by externals preserves the integrity of one's path. If all under Heaven preserve their own integrity, then all who claim the name of "self" will be preserved.

*[Annotation]* *Mi* means lost; *yang* means brightness or movement. Lu Tong exhorted Confucius to conceal his advancement and veil his brilliance, advocating the effortless non-action of solitary transformation and forgetting the discriminating wisdom of responding to things. Thereby, one remains within their proper bounds, and the path of preserving life remains unharmed.

"My path winds through hollows—do not harm my feet."
*[Annotation]* When the path bends to completion, each is self-sufficient.

*[Annotation]* *Bu* means emptiness; *qu* means compliance. Emptying the mind and following the nature of things, each who claims the name of "self" becomes self-sufficient.

Mountain trees bring ruin upon themselves; fat burns itself in the flame.
*[Annotation]* *Kou* means to fell. Trees in the mountains—cedars and catalpas—are valued for their usefulness and thus suffer felling. Fat provides bright illumination when used for torches, and for its usefulness, it is consumed by fire. Not only fat and wood—so too with people. Cinnamon is edible, so it is cut down; lacquer is useful, so it is tapped.

*[Annotation]* Cinnamon’s heart is pungent and fragrant, so it is felled; lacquer is used for vessels, so it is tapped. Both are valued for their utility and thus meet their end by axe and blade. People know the usefulness of what is useful but do not know the usefulness of what is useless.

*[Annotation]* What is useful serves others; what is useless preserves one’s own life. Those who cut their flesh for the world are known by the world. To allow the people to preserve their own integrity while both self and other are at ease—this is a joy so subtle one does not sense its wonder within.

*[Annotation]* The cedar, cypress, orange, and lacquer—these are useful. The crooked-trunked tree, the tree of Shangqiu, the white-foreheaded ox, the snub-nosed pig—these are useless. Yet the world flaunts its talents as the usefulness of the useful, unaware that the fragmentation of virtue is the usefulness of the useless. Thus, as Guo’s commentary states: "What is useful serves others; what is useless preserves one’s own life."
