**Annotations and Commentary on the Southern Florescence Scripture (Nanhua Zhenjing Zhushu), Scroll Six**
*Guo Xiang of Henan, Annotation*

**Tang Dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary**
*Inner Chapters, "Virtue’s Full Manifestation" (Dechongfu), Fifth*

Virtue fills the inner, things respond to the outer—outer and inner merge in mystery, as if tallying with destiny yet transcending it. Such is his physical form.

In Lu there was a foot-amputee named Wang Fu.
**[Subcommentary]** Surnamed Wang, given name Chi, a man of Lu. To be amputated of one foot is called *wu* (兀). Though his form was maimed and incomplete, his heart was truly empty and forgetful, thus he heads the chapter *"Virtue’s Full Manifestation."*

Those who followed him in study were comparable to Confucius.
**[Annotation]** The number of his disciples rivaled that of Confucius.
**[Subcommentary]** *Ru* (若) means "like." Those who accompanied Wang to listen and learn were in number like those of Confucius.

Chang Ji asked Confucius, saying: "Wang Fu is a foot-amputee, yet those who follow him in study divide Lu equally with you."
**[Subcommentary]** Surnamed Chang, given name Ji, a worthy man of Lu. Wang Chi’s conduct forgot the outer form while his inner virtue was full, so those who followed him in study numbered three thousand, the same as Confucius, thus dividing Lu equally. Chang Ji, not yet grasping the true essence, therefore harbored doubt.

Standing, he taught not; sitting, he discussed not. They came empty and departed full.
**[Annotation]** Each attained self-sufficiency.
**[Subcommentary]** Though his disciples were many, there was never any instruction. Standing, he did not teach; sitting, he did not debate. They sought benefit with empty hearts and returned with full understanding.
**Alternative interpretation:** The unlearned and virtueless also came empty.
Is there truly a teaching without words, a shaping of the heart without form?

**[Annotation]** Marveling that though his form was maimed, his heart was full.
When the heart is whole, it transcends the body and form, forgets the five organs, and suddenly departs alone—yet all under heaven cannot part from it.
**[Subcommentary]** He taught his disciples without words or debate. Though maimed and incomplete, without further form, his profound Dao and perfect virtue filled his inner heart. Surely this is why the multitude followed him.

What manner of man is this?
**[Subcommentary]** Chang Ji marveled that though maimed, he gathered so many. To reveal the beauty of full virtue, he thus posed this question.

Confucius said: "This Master is a sage. I merely follow behind and have not yet gone to him. I shall take him as my teacher—how much more should those inferior to me?"
**[Subcommentary]** Xuanni addressed Wang Chi as "Master," replying to Chang Ji: "Wang Chi is a sage who embodies the Dao. You fail to recognize him, hence your doubt. I merely lag behind and have not yet gone to study under him. I shall revere him as my teacher and inquire of the Dao—how much more should those of later learning, inferior to me, do the same? To seek benefit and hold fast to his teachings is surely fitting. Why limit it to Lu?"

"I shall lead all under heaven to follow him."
**[Annotation]** When the spirit is whole and the heart complete, the body merges with things. One who merges with things cannot be distanced by all under heaven—how could it be merely one state?
**[Subcommentary]** *Xi* (奚) means "why." Why merely borrow Lu as a single domain? I shall guide all within the four seas to receive his abundant virtue, yet still fear I may not exhaust his Way.

Chang Ji said: "He is a foot-amputee, yet he surpasses Master Wang—his distinction from the common is indeed great."
**[Subcommentary]** *Wang* (王) means "abundant." *Yong* (庸) means "ordinary." *Xiansheng* (先生) refers to Confucius. That Wang Chi, a maimed man, had disciples attending him like those of the Master—marveling at this strangeness, he must differ from the common stream, and surely be far removed from ordinary people.
If so, how does he employ his heart uniquely?

**[Subcommentary]** *Ran* (然) means "thus." Wang Chi’s abundant virtue being thus, drawing all to him—how does he apply his wisdom and employ his heart in such a manner? Chang Ji, not yet comprehending, raised this doubt.

Confucius said: "Life and death are indeed great matters,
**[Annotation]** Though people are said to change, the change of life and death is the greatest of changes.
yet he does not alter with them;
**[Annotation]** He moves with change, thus life and death do not alter him.
**[Subcommentary]** Though mountains and boats may vanish, firewood and fingers shift—while all things undergo myriad changes, none is greater than life and death. Yet Wang Chi’s heart merges with the Creator, moving with transformation, traversing the human realm, accompanying life and death—thus he is not altered by what alters.

Though heaven and earth collapse, he will not lose them.
**[Annotation]** Even for a moment.
**[Subcommentary]** *Yi* (遗) means "to lose." Though the round heavens topple and the square earth crumbles, merged with safety and peril, he has never lost himself.

He examines what requires no borrowing,
**[Annotation]** Clarifying the constancy of nature and destiny.
and does not shift with things.
**[Annotation]** Letting things shift of themselves.
**[Subcommentary]** His numinous heart is serene, his wondrous essence true and original—aligned with the Dao, he is not altered by things.

He commands the transformation of things
**[Annotation]** Taking transformation as destiny, without marveling at its circuit.
and guards its root.
**[Annotation]** Not departing from the ultimate of perfect appropriateness.
**[Subcommentary]** Grasping destiny, merging with external things, he moves with transformation as one, acting without departing from stillness—thus he abides in the root.

Chang Ji said: "What does this mean?"
**[Subcommentary]** The meaning being profound and difficult to grasp, he further inquired.

Confucius said: "Viewed from what makes them different, the liver and gallbladder are as distant as Chu and Yue.
**[Annotation]** When the natures of tranquility and bitterness diverge, the feelings of beauty and ugliness turn their backs.
**[Subcommentary]** All things, however manifold, ultimately return to emptiness and stillness. Yet inverted distinctions, clinging to right and wrong, arbitrarily impose divisions within the profound Dao. How is this different from the gallbladder growing attached to the liver—both originally one body—while Chu and Yue lie thousands of miles apart? Within a single body, they create a division of thousands of miles. Those who see differences do so in every case.

Viewed from what makes them the same, the myriad things are all one.
**[Annotation]** Though what they find beautiful differs, they all find something beautiful. Each finds beauty in its own beauty, and thus the myriad things share one beauty; each affirms its own affirmation, and thus the world shares one affirmation. If one emphasizes their differences to make them different, then nothing in the world is not different. Yet the one who embraces the vast vision commands heaven and earth, encompasses the myriad things, and knows that difference is not truly different. Thus, emphasizing what they share to make them the same, nothing in the world is not the same. Further, knowing that sameness is not truly possessed, emphasizing what they lack to make them nothing, then right and wrong, beauty and ugliness—nothing is not nothing. To affirm oneself and negate others, to find beauty in oneself and ugliness in others—from those of middling understanding down to the crawling insects, none do not do this. Yet this is merely to be clear about oneself and unclear about others. As for the one of profound penetration and merged comprehension, they illuminate the world through the world. The world never says, 'I am wrong'—thus they illuminate the world’s lack of wrong; never says, 'that is right'—thus they illuminate the world’s lack of right. Without right, without wrong, all blends into one. Therefore, they can ride transformation and follow change, meeting things without resistance.
**[Subcommentary]** As for the one of profound penetration, embracing the vast vision, the Two Modes and the myriad things are like pointing to a single horse. Thus, they can forget cares and follow things, fully accord with the multitude of beings. Yet those who see sameness see sameness, those who see difference see difference. In the ultimate discussion of the wondrous realm, it is neither different nor the same. If this is so, then one does not even know what suits the ears and eyes.
**[Annotation]** Suitability arises from what is not suitable. Without beauty, without ugliness, then nothing is not suitable. Nothing is not suitable, thus one forgets suitability.
**[Subcommentary]** What suits the ears and eyes is what suits sounds and sights. Yet when the feelings of the moment make distinctions, clinging to sounds and sights, there arises what is suitable and unsuitable, permissible and impermissible. But one who gallops through the merging of the myriad things, darkly uniting life and death—how could they, amidst the roots and dust, harbor views of beauty and ugliness? Thus, they roam their heart in the harmony of virtue.
**[Annotation]** Completely forgetting suitability, thus nothing is not entrusted. Entrusting everything and not obtaining it—this has never been; not obtaining and not harmonizing—this too has never been heard. Thus, releasing the heart amidst the Dao and virtue, all is fittingly vast, and all is fittingly free.
**[Subcommentary]** Having merged the myriad things, not knowing what suits the ears and eyes, they can roam the realm of virtue and release themselves into the境 of the ultimate Dao.

Things see their unity and do not see what they have lost—seeing the loss of a foot as discarding dirt.
**[Annotation]** Embracing the wondrous heart of the utmost number, thus nothing is not the same. Nothing is not the same, then death and life, transformation—nowhere is it not oneself. Thus, life is my time, death is my compliance; time is my gathering, compliance is my scattering. Though gathering and scattering differ, I am always myself. Thus, life is merely myself—there has never been a gain; death is also myself—there has never been a loss. The change of death and life is still regarded as one. Having witnessed this oneness, then joyfully without entanglement, darkly uniting self and other, taking death and life as waking and sleeping, the body as a temporary lodging—departing life like removing a shoe, severing a foot like discarding dirt. I have never seen this ensnare their heart.
**[Subcommentary]** "Things see" means seeing things. One who unites life and death, things and self—life as my time, not seeing gain; death as my compliance, not seeing loss. Observing the myriad things, merging them as one, thus even the loss of a foot is seen like discarding dirt.

Chang Ji said: "He cultivates himself through his knowledge,
**[Annotation]** Suspecting that Wang Ni has not yet forgotten knowledge to preserve himself.
**[Subcommentary]** "He" refers to Wang Ni. Wang Ni cultivates his person and cultivates himself, still employing knowledge. It is suspected that he has not yet forgotten knowledge to entrust himself to solitude.

obtains his heart through his heart.
**[Annotation]** Suspecting that he has not yet forgotten the heart to obtain himself.
**[Subcommentary]** It is suspected that Wang Ni cannot forget cares to fully entrust himself, still employing the heart to obtain the heart. As for obtaining the heart—no thought, no deliberation, forgetting knowledge, forgetting awareness, like dead ashes or withered wood, utterly without emotion—placing it within the square inch, arising beyond seeing and hearing, equal to the Two Modes’ covering and bearing, following the Three Luminaries to illuminate, merging with dust and filth without disturbing the spirit, treading hardship and obstruction without stirring concern. Not obtaining is obtaining, and obtaining lies in non-obtaining—this is true obtaining. If one obtains it through the defense of heart and knowledge, it is not true obtaining.

Obtaining his constant heart—how could things gather around him?
**[Annotation]** Obtaining the constant heart is to be level in going. It is suspected that he cannot be level in going and thus passes with things, causing things to come to him.
**[Subcommentary]** "Gather" means to assemble. If one can be empty and forgetful, level and bland, obtaining the true constant heart, then one should certainly harmonize light and conceal brilliance, not differing from the common. How could one be uniquely different from things, causing the multitude to gather?"

Confucius said: "People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water."
**[Annotation]** The stillness of water that allows reflection is not stillness sought for the purpose of reflection.
Thus, when the king gallops, the multitude gathers—yet the multitude comes of its own accord, not drawn by force.
**[Subcommentary]** *Jian* means "to reflect."
Still water retains its clarity, and thus reflects; the king gallops to gather the multitude because he embodies tranquility.
Still water has no intent to reflect things, yet things mirror themselves in it; the king gallops with no design to summon others, yet the multitude comes to him of its own accord.
Only stillness can still the stillness of others.
**[Annotation]** If one acts deliberately, one cannot abide in the stillness of all things.
**[Subcommentary]** *Wei* means "only." Only stillness—water’s inherent clarity—can still the lingering of men; the stillness of others is the coming of things to be reflected.
Just as the king gallops, embracing emptiness and tranquility, and thus can contain and still all beings, so too does his power draw the multitude to gather.
Receiving its mandate from the earth, only the pine and cypress remain verdant through winter and summer.
**[Annotation]** The pine and cypress are uniquely endowed with the qi of nature, and thus stand as the finest of trees—not through effort, but by inherent disposition.
**[Subcommentary]** All grasses and trees rely on the fertile earth. Yet those that possess unyielding strength and remain undiminished in the depths of winter—the pine and cypress, which preserve their verdure through all four seasons—do so by receiving qi naturally, not by deliberate intent.
The king’s gathering of the multitude follows the same principle.
Receiving its mandate from heaven, only Shun stands truly upright.
**[Annotation]** Those who uniquely receive the upright qi of nature are exceedingly rare: below, only the pine and cypress; above, only the sage. Thus, all that are not upright come seeking uprightness.
If all things were verdant, the pine and cypress would hold no distinction; if all people were upright, none would admire the great sage and turn toward him.
**[Subcommentary]** Humans receive their mandate from the three powers, their lives from the azure heavens, their forms round-headed and square-footed—yet their kind is vast.
Only one like Yu Shun, who embodies upright qi and unadulterated truth, stands apart—not by effort, but by natural endowment.
The king’s union with the Dao follows the same principle.
**[Master Guo’s Annotation]** "Above, only the sage": since the human head is above, severing it brings death; the root of a tree is below, severing it brings death. Thus, humans are called the "upper end," trees the "lower end."
The upper end consumes the side end, the side end consumes the lower end. The lower end refers to grasses and trees; the side end, to insects and beasts.
Fortunate to be upright in life, he thereby sets others upright.
**[Annotation]** Fortunate to be upright himself—not seeking to set others upright by doing so.
**[Subcommentary]** Receiving qi from the supreme mystery, he naturally embodies the upright Way—not by deliberate effort, but by fortunate spontaneity. Not only is he upright himself, but he also sets others upright.
Uprightness in self and others—self-benefit and other-benefit—perfects inner and outer conduct, and this is called the great sage.
Yu Shun was thus, and so too is the king who gallops. Yet Shun received the abdication of men, and thus serves as the exemplar.
The proof of preserving the beginning lies in the substance of fearlessness.
A single brave warrior, boldly entering the nine armies—
even one who seeks fame and binds himself to it, yet acts thus,
**[Annotation]** Not abandoning fame, yet capable of all undertakings.
**[Subcommentary]** *Zheng* means "to fulfill," "to verify."
The Son of Heaven commands six armies, the feudal lords three—hence, nine armies.
There may be one man, endowed with courage and martial prowess, who preserves the heart of a good beginning, fulfills the integrity of a steadfast end, harbors a will without fear, and displays a bearing of heroic might.
Even one who enters the nine armies to seek fame and rank, binding his heart to reputation and forgetting life and death—
how much more so the king who gallops.
The state of embodying the Dao is described below.
How much more one who governs heaven and earth, who stores the myriad things,
**[Annotation]** Profoundly embodying all without exception.
**[Subcommentary]** To govern the two poles is to "govern heaven and earth"; to contain the cosmos is to "store the myriad things."
If a brave warrior entering the army, merely seeking fame and rank, can disregard life and death, forgetting his own existence—
how much more fitting for one who governs the two poles and unites the myriad things, seeing death as life.
Simply lodging in the six senses,
**[Annotation]** That is, the inn of the transient.
**[Subcommentary]** *Yu* means "to lodge." The six bones refer to the head, torso, and four limbs.
The king who listens perceives that the body is not real, that the ten thousand existences are all true. Thus, he mingles the dust and filth of the world, lodging his spirit within form—yet this is but a temporary sojourn, not an attachment.
Resembling the ears and eyes,
**[Annotation]** People use ears and eyes, yet he too uses ears and eyes—not needing ears and eyes.
**[Subcommentary]** *Xiang* means "to resemble." Harmonizing light and merging with the dust, he seems to use ears and eyes, yet does not need them.
In the knowing of the One’s knowledge, the heart has never died.
**[Annotation]** When knowledge moves with transformation, there is nowhere it does not become profound—this is the knowing of the One.
When the heart follows life and death, there is no time it is not alive—this is the heart that has never died.
**[Subcommentary]** *Yi zhi* is wisdom; *zhi suo zhi* is the object of knowledge.
The wisdom that knows illuminates the object of knowledge; when object and illumination merge, wisdom and its absence become one.
Though traversing the transformations of things, the heart has never encountered death—how could it be confined or dulled in its midst?
He then chooses a day to ascend to the great transformation, and people follow accordingly.
**[Annotation]** His choice lies in not missing the moment; this man makes no choice, but moves with the heavenly course when the time comes.
Thus, those who borrow from him gather around him.
**[Subcommentary]** Does the king who gallops ever select an auspicious day to ascend the mysterious Dao?

Indeed, is it not so? One simply sets aside emptiness and tranquility, forgetting the heart, and thus attains union. The perfected man is without mind, like still water that holds a reflection. Yet the world’s false and hollow men follow him because of this. How could he ever take external things as his concern?

**[Annotation]** His serenity is so complete that his wholeness remains intact.

**[Subcommentary]** Only that royal embryo, darkly merging with the true and uniting with the Dao—false and hollow things naturally come to submit to him. How could he ever take them as his own task?

Shentu Jia was a man who had lost a foot. Yet he studied under Bohun Wuren alongside Zichan of Zheng.

**[Subcommentary]** His surname was Shentu, his given name Jia, a worthy man of Zheng who had lost a foot. His surname was Gongsun, his given name Qiao, styled Zichan, a worthy minister of Zheng. Bohun Wuren was the honorific title of their teacher. *Bo* means "elder"; *hun* means "to merge." His virtue stood as the elder among things, concealing his brilliance as if veiled, utterly forgetting both self and others—hence the name Bohun Wuren. Zichan and Shentu Jia both studied the mysterious Dao, though their stations in life were far apart, they shared the same teacher. Thus, these three are cited here to illustrate the meaning of virtue’s fullness.

Zichan said to Shentu Jia, "If I leave first, you stay behind; if you leave first, I will stay behind."

**[Annotation]** He was ashamed to walk alongside a man who had lost a foot.

**[Subcommentary]** Zichan held political power and enjoyed glory, wealth, and honor. Shentu Jia, his form maimed and incomplete, had lost all appearance of dignity. Though Zichan studied under Bohun, he had not yet forgotten distinctions, still clinging to favor and disgrace. Ashamed to be seen with a maimed man, he preemptively set terms to ensure they would not walk together.

The next day, they again sat together in the same hall, sharing the same mat. Zichan said to Shentu Jia, "If I leave first, you stay behind; if you leave first, I will stay behind. Now I am about to leave—can you stay behind? Or not?"

**[Annotation]** He pressed the question bluntly, wanting to ensure they would not walk together.

**[Subcommentary]** Zichan still harbored thoughts of honor and disgrace, while Shentu had forgotten all distinctions of noble and base. Though Zichan had spoken before, Shentu paid no heed, so they still shared the same hall and sat on the same mat. Seeing this, Gongsun pressed the question directly: "When you see one who holds office, you do not yield—do you consider yourself equal to one who holds office?"

**[Annotation]** He should have taken pride in his own office, so the direct question, "Do you consider yourself equal?" was enough to show his lack of deference.

**[Subcommentary]** Their paths in life were different, their stations in governance distinct. I hold office and am thus a man of rank; you are lowly and maimed in form—you should defer to me. Yet you show no humility, even seeking to equal me.

Shentu Jia said, "In the master’s gate, is there truly one who holds office in such a manner?"

**[Annotation]** This is a matter of virtue, not of rank.

**[Subcommentary]** The master is Bohun. At the master’s gate, where the profound mysteries are made clear, honor and disgrace are merged, life and death are equalized—how could one take pride in holding office in such a way? "Do you delight in your office and thus put others behind?"

**[Annotation]** He mocked his pride in his position and his desire to put himself before others.

**[Subcommentary]** You still delight in glory and take pride in your governance, pushing others behind while seeking to be first. With such an attitude, how can you be said to study the Dao?

I have heard it said: When a mirror is bright, dust does not settle; if dust settles, it is not bright. If one dwells long with a worthy person, one does not err. Now, the greatest thing you have chosen is the master—yet you still speak in this way. Is this not an error?

**[Annotation]** To serve a clear master yet still not shed one’s petty and stingy heart—this is truly an error.

**[Subcommentary]** A mirror: when its surface is bright, dust does not settle; if dust settles, it is not a bright reflection. Likewise, dwelling long with a worthy person leaves no room for error; if there is error, one is not truly worthy. The greatest thing you have chosen is the master’s Dao. Yet the master’s Dao is to retreat into emptiness and forgetfulness, while you take pride in yourself, deeply contradicting its profound meaning. To speak as you do—is this not an error?

Zichan said, "Since you are as you are,"

**[Annotation]** As you are, maimed in form.

"you still contend with Yao in goodness. Do you not reflect that your virtue is insufficient?"

**[Annotation]** He did not look back at himself but sought to belittle one in office, comparing himself to one of virtue. Calculating his own virtue, it was surely insufficient to make up for his maimed form.

**[Subcommentary]** *Fan* means "again." Shentu Jia, maimed in form as he was, did not know himself but sought to walk alongside me—this is like contending with Yao in goodness. Though you have virtue, what is it worth? Even if virtue could compensate for your maimed form, it would still not be enough.

Shentu Jia said, "Those who justify their faults and claim they should not have perished are many."

**[Annotation]** Many declare their faults and argue that they should not have perished.

"Those who do not justify their faults and claim they should not have lived are few."

**[Annotation]** Few silently acknowledge their faults and accept that they should have died.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who display their faults, shifting blame to others, claiming they have no transgressions and should not have been punished—such people are many in the world. Those who do not display their faults, taking blame upon themselves, accepting that their faults mean they should not long remain alive—such people are few in the world. Zichan of Zheng, extravagant and self-aggrandizing, was just such a one in terms of righteousness.

Do you know that nothing can be done and yet accept it as fate? Only one of great virtue can do this.

**[Subcommentary]** *Ruo* means "to follow." This plain and maimed form was received as heavenly fate. Though one may know and calculate, nothing can be done about it—one can only accept and follow it, and all one’s actions will be fitting. Without abundant virtue, who could do this?

Amidst the target range of Yi’s arrows, the center is the bullseye—yet whether one is struck or not is a matter of fate.

**[Commentary]** Yi was a master archer of antiquity. The area within arrow’s reach was called the "target." When profit and harm contend, the world is full of archers like Yi. Those who do not abandon their bodies, forget their knowledge, and flow with things are all wandering within Yi’s target. Even if one ventures forth like Zhang Yi or retreats like Shan Bao, one cannot escape the bullseye—whether struck or spared depends solely on fate. Yet the petty-minded each encounter their lot and fail to grasp that fate is simply thus. Those who evade harm from arrows deem themselves skillful, exulting in their cleverness; when they cannot evade it, they resent their error, their will wounded and spirit shamed—such people have yet to comprehend the nature of fate. Our lives are not of our own making. Within a single lifetime, across a hundred years, from sitting and rising to moving and pausing, from stillness and action to inclinations and aversions, from temperament and intellect to all we possess—none of it is truly ours. The principle is simply thus. To arbitrarily generate joy and sorrow within it is to go against nature and lose oneself.

**[Subcommentary]** Yi was a skilled archer in the time of Yao. Wherever his arrows reached was called the "target." Yi’s skill ensured his arrows never missed; the target’s center was always struck, leaving no creature—beast or bird—unscathed. To escape by chance is a matter of heavenly fate. Struck or spared is not a question of skill or clumsiness. Those who do not abandon their form or forget their knowledge all wander within Yi’s target. Thus, Shentu Jia lost his foot to Yi’s arrow, while Zichan, physically whole, escaped by chance—neither outcome was due to human effort, so neither is worth self-congratulation. Many mock me for my missing foot, unaware of fate’s role in their laughter. Enraged, I seethed with anger—yet this too was ignorance of fate. Arriving at the Master’s abode, my anger dissolved, and I returned to myself. Was it the Master’s goodness that cleansed me? Or was it my own reflection? I forgot my form and shed my burdens.

I have wandered with you, Master, for nineteen years, yet you have never noticed my missing foot.

**[Commentary]** This is because he forgot form.

**[Subcommentary]** I wandered with Bohun in the Dao, plumbing the mysteries of yin and yang and the subtleties of the supreme principle. Having forgotten knowledge and form, how could he perceive my disability? Now you wander with me within the confines of form, yet seek me beyond it—is this not a mistake?

**[Commentary]** Form lies outside; virtue resides within. You wander with me in virtue, not in form, yet seek my outward appearance—is this not an error?

**[Subcommentary]** As Guo’s commentary states: "Form lies outside; virtue resides within. You wander with me in virtue, not in form, yet seek my outward appearance—is this not an error?" This note requires no further explanation.

Zichan, startled, changed his expression and said, "Say no more."

**[Commentary]** He grew weary of his own loquacity.

**[Subcommentary]** *Curan* means startled and ashamed. Zichan, unable to forget his attachments and desires, often spoke out of turn. Rebuked, he was taken aback, altering his proud demeanor to one of humility. Realizing his error, he ceased speaking.

In Lu there was a man without toes named Shushan Wuzhi, who approached Confucius on his heels.

**[Commentary]** *Zhong* means "to follow closely."

**[Subcommentary]** Shushan was his given name. *Zhong* means "to follow closely." Though maimed, this man from Lu retained a desire to learn, so he sought out a teacher to inquire about the Dao. Lacking toes, he was thus named.

Confucius said, "You were not careful, and already suffered such misfortune. Though you come now, what can be done?"

**[Subcommentary]** You failed to cultivate yourself with caution, violated the laws, and already endured punishment, suffering hardship and disfigurement. What can be achieved by coming now?

Wuzhi said, "I was ignorant of my duties and recklessly used my body, which is why I lost my foot.

**[Commentary]** Life arises of itself by principle. To do nothing and let it unfold naturally is to value one’s body and understand one’s duties. To forget one’s natural life, act with caution, and take pride in it is to use one’s body recklessly and fail in one’s duties. Thus, the five organs contend within, and hands and feet are maimed without.

Now I come, and what remains is still that which honors the foot.

**[Commentary]** Losing one foot is not enough to diminish one’s virtue, for the body is but a temporary abode.

Thus, I strive to preserve it whole.

**[Commentary]** Abandoning caution and pride, allowing life to unfold naturally—this is how one strives to preserve wholeness.

**[Subcommentary]** Wuzhi was circumspect in his associations, valuing virtue over the body. Yet he sang only to borrow fame, unaware of the Way of preserving life whole. Thus, he violated the laws and suffered mutilation. Though his form was damaged, his virtue remained, so he repeatedly sought counsel to safeguard his moral integrity. Comparing virtue to form, he spoke of "that which honors the foot" as still present. *Present* means *existing*.

Heaven covers all without exception; Earth bears all without distinction.

**[Commentary]** Heaven does not *act* to cover, yet it always covers; Earth does not *act* to bear, yet it always bears. If Heaven and Earth *acted* to cover and bear, they would sometimes rest. If a boat *acted* to float a man, it would sometimes sink. Thus, when things *act* for a purpose, they cannot endure to the end of their lives.

I took you, Master, for Heaven and Earth—how could I have known you were still like this?

**[Commentary]** This reproaches his lack of caution, for he falls short of Heaven and Earth.

**[Subcommentary]** Heaven and Earth nurture all, covering and bearing without partiality. The sage’s virtue aligns with these two forces, so he should likewise embrace all without rejection. How could I have known you, Master, would not overlook a maimed form? Is this truly the heart of one who saves others?

Confucius said, "I am but crude."

**[Subcommentary]** What Confucius offered was no more than the teachings of the sages. Wuzhi sought instruction in preserving life whole, and my shallow response to his profound question only revealed my crudeness.

"Why do you not enter?" he asked. "Let me share what I have heard."

Wuzhi departed.

**[Commentary]** He heard what he heard and left, preserving his non-action.

**[Subcommentary]** *Master* refers to Wuzhi. *Why* means *how*. Confucius, humbled by his own crudeness, felt deep shame and deferred to Wuzhi, inviting him in to expound on the teachings of the human realm. Yet after lingering too long, repeating worn-out doctrines like straw dogs, Wuzhi, weary of hearing them, silently withdrew.

Confucius said, "Disciples, take heed. Even Wuzhi, a maimed man, still strives to learn and redress his past wrongs—how much more should those whose virtue is whole?"

**[Commentary]** One whose virtue is whole forgets life from the moment of birth.

**[Subcommentary]** *Take heed* means *exert yourselves*. Even Wuzhi, though maimed, still seeks to preserve life whole and amend his past errors. How much more should the worthy and the virtuous, whose form and virtue are both intact, forget life and death, their inner power overflowing? You, my disciples, should be urged to do the same.

Wuzhi said to Lao Dan, "Is Confucius not yet a perfected man? Why does he so deferentially treat you as his teacher?"

**[Commentary]** He marvels that Confucius would still study under Lao Dan, as if ashamed.

**[Subcommentary]** *Deferentially* describes his reverent manner. The man of profound virtue fathoms the ultimate mysteries, transcends words and learning, and follows his nature with innate knowledge. Yet Confucius clings to texts, pursues the path of the sages, and humbly seeks instruction from Lao Dan. By your standards, he has not yet attained perfection—why does he study under you?

"Does he not seek strange and fantastical fame, unaware that the perfected man uses such things as his own shackles?"

**[Commentary]** The man without fixed intentions learns when others learn. Yet the ancients learned for themselves, while men today learn for others. This flaw leads them to do what others do. Those who teach others to attain self-realization follow what is constant; those who abandon themselves to imitate others and chase external things seek extraordinary fame. Yet extraordinary fame arises from what is constant. Thus, the learner does not seek the fantastical—fantastical things arise from learning. Ritual is not for ornamentation—yet ornamentation arises from ritual. This is the principle the perfected man cannot help but accept, so he treats such things as his own fetters.

**[Subcommentary]** *Seek* means *pursue*. *Strange and fantastical* means *bizarre and cunning*. *Shackles* refers to restraints: those for the hands are called *gui*, and those for the feet are called *ju*—what we now call *fetters*. That Confucius, bound to the path of the sages, studies bizarre and cunning things, chasing illusory fame—does he not know that the man who embodies the Dao beyond the world uses such teachings as his own bonds?

Lao Dan said, "Why not simply lead him to see life and death as a single thread, right and wrong as a single strand, and thus free him from his shackles?"

**[Commentary]** He wishes to guide him with direct principle, hoping he will cease his striving.

**[Subcommentary]** When Wuzhi previously met Confucius, why did he not urge him to forget benevolence and righteousness, merge life and death, and equalize right and wrong? Once these distinctions dissolve, the bonds will loosen—would this not free him from his fetters?

Wuzhi said, "Heaven has punished him—how can it be undone?"

**[Commentary]** Confucius is not unenlightened. Yet the principle of nature is such that actions cast shadows, and words echo. To follow things is to establish fame, yet following things is not for fame. If not for fame, one attains perfection—yet fame cannot be avoided. Who, then, can free him from it? Fame is but an echo and shadow, and echoes and shadows are the shackles of form and sound. Understanding this, fame can be forgotten; forgetting fame, the pursuit of externals can be severed; severing the pursuit of externals, one’s nature and life can be preserved whole.

**[Subcommentary]** Confucius revered the laws of Wen and Wu, followed the ways of Yao and Shun, edited the *Book of Songs* and *Book of Documents*, established rituals and music, endured hardship in Chen and Cai, and was besieged in Shang and Zhou. Clinging to benevolence and righteousness, he suffered humiliation and punishment.

Just as movement brings shadows in tow and speech elicits echoes in response, this is the natural course, the fitting consequence that must follow. Thus, once contention arises, flaws and strife inevitably emerge—how could one avoid exhaustion and ruin? Therefore, the punishment of Heaven’s natural law cannot be undone.

Duke Ai of Lu asked Confucius: “In Wei there was an ugly man named Ai Taituo.” **[Annotation]** *E* 恶 means "ugly." **[Subcommentary]** *E* 恶 means "ugly." It is said that in the state of Wei there was a man whose appearance was grotesque, yet his inner virtue was full, and he was revered by the common people. Duke Ai, hearing of his ugliness, took it as his name. Wherever men dwelled with him, they longed for him and could not bear to leave. When women saw him, they pleaded with their parents, saying, “I would rather be this man’s concubine than another’s wife”—and this occurred ten times over without cease. **[Subcommentary]** A *wife* (妻) is one who stands equal (齐) to her husband; a *concubine* (妾) is one who merely attends (接) to the gentleman. Ai Taituo’s talent was complete and his virtue full, so all things turned to him as their refuge. He so perfectly accorded with all beings that they forgot his ugliness. Thus, men who lived with him cherished him and could not bring themselves to depart, while women, admiring his talent and virtue, vied to become his concubines. That this occurred ten times without cease shows how many were drawn to his righteousness; that none sought to be his wife demonstrates how his Dao could move all things.

He never initiated speech but only responded to others. **[Subcommentary]** He concealed his brilliance and concealed his beginnings, humbly placing himself behind others. He merely answered in harmony, never leading or provoking speech.

He held no lordly position to save others from death. **[Annotation]** This shows that people did not follow him because of authority. **[Subcommentary]** A lord is one who can pardon transgressions, absolve crimes, and protect life. Yet Ai Taituo, though poor and a commoner, held no throne, no power, no authority to aid others—showing that his appeal did not stem from might.

He had no wealth to fill others’ bellies. **[Annotation]** This shows that people did not follow him for food. **[Subcommentary]** Storing grain in granaries and amassing wealth is how one attracts followers, hoping to fill their stomachs. Yet Ai Taituo had no such wealth—how then could he draw people? This shows that they were drawn to his righteousness, not to food.

Moreover, his ugliness shocked the world. **[Annotation]** This shows that people did not follow him for his appearance. **[Subcommentary]** Ai Taituo’s form was extraordinarily vile; his ugliness startled all under Heaven. This makes clear that the crowds did not gather because of his beauty.

He harmonized but did not lead. **[Annotation]** He did not summon them but was sought. **[Subcommentary]** Like the echo in a deep valley, he responded without intent, never using words to entice or provoke, never initiating speech before others.

His knowledge did not extend beyond the four bounds. **[Annotation]** He did not exert his thoughts beyond his proper sphere. **[Subcommentary]** *Bounds* (域) means "limits." With a mind free of contrivance and a nature true to itself, he never strained his thoughts or extended his concerns beyond the four directions.

Yet male and female creatures gathered before him. **[Annotation]** One whose talent is complete harms nothing, so when he enters a herd of beasts, they do not scatter; when he enters a flock of birds, they do not disperse. Thus, he becomes a forest and marsh for all things. **[Subcommentary]** *Male and female* refers to birds and beasts. A man of complete talent moves with all things, harboring no intent to harm, so creatures feel no fear of him. Thus, birds and beasts gathered before him.

There must have been something extraordinary about him. **[Subcommentary]** First, he had no authority; second, no wealth; third, no beauty; fourth, no persuasive speech; fifth, no far-reaching schemes. None of these things drew people to him—yet Ai Taituo was sought by all. Since he did not rely on these five things, this proves he was no ordinary man.

I summoned him to observe him, and indeed, his ugliness shocked the world. When he stayed with me, before a month had passed, I sensed something profound in his character. **[Annotation]** Before a month had passed, I already perceived his depth. **[Subcommentary]** Having heard of his extraordinary nature, I ordered him summoned. His appearance was indeed grotesque, shocking all under Heaven. Yet after sharing his company for no more than twenty days, observing his conduct and discerning his intent, I found his spirit serene and his insight far-reaching.

Before a full year had passed, I trusted him completely. When my state had no minister, I offered him the governance of the realm. **[Annotation]** I entrusted him with the state’s affairs. **[Subcommentary]** As days and months passed, my understanding of him deepened. Thus, after a year in his company, I placed my full trust in him. With no worthy minister to govern, I sought to enlist this worthy man and entrust him with the state’s affairs.

He responded only after a long silence. **[Annotation]** Neither favor nor disgrace could disturb his spirit. **[Subcommentary]** His delayed response was an unguarded demeanor, a sign of his emptiness and tranquility. Unmoved by profit or rank, how could he be swayed by worldly honors? Thus, he answered only after a pause, as if unaware.

His words were as if drifting. **[Annotation]** He spoke as others spoke. **[Subcommentary]** *Drifting* suggests an aimless, unanchored manner. Though unmoved by favor or disgrace, he remained humble and yielding, so his words were no different from those of ordinary men.

I felt ashamed and ultimately entrusted him with the state. Before long, he left me and departed. I grieved as if I had lost something, as if there were no one with whom to share the joy of ruling this state. What manner of man was he? **[Subcommentary]** *Ashamed* (愧) means "to feel remorse." *Ultimately* (卒) means "in the end." *Before long* (无几何) means "in a brief moment." *Grieved* (恤) means "to sorrow." *I* (寡人) is the humble title of one of the five ranks. Having met this worthy man, I felt my own shallowness and was moved by admiration. In the end, I wished to entrust him with the state’s governance and make him my chief minister. Yet in a brief moment, he fled and vanished. Losing such a worthy minister filled me with sorrow; my spirit was unsettled, as if something had been lost. Though I ruled the state of Lu, I found no joy in it.

The joy of his coming and the sorrow of his going moved me so deeply—what manner of man was he, and from what land, that he could affect me thus?

Confucius said: Once, when I was traveling in Chu, I chanced to see a piglet nursing from its dead mother. After a brief moment, the entire litter abandoned her and fled. They did so because they no longer saw their likeness in her, no longer found kinship in her. For the living recognize their kind by talent and virtue; when these depart in death, the living turn away, having lost their kind.

Thus, those whose virtue is profoundly rooted are like newborn infants—wherever they go, they remain as infants to the world. None in the world would harm them, for they have found their kind and made themselves known. If the heart shares kinship, even if the form differs, things will not harm it; if the heart lacks kinship, even if the form is that of mother and child, it is not enough to secure their bond.

**[Subcommentary]** Duke Ai recounted his feelings to ask Confucius, who answered with the parable of the piglet: I once led my disciples through the land of Chu and happened to see a piglet nursing from its dead mother. In the blink of an eye, after but a short while, they abandoned their dead mother and scattered in flight. They did so because they no longer saw their likeness in her. Thus, as Guo’s commentary notes, the living recognize their kind by talent and virtue; when these depart in death, the living flee, having lost their kind. This is like Duke Ai, who, possessing no talent or virtue, was not of their kind, and so was abandoned. Yet when talent and virtue are complete, as in an infant, the world’s affection is naturally secured. What is loved in a mother is not her form, but that which animates her form.

**[Annotation]** *That which animates the form* refers to talent and virtue.
**[Subcommentary]** As Guo’s commentary notes, *that which animates the form* is talent and virtue. And talent and virtue are the spirit. The piglet loves its mother for her spirit; the people admire their lord for his talent and virtue.

Those who die in battle are not buried with their armor;
**[Annotation]** *Armor* (婴) is what warriors rely upon. Those who die in battle have no use for armor—where would it be applied?
Nor are the shoes of the mutilated cherished;
**[Annotation]** Shoes are cherished for the sake of the feet. Here, the root is gone.
**[Annotation]** *Armor and shoes* rely on the feet and martial prowess as their root.
**[Subcommentary]** *Armor* (婴) is the adornment of warriors, created by King Wu—or some say by the Duke of Zhou. Its shape resembles a square fan, decorating both sides of a chariot. When generals lead troops into battle and die in the breach, their burials do not include armor. Thus, we know armor is what warriors rely upon, just as shoes are used by the feet, and form is animated by the spirit. Without feet, shoes are useless; without martial prowess, armor has no purpose; without spirit, form is unloved. Thus, armor and shoes rely on feet and martial prowess as their root, just as form relies on talent and virtue as its origin. Without these roots, both become useless.

The consorts of the Son of Heaven do not pare their nails or pierce their ears;
**[Annotation]** To preserve their form intact.
Those who take a wife keep her at home and do not send her out to labor;
**[Annotation]** Lest her form be harmed.
**[Subcommentary]** The emperor’s palace selects consorts with care, avoiding pierced ears or pared nails to prevent harm to their form. When a common man marries, he keeps his wife from external affairs, sparing her from labor to preserve her beauty. These analogies illustrate the importance of preserving wholeness.

If the wholeness of form alone suffices to elicit such devotion—
**[Annotation]** The selection of consorts and the joy of new marriage are based on the beauty of form.
Then how much more so for one whose virtue is complete?
**[Annotation]** When virtue is complete, the world naturally loves them.
**[Subcommentary]** *Thus* (尔) means "in this way." If the wholeness of form can humble the noble and move the chaste, how much more so for one whose virtue is complete? This concludes the analogy. As Guo’s commentary notes, *when virtue is complete, the world naturally loves them.*

Now, when Zai Wo arrived, he was trusted before speaking, befriended without merit, and offered the governance of the state—so eager was I for him to accept. He must have been one whose talent was complete and whose virtue was unmanifest.

**[Subcommentary]** Trust is built on words, and closeness on deeds. Yet Zai Wo was entrusted before he spoke, befriended without merit, and Duke Ai, emptying his heart, offered him the state’s governance, humbling himself in deference, fearing only that he would not accept. Such a man must possess complete talent yet attribute his achievements to others, so his virtue remains unseen.

Duke Ai asked: What do you mean by *complete talent*?

Confucius said: Life and death, survival and ruin, poverty and wealth, worthiness and unworthiness, praise and blame, hunger and thirst, cold and heat—these are the changes of affairs, the workings of fate. Their principles are fixed and inescapable.

Thus, human life is not a mistake; what life brings is always fitting. Though heaven and earth are vast and the myriad things numerous, what I encounter is precisely what is meant for me. Even the gods of heaven and earth, the sages of the state, with all their strength and wisdom, cannot alter it. Therefore, what one does not encounter, one cannot encounter; what one encounters, one cannot avoid. What one does not do, one cannot do; what one does, one cannot refrain from doing. Thus, one must accept it as it is.

**[Subcommentary]** Though the two poles are vast and the myriad things numerous, what one encounters in life is precisely what is meant for them. The eight pairs mentioned above are the transformations of affairs and the flow of heavenly mandate—inescapable, unceasing, unshakable. One must submit to the unfolding.

What one encounters is always fitting. Unless one is a person of full virtue, who could achieve this? This reflects Confucius’ response to Duke Ai on the meaning of "complete talent." Day and night alternate before us.

**[Annotation]** The flow of fate and the transformations of affairs do not align with day or night; they cannot be pushed away, nor can they be halted. Thus, one of complete talent follows what is encountered and accepts it. Yet knowledge cannot plan for their beginning.

**[Annotation]** The beginning is not something knowledge can plan, nor is the past something emotion can cling to. Therefore, those who understand that fate’s flow is inexorable and affairs’ changes are inevitable—how could they scheme for endings by planning beginnings, or cling to the new by longing for the old? Even with the utmost knowledge, they cannot plan for it.

What has passed is gone—what can I do about it?

**[Subcommentary]** The flow of fate and the transformations of affairs are swift as a galloping horse; their succession and flux do not align with day or night. One after another, they cycle endlessly. Even with the utmost knowledge, they cannot be measured—how could one cling to the new or long for the old, plan for endings by scheming at beginnings? This is not the case. Only by following change and accepting transformation can one be free and at ease in all circumstances.

Thus, it does not disturb harmony.

**[Annotation]** If one truly understands the inherent constancy of nature and fate, then though death and life, poverty and success, undergo a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, one remains serene and composed, with harmony and principle abiding within.

**[Subcommentary]** *Gǔ* means "to disturb." Though affairs shift and fate alters, by following form and yielding to transformation, one remains serene and composed, undisturbed in the Dao of central harmony.

It cannot enter the numinous chamber.

**[Annotation]** The numinous chamber is the dwelling of spirit. The utterly sufficient do not allow cares to pass through their spirit like mere external things.

**[Subcommentary]** The numinous chamber is the dwelling of spirit—what is called the heart-mind. Through cold and heat, order and chaos, a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, one moves with things as they pass, never harboring intent—how could it concern the heart-mind?

This brings harmony and ease, allowing free flow without losing joy.

**[Annotation]** If one keeps harmony undisturbed and the numinous chamber at ease, then though one traverses the utmost changes, one does not lose this joy.

**[Subcommentary]** *Duì* means "joyful." Whether in poverty or success, life or death, one ensures that all encounters are harmonious and joyful, the center at ease. Through peril and safety, one remains joyfully self-possessed, never losing this contentment.

This allows day and night to continue without interruption.

**[Annotation]** To be utterly at one with it.

**[Subcommentary]** *Nà* means "interruption." Flowing and turning without cease, day and night unbroken, each thought linked to the next, without any gap.

And to be spring for all things.

**[Annotation]** To be what all living beings depend upon.

**[Subcommentary]** With compassion illuminating all life, grace extending to the moving and the still, one bestows kindness upon things, making all affairs like the verdant spring.

This is to generate timeliness in the heart-mind.

**[Annotation]** To transform in accord with the four seasons.

**[Subcommentary]** *This* refers to what was stated above. The person of complete talent aids and sustains all beings, nurturing the myriad things, responding to and following the seasons with a heart-mind that is no-heart-mind, illuminating by attuning to the moment.

This is called "complete talent."

**[Subcommentary]** Summarizing the above, this is the meaning of "complete talent."

What is meant by "virtue unmanifest"?

**[Subcommentary]** Having grasped "complete talent," one has yet to realize the meaning of "virtue unmanifest." Thus, the question is posed again, that the subsequent purport may be heard.

It is said: Levelness is the fullness of still water.

**[Annotation]** Of all levelness in the world, none is more perfect than still water.

**[Subcommentary]** *Tíng* means "still." Of all levelness in the world, none is more perfect than still water. Thus, the earlier text states: "People do not mirror themselves in flowing water but in still water." This is raised as an analogy to illuminate the meaning of "virtue unmanifest."

**[Annotation]** Being without emotion, it attains perfect levelness—thus the world takes it as the standard. Within, it preserves itself; without, it does not sway.

**[Annotation]** Within, it preserves its clarity; without, it is free from emotional falsity. Its profound mirroring penetrates all, impartial toward things. Thus it perfects its levelness and enacts its model.

**[Subcommentary]** Now, the nature of water is limpid and clear, mirroring all things. Though the master craftsman be skilled, without water he cannot level. Therefore, one who can preserve its clarity without rippling may serve as the rule for artisans, discerning beauty and ugliness with unobstructed vision. Hence the subsequent text states: "Water is level and serves as the standard; the great craftsman takes it as his model." How much more so the perfected person, who darkly unites with the Dao and harmonizes his radiance with things, serving as the pattern for the multitudes? Moving yet ever still, this is what is meant by "within, it preserves itself; without, it does not sway."

Virtue is the cultivation of completion and harmony.

**[Annotation]** That by which affairs are completed and things are harmonized is called *virtue*.

**[Subcommentary]** Who but one of abundant virtue can bring all affairs to completion and harmonize the myriad things? First, one must cultivate the self and establish conduct; only then can one complete affairs and harmonize things. Only when virtue is harmonious and I do not lose myself may it be called *virtue*.

"Virtue unmanifest" means things cannot depart from it.

**[Annotation]** Nothing is left incomplete, nothing left disharmonious—this is the unmanifest nature of virtue. Thus the world delights in exalting it without weariness.

**[Subcommentary]** One whose illumination rivals the sun and moon yet returns brightness to the dim, whose merit parallels creation yet ascribes achievement to things—this is the unmanifest nature of virtue. Thus one of profound virtue is likened to an infant; the world delights in exalting him without weariness, and nothing departs from him.

Duke Ai later told Minzi: "At first, I faced south as ruler of the world, holding the people’s guiding threads and fearing their death. I considered myself most penetrating. Now, having heard the words of the perfected person, I fear I lack their substance, have lightly used my body, and lost my state. Confucius and I are not lord and minister—we are friends in virtue alone."

**[Annotation]** One who hears the wind of virtue’s fullness, though he be Duke Ai, still wishes to cast off his bodily form and forget nobility and baseness.

**[Subcommentary]** His surname was Min, given name Sun, courtesy name Ziqian. A disciple of Confucius, he ranked among the Four Categories and was greatly filial—a man of Lu. *Yiri* means "another day." *Nanmian* refers to the ruler’s position. Initially, the duke was unenlightened, proud in his rule of Lu, holding fast to the state’s guiding threads and worrying over the masses, nurturing and instructing them lest they die young. By this governance, he deemed himself most excellent and penetrating. Now, hearing Confucius’ discourse and the meaning of talent and virtue, the Duke of Lu awakened and recognized his former errors. His penetrating words about fearing death now seemed illusory; his grand rule as a south-facing lord held no true record. Thus he cast off his limbs, dimmed his brilliance, relinquished rank, forgot titles, saw the state of Lu as a snail’s horn, and regarded his own form as a fleeting shadow. He befriended Confucius to perfect his virtue and honored him as Minister of Justice to distinguish their non-hierarchical bond. Thus we know the discourse of Zhuangzi and Laozi is lofty and pure, and the beauty of virtue’s fullness reaches this extreme.

When the hunchbacked, cleft-lipped man without lips spoke to Duke Ling of Wei, the duke was pleased; yet when he saw a whole person, his neck seemed slender. When the man with a jar-like goiter spoke to Duke Huan of Qi, the duke was pleased; yet when he saw a whole person, his neck seemed slender.

**[Annotation]** With partial emotion and one-sided attachment, the ugly appears more pleasing and the pleasing more ugly.

**[Subcommentary]** *Chǎn* means crooked—walking with a hunched, swollen gait. *Chún* means lips—his limbs were cracked and split, his body maimed and diseased, and he lacked lips. *Wèng* means jar. *Dòu* means neck. *Jiānjiān* describes something thin and small. The man with disjointed limbs walked on tiptoe; the man with a goiter had a growth as large as a jar.

These two men embodied the utmost ugliness under heaven, yet both could transcend form to establish virtue, embody their Dao, and discourse on the profound. Thus they moved the lords of Qi and Wei to revere their influence and delight in their presence, admiring their abundant virtue—unaware of deformity or ugliness, and turning to regard the necks of whole men as if they were thin and small.

For where virtue excels, form is forgotten.
**[Annotation]** When virtue excels in harmonizing with things, others forget their ugliness; when it excels in opposing things, others forget their beauty.

**[Subcommentary]** Though emaciated and maimed, their virtue was vast and far-reaching, so that the lords of Qi and Wei forgot their physical repulsiveness. Yet men forget what should be forgotten and remember what should not—this is called true forgetting.

**[Annotation]** They cherish life but discard the dead.

Thus virtue is what the world does not forget, while form is what principle does not preserve. Therefore, to forget form is not true forgetting; only to remember form while forgetting virtue is true forgetting.

**[Subcommentary]** *Chéng* means real. What is forgotten is form; what is not forgotten is virtue. Forgetting form is easy, forgetting virtue is difficult—hence form is called "what should be forgotten," and virtue "what should not be forgotten." To remember form while forgetting virtue is true forgetting. This is the meaning of virtue transcending form.

Thus the sage wanders freely,
**[Annotation]** Wandering in the realm of self-attainment, unfettered and boundless—his talent and virtue are complete.

**[Subcommentary]** Abandoning both self and things, forgetting both form and virtue, he roams the field of transformation and soars in the realm of ultimate emptiness.

Yet knowledge becomes a snare, restraint a glue, virtue a bond, and craft a merchant.
**[Annotation]** These four arise naturally from one another; their principle is already complete.

**[Subcommentary]** The perfected one’s Dao transcends the Three Clarities and his spirit roams the Six Directions. Thus he wields wisdom to dispel calamity, imposes restraint to curb distraction, cultivates virtue to embrace all beings, and employs skill to benefit all creatures. These four exist among the common people, yet the great sage, in his compassion, harmonizes with the dust and follows things.

The sage does not scheme—why employ knowledge? He does not sever—why employ glue? He suffers no loss—why employ virtue? He does not trade—why employ commerce?
**[Annotation]** Nature is already complete.

Thus the sage has no use for his own abilities.
**[Subcommentary]** *Wū* means "why." The perfected one does not scheme against calamity—why use wisdom? He does not carve or destroy—why use restraint? He has not lost the Dao—why employ virtue? He does not value rare goods—why labor as a merchant? All this is to harmonize with the light and blend with things, hence their existence.

These four are the fasting of the heavens. The fasting of the heavens is the food of the heavens.
**[Annotation]** They are naturally endowed.

**[Subcommentary]** *Cháng* means "to eat." *Shí* means "to examine." *Tiān* means "nature." The preceding four exist among the people, endowed by nature, each following its own nature. The sage complies with them, thus having no use for his own abilities. Having received sustenance from heaven, why employ man?

**[Annotation]** When endowment is natural, its principle is already sufficient. Though one may ponder deeply to avoid disaster or clearly admonish to evade misfortune, nothing occurs without reason—all are the convergence of heaven and earth, the direction of ultimate principle. Whether one ponders and escapes, or ponders and does not escape; whether one does not ponder and escapes, or does not ponder and does not escape—none of this is of me. What is there to do? Let it be, and it will come of itself.

**[Subcommentary]** Endowment is natural, each with its fixed portion. Why add extraneous human sentiment? To defy heaven and rely on man is to invite regret.

He has the form of a man,
**[Annotation]** His appearance resembles that of a man.

Yet lacks the feelings of a man.
**[Annotation]** Like the branch of a withered tree.

**[Subcommentary]** The sage, dwelling in the world, bears the form of a living being; embodying the Dao in emptiness, he is free from the feelings of right and wrong. Having the form of a man, he mingles with men,
**[Annotation]** Like attracts like, and kind gathers with kind—this is the natural way.

**[Subcommentary]** Harmonizing with the light and blending with the dust, he gathers among the worldly. This explains "having the form of a man."

Lacking the feelings of a man, right and wrong cannot adhere to him.
**[Annotation]** Without feelings, he entrusts all to things.

**[Subcommentary]** Like the numinous immortals, devoid of consciousness; having forgotten both self and things, how can right and wrong exist? This explains "lacking the feelings of a man."

How minute and small—thus he belongs to mankind.
**[Annotation]** His form resembles that of a man.

**[Subcommentary]** *Shǔ* means "to belong." Pitiful and constrained, his form is bound to the human realm, no different from other things—hence he is called minute and small. This concludes the meaning of "having the form of a man."

How vast and great—alone he completes his heaven.
**[Annotation]** Without feelings, he is vast and unfettered, unrestrained in all things. What the emotional cannot achieve, he achieves without feelings—thus alone he completes his heaven.

**[Subcommentary]** *Jǐng* means "lofty and great." Vast and boundless, he forgets all realms; his wisdom and virtue are profound, his illumination far-reaching. Thus he surpasses the noble and great, alone fulfilling the perfection of nature. This concludes the meaning of "lacking the feelings of a man."

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi: "Do men truly have no feelings?"
**[Subcommentary]** The preceding text states, "He has the form of a man, yet lacks the feelings of a man." Hui Shi cited this to raise a question: Are those whom Zhuangzi calls "men" truly without feelings?

Zhuangzi said: "Yes."
**[Subcommentary]** *Rán* means "so." He affirmed the question, thus answering "yes."

Hui Shi said: "If a man has no feelings, how can he be called a man?"

**[Subcommentary]** If one lacks the wisdom of nature, how can he be called a man? This is Hui Shi’s further challenge to Zhuangzi.

Zhuangzi said: The Dao bestows upon him his appearance, Heaven grants him his form—how can he not be called a man?

**[Annotation]** Man’s life does not arise from feeling; what life knows is not what feeling knows. Thus, though one may feel the desire to become detached and free, he cannot; yet the detached and free attain clarity through their absence of feeling. Though one may feel the desire to become worthy and sagely, he cannot; yet the worthy and sagely become so through their absence of feeling. Is it only that the worthy and sagely are remote and the detached and free are hard to emulate? Even the dullest, the deaf, the blind, the crowing of roosters, the barking of dogs—none can achieve these things through feeling. Whether distant or near, even if separated by but a hair’s breadth, in the space between brow and eye, none can attain them. Thus, when the myriad things are considered, one returns to the self: the ears and eyes cannot exchange their tasks to succeed, nor can the hands and feet substitute for one another in their duties. When an infant first comes into the world, it does not seek milk with its eyes, turn toward light with its ears, grasp objects with its feet, or crawl with its hands. How could the hundred limbs lack fixed functions, the form and appearance lack an inherent master, and all be governed solely by feeling?

**[Subcommentary]** *Wū* means "how." The Dao of emptiness and penetration shapes his appearance; the principle of nature bestows his form. With both form and appearance, how can he not be called a man? Moreover, form and appearance are not distinct. The Dao and nature merely alternate in their phrasing. To clarify this meaning, the point is reiterated.

Hui Shi said: If he is called a man, how can he be without feeling?

**[Annotation]** He has not yet understood that form and appearance are not feeling.

**[Subcommentary]** If he is named a man, he must possess feeling and thought. If he lacks feeling, how can he be called a man? This shows that Hui Shi has not yet grasped that form and appearance are not feeling.

Zhuangzi said: This is not what I mean by feeling.

**[Annotation]** If right and wrong are considered feeling, then one who is without right and wrong, without likes and dislikes—though he has form and appearance—is merely a man; where, then, does feeling reside?

**[Subcommentary]** What I call feeling refers to right and wrong, self and other, likes and dislikes, resentments and aversions. If one is without right and wrong, though he has form and appearance, he is merely a man—where, then, does feeling reside? What I mean by "without feeling" is that a man does not inwardly harm his body with likes and dislikes.

**[Annotation]** To proceed directly according to what is fitting is not feeling.

**[Subcommentary]** When Zhuangzi speaks of "without feeling," he does not mean one is like wood or stone. Rather, he means one does not allow likes and dislikes to disturb his thoughts beyond their proper bounds, thus preserving his nature and inwardly ordering his body. Why is this so? It is the wisdom of storing emptiness and illumination—the feeling of no-feeling. One constantly follows nature and does not augment life.

**[Annotation]** To stop at what is fitting.

**[Subcommentary]** One follows the principle of nature as a constant; one stops at the limits of what one has received, not knowing the bounds of life.

Hui Shi said: If one does not augment life, how can he have a body?

**[Annotation]** He has not yet understood that life arises of itself and principle is self-sufficient.

**[Subcommentary]** If one does not rely on the Dao of augmenting life, how can he possess this body? This shows he has not yet understood that life arises of itself and principle is self-sufficient.

Zhuangzi said: The Dao bestows upon him his appearance, Heaven grants him his form.

**[Annotation]** The principle of life is already sufficient within form and appearance; one need only follow it, and the body endures.

**[Subcommentary]** The Dao bestows form and appearance, and the principle of life is already sufficient. One need only follow it, without need for deliberate effort.

He does not inwardly harm his body with likes and dislikes.

**[Annotation]** The feelings of likes and dislikes do not augment life; they only suffice to harm the body, for life has its allotted measure.

**[Subcommentary]** This returns to address the earlier question.

Now you externalize your spirit and exhaust your essence, leaning against a tree to chant, resting your head on a withered catalpa to sleep.

**[Annotation]** If the spirit does not rest within the bounds of one’s nature, it becomes external; if essence does not stop at the limit of one’s natural life, it becomes exhausted. Thus, when walking, one leans against a tree to chant; when sitting, one rests on a catalpa to sleep—this describes how those with feeling bring trouble upon themselves.

**[Subcommentary]** *Gǎo wú* refers to a lacquered armrest. Hui Shi has not abandoned the snares and traps of conventional learning; he is deeply attached to ordinary principles, externalizing his spirit and exhausting his essence. Thus, when walking, he leans against a tree to chant; when sitting, he rests on an armrest to discourse. In this way, his form is wearied and his mind fatigued, leading to weariness and sleep.

Heaven has chosen your form, yet you clamor with "hard" and "white."

**[Annotation]** All that you do—externalizing your spirit, exhausting your essence, leaning against trees, resting on catalpas, chanting and sleeping—this is what the world calls feeling. Yet to say "Heaven has chosen" makes clear that feeling does not arise from feeling, let alone anything else. Thus, though the myriad things take myriad forms, their actions and choices all arise within the absence of feeling—what use is feeling in such matters?

**[Subcommentary]** *Xuǎn* means "to bestow." *Wū* means "to speak." The Dao of nature bestows your form; whether short-lived or long-lived, beautiful or ugly, the principle is already fixed. There is no need for deliberate effort or augmenting life beyond its bounds. Yet you, endowed with a keen nature, dissect and clarify principles, clinging to your own virtue and flaunting it before others. How is this different from Gongsun Long composing the *Discourse on the White Horse*, claiming that a white horse is not a horse, rigidly upholding this argument to exalt himself? His words may convince others’ mouths, but they cannot convince their hearts. Now your boastful discourse beyond proper bounds is of the same kind.

**[Textual Variants]**
