**[Annotation]** The rites of the mundane world value restraint and decorum. Even neighbors in mourning do not pound grain for one another. How much less should one face the corpse of a friend without grief or weeping, playing the zither and singing as if nothing were amiss? Is this not a breach of ritual? Zigong, astonished by their conduct, hurried forward to question them.

The two looked at each other and laughed, saying, "How could he know the meaning of ritual?"

**[Annotation]** One who understands the meaning of ritual roams beyond to order what is within, guards the mother to preserve the child, and follows the promptings of the heart without deviation. If one is bound by reputation and constrained by form, then filial piety cannot be sincere, compassion cannot be genuine, and fathers and sons, brothers and kin, will harbor feelings and deceive one another. How could this be the great meaning of ritual?

**[Annotation]** The great ritual moves in harmony with Heaven and Earth, unbound by form or name. It attains its end by following truth, proceeding as the heart dictates. How much more so when one profoundly unites life and death—how could grief or joy remain in the breast? Yet Zigong is a Confucian scholar of the mundane world, his nature still partial and rigid, valuing only superficial refinement, not yet attuned to the subtle root. How could such a one fathom the depth of ritual? It is only fitting that those beyond the world should mock him.

Zigong returned and reported to Confucius, saying, "What manner of men are they? They cultivate no conduct, yet disregard their physical forms. They sing before the corpse, their countenances unchanged. I have no words to describe them. What manner of men are they?"

**[Annotation]** *Ming* means "name." Zigong returned and told the Master: "Those two are difficult to fathom. They cultivate no virtue or conduct, yet forget their physical forms, merging life and death. They sing and rejoice before the dead, their spirit and form unchanged. Since their Way cannot be grasped, it is hard to name them."

Confucius said, "They roam beyond the bounds; I roam within them."

**[Annotation]** Principle has its ultimate limit, and what is within and beyond interpenetrate. There has never been one who attained the utmost in roaming beyond yet did not interpenetrate with what is within, nor one who interpenetrated with what is within yet did not roam beyond. Thus the sage constantly roams beyond to broaden what is within, responds without intention to what is, and though he moves his form all day, his spirit and qi remain unchanged. Though he attends to the myriad affairs, he remains serene and at ease. To see the form but not the spirit—this is the common affliction of the world. Thus, when one sees him moving among things, none can say he has left things behind and departed from men. When one observes him transforming in response to affairs, none can say he sits in forgetfulness and attains self-mastery. How could this apply only to the sage? It is rather that the utmost principle has no such distinctions. Therefore, Zhuangzi, in clarifying the lineage to which the tradition belongs to awaken the world, does not directly attribute this to Confucius. Otherwise, some might rely on their own views to reject it. Thus he transcends the sage’s inner realm and entrusts the teaching to those beyond the bounds. One should forget the vehicle of this entrustment to seek the great meaning of the work’s composition. Then the Way of roaming beyond to broaden what is within will be clearly evident, and the *Zhuangzi* will indeed be seen as a discourse that traverses the vulgar and surpasses the world.

**[Annotation]** *Fang* means "realm." Those two equalize life and death, unbound by the constraints of teaching and conduct, and thus roam their hearts beyond the cosmos. Yet Confucius and Zigong are great Confucians of their age, practicing the rites of mourning and observing the decorum of ritual, their minds fixed on grief and joy, their hearts bound within the realm. This is why they differ.

What is within and beyond do not reach one another, yet I sent you to offer condolences—how shallow I am!

**[Annotation]** Offering condolences is a minor affair of the mundane world; to apply it to those beyond is shallow indeed.

**[Annotation]** The profound and the Confucian are separated by principle, their Ways distinct. Judged by superiority and inferiority, they do not reach one another. To use the vulgar rites of the mundane realm to offer condolences to those beyond is like reusing a straw dog—how utterly base! They, however, join with the Creator as companions and roam in the single qi of Heaven and Earth.

**[Annotation]** All is merged, thus there is no duality.

**[Annotation]** They comprehend the transformations of yin and yang and join with the Creator as companions. They embody the unity of the myriad things and roam in the single qi of the two poles.

They regard life as an excrescence or dangling tumor,

**[Annotation]** Like a tumor that hangs of itself, an excrescence that attaches of itself—this is the accidental fruition of qi, not what they delight in.

and death as the bursting of a tumor or the draining of an abscess,

**[Annotation]** Like a tumor that bursts of itself, an abscess that drains of itself—this is the natural dispersal of qi, not what they regret.

**[Annotation]** These three are men who embody the Dao, who comprehend life and death and merge with transformation. Thus, when qi gathers and life arises, it is like an excrescence or tumor attaching and hanging—nothing they delight in. When qi scatters and death comes, it is like a tumor bursting or an abscess draining—nothing they regret.

If this is so, how could they know where life and death, superiority and inferiority, lie?

**[Annotation]** Life and death alternate without end. Moving with them, there is nowhere one cannot go, and thus one does not know where victory or defeat lies.

**[Annotation]** *Xian* means "superior," *hou* means "inferior." An excrescence, a tumor, an abscess—these four are all ailments, yet qi gathers and scatters, and the illness has no victory or defeat. If one compares this to life and death, how can one know where superiority or inferiority lie?

They borrow from other things and entrust themselves to the same body.

**[Annotation]** *Jia* means "to rely on." Now life and death, gathering and scattering, change without pattern—all are other things. There is nothing other that is not relied upon, and thus what is relied upon, though other, together forms a single body.

The elements—water, fire, metal, wood—though disparate things, borrow from one another; the myriad forms lodge together, jointly composing a single body. Thus we know the physical form has always been empty and false. Forget the liver and gallbladder; abandon the ears and eyes.

**[Annotation]** Entrust them to principle and proceed in darkness.

**[Annotation]** Once one knows the bodily form is hollow and false, nothing remains to delight or cling to. Thus inwardly one forgets the organs and viscera, outwardly forgets the sense-gates.

Revolving through beginning and end, one knows not where the thread begins or the boundary lies.

**[Annotation]** When even the five viscera are forgotten, what thing remains to be recognized? Never having possessed discernment, one may release the self upon the path of transformation, darkly merging with the waves of reversal, never knowing where beginning or end reaches its limit.

**[Annotation]** *Duan* means "thread," *ni* means "boundary." *Fanfu* means "coming and going"; *zhongshi* means "life and death." Having forgotten the bodily form and dismissed the faculties, one may go and come with life and death, moving together with transformation. Since transformation has no limit, none can know its thread or boundary.

Vague and wandering beyond the dust and grime, carefree in the work of non-action.

**[Annotation]** The so-called work of non-action is not mere folded-hands silence; the so-called beyond the dust and grime is not hiding in the mountains and forests.

**[Annotation]** *Mangran* describes the appearance of unknowing. *Panghuang* and *xiaoyao* are both names for self-possessed ease. Dust and grime are the things of effort—forms, sounds, and the like. Having already relinquished the bodily frame, one here further forgets the mind’s cunning, thus roaming beyond the dust’s burdens, at ease in the realm of clarity and emptiness, making non-action one’s enterprise. How could such a one fret over the rites of the vulgar world to display before the eyes and ears of the crowd?

**[Annotation]** What they display before the crowd are merely the dust and grime, not the dark things beyond form.

**[Annotation]** *Fenfen* means "disturbed." These several persons, pure and lofty, empty and serene, arrange nothing against transformation, following nature and entrusting themselves to truth. How could they force themselves to observe ritual refinements and be bound by the rites of the vulgar world?

The display of solemn demeanor delights the eyes and ears of the crowd. Zigong said: "In that case, what path does the Master follow?"

**[Annotation]** Zigong had not heard of *xing* and the Dao of Heaven, so he saw what the Master followed but not *how* he followed it.

What he followed was no following—how could the world perceive this?

**[Annotation]** Within the realm and beyond it, depths differ; he did not know which Way the Master adhered to. The exchange between teacher and disciple gave rise to this doubt.

The Master said: "Qiu is one punished by Heaven."

**[Annotation]** Within the realm, one is like the cassia or the tangerine—what is prized lies beyond it. Those who roam beyond depend on what is within; those who depart from others conform to the vulgar. Thus, one who possesses the world does not take the world as his heart’s concern. Only after relinquishing things can one enter the multitude; only after sitting in forgetfulness can one respond to affairs. The more one relinquishes, the more one attains. If one abides in this ultimate state, though one may wish to cast it aside, principle will naturally come—this is what neither Heaven nor man can pardon.

**[Annotation]** The sage’s exposition of ritual and propriety is like the cassia or tangerine in form and nature. Since Confucius adhered to what lies within the realm, he was by principle one punished by Heaven. Thus, the *Dechong* chapter says, "How can one escape Heaven’s punishment?" Nevertheless, I share this with you.

**[Annotation]** Though he was utterly condemned by the world, he simply shared it with you—showing that he himself dwelt beyond.

**[Annotation]** Confucius, the sage, blended his light to engage with things, riding the waves in harmony with the world, prizing these vulgar rites. Though he descended to expound what lies within the realm and shared it with you, his mind roamed beyond it, detached and unconfined.

Zigong said: "May I ask about this path?"

**[Annotation]** He asked about the meaning of roaming beyond while sharing what lies within.

**[Annotation]** *Fang* means "Way." He asked: though he expounded within the mixed realm, his mind roamed beyond it—how did the inner and outer mysteriously unite?

Confucius said: "Fish come together in water; men come together in the Dao."

**[Annotation]** *Zao* means "to go to." What fish go to is nothing more fitting to their nature than deep water; what men reach is nothing more fulfilling than the defense of the Dao. Though their emotions and wisdom differ, all alike do so. This briefly sets forth the principle; the explanation follows below.

Those who come together in water dig ponds to secure their sustenance; those who come together in the Dao attain stability without effort.

**[Annotation]** Though what they come to differs, all alike, by doing nothing, achieve their ends—from beyond the realm they share what lies within. Only thus do they secure sustenance and settle into mastery. None fail to do so; they simply remain unaware, and so perfect non-action.

**[Annotation]** This explains the preceding principle. The great rivers, lakes, and seas are all called "heavenly ponds." Fish in the vast waters dwell in mud and sand, drawing from them their nourishment and supply. So too do men abide in the great Dao, nurturing their nature through clarity and emptiness, at ease without affairs, and thus attain the stillness and peace of their inherent nature. Hence it is said: fish forget one another in rivers and lakes; men forget one another in the defense of the Dao.

**[Annotation]** When each is self-sufficient, they forget one another—none in the world is otherwise. The perfected man is ever sufficient, and so ever forgetful.

**[Annotation]** This further explains the preceding principle. In deep waters, fish swim freely, each sufficient and forgetful of the other. Within the defense of the Dao, inner fullness severs partial attachments—how can this be compared to those who chase after the dregs of benevolence and righteousness? Thus the meaning of singing before the corpse.

Zigong said: "May I ask about the *jiren*?"

**[Annotation]** He asked: where are those who, as mentioned before, roam beyond the realm and do not pair with the common?

**[Annotation]** *Ji* means "unpaired." Those who cultivate non-action, distancing themselves from the body and estranged from human relations, do not pair with the common. May I ask about such a one—what is his Way?

Confucius said: "The *jiren* is unpaired among men but companioned by Heaven."

**[Annotation]** Those who inwardly merge with the mysterious roam outwardly. Only one who alone can roam outwardly while merging inwardly, letting the myriad things follow their nature, allowing each Heavenly nature to be fulfilled and the Dao of emperors and kings to be realized—such a one is unpaired among men but companioned by Heaven.

**[Annotation]** From here onward, Confucius answers Zigong. *Companioned* means "equal" or "the same." One who does not cultivate benevolence and righteousness, does not pair with things, but follows his original nature—such a one is the same as the principle of spontaneity. Hence it is said: what is a petty man in Heaven is a noble man among men; what is a noble man among men is a petty man in Heaven.

**[Annotation]** In terms of spontaneity, there are no petty or noble men. In terms of human principles, one companioned by Heaven may be called a noble man.

**[Annotation]** One who embraces transformation and practices righteousness is a noble man; one who deviates from the Dao and violates virtue is a petty man. Thus, those who enact rigid benevolence and employ ostentatious righteousness are called noble men by human standards but petty men by the standards of Heaven. Hence we know that Zifan and Qinzhang, unpaired with the common, are called *jiren*—truly noble men of Heaven. The repetition emphasizes the meaning.

Yan Hui asked Zhongni: "Mengsun Cai, when his mother died, wept without tears, felt no grief in his heart, and did not mourn with sorrow. Lacking these three, he was praised for his mourning.

**[Annotation]** Mengsun Cai was a worthy man of Lu. Embracing the Dao of non-action, he understood that life and death are not two, and so could advance within the realm while his mind roamed beyond it. Though he observed the rites for his mother’s mourning without flaw, his demeanor was composed and refined, full of filial grace—yet his tears did not flow, his heart felt no grief, and his voice held no sorrow. Lacking these three, he was not called a filial son, yet within his village and state, all praised him, saying his mourning was deeply in accord with ritual propriety. Was there indeed one in Lu who gained the name without the reality?"

Yan Hui found this strange.

**[Annotation]** The people of Lu observed his rites, but Yan Hui examined his heart. It was merely an introductory phrase. Wailing and wearing sackcloth were the common customs within the realm; a heart without grief aligned with the forgetfulness beyond it. The people of Lu saw only his outward display, thus granting him the reputation of mourning well; Yan Hui, perceiving his inner heart, knew there was no true filial substance. Therefore, upon seeing Mengsun Cai, he immediately felt doubt and wonder.

Confucius said: "That Mengsun clan has exhausted it—surpassed even knowledge."

**[Annotation]** One who exhausts the principle of life and death, responding to both inner and outer with fitting action, moves in accord with Heaven’s course—none can match such knowledge.

**[Annotation]** *Surpassed* means gone beyond. The Mengsun clan had plumbed the root of joy and sorrow, hence neither joy nor sorrow; they had fathomed the source of life and death, hence forgetting both life and death. Having traced the origin, they could harmonize inner and outer; responding to things without intent, how could this be the proper use of knowledge? Only when one seeks to distinguish and finds no difference—

**[Annotation]** Seeking to distinguish life and death yet finding no difference between them, like the four seasons of spring, summer, autumn, and winter proceeding in their course.

**[Annotation]** Life comes and death departs, like the four seasons—thus Mengsun sought to distinguish but found no difference. Yet he had already made distinctions. The Mengsun clan knew not how they lived, knew not how they died;

**[Annotation]** Having sought distinction yet found none, there was nothing they did not accept. Accepting all, they did not dwell on life and death but entrusted them to natural transformation.

**[Annotation]** Though they had sought to distinguish, they ultimately knew no difference between life and death, thus they could rest in change without allowing joy or sorrow to disturb their hearts. They knew not to cling to what came before, knew not to cling to what came after;

**[Annotation]** They accepted whatever they encountered. Like things transformed—

**[Annotation]** They did not resist transformation.

**[Annotation]** *What came before* refers to life; *what came after*, to death. *Like* means to follow. Having unified life and death, they neither departed nor clung; having merged with transformation, they followed it as things changed. —awaiting the transformations they did not yet know. Had they not already done so?

**[Annotation]** Life and death turn and flow as one with transformation, so that they even forgot what they knew in the present—how could they await what they did not yet know and preemptively grieve?

**[Annotation]** *Transformations they did not yet know* refers to future, unmanifest changes. *Already* means to cease. Even present life is forgotten—how much more the transformations to come? If one were to use the mind to anticipate, it would be better to cease and do nothing. For just as one is about to transform, how can one know it will not transform? Just as one is about to remain untransformed, how can one know it has not already transformed?

**[Annotation]** Having transformed and come to life, how can one know the time before birth? Being in the midst of transformation and facing death, how can one know what comes after death? Thus there is nothing to avoid or cling to, and one goes along with transformation.

**[Annotation]** Just now, in the midst of transforming into a person, how can one know what came before this untransformed state? Just now, alive one day and untransformed the next, how can one know what comes after death? One should simply follow reason and proceed, going along with transformation, without the labor of grieving death while alive or vainly rejoicing or lamenting. "It is only you and I who remain dreaming, never yet awakened.

**[Annotation]** Life and death are but waking and dreaming. Now, if one dreams and takes it for waking, there is no way to prove that waking is not dreaming; if there is no way to prove that waking is not dreaming, then there is also no way to prove that life is not death. Life and death, waking and dreaming—one knows not where they lie. In whatever one encounters, there is nothing that is not self-possessed. Why grieve over this while worrying about that?

**[Annotation]** Dreaming occurs in the stupor of sleep; waking is the clarity of day. Confucius and Yan Hui were still bound by names and teachings, benighted within the realm of waking and dreaming, not yet awakened to life and death. Moreover, he experienced bodily shock without harm to the heart,

**[Annotation]** He took transformation as mere bodily disturbance, thus life and death did not harm or burden his heart.

**[Annotation]** That Mengsun, merged with transformation, saw life and death as mere startling changes to the body, yet ultimately felt no joy or sorrow to burden his spirit. —having a new dwelling each day without the emotion of death.

**[Annotation]** He took the body’s changes as daily renewal of his dwelling, his nature not regarding it as death.

**[Annotation]** *Each day* means daily renewal. *Dwelling* is the abode of the spirit. Because of the body’s changes, he saw his abode as renewed each day, his tranquil spirit undisturbed, ultimately without distinction between life and death. The Mengsun clan alone was awakened; when others wept, he wept too—this was simply what was fitting for him.

**[Annotation]** The perpetually awakened encounter nothing contrary, thus when others wept, he wept too—this was precisely what was fitting for him.

**[Annotation]** Mengsun, unified with life and death, dwelled alone in awakening, responding to inner and outer without transgressing human principles. When others wept, he wept too—this was simply following what was fitting for things. Moreover, all this is "us" to me.

**[Annotation]** Life and death, transformation—all are "us." Since all is "us," what have I lost? Having lost nothing, what cause for sorrow? Without resistance, when others wept, he wept too; without sorrow, though he wept, he was not grieved.

**[Annotation]** Life and death, all is "us"—nothing is not "us," so what have I lost? If one takes attachment to "us" as intent, then what is not "us"? How indeed could one know what I mean by "us"?

**[Annotation]** There is nothing that is not "us," thus inner and outer are mystically one, pervading past and present, daily renewed with transformation—how could one know where "us" resides?

Should myriad transformations unfold, yet I remain constant—whether new self or old self, what cause for joy or aversion? Moreover, you dream of becoming a raven and soaring to the heavens, or of turning into a fish and plunging into the abyss.

**[Annotation]** This speaks of finding fulfillment in every circumstance.

How can one know whether the speaker now is awake or still dreaming?

**[Annotation]** In dreams, one believes oneself awake—how then can we be certain that the present is not a dream, or that it is not wakefulness? Since the shifts between waking and dreaming are without limit, the changes of life and death are nothing to cling to.

**[Annotation]** 厉 means "to reach." Whether as fish or raven, one follows nature and wanders freely, at ease in life or death. Since fish and raven hold no hierarchy, why rank life and death or cling to either? Mengsun mastered this source, thus never troubled his mind.

Moreover, how can we know whether this discourse on fish and raven occurs in waking clarity or in the midst of a dream? In dreams, one takes oneself for awake—how can today’s wakefulness be distinguished from dreaming? Thus, waking, dreaming, life, and death cannot be fixed.

What one attains brings no occasion for laughter; laughter offered brings no occasion for rejection.

**[Annotation]** When all one attains is fitting, one forgets the fitting—thus no cause for laughter. *Pai* means "to shift." Mourning rites and sorrowful wailing, joyful laughter and celebration—when grief or joy linger in the heart, one cannot move with what is fitting. But Mengsun was ever at ease, so though he wept, he felt no sorrow, flowing with transformation.

**[Annotation]** 造 means "to arrive"; 献 means "to offer."

"To *pai* means to shift with change. When all one encounters is fitting, this too is fitting—how could one need joyful laughter to then find delight? If one waits for good fortune to move one before finding fittingness, this is to be unable to follow transformation and shift with things. Now Mengsun was ever fitting, thus though he wept, he felt no sorrow. Abiding in shifting, he departed with transformation, thereby entering the vast oneness of heaven.

**[Annotation]** Abiding in shifting and departing with transformation, one thus enters the silence and vastness, becoming one with heaven.

From this point up to Zisi, their attainment was the same. The mourning they observed differed, hence their songs and wailing were not alike.

**[Annotation]** Wherever one is, all is fitting, thus one abides in shifting with change, never departing from oneself, and departing with transformation. Such a person can enter the wondrous gate of vast emptiness and the singular Dao of spontaneity.

Yier visited Xu You. Xu You said: 'How did Yao aid you?'

**[Annotation]** *Zi* means to supply or assist.

**[Annotation]** Yier was a worthy of antiquity. *Zi* means to supply or assist. Yier first paid homage to Emperor Yao, then met Zhongwu. He was asked: 'Emperor Yao is a great sage, his virtue and power most lofty. Since you have paid him homage, what teachings or aid did he provide? Pray, recount them.'

Yier said: 'Yao told me, "You must personally practice benevolence and righteousness, and clearly speak of right and wrong."'

**[Annotation]** *Gong* means "personally." Benevolence is the nurturing kindness toward things; righteousness is the cutting away of wrong. Right means to clearly reward the good; wrong means to clearly punish the evil. These four are what human relations esteem. You must personally enact them and also clearly speak of them to instruct others.' These words show Yier’s confusion at Yao’s teachings.

Xu You said: 'Then why have you come to court?'"

**[Annotation]** *Er* means "you." *Xi* means "why." *Wei* is a particle."

Yao seeks to instruct you further in the harms of punishments—your wounds are already grievous; why come again? Now that Yao has branded you with benevolence and righteousness and mutilated you with right and wrong, how will you wander the path of boundless freedom, unbridled spontaneity, and ceaseless transformation?

**[Annotation]** This means he will mar himself with the teachings of form, unable to roam again the realm of self-attainment or the unbound Way.

**[Commentary]** *Jing* means "to chisel the forehead." *Yi* means "to cut off the nose." *Zisui* means "unrestrained." *Zhuanxi* means "to change." *Tu* means "Way." Benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong injure the true nature, their harm akin to mutilation by punishment. Now that you have been branded and mutilated by Yao, your nature and feelings constrained, how can you again roam in self-attainment, wander in carefree ease, or move with unhurried freedom along the Way of transformation? This means you can no longer do so.

Yier said: "Even so, I wish to wander its outskirts."

**[Annotation]** Not daring to tread the central Way again, I would be content to wander its borders.

**[Commentary]** Though I suffer this mutilation, my hope remains unabated. No longer daring to walk the heart of the Way, I wish only to tread its outer edges.

Xu You said: "It cannot be. The blind have no part in the beauty of brows, eyes, and countenance; the sightless have no share in the sight of blue and yellow, of *ling* and *bi*."

**[Commentary]** The blind have eyes yet see no things; the sightless have eyes like drumskin, sealed and unseeing. Such people, their eyes already ruined, cannot behold the colors of blue and yellow, nor delight in the beauty of brows, eyes, and countenance. This is like Yier, who, having suffered Yao’s branding and mutilation, has had his nature and wisdom wounded—how can he then cherish the profound and mysterious or behold the manifold wonders?

Yier said: "Though Wu Zhuang lost her beauty, Ju Liang lost his strength, and the Yellow Emperor lost his wisdom, all occurred within the forging of the furnace."

**[Annotation]** This means that not all things in the world are self-complete; the principle of spontaneity sometimes requires smelting and forging to become vessels. Thus, these three, too, having heard the Dao, afterward lost what they had pursued.

This is all figurative speech, to dispel the burden of *yunwei*."

**[Subcommentary]**
Wu Zhuang was a beauty of antiquity who, upon hearing the Dao, no longer adorned herself and thus forgot her own loveliness. Ju Liang was a man of great strength in ancient times who, upon hearing the Dao and embracing femininity, no longer boasted of his power. The Yellow Emperor, Xuanyuan, possessed sagely wisdom, yet upon hearing the Dao, he too was able to relinquish and forsake his knowledge. The *lu* is the furnace; the *chui*, the hammer. These three individuals, having heard the Dao, afterward forgot what they had pursued to accord with their true nature—just as worldly vessels rely on smelting and forging to fulfill their use. Why then should the principle of spontaneity be hindered? Now that you, Master, instruct and enlighten me to perfect my Way, is this not so?

Thus we know that the spontaneous creation of things lies within the workings of the furnace and hammer, which is to say, there is meaning in cultivation, refinement, and forging. How do we know that the Creator does not cease my branding and repair my mutilation, allowing me to mount the completed Way and follow you, Master?

**[Annotation]**
That which proceeds directly and without restraint is spontaneity; yet when such proceeding wounds one’s nature, and one is able to change upon wounding—this too is spontaneity. How do we know that my spontaneity will not cease the branding and repair the mutilation, allowing me to mount the completable Way and follow you, Master? To abandon me and refuse instruction would seem contrary to the utmost of the Creator.

**[Subcommentary]**
The Creator is akin to the transforming power of creation. Though I have suffered the maiming of benevolence, righteousness, right, and wrong upon my nature, how do we know that within the workings of creation, it will not repair my mutilation and cease my branding, enabling me to reform and renew, mount the completable Way, and follow you, Master, to seek further benefit? To cast me aside and withhold teaching would seem to defy the Creator.

Xu You said: "Alas! It cannot be known."

I shall speak to you of its general outline.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Alas*—this is an exclamation. The supreme Dao is profoundly mysterious, transcending speech and form, ungraspable by the mind’s reckoning. Thus, he feigned ignorance, saying, “It cannot be known.” Yet since your plea for instruction is so earnest, I cannot remain silent. Though its depths cannot be fully expressed in words, I shall sketch its essentials for you.

O my Master! O my Master! You order the myriad things yet claim no righteousness; your blessings extend through ten thousand generations yet claim no benevolence.

**[Annotation]**
All is thus of itself—there is no deliberate act of love in its midst. Where, then, would benevolence and righteousness reside?

**[Subcommentary]**
“O my Master” refers to the supreme Dao. Though it cannot be grasped by the mind, I shall briefly convey its essence: it is my Master. *Sheng* means “to shatter.” Consider the autumn frost descending—it withers the myriad things, yet does it act with intent to sever or judge? The balmy breath of spring nurtures all life, yet does it act with deliberate affection to be called benevolent? It is simply thus, not otherwise. Since Xu You takes the supreme Dao as his teacher, and the Dao is as I have described, how can you cling to benevolence and righteousness? This is but a rough outline of the method to cease branding and repair mutilation.

You are older than high antiquity yet do not grow old.

**[Annotation]**
It is ever-renewing.

You embrace heaven and earth, carve and shape all forms, yet claim no artistry.

**[Annotation]**
It is natural, thus not artful.

**[Subcommentary]**
Before the myriad forms existed, this Dao was already present, complete in wisdom and power. Thus, it is metaphorically called “elder,” though in truth it has no age. If it is not “elder,” how could it grow old? To clarify that it is not “elder” yet is elder, not old yet is old, it is said: *older than high antiquity yet does not grow old.* Though heaven covers and earth bears, the Dao is their source. All forms are carved and shaped, yet they all draw from the transformative power of creation, sharing in spontaneity. Thus, the name of artistry vanishes. Since it is neither old nor artful, neither right nor wrong, what can you possibly articulate? This is the realm in which it moves.

**[Annotation]**
It wanders in non-action and takes as teacher that which has no teacher.

**[Subcommentary]**
The realm in which my Master’s mind roams is expressed in these words alone. This summarizes the preceding meaning of “my Master.”

Yan Hui said: I have gained.

**[Annotation]**
To diminish is to gain.

**[Subcommentary]**
Yan Hui, having received the teachings of Confucius and held them fast in his heart while seeking the Dao, felt his understanding advance and presented his realization to his teacher. To diminish the full is to gain emptiness, thus diminishing is gaining.

Zhongni said: What do you mean?

**[Subcommentary]**
Since you say you have gained, what is your meaning?

He said: I have forgotten benevolence and righteousness.

**[Subcommentary]**
I have forgotten the benevolence of universal love and the righteousness of judging right and wrong. This is what I mean by gaining.

He said: Good, but not yet sufficient.

**[Annotation]**
Benevolence is the expression of universal love; righteousness is the function of perfecting things. Love is not benevolence—benevolence is merely its outward conduct. Perfecting is not righteousness—righteousness is merely its visible effect. To retain benevolence and righteousness is insufficient to understand that love and benefit arise from non-action. Thus, forgetting them is permissible, but merely forgetting their effects and expressions does not yet plumb the profound.

**[Subcommentary]**
To have forgotten benevolence and righteousness is gradually acceptable in principle, but your understanding remains shallow, so it is still not enough.

Another day, he met again and said: I have gained.

**[Subcommentary]**
“Another day” means a different time. With each day, his empty understanding renewed, and he met again. The progress he spoke of is detailed below.

He said: What do you mean?

**[Subcommentary]**
What is the meaning of your saying you have gained?

He said: I have forgotten ritual and music.

**[Subcommentary]**
Ritual is the root of chaos and disorder; music is the instrument of excess and dissipation. Their burdens are even heavier, so they are forgotten next.

He said: Good, but not yet sufficient.

**[Annotation]**
Ritual is the function of the body; music is the instrument of joy in life. To forget the instruments is not as good as forgetting that which produces the instruments.

**[Subcommentary]**
To have forgotten them is gradually acceptable, but it does not yet reach the ultimate.

Another day, he met again and said: I have gained.

He said: What do you mean?

**[Subcommentary]**
The meaning is no different from before.

He said: I have attained *zuowang* (sitting in forgetfulness).

**[Subcommentary]**
With an empty mind and nothing to cling to, one can sit upright and forget. The meaning of *zuowang* is explained below.

Zhongni started and said: What do you mean by *zuowang*?

**[Annotation]**
*Cu ran* describes a startled appearance. Since the forgetting has grown so deep, he is startled and asks: What is the meaning of *zuowang*?

Yan Hui said: I have dissolved my limbs and body, discarded my hearing and sight.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Liao* means to destroy or abandon. *Chu* means to withdraw or remove. Though hearing belongs to the ears and sight to the eyes, their function arises from the mind’s intelligence. Having awakened to the truth that the body is not truly one’s own and all realms are empty, one can destroy the four limbs and the hundred parts of the body, casting aside the mind’s intelligence, hearing, and sight.

I have departed from form and abandoned knowledge, becoming one with the Great Thoroughfare. This is called *zuowang*.

**[Annotation]**
What is there that *zuowang* does not forget? Having forgotten its conduct, it also forgets that which produces the conduct. Within, it is unaware of its own body; without, it does not recognize heaven and earth. Then, vast and open, it becomes one with transformation and is unobstructed in all things.

**[Subcommentary]**
The Great Thoroughfare is the great Dao. The Dao can penetrate and give life to the myriad things, thus it is called the Great Thoroughfare. Externally, one dissolves attachment to the body, seeing each part as illusory—this explains the dissolution of the limbs. Internally, one removes the mind’s knowledge, becoming utterly unaware—this explains the discarding of hearing and sight. Then, like withered wood or dead ashes, one merges with the great Dao. Such progress is called *zuowang*.

Zhongni said: To be the same is to have no preferences.

**[Annotation]**
When nothing is not the same, there is nothing one does not find suitable. When nothing is not suitable, what preferences or aversions can there be?

To transform is to have no constancy.

**[Annotation]**
To be the same as transformation is to follow only where transformation leads, thus there is no constancy.

**[Subcommentary]**
Having merged with the great Dao, one has no affirmations or negations, no preferences or aversions; having become one with change and transformation, one does not cling or stagnate in constancy.

"Yet is he truly worthy?"
"Qiu would follow behind him."

**[Subcommentary]**
*Guo* means "next." *Er* means "you." To have forgotten and abandoned all thus is surely to be a great worthy. Though Qiu is your teacher, he now falls behind you. To follow and learn from you—this is Qiu’s wish. This is Confucius humbly yielding himself to advance Yan Hui.

Ziyu and Zisang were friends, and for ten days there was ceaseless rain. Ziyu said: "Zisang must be in dire straits." He wrapped up rice and went to feed him.

**[Annotation]**
These two acted for one another without acting for one another. Now, wrapping rice to feed him arises from following heaven’s principle and happens of itself—it is not that he went only after acting for him.

**[Subcommentary]**
Rain lasting three days or more is called *lin*. *Dai* means "near." Zisang was poor, and with this ceaseless rain, he was near to starvation and illness. This matter is beyond doubt for those whose friendship transcends conventional bounds: one follows principle in going, and though he wrapped rice, there was no sentiment of acting for another.

When he reached Zisang’s gate, he heard sounds like singing, like weeping, as Zisang plucked his zither and said: "Father? Mother? Heaven?"

He entered the human realm.
There was one who could not bear the sound and so hastened to recite his verses.

**[Subcommentary]**
*Ren* means "to endure." *Qu* means "sudden and swift." Zisang, having suffered hunger and privation, thus produced the sound of his zither, asking from whom this hunger and poverty had come—whether from father or mother, or from man or husband. These were the words of his song and weeping. Unable to endure this sound, he then spontaneously recited his verses.

Ziyu entered and said: "Why do you recite verses in this manner?"
**[Annotation]**
He reproved him for having sentiment, for this hastened him far from the principle.
**[Subcommentary]**
One who is unified with life and death, who forgets sorrow and joy, who joins with others in non-joining—this is friendship beyond convention. Now, that you recite verses seems to harbor resentment, so I entered the gate in surprise and asked the reason.

He said: "I pondered who had brought me to this extremity, but I could not find the answer. Would my parents wish me to be poor and lowly? Heaven covers all without partiality; earth bears all without partiality. Would heaven and earth single me out for poverty? I sought the one who had done this, but I could not find him. Yet that I have come to this extremity is fate, is it not?"
**[Annotation]**
All things are spontaneous; none acts as a doer.
**[Subcommentary]**
Parents, in their kindness, do not wish their children to suffer hunger and cold. Heaven and earth are impartial—would they alone impoverish me? Considering the master and ruler, all is spontaneous. Seeking the origin, I found no sign at all. That I have come to this utter extremity is my allotted fate—what is there to resent?"

**Textual Variants and Emendations in the *Nanhua Zhenjing Zhushu*, Scroll Nine**

1. The Zhao edition omits the character *Dao* (道).
2. Guo Qingfan’s cited text emends *you* (有, "there is") to *qi* (其, "its").
3. Guo Qingfan’s cited text reads *yun yun xin xin* (运运新新, "ever-renewing") for the four characters *yun xin yun xin* (运新运新).
4. The *Quewu* cites the Jiangnan ancient manuscript, which includes *gu* (故, "therefore") above *sha* (杀, "kill").
5. Following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the main body, *ji si* (既死, "having already died") should be supplied.
6. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *hui* (惠, "favor") for *jiu* (救, "save").
7. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *xun* (循, "follow") for *xiu* (修, "cultivate").
8. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *er* (而, "and") for *ye* (也, "also").
9. The original *yi* (一, "one") is emended to *er* (二, "two") following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the context.
10. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *li* (离, "separate") for *sui* (虽, "although").
11. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *qi* (脐, "navel") for *qi* (齐, "equal").
12. The original *wen* (问, "ask") is emended to *xian* (闲, "leisurely") following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the context.
13. The *zhi* (之) character should be deleted following the Shide Tang edition; the Zhejiang Bureau edition omits it.
14. The Shide Tang edition has *er* (而, "and") for *bian* (变, "change").
15. The Zhao edition omits the characters *fu* (夫, "now") and *zhe* (者, "one who").
16. The Shide Tang and Zhejiang Bureau editions both have *guan* (管, "control") for *guan* (官, "office").
17. Following the Siku and Zhejiang Bureau editions, *you* (有, "have") should be emended to *you* (友, "friend").
18. In the Zhao edition, both instances of *hong* (弘, "great") are written as *ming* (冥, "dark"); in the Siku edition, both are written as *si* (私, "private").
19. Wang Xiaoyu emends *hui* (挥, "brandish") to *jian* (见, "see") following the Shide Tang edition.
20. Guo Qingfan’s cited text omits the two characters *zhi zhe* (之者, "those who").
21. The Zhejiang Bureau and Shide Tang editions have *ji* (及, "reach") for *ji* (极, "extreme").
22. The original *ruo* (若, "if") is emended to *gong* (共, "together") following the Siku and Zhejiang Bureau editions.
23. The Zhao edition has *ren* (人, "person") for *da* (大, "great").
24. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *tuo* (沱, "flowing") for *tuo* (拖, "drag").
25. The Siku and Zhejiang Bureau editions both have *yi* (一, "one") for *yi* (壹, "one").
26. The Shide Tang edition has *sheng* (生, "life") for *wang* (往, "go").
27. The original *dan* (旦, "dawn") is corrected to *dan* (但, "only") following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the main body.
28. Guo Qingfan’s cited text includes *er* (耳, "only") below *xin* (新, "new") and omits *li* (利, "profit").
29. Guo Qingfan’s cited text has *lei zhe* (累者, "burdensome ones") for *yi* (异, "different").
30. The Siku and Zhejiang Bureau editions both have *nai* (乃, "then") for *yi ye* (宜也, "fitting").
31. The Siku and Zhejiang Bureau editions both have *chui* (捶, "beat") for *chui* (锤, "hammer").
32. The Shide Tang edition has *wo zhi* (我知, "I know") for *zhi wo* (知我, "know me").
33. Guo Qingfan’s cited text inverts the two characters *ke diao* (刻雕, "carve and chisel").
34. The original *huo* (或, "perhaps") is suspected to be an error for *xian* (咸, "all"), following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the meaning.
35. Guo Qingfan’s cited text includes *ye* (也, "also") below *ji* (极, "extreme").
36. The Siku and Zhejiang Bureau editions both have *lin* (霖, "continuous rain") for *lin* (淋, "drip").
37. The two characters *xiang yu* (相与, "together") are supplied following Guo Qingfan’s cited text.

*Commentary and Subcommentary on the Nanhua Zhenjing, Scroll Nine*
*Annotated by Guo Xiang of Henan*

The Tang dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary
*Inner Chapters, "Fit for Emperors and Kings," Seventh*

To be without intent yet entrust all to self-transformation—this is how one becomes fit for emperors and kings.

Nie Que questioned Wang Ni four times, and four times received no answer.
*Subcommentary:* These four questions and four non-answers are the same four questions found in the *"Equalizing Things"* chapter. The Way of emperors and kings lies in nothing so much as forgetting knowledge, and thus this meaning is placed at the head of the chapter. As the *Laozi* says, "Not using wisdom to govern the state is the state’s virtue."

Thereupon Nie Que leapt up in great joy and went to tell Master Pu Yi.
Master Pu Yi said, "So only now do you know this?"
*Subcommentary:* Master Pu Yi was a worthy man of Yao’s time. At the age of eight, Shun took him as his teacher and offered him the throne, which he declined. He is the same as the Master Clad in Furs. Nie Que, having grasped the wondrous purport of non-knowing, leapt up in joy and ran to tell Master Pu Yi, yet still failed to fathom Wang Ni’s profound meaning. Pu Yi, a great worthy beyond the world, had already mastered the ultimate Dao of wordless understanding—how enduringly rooted in non-knowing! And only now, today, do you come to know it?

The House of Yu did not measure up to the House of Tai.
*Annotation:* The House of Yu and the House of Tai were both mere margins of worldly affairs, not worth recounting. What one flees is no escape at all—who in the world understands this? Before it was ever named, what victory or defeat could there be? Yet the unrecounted rides the flux of the many changes, spans the ten thousand generations, and though the world knows both peace and peril, recounting will always fall short.

*Subcommentary:* The House of Yu refers to Shun. The House of Tai refers to Tai Hao, that is, Fuxi. In the age of the Three Sovereigns, customs were pure and harmonious; by the time of the Five Emperors, mores had grown thin.

The age of strife and thinness operates through knowing to nurture things, while the age of purity and harmony preserves the real and governs through lodging—this is how the meaning of "not measuring up" may be verified.

The House of Yu, in its way, hoarded virtue to win over people. It did win people over, yet never emerged from the realm of "non-people."
*Annotation:* To take what people love as "people" and what they hate as "non-people" is to remain within the bounds of right and wrong. Only by stepping beyond the realm of "non-people" can one enter the state where there are no "non-people" at all. Thus, there is no gain, no loss, no right, no wrong—how could it be merely hoarding the Seven Virtues to win over people?

*Subcommentary:* Shun embraced the Seven Virtues and sought the allegiance of the common folk, thereby winning the hearts of the people. Yet he had not yet forgotten himself to merge with the world, so he remained within the realm of right and wrong. Some texts write *zang* (臧) as *cang* (藏). *Zang* means "good"—good at benevolence and righteousness, seeking the hearts of people.

The House of Tai moved with unhurried grace, awakening in carefree ease.
*Subcommentary:* *Xuxu* (徐徐) describes a relaxed and leisurely bearing; *yuyu* (于于), a self-contented demeanor. In Fuxi’s time, the pure customs still endured, so outwardly he was serene and unhurried, and in his awakening, joyful and at ease.

One moment he took himself for a horse, the next for an ox.
*Annotation:* In this way, how could there be any "people" or "non-people"? This is what it means to step beyond the realm of "non-people."
*Subcommentary:* Forgetting self and other, casting off right and wrong, he became horse or ox at others’ beck and call. If even beasts had no fixed nature, how could there be right or wrong?

His knowing was genuine and trustworthy.
*Annotation:* He let knowing be itself, so it was genuine and trustworthy.
*Subcommentary:* Following his true knowing, his feelings were free of pretense, thus truly trustworthy.

His virtue was utterly real.
*Annotation:* He let virtue be itself, so it was without falsity.
*Subcommentary:* Taking non-virtue as virtue, his virtue was without virtue, thus without falsity.

Yet he never entered the realm of "non-people."
*Annotation:* Not entering the realm of right and wrong is what sets him apart from the age of Yu.
*Subcommentary:* Following his true feelings, his virtue free of falsity, he transcended the bounds of knowing and never entered the realm of right and wrong.

Jian Wu met the madman Jie Yu. Jie Yu asked, "What did Ri Zhongshi tell you?"
*Subcommentary:* Jian Wu and Jie Yu have already been explained earlier. Ri Zhongshi was a worthy man, Jian Wu’s teacher. Since he was your teacher, what did he instruct you? This is Jie Yu posing the question.

Jian Wu replied, "He told me that a ruler must devise standards and measures from himself to govern others—who would dare not listen and be transformed?"
*Subcommentary:* *Shi* (式) means "to employ." He taught me the way of being a ruler and the method of transforming things: one must devise strategies from one’s own wisdom, employ benevolence and righteousness to guide customs, and then the people of the four directions—who would not listen? The distant masses—who would dare not submit?

Jie Yu said, "This is deceptive virtue."
*Annotation:* To impose one’s own standards on things is to make them lose their reality.
*Subcommentary:* Imposing one’s own standards on things makes them lose their reality—such deceptive virtue is not the true Way.

"In governing the world, it would be like crossing the sea by digging a river or making a flea carry a mountain."
*Annotation:* Entrusting oneself to the myriad things means nothing is left undone of itself. Trying to govern the world with one’s own body means no task is accomplished and no burden is borne.
*Subcommentary:* The vastness of the sea is deep and boundless, impossible to fathom, yet digging it into a river would yield no result. Likewise, the Way is distant and boundless, utterly beyond knowing, yet carving it into principles would be equally futile. A flea is tiny, a mountain immense—making it bear the load would be impossible. Governing with wisdom and ordering with benevolence, small virtue attempting great schemes—this is the same.

"Does the sage govern externally?"
*Annotation:* He governs only what lies within his own nature and destiny.
*Subcommentary:* He governs only what lies within his own nature and destiny, never extending beyond it.

"To govern externally is to say one does not govern. First rectify, then act."
*Annotation:* Each rectifies its own nature and destiny.
*Subcommentary:* First align with the true nature, then act to transform.

"Simply ensure that each can do what it is capable of."
*Annotation:* Do not do what one is incapable of.
*Subcommentary:* *Que* (确) means "solid." Align with the solid nature of things, enabling what each is capable of. Entrusting tasks accordingly, stopping at what lies within one’s nature, never reaching beyond.

"The cormorant flies high to avoid the harm of nets and arrows, while the mole digs deep beneath the sacred mound to escape the disaster of fumigation and digging."
*Annotation:* Even birds and beasts each have their own way of preserving themselves. Thus, if the emperor-king entrusts things to themselves and does not act, they will naturally come to completion.
*Subcommentary:* *Zeng* (缯) is a net; *yi* (弋), shooting with an arrow tied to a string. *Yanshu* (鼹鼠) is a small mouse; *shenqiu* (神丘), the altar of the earth god. The bird flies high to escape the net, the mouse digs deep to avoid fumigation—both follow their nature spontaneously, needing no instruction to avoid harm. If even birds and mice do this, so too do humans. Thus, to devise standards and impose principles is the height of deception. How could you fail to recognize the wisdom of these two creatures?"

*Annotation:* Do you truly not know that these two creatures each preserve themselves without needing instruction?
*Subcommentary:* *Er* (而) means "you." Do you not know that these two creatures, without instruction, naturally avoid harm and preserve themselves? If even they, digging deep and flying high, are not without wisdom, how much more so for humans? Yet you would devise standards and impose principles to deceive and manipulate things—is this not delusion?

Tian Gen wandered to Yin Yang and came to the banks of Meng Water, where he happened upon an unnamed man and asked him, "May I ask how to govern the world?"

The *Subcommentary* states: "Tian Gen" and "Unnamed Man" are both fictitious names, serving as allegorical figures in a dialogue. "Yin Yang" refers to the southern slope of Yin Mountain. "Meng Water" lies within the borders of Zhao. "Encountered" means "met." Tian Gen, wandering along the mountains and rivers, happened upon the Unnamed Man and questioned him, his inquiry concerning the governance of the world.

The Unnamed Man replied: "Begone! You are a vulgar man—why do you ask such unwelcome questions?"

*Annotation:* To ask about governing the world is to fail to begin from the Great Beginning and end in the Dark Obscurity.

*Subcommentary:* You are a coarse and ignorant man—you should leave at once. The intent of your question brings me no joy. "I am about to become a man with the Creator of Things."

*Annotation:* Allowing people to act of their own accord.

*Subcommentary:* When the Creator makes a man, each is endowed with a natural allotment—why labor to devise laws and impose governance? Since all is one with the Great Thoroughfare, one simply lets be without aiding.

"When weary, I then ride the boundless bird, soaring beyond the Six Directions, and wander in the land of Nothing Whatever, dwelling in the vast and boundless wilds."

*Annotation:* "Boundless" refers to the myriad fragments. Riding the myriad fragments, one gallops through the ten thousand things, thus able to come and go with constant freedom, without any constricted or stagnant place.

*Subcommentary:* "Boundless" means profound and deep. "Vast and boundless" is a term for expansive breadth. The bird is chosen for its lightness and ease of ascent. The Six Directions are like the Six Harmonies. The sage who governs the world is tranquil and inactive, in great accord with the nature of things, akin to the transformations of creation. If he ceases activity and returns to the root, weary of the world, then he rides the profound and distant Dao, soaring through the void and vanishing without trace. He transcends the Six Harmonies in freedom, advances into Nothing Whatever in carefree wandering, concentrates his spirit and wisdom on the shooting star, and abides in the clear and empty wilderness. In this way, how could there be any governing of the world? It is simply non-action.

"Why do you disturb my heart with such questions about governing the world?"

*Annotation:* All things are left to their own self-attainment, and thus they govern themselves without governance.

*Subcommentary:* If one lets things be and allows them to follow their course, all things transform themselves. What need is there for elaborate schemes to sing of governance? Why do you agitate my heart in this way?

The Unnamed Man asked again.

*Subcommentary:* Tian Gen had not yet understood, so he posed another question.

The Unnamed Man said: "Let your mind wander in simplicity, unite your *qi* with stillness."

*Annotation:* When one follows one’s nature without adornment, that is simplicity. To be still in one’s nature and abide therein.

*Subcommentary:* Direct your mind and spirit to the realm of tranquility, unite your form and *qi* with the land of silence. Let both form and spirit be utterly empty and still. Only then will the world transform itself without need of governance. Follow the self-so of things without harboring private designs, and the world will be well-ordered.

*Annotation:* To let nature take its course is impartial; to seek to augment it with the mind’s desires is partial. Partiality is truly insufficient for generating life, while following the impartial preserves it wholly.

*Subcommentary:* Follow the nature of things as transformed by creation, comply with the inherent tendencies of the self-so, without harboring private designs or imposing governance. Let things be, and both self and others will be preserved whole.

Yang Ziju saw Lao Dan and said: "Suppose there were a man here—quick-witted and resolute, penetrating and perspicacious, diligent in the study of the Dao without weariness. Could such a one be compared to an enlightened king?"

*Subcommentary:* His surname was Yang, his given name Zhu, and his courtesy name Ziju. He asked Laozi about the way of the enlightened king: Suppose there were a man whose nature was keen and swift, whose spirit and intelligence responded as swiftly as an echo, who handled affairs with strength and decisiveness, who discerned things with clarity and thoroughness, who studied the Dao with unflagging diligence. Could such a man be compared in virtue to an enlightened king or sage emperor?

Lao Dan said: "Compared to the sage, such a man is but a menial, entangled by skills, wearied in body and troubled in mind."

*Annotation:* Such abilities cannot secure one’s person, and are insufficient to compare with a sage ruler.

*Subcommentary:* If one were to compare such a man to a sage ruler, he would be no more than a laborer, altering his appearance through toil. His skills and craft entangle his spirit, causing weariness, so his form changes; entangled, his mind is troubled. "Moreover, the patterns of tigers and leopards bring hunters, the agility of monkeys brings trappers, and the skill of foxes in catching foxes brings leashing. Could such as these be compared to an enlightened king?"

*Annotation:* All these are entangled by their patterns and skills, not riding the empty to master the boundless.

*Subcommentary:* "Leashing" means binding. "Monkey" refers to the macaque. The skins of tigers and leopards have patterns, hence they attract hunters. Monkeys, with their agility in leaping, are inevitably bound by ropes. Dogs, skilled in catching foxes, are often leashed by the neck. If one were to compare the quick-witted man to a sage emperor, then these three creatures could also be compared to an enlightened king.

Yang Ziju, startled, said: "May I ask about the governance of the enlightened king?"

*Subcommentary:* Having asked amiss, he was taken aback and changed his expression, then respectfully inquired again about the principles of enlightened kingship.

Lao Dan said: "The achievements of the enlightened king cover the world yet seem not his own."

*Annotation:* If the world lacked an enlightened ruler, none could attain self-realization. What is now called self-realization is truly the achievement of the enlightened king. Yet his achievement lies in non-action, and the return lies with the world. All attain self-mastery, so it seems not the enlightened king’s achievement.

*Subcommentary:* The sage’s governance is as encompassing as creation, as all-embracing as heaven and earth, yet his achievements remain unclaimed, so they seem not his own work. "He transforms and bestows upon the ten thousand things, yet the people do not rely on him."

*Annotation:* The enlightened king fully satisfies the nature of things, so each person says, "I am thus of myself," without knowing their reliance on the enlightened king.

The sage guides and transforms the multitudes, bidding them forsake evil; he bestows upon the ten thousand things, granting them blessings for their goodness. Yet his profound power works in hidden depths, unknown in daily use, so the common people say, "I am thus of myself," without relying on the ruler’s virtue. His achievements remain unnamed, allowing all things to rejoice of their own accord.

*Annotation:* Though his merit encompasses all under heaven, he does not claim it as his own name, so all things believe they have attained it themselves and rejoice.

*Subcommentary:* "Mo" means "none"; "ju" means "to display." He ascribes merit to all things rather than making his name known, so each thing attains its own fulfillment and delights in contentment.

He stands in the unfathomable,
*Annotation:* Dwelling in the path of transformation, ever-renewing and without fixed form.

and wanders in the realm of nothingness.
*Annotation:* When he embodies the ten thousand things, his wanderings are in emptiness. If he cannot merge with things, he will be endlessly occupied in responding to them—how could he then wander in emptiness?

*Subcommentary:* "Nothingness" is the wondrous root. In establishing virtue and accomplishing merit, his spirit is profound and unknowable, yet he is at once on the path and at the root, thus ever roaming his mind in the ultimate.

In Zheng there was a divine diviner named Ji Xian,
*Subcommentary:* In the state of Zheng there was a diviner of extraordinary spiritual power, highly accurate in his predictions. Having come from Qi, his surname was Ji and his given name Xian.

who knew men’s deaths and lives, survival and ruin, fortune and misfortune, longevity and early demise, predicting them by the year, month, ten-day period, or day, as if he were a spirit. When the people of Zheng saw him, they all fled in haste,
*Annotation:* They disliked hearing of their own death dates.
*Subcommentary:* His divinations of good and ill fortune were never in error; he fixed the time with precision, as if verified by spirits. No one wished to hear of impending misfortune in advance, so they fled to avoid him.

but when Liezi saw him, he was entranced. Returning home, he told Master Hu,
*Subcommentary:* Liezi’s progress in learning is detailed in the "Free and Easy Wandering" chapter; it need not be repeated here. Master Hu was an adept of the Dao in Zheng, known as Huzi, with the given name Lin—Liezi’s teacher. Seeing Ji Xian’s minor arts, as accurate as if he were a spirit, Liezi was filled with admiration, as if intoxicated. Upon returning, he told his teacher all that had transpired.

saying, "At first I took the Master’s Way to be the ultimate, but now there is something even more ultimate."
*Annotation:* He meant that Ji Xian’s attainment surpassed even the Master’s.
*Subcommentary:* "The Master" refers to Huzi; "ultimate" means "supreme." Initially, upon receiving instruction, he believed the Master’s Way to be the highest, but now, having seen Ji Xian, he found his Way even more supreme. These were Liezi’s words of infatuation.

Master Hu said, "I have taught you only the outward forms, not yet the reality—do you truly believe you have attained the Dao?
*Subcommentary:* "Yu" means "to teach"; "ji" means "exhaust." Compared to what I have taught you, I have only conveyed the literary expressions, not yet the profound essence. You cling to words, believing you have grasped the Dao—how do you know the fish-trap and rabbit-snare are not the fish and rabbit themselves?

With many hens but no rooster, how can there be eggs?"
*Annotation:* This speaks of Liezi’s lack of true attainment.
*Subcommentary:* With many hens and no rooster, there can be no eggs. Since you have only form without substance, how can you possess the Dao?

If you contend with the world using the Dao and insist on being believed, you make it possible for others to divine your fate.
*Annotation:* Without true attainment, you still have a mind; having a mind, you contend with one aspect of the world, seeking to be believed—thus others can divine your fate.
*Subcommentary:* You use the Dao of words to contend with the world, lacking great wisdom yet trusting in petty skills—this is why Ji Xian could divine your fate.

Come with him and let me show myself to him."
*Subcommentary:* The perfected person is serene and remote, his spirit profound and unknowable, at rest in stillness yet responsive in movement—beyond the measure of ordinary minds. Thus he summoned Ji Xian to come and observe him.

The next day, Liezi brought Ji Xian to see Master Hu. When they departed, Ji Xian said to Liezi, "Alas!"

"Your master is dead. He cannot live again. It will not be ten days before he perishes. I saw something strange in him—he resembled damp ashes."

*Subcommentary:* Alas! This is an exclamation of surprise. Zilin showed his still and desolate countenance, and Ji Xian declared he would die. The omen of strangeness had already manifested; within ten days, the sign of his demise would be like damp ashes.

Liezi entered, his tears soaking his lapels as he told Master Hu. Master Hu said, "I changed my manifestation to show him the *earthly pattern*, sprouting yet neither trembling nor upright."

*Annotation:* Sprouting yet unmoving, neither correcting itself—like a withered tree sharing its lack of bloom, or damp ashes equal in their lifeless stillness—this is the time when the perfected person is without response. The perfected person’s movement is like heaven, their stillness like earth; their flowing is like water, their cessation like the profound silence of an abyss. The abyss’s silence and water’s flow, heaven’s movement and earth’s stillness—these are not acts of doing yet arise of themselves, all one in nature. Now, when Ji Xian saw him dwelling like a corpse and sitting in oblivion, he called it impending death; when he beheld his spirit moving and heaven following, he declared it life. Truly, response does not rely on the mind, for principle naturally aligns with the mysterious tally. Ascending and descending with transformation, measuring by the world—only then can one be master of things and follow the boundless flow of time without limit. Thus, such a one is beyond the divination of soothsayers. This is the great meaning of *Responding to Emperors and Kings*.

*Subcommentary:* *Pattern* means form; *trembling* means movement. Earth is tranquil through its lack of intent, so its pattern is stillness. Sprouting yet still, never trembling, without intent yet upright—its form resembles collapse. This is the time when the great sage is without response, and the petty shaman calls it death. Yet Master Hu’s manifestations have four levels: first, showing the wondrous root’s empty concentration, still and unmoving; second, showing the near descent of responsive activation, moving yet not still; third, the root and branches merging, movement and stillness as one; fourth, the root and branches both forgotten, movement and stillness both transcended. This is the first: the wondrous root’s empty concentration, still and unmoving. It is nearly like seeing my *blocked virtue-mechanism*."

*Annotation:* When the virtue-mechanism does not activate, it is called *blocked*.

*Subcommentary:* *Nearly* means approaching; *blocked* means obstructed; *mechanism* means movement. The mechanism of utmost virtue is sealed and unactivated. Showing its congealed tranquility resembles damp ashes, and the petty shaman, in his vulgarity, nearly saw this.

"Try bringing him again."

*Subcommentary:* Previously, he falsely claimed I was dead; now, he summons him again to come once more.

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Master Hu again. When they departed, Ji Xian said to Liezi, "Fortunate indeed that your master met me! There is hope now—he is fully alive again!"

*Subcommentary:* This is the second: the near descent of responsive activation, moving yet not still. Showing the responsive countenance, his spirit and qi stirred slightly, no longer like withered wood but entirely like his usual self. Yet he falsely attributed this sagely power to his own skill, claiming it was fortunate to have met him—how mistakenly he took credit for the cure! "I saw his *blocked potentiality*."

Here, "power" (*quan*) means "mechanism." Now, he himself realizes that what he saw yesterday was merely the *blocked mechanism*, hence he declared him near death.

*Subcommentary:* "Power" (*quan*) means "mechanism." Previously, at a single glance, he saw only something like damp ashes—blocked mechanism, utterly devoid of responsive movement. Today, having met me, he awaits full revival. How shallow the petty shaman’s knowledge, to so presumptuously claim credit!

Liezi entered and reported this to Master Hu. Master Hu said: "Just now, I showed him *Heaven-and-Earth*."

*Annotation:* Within Heaven-and-Earth, the power of covering and bearing is manifest. Compared to *Earth’s Pattern*, this is not merely external—it is the countenance of responsive activation.

*Subcommentary:* "Earth" (*rang*) means the ground. To show him *Heaven-and-Earth* is to display the countenance of responsive movement. Like the Two Modes covering and bearing the myriad things, the perfected one’s responsive activation follows the same principle. *Name and reality do not enter*—

*Annotation:* When one covers and bears through natural spontaneity, the celestial mechanism responds mysteriously, and the adornments of fame and profit become discarded things.

*Subcommentary:* Though he descends to mingle with the dust and harmonizes his light to benefit beings, fame and true reality never enter his numinous core. *—yet the mechanism arises from the heels.*

*Annotation:* It always arises from the utmost extremity.

*Subcommentary:* "Heels" (*zhong*) means the root. Though things stir and move in response, he never loses timely appropriateness, for this numinous mechanism issues from the wondrous root, moving yet ever still. *This is nearly seeing my good mechanism.*

*Annotation:* The mechanism arises and is good for him, so he sees it.

*Subcommentary:* He showed the good mechanism, responding to the Two Modes. Ji Xian, seeing this form and countenance, called it "good." To be "fully alive" is precisely what it means to see the good.

"Try bringing him again."

The next day, Liezi brought him to see Master Hu again. When they departed, Ji Xian said to Liezi: "Your master is unsettled. I cannot fathom his signs. Let him settle himself, and I will observe him again."

*Subcommentary:* This is the third: showing the non-duality of root and traces, movement and stillness as one. The perfected one’s virtue is full, wisdom complete; his empty mind congeals in illumination. Root and traces are not separate, movement and stillness not distinct. His Dao is profoundly mysterious—how could a petty shaman plumb it? He means to settle his mind and advance, then try observing him again. Not daring to definitively predict fortune or misfortune, he merely says, "I will observe him again."

Liezi entered and reported this to Master Hu. Master Hu said: "Just now, I showed him *Supreme Vacuity, No Victory*."

*Annotation:* Abiding at the extremity of Supreme Vacuity, one governs the mind with vastness and harmonizes with the ten thousand directions. Thus, victory and defeat cannot find a place to intervene.

*Subcommentary:* "Vacuity" (*chong*) means emptiness; "no" (*mo*) means without. The sage’s illumination is profoundly congealed, equal in measure to the Great Vacuity. Root and traces are non-dual, movement and stillness simultaneous—there is no superiority or inferiority, so what victory or defeat could there be? *This is the first time he sees my balanced qi-mechanism.*

*Annotation:* Without names, there is no imbalance; all is merged into one. To those who gauge Heaven with a tube, its limits are unseen, so it seems unsettled.

*Subcommentary:* "Balanced" (*heng*) means level. Root and traces are one, no superiority or inferiority; the spirit and qi are equal, responding to the mechanism in this way. The petty shaman, seeing only what is near, cannot fathom what is distant. His mind is confused, which is why he asks for settlement.

*"The abyss is known by nine names—here, three are given:*
*The abyss where the *kui*-fish coils,*
*The abyss of still water,*
*The abyss of flowing water."*

*Annotation:* By "abyss" is meant stillness and silence. Water is ever without mind, yielding and following external things. Thus, whether flowing or still, whether the *kui*-fish coils or the dragon leaps, it remains profoundly self-possessed, never losing its stillness and silence. The perfected one acts when employed, ceases when set aside. Though action and cessation differ, his profound silence remains one. Thus, I briefly cite three differences to illustrate this. Though waves surge in nine transformations, and order and chaos intermingle, he who abides at the extremity remains serenely self-possessed, utterly forgetting all doing.

*Subcommentary:* This is a metaphor. The *kui* is a great fish; "coils" (*huan*) means to spiral. "Known" (*shen*) means to gather. The water’s nature is without mind, its movement and stillness following things. Whether the whale coils, the dragon soars, the water congeals in stillness, or the waves surge in turbulence—though the ripples and currents vary in myriad ways, its profound silence remains without mind, its essence unified. Thus, the coiled *kui* is likened to the balanced qi, still water to *Earth’s Pattern*, and flowing water to *Heaven-and-Earth*. Though these three differ, their empty illumination is one.

As for the abyss having nine names, they are: the abyss of the coiled *kui*, the abyss of still water, the abyss of flowing water, the abyss of overflowing water, the abyss of flooding water, the abyss of wave water, the abyss of dammed water, the abyss of patterned water, and the abyss of rich water—hence the nine. All appear in the *Liezi*; that text records them in full, while here only these three are briefly cited.

"Try bringing him again."

[Commentary] Desiring to reveal the utmost mystery, it was necessary to summon him again.

The next day, he was brought once more to see Master Hu. Before he could steady himself, he lost his bearings and fled.

[Commentary] In previous encounters, Ji Xian had gauged and assessed him, yet the profound and distant remained unmanifest, still clouded by superficial perceptions. Now, in this fourth meeting, the Way had reached its deepest, where root and trace were both forgotten, movement and stillness both transcended. Where the sage’s mind moved, the ordinary could not fathom—thus, before he could stand firm, he bolted in flight.

Master Yazi said, “Pursue him.”

[Commentary] Having witnessed his flight, he commanded that he be seized.

Liezi pursued but could not overtake him. Returning, he reported to Master Hu, saying, “He has vanished! He is lost! I could not catch him.”

[Commentary] Overwhelmed by terror, he fled with such speed that he was gone—lost—no one knew where.

Master Hu said, “I showed him only that which had never yet departed from my source.”

[Annotation] Though its transformations are boundless, it ever abides in the deep root of tranquility.

[Commentary] The wondrous origin of the mysterious source lies in the obscure and indistinct, transcending the four propositions, leaving behind the hundred negations. It cannot be grasped by thought or known by deliberation—how then could it be seized by form or name? Having severed all speech and image, without fixed source or path, its course unfathomable, he lost himself and fled. I met him with emptiness and yielded to his flow,

[Annotation] Without mind, following the transformations of things.

not knowing who or what he was,

[Annotation] Drifting without attachment.

[Commentary] *Wei yi* describes the manner of yielding and compliance. The perfected one responds to things with emptiness, forgetting self and intent, adapting to the moment without clinging to any root. Since it cannot be named or defined, one knows not who or what it truly is. Thus, it becomes like crumbling decay, like surging waves—hence his flight.

[Annotation] In dissolution and decline, in the ebb and flow of worldly affairs, there is nowhere it does not follow. Though the perfected one is one, he moves with the changes of the age, so the diviner finds no place to fix his gaze and flees in disarray. This illustrates that one who would respond as emperor to the world acts without fixed method.

[Commentary] *Tui* means to let go; *mi* means to comply. The highest virtue is without intent, responding only when moved. Letting go without exertion, complying with things, it stirs the dust of the world and flows with its currents, following the moment without obstruction. In its thousand transformations and ten thousand changes, it remains beyond the diviner’s ken—thus Ji Xian rightly fled.

Thereafter, Liezi realized he had never truly learned and returned home.

[Commentary] Only after Ji Xian’s flight did Liezi awaken to his own delusion, perceiving at last the depth of Master Hu’s Way and the shallowness of the divine seer. Knowing he had not yet learned, he begged to withdraw, to cultivate non-action and devote himself to the mysterious study. For three years, he did not emerge.

He cooked for his wife and fed pigs as he would feed people.
**[Annotation]** Forgetting distinctions of noble and base.
**[Commentary]** Before three years had passed, he secluded himself from worldly affairs. Cooking for his wife, he forgot honor and disgrace; feeding pigs as he would people, he treated filth and purity as equal. In matters, he held no partiality—
**[Annotation]** Whatever he encountered was all.
**[Commentary]** Awakened to the ultimate principle, he equalized self and other; engaging in worldly affairs, he made no distinction of near or far. Carving and polishing returned to simplicity—
**[Annotation]** Discarding ornament to embrace reality.
**[Commentary]** All tasks of carving and polishing, all embellishments, he cast aside, resting in unadorned truth to return to the Way of simplicity. Like a clod of earth, he stood alone in his form—
**[Annotation]** External adornments were gone.
**[Commentary]** *Kuai ran*: the appearance of being without emotion. Outwardly, he shed all ornament; inwardly, he rejected cunning and intellect. His form was like a withered tree, solitary and unmatched. Though entangled in the world’s dust, he guarded his true nature—
**[Annotation]** Though active, his essence remained undispersed.
**[Commentary]** *Feng*: to guard. Though he engaged with the world’s entanglements, harmonizing with things, he preserved his original truth, steadfast and unshaken. He ended as he began—
**[Annotation]** Letting things fulfill themselves.
**[Commentary]** In movement, he did not stray from stillness; though divided by disturbance, he guarded his truth. In response, he did not depart from reality, ever embracing the One from beginning to end. He did not become a vessel of fame—
**[Annotation]** Following things, each bore its own name.
