**[Commentary]** *Shi*: master. Even his body was forgotten—where then could fame reside? Thus, he no longer served as master of reputation. He did not become a storehouse of schemes—
**[Annotation]** Letting things devise their own plans.
**[Commentary]** Empty and serene, without intent, he entrusted all to things, no longer harboring schemes in his spirit’s abode. He did not take on tasks—
**[Annotation]** Entrusting each thing to fulfill its own role.
**[Commentary]** Each followed its natural allotment, letting things act of their own accord, no longer burdening himself with affairs. He did not become a master of knowledge—
**[Annotation]** Without intent, each thing mastered its own knowledge.
**[Commentary]** Forgetting the mind, severing thought, he followed the natural course of all beings, never employing knowledge to govern things. His embodiment encompassed the boundless—
**[Annotation]** Following the self-directed nature of the world, he roamed among the ten thousand things without limit.
**[Commentary]** Realizing the true source, he merged with the wisdom of the boundless—thus all things were inexhaustible. And he wandered without trace—
**[Annotation]** Entrusting all to things, he left no boundary.
**[Commentary]** *Zhen*: trace. Though he roamed the world, aiding all beings, he concealed his brilliance, leaving no mark. He fulfilled what he received from Heaven—
**[Annotation]** When sufficient, he stopped.
**[Commentary]** Each thing’s endowment from Heaven differed; each exhausted its capacity, yet none found it lacking. Without appearing to gain—
**[Annotation]** To appear to gain is to not know when to stop.
**[Commentary]** What the eye sees, though seen, is not truly seen; what is gained within one’s allotment, though gained, is not truly gained. Having no intent to see or gain, though he saw and gained, it was as if he did not. It was emptiness alone—
**[Annotation]** Without emptiness, one cannot bear the fullness of things.
**[Commentary]** That he exhausted his allotment without appearing to gain was simply due to his empty heart, forgetting all. The perfected person’s mind is like a mirror—
**[Annotation]** Reflecting things without emotion.
**[Commentary]** A mirror hung in a high hall reflects whatever comes before it; the perfected person’s empty response follows the same principle. Neither sending off nor welcoming,
responding yet not storing—
**[Annotation]** It reflects what comes and ceases when it goes.
**[Commentary]** *Jiang*: to send off. Things come and go, yet the mirror neither welcomes nor sends them away; what comes is reflected, yet nothing is concealed. Likewise, the sage’s wisdom, empty and still, illuminates even the hidden. Things move, and he responds—not with the heart, without sending or welcoming, how could he conceal anything with emotion? Thus, he could master things without harm—
**[Annotation]** Things come, and it reflects them; reflecting without intent, even if the whole world came to be mirrored, there would be no weariness of spirit.
**[Commentary]** Things arise and perish, yet the mirror neither conceals nor reveals—thus it can always reflect things without being harmed. Likewise, the sage’s virtue harmonizes with the two poles, his clarity equal to the three luminaries; his illumination vast, his embrace impartial. His mind unwearied, he suffers no harm, for he masters things without injury.

The Lord of the Southern Sea was Shu, the Lord of the Northern Sea was Hu, and the Lord of the Center was Hundun.
**[Commentary]** The Southern Sea is the realm of brightness, thus Shu represents being. The North is the domain of darkness, thus Hu represents non-being. The Center is neither North nor South, thus Hundun represents neither being nor non-being. Shu and Hu often met in Hundun’s land, and Hundun treated them very well.
**[Commentary]** The two minds of being and non-being met in the realm of neither being nor non-being, harmonizing the two partial perspectives into a single central intent—thus it is said he treated them very well. Shu and Hu plotted to repay Hundun’s virtue, saying: "All people have seven apertures for seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing—only this one has none. Let us try to bore them."
**[Commentary]** Shu and Hu, clinging to partiality, could not harmonize; still moved by the impulse to learn, they forgot Hundun’s lack of intent and thought drilling apertures would be beneficial. Each day they bored one aperture, and on the seventh day, Hundun died.
**[Annotation]** To act is to ruin.
**[Commentary]** Applying the four limbs to cling to conditions, boring seven apertures to be stained by dust, violating Hundun’s perfect purity, following the grasping of being and non-being—thus he did not complete his Heavenly years, dying midway. Let scholars take heed and avoid this fate. Thus Guo’s annotation says: "To act is to ruin."
*End of the Ninth Scroll of the Zhuangzi’s Annotations and Commentaries*

*Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Commentary by Tang Dynasty Master of the Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying**

**Outer Chapters, "Webbed Toes" (Chapter Eight)**

Webbed toes and supernumerary fingers emerge from one’s nature—yet they exceed in virtue.

**[Subcommentary]** *Bing* (骈) means "joined"; *mu* (拇) refers to the big toe. It denotes the big toe and the second toe grown together as one. *Zhizhi* (枝指) refers to an extra finger branching from the side of the thumb, resulting in six fingers. "Emerge from one’s nature" means these webbed or branched digits are both endowed by nature, present within the generative mandate of life. *Chi* (侈) means "excess." *De* (德) refers to the five virtues: benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust. This states that Zengzi and Shun’s discernment of the five virtues, stored within the five viscera, is not superfluous to nature.

Hanging tumors and pendulous wens emerge from one’s form—yet they exceed in nature.

**[Annotation]** What is long is not considered surplus; what is short is not considered deficient. Thus, both webbed and non-webbed growths arise from form and nature, not borrowed from external things. Yet while webbed and non-webbed are each sufficient in their own way, these alone are webbed or branched, appearing excessive to others—hence called *chi* ("excess"). Deluded ones may claim these are not of nature, seeking to excise and discard them. This would mean the Dao has no place to abide, virtue has no vessel to bear it, humans discard talent, and things discard their use—how could this be the intent of perfect governance? Things have their sizes, capacities their quantities; what is large is webbed, what is numerous is superfluous. The distinction between webbed and superfluous exists in all things. To refuse their function is to discard the nature of the myriad things entirely.

**[Subcommentary]** Attached growths of flesh and dangling wens both arise only after form is endowed—thus they emerge from form and exceed nature. For example, Li Kuang’s innate intelligence, stored within the organs, is not acquired through study, so it does not exceed nature. Those who employ benevolence and righteousness in manifold ways are arrayed within the five viscera—yet this is not the true alignment of the Dao and virtue.

Those who merge with things in darkness do so without excess. Thus, those who employ benevolence and righteousness in manifold ways, though arrayed within the five viscera, merely adhere to the orthodoxy of a single school—they cannot align with things without distinction and rectify each according to its nature and destiny. Hence, this is not the true alignment of the Dao and virtue. The degrees of distinction in these ways are without limit in the world, yet the gradations of more and less each have their fixed allotment. Even a difference as slight as a hair’s tip cannot be transgressed. Thus, if each guards its own distinction, then more and less will all attain their proper place. Yet some, hearing that excess cannot rectify deficiency, seek to discard the many and rely on the few—this is to cast aside the entire world, is it not absurd?

**[Subcommentary]** *Distinction* refers to the unfolding of the Dao. The virtues of Zeng and Shi abound in benevolence and righteousness, arrayed within the viscera and put into practice—this is merely the wisdom of a single school, unable to merge with the myriad things in boundless darkness. Those who can merge with things do not cling to righteousness yet respond to righteousness, neither excess nor deficiency yet respond to excess and deficiency. In endless transformations, they harmonize with things without end, free from partiality—this is the true alignment of the Dao and virtue.

Thus, what is webbed in the feet is conjoined flesh without use; what is branched in the hands is an extra finger without use.
**[Annotation]** These arise simply because nature and destiny cannot be otherwise, not because they serve a purpose.
**[Subcommentary]** The conjoined big toe is of no benefit to walking; though such flesh exists, it remains ultimately without use. The extra finger branching from the hand offers no aid in grasping; though such flesh is present, it is ultimately a useless digit. This illustrates that such things are endowed by natural heavenly nature, not generated to assist function.

Those whose emotions are webbed and branched within the five viscera indulge in deviant conduct through benevolence and righteousness.
**[Annotation]** The emotions of the five viscera are naturally manifold, yet those with fewer distinctions forcibly emulate them, leading to excess and deviance, losing the perfect equilibrium within the body.
**[Subcommentary]** The followers of Zeng and Shi, by nature abundant in benevolence and righteousness, allow these emotions to become webbed within the viscera. Those of lesser nature, distorting their true disposition, pride themselves on such conduct and seek heavenly principle—yet lacking spontaneity, they fall into deviance. *Deviance* means stagnation; *perversity* describes unorthodox appearance. They multiply distinctions in the use of intelligence.
**[Annotation]** The use of intelligence has its proper allotment; thus, manifold distinctions are not excessive, nor are few distinctions deficient. Yet the sway of human desires invariably devalues the few and esteems the many. Seeing what is esteemed, they distort themselves to emulate it, thereby exceeding their inherent use and straining their natural disposition. If, however, one forgets what is esteemed and preserves one’s original allotment, then one remains without excess in nature while embracing all distinctions.
**[Subcommentary]** Li Kuang’s original allotment exceeds others in intelligence, yet those of lesser nature distort their emotions to emulate him—is this not deluded?

Thus, what is webbed in clarity disrupts the five colors, indulges in ornate patterns, and dazzles with the brilliance of blue and yellow, vermilion and green—is this not Li Zhu? Indeed, it is.
**[Subcommentary]** The character *wěi* (鮪) denotes an axe-shaped pattern. *Zuò* (做) means two *jǐ* (己) characters back-to-back. The five colors are blue, yellow, red, white, and black. Blue and red form *patterns*; red and white form *ornamentation*. *Huánghuáng* (煌煌) describes a blinding radiance. Is this not Li Zhu? It is. The character *yǐ* (已) is an auxiliary sound. Li Zhu, also called Li Lou, was a keen-sighted man from the time of the Yellow Emperor who could discern the tip of a hair at a hundred paces.

What is excessive in hearing disrupts the five notes, indulges in the six pitch-standards, and clings to the sounds of metal, stone, silk, bamboo, the Yellow Bell, and the Great Regulator—is this not Shi Kuang? Indeed, it is.
**[Annotation]** Those with ears and eyes never trouble themselves by aspiring to deafness or blindness; their trouble always lies in yearning for Li Zhu and Shi Kuang. Thus, though Li Zhu and Shi Kuang are by nature keen of sight and hearing, they become the very agents that disrupt the senses.
**[Subcommentary]** The five notes are *gōng* (宮), *shāng* (商), *jué* (角), *zhǐ* (徵), and *yǔ* (羽). The six pitch-standards include the Yellow Bell, the Great Regulator, Guxi, Linzhong, Wuyi, and Jiazhong. The six pitch-standards are yang; the six pitch-pipes are yin, totaling twelve. The eight sounds are metal, stone, silk, bamboo, gourd, earth, leather, and wood. *Is this not* means clinging to these sounds—is this not Shi Kuang? Shi Kuang, styled Ziye, was a music master of Duke Ping of Jin, profoundly versed in musical harmony. Li Zhu and Shi Kuang, in their original allotment of keen sight and hearing, are emulated by the benighted—having lost their true nature, are they not troubled? Yet their clarity and keenness become the very agents that disrupt the senses.

What is branched in benevolence plucks at virtue and obstructs nature to gather fame, causing the world to clamor like reeds and drums in service of unattainable standards—is this not Zeng and Shi? Indeed, it is.
**[Annotation]** Zeng and Shi were by nature inclined toward benevolence, yet those not so inclined forcibly emulate them, and their emulation of benevolence becomes artificial. The world never emulates Jie’s depravity but instead clamors to follow Zeng and Shi—thus, Zeng and Shi’s fame stirs the world to lose its true nature, more grievously than even Jie’s tyranny.
**[Subcommentary]** *Branched in benevolence* means their original allotment is excessive in benevolence and righteousness, like an extra finger branching from the hand. Displaying the five virtues, they become mired in partiality and deviance, obstructing their true nature. In their dealings with others, they gather fame, causing the common people to rush about in competition, like reeds and drums stirring emotions.

Yet Zeng and Shi were by nature abundant in benevolence and righteousness, while those not so endowed forcibly emulate them, grasping at shortcomings to mimic strengths—thus they uphold laws beyond their reach. *Extraction* means to pluck out; it refers to plucking false virtue, thereby obstructing their true nature.

Zeng was surnamed Zeng, named Shen, styled Ziyu, a disciple of Confucius. Shi was surnamed Shi, named Zeng, styled Ziyu, a minister to Duke Ling of Wei. These two men were both endowed by nature with benevolence and filial piety, hence they are cited as examples.

*Branched in disputation*—like knotting cords or weaving sentences, they roam the mind amid questions of "hard and white" or "same and different," yet exhaust themselves in vaunting useless words—are they not like Yang and Mo?

**[Annotation]** Those who gallop in strange disputation and vie in perilous rhetoric have never paused to ponder the rivers of Taowu, yet they vie in disputation amid the questions of Yang and Mo—thus Yang and Mo become the masters of chaotic discourse.

**[Subcommentary]** Yang was surnamed Yang, named Zhu, styled Ziju, a native of Song. Mo was named Di, also of Song, a grandee of that state; as he practiced the Way of ink, he was called Mo. These two men and their followers, abandoning their true nature, indulged in excessive disputation, all capable of lofty and perilous rhetoric that stirred the nature of things, obstinately clinging to right and wrong. Like knotting and concealing phrases to make them difficult to unravel, their roaming minds in learning dwelt solely on debates over "holding fast to the white" and questions of "same and different," never emerging from the realm of inhumanity.

*Arrogance* arises from self-reliance, and also describes the appearance of exertion. *Praise* means to glorify and commend. The followers of Yang and Mo both flaunt their petty learning, dazzling the multitude, boasting of useless words, and confusing the common people—then are Yang and Mo not the teachers of disorder? This refers precisely to Yang and Mo.

Thus all these are ways of excessive branching and side growths, not the ultimate correctness of the world.

**[Annotation]** These several masters all follow their natural endowments, truly abundant in branching and side growths, each being the correctness of their own school. Yet to take one correctness and apply it to the myriad things is to render the myriad things incorrect. Therefore, the ultimately correct does not use its own correctness to correct the world, but allows the world each to attain its own correctness.

**[Subcommentary]** These several masters all possess natural intelligence, benevolence, and disputation, like conjoined thumbs or extra fingers branching from the side—endowments of their original allotment, not the result of human effort. Thus to follow one’s nature in excess is the way of branching and side growths. Yet the deluded multitude, grasping their own shortcomings to emulate others, seek what lies beyond their allotment, and persist in doing so. By agitating the nature of things, these several men take one correctness and apply it to the myriad, hence they are not the ultimate Way or correct principle of the world.

The truly correct in correcting does not lose the genuine nature of life and destiny.

**[Annotation]** When things each follow their nature, that is true correctness. From this point onward, the ultimate correctness becomes evident.

**[Subcommentary]** Using the correct principle of nature to correct the nature and destiny of the common people—hence it is called *correcting*. Things each attain their own, hence it is said they do not lose. The *nature* spoken of here is the nature of the self, and the *destiny* is also the destiny of the self—how distant is it? Thus *correcting in correcting* speaks of correcting what is not correct, and not correcting what is correct.

From this point upward clarifies the loss in distorting nature; from this point downward reveals the attainment in following nature.

Thus what is joined is not called *conjoined*;
**[Annotation]** When a branch is corrected by the main, then what is joined is called *conjoined*.

nor is what branches called *forked*.
**[Annotation]** When the main is corrected by a branch, then what branches is called *forked*.

**[Subcommentary]** When a branch is corrected by the main, what is joined is called *conjoined*, yet in truth it is not conjoined; when the main is viewed from a branch, what branches is called *forked*, yet in truth it is not forked.

What is long is not called *excessive*;
**[Annotation]** When the short is corrected by the long, then the long is called *excessive*.

nor is what is short called *insufficient*.
**[Annotation]** When the long is corrected by the short, then the short is called *insufficient*.

**[Subcommentary]** The *long* refers to Zeng, Shi, Li Kuang, Yang, and Mo—all endowed by nature with accumulated benevolence and righteousness, intelligence and disputation, surpassing the multitude, hence called *long*. Following their nature in action, they are not excessive. The *short* refers to the common people who do not match Zeng and Shi, hence called *short*; yet their natural mechanism unfolds of itself, hence they are not insufficient.

Thus the leg of a teal, though short, if lengthened causes sorrow; the leg of a crane, though long, if cut causes grief.
**[Annotation]** Each has its own correctness; one cannot use this to correct that and thereby diminish or augment it.

**[Subcommentary]** The *teal* is a small duck. The *crane* is a kind of heron. *Leg* refers to the foot. The principle of nature nurtures all forms: though their lengths differ, each body is sufficient for its function, all attaining carefree ease. Yet some would sever the crane’s long leg to lengthen the teal’s short one, deeply violating creation and losing their original nature—hence sorrow and grief. Thus what is long by nature is not to be cut, and what is short by nature is not to be lengthened; there is nothing to remove or sorrow over.

**[Annotation]** Knowing that one’s allotted nature is not to be cut or lengthened and allowing it to be, there is nothing to remove, and sorrow removes itself.

**[Subcommentary]** Endowed with nature and receiving form, each has its measure; long and short are fitting, their original allotments different. Like the teal and crane, they are not to be cut or lengthened. Thus, each guarding their allotted portion, though there is no effort to remove sorrow, sorrow removes itself.

Alas! Are benevolence and righteousness not part of human nature?
**[Annotation]** Benevolence and righteousness are indeed part of human nature and emotions, but they should simply be allowed to follow their course.

Why then are those benevolent men so full of sorrow?
**[Annotation]** Those who fear that benevolence and righteousness are not part of human nature and thus sorrow over it—truly they may be called full of sorrow.

**[Subcommentary]** *Alas* is an exclamation of sighing.

Those of benevolent and righteous disposition act from Heavenly principle, following their nature in possessing them—not through imitation or emulation. Yet the so-called benevolent men, followers of Zeng and Shi, fail to embody the true essence, arbitrarily generating exhortations and rewards, claiming the Way of benevolence and righteousness can be learned and achieved. Master Zhuang deeply lamented this delusion, hence his sigh of sorrow. For they draw things beyond their proper bounds—thus are they called "full of sorrow."

Is it not part of human nature? Indeed, it is part of human nature and emotions.

Moreover, those with conjoined toes weep when severed; those with extra fingers wail when cut. Whether in excess or deficiency of the proper number, their sorrow is the same.

**[Annotation]** Deemed deficient, they weep when excised; considered excessive, they wail when severed. How could it be otherwise? Though the myriad beings differ in kind, there is no ground for releasing sorrow. Only by each abiding in their Heaven-given nature, neither excising conjoined toes nor severing extra fingers, can they be perfectly formed without harm—what sorrow then remains?

**[Subcommentary]** *Yi* means to gnaw and sever; *ci* means to separate and divide. "Excess in number" refers to the growth of a sixth finger; "deficiency in number" refers to conjoined toes forming four. These two conditions, conjoined toes and extra fingers, arise naturally from Heaven. They should simply be left as they are, for neither is more nor less. Yet some cannot remain indifferent, stubbornly clinging to right and wrong, deeming extra fingers excessive and conjoined toes deficient, arbitrarily seeking to excise or sever them to conform to the number five. Having harmed the work of creation, they cause weeping and wailing—thus, though the methods of excision differ, their sorrow is one.

The benevolent men of this age, their eyes troubled by the world’s ills,

**[Annotation]** If the path of universal love is deemed admirable, then the world’s eyes will be thrown into chaos. To admire such a path, then lament that it has not yet brought peace, is to plunge people into peril before rescuing them—yet this is precisely what the present age calls benevolence.

**[Subcommentary]** *Hao* means eyes in turmoil. Benevolence is the advancement of universal love. "This age" refers to the degenerate era.

The followers of Zengzi and Shishu, practicing this universal love, thus lead some to imitate others in emulating them. Once the path of seeking favor is opened, the functions of ears and eyes are thrown into chaos. When ears and eyes are in chaos, calamities and difficulties arise. Thereupon, they lament the turmoil and seek to remedy it with benevolence and righteousness, unaware that the source of calamities and difficulties lies in the promotion of sagely conduct.

The unbenevolent, severing the true nature of life and its essence, covet wealth and honor.
**[Annotation]** Wealth and honor are coveted only because there are those who esteem them. If there were no promotion of what is admirable, people would rest content in their lot, measuring their strength to accept their tasks—how could they imitate others to covet and usurp what is beyond their due?

**[Subcommentary]** *Tao* means to covet wealth. Those who, by nature, do not embrace benevolence and righteousness are called the unbenevolent. Their intent lies in seeking profit and emolument, stealthily usurping wealth and honor. Thus, they sever their innate nature, lose the true essence of their allotted fate, and feign a false nature, abandoning themselves to pursue external things. This arises precisely because the promotion of sagely conduct is deemed admirable, giving rise to such abuses. From this, we know that to embrace simplicity and return to purity, one must sever benevolence and abandon righteousness. Thus, can benevolence and righteousness truly be considered the natural sentiments of humanity?

**[Subcommentary]** This further reinforces the preceding argument. Since the Three Dynasties, why has the world been so clamorous?
**[Annotation]** Benevolence and righteousness are indeed human sentiments. Yet since the Three Dynasties, people have clamorously abandoned their true nature to pursue promotion, as if they could not keep up—is this not a cause for great sorrow?

**[Subcommentary]** *Since* means from. The Three Dynasties refer to Xia, Yin, and Zhou. *Clamorous* means noisy and chaotic. Benevolence and righteousness arise from innate nature. Yet since the Three Dynasties, people have abandoned their nature to chase after external pursuits, clamorously competing—how foolish this is! Thus, the Xia practiced benevolence, the Yin practiced righteousness, and the Zhou practiced ritual—this is the very state of clamor.

Those who rely on hooks, plumb lines, compasses, and squares to set things right are carving away at their nature.
**[Subcommentary]** Hooks make things curved; plumb lines, straight. Compasses make things round; squares, square. Things rely on hooks, plumb lines, compasses, and squares to achieve curvature, straightness, roundness, and squareness—these are not their natural state. This illustrates that people who rely on teachings to practice benevolence and righteousness do not act from their true nature. To act with true spontaneity is not to rely on learning. Thus, those who feign a false nature, abandon themselves to imitate external things, and practice benevolence and righteousness are destroying and damaging their innate nature.

Those who rely on ropes, glue, and lacquer to make things firm are encroaching upon their virtue.
**[Subcommentary]** *Rely* means to bind. *Firm* means secure. *Encroaching* means to harm. *Virtue* means true wisdom. Those who rely on ropes to bind and glue and lacquer to secure are depending on external things rather than true firmness. This illustrates that those who emulate Zengzi and Shishu to practice benevolence are acting with falsity, not from their true nature. Having deviated from their original nature, they thus encroach upon their virtue.

To bend and break with ritual and music, to comply with benevolence and righteousness in order to comfort the hearts of the world, is to lose one’s constant nature.
**[Subcommentary]** *Bend* means to curve; *break*, to sever. *Comply* means to nurture and soothe. To twist the straight into the curved is to impose ritual with its nodes and patterns; to sever the long to fit the short is to practice music with its extravagance. To nurture partial love as benevolence and to comply with the path of righteousness—using these falsehoods to comfort the hearts of things—leads beings to lose their truth and people to forsake their roots. Thus, they abandon the root to chase the branches, losing their true, constant, and natural nature. This summarizes the errors of the preceding text to introduce the gains of what follows.

The world has its constant nature. That which is constant: the curved does not rely on hooks, the straight does not rely on plumb lines, the round does not rely on compasses, the square does not rely on squares, adhesion does not rely on glue and lacquer, and binding does not rely on ropes.
**[Subcommentary]** The myriad things of the world each have their constant allotment. For example, mugwort is curved and hemp is straight; heads are round and feet are square. Water congeals in winter and melts in summer; fish gather in spring and scatter in autumn. These arise from nature, not from external things—how could hooks, plumb lines, compasses, squares, glue, lacquer, or ropes be applied to them? Just as this is so for forms, so it is for nature. Thus, we know that ritual, music, benevolence, and righteousness are what disorder the warp of heaven.

**[Alternative Explanation]** *Adhesion* means to depend. Thus, the *Han History* states: "During the reign of Emperor Ai, those who depended on the Dong clan all rose to positions of two thousand bushels." The annotation explains: *Depend* means to rely upon. Thus, the world, in its natural course, gives birth to all things without knowing why they are born, and all attain their lot without knowing how they attain it.
**[Annotation]** Things have their constant nature. When left to themselves without interference, people naturally attain their lot without self-awareness.

**[Subcommentary]** As things are born, receiving qi and taking form, some are square, some round, now curved, now straight. Nurtured and poisoned, each is sufficient in its nature, yet none discerns why this is so, nor knows the reason. How could they be troubled by anxious thoughts or their hearts bound to gain and loss? Thus, to bend and comply is to lose one’s constant nature. Therefore, from ancient times to the present, there is no duality—it cannot be diminished.

**[Annotation]** Being of the same substance as things, one remains undivided and constantly whole with them.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who see beginnings and ends as not one are deluded by common sentiments. Those who perceive that from ancient times to the present there is no duality possess the illumination of sagely wisdom. Thus, though not born, they are born without knowing why; though not attaining, they attain without knowing how. Though there may be ancient times and the present, the Dao remains undiminished. Through a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, it is ever one and constant. Then why should benevolence and righteousness cling like glue and lacquer, ropes and bindings, wandering amidst the questions of the Dao and virtue?

**[Annotation]** Those who attain by following the Dao embrace simplicity and walk alone, free from the clinging of external things, acting without interference.

**[Subcommentary]** *Why* means what. *Clinging* means continuous attachment.

The Dao and virtue are neither being nor non-being, neither arising nor ceasing. They cannot be sought through sagely wisdom, nor grasped through forms and names. Yet the likes of Zengzi and Shishi, whose natures abound in benevolence, lead others by their own example, entangled in the web of names and teachings. Bound as if by ropes, fixed as if by glue and lacquer, their thoughts follow one after another in unbroken succession. Those who carry such conduct and arrogantly wander the realm of the Dao and virtue are like one who studies the square to master the round, or a fish that yearns to be a bird—vainly chasing the name of lofty aspiration while lacking any true efficacy. They forget not the fish and hare in their pursuit of the trap and snare, yet lose even the straw dogs already discarded. What value is there in this? It only serves to confuse the world.

**[Annotation]** The unbroken clinging to benevolence and righteousness is enough to delude others and cause them to lose their true nature.

**[Subcommentary]** The teachings of the Seven Virtues and the discourses of the wise deviate from the natural Way and disorder the hearts of the world. Minor delusion confuses direction; great delusion alters one’s nature.

**[Annotation]** Though east and west may be confused, the body remains unharmed. But to pride oneself on transformation and exalt righteousness is to lose one’s constant nature. To die for such causes is the greatest delusion.

**[Subcommentary]** To mistake south for north is but a small error; to be ensnared by teachings and lose one’s true nature is a far greater delusion. How do we know this is so?

**[Subcommentary]** *So* means thus. This is a rhetorical question leading to what follows.

Ever since the time of Yu’s promotion of benevolence and righteousness to govern the world, none have not rushed to answer the call of benevolence and righteousness.

**[Annotation]** One who harms nothing is not acting out of benevolence, yet transformation naturally unfolds. One who makes all principles accord is not acting out of righteousness, yet the efficacy of righteousness manifests. Thus, what is fitting and harmless is not the result of benevolence and righteousness. Yet the world rushes and races, abandoning the self to pursue externals, losing its constant nature. Therefore, the mind is not disordered by ugliness but by beauty; the world is not troubled by evil but by benevolence and righteousness. Thus, benevolence and righteousness are the very tools that disorder the world.

**[Subcommentary]** *Yu* refers to Shun. *Promotion* means adoption. *Disorder* means confusion. Before the time of Yao, people still embraced simplicity; after Shun, the pure wind gradually dissipated. Thus, the sagely discourses of the Seven Virtues were used to guide the common people, causing all under heaven to rush about in confusion, losing their nature and chasing after sagely teachings. Is this not a case of benevolence and righteousness altering one’s nature?

**[Annotation]** Though Shun had no intention of altering others, the nature of the world was already changed.

**[Subcommentary]** From this, is it not clear that the use of benevolence and sagely teachings has disordered the world, causing people to abandon the root and pursue the branch, thereby corrupting their natural nature?

Thus, let us examine the matter: from the Three Dynasties onward, none under heaven have not exchanged their nature for external things.

**[Annotation]** Before the Three Dynasties, there were indeed teachings of non-action. Yet even the promotion of non-action is something the active seek to emulate. To emulate it is to lose one’s natural simplicity. Thus, even the sage has no choice but to sometimes exchange the ease of effortless rule for the toil of hardship. How much more so for the common people?

**[Subcommentary]** Before the Five Emperors, the wind of non-action still prevailed; from the Three Dynasties onward, teachings of action gradually arose. Different ages, different customs—thus, people imitate others and abandon their true nature, chasing externals without return. Is this not lamentable? The annotation speaks of exchanging the ease of effortless rule for the toil of hardship: *hardship* refers to injury. It says that Yu endured wind and rain, his hands and feet calloused, exchanging the work of non-action for such toil. Since the ruler did so, the people followed suit.

The petty person sacrifices himself for profit; the scholar, for fame; the grandee, for his family; the sage, for the world.

**[Annotation]** The quail dwells in a nest, the crow flies without pattern—what do they惜 not to sacrifice? Thus, they remain ever in harmony with the world, adapting to whatever comes. Their path is but the course of worldly sacrifice. Yet what they encounter may sometimes involve the hardship of injury or the loss of hair. Their course is but the way of harming nature. Yet though they roam the eight extremities, their spirit and qi remain unchanged; though their hands and feet may be calloused, their embodied form is undisturbed. What, then, do they sacrifice? Nothing. Thus, they do not sacrifice what they seem to sacrifice but instead follow the world in its sacrifices.

**[Subcommentary]** *Sacrifice* means to follow, to pursue, to seek, to chase—what the self follows. The petty person chases profit; the scholar values fame; the grandee sacrifices himself for his family; the emperor pursues the world. Though what they sacrifice differs, their alteration of nature is the same. Yet the sage remains ever in harmony with the world, and his course is but sacrifice. Thus, though he may suffer injury or loss, his spirit is never burdened. Therefore, though these several types differ in their undertakings and their reputations vary, in their harm to nature and their self-sacrifice, they are one.

**[Subcommentary]** *These several types* refers to the four mentioned above. *Undertakings* refers to their differing pursuits—profit, fame, family, and the world. *Reputations* refers to the varying titles of petty person, scholar, grandee, and sage. Though these four differ in their undertakings and reputations, in their harm to life and pursuit of externals, they are no different.

Zang and Gu, the two of them, were herding sheep together and both lost their sheep.

**[Subcommentary]** This continues the previous analogy to introduce what follows. The *Mencius* says: Zang was a good learner; Gu, a young man. Yang Xiong says: *Zang* refers to a son-in-law; *Gu*, to a child of a good family. *Herding* means tending. *Lost* means to lose.

These two men, though differing in name and pursuit, both lost their sheep. When asked what Zang was doing, he was clutching bamboo slips and reading; when asked what Gu was doing, he was gambling and idling. Though their pursuits differed, in losing their sheep they were the same.

**[Subcommentary]** *What* means "why." *Slips* refers to bamboo or wooden tablets. In ancient times, without paper, all books were written on slips. *Five roads intersecting and tossing dice* is called *bo*; without tossing dice, it is called *se*. Though Zang and Gu differed—one with books, the other with dice—in herding sheep and losing them, there was no difference.

Boyi died for fame beneath Shouyang Mountain, while Robber Zhi died for profit atop Dongling Peak.

**[Subcommentary]** This continues the analogy. Boyi and Shuqi were both sons of the Lord of Guboo, descendants of Shennong of the Jiang clan. Boyi, named Yun, styled Gongxin; Shuqi, named Zheng, styled Gongyuan. Boyi was the elder but born of a concubine; Shuqi was younger but born of the wife. Their father favored Shuqi and often praised him to Boyi. When their father died, the brothers yielded the succession to each other and did not inherit the throne. Hearing that King Wen was virtuous, they went to Zhou. When King Wu campaigned against Zhou, they grasped his horse’s bridle to remonstrate. Their advice was ignored, so they fled to Shouyang Mountain, gathering ferns for food and refusing to eat grain. They starved to death on Shouyang Mountain, which lies in present-day Pu County, Shanxi. Thirty *li* south of the prefectural city, the temple and tomb of Boyi and Shuqi stand amid dense forests. Robber Zhi was the younger brother of Liuxia Hui, named Zhi, with nine thousand followers. A notorious bandit, he was named for his trade. Dongling was a mountain, also said to be Mount Tai, located in Qi Prefecture, fifteen *li* from Dongping. Zhi died there. Though their deaths differed, in harming life and injuring nature they were the same.

**[Subcommentary]** Boyi died for fame beneath Shouyang Mountain; Robber Zhi died for profit atop Dongling Peak. Though what they died for—fame or profit—differed, in harming and injuring themselves, they were no different. Why must Boyi be right and Robber Zhi wrong?

**[Commentary]** What the world values is life. Now, when they sacrifice it so excessively, both harm their lives. Then the rightness or wrongness of what they sacrifice is no longer worth discussing.

**[Subcommentary]** By worldly standards, there is good and bad; from the perspective of the Dao, what is right and what is wrong? Thus, Robber Zhi is not necessarily wrong, nor is Boyi uniquely right. The world is wholly given to sacrifice. Those who sacrifice for benevolence and righteousness are called *junzi* by the world; those who sacrifice for wealth and property are called *xiaoren*.

**[Subcommentary]** This summarizes the preceding to introduce what follows. The Dao has long been lost, and none act rightly. Now, in the world, all sacrifice—how could only Boyi and Zhi do so? Those who follow benevolence and righteousness never escape fame; those who chase wealth and property are fixed on profit. Only fame and profit are the roots of harming life, not the heavenly principle but arising from worldly sentiment. *Junzi* and *xiaoren* cannot be taken as reliable standards. Since their sacrifice is one, there are *junzi* and *xiaoren*; but if one considers harming life and injuring nature, then Robber Zhi is no different from Boyi. How then can one distinguish *junzi* from *xiaoren*?

**[Commentary]** The world all considers not harming life as good. Now, when all equally harm life, though what they sacrifice differs, it is no longer worth calculating. Why harm life? Why alter nature? It all stems from esteeming the path of non-action. If one knows that advancement arises from non-action and is accomplished thereby, then one will cease excessive esteem and return to the profound limit of the self.

Yao and Jie will be equal in self-contentment; how then distinguish *junzi* from *xiaoren*?

**[Subcommentary]** *How* means "why." Though their sacrifices—fame or profit—differ, producing the distinction between *junzi* and *xiaoren*, in harming life and injuring nature, there is no difference between Robber Zhi and Boyi. This is merely a worldly distinction, unrelated to the true ultimate. By what can one take *junzi*? By what can one distinguish *xiaoren*? There is no difference.

Moreover, those who bind their nature to benevolence and righteousness, though as accomplished as Zengzi and Shishi, are not what I call good.

**[Commentary]** *Bind* means to attach to that. Binding one’s nature to benevolence is merely sacrificing for benevolence, which is not good.

**[Subcommentary]** *Bind* means to attach. *Good* refers to excellence. *I* refers to Zhuangzi himself. Those who abandon themselves to imitate others, gaining things at the cost of the self, follow the false sentiments of the vulgar. Thus, to attach one’s heavenly nature to learning benevolence and righteousness, though as accomplished and near to sageliness as Mo Di or Yang Zhu, is contrary to one’s original nature and not what I call good in nurturing life.

Those who bind their nature to the five flavors, though as accomplished as Yu Er, are not what I call good.

**[Commentary]** Following one’s nature to master flavors is good.

**[Subcommentary]** The *Mencius* says: Yu Er was a man of Qi skilled in flavors. The *Shizi* says: Yu Er blended ginger and cinnamon for the ruler’s meals. Those who lack their own heavenly essence and imitate things to gain knowledge, even if as accomplished as Yu Er, are not good.

Those who bind their nature to the five sounds, though as accomplished as Music Master Kuang, are not what I call keen of hearing; those who bind their nature to the five colors, though as accomplished as Li Zhu, are not what I call clear of sight.

**[Commentary]** Not entrusting it to the self but binding it to that, though as accomplished as that, the self is already lost. Thus, to employ one’s ears and eyes freely without binding them to Li or Kuang is true keenness and clarity.

**[Subcommentary]** Li Zhu and Music Master Kuang were endowed with keen sight and hearing, following their nature to excel, not through learning. Now, to distort one’s nature and feign sentiment, abandoning the self to imitate things—though accomplished, this is not worth calling good.

What I call good is not benevolence and righteousness; it is being good in one’s own power alone.

**[Commentary]** Good in attaining the self, forgetting benevolence yet embodying benevolence.

**[Subcommentary]** *Virtue* is *attainment*. Those who penetrate the mysterious Dao do not alter their nature to follow others—how could they still cling to the straw dogs of their own past or govern with the linked huts of former kings? Thus, to know what one inherently knows, to attain what one inherently attains, and to regard this as good—is this not fitting?

What I call *good* is not what is meant by benevolence and righteousness; it is simply following the true nature of one’s life and destiny.

**[Commentary]** To call benevolence and righteousness *good* is to harm the self in pursuit of them—this is truly unbenevolent toward one’s own nature and life. If the self is not benevolent, how can it be so toward others? Therefore, to follow one’s nature and life is to be able to reach others; reaching others without burdening the self, both self and other abide in attainment—this may be called *good*.

**[Subcommentary]** Zeng Shen, Shi Yu, Yang Zhu, and Mo Di—these four practiced benevolence and righteousness, yet they did so by following their nature and yielding to their innate endowment, like branches growing paired from birth, not through learned effort. But some, ignorant of Zeng and Shi’s benevolence, claim that imitation can achieve it; hearing of Li Zhu and Music Master Kuang’s keenness, they believe such skill can be attained through diligent practice.

Does one truly comprehend the Creator’s nurturing and sustaining power? Thus Wang Bi’s commentary on the *Book of Changes* states: "Without following one’s nature in its true essence, how can one endure long in its practice?" This is precisely the meaning here.

What I call "keen hearing" does not mean hearing others, but hearing oneself alone. What I call "clear sight" does not mean seeing others, but seeing oneself alone.

**[Annotation]** To sever all ties with Li Zhu and Music Master Kuang, relying solely on one’s own hearing and sight—this is how the keen perception and clarity of all directions are preserved intact.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who yearn for Li Zhu’s vision or emulate Music Master Kuang’s acuity, straining to see what lies beyond or hear what is distant, scatter their spirit and exhaust their ears and eyes—this is mere folly, not true clarity. But if one listens only to what the ear naturally hears and sees only what the eye naturally sees, preserving one’s allotted nature and remaining unshaken by externals, then all things are perceived with perfect clarity.

To see not oneself but others, to attain not one’s own attainment but another’s—this is to gain another’s gains while losing one’s own, to follow another’s path while forsaking one’s own.

**[Annotation]** This is to abandon oneself and imitate others. Though one may mimic them perfectly, one’s own self is already lost.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who cannot see what their own eyes see but instead seek Li Zhu’s clarity, or who cannot know what their own knowledge knows but instead strive to emulate Shi Yu’s righteousness—these merely feign the attainments of others through learned pretense, not by following their nature to attain their own. Having thus falsely learned and outwardly displayed, they imitate others to please the world, laboring in deception—hence they do not follow their own path. To follow another’s path while forsaking one’s own, whether one be a thief like Zhi or a paragon like Boyi, is equally perverse and excessive.

**[Annotation]** If one takes the loss of one’s nature as perversity, then though the paths of loss may differ, the loss itself is the same.

**[Subcommentary]** *Yin* means stagnation; *pi* means deviation. To preserve one’s allotted nature and follow the true Way is upright; to pursue fame and rivalry is perverse and excessive. Thus those who abandon themselves to chase externals, opening the path of vain hope—whether in Boyi’s goodness or Zhi’s evil—are equally deviant. The repetition of "following another’s path" here serves to conclude the preceding and introduce what follows, strengthening the rhetorical flow.

I am ashamed before the Dao and virtue. Thus above, I dare not adopt the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, and below, I dare not engage in perverse and excessive actions.

**[Annotation]** Ashamed of not embodying the Dao and virtue, and acknowledging no achievement in profound return, I therefore sever all conduct, forget fame and profit, move with ease through burdens, relinquish the self, and forget others—this alone suffices.

**[Subcommentary]** The Way of emptiness and penetration, the virtue of perfect forgetting—it transcends benevolence and righteousness, beyond categories and names. Yet Master Zhuang, subtly abiding in the center, roams beyond the realm of things, his resolve and conduct free from benevolence and righteousness, his heart and actions forgetful of right and wrong. He embodies the natural absence of being, the non-action of the Dao and virtue. The reference to "above and below" distinguishes the superiority of benevolence and righteousness from the inferiority of perversity and excess. To say "I am ashamed and dare not" is an expression of humility.

Guo Xiang’s annotation speaks of "moving with ease through burdens": *congrong* means unhurried; *chuilei* means acting without intention—like the wind stirring, lifting the lightest dust.

*Annotations and Subcommentary on the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Ten, concludes. (Wang Xiaoyu supplements based on *Shiwen*.)

**#4** *Quewu* 《阙误》 cites Zhang Junfang’s edition with *fang* 方 rendered as *kou* 口.
**#5** Guo Qingfan’s citation omits the character *er* 而, and *zhi* 之 appears below *yan* 言.
**#6** Guo Qingfan’s citation renders *zheng* 正 as *wang* 望.
**#7** The character *wang* 望 is supplied following Guo Qingfan’s citation and the context above and below.
**#8** Guo Qingfan’s citation renders *ci* 此 as *bi* 比.
**#9** Wang Xiaoyu emends the text, placing *fei* 非 below *qi* 其.
**#10** The Zhejiang Bureau edition and Shide Hall edition render *sui* 虽 as *ju* 举.
**#11** Guo Qingfan’s citation includes the character *sheng* 生 below *yi* 以.
**#12** The Siku edition and Zhejiang Bureau edition both render *pan* 盘 as *pan* 盘; the subcommentary follows suit.

**#14** Wang Xiaoyu supplies the character *jia* 家 below *ming* 名 in accordance with the main text.
**#15** The Siku edition and Zhejiang Bureau edition both render *bian* 辩 as *bian* 辨; Wang Xiaoyu emends to *bian* 辩 following the Shide Hall edition.
**#16** Guo Qingfan’s citation renders *Mo Di, Yang Zhu* 墨翟、杨朱 as *Zeng Shen, Shi Yu* 曾参、史鱼.
**#17** Guo Qingfan’s citation renders *qi* 歧 as *zhi* 致.
**#18** Guo Qingfan’s citation renders *jie* 结 as *die* 迭.
The character *chao* 超 is suspected to be an error for *qi* 起; here corrected following Guo Qingfan’s citation.

*Annotations and Subcommentary on the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*, Scroll Eleven.
**Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan.**

**Exegesis by Tang Dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying**
*Outer Chapters, "Horse's Hooves," Ninth*

The horse’s hooves tread frost and snow; its coat wards off wind and cold. It grazes on grass when hungry, drinks from streams when thirsty, and leaps with lifted hooves—this is the horse’s true nature.

*[Annotation]*
Each steed, whether swift or slow, finds sufficiency in its own body.

*[Exegesis]*
*Yóu* 鱿 means "teeth"; *jiàn* 践, "to tread"; *yù* 御, "to shield"; *qiào* 翘, "to raise." The hooves tread frost and snow; the coat shields against wind and cold. When hungry, it grazes; when thirsty, it drinks. At ease and content in its nature, it lifts its hooves to bound and prance, following the endowment of the Creator. How could its true nature desire the bit and bridle, the tether and stable, to be tamed and kept? Moreover, the myriad beings differ in form, yet all rely on their innate allotment. When left to follow their nature, each attains freedom. Without pride or ambition, their lives remain secure. Though there be *Xī* pavilions and *Lù* halls, they are of no use.

*[Annotation]*
The horse’s true nature does not shun the saddle or despise riding; it simply harbors no longing for glory and splendor.

*[Exegesis]*
*Xī* 羲 means "to nurture," referring to the pavilions where nobles raise and guard their retinues. Alternatively, *Xī* 羲 may signify *líng* 灵, the "spirit terrace." *Lù* 路 means "grand" or "proper," denoting the great hall of the main residence. The horse’s nature delights in the open wilds; though there be lofty pavilions and grand halls, they are of no use to it. How much more so for the man of pure emptiness or the folk of unadorned simplicity, who find joy in thatched cottages and contentment in earthen windows? Even if vermilion pillars and carved rafters were offered, what would they matter to me?

Then came Bo Le, who declared, "I excel at managing horses." He branded them, trimmed them, pared their hooves, bound them with bridles and halters, and confined them with slatted stalls—of these, two or three in ten perished.

*[Annotation]*
To treat them with intent is to fail in treating them. What is called "good treatment" is in truth no treatment at all.

*[Exegesis]*
The *Liezi* states: His surname was Sūn, given name Yáng, courtesy name Bó Lè, a man of the state of Qín during the reign of Duke Mù, famed for his skill in managing horses. *Shāo* 烧 means "to sear with hot iron"; *tī* 剔, "to shear their coats"; *kè* 刻, "to pare their hooves"; *luò* 络, "to fit them with bridles." *Jī* 羁 refers to the hobble that connects the legs; *bì* 毕, the tether that restrains the front hooves. *Zào* 阜 denotes the feeding trough; *zhàn* 栈, the slatted boards placed beneath the horse’s hooves to keep them dry—what is called a "horse stall." Unable to allow the horse’s true nature free rein, he wantonly sears and trims them, violating Heaven’s principle, and many die as a result. How much more so for those who, without intent, follow things as they are—thus preserving their nature and life. But to treat them with intent is to cut short their Heaven-appointed years. He starves them, parches them, drives them to gallop, forces them to sprint, disciplines and orders them. Ahead lies the peril of ornate trappings; behind, the threat of whip and rod. Of these horses, more than half perish.

*[Annotation]*
The skilled charioteer seeks to exhaust the horse’s abilities. Yet exhausting its abilities lies in allowing it to act of its own accord. Instead, he drives it to perform beyond its capacity, and thus many cannot endure and die. If one were to employ the strengths of swift and slow horses alike, adapting to their natural pace—though they might traverse the ends of the Eight Wastes—the nature of all horses would remain intact. Yet some, upon hearing of allowing the horse’s nature free rein, assume this means abandoning it unridden. Upon hearing of the wind of non-action, they claim that inaction is superior to action. How far have they strayed, never to return! They have utterly lost the essence of Master Zhuāng’s teaching.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Root" refers to the crosspiece, meaning the furnace is adorned with precious ornaments. A whip is made with hide, while a rod is without; both are implements for driving horses. When galloping exceeds their capacity and hunger and thirst disrupt their routine, they are restrained with the crossbar and yoke, aligned with bit and bridle, and coerced with rod and whip—all to demand abilities beyond their nature. Thus, the weak and slow cannot endure, and more than half perish. The harm wrought by sagely wisdom in governing things is no different.

The potter says: "I excel at shaping clay. The round conforms to the compass, the square to the carpenter’s square."
**[Subcommentary]** *Fàn* means to mold earth. *Táo* is the potter’s wheel, also a kiln. *Shī* is clay, also earth. The potter skillfully blends water and earth to craft vessels, ensuring that round and square shapes precisely meet the compass and square.

The carpenter says: "I excel at shaping wood. The curved fits the hook, the straight aligns with the plumb line."
**[Subcommentary]** *Shé* means curved. *Shéng* is the plumb line. The carpenter, with ingenuity, skillfully works wood, so that its curves and straightness conform to hook and line.

Yet do the natures of clay and wood truly desire to meet compass, square, hook, and line?
**[Subcommentary]** The natures of earth and wood are endowed by the Creator. They do not seek curvature or straightness, nor do they yearn for square or round. Yet potters and carpenters arbitrarily judge them as good or bad.

Nevertheless, generation after generation, people praise Bo Le for his skill in training horses and potters and carpenters for their mastery of clay and wood—this is the error of those who govern the world.
**[Annotation]** The world deems those who follow nature without artifice as unskilled in governance. To bend the crooked into straightness, to grind the dull into sharpness, to wield compass and square to forcefully correct their natures until death—this is called "skillful governance." Is this not a grave error?
**[Subcommentary]** This summarizes the preceding analogy to unify the comparison. Yet the world’s foolishness and delusion regard governance as virtue and non-governance as deceit—the greatest deceit of all. My view is that those who truly govern the world well do not act thus.
**[Annotation]** To govern through non-governance—this is true governance.
**[Subcommentary]** *Rán* means "in this manner." *Zhuāngzǐ* states: My view is that those who govern the world well do not resemble the potters and carpenters of old. The principles of good governance are elaborated below.

The people possess an enduring nature: they weave to clothe themselves and till to feed themselves—this is called "shared virtue."
**[Annotation]** The people’s virtue differs in small ways but aligns in the essentials. What cannot be removed from their nature is clothing and food; what cannot be abandoned in their affairs is plowing and weaving. These are the shared foundations of the world. To uphold this Way is the perfection of non-action.
**[Subcommentary]** *Bǐ mín* refers to the common folk. It means all living beings possess a true and constant nature, unburdened by external things. *Dé* means "attainment." Following their true and constant nature, each thing is self-sufficient—hence "shared virtue." Guo Xiang says: What cannot be removed from their nature is clothing and food; what cannot be abandoned in their affairs is plowing and weaving. These are the world’s shared foundations. To uphold this Way is the perfection of non-action.

Being unified yet impartial, this is called "Heaven’s release."
**[Annotation]** Released, they naturally become one—not partial, hence called "Heaven’s release."
**[Subcommentary]** *Dǎng* means bias. *Mìng* means "to name." *Tiān* is nature. The empty and unobstructed Way nurtures all things, fostering and sustaining them without bias. If one governs with intent, it deviates from nature. To simply release and entrust them is to allow all things to fulfill themselves—hence the name "Heaven’s release."

Thus, in the age of utmost virtue, their movements are full and steady, their gazes lofty and unyielding.
**[Annotation]** This describes their self-sufficiency within, seeking nothing beyond.
**[Subcommentary]** *Tián-tián* expresses a heart filled with contentment. *Diān-diān* conveys a gaze of lofty integrity. In the era of primordial harmony and utmost virtue, minds are freed from right and wrong, actions forget self and other. Thus, guarding their true nature within, they dwell in fullness through non-action; without seeking externally, they advance in loftiness toward emptiness and tranquility.

In such times, mountains have no paths or tunnels, marshes no boats or bridges.
**[Annotation]** Without seeking undeserved gains, they remain content within their households.
**[Subcommentary]** *Qī* means paths; *suì* means roads. *Zhōu* means boats. In such an age—the era of utmost virtue—people know their proper limits, and all things are pure and simple. Without plundering or seizing, paths and roads are abandoned; without coming or going, boats and bridges fall into disuse.

The myriad things flourish, each connected to its homeland.
**[Annotation]** In their primal chaos, all things attain their nature equally. They blend indistinguishably with the world, so how could nations differ or households diverge?
**[Subcommentary]** In this primal and indistinct era, harmony is pure and tranquil. Thus, the senseless myriad things are linked, sharing the same villages; the sentient multitude are bound, sharing the same districts. How could nations differ in governance or households vary in custom?

Birds and beasts form flocks, grasses and trees grow unchecked.
**[Annotation]** Content with their nature, they harbor no desires to consume or destroy—hence all things remain whole.
**[Subcommentary]** Flying birds and running beasts are unharmed, so they gather in flocks; herbs and trees are uncut, so they flourish in abundance.

Thus, birds and beasts can be leashed and led to roam, and the nests of crows and magpies can be climbed to peer inside.
**[Annotation]** Harmless to things, all things become docile.
**[Subcommentary]** Without intent to harm, things feel no fear of humans. Thus, mountain birds and wild beasts can be leashed and led to wander; the nests of crows and magpies can be climbed to observe.

In the age of utmost virtue, humans dwell alongside birds and beasts, and their kind mingles with the myriad things. How then can one distinguish between noble and base?
**[Subcommentary]** Those who pursue external things with perverse intent are the base; those who tread the Way with upright conduct are the noble. Yet in such an age, dwelling in nests and caves, they resemble birds and beasts—how can one distinguish between them?

With mouths full and bellies drumming, they mingle with the myriad things without distinction. How then can one discern the noble? How then can one distinguish the base?

Alike in non-knowing, their virtue does not depart.
**[Annotation]** Knowing departs from the Dao to pursue goodness.
**[Subcommentary]** Devoid of discriminating minds, they are one with the principle of non-knowing. Without resorting to perilous virtue to seek conduct, they embrace the One and do not stray.

Alike in non-desiring, this is called plain simplicity.
**[Annotation]** Desire departs from nature to pursue adornment.
**[Subcommentary]** Alike in the desirelessness of their original state, things remain pure and at peace; unlike the decadence of later ages, people retain their unadorned simplicity. In plain simplicity, the people’s nature is preserved.
**[Annotation]** Free from the entanglements of knowing and desiring.
**[Subcommentary]** The reason the common people lose their nature is that they are ensnared by desire. Thus, in desirelessness and plain simplicity, their true nature remains unlost—hence it is said to be preserved. This line summarizes the beauty of the age of utmost virtue.

Yet when it comes to the sage,
**[Annotation]** The sage is the path by which the people recover their nature, not the path they follow. Here, "when it comes to the sage" means "when it comes to their advancement."
they strain and stumble in the name of benevolence, they totter and trip in the name of righteousness—and the world begins to doubt. They indulge in extravagance as joy, they pick and choose in the name of ritual—and the world begins to divide.
**[Annotation]** Once the sage’s advancement becomes manifest, benevolence and righteousness are no longer genuine, and ritual and music depart from nature, merely assuming outward forms.
If the sage gives rise to such ills, what am I to do?

**[Subcommentary]** From the above to here, the text extols the virtue of unadorned simplicity; from here onward, it censures the failings of the sage’s advancement. "When it comes to the sage" refers to those who practiced sage-like advancement from the Five Emperors onward. "Straining and stumbling" describes the exertion of effort; "tottering and tripping" conveys an air of self-importance. "Extravagance" denotes a heart given to indulgence; "picking and choosing" refers to conduct that is convoluted and constrained. As unadorned simplicity wanes, artifice arises. Tottering and tripping in the name of righteousness that is partial and judgmental, straining and stumbling in the name of benevolence that is biased and loving; indulging in extravagance that values excess and debauchery, prizing ritual that is superficial and ornate—thus the world becomes divided, the common people grow doubtful, the warp of Heaven is disrupted, and all begins here.

If plain simplicity remains unmarred, who would fashion sacrificial goblets? If white jade remains uncarved, who would shape it into ritual tablets?

A "gloss" here: "Uncarved simplicity" is a whole tree; "unmarred" means undecorated. *Shú* means "who." *Xīzūn* are wine vessels, carved with ox-heads for ancestral temple sacrifices. A *guī* is a tablet tapering upward and squared at the base; half a *guī* is called a *zhāng*. This briefly offers a parable to illustrate the governance of an age given to contention and rivalry.

When the Dao and its power remain unabandoned, who would seek benevolence and righteousness?

A "gloss" here: This draws the parable together. In the age of the Great Dao, no distinctions of right and wrong are drawn; in the time of utmost virtue, no judgments of love and hate are made. Without love, the human heart finds rest of itself; without wrong, the root of contention is forgotten. Thus the *Lao[jing]* says: "When the Great Dao is abandoned, there are benevolence and righteousness." When nature and feeling remain undivided, who would need ritual and music?

A "gloss": Ritual serves to restrain excess; music serves to harmonize the heart. If feeling does not scatter, who would need to harmonize the heart? If nature does not stray, what need is there to restrain excess? Thus we know that harmonizing the heart and restraining excess arise only when the Dao is lost.

When the five colors do not run together, who would fashion patterned embroidery? When the five notes do not clash, who would tune them to the six pitch-pipes?

A "note": All these are instances of turning simplicity into ornament, abandoning the root to exalt the branch. In their pristine whiteness, they are marred and diminished. Though the world may prize them, they are not truly prized.

A "gloss": Patterned embroidery arises from the interplay of colors; music is valued for its harmony. If each color and each note stands alone, not enhancing one another, then the pentatonic scale scatters, and no use can be made of it. This restates the parable to reinforce the earlier point.

To mar simplicity in order to craft vessels is the fault of the artisan; to destroy the Dao and its power in order to establish benevolence and righteousness is the error of the sage.

A "note": The artisan has his compass and square; the sage has his exalted progress.

A "gloss": This sums up the foregoing. The artisan, in making sacrificial vessels, mars the uncarved wood; the sage, in advancing benevolence and righteousness, destroys the Dao of non-action. The harm is the same, and the fault should be equally shared.

The horse, dwelling on land, eats grass and drinks water; when pleased, it rubs necks with its companions; when angry, it turns its back and kicks. The horse’s knowledge extends no further than this.

A "note": If one guides it by its true knowledge and rides it in its natural state, then a journey of ten thousand *li* may be accomplished, and the nature of the herd remains unspoiled.

A "gloss": *Mǐ* means "to rub" or "to yield." *Tí* means "to kick." *Yǐ* means "to stop." The emotions of creatures are endowed by Heaven; they move in accord with their nature, not through artifice. Thus, when pleased, they rub necks in yielding harmony; when angry, they turn their backs and kick. The horse’s understanding goes no further than this: eating grass, drinking water, and finding joy therein.

When a crossbar is placed upon it and a moon-shaped ornament is fitted to its forehead, the horse’s knowledge extends to defiance, twisting its neck, rearing, startling, bolting, biting the bit, and stealing the bridle.

A "gloss": The *héng* is the crossbar at the front of the carriage shaft. The *è* is the yoke around the horse’s neck. The *yuètí* is the ornament on its forehead, shaped like the crescent moon. *Jiè* means "alone." *Ní* means "to glare." *Mǐn* means "to twist." *Jǐng* means "to butt." *Màn* means "to bolt." *Guǐ* means "to deceive." *Qiè* means "to steal." The horse’s true knowledge delights only in freedom; it does not seek adornment, nor does it covet splendor. Yet when a moon-shaped ornament is placed upon it and a crossbar and yoke are fitted, its nature is thwarted, and it cannot endure the hardship. Thus deceit arises: it glares, twists its neck, butts, bolts, and resists the driver. It steals the bridle, meaning it slips its headstall; it deceives with the bit, meaning it spits out the bit. All this arises from the violation of its true nature, giving rise to a hundred forms of artifice.

Thus, that the horse’s knowledge extends to theft is the fault of Bo Le.

A "note": Horses differ in nature, yet one seeks to make uniform their use; hence some exhaust their strength and resort to deceit.

A "gloss": *Tài* means "deceit." The horse’s true knowledge suits the open wilds; when driven beyond its capacity, deceitful thoughts arise, and the fault for its cunning and thievery lies with Bo Le.

In the age of Emperor Hexu, the people dwelt without knowing what to do, wandered without knowing where to go, fed at the breast and played, patted their bellies and roamed. The people’s abilities went no further than this.

A "note": This is the people’s true ability.

A "gloss": *Zhī* means "to go." Hexu was an ancient sovereign; it is also said that he had a radiant virtue (*hè*), causing the people to follow him (*xū*), hence the name Hexu. He is said to be the Flame Emperor. In the age when the Dao was practiced, in the era of non-action, the heart was free of anxious thoughts; one dwelt in peace without striving. Moving in accord with nature, one wandered without destination. Thus, feeding at the breast and playing, they were no different from infants; patting their bellies and roaming, they were no different from children. In this age of utmost simplicity, the people’s abilities were thus.

Yet when the sages came, they bent and twisted ritual and music to correct the forms of the world, hung up benevolence and righteousness to console the hearts of the world—and the people then began to totter and trip, to favor cunning and contend for profit, unable to stop. This, too, is the fault of the sages.

A "note": Their fault lies in making progress something to be exalted.

A "gloss": They bent and twisted, practicing ritual and music to correct the body; they hung up benevolence and righteousness, causing people to aspire to them and console their hearts. Thus, people began to totter and trip in self-importance, to favor cunning and give rise to deceit, to scheme for profit and contend without cease. Alas!

The faults of the sages at the margins. *Nanhua Zhenjing Zhushu*, Scroll Eleven concludes.

---

*Southern Florescence True Classic: Annotated and Elucidated*, Scroll Twelve

Annotations by Guo Xiang of Henan

The Tang dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s *Subcommentary*
*Outer Chapters: "My Coffer" Tenth*

When guarding against thieves who pry open chests, delve into sacks, or force open coffers, one must gather the cords, fasten the knots, secure the hasps, and fortify the locks—this is what the world calls "wisdom."

**[Subcommentary]**
*Dun* means "to open"; *kuang*, "chest"; *nang*, "sack"; *she*, "to gather"; *jian*, "to knot"; *teng*, "cord." *Jian* refers to the latch; *lei*, to the lock and key. Now, those who open chests, search sacks, or break into coffers to seize wealth are but petty thieves, not great ones. If one wishes to guard against them, what measures should be taken? The cords of chests and sacks must be gathered and knotted, the bindings tightened, and the latches and locks made fast to prevent careless concealment. This is the shallow "wisdom" of the common world. Yet when the great thief arrives, he hoists the coffer, lifts the chest, and shoulders the sack, hurrying away—only fearing that the cords, knots, latches, and locks are not secure enough. Thus, what was once called "wisdom" is nothing but provision amassed for the great thief.

**[Annotation]**
Such is the insufficiency of so-called "wisdom."

**[Subcommentary]**
Gathering cords and fastening locks are meant to guard against petty thieves. Yet when the great thief comes, he bears and lifts them away, even fearing that the bindings and latches are not firm enough. What was once a defense thus becomes the thief’s resource, proving that worldly "wisdom" cannot be relied upon. Let us then consider: Is there any so-called "wisdom" in the world that does not accumulate for the great Dao? Are there any so-called "sages" who do not serve the great thief?

**[Subcommentary]**
The great worthy who embodies the Dao speaks without fixed intent, and so, to reveal the principle of "forgetting words," he provisionally proposes this argument: The worldly, with their shallow and superficial understanding, and the sages who advance in fame—though they claim to grasp the principle—remain far from its depth. Their intent to prevent and restrain only serves to amass for the thief; though they govern the world, they become but guards for the great robber. If one insists there are exceptions, then let it be asked: Is there truly any who does not accumulate for or guard the great thief? This is to say, they invariably serve the thief’s ends. How do we know this is so?

**[Subcommentary]**
This hypothetical question clarifies the meaning.

In ancient times, the villages of the state of Qi stood in sight of one another, and the cries of cocks and dogs carried between them. The nets and snares were spread, and the plow and hoe pierced the earth, across more than two thousand *li*.

**[Subcommentary]**
Qi was the land granted to the descendants of the Grand Duke, enfeoffed at Yingqiu. By the time of Duke Huan, who nine times convened the feudal lords and once rectified the realm, the people of Qi prospered beyond all others. Thus, the crowing of cocks and barking of dogs could be heard between villages, and the rooftops of neighboring settlements stood in view of one another. Nets and snares were cast for hunting and fishing, while plows and hoes tilled the fields. The territory spanned over two thousand *li*, and in its flourishing splendor, Qi surpassed all other feudal states. *Wei* refers to the plowshare; *nou*, to the hoe. Within its four borders, wherever ancestral temples, altars of soil and grain, cities, villages, districts, and hamlets were established—was there ever a place where the models of the sages were not followed?

**[Subcommentary]**
Man cannot stand without earth, nor eat without grain; thus, the altar of soil is called *she*, and the altar of grain, *ji*. *Ji* is the chief of the five grains; *she* means "to sprout," for it is said to bring forth all things. According to the *Art of War of Sima*: six feet make a *bu*, a hundred *bu* make a *mu*, a hundred *mu* make a *fu*, three *fu* make a *wu*, three *wu* make a *jing*, and four *jing* make a village. It also states: five households make a *bi*, five *bi* make a *jian*, five *jian* make a *zu*, five *zu* make a *dang*, five *dang* make a *zhou*, and five *zhou* make a *xiang*. Zheng Xuan says: twenty-five households make a *jian*, two thousand five hundred households make a *zhou*, and twelve thousand five hundred households make a *xiang*. *He* means "to encompass"; *he* means "how." Within the four borders of Qi, in all its cities and villages, the establishment of ancestral temples and other institutions followed the models of Yao and Shun, emulating the sages to create the laws of the state. Yet Tian Chengzi, in a single day, slew the ruler of Qi and stole his state.

**[Annotation]**
To "follow the sages" is merely to imitate their traces. But traces are things already departed, not tools for responding to change. How can they be revered and clung to? Clinging to fixed models to govern the boundless is like facing the infinite with stagnation—thus, one guards the state only to have it guarded by others.

**[Subcommentary]**
Tian Chengzi was Chen Heng, a grandee of Qi and the seventh-generation descendant of Jingzhong. Initially, Jingzhong fled to Qi and was enfeoffed at Tian, hence the change of surname. In the fourteenth year of Duke Ai of Lu, Chen Heng assassinated his ruler, Duke Jian of Qi, and seized territory from Anping to Langye as his own fief. His descendant, Duke Tai of Tian, later exiled Duke Kang of Qi to the coast and established himself as ruler of Qi. From Jingzhong to Duke Zhuang, nine generations held power in Qi; from King Wei of Tian to the third generation, they ruled as marquises of Qi. In total, twelve generations controlled Qi. Zhuangzi lived during the reign of King Xuan, but since King Xuan is not counted here, it is said to be twelve generations. Did he steal only the state? He also stole the sagely laws of wisdom along with it.

**[Annotation]**
Without stealing the sagely laws, he would have had no means to seize the state.

**[Subcommentary]**
What Tian Heng stole was not merely the state of Qi—he first stole sagely wisdom, thereby gaining the allegiance of the feudal lords. Thus, we know that the display of benevolence and righteousness is but the root of theft. Therefore, though Tian Chengzi bore the name of a bandit, he dwelled in the ease of Yao and Shun. Small states dared not criticize him; great states dared not punish him. For twelve generations, he held Qi.

**[Subcommentary]**
A minor state dared not condemn him; a major state could not subdue him. His descendants continued in succession, and his ancestral temples endured. For twelve generations, as explained above, he not only stole the state of Qi but also took its sagely laws of wisdom to guard his bandit’s body.

**[Annotation]**
The sagely laws are but tools for men to use; they are not infallible instruments for complete security.

**[Subcommentary]**
He raised benevolence and righteousness to steal the state and relied on sagely wisdom to preserve himself. This reiterates the preceding text to conclude its meaning.

Let us consider this: among those whom the world calls the wisest, is there any who does not accumulate for the great thief? Among those called the greatest sages, is there any who does not guard for the great thief?

**[Subcommentary]**
This restates the earlier meaning to introduce what follows.

How do we know this is so?

**[Subcommentary]**
This hypothetical question clarifies the meaning.

In ancient times, Guan Longfeng was beheaded, Bi Gan was disemboweled, Chang Hong was torn apart, and Wu Zixu was pulverized. Thus, though these four were virtuous, they could not escape execution.

**[Annotation]**
Tyrannical rulers could wield the authority of their position to execute worthy men without opposition—all because of the sagely laws. Without such laws, how could Jie and Zhou have maintained their thrones to spread their poison, making the world shudder?

**[Subcommentary]**
