Guan Longfeng, surnamed Guan, was a worthy minister of Jie of Xia, killed by Jie. Bi Gan was a prince of the royal house, remonstrating with Zhou of Shang, who cut open his heart to examine it. Chang Hong was a worthy minister of King Ling of Zhou. The *Garden of Persuasions* states: When Jin’s Shu Xiang killed Chang Hong, Chang Hong had repeatedly appeared in Zhou, so Shu Xiang sent a letter accusing him: "You incited the army of Jin to attack Zhou, to depose the Liu clan and establish the Shan clan." The ruler, believing Liu, executed Chang Hong. *Chi* means "to tear"; it is also said to mean "to disembowel." *Mi* means "to rot" or "to shatter." Wu Zixu was executed, his corpse cast into the river to disintegrate. These four men were all loyal and virtuous, yet they could not escape execution because lawless rulers, relying on the power of their position and the authority of sagely laws, could trample loyal ministers and unleash their venom.

Thus the followers of Robber Zhi asked Guang, saying: "Does even theft have its Dao?"

[Commentary: This sets forth a question from a base sort to open the discussion.]

Guang replied: "Where could there be no Dao?"

[Commentary: This answers the preceding question.]

The Dao is nowhere absent—where could one go that is not the Dao?

Wherever the Dao resides is set forth below.

To divine the treasures hidden in a chamber is sagacity;
to enter first is courage;
to withdraw last is righteousness;
to know what may or may not be done is wisdom;
to divide spoils equally is benevolence.
Without these five, none in the world has ever become a great thief.

[Annotation: These five qualities restrain theft, yet they become the thief’s very resources.]

[Commentary: Within a chamber’s storehouse lie treasures; when a thief conceives a reckless intent, he weighs and measures, divining presence or absence with uncanny accuracy—hence sagacity. Joining strength and will, he shuns no resistance, striving to enter first—hence courage. Amidst arrows and stones, he heeds not his life, yet in retreat he yields the lead—hence righteousness. He acts when he may, desists when he must, discerning safety from peril, fortune from misfortune, ensuring victory wherever he goes—hence wisdom. Light of wealth, heavy of honor, he takes little and yields much, dividing goods with equity—hence benevolence. These five are the very sagacity, courage, righteousness, wisdom, and benevolence just named. To commit a single theft requires all five virtues; without them, theft cannot succeed. Thus it is known: without sagacity and wisdom, none in the world has ever become a great thief.

From this it may be seen: the good cannot stand without the Dao of the sage, nor can the base proceed without the Dao of the sage.

[Commentary: The Dao of the sage refers to the five virtues. Reasoning thus, those who would do good cannot establish themselves or practice the Way without treading the five virtues, while the base and corrupt cannot carry out their theft without the resources of sagacity and wisdom.]

Since the good in the world are few and the ungood many, the sage’s benefit to the world is slight, while his harm to the world is great.

[Annotation: True indeed are these words. Though true, the sage cannot be done away with, for the world’s knowledge cannot be wholly extinguished; thus the Dao of the sage is needed to govern it. If all knowledge were lost save that of the sage, the world’s harm would be greater still than with the sage’s presence. Though the harm of the sage’s presence is great, it is still preferable to the chaos of his absence. Yet even this is not so good as the total absence of harm.]

How extreme it is! The world seeks nothing but profit, yet cannot wholly abandon its knowledge—how deluded and lost to the proper end!

[Commentary: Both good and evil paths arise from sagacity and wisdom. Boyi guarded his purity and won fame, while Robber Zhi indulged his greed and seized profit. Yet Robber Zhi’s kind are legion, while Boyi’s are few. Thus it is known that the sage’s advent benefits the world little and harms it much. Hence it is said: When the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold; when Lu’s wine was thin, Deng and Ye were besieged; when the sage arises, great thieves appear.]

[Annotation: The lips’ loss does not chill the teeth, nor did Lu’s thin wine besiege Deng and Ye, nor does the sage’s rise give rise to great thieves—yet these follow one another naturally, by the force of circumstance. Though the sage does not set himself above things, he cannot prevent things from exalting him. Thus, whether noble or base, true or false, if one emulates the sage’s methods, the world swallows its voice and submits in unison—this is precisely what Jie and Zhi relied upon to become great thieves.]

[Commentary: The *Spring and Autumn Annals* states: "When the lips are gone, the teeth grow cold"—this refers to Yu and Guo. Deng and Ye were cities of Zhao. Once, King Xuan of Chu summoned the feudal lords; Duke Gong of Lu arrived late, and his wine was thin. The king grew angry and sought to humiliate him. The duke said: "I am a descendant of the Duke of Zhou, who practiced the rites and music of the Son of Heaven and rendered service to the Zhou house. Now I offer wine with some lapse in ritual, and you rebuke its thinness—is this not excessive?" He then departed without leave. Enraged, the king raised troops to attack Lu. King Hui of Liang, eager to attack Zhao but fearing Lu’s aid, now saw that Chu and Lu were at odds. Thus Liang besieged Deng and Ye, and Deng and Ye were besieged. This too arose from the sage’s rise—not that he wished to give rise to great thieves, but circumstances made it so.]

Strike down the sage, release the thief—and only then will the world be well-governed.

[Annotation: The sage is what the world exalts. If one were to abolish what is exalted and preserve one’s original simplicity, discard prohibitions and replace them with few desires, this would mean striking down the sage to preserve one’s own simplicity, releasing the thief to still his villainy.]

Thus the ancients said: To guard against depravity and preserve sincerity, one need not rely on keen scrutiny; to quell excess and cast off ostentation, one need not depend on harsh punishments—this is what is meant.

[Commentary: *Strike* means "to beat."]

The sage is akin to "sagely advancement." The sage, in truth, encompasses all things with wisdom and aids the world with the Dao. Yet when we speak of "striking down," this also conveys the intent to denounce benevolence and righteousness, to abolish sageliness and discard wisdom. By not prizing rare and precious goods, one may release the thief, dispense with harsh punishments, and the world will attain great peace.

When rivers run dry, valleys empty; when hills are leveled, abysses fill. Once the sage is dead, great thieves will no longer arise.

[Annotation: Rivers do not empty valleys by draining them, nor do leveled hills fill abysses by depositing earth. The cessation of sageliness does not halt thievery by design.]

Thus, to halt thievery lies in eliminating desire, not in exalting sageliness and knowledge.

[Commentary: When wisdom and cunning emerge, deceit and falsehood arise; when sagely advancement perishes, great thieves cease. This is like rivers running dry and valleys emptying, hills leveling and abysses filling—how could one contrive such an outcome? It is the natural course. "Dead" means "to cease." The world is at peace and free of disturbances.

[Annotation: Not only do thieves cease, but the paths of contention and ostentation also vanish entirely.

[Commentary: "Disturbances" means affairs. With the abolition of sageliness and the rejection of wisdom, the world attains great peace, people sing as they till the soil, and there are no affairs of deliberate action.]

If the sage does not die, great thieves will not cease. To govern the world by revering the sage is to heavily profit the thief.

[Annotation: To revere the sage in governing the world is to provide the tools for tyrants like Jie to exploit. What they exploit is weighty, so the profit they gain cannot be light.

[Commentary: In an age of pure simplicity, where people are tranquil and act without contrivance, things return to their roots, and all fulfill their destinies—how could this depend on teachings and advancements to attain obscurity? Yet when sageliness and wisdom are not forgotten, great thieves arise. Though one may revere sagely laws to govern the world, this is no different from heavily profiting the thief. Why? Because the harm and poison unleashed by Xia Jie, the rapacity and cruelty of the thief Zhi—these stem from reliance on sagely advancement. Without sagely advancement, how could Xia Jie have ascended to the ninefold dignity and poisoned the black-haired people? How could the thief Zhi have amassed thousands of troops and rampaged across the land? What they relied upon was weighty, so the profit they gained was not light. From this, we may infer that the fault lies with sageliness and wisdom.

They create measuring vessels to quantify, yet thieves steal both the vessels and what they measure. They create scales and balances to weigh, yet thieves steal both the scales and what they weigh. They create tallies and seals to authenticate, yet thieves steal both the tallies and seals. They create benevolence and righteousness to rectify, yet thieves steal both benevolence and righteousness.

[Annotation: What confounds petty thieves becomes the resource and profit of great thieves.

[Commentary: A *hu* is a vessel like today’s *dou*, used to measure quantity. *Quan* is the weight, and *heng* is the beam of a scale, used to balance weight. Tallies are split into two parts, reuniting to form a whole—like today’s bronze fish or wooden contracts. Seals are the jade insignia of rulers, used to summon and command the world. Benevolence is kindness; righteousness is propriety. The ruler’s kindness extends to all, following propriety to establish norms and nurture the black-haired people. These eight are the world’s precious instruments, indispensable to one another. The sage establishes teachings to govern the state, yet Tian Cheng exploits them to steal the state of Qi—is this not harming petty thieves while profiting great ones? How do we know this is so? Those who steal a belt hook are executed, while those who steal a state become lords. Where lords reside, benevolence and righteousness abide—does this not mean they have stolen benevolence, righteousness, sageliness, and wisdom?

[Commentary: The belt hook refers to a waist belt clasp. The rise of sagely teachings was originally to punish evil and encourage good. Yet those who privately steal a belt hook are executed, while those who publicly seize the state of Qi become lords. Without benevolence and righteousness, how could they lead the masses? From this, how can we not conclude that they have stolen sageliness and wisdom to rob the state? The question "How do we know this?" is hypothetical; the passage from "Those who steal..." onward provides the hypothetical answer.]

Thus, those who pursue great thieves, usurp the position of lords, and steal the benefits of benevolence, righteousness, measuring vessels, scales, tallies, and seals—even with the rewards of high rank and emolument, they cannot be encouraged; even with the threat of axes and execution, they cannot be restrained.

[Annotation: High rank and axes are the weightiest of rewards and punishments. Yet when rewards and punishments are used to restrain thieves, great thieves merely follow and steal them, turning them into tools for thievery. What they employ is weighty, and thus it enables their great thievery.]

The great thief, then, necessarily acts with benevolence and righteousness, balances with scales, authenticates with tallies and seals, encourages with high rank, and threatens with axes—stealing these public instruments before lords can be usurped. Thus, benevolence, righteousness, rewards, and punishments are merely sufficient to execute those who steal belt hooks.

[Commentary: "Pursue" means to follow; "encourage" means to urge; "restrain" means to halt. *Xuan* is a carriage; *mian* is a crown. The establishment of sagely advancement was originally to quell deceit and treachery, yet Tian Cheng exploited its methods to steal the state of Qi, seizing scales, tallies, and seals, usurping the position of lord and calmly facing south—how could he be encouraged with carriages and crowns or threatened with axes? The smaller axe is called *fu*; the larger, *yue*. Some say the axe is adorned with gold. This heavy profit for thieves renders them uncontrollable—this is the fault of the sage.

[Annotation: That they cannot be restrained arises from the weight of what they steal. That what they steal is weighty arises from the sage’s failure to diminish it. Thus, the remedy lies in devaluing goods, not in revering the sage.

[Commentary: That the thief Zhi could amass nine thousand troops and rampage across the land also relied on the Five Powers. Without sageliness and wisdom, how could this have been possible? We know that the inability to restrain those who plunder and seize people stems from the fault of the sage in creating laws.]

Thus it is said: "Fish must not leave the depths; the state’s sharpest tools must not be shown to a single soul."

Fish parted from the deep become prey for men; sharp tools displayed become resources for thieves—hence they must not be shown.

The sage is the state’s sharpest tool. Were the sage truly to renounce sageliness and forsake knowledge, returning to the hidden extremity of things—where each extremity is itself hidden—then the instrument of his advancement in service to things would be but a vessel, to be grasped and used as such.

Such sages as Yao, Shun, Wen, and Wu are not to be paraded before the world. To display sharp tools to the world is to arm its thieves and bandits.

When the sage governs, he responds to things as they arise and adapts to the times, now yielding, now wielding the shield and spear, his conduct never fixed. He cannot be rigidly grasped or openly displayed to the world. To cling to a single course is to invite ruin, as seen in the cases of Zizhi of Yan and Baigong.

Thus, when sageliness is renounced and knowledge abandoned, great thievery ceases. Remove what thieves rely upon, and their crimes halt without need for prohibition.

Shatter jade and crush pearls, and petty theft will not arise. Devalue what men treasure, and crime will fade without punishment.

Burn tallies and break seals, and the people will return to simplicity. Destroy what deceivers depend upon, and their cunning will have no means to operate.

Abandon measuring cups and smash scales, and the people will know no strife. For the small equalities are but the tools of greater inequalities.

Once the measures of quantity and weight are shattered, they can no longer be stolen and turned to thieves’ ends. To strike and break them is to align with the wisdom of the ancients, and so all contention ceases.

Exhaust and destroy the sagely laws of the world, and only then may the people be fit for discourse. When nothing remains to be falsified, the inner integrity of uncarved simplicity is preserved, and no words are lost to self-deception.

Eradicate the Three Kings, demolish the Five Emperors, and return to the utmost emptiness—where straw dogs are not arrayed, where traps and snares are forgotten, where self and things merge into obscurity. Only then may one begin to discuss the profoundest mysteries, to discourse on the far reaches of the Dao and virtue.

Confound the six pitch-pipes, melt down the zithers and se, seal the ears of Music-Master Kuang, and the world will at last hold fast to its innate hearing.

Erase patterns, scatter the five colors, glue shut the eyes of Li Zhu, and the world will at last hold fast to its innate clarity.

For sound and color, clarity and vastness—these are what those with ears and eyes esteem. Yet all beings are born with their allotted share, and if one is led astray by what they esteem, their nature and life are lost. Only by destroying what they esteem, abandoning external things to follow one’s own nature, may hearing and sight each remain whole, and each person preserve their true essence.

To pluck is to extract; to smelt is to dissolve. The *yu* resembles the sheng, with pipes arrayed within a gourd and yellow wax applied to their ends. The *se* is eight feet and one inch long, one foot and eight inches wide, with twenty-seven strings—created by Fuxi. When the ear is seduced by the five notes, it admires Music-Master Kuang’s acuity; when the eye is ensnared by dark and bright hues, it covets Li Zhu’s vision. Thus the mind and spirit race, and hearing and sight are exhausted. Yet if one tears out the pipes and severs the strings, melts down the metal and cuts the warp; if one destroys the melodies of *Huanghua* and abandons the songs of *Baixue*; if one erases the patterns of martial display and scatters the reds and purples—then one may glue shut Li Zhu’s eyes, removing the source of artificial imitation, and seal Music-Master Kuang’s ears, dispelling the leader of the disorderly throng. Only then may all people find their own way: sounds and things no longer rob me, the ear listens to its utmost and returns to hearing nothing, the eye gazes with full power and inwardly sees no color. The celestial mechanism unfolds of itself, reaching the perfection of non-action—how could there be any distinction of brightness or dimness, excellence or inferiority? Thus the world attains peace, and all things share in the same virtue. Following one’s own hearing and sight, each person preserves their innate clarity and acuity. To *preserve* is to nurture within.

Break the compass and square, snap the carpenter’s fingers, and the world will at last hold fast to its innate skill. Thus it is said: *Great skill appears clumsy.*

For even the lowly spider and mole-cricket spin webs and roll pellets without seeking instruction from craftsmen—each thing possesses its own ability. Though their abilities differ, none dares deviate from what they are accustomed to, and so what seems skillful is in fact clumsy. Therefore, one who is adept at employing others lets the square be square and the round be round, each entrusted with what they can do. People rest in their nature, and no one is burdened with the craftsmanship of the master artisan. Thus, when all skills appear mutually inept, the world naturally attains great skill. For when each relies on their own ability, compass and square may be discarded, and the master artisan’s fingers may be snapped.

The compass bends; the marking-cord straightens; the compass draws circles; the square measures angles. Gongren was a craftsman of Yao who devised the methods of compass and square—some say he was a minister of Shun. To *snap* is to break or sever. Gongren, endowed with ingenious nature, wielded compass and marking-cord, carving and shaping strange devices, creating rules and measures that led the common people of the world to blindly imitate, abandoning themselves to chase after things—all stemming from this. But if one discards compass and marking-cord, snaps the fingers and lets them act freely, then each person, following their own inner standard, will possess their own skill. It is like the spider’s web or the mole-cricket’s pellet—how could these depend on human effort? They are the workings of celestial skill. This matter is expounded in the *Lao Jing*.

Eradicate the conduct of Zeng and Shi, silence the mouths of Yang and Mo, cast aside benevolence and righteousness, and the world’s virtue will at last return to primordial unity.

Remove the leaders of the disorderly throng, and the world will each revert to their uncarved simplicity, uniting in the profound virtue.

To *eradicate* is to eliminate; to *silence* is to shut; to *cast aside* is to reject. *Primordial* means origin, the Dao. Zeng Shen was the paragon of filial piety, Shi Yu of loyalty and integrity; Yang Zhu and Mo Di possessed vast eloquence by nature. These four, born with their allotted share, led the scholars of the world to imitate others, abandoning themselves—thus causing disorder and losing their original nature. Therefore, one must eliminate the conduct of loyalty and trust, silence the mouths of frivolous eloquence, reject the ostentatious benevolence of the well-ordered, and discard the grasping righteousness of the self-righteous. Then things will not lose their truth, and people will each find their own way. Following their nature and preserving principle, they merge with the profound Dao.

When people preserve their clarity, the world is not scattered; when people preserve their acuity, the world is not burdened.

To *scatter* is to dissolve; to *burden* is to be weighed down by cares. It is because one parades their acuity and clarity that cares and exhaustion gather, causing the common people to be deluded and scattered. But if one embraces acuity and clarity within and does not display them outwardly, then all things will be content and free from care.

When people preserve their knowledge, the world is not deluded; when people preserve their virtue, the world is not perverse.

If one’s knowledge remains within its proper bounds and one nurtures virtue without excess, they will naturally walk the central path of the ring, wandering within and free from delusion—how could there be any inversion or perversity?

Those such as Zeng, Shi, Yang, Mo, Music-Master Kuang, Gongren, and Li Zhu all established their virtue externally and thereby confused the world.

These several individuals, each endowed with diverse talents, caused the world to leap forth and imitate them. In imitation, one loses oneself; when the self is lost because of another, that other becomes the source of disorder. The world’s greatest affliction lies in losing oneself.

The aforementioned individuals, all surpassing others in their allotted share, could not conceal their brilliance or hide their radiance. Instead, they stirred the waves and muddied the world, flaunting their names and establishing their virtue externally, drawing things to follow them and dazzling the multitude. The world, having lost virtue, did not return to its root—this is the origin of losing oneself.

What the law deems useless is this.

For what the law deems useful is this: sight does not exceed what is seen, and so all eyes are bright; hearing does not exceed what is heard, and so all ears are keen; skill does not exceed what one is capable of, and so all crafts are mastered; knowledge does not exceed what one knows, and so all natures are at ease; virtue does not exceed what one has attained, and so all virtues are fitting. Why establish what lies beyond the bounds of one’s nature, causing the world to race about and be unable to return to itself?

The essence of the law lies in following one’s nature in movement, for movement arises from nature—this is the marvel of the law. Yet the followers of Zeng and Shi, drawing things to themselves, not only fail to benefit the present age but even harm future generations. Though this law is established, it ultimately serves no purpose.

Do you alone not know of the age of utmost virtue? In ancient times, under the reigns of Rongcheng, Dating, Bohuang, Zhongyang, Lilu, Lixu, Xuanyuan, Hexu, Zunlu, Zhu Rong, Fuxi, and Shennong, the people used knotted cords to keep records—sufficient merely to note what was essential. The twelve rulers above were all sovereigns of high antiquity. In those days, before the existence of historical records, the sequence of their reigns was unknown. They carved wood to make tallies and knotted cords to signify trust. Above and below lived in harmony, and human hearts were pure and simple. Thus, the *Book of Changes* says, "In high antiquity, governance was by knotted cords; later sages replaced them with written tallies."

They found their food sweet and their clothing beautiful—for what suited them was always sweet, and what fit was always fine. Had they longed for excess and extravagance, there would have been no end to dissatisfaction. They delighted in their customs and dwelled contentedly in their homes—for they kept to their allotted share, thus finding sweetness; they cast off ornament, thus finding beauty; they lived in harmony, thus delighting in their ways; they embraced tranquility, thus resting peacefully in their abodes. Neighboring states were within sight of one another, the sounds of their roosters and dogs carried between them, yet the people grew old and died without ever traveling to visit one another—for they were utterly without desire.

In such an age, perfect governance was already achieved. Without desire or seeking, embracing the Dao and holding to virtue—how could such a time not be the ultimate? Yet now, people crane their necks and stand on tiptoe, saying, "In such-and-such a place there is a worthy one," and they pack provisions to hasten toward them. They abandon their parents within and forsake their lords’ affairs without. Their footprints tread across the borders of feudal lords, and their carriage tracks crisscross a thousand *li* away. This is the very trace of perfect governance, yet it leads to such corruption.

This is the fault of those above who esteem knowledge. When rulers esteem and pursue knowledge, such excesses arise. If those above truly favor knowledge and lack the Dao, the world will fall into great chaos. As the Old Master said, "To govern the state with knowledge is the state’s ruin." How do we know this is so?

When the knowledge of bows, crossbows, snares, and cunning traps abounds, birds are thrown into chaos in the skies. When the knowledge of hooks, bait, nets, weirs, and layered traps multiplies, fish are thrown into chaos in the waters. When the knowledge of fences, snares, nets, and pitfall traps proliferates, beasts are thrown into chaos in the marshes. The more densely one attacks, the more skillfully they evade—even birds and beasts cannot be captured by knowledge, let alone humans. Thus, those who govern the world must not rely on knowledge, for relying on knowledge lacks subtlety.

When the knowledge of deceit, gradual poison, cunning, sophistry, the "hard and white" debate, the "removing filth" argument, and the "same and different" distinctions multiplies, the common folk are bewildered by eloquence. What those above value, those below cannot rest content with their own simplicity. When the simple pursue the complex, they become lost.

Deceitful schemes and poisonous influences gradually harm all things. *Hanhua* refers to cunning and treachery; "hard and white" denotes sophistry; "removing filth" signifies deceit. Such cunning knowledge and specious debates on "same and different" truly undermine true principle and offer no benefit to the world’s teachings. Thus, from afar, they may appear as mere stammering, yet the foolish multitude is misled by petty eloquence.

Therefore, whenever the world falls into great chaos, the fault lies in the love of knowledge. When all under heaven know to seek what they do not know yet do not know to seek what they already know—this is abandoning the self to imitate others, exceeding one’s proper bounds. What one knows lies within one’s nature; what one does not know lies beyond it. To seek beyond one’s nature—how is this not delusion?

When all know to condemn what they deem unworthy yet do not know to condemn what they deem worthy—this is clinging to what one approves, and from this arises contention and strife.

What the unworthy deem "unworthy" refers to the ruin wrought by Jie; what they deem "worthy" refers to the sagely way of Yao and Shun. Robber Zhi practiced unworthiness to seize Dongling, while Tian Cheng followed the sagely way to usurp the state of Qi. Thus, whether one hoards or squanders, the outcome is the same as losing sheep to divergent paths—whether one follows the ruin of Jie or the distinct path of the sages, the harm to one’s nature is equal. Yet the foolish multitude recklessly passes judgment, deeming some things worthy and others unworthy, though in truth, worthiness and unworthiness cannot be fixed. Hence arises great chaos.

Thus, above, it obscures the brightness of sun and moon; below, it melts the essence of mountains and rivers; and in between, it disrupts the seasons’ unfolding. Gasping creatures of the earth and fluttering things of the air—none fail to lose their nature. How severe is the chaos wrought by the love of knowledge upon all under heaven!

**Commentary:**
Fortune and misfortune, regret and shame arise from action. Yet the action of knowledge can truly shake heaven and earth, driving the masses before it. How, then, can those who rule over others fail to forget their knowledge?

**Subcommentary:**
This continues the preceding argument. Precisely because those above employ cunning and pursue advancement, all under heaven falls into great chaos. *Bèi* means "to disrupt"; *shuò* means "to melt"; *duò* means "to ruin." Creatures that cling to the earth are called *chuǎnyì*; those that fly in the air are called *xiāoqiáo*—both are small and insignificant. Yet clinging to the sagely way and employing knowledge brings harm so extreme that it stirs yin and yang, shakes heaven and earth, causes the sun and moon to dim, the mountains and rivers to collapse and dry up, the cycles of heat and cold to falter, and wind and rain to arrive untimely. Flying and crawling creatures, those of water and land—all lose their original nature. The poison of the love of knowledge reaches this extremity.

From the Three Dynasties onward, this has been the case: abandoning the simple and varied people to delight in the fawning flatterers, forsaking tranquil nonaction to take pleasure in the humming and hawing of self-assertion—such humming and hawing have already thrown all under heaven into chaos.

**Commentary:**
*Hēnghēng* refers to instructing others with one’s own views.

**Subcommentary:**
*From* means "beginning with." The Three Dynasties refer to Xia, Yin, and Zhou. *Zhǒngzhǒng* describes the unadorned and honest people; *yìyì* depicts the frivolous and restless. *Shì* means "to abandon"; *hēnghēng* means "to instruct others with one’s own views." In the most ancient and perfectly pure age, the pristine era, people emulated the round heavens in their clarity and emptiness, modeled the square earth in their stability and stillness, united the myriad things as one family, and lived like birds and beasts, free of knowledge. But when simplicity dissolved and cunning spread, when the Dao was forsaken and virtue abandoned, the sagely way of the Five Constants became manifest, and the Three Dynasties employed knowledge to an even greater degree. They cast aside the unadorned scholars of simplicity, cherished the frivolous flatterers, abandoned the self-contentment of desirelessness, and delighted in the meddlesome instruction of things. Having already thrown all under heaven into chaos, can this not be lamented?

The Tang dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary

**Outer Chapters: "In Yu" (Chapter Eleven)**

To hear of governing the world through *yu* (letting-be) is to know it; to hear of ruling the world is not. **[Annotation]** To let beings be in their own freedom is to govern; to govern them is to bring chaos.

Man’s life is upright by nature, undisturbed by anything, so that his nature and destiny remain unexceeded, and his desires and aversions do not err. Yet those above cannot practice non-action; what those above do, the people all rush to emulate. Thus, when they are lured by admiration and desires, the people’s nature becomes licentious.

Therefore, what is demanded of a sagely king is not to prize his ability to govern, but to prize his non-action and allowing things to act of themselves. **[Subcommentary]** *Yu* means leniency; *zai* means self-so freedom. *Zhi* means control and domination. The parable says: I have heard that when the worthy and sagely entrust things to their own freedom and leniently let them be, the world is at peace. But if they establish teachings to dominate the common people, things lose their nature—like Bo Le training horses.

To *zai* (let be) is to fear that the world will become licentious in its nature; to *yu* (let alone) is to fear that the world will alter its virtue. **[Subcommentary]** Nature is the principle received at birth; virtue is the name for meritorious conduct. Thus, the words *zai* and *yu* are employed to guard against the errors of alteration and licentiousness. If one does not allow nature to be self-so, one fears things will become licentious and lose their nature. If one does not *yu* them, one fears they will imitate others and their virtue will change.

If the world does not become licentious in its nature nor alter its virtue, is there any need to govern it? **[Annotation]** Without governance, there is no alteration or licentiousness. **[Subcommentary]** When nature is upright and virtue settled, why labor to impose governance? Governance does not surpass non-governance; action does not surpass non-action.

In ancient times, when Yao governed the world, he made the world joyful, and people delighted in their nature—yet this was not tranquility. When Jie governed the world, he made the world weary, and people suffered in their nature—yet this was not contentment. **[Annotation]** Though Yao let the world be in freedom, his advancement was governance. Though governance and chaos differ, both lose the tranquility and joy of later generations, causing things to vie for esteem, fear degradation, and fail to attain self-contentment—this is the same. Thus, praising Yao and blaming Jie is not as good as forgetting both. **[Subcommentary]** *Tian* means stillness; *yu* means joy; *cui* means sorrow. Yao ruled with virtue, and people sang and played *ji zhang*, yet this violated their tranquil nature. Jie harmed things, and beings suffered sorrow, violating their joyful nature. Though Yao and Jie’s governance differed, their causing things to lose their nature was the same.

That which is not tranquil and not content is not virtue. And that which is not virtue—can it endure long? The world has none such. **[Annotation]** Only self-contentment in tranquility and joy can endure long. **[Subcommentary]** Yao, by failing to be tranquil, disturbed people; Jie, by failing to bring joy, oppressed beings. Neither accorded with the pure harmony of nature. If one seeks to endure long, the world has never known such a thing.

Is great joy not excessive? It aids the yang. Is great anger not excessive? It aids the yin. When yin and yang are both aided, the four seasons fail to arrive, the harmony of cold and heat is not achieved—does this not injure man’s form? It causes people’s joy and anger to lose their proper place, their dwellings to lack constancy. **[Subcommentary]** *Pi* means to assist. Joy arises from the *hun*; anger from the *po*. Man receives yin and yang, sharing the same qi as the Two Modes. Yao made the hundred clans joyful, aiding the yang’s warmth and expansion; Jie made people angry, assisting the yin’s severity and contraction. When people’s joy and anger exceed their bounds, heaven loses its constancy—midsummer lacks heat, deep winter lacks frost. Having lost harmonious qi and suffered celestial disasters, people fall ill—does this not injure their forms? One must not act or establish laws, lest harm result.

When thoughts and deliberations fail to attain self-contentment, the Way is not fully realized mid-course. **[Annotation]** These are all like Yao and Jie, causing things’ joy and anger to exceed bounds, extinguishing them through governance. Man, within heaven and earth, is most capable of using his numinous awareness to disturb the myriad beings with joy and anger, agitating yin and yang.

Thus, between gain and loss, joy and anger gather in the hearts of the hundred clans, the harmony of cold and heat is ruined, the seasons’ rhythms are disrupted, the hundred measures fall into confusion, and the myriad affairs wither and perish. **[Subcommentary]** Being mired in joy and anger, the hundred clans’ plans and deliberations lose their truth, violating the laws of proper order—this is ruin indeed.

Thereupon, the world first became cunning, demanding, arrogant, and fierce, and afterward there arose the conduct of thieves, Zeng, and Shi. Thus, to reward the good throughout the world is insufficient, **[Annotation]** Admiring rewards makes one good, so rewards cannot suffice. to punish the evil throughout the world is inadequate, **[Annotation]** Fearing punishment makes one stop, so punishments cannot prevail. **[Subcommentary]** *Qiao* means deceit; *qing* means reproach; *zhuo* means solitary; *jing* means fierce. Thus, deceit, reproach, solitary arrogance, and fierce domination of others—beginning with Yao, followed by the evil of thieves and the goodness of Zeng and Shi—once good and evil became manifest, rewards and punishments were tied to them. Admiring rewards, people act good; fearing punishments, they cease evil. Yet even if the world’s axes and blades were used to punish evil, and the cosmos’ treasuries emptied to reward good, it would still be insufficient. *Ji* means sufficiency.

If one forgets rewards and punishments, allowing authenticity to prevail, then it is sufficient. **[Subcommentary]** From the Three Dynasties onward, they clamored endlessly, making rewards and punishments their sole concern. When would they have leisure to settle the feelings of their nature and destiny? **[Annotation]** Forgetting rewards and punishments to be naturally good—only then are nature and destiny fully sufficient.

Rewards and punishments are what the sagely kings used to address merit and fault, not to manifest encouragement and fear. Thus, when principle reaches its utmost, they are abandoned, and only then can unity be restored. Yet from the Three Dynasties onward, they have pursued these affairs in escape, thus clamoring and competing for advancement, making what they entrust their sole concern. When would the feelings of nature and destiny have leisure to be at peace?

**[Subcommentary]** "Clamorous" denotes the clamor of a crowd, the meaning of competing and chasing. People fear the executioner’s axe and admire the rewards of official caps and carriages. Their hearts harbor a hundred anxieties, their affairs branch into ten thousand ends, clamoring and competing without cease. Since the Xia and Yin dynasties, this trend has gradually fanned into flame—rewards and punishments entangle and disturb, leaving no respite throughout the day. How could there be leisure to settle the feelings of nature and destiny?

Moreover, do they delight in clarity? This is indulgence in form. Do they delight in keen hearing? This is indulgence in sound. **[Subcommentary]** "Delight" means to be stained. "Indulgence" means to be mired. Yearning for Li [Li Zhu] and admiring Kuang [Shi Kuang] is to be mired in sound and form.

Do they delight in benevolence? This is disorder in virtue. Do they delight in righteousness? This is perversion of principle. **[Subcommentary]** Virtue knows no partiality; partial love thus disorders virtue. Principle admits no right or wrong; imposing wrong thus violates principle. "Perversion" means opposition.

Do they delight in ritual? This is mutual assistance in artifice. Do they delight in music? This is mutual assistance in indulgence. **[Subcommentary]** Ritual involves bowing and scraping, regulated flourishes and restraints. Music encompasses the *Xianchi* and *Daxia*, the twelve pitches and eight timbres. Delighting in ritual thus aids ostentatious skill; loving music further abets lewd tones.

Do they delight in sageliness? This is mutual assistance in art. Do they delight in wisdom? This is mutual assistance in blemish. **[Annotation]** When principle is rightly aligned, there is no delight; delight in these leads to the calamity of indulgence and perversion. "Mutual assistance" means to aid.

**[Subcommentary]** Delighting in sageliness aids the proliferation of worldly arts; loving cunning exacerbates the blemishes of right and wrong.

If the world seeks to settle the feelings of nature and destiny, these eight may exist or vanish—it matters not. **[Annotation]** Whether they exist or vanish is of no consequence; abiding by one’s allotted portion settles nature and destiny. **[Subcommentary]** The eight are keen hearing, clarity, benevolence, righteousness, ritual, music, sageliness, and wisdom. People’s endowments differ, their natures and feelings vary. Those like Li Zhu and Shi Kuang, who possess these by original endowment, may retain them; the multitude, whose natures lack them, vainly emulate and stray from their true selves—letting them vanish is fitting.

If the world does not seek to settle the feelings of nature and destiny, these eight become like the cramped coils of southern barbarians or the hasty flurry of rustics, throwing the world into chaos. **[Annotation]** Clinging to these eight prevents the free unfolding of spontaneity, hence the cramped coils and hasty flurry. **[Subcommentary]** "Cramped coils" describes a constrained, unrelaxed demeanor. "Hasty flurry" depicts a frantic, hurried appearance. The multitudes of the world, knowing only what lies beyond their nature, fail to abide in tranquility. Confined to narrow lanes, they boast of worldly affairs, rushing about in haste, competing and chasing—all because they do not forget these eight.

Yet the world begins to revere and cherish them. How deeply deluded the world has become! **[Annotation]** Failing to relinquish them is already an error, yet they further exalt them as treasures—how could this not be profound delusion? **[Subcommentary]** The preceding eight disrupt the warp of heaven; failing to forget them is already grave delusion. To then revere them as models, clinging to them so dearly—how far this strays from simply correcting the error and moving on!

Thus, with fasting and purification, they speak of them; kneeling and seated, they present them; with drums and songs, they consecrate them—what am I to make of this?

**[Annotation]** It is not merely a matter of passing them by in passing; rather, they treasure and revere them to such an extent.

**[Subcommentary]** The meaning of these eight principles is like that of straw dogs: once past, they ought not be taken up again. Yet they observe precepts, perform rites of purification, speak solemnly of them with reverence, kneel and sit in formal audience, offer them to one another in turn, strike up the *Nine Shao* songs, and dance the *Great Zhang* melodies. They cherish and honor them, returning to their chambers with such devotion—even Zhuangzi himself would strike his breast in helplessness. Therefore, when the noble person cannot but oversee the world, there is nothing better than non-action. Only through non-action can the natural dispositions of life and destiny be preserved in tranquility.

**[Annotation]** Non-action does not mean clasping the hands in silence; it means allowing each to follow its own course, so that life and destiny are at peace. "Cannot but" does not mean being coerced by authority or punishment; it means embracing the Dao and holding to simplicity, entrusting oneself to the ultimate spontaneity of things, whereupon the world naturally submits.

**[Subcommentary]** The noble person is the sage. When he cannot but oversee the world, he is pained to act without acting. Though he acts without acting, this is not mere silence or stillness; in movement and quiescence alike, he is without intent, yet the natural dispositions of life and destiny remain ever at peace. Thus, one who values his person above governing the world may be entrusted with the world; one who cherishes his person in governing the world may be charged with the world.

**[Annotation]** If one轻身轻身轻身轻身 to pursue profit, abandoning the self to follow things, then the person cannot even be at peace—how then can the world be governed?

**[Subcommentary]** One who values the person and scorns profit, who keeps the self within and things without, who preserves and cherishes the spirit without dissipating it in the world—such a one may be entrusted to sit above the myriad things and transform the world. Therefore, if the noble person can refrain from unraveling the five viscera or flaunting his keen perception—

**[Annotation]** To unravel or flaunt is to cause harm.

**[Subcommentary]** The five viscera are the abode of essence and spirit; keen perception is the function of the ears and eyes. If one dissects the emotions and consciousness of the five viscera and displays the functions of keen perception, then the spirit races within, and the ears and eyes are exhausted without. Abiding like a corpse yet manifesting like a dragon, silent as an abyss yet resounding like thunder—

**[Annotation]** In going out and staying in, in silence and speech, one is ever without intent, entrusting all to spontaneity.

**[Subcommentary]** The sage is as still as a corpse in quiescence, yet as dynamic as a soaring dragon in movement. Is there any difference between quiescence and movement, principle and teaching? Thus, in quiescence there is movement—abiding like a corpse yet manifesting like a dragon; silent as an abyss yet resounding like thunder. This illustrates that quiescence and movement, principle and teaching, are neither one nor different. The spirit moves, and heaven follows—

**[Annotation]** The spirit moves in accord with things; heaven acts in accord with principle.

**[Subcommentary]** The spirit is that by which the myriad things are wondrously spoken of—it is both movement and quiescence, its power equal to the azure sky, following and submitting to the arising of things. At ease and without action, the myriad things pile up like dust.

**[Annotation]** Like motes of dust moving of themselves.

**[Subcommentary]** *Lei* means dust. At ease and self-possessed, without action and in emptiness, like the wind stirring fine dust or floating objects in the clear void, like the drifting yang qi, going and staying as they naturally must—what leisure do I have to govern the world?

**[Annotation]** Simply entrusting all to its natural course.

**[Subcommentary]** Things and self blend indistinguishably, all in accord with spontaneity—why labor or take leisure to impose governance?

Cui Qu asked Lao Cong, "If one does not govern the world, how can the human heart be settled?"
Lao Cong replied, "Take care not to constrain the human heart."

**[Annotation]** To constrain it is to harm its innate goodness.

**[Subcommentary]** Cui, by surname; Qu, by given name—his origins are unknown. He asked: If one leaves the human heart to its own devices without governing it, how can it tread the path of goodness? The answer: To leave it be and let it go is to allow it to accord with principle; to impose laws and regulate things is to constrain and disturb the human heart. As the text below says: The human heart pushes downward and advances upward—

**[Annotation]** To push it downward is to make it sink; to advance it upward is to make it rise—this shows how easily it is swayed.

**[Subcommentary]** The human heart pushes others down to be below and advances itself to be above—this is the common tendency. Above and below, imprisoned and slain—

**[Annotation]** Only when there is no pushing or advancing can it be secure.

**[Subcommentary]** Sinking the heart in the struggle between above and below, it is led by circumstances like a prisoner in bonds, wearied and distressed by vexations. Deep and yielding, pliant yet strong—

**[Annotation]** If one can be pure and yielding, then the strong will become pliant.

**[Subcommentary]** Deep and yielding mean soft and weak. By tempering the emotions and acting with softness and weakness, one seeks to subdue and master the strong. Carved and chiseled, its heat scorches like fire, its cold congeals like ice—

**[Annotation]** The heat of a burning fire and the cold of congealed ice both arise from the accumulation of joy and anger. If one neither carves nor chisels, preserving one’s natural simplicity, then how can there be such extremes of ice and fire?

**[Subcommentary]** *Lian* means to strive; *ju* means to wound. To carve and chisel one’s reputation and conduct, seeking to be ahead of others—if one acts contrary to the emotions and stirs up anger, the cold becomes as severe as congealed ice; if one follows the heart and generates joy, the heat is like a scorching fire. Its swiftness is such that in the time it takes to glance up and down, it has twice caressed the lands beyond the four seas.

**[Annotation]** It is moved by customs and habits.

The heart that chases external realms—
in a single thought’s instant, it has already traversed the ten directions.
How much more, then, in the time it takes to glance up and down,
would it not twice over face the four seas?

Its dwelling is deep and still as an abyss;
its movement, suspended, leaps to the heavens.
**[Annotation]** Stillness may be made as profound as an abyss;
movement then hangs from the sky in exultant bounds.

**[Subcommentary]** The heart of desire has no fixed standard for departure.
By chance it grows still, like flowing water encountering a deep pool;
provoked by external realms, it stirs like the high heavens suspended above.
If left unchecked in its motion, it binds itself to the sky in ceaseless leaps.
That which swells in pride and cannot be restrained—
is it not the human heart alone?

**[Annotation]** The transformations of the human heart know no bounds.
If left to follow its course, it grows still and naturally penetrates all;
if governed and restrained, it crouches in frustration and pride.
Pride is an impulse that cannot be curbed.

**[Subcommentary]** Driving down and thrusting up,
beauty and ugliness, joy and anger,
bursting forth in arrogance and self-importance—
that which cannot be restrained lies in the human heart alone.

Formerly, the Yellow Emperor first used benevolence and righteousness to carve the human heart.
**[Annotation]** The Yellow Emperor did not act for benevolence and righteousness;
he simply merged with things, and the manifestations of the seven virtues naturally appeared.
Once they appeared, later generations’ hearts then pursued them of their own accord—
this was also the Yellow Emperor’s way of leading things to carve themselves.

**[Subcommentary]** The Yellow Emperor established standards according to what was fitting,
cherishing and nurturing the people—
truly different from the partial emphasis of the seven virtues,
the restrictive measures of righteousness.
Later rulers followed his tracks,
and the common people named him a sage.
The carving of the human heart began from this.

The fault arose with later kings; the blame does not lie with the Yellow Emperor.
Yao and Shun thus wore their thighs lean and their shins bare,
exhausting their forms to nourish the world,
tormenting their five viscera to enact benevolence and righteousness,
straining their blood and qi to model laws and standards.
Yet even so, they could not fully prevail.
**[Subcommentary]** *Gong* refers to the white flesh of the thigh.
Yao and Shun followed the Yellow Emperor’s path,
their hearts and forms emaciated,
their thighs lean without white flesh,
their shins bare of fine hair.
They nourished the world’s forms,
settled the natures and dispositions of all things,
tormented their five viscera within,
strained their blood and qi without,
practicing benevolence and righteousness as their compass,
establishing laws and standards as their model—
yet still they could not avoid banishing the violent clans, for there were those they could not overcome.
Thus Yao banished Gun to Mount Chong,
exiled the Three Miao to Sanwei,
and sent Gonggong to Youdu—
these were his failures to overcome the world.

**[Subcommentary]** Formerly, the Lord of the Grand Ancestor had an unworthy son,
whom the world called Chaos—this was Gun.
He conspired with Gonggong and was exiled to the southern wilds.
The Lord of Red Cloud had an unworthy son,
whom the world called the Glutton—this was the Three Miao.
He was a vassal of Yao, enfeoffed in the land of the Three Miao,
which lay to the left of Dongting and the right of Poyang,
in Yuzhang, near the Southern Mountains.
Sanwei is a mountain name, in the western wilds—
this is the region of the Qiang in Qinzhou.
The Lord of Lesser Brilliance had an unworthy son,
whom the world called the Strange Beast—this was Gonggong.
He served as Yao’s minister of waterworks.
Youdu lies in the north—this is the land of Youzhou.
The *Book of Documents* records the execution of Gun;
this text is more comprehensive.
All four harbored malice and refused to follow Yao’s transformation,
so he banished them to the four frontiers—
this was Yao’s failure to overcome the world.
That the Four Fiends are attributed to Shun, while here they are called Yao’s,
is because at that time Shun was acting as regent for Yao.

Thus, extending to the Three Kings, the world was thrown into great alarm.
**[Annotation]** The names of Yao and Shun as emperors and kings
are merely their manifestations;
I dwell in this path, but the manifestations are not mine.
Thus, those who are alarmed belong to the world itself.
The more the world is alarmed, the coarser its edges become.
Coarseness and subtlety are but the levelness or ruggedness of the path itself—
does the traveler ever change his feet?

Therefore, the sage is one,
yet there are differences among Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu.
These differences are but the names of their times;
they are not sufficient to name the sage’s true reality.
Thus, Yao and Shun—
were they merely one Yao and one Shun?
Therefore, though they bore the appearance of strain and sorrow,
the path of benevolence and righteousness,
the means by which they traversed it remained whole.

**[Subcommentary]** *Shi* means to extend.
From the Yellow Emperor to Yao and Shun,
the sagely path stagnated and the world grew chaotic.
Extending to the Three Kings, the alarm only deepened.
Below were Jie and Robber Zhi,
**[Subcommentary]** Jie embodied the conduct of petty men below;
Zeng and Shi embodied the conduct of gentlemen above.
above were Zeng and Shi,
and the Confucians and Mohists all arose.
**[Subcommentary]** The Confucians and Mohists held fast to their doctrines,
and disputes over right and wrong arose from them.
Thus, joy and anger suspected each other,
**[Subcommentary]** What one rejoiced in, the other condemned;
they grew mutually suspicious.
the foolish and the wise deceived each other,
**[Subcommentary]** They adorned their wisdom to startle the foolish,
each deceiving the other.
good and bad denounced each other,
**[Subcommentary]** Good and not-good,
each side denounced the other.
falsehood and truth mocked each other,
**[Subcommentary]** The false mocked the true,
and the true mocked the false.
and the world declined.
**[Annotation]** None could equal the self-sufficiency of the natural.
**[Subcommentary]** They endlessly entangled and confused one another,
and the cosmos declined.
Great virtue diverged,
and the natural mandate scattered and dissolved.
**[Annotation]** They established minor differences and did not stop at division.
**[Subcommentary]** Joy and anger, right and wrong,
blazed forth in great profusion,
and thus the natural lifespan was cut short,
the natural mandate scattered and dissolved.
*Lanman* means to disperse and disorder.
The world delighted in knowledge,
and the common people exhausted themselves in pursuit.
**[Annotation]** Knowledge is without limit, and they delighted in it—
thus, there was nothing to satisfy their pursuit.
**[Subcommentary]** The sages exhausted limitless knowledge,
and how could the common people not be exhausted in pursuit?

Thus, the adze and saw were applied,
the inked cord struck,
the mallet and chisel forced into service.
**[Annotation]** They carved and chiseled their natures and destinies,
and it came to this.
**[Subcommentary]** The inked cord straightens the crookedness of wood;
rites and ceremonies show the gradations of human conduct.
The mallet and chisel bore holes in wood...

Punishments and laws sever men’s bodies and heads. Craftsmen wield axes and saws to mutilate wood; sages employ rites and laws to harm the Dao. The world reels in chaos, the fault lying in the corruption of human hearts. Thus, the worthy conceal themselves in the ravines and crags of great mountains, while lords of ten thousand chariots tremble with dread in their ancestral halls.

**[Annotation]** If one were to follow nature and dwell in what is fitting, then the worthy and the foolish would each follow their true feelings, the noble and the base would each tread their proper stations, and ruler and subject, high and low, would all attain their ultimate state—so that the world would know no strife.

Yet this discourse has so transformed the hearts of the world that they race headlong without cease. Thus, those of middling wisdom and below all adorn their natures outwardly to dazzle the multitude, hating the upright and reviling the just, drawing followers in throngs. Thereby, those who uphold authenticity lose their foothold, while those who exalt falsity usurp their authority. Thus, rulers are beset by cares above, and the people are oppressed below.

**[Subcommentary]** *Jiji* means trampling one another. Some say it means chaos—cosmic chaos, the fault of sagely wisdom. The Way of the noble man recedes, and he retreats into the hidden depths of forests and marshes. Though the lord remains in his ancestral hall, his heart quakes with dread, for lacking worthy counselors, he fears the collapse of his state.

In this age, those condemned to death lie heaped upon one another; those in cangues and stocks jostle in crowds; and those subjected to punishment and execution stand in unbroken ranks.

**[Subcommentary]** *Shu* means those sentenced to certain death. *Hengyang* refers to fetters—devices that bind the feet and neck, all called *hengyang*. From the time of the Six States to the declining Zhou, the advance of sagely governance led to the proliferation of the five mutilating punishments, so that those in cangues filled the streets, the condemned lay heaped together, and the maimed and crippled lined the roads. "Heaped" and "in unbroken ranks" make clear their multitude. Yet the Confucians and Mohists now begin to brandish their arms in the very midst of the stocks and gallows.

Alas! How extreme is their shamelessness, how utterly devoid of conscience!

**[Annotation]** This calamity stems from the pedantry of decayed scholars clinging to their doctrines. They never consider casting aside their crooked paths to return to the One, yet here they are, brandishing their arms and striving to govern those very paths—truly, their shamelessness and lack of conscience are extreme.

**[Subcommentary]** *Líbá* describes the exertion of force. The implements of the sage’s reign are meant to harm, yet the Confucians and Mohists now strain with all their might amid the stocks and gallows, clinging to their doctrines of advancement and sealed teachings, seeking to remedy the ills of the age. How could such chaos ever end? Thus, the sigh of lament arises, grieving their stubborn ignorance without cease—so conscience-stricken, yet never ashamed.

I know not whether the wisdom of the sages does not serve as the very joints that fasten the cangue, or whether benevolence and righteousness do not act as the chisel that carves the gallows’ handle.

**[Annotation]** The cangue’s frame is bound with overlapping boards as its mechanism, while the gallows’ crossbeam is fitted with a carved peg for use. The wisdom of sages and the virtues of benevolence and righteousness are far removed from the path of guilt. Yet when people esteem them, arrogance and deceit arise; and where arrogance and deceit flourish, the tools to suppress treachery are never lacking. Thus, to discard what is esteemed is to end deceit; when deceit ceases, the cangue and gallows fall into disuse—what need then for carved handles or overlapping boards?

**[Subcommentary]** *Jiēxié* refers to the wedges of restraints. *Záo* means a hole; to insert an object into a hole is called *bǐng* (a handle). Shackles without wedges are insecure; a crossbeam without holes is useless. Just as governance cannot stand without sagely advancement, nor tyranny prevail without benevolence and righteousness, so sagely advancement is the root of disorder, and benevolence and righteousness the foundation of harm. How can we know that Zeng [Can] and Shi [Qiu] do not serve as the sharp arrows of Jie’s tyranny?

**[Annotation]** *Cuìshǐ* are the fiercest arrows—here, they signify that Zeng and Shi are but tools of Jie’s cruelty.

**[Subcommentary]** *Cuì* refers to the piercing sound of an arrowhead with a hole. Sagely wisdom is the instrument of usurping the state; benevolence and righteousness are the resources of violence. Zeng and Shi become the sharp arrows wielded by Jie’s tyranny—hence the claim.

Thus it is said: "Abandon sagacity, discard wisdom, and the world will be greatly ordered."

**[Annotation]** Follow the principle of their disorder.

**[Subcommentary]** Cast aside the instruments of usurpation, reject the resources of violence, and the realm will be at peace—this is what is meant by "great order."

The Yellow Emperor ruled as Son of Heaven for nineteen years, and his commands prevailed throughout the world.

**[Subcommentary]** His virtuous transformation and edicts spread universally.

Having heard that Master Guangcheng dwelt upon Mount Kongtong, he went to seek him out.

**[Subcommentary]** Mount Kongtong lies on the northern frontier of Liangzhou. Guangcheng is another name for Laozi.

He said: "I have heard that you, Master, have attained the utmost Dao. I venture to ask: what is the essence of the utmost Dao? I wish to gather the essence of Heaven and Earth to aid the Five Grains and nourish the people."

**[Subcommentary]** The Five Grains are millet, panicled millet, beans, hemp, and wheat. He desired to draw upon the subtle and obscure principles of Heaven and Earth, the essential qi of yin and yang, to assist the growth of the Five Grains and nourish all living beings.

"I further wish to regulate yin and yang to nurture the flourishing of life. How may this be done?"

**[Subcommentary]** *Sui* means "to follow." He wished to emulate yin and yang by establishing offices and dividing duties, thereby following the nature of living things, and so he asked how this might be accomplished.

Master Guangcheng replied: "What you wish to ask concerns the substance of things."

**[Annotation]** To ask about the essence of the utmost Dao may indeed be called "substance."

**[Subcommentary]** *Er* means "you." To desire to sow and cultivate the Five Grains and to establish offices for the Two Modes—your questions are shallow, no more than matters of form and substance, deviating from the profound and mysterious subtlety. This is truly reproachable.

"What you wish to regulate is the ruin of things."

**[Annotation]** To impose regulation upon what is naturally so is to ruin it.

**[Subcommentary]** If you insist on establishing offices and dividing duties, compelling things to follow your will, you will deviate from the workings of creation and inevitably bring about harm and ruin.

"Since you have governed the world, clouds have not gathered before raining, and plants have not waited to yellow before falling. The light of the sun and moon has grown ever more dim."

**[Subcommentary]** *Zu* means "to gather." To appoint officials to manage yin and yang and to govern all things with intent is to invite calamity. Winds and rains will not be harmonized, heat and cold will lose their proper seasons; clouds will not gather before rain falls, and trees will shed their leaves while still green. Eclipses will press upon the Three Luminaries, dimming their light; the human heart will be disturbed, and celestial signs will grow faint and sluggish.

"As for the heart of a flatterer, ever eager to meddle—how could it be worthy to speak of the utmost Dao?"

**[Subcommentary]** "Myriad myriad" describes a narrow and inferior appearance. You are a flattering and deceitful person—how could your heart, so cramped and base, be capable of discoursing on the utmost Dao?

The Yellow Emperor withdrew, relinquished the world, built a solitary chamber, spread white cogon grass for his seat, and dwelt in seclusion for three months before returning to seek him again.

**[Subcommentary]** The Yellow Emperor withdrew, purifying his mind and unifying his intent. Though he held the honored position of the Nine-Five, he built a solitary chamber to escape clamor, spread white cogon grass to keep his counsel pure, and remained in quietude for a season before journeying once more to request the Dao. *Yao* means "to visit." Broadly Accomplished Master lay with his head to the south, facing outward, while the Yellow Emperor descended to the lower wind, advancing on his knees. Twice he bowed, touching his forehead to the ground, and inquired: "I have heard that you, Master, have attained the utmost Dao. I venture to ask: how should one govern the body so as to attain longevity?"

Broadly Accomplished Master rose abruptly and said: "Excellent indeed is your question!"

**[Annotation]** If all people cultivated themselves and did not govern the world, the world would be well-governed—thus he praised it.

**[Subcommentary]** To set people to ordering things only invites entanglement and vexation; if each governs their own body, the world will be clear and upright—thus he praised it. *Jué rán* means "to rise swiftly." "Come!"

I shall tell you the utmost Dao. The essence of the utmost Dao is profound and obscure; the ultimate of the utmost Dao is dark and silent.

**[Annotation]** *Profound and obscure, dark and silent*—all denote absolute nothingness. Why do Zhuangzi and Laozi so often speak of "nothing"? To clarify that what gives birth to things is no-thing, and things arise of themselves. They arise of themselves—not for the sake of arising—so how could there be any further action upon what has already arisen?

**[Subcommentary]** The essence of the utmost Dao is so subtle that the mind cannot fathom it; thus it is likened to the profound and deep, the dark and abstruse. Without seeing, yet seeing of itself; without hearing, yet hearing of itself—then the spirit remains undisturbed and the form does not stray.

Guard your spirit in stillness, and your form will naturally align. Be still, be pure; do not weary your form, do not agitate your essence—only then can you attain longevity.

**[Annotation]** Let it move of itself, and thus it remains tranquil without premature decay.

**[Subcommentary]** Purify the spirit and still the thoughts; let the body rest without toil. Unmoved by external phenomena, the essence remains serene. With the mind at ease and the form relaxed, one attains long life and enduring vision.

Eyes seeing nothing, ears hearing nothing, the mind knowing nothing—then your spirit will guard your form, and your form will attain long life.

**[Annotation]** This is all movement in accord with one’s nature, hence long life.

**[Subcommentary]** Though seeing and hearing occur, nothing is perceived; with roots and dust emptied, the mind too becomes still. Illuminating without cognition, responding with constant tranquility—the spirit, unagitated, guards the form, enabling long life and enduring vision.

Be cautious within.

**[Annotation]** Preserve your true nature.

**[Subcommentary]** Forget the mind to preserve the true.

Be vigilant without.

**[Annotation]** Keep to your proper place.

**[Subcommentary]** Cut off seeing and hearing to keep to your place.

Excessive knowledge leads to ruin.

**[Annotation]** Knowledge has no bounds, hence ruin.

**[Subcommentary]** Without caution in wisdom and thought, the spirit becomes exhausted, the ears and eyes depleted by externals—how could this not lead to ruin?

I have led you to the great brightness above, to the source of utmost yang; I have guided you into the gate of profound obscurity, to the source of utmost yin.

**[Annotation]** To reach the source of yin and yang is to ascend to the great brightness above and enter the gate of profound obscurity.

**[Subcommentary]** Yang is movement; yin is stillness. *Led you*—means to emerge. When the perfected one responds to movement, wisdom shines like the sun and moon—this is called great brightness. The source of utmost yang signifies descent from the root and advance—hence it is said to emerge. When unaroused, the root is deeply still and serene. The source of utmost yin signifies gathering the branches to return to the root—hence it is said to enter the gate of profound obscurity. Broadly Accomplished Master showed the Yellow Emperor the two principles of movement and stillness, thus employing the two gates of yin and yang.

Heaven and earth have their offices, yin and yang have their repositories.

**[Annotation]** Simply let them be.

Guard your body with care, and things will flourish of themselves.

**[Subcommentary]** The offices of heaven are the sun, moon, and stars, which illuminate the four directions and govern the myriad things—hence they are called offices. The offices of earth are metal, wood, water, fire, and soil, which sustain the living and the growing, bearing and carrying all beings—hence they too are called offices. The two qi of yin and yang, spring and summer, autumn and winter, each have their overseers, like the organs and viscera. All follow their nature without obstruction—why defy creation by setting up further offices? If you but practice non-action and guard your body with care, all things will naturally prosper—why trouble the mind and invite sorrow?

I preserve the One and abide in harmony; thus I have cultivated my body for one thousand two hundred years, yet my form has never decayed.

**[Annotation]** This is to exhaust the utmost of life and destiny, to reach the ultimate of long life.

**[Subcommentary]** Preserving tranquility and the One, dwelling in the wondrous harmony of the Dao, nurturing and protecting the body—though the years may be long, there will be no day of decline.

Only one whose body does not decay prematurely can extend care to others.

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touching his forehead to the ground, and said: "Broadly Accomplished Master is what is meant by Heaven!"

**[Annotation]** Heaven is non-action.

**[Subcommentary]** The loftiness of the sage’s Dao may join in virtue with the mysterious Heaven.

Broadly Accomplished Master said: "Come. I shall tell you more."

Those beings are without end, yet people all deem them finite;
**[Subcommentary]** Life and death, transformation—such principles are endless, yet the common folk, deluded and confused, believe in beginnings and endings.

Those beings are unfathomable, yet people all deem them bounded;
**[Annotation]** They see only one of their transformations.
**[Subcommentary]** The myriad beings are beyond measure, shifting through a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, yet the foolish cling to the notion of limits.

One who attains my Dao may ascend as Sovereign or descend as King;
**[Annotation]** The titles of Sovereign and King vary with the rise and fall of the age, yet in attaining the Dao of adaptability to respond to the endless, they are one.
**[Subcommentary]** One who grasps the Dao of spontaneity, encountering an era of pristine simplicity, becomes a Fuxi or Shen Nong; facing an age of decadence, responds as Tang or Wu. Whether Sovereign or King, through peace or peril, the Dao remains one.

One who loses my Dao may appear radiant above yet become earth below;
**[Annotation]** Losing the endless Dao, one clings to a single transformation, unable to harmonize above and below, thus bowing and rising with divided heart.
**[Subcommentary]** Forsaking the Dao of non-action, mired in the heart of desire, one may live in the light of glory but in death revert to dust. Deluded by life and death, unable to harmonize above and below, one bears two names.

Now, the hundred flourishing beings all arise from earth and return to earth—thus I shall leave you.
**[Annotation]** Earth is without intent. Born from the unintentional, one must return to guard the unintentional and journey alone.
**[Subcommentary]** All flourishing beings arise from the earth, and when they wither, return to the soil. The myriad things of the world are born from nothingness and, in death, revert to emptiness. Unbound by life or death, untethered to any single state, I now depart from you to follow my course.

I enter the gate of the endless to wander the boundless wilds;
**[Annotation]** To move as one with transformation.
**[Subcommentary]** Returning to the profound stillness of the origin, entering the gate of the endless, responding to change between heaven and earth, roaming the boundless wilds.

I share the radiance of the sun and moon, I endure with heaven and earth.
**[Annotation]** To yield entirely to it.
**[Subcommentary]** To share (参) is to be one. Aligning with the three luminaries in brightness, matching the two poles in duration—how could it be a mere thousand two hundred years?

When near me, all is luminous; when far from me, all is dark.

The comings and goings of things—all pass unperceived.
**[Annotation]** The sage’s mind is like a mirror: when the mechanism meets stimulus, it responds in hidden accord; if no stimulus comes, it remains dim and obscure.

"All others will perish entirely, yet I alone endure?"
**[Annotation]** To regard death and life as one body is to find no place where one does not endure.
**[Subcommentary]** To unite death and life is to illuminate transformation—nothing has ever ceased to be the self. With no going and no coming, I alone endure.

People cling to life and death, and thus know sorrow and rest.

Cloud General was traveling east when he passed the branch of the Whirling Gale and there chanced upon Vast Vagueness. Vast Vagueness was just then clapping his knees and leaping about in play.
**[Subcommentary]** *Cloud General*: the lord of clouds. *Vast Vagueness*: primordial qi. *Whirling Gale*: the spirit of the tree, born in the Eastern Sea—also called the wind. *Chanced upon*: encountered. *Clapping*: striking. *Leaping about*: jumping in play. This is a parable. Qi is the source of living things; clouds are the root of rain and moisture; the tree is the realm of spring yang; the east is the direction of benevolence and kindness. These four images show the ruler how to govern: virtue and beneficence come first.

When Cloud General saw him,
**[Subcommentary]** Marveling at his appearance, so unlike the common world, and his movements, so different from the ordinary, he asked the reason for his journey, hoping to learn how to order things rightly.

he halted in astonishment, stood motionless, and said: "Old sir, who are you? What are you doing here?"

The Venerable Hongmeng continued leaping and bounding without cease, and replied to Cloud General: "Wandering."
**[Subcommentary]** Roaming freely through the transformations of nature.

Cloud General said: "I wish to ask you something."
Hongmeng looked up at Cloud General and sighed: "Hmm!"

Cloud General said: "Heaven’s qi is disharmonious, earth’s qi is pent up—
**[Subcommentary]** The two qi neither descend nor ascend, thus pent up.
the six qi are unbalanced,
**[Subcommentary]** Yin and yang, wind and rain, darkness and light—these are the six qi.
and the four seasons are out of joint.
**[Subcommentary]** Spring, summer, autumn, and winter—seasonal ordinances are disordered in their sequence.
Now I wish to blend the essence of the six qi to nurture all living things. How should I go about it?"
**[Subcommentary]** I desire to harmonize the essence of the six qi to nourish the myriad beings, hence my question.

The Venerable Hongmeng continued leaping and bounding, shook his head, and said: "I do not know. I do not know."
**[Subcommentary]** All things receive their nature spontaneously; if one deliberately intervenes to order them, this contravenes the workings of creation, hence he shook his head and gave no answer.

Cloud General could get no answer.
Three years later, he journeyed eastward, passing through the wilds of Song, where he chanced upon Hongmeng again.
Cloud General rejoiced greatly, hastened forward, and said: "Has Heaven forgotten me? Has Heaven forgotten me?"
He bowed twice, touching his head to the ground, and entreated Hongmeng: "I wish to hear your teaching."
**[Subcommentary]** As though addressing Heaven itself, he repeated "forgotten me" in hopes of recalling their former encounter.

Hongmeng said: "Drifting, knowing not what I seek—
**[Annotation]** Yet attaining what I seek.
**[Subcommentary]** Drifting through the world, without deliberate pursuit.
Wild and unrestrained, knowing not where I go—
**[Annotation]** Yet attaining where I go.
**[Subcommentary]** Without intent or fixed course, without set destination.
The wanderer moves freely, observing the primal and the illusory.
**[Annotation]** One who is inwardly sufficient finds all things naturally correct.
**[Subcommentary]** Hongmeng’s wandering heart roams boundlessly, encountering myriad things; his observing wisdom knows that the realm he perceives is without falsehood. *Freely* here means "in abundance."
What do I know?"
**[Annotation]** This is all there is to it.

Yunjiang said: "I deemed myself wild and unrestrained, yet the people follow wherever I go. I cannot escape them—now they imitate me in all things."

**[Annotation]** One who rides the world does not advance by force, yet the Way manifests of itself; one who is wild and unrestrained does not summon the people, yet the people follow of themselves. Thus, compelled by the people’s imitation, one cannot but yield.

**[Subcommentary]** Like Hongmeng, I wander without intent to govern, yet find myself among men; the people follow and imitate me, and so I am made to serve as their model.

"I wish to hear a single word."

**[Subcommentary]** I wish to hear the essential teaching, that my deep doubts may be resolved.

Hongmeng said: "To disorder heaven’s principles, to oppose the nature of things—then the mysterious workings of heaven cannot be fulfilled."

**[Annotation]** If one follows the nature of things without governing, then feelings are not opposed and principles are not disordered; the profound stillness is complete, and the natural is attained.

**[Subcommentary]** To disorder heaven’s constant Way, to oppose the true nature of things—then deceit and cunning arise, and the transformations of the natural are not fulfilled.

"To loose the beasts’ assaults, and the birds all cry out at night;"

**[Annotation]** They depart from their state of stillness.

**[Subcommentary]** When imitation spreads and prominence is sought, harm to things blazes forth: beasts are startled into scattering, birds are frightened into night cries.

"Disaster reaches the grasses and trees, calamity befalls the insects."

**[Annotation]** All suffer harm while sitting idle.

**[Subcommentary]** Grasses and trees wither before frost, and calamity reaches the insects. *Kun* means "bright," facing the sun, opening and settling.

"Alas! This is the fault of those who govern."
