**[Annotation]** Where there is governance, there is escape; from this, disorder arises.

**[Subcommentary]** Heaven’s governance is destroyed—this is the fault of those who govern.

Yunjiang said: "Then what am I to do?"

**[Subcommentary]** He wishes to learn the defense of non-governance.

Hongmeng said: "Alas! How poisonous!"

**[Annotation]** The fault of those who govern runs deep.

**[Subcommentary]** He sighs repeatedly at the repeated wounds and disasters.

*Yu*—a sound of lament.

"Restlessly, return!"

**[Annotation]** *Juanjuan*: the appearance of rising and sitting. Suspecting he cannot suddenly break free and roam at ease, he sends him to return.

**[Subcommentary]** *Juanjuan*: the appearance of light rising. Fearing Yunjiang’s governance of things will bring calamity, he demonstrates light rising and urges him to cease his entanglements and return to the root.

Yunjiang said: "I have encountered great difficulty. I wish to hear a single word."

Hongmeng said: "Alas! Cultivate the heart-mind."

**[Annotation]** When the heart-mind is harmed by use, then to cultivate the heart-mind—is it not to refrain from using the heart-mind?

**[Subcommentary]** The extension of cultivating the heart-mind is set forth below.

"Simply abide in non-action, and things will transform of themselves."

**[Subcommentary]** *Tu*: merely. Merely abide in the heart-mind’s non-action, and things will transform of themselves.

"Cast off your form, expel your brilliance; let reason and things be forgotten."

**[Annotation]** When principle and things are not held in the heart, but are entrusted to the natural, then there is non-action, and transformation occurs of itself.

**[Subcommentary]** *Lun*: principle. To cast off form is to forget the body; to expel brilliance is to forget the heart-mind. When body and heart-mind are both forgotten, self and things are both relinquished—this is cultivating the heart-mind.

"Merge in great sameness with the turbid and the clear."

**[Annotation]** To be without boundary with things.

**[Subcommentary]** *Qi* and *jin* are the qi of spontaneity. Vast and boundless, body and heart-mind merge in great sameness, naturally uniting with the whole. Release the heart-mind, liberate the spirit—become utterly devoid of soul.

**[Annotation]** Sit in forgetfulness, entrusting to solitude.

**[Subcommentary]** *Hun*: the pursuit of discriminating knowledge. *Jie shi* (release and dissolve): to dispel and let go. *Moran* (utterly devoid): without knowledge. Scouring and purifying the heart-mind, one becomes like dead ashes or withered wood—without knowing soul.

The myriad things, teeming and multitudinous, each return to their root; each return to their root yet do not know it.

**[Annotation]** To return without knowing is the true return.

**[Subcommentary]** *Yun yun*: in great numbers. The multitudes come and go, arising and perishing without departing from spontaneity. Their return to the root is evident—how could one rely on knowledge to restore the mandate?

Chaotic and undifferentiated, one remains thus for a lifetime without departure.

**[Annotation]** Abiding in chaos without knowledge, entrusting to spontaneous return—only thus can one remain lifelong without departing from the root.

**[Subcommentary]** Chaos without knowledge, entrusting to solitude—through ten thousand transformations, one does not depart from spontaneity. If one knows it, then one has already departed from it.

**[Annotation]** To return through knowledge is to deviate from return.

**[Subcommentary]** To employ knowledge in longing for the root is to depart from the natural nature.

Ask not its name, inquire not into its conditions—things arise of themselves.

**[Annotation]** To inquire is to lose their spontaneous arising.

**[Subcommentary]** The Dao is beyond names and words; principle is beyond conditions and thoughts. If one seeks the Dao through names or inquires into principle through conditions, how far astray one goes! Only by relinquishing conditions and forgetting names, entrusting to solitary transformation, do things attain their inherent principle.

Cloud General said: "Heaven bestowed virtue upon me, revealed silence to me. Seeking it in my own person, only now have I attained it."

**[Annotation]** To know yet not remain silent is to constantly lose oneself.

**[Subcommentary]** Bestowing words of virtue and power, demonstrating the practice of profound stillness—since establishing myself, only now have I awakened. Bowing twice with head to the ground, he rose, took leave, and departed.

The people of the world all delight in others being the same as themselves and detest others being different from themselves.

**[Subcommentary]** Those mired in habitual patterns, deluded and attached for so long, rejoice in sameness and fear difference.

Those who desire sameness with themselves and reject difference do so with the intent to stand out from the crowd.

**[Annotation]** The heart-mind desires to stand out from the ordinary and be the center of the crowd.

**[Subcommentary]** To affirm oneself and negate others, to delight in sameness and detest difference—this is invariably to display one’s merit and fame, to surpass the multitude. Yet those who take standing out from the crowd as their aim—how can they ever truly stand out?

**[Annotation]** All take standing out as their aim, and thus they are the crowd. If I too desire to stand out from the crowd, then I am no different from them and cannot surpass them. When all take surpassing others as their aim, and I alone go along without resistance, then I am vastly different from the crowd and become their master.

**[Subcommentary]** People take competing to stand out from the crowd as their aim—this is the vulgar sentiment of ordinary things. How can one alone transcend the ordinary? Only by merging with their radiance and dust can one be vastly different from the crowd and become their paragon.

Relying on the multitude to secure what one has heard is better than relying on the skills of the multitude.

**[Annotation]** What I alone have heard is not as much as the skills of the multitude, so it is better to rely on them. If one does not rely on the multitude, then the thousands upon thousands of the multitude become one’s adversaries.

**[Subcommentary]** Employing the skills of the multitude, relying on their knowledge and perceptions—this is without contention. This is what is meant by "the enlightened see for them, the wise plan for them."

Yet those who desire to govern others’ states seize the benefits of the Three Kings without seeing the harm.

**[Annotation]** Those who desire to govern others’ states, not relying on the multitude’s self-governance but imposing their own governance—this is to seek the benefits of the Three Kings in ruling things while failing to see the exhaustion of governing by oneself. Yet how did the Three Kings attain their benefits? They relied on the self-governance of all under heaven and entrusted to it.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who govern a state with their own partial attachments seek only the benefits of the Three Kings in ruling things, unaware that this brings great harm to themselves. This is to gamble with others’ states—how many such gambles do not result in the loss of others’ states?

Those who preserve others’ states are fewer than one in ten thousand; those who lose others’ states fail once and bring ruin to more than ten thousand.

**[Annotation]** Oneself and all under heaven are mutually reliant in completion. Now, if one alone monopolizes control over all under heaven, then all under heaven is obstructed—how can one be unobstructed? Thus, the self is not completed, and the myriad regions suffer ruin.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who govern as emperors and kings with a gambler’s heart—when it comes to preserving themselves, not one succeeds; when it comes to ruin, there is more than enough. Alas, how ignorant are those who possess lands!

Those who possess lands possess great things.

**[Subcommentary]** The exalted position of the Nine-Five, vast and expansive as the four seas—this is called a great thing.

Those who possess great things cannot be used by things.

**[Annotation]** Unable to use things but instead used by things—this is merely a thing. How can one use things?

If one cannot use things, then one is not sufficient to possess great things.

**[Subcommentary]** If one seeks the state of the Three Kings yet cannot entrust things to self-governance, one is instead used by things. If one is oneself a thing, how can one use things? This is utterly impossible. Only by not being used by things can one use things.

**[Annotation]** Those who use things are not used by things. Not being used by things, they are not things. Not being things, they can use the things of all under heaven, allowing each to attain its own nature.

The subcommentary states: not being used by things yet able to use things. Clearly, those who use things are not things themselves—how could their governance be limited to the people of all under heaven? They move within the six directions, roam across the nine provinces.

**[Annotation]** Using the self-governance of all under heaven, they drive the myriad things without exhaustion.

**[Subcommentary]** The sage penetrates the natural, comprehends creation, employs the knowledge of the people, and utilizes the senses of all living beings. Thus, those who use things are not things themselves. How could their role be confined to wearing the imperial crown, sitting in the Fenyang Palace, bearing the jade seal, and ruling the world? They must instead transcend the six directions, ascend the great purity, surpass the nine provinces, and wander the Gushe Mountains. Alone they come, alone they go—this is called possessing singularity. Possessing singularity in this singular way may truly be called singular possession. Those who possess singularity are called the most noble.

**[Annotation]** Those who harmonize with the multitude in profound unity do not seek nobility among the crowd, yet the crowd cannot but regard them as noble—this is the highest nobility. If one clings to partial views and takes singularity as one’s heart, then even if one aligns with a single purpose, one remains but a thing among the vulgar, opposing true singular possession. Without possessing singularity, one may covet rank and emblems, usurping what is not one’s due—how could the multitude ever follow?

**[Subcommentary]** While others distinguish themselves, one alone wanders in harmony—this is alone coming, alone going. Possessing singularity in this singular way may truly be called singular possession. While others seek to stand out, one alone wanders freely, a capacity none possess—hence the name singular possession. Those who possess singularity are joyfully upheld by the people, borne by the masses. To make such a one their lord is to attain the highest honor and nobility.

The teachings of the great person are like a shadow following form, an echo responding to sound.

**[Annotation]** The hearts of the people are form and sound; the teachings of the great person are shadow and echo. What intent does the great person hold toward all under heaven? They are but shadow and echo following form and sound.

**[Subcommentary]** The great person is the sage. Without intent, they respond—response is not by intent. Thus, the hearts of the people are form and sound; the teachings of the great person are shadow and echo. When questioned, they respond, exhausting what is held within.

**[Annotation]** Allowing each being’s held aspirations to attain their full expression.

**[Subcommentary]** The sage’s heart follows the stimulus of things, responding in accord with the moment, exhausting the aspirations of all beings. They pair with all under heaven.

**[Annotation]** The questioner is the host; the response is the counterpart.

**[Subcommentary]** *Pair* means to match: the first stimulus is the host; the response is the counterpart. They abide in no echo.

**[Annotation]** They await things in stillness.

**[Subcommentary]** *Abide* means stillness. In times without stimulus, the heart is like withered wood, still and without shadow or echo. They move without fixed direction.

**[Annotation]** They transform in accord with things.

**[Subcommentary]** *Move* means to respond to the moment. They adapt to the moment without fixed place. They lift and guide you, returning you to the restless stirrings.

**[Annotation]** *Restless stirrings* means self-movement. Lifting and guiding the myriad things, they return them to the nature of self-movement—this is the perfection of non-action.

**[Subcommentary]** *Restless stirrings* means self-movement. Adapting to the moment without fixed direction, they seek to lift and guide you and others of the common sort, returning you to your original nature—this is the perfection of non-action. They wander without end.

**[Annotation]** They move with transformation, hence without end.

**[Subcommentary]** *Wander* means the heart moves in unison with the natural—hence without trace or boundary. They enter and exit without side.

**[Annotation]** Profoundly identical, without outward mark.

**[Subcommentary]** Entering and exiting the dust and bounds of life and death, they are profoundly one with creation, without visible edge. They share no beginning with the sun.

**[Annotation]** They renew together with each day, hence without beginning.

**[Subcommentary]** Renewing together with each day, they are without end or beginning. Praising and discussing the bodily form, they unite with the great harmony.

**[Annotation]** Their form and appearance differ not from heaven and earth.

**[Subcommentary]** *Praise* and *discuss* are words. The sage’s abundant virtue and bodily form unite with the great Way of the two powers, outwardly not bounded by the cosmos, inwardly not possessing their own body. They unite with the great harmony yet have no self.

**[Annotation]** With self, one cannot unite with the great harmony.

**[Subcommentary]** United with the two powers and the great Way, both self and other are forgotten. Without self, how could there be anything possessed?

**[Annotation]** The difficulty in all under heaven lies in the self. Once the self is gone, the myriad things are no longer sufficient to be possessed.

**[Subcommentary]** Once the self is gone, how could things exist? Those who perceive being are the gentlemen of old.

**[Annotation]** They are merely those who beautify their names.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who practice benevolence and righteousness, observe ritual and lord-subject relations, do not depart from being—these are the gentlemen. Those who perceive non-being are friends of heaven and earth.

**[Annotation]** Perceiving non-being, they allow things to live in their singularity.

**[Subcommentary]** Perceiving the wondrous principle of non-action, seeing the true nature of the natural, the two powers are not being, the myriad things are all empty—turning from being to enter non-being, they are thus called friends. What is lowly yet cannot be left unentrusted is things; what is humble yet cannot be left unaccommodated is the people.

**[Annotation]** Accommodating their nature and entrusting them leads to order; opposing their nature and overpowering them leads to chaos. The reason the people and things are humble and lowly is their inability to be accommodated and entrusted. Thus, entrusting the lowly makes them noble; accommodating the humble makes them honored—this is the natural tally.

**[Subcommentary]** Though the people dwell below, each has their function; though things are light and lowly, all bear their use. No material is to be discarded, no person is to be left unused—thus all may flourish. What is hidden yet cannot be left undone is affairs.

**[Annotation]** Affairs are concealed in that, hence hidden. Each acts on its own, hence cannot be left undone—but one should only accommodate and entrust them.

**[Subcommentary]** *Hidden* means concealed.

Affairs possess concealment and manifestation; natures bear skill and clumsiness. Some manifest here, some conceal there; some are skillful here, some clumsy there—yet one should only entrust them, and all affairs become equal.

That which is evident yet cannot remain unexpressed is *law*.
**[Annotation]** Law is the advancement of wondrous affairs—how can one be remiss and fail to express wondrous affairs?
**[Subcommentary]** Law refers to teaching. Teaching aims at principle, yet principle is wondrous while law is coarse—like the fish-trap and rabbit-snare, it must be expressed.

That which is distant yet cannot remain unoccupied is *rightness*.
**[Annotation]** Only by occupying it does one make it distant.
**[Subcommentary]** Though rightness is remote from the Dao, if it accords with principle, one must adopt and decide by it.

That which is intimate yet cannot remain narrow is *benevolence*.
**[Annotation]** Intimacy may be partial, thus only by broadening it does one achieve benevolence.
**[Subcommentary]** Though intimacy may be partial and love limited, encompassing and universal love is great benevolence.

That which is regulated yet cannot remain unaccumulated is *ritual*.
**[Annotation]** Ritual regulation halts at fixation on one thing; when each thing embodies it, it accumulates and becomes all-encompassing.
**[Subcommentary]** Accumulation means depth. Regulation is pattern. Ritual values reciprocity, yet human feelings are shallow and thin—thus outwardly it displays refined movements while inwardly it fosters profound accumulation: this is true ritual.

That which is centered yet cannot remain lowly is *virtue*.
**[Annotation]** In affairs of inferiority, though centered, it is not virtue.
**[Subcommentary]** Centered means compliant. Those who cultivate the Dao harmonize their light and dwell in the world, humbling themselves before things while their aspirations and conduct remain lofty—though steeped in defilement, their virtue remains unstained.

That which is unified yet cannot remain unchanged is the *Dao*.
**[Annotation]** In difficult affairs, though unified, it is not the Dao—how much less when not unified?
**[Subcommentary]** The wondrous origin is a single qi, universally generating the myriad things—so utterly simple and easy, is this not the Dao?

That which is numinous yet cannot remain unenacted is *Heaven*.
**[Annotation]** To cling to intent and refuse to act—though numinous, it is not Heaven; how much less when not numinous?
**[Subcommentary]** Heaven’s numinous workings are unfathomable, manifesting and concealing without fixed pattern, responding to the moment without obstruction—this accords with Heaven’s nature.

Thus the sage observes Heaven yet does not assist,
**[Annotation]** Simply following its self-enactment.
**[Subcommentary]** The sage observes the wondrous principle of nature, greatly complying with things without aiding their inherent dispositions. *The following explains the preceding text.*

accomplishes virtue yet is not burdened,
**[Annotation]** Naturally meeting in lofty convergence.
**[Subcommentary]** Able to make realm and wisdom merge in darkness, once supreme virtue is accomplished, it is naturally free from flaws and burdens.

emerges from the Dao yet does not scheme,
**[Annotation]** Not scheming yet unified—this is the body’s way.
**[Subcommentary]** Manifesting the wondrously unified Dao, how could one wait for schemes to further expound it? *The* Laozi *states: "Acting without reliance."* Benevolence and universal love are prized for their appropriateness—thus there is no reliance.

is sparing in rightness yet does not accumulate,
**[Annotation]** Following one’s nature and dwelling in remoteness is not accumulation.
**[Subcommentary]** The thatched huts of the former kings were not to be treasured; once straw dogs have been displayed, how could they be accumulated and retained?

responds to ritual yet does not taboo,
**[Annotation]** Naturally responding to ritual, not through avoidance of taboos.
**[Subcommentary]** The wondrous origin is profoundly still—advancing to respond to ritual, how could it be bound by taboos?

engages with affairs yet does not decline,
**[Annotation]** Affairs are engaged through principle; success or failure rests with oneself. One responds to movement with movement, without refusal or declination.
**[Subcommentary]** Blending with the world and riding its waves, one engages with things as affairs arise, responding to the moment without selection or declination.

equalizes through law yet is not disordered,
**[Annotation]** Governing the coarse with the wondrous, thus it is not disordered.
**[Subcommentary]** Following the natures of things, one equalizes them with law—thus there is no disorder.

attends to the people yet does not belittle them,
**[Annotation]** Relying on their self-enactment, not lightly employing them.
**[Subcommentary]** The people are the state’s root; when the root is firm, the state is tranquil—thus one attends to and relies on them without daring to employ them lightly.

follows things yet does not abandon them.
**[Annotation]** Following and entrusting them, not abandoning their root.
**[Subcommentary]** Complying with the hearts of the black-haired people and following the natures of the myriad things, though applying laws and teachings, one does not allow them to become mixed with their original nature.

Things are never sufficient to act upon, yet cannot remain unacted upon.
**[Annotation]** Why act because they are sufficient to act upon? This acting is self-embodied—thus it cannot be stopped.
**[Subcommentary]** The endowment of things in their arising is of myriad differences—like the dung-beetle rolling its pellet or the spider weaving its web, emerging from Heaven’s nature, not dependent on acquired learning. Thus what is absent in their nature cannot be forcibly enacted, while what is present in their nature cannot remain unenacted.

Those who are unclear about Heaven are not pure in virtue;
**[Annotation]** Being unclear about nature leads to contrivance; with contrivance, virtue is not pure.
**[Subcommentary]** Aligning with nature’s principle, then the shallow and thin virtue is not pure.

those who do not penetrate the Dao have no means by which to proceed;
**[Annotation]** Unable to empty oneself and await things, one loses accord in every affair.
**[Subcommentary]** Obstructing the empty and wondrous Dao-nature, thus in every encounter one fails—truly there is no means by which to proceed.

those who are unclear about the Dao—how lamentable!
**[Subcommentary]** Aligning with Heaven and humanity’s principle yet confusing the meaning of ruler and minister, their undertakings are all constricted—deeply lamentable.

What is the Dao?
There is the Dao of Heaven, and the Dao of Man.

Without action yet revered—this is the Dao of Heaven.
**[Annotation]** Above yet allowing the myriad things to act of themselves.
**[Subcommentary]** Free from affairs and action, exalted and on high—this accords with the natural Dao of Heaven.

With action yet encumbered—this is the Dao of Man.
**[Annotation]** To be burdened by action is to fail in following one’s spontaneous attainment.
**[Subcommentary]** Managing duties with action, entangled in worldly cares—this is the Dao of human relations.

The ruler embodies the Dao of Heaven;
**[Annotation]** In harmony with Heaven’s letting-be of things, one naturally presides over them.
**[Subcommentary]** The sovereign, above and allowing things to be, accords with the non-action of Heaven’s Dao.

The minister embodies the Dao of Man.
**[Annotation]** Each fulfills their proper charge.

Between the Dao of Heaven and the Dao of Man, the distance is vast.
**[Annotation]** The ruler practices non-action and delegates to the hundred officials; the officials each have their duties, while the ruler does not intervene. Both attain spontaneity through non-action, yet the ruler’s path is ease, the minister’s path is toil—between their labor and leisure, they cannot be spoken of in the same breath.
**[Subcommentary]** The ruler’s position is exalted, entrusted to stewards; the minister’s path is humble, exhausting sincerity in service to the throne. Thus the ruler’s path is ease, the minister’s path is toil—they cannot be spoken of in the same breath.

This must not go unexamined.
**[Annotation]** Without examination, the positions of ruler and minister become disordered.
**[Subcommentary]** The Dao of Heaven is for the ruler and non-action; the Dao of Man is for the minister and affairs. With hierarchy distinct and labor and leisure unequal, each keeping to their station, then ruler and minister alike attain non-action. If one fails to discern this principle, labor and leisure become misaligned, and ruler and minister fall into disorder.

The Two Modes generate and nurture, their transformations boundless. Within the realm of form and substance, they are most vast, ever renewing and changing, moment by moment advancing—truly equal and impartial, what is called "nurturing and ripening."

*Zhuangzi: Annotated and Subcommented, Scroll Fourteen*
*Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Tang Dynasty Master of the Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary**
*Outer Chapters, "Heaven and Earth" (Chapter Twelve)*

Though heaven and earth are vast, their transformations are uniform.
**Annotation:** Uniform in their non-action, transforming of themselves.
**Subcommentary:** The Two Modes engender and nurture, covering and bearing without end. Among all forms and substances, they are the most expansive. Yet their ceaseless transformations remain unchanged in appearance; their moment-to-moment transience is truly equal—this is what is meant by "leveling" them. Thus it is said: "Heaven and earth give birth to me, and all things are born alongside me."

Though the myriad things are numerous, their governance is one.
**Annotation:** Governance is achieved through self-attainment.
**Subcommentary:** The four modes of generation produce the myriad things, their kinds most abundant. Yet when each follows its nature and attains itself, this principle is singular—this is what is meant by "harmonizing" them. Thus it is further said: "The myriad things and I are one."

Though the masses of people are many, their lord is the ruler.
**Annotation:** When the world harbors divergent minds, the mindless one becomes the lord.
**Subcommentary:** Though the black-haired commoners and servants are numerous, the one who rules as lord is but a single person. Without intent, following and yielding, one rightfully occupies this position.

The ruler originates in virtue and is completed by heaven.
**Annotation:** Taking virtue as its origin, nothing fails to attain. The attainer attains of itself, thus attainment incurs no gratitude—this is how heaven is completed.
**Subcommentary:** *Yuan* means "origin." The ruler of men and things must take virtue as its foundation. Each thing attains itself, thus fully realizing the nature of spontaneity. Hence it is said: "The ancient rulers of the world in the distant past governed without action, possessing only the virtue of heaven."

**Annotation:** Following the spontaneous movement of nature.
**Subcommentary:** *Xuan* means "distant." The ancient rulers refer to the emperors before the Three Sovereigns. It is said that the sage rulers of antiquity governed the world without action—what did they do? This cites the ancients to verify the present, establishing the meaning of heavenly virtue.

Viewing through the Dao in speech, the rulers of the world are upright.
**Annotation:** The non-active naturally become rulers, not through perversity.
**Subcommentary:** Observing the principle of emptiness and penetration in the workings of response to things, the ruler who acts without action and follows without contrivance does not employ perverse speech, thus rightly attaining the kingly way.

Viewing through the Dao in division, the righteousness of ruler and minister is clear.
**Annotation:** Each abiding in its proper place, the non-active occupy the superior position, the active the inferior.
**Subcommentary:** The way of the ruler is non-action, while the way of the minister involves affairs. Noble and base, labor and ease—by principle, they are inherently distinct. For example, the head naturally resides above, the feet below. Observing through the Dao, the righteousness of their division is evident.

Viewing through the Dao in ability, the offices of the world are well-governed.
**Annotation:** Each office is well-governed according to its ability.
**Subcommentary:** Though offices vary in rank and abilities in excellence, when each receives its proper duty, things are impartially attained. Thus the offices of the world are well-governed.

Viewing through the Dao in generality, the responses of the myriad things are complete.
**Annotation:** Without action, the world responds to each through its own non-action.
**Subcommentary:** The great Dao generates things, whose natures and dispositions differ. Following their own inclinations, all are fully equipped—some run, some fly, each responding to its use, unaware of how, nor where the mind is applied. Thus observing through principle in its entirety, the responses of the myriad things are complete.

Therefore, that which penetrates heaven and earth is virtue.
**Annotation:** When nothing fails to attain, heaven and earth are penetrated.
**Subcommentary:** *Tong* means "to unite." That which unites with the covering and bearing of the Two Modes, co-arising with heaven and earth, is virtue.

That which moves through the myriad things is the Dao.
**Annotation:** When the Dao does not obstruct its course, the myriad things naturally attain their movement.
**Subcommentary:** The ultimate principle is unobstructed, allowing things to come and go freely. Moving together with the myriad things, it is called the Dao.

That which governs people above is affairs.
**Annotation:** Allowing each person to attain their own affairs.
**Subcommentary:** Though governing people, one follows their fundamental nature. Each thing follows its ability, and power naturally accords with fitness. Each affair is fitting, and the world is well-governed.

That which possesses skill is technique.
**Annotation:** Technique is what the myriad things do not employ.
**Subcommentary:** Following their fundamental nature, each has its own skill and ability, not relying on external fabrication—thus true technique flourishes.

Technique is encompassed by affairs, affairs by righteousness, righteousness by virtue, virtue by the Dao, the Dao by heaven.
**Annotation:** The mutual encompassing of root and branch is like the mutual enfolding of hand and arm. Thus when the body is harmonious, all joints are at ease; when the heavenly Dao is followed, root and branch are both unimpeded.
**Subcommentary:** *Jian* means "to carry," "to aid," "to return." The skills of technique must be carried by affairs. Without being carried by affairs, where would technique be applied? If affairs are improper, technique becomes useless. Though proceeding through righteousness, it must not deviate from virtue. Though possessing this virtue, in principle it must model itself on the emptiness and penetration of the Dao. Thus it is said: emptiness and penetration ultimately return to the flourishing of spontaneity. This is the mutual enfolding of principle and affair, though their functions differ. Hence it demonstrates the meaning of the root embracing the branch, proceeding from the shallow to the profound.

Thus it is said: "The ancients who nurtured the world had no desires, and the world was sufficient; they acted without action, and the myriad things were transformed."
**Subcommentary:** To embrace the world is to act without action; to embrace the Dao is to be without desire. Thus the ancient emperors who nurtured and reared the multitudes—what did they do? They had no desires, and the black-haired people were each sufficient; they acted without action, and the myriad things transformed themselves.

Profoundly still, the hundred clans were settled.
**Subcommentary:** One person hangs his robe and remains in profound silence, and the hundred clans are such that every household could be enfeoffed. Thus the *Laozi* says: "I value stillness, and the people rectify themselves." The *Records* state: "Penetrate the One, and the myriad affairs are complete."

**Subcommentary:** The One is the Dao. Affairs arise from principle, and principle must encompass affairs. The root can embrace the branch, thus knowing the One, the myriad affairs are complete. This saying appears in the *Scripture of Western Ascent*, and Zhuangzi cites it as evidence.

Without intent, one attains—and ghosts and spirits submit.

**Annotation:** Acting without action, all principles naturally align.

**Subcommentary:** When one delves into the affairs of the undifferentiated human realm, verifying the principle of spontaneity through the mind, plumbing origins and penetrating boundaries, and mastering the subtlety of profound mystery—then, in the manifest, all beings turn toward them, and in the hidden, even ghosts and spirits submit. The Master said: "The Dao—it covers and sustains the myriad things, vast and boundless! How great!" The noble person cannot but purge the heart.

**Annotation:** With intent, one burdens spontaneity; thus, one must excise and remove it.

**Subcommentary:** The Master here is Laozi. Zhuangzi took Laozi as his teacher, hence he is called "the Master." *Zhi* means to remove, to cleanse. The Dao of emptiness and penetration encompasses all without exclusion. The Two Modes depend on it for covering and sustaining, and the myriad things obtain it to transform and live. What does not proceed from this? It is the root of all things. Marveling at its vast and boundless greatness, he exhorts the lords of the age: should they not model themselves on the Dao’s nothingness, washing away the burden of intent?

Acting without acting is called Heaven.

**Annotation:** Not acting for this act, yet this act acts itself—this is the Heavenly Dao.

**Subcommentary:** "Acting without acting" means moving in accord with one’s nature. The mechanism of Heaven unfolds of itself, hence it is called Heaven. This is "not acting for this act."

Speaking without speaking is called virtue.

**Annotation:** Not speaking for this speech, yet this speech speaks itself—this is true virtue.

**Subcommentary:** Silent and wordless, yet responding without limit—like a mirror hung high in the hall, things come and are reflected. Speech and silence are no different, hence it is called virtue. This is "not speaking for this speech."

Loving people and benefiting things is called benevolence.

**Annotation:** This is following the natural dispositions of life and destiny.

**Subcommentary:** Compassion flows like clouds, love showers like rain. Without partiality in the heart, virtue’s blessings spread far and wide. Cherishing life and destiny, this is called benevolence.

Not forcing sameness upon differences is called greatness.

**Annotation:** The myriad things take myriad forms, each right in its place. Not drawing others to be the same as oneself—this is what makes one great.

**Subcommentary:** Carving and sculpting the multitude of forms, each with its distinct nature—following their inherent allotment, merging with spontaneity, acting without cutting or dividing—this is called greatness.

Acting without eccentricity is called magnanimity.

**Annotation:** Mysteriously identifying with others, the myriad things naturally find room, hence there is abundance.

**Subcommentary:** Concealing brilliance and obscuring traces, blending with the world and riding its waves—if one’s virtue is no different from others, and one’s conduct no different from things, yet the heart has no boundaries, like a lake of ten thousand acres, where forests and marshes teem with life—this may be called magnanimity.

Possessing ten thousand differences is called wealth.

**Annotation:** Without difference from myself, I alone can possess these ten thousand.

**Subcommentary:** Occupying the position of the Nine-Fives, wielding the might of ten thousand chariots, embracing the myriad things in their differences, following the people in their diversity, allowing all natures to find their place—thus one can be rich in possessing all under Heaven.

Thus, holding fast to virtue is called the guiding principle.

**Annotation:** Virtue is the guiding thread of human beings.

**Subcommentary:** One who can uphold their inherent virtue may be called the guiding thread of things.

Virtue’s completion is called establishment.

**Annotation:** What is not completed through virtue cannot be called establishment.

**Subcommentary:** Only when virtue is complete can one establish merit and aid others.

Following the Dao is called fulfillment.

**Annotation:** The Dao is not partial to any one thing.

**Subcommentary:** *Xun* means to follow. Only by following emptiness and penetration is one’s virtue fully sufficient.

Not allowing things to thwart one’s resolve is called wholeness.

**Annotation:** Inner self-possession.

**Subcommentary:** *Cuo* means to bend. Undisturbed by praise or blame, unmoved by glory or disgrace, not allowing worldly things to bend one’s integrity—such virtue is complete.

When the noble person is enlightened regarding these ten, then their mind is vast in its capacity for affairs.

**Annotation:** With a vast mind, no affair is unaccommodated.

**Subcommentary:** *Tao* means to encompass. When the noble person, in praising others, freely applies these ten principles to themselves, they can embrace all affairs, and their mind and nature become magnanimous.

Their virtue flows abundantly, and the myriad things come to them.

**Annotation:** Virtue’s blessings overflow, allowing the myriad things to go their own way.

**Subcommentary:** *Shi* means to go. With a mind and nature at ease, virtue’s blessings overflow, hence all living beings turn toward them.

Thus, one hides gold in the mountains and pearls in the depths.

**Annotation:** Not valuing rare and precious things.

**Subcommentary:** Acting as described above is acting without action. Not coveting glory and splendor, one does not prize treasures or goods. Thus, pearls born in water need not be sought, for they are naturally stored in the depths; gold issuing from mountains need not be pursued, for it is naturally concealed in the peaks.

One does not profit from goods or wealth.

**Annotation:** One can forget the self—how much more, then, goods and wealth?

**Subcommentary:** Though one may obtain pearls and jade, one does not consume them to sustain the body. How much less would one use goods and wealth for profit?

One does not draw near to nobility or riches.

**Annotation:** They come and go as guests; the heart always keeps them at a distance.

**Subcommentary:** Coming and going as guests, neither grieving nor rejoicing, one externally distances oneself from high rank and chariots, and internally does not draw near to wealth and nobility.

One does not delight in long life, nor grieve over early death.

**Annotation:** This is what is called "suspended liberation."

**Subcommentary:** Even if one’s years are long, one does not take joy in it; if one’s life is cut short, one does not grieve. One does not glory in success, nor feel shame in poverty.

**Annotation:** Forgetting life and death in the heart—how much more, then, the space between poverty and success?

**Subcommentary:** Wealth, nobility, glory, and success—one does not take them as glory. Lowliness, poverty, obstruction, and blockage—one does not take them as shame. Neither long life nor early death ever occupy one’s thoughts; how could the feelings of glory and shame find a place in the heart?

One does not confine the world’s benefits to one’s private share.

**Annotation:** All is entrusted to the myriad things.

**Subcommentary:** Illuminating the cosmos, governing all under Heaven, with the treasures of the Four Seas all under one’s sway—yet one does not profit from goods or wealth, entrusting them to the myriad states. How could one confine them for private use?

He does not take ruling all under Heaven as his own exalted position.

**Annotation:** Suddenly, one is unaware of glory residing in oneself.

**Subcommentary:** Encompassing all the black-haired people, governing all under Heaven, yet one attributes merit to things, forgetting one’s own wealth and nobility—thus one does not take oneself as great and exalted. Exalted means manifest.

**Annotation:** If not exalted, then silent and still.

**Subcommentary:** Manifest means to make evident. Though seated in Fen-yang, having lost all under Heaven, still one’s wisdom shines forth—how could one say it is concealed light? The myriad things are a single treasury; death and life share the same form.

**Annotation:** Like a cicada’s molting, nowhere to be found.

**Subcommentary:** Forgetting self and others, thus the myriad things may be as one treasury; obscured to transformation, thus death and life share the same form. If death and life bring no change to oneself, how much less the space between poverty and success?

The Master said: The Dao—profound is its abode, floating is its purity.

**Subcommentary:** The utmost principle is profoundly mysterious, like the abyss of the sea; limpid and pure, it illumines even the temples and brows. Profound, one sighs at its abode’s stillness and deep clarity; floating, one sighs that though in motion, it remains unsullied. Originally, this also wrote the character for "lord."

Metal and stone cannot sound without being struck.

**Annotation:** Sound arises from stillness.

**Subcommentary:** Sound arises from stillness; response arises from the real. Thus metal and stone have voices, but if not struck, they do not sound.

**Annotation:** This is used to illustrate that one who embodies the Dao responds only after things move.

**Subcommentary:** *Kao-gong* means to strike. Within metal and stone, the notes of the *gong* and *shang* scales lie dormant; if not struck, they will never produce sound. Likewise, the heart of the perfected person truly holds sagely virtue, yet if things do not move it, there is no way for response to appear. Earlier, the abyss of water was invoked to clarify the utmost Dao; here, metal and stone are used to reveal the sagely heart. Which among the myriad things can fix it?

**Annotation:** Response and stimulus have no fixed direction.

**Subcommentary:** It is like a bright mirror or an empty valley: things come, and it responds, responding yet without intent. Since things are endless in their long and short, responses are likewise boundless in their square and round. The person of royal virtue, holding fast to simplicity, feels shame at becoming entangled in affairs.

**Annotation:** One follows simplicity and moves on—it is not that one delights in becoming entangled in affairs.

**Subcommentary:** *Su* means real; *shi* means to go. The royal one, neither arrogant nor self-important, follows the real and moves on. Embracing simplicity in lofty purity, one feels shame at becoming entangled in worldly affairs. One establishes the root and origin, and knows how to penetrate the divine.

**Annotation:** With the root established, one knows not to go against it.

**Subcommentary:** The divine is the unfathomable function. Always abiding in principle, one moves and responds to things. The unfathomable divine knows how to penetrate things—this wondrous function must rely on the root. This is to show that the root can give rise to function, and function does not depart from the root’s meaning. Thus one’s virtue is vast.

**Annotation:** Following simplicity to penetrate the divine, only then does it become boundless.

**Subcommentary:** To be pure and without action, to follow the real and move on, to know the divine and penetrate things, yet always establish the root and origin—function does not depart from substance, movement does not harm stillness. With virtue like this, how could one not be the greatest and most central? When one’s heart issues forth, things seek it out.

**Annotation:** Things seek it out, and only then does it issue forth—not that it precedes things in singing.

**Subcommentary:** To seek is to request. The utmost sage, empty of self, responds to things and the self; if things do not seek sagely virtue, there is no way for the sagely heart to issue forth. The issuing of the sagely heart truly comes from things seeking it. One desires harmony yet does not sing, does not precede things. Thus form does not arise without the Dao; life does not become manifest without virtue.

**Subcommentary:** Form is the seven-foot body; life is the hundred-year span; virtue is the power of clarity and wisdom; the Dao is the realm that can be penetrated. The Dao can penetrate and give life to the myriad things, thus without the Dao there is no life; virtue can illumine the root of principle, thus without virtue there is no manifestation. The *Laozi* says: "The Dao gives birth to them, virtue rears them." To preserve form and exhaust life, to establish virtue and illumine the Dao—is this not the royal virtue?

**Subcommentary:** *Cun* means to follow; *qiong* means to exhaust. To follow the beauty or ugliness of form, to exhaust the long or short of life, to establish great virtue to guide the times, to use the utmost Dao to penetrate things—who but the royal virtue can do this? Vast and boundless, suddenly it issues forth, suddenly it moves, and the myriad things follow it. This is called the person of royal virtue.

**Annotation:** *Hu* and *bo* both describe the manner of responding without intent. Movement and issuing forth are without intent, thus the myriad things follow—this is the vast and boundless. Thus one can preserve form and exhaust life, establish virtue and illumine the Dao, and so become the royal virtue.

**Subcommentary:** *Dangdang* is the name for broad and level. *Hu* and *bo* describe the manner of being without intent. Moved by things, it issues forth in accord with the moment, following and yielding to things—thus things follow it. Possessing all excellences, it is called the royal virtue. Gazing into the darkness, listening to the silent. The utmost Dao is profoundly mysterious, the sagely heart is congealed and still—without form, it cannot be seen by the eyes; without sound, it cannot be heard by the ears. Within the darkness, one alone sees the dawn; within the silence, one alone hears the harmony.

**Annotation:** As for seeing and hearing, if one does not entrust them to stillness, then there will be convergence and obscurity, not harmony.

**Subcommentary:** Though the darkness is without form, it can shape the myriad images; though the silence is without sound, it can harmonize the eight tones. This is to clarify that from substance arises function, and such is its power. Thus the deeper it is, the deeper it can give form to things.

**Annotation:** Only by exhausting the source can one give form to things.

**Subcommentary:** Neither being nor non-being, neither stillness nor response—dispelling again and again, thus the deeper it is, the deeper. Having exhausted principle and fully realized nature, thus one can give form to the myriad things. The more divine it is, the more divine, and thus it can be refined.

**Annotation:** Only by reaching the utmost compliance can one fully realize the wondrous.

**Subcommentary:** "Spirit" is the name for the unfathomable. Response and stillness are mutually entailed; being and non-being are thoroughly penetrated. Yet it is neither fathomable nor unfathomable, nor even "not unfathomable"—such is the subtlety of spirit. Thus, in its interaction with the myriad things, it is utterly formless yet fulfills all demands.

**Annotation:** When I am thus steadfast and wholly yield to them, their demands are met of themselves.

**Subcommentary:** Dispelling again and again, this is called "utter formlessness." In engaging with things, it has no fixed method; adapting to conditions, it accords with what is fitting. Though the ten thousand kinds differ in a thousand ways, whatever is sought is supplied—like a mirror hung high in the hall, reflecting whatever comes before it. At times it gallops forth to meet their long-standing, great or small, long or short, distant or near needs.

**Annotation:** All are indulged and allowed free rein, converging only at their utmost limit.

**Subcommentary:** Gallop means to release; *su* means to converge. Only by embodying utter formlessness can it adapt to demands as they arise. Thus it can follow the times, respond to things in manifold ways, and converge without clinging to any one path. Whether great or small, now short, now long, even to the distant—whatever comes, it meets the needs of each condition, supplying what is sought. Like prescribing medicine for illness, its principle is never amiss.

The Yellow Emperor roamed north of the Red Water, ascended the Kunlun heights, and gazed south. Upon returning, he lost his dark pearl.

**Annotation:** This illustrates the means by which the true is attained.

**Subcommentary:** Red is the color of the south, and the heart is the viscera of the south. Water’s nature is to flow, and its position is in the north. This is like a deluded heart and a tarnished mirror, which together reflect nothing—hence "north of the Red Water." Kunlun is the body; south is the direction of brightness; *wang* means to observe; *xuan* denotes what is remote; and the pearl is a precious treasure. This shows that the world’s myriad beings, without exception, are deluded in body and mind. Racing and indulging in desires, they lack all awareness—akin to the north, flowing like water, losing the true and forfeiting the Way. This is the reason. Now, to return to the root and restore the source, to analyze the true and seek the Way, one gazes south to demonstrate discernment, and "returns" to signify the recovery of destiny. Thus, the text first clarifies where the true is lost, then reveals the means to attain the Way. The method it illustrates is set forth below.

It is such that when one seeks it, one cannot obtain it.

**Annotation:** This means that the use of knowledge is insufficient to attain the true.

**Subcommentary:** *Suo* means to seek. Thus, one must sever thought and cannot seek with the heart.

Even Li Zhu could not obtain it by seeking.

**Subcommentary:** It is not form, so it cannot be grasped by the eye.

Nor could Chi Gou obtain it by seeking.

**Annotation:** Though keen of hearing and sharp of speech, the more one relies on them, the farther one strays from the true.

**Subcommentary:** Chi Gou refers to eloquence. It cannot be sought through words.

Only Xiangwang obtained it.

**Subcommentary:** *Wangxiang* means "without heart." Abandoning sound and form, severing thought, wisdom and Li Zhu turn back in exhaustion, while Chi Gou’s eloquence, exerting effort, loses the true. Only Xiangwang, being without heart, alone attains the dark pearl.

The Yellow Emperor said: How extraordinary! Could Xiangwang truly obtain it?

**Annotation:** This clarifies that attaining the true does not rely on the use of the heart. Being like Xiangwang is to be the true itself.

**Subcommentary:** Li Lou lost his nature by relying on his keen eyesight and thus forfeited the Way. The Yellow Emperor, awakening to principle, marveled that Xiangwang obtained the pearl. Exhorting his disciples, he showed that one need not depart from form or abandon wisdom, but only dim one’s hearing and rest in the body.

Yao’s teacher was Xu You; Xu You’s teacher was Nie Que; Nie Que’s teacher was Wang Ni; and Wang Ni’s teacher was Pi Yi.

**Subcommentary:** The four men above were all recluses of Yao’s time. Disgusted by the world’s filth, they embraced the Way and held to virtue, keeping themselves pure and unsullied, refusing to partake in worldly affairs. Yao, knowing their worth, wished to yield the throne to them. Zhuangzi demonstrated their succession, thus listing their teacher-student lineage.

Yao asked Xu You: Could Nie Que be fit to match Heaven?

**Annotation:** That is, to be the Son of Heaven.

I would rely on Wang Ni to summon him.

**Annotation:** He wished to use his teacher to summon and employ him.

**Subcommentary:** *Pei* means to match; *jie* means to rely on. Yao said: Nie Que’s worthiness is such that his virtue matches Heaven’s position. Perhaps by relying on Wang Ni, he could be persuaded to take the throne. The circumstances were out of order, so he asked Xu You.

Xu You said: How perilous it would be to endanger the world by employing Nie Que!

**Annotation:** *Ji* means peril.

**Subcommentary:** *Dai* means near; *ji* means peril. If one were to summon Nie Que to yield the realm of ten thousand chariots, the signs of peril and ruin would not be far off. Nie Que’s nature is such that his intelligence and acuity surpass others.

**Annotation:** Being overly intelligent and quick surpasses others, which would lead people to tread upon him, repeatedly harming the people.

**Subcommentary:** *Huan* means sagacity; *gei* means agility; *min* means swiftness. The sage who governs the world wears a cap with pendants that hang before his eyes and cords that plug his ears, thereby blocking keen perception and avoiding excessive hearing and seeing. Yet Nie Que inwardly harbors sagacity and intelligence, outwardly dazzles with keen perception, wields a sharp tongue, and excels in calculation. His virtue, conduct, and nature surpass others; his reputation is already manifest, and thus he would surely be harmed. The signs of peril and ruin are listed below.

Moreover, he would use man to match Heaven.

**Annotation:** Employing knowledge to seek to restore its natural state.

**Subcommentary:** The loss of the true in things has endured for a long time. Using the devices of the heart and mind to restore their original state thus strays far from natural nature.

He is keen to prohibit transgressions yet does not know whence transgressions arise.

**Annotation:** Transgressions arise from keen intelligence, yet he would employ intelligence to prohibit them—his transgressions would only grow worse. Thus it is said: There is no transgression in eliminating knowledge; it does not lie in forced prohibition.

**Subcommentary:** The source from which transgressions arise is knowledge.

Qiè Qué merely knows to scrutinize and prohibit the transgressions of the common people, yet does not understand that the cessation of transgressions arises from the elimination of knowledge. Could one thus match him with Heaven?

He would ride upon man and be without Heaven.
**Annotation:** If one were to entrust him with the world, he would only lead later generations to employ knowledge and lose the true.
**Subcommentary:** If granted the throne to govern the people, he would wield the mechanisms of the heart and mind, delighting in heavenly principles, causing all things to lose their inherent nature and no longer possess their natural state.

He would take his own body as the root and make forms different.
**Annotation:** If one takes the myriad things as the root, then transformations may be unified and differing forms may be made the same.
**Subcommentary:** He would act thus: Qiè Qué, taking his own body as the root, would draw things to himself, compelling the world’s diverse forms to follow his transformations. The loss of things’ inherent nature would stem from this, and the calamities of later generations would begin here.

He would exalt knowledge and race like fire.
**Annotation:** When the worthy occupy positions of precedence, knowledge and perception are exalted thereafter, and the pursuit of gain races like fire.
**Subcommentary:** Unable to forget knowledge and entrust things to their own course, he would exalt knowledge to govern the world, thereby fostering competition, emulating others, and racing in pursuit—swift as fire.

He would become the initiator of toil.
**Annotation:** He would open the path for the affairs and labors of later generations.
**Subcommentary:** *Xù* means "beginning"; *shǐ* means "toil." Unable to practice non-action and instead employing knowledge to govern things, the toil of later generations would originate from this.

He would become the shackle of things.
**Annotation:** He would thereby cause later generations to be constrained and controlled by things.
**Subcommentary:** *Ài* means "to hinder." Unable to employ the Dao to harmonize people, he would instead rely on knowledge to shackle things.

He would look in all four directions and have things respond.
**Annotation:** He would thereby cause later generations to command and move things, making them respond to his demands.
**Subcommentary:** He would look in all four directions, pacifying the myriad states, causing the common people to respond to his transformative laws.

He would respond to the needs of the multitude.
**Annotation:** He would thereby cause later generations to be unable to forget goodness, employing benevolence and righteousness to meet needs.
**Subcommentary:** Using his own knowledge to respond to the needs of the multitude, lacking a mind of non-action, he would not escape peril.

He would transform along with things.
**Annotation:** He would thereby cause later generations to chase after things and be unable to attain inner self-realization.
**Subcommentary:** He would apply his own knowledge to the multitude of things, compelling them to follow his transformations. Having lost their inherent nature, neither things nor he himself would attain it.

And he would never attain constancy.
**Annotation:** All these are expedient measures for the moment, yet today one receives their benefits, while tomorrow one bears their harms. Thus it is said: he would never attain constancy.
**Subcommentary:** Governing things with knowledge, policies issue from many sources. One may bear their benefits first, only to suffer their harms later. Having departed from the simplicity of antiquity, there is no constancy.

How could he be worthy to match Heaven?

Yet though this be so, he has his kind and his forebears.
**Annotation:** His deeds may be traced to forebears and emulated.
**Subcommentary:** *Zú* means "gathering place." Qiè Qué dwells in seclusion among the mountains, upholding lofty aspirations. Unable to blend with the world, he is unfit to match Heaven. Yet among the common people, his kind is rare. Thus his aspirations and purity may indeed be emulated.

He may serve as the father of the multitude, but he cannot serve as the father of fathers.
**Annotation:** The father of fathers is he who transmits the legacy.
**Subcommentary:** *Fù* means "ruler." Qiè Qué, lofty and non-active, does not level himself with the common. Though his Dao may be followed, he is fit only to be the father of the multitude, not the father of fathers. The father of fathers is Yao. Yao sat enthroned above the myriad things, yet his heart roamed to Mount Gūyè, where he visited the Four Masters in the land of Fényáng. Thus, in stillness he acted, in action he was still; non-action became action, action became non-action. Being and non-being were simultaneous, movement and stillness were one. Therefore, he could be the ruler among rulers, the father among fathers. He was one who exhausted principle and fulfilled nature, entering ever deeper into the mysterious, and thus was the father of all living beings. As Guo’s annotation says: "The father of fathers is he who advances."

Order and chaos alike take him as their leader.
**Annotation:** He is not merely the lord of order, but also the leader of chaos.
**Subcommentary:** *Shuài* means "leader." If one employs knowledge to govern things, though order may prevail at the time, chaos will follow. Both paths take knowledge as their leader.

He is the calamity of those who face north.
**Annotation:** Jie and Zhou were not themselves able to kill worthy ministers; they relied on the path of sagely knowledge to bring them to ruin.
**Subcommentary:** Jie and Zhou relied on sagely knowledge to kill worthy ministers; thus, sagely knowledge is the calamity of those who face north.

He is the thief of those who face south.
**Annotation:** Tian Heng was not himself able to kill his lord; he relied on benevolence and righteousness to steal his throne.
**Subcommentary:** Tian Chang relied on benevolence and righteousness to kill his lord; thus, benevolence and righteousness are the thieves of those who face south. The annotation states: "Tian Chang was not himself able to kill his lord; he relied on benevolence and righteousness to steal his throne."

Yao observed Hua. The border guard of Hua said: "Ah! Sage! I pray to bless the sage." He wished the sage long life. Yao declined. He wished the sage wealth. Yao declined. He wished the sage many sons. Yao declined.
**Subcommentary:** Wealth, longevity, and many sons are indeed burdensome entanglements, yet one who embodies them may abandon non-action. Thus, by alluding to these two men, he clarifies these three refusals.

The purport of refusal and yielding is expounded below.

The border guard said: "Longevity, wealth, and many sons—these are what all men desire. Why do you alone not desire them?"

**Subcommentary:** The three things mentioned earlier are the greatest desires of men. Why do you alone refuse them? What is your meaning?

Yao said: "Many sons bring many fears; wealth brings many affairs; longevity brings many humiliations. These three are not what nurture virtue, so I refuse them."

**Subcommentary:** When sons are numerous, worries and fears multiply; when wealth abounds, affairs become burdensome; when life is long, humiliations accumulate. These three do not nourish the virtue of non-action but only increase the entanglements of action, so I refuse them all.

The border guard said: "At first, I took you for a sage, but now you are merely a gentleman."

**Subcommentary:** I thought you possessed unparalleled illumination and embodied the Dao as a sage, but now, having abandoned the pursuit of such things, you are only a worthy gentleman.

"Heaven generates the myriad people and must assign them duties. If you have many sons and assign them duties, what fear is there?"

**Annotation:** All things find their proper place, and their wills are settled.

**Subcommentary:** Heaven and Earth create all things, each with its own abilities. When offices are assigned according to talent, what cause for fear is there?

"If you are wealthy and distribute it among others, what affairs remain?"

**Annotation:** Entrust it to all under Heaven, and there are no affairs.

**Subcommentary:** When the people are prosperous and the Four Seas are abundant, entrusting wealth to all without claiming it as private, affairs become non-action.

"The sage dwells like a quail,

**Annotation:** Without intention, he awaits tranquility.

and eats like a fledgling,

**Annotation:** He relies on things to be sufficient.

**Subcommentary:** The quail is a bird that dwells in the wild without fixed abode. The fledgling, a young crow, is fed by its mother and thus has enough. The sage’s dwelling is simple, like the quail’s; his sustenance is modest, like the fledgling’s. Having no heart for extravagance, how could he have a taste for rich flavors?

"He moves like a bird, leaving no trace.

**Annotation:** He follows his nature in movement, not advancing by force.

**Subcommentary:** *Zhāng* means patterned tracks. The sage extinguishes his heart and erases his knowledge, merging with things in obscurity, like a bird in flight—visible yet leaving no trace.

When the world follows the Dao, all things flourish with him.

**Annotation:** He wanders wildly and recklessly, yet naturally treads the great path.

**Subcommentary:** When the age is governed by clarity, he rules over the multitudes; when things come to him, he responds, and all flourishes in due time. Guo’s annotation speaks of "wandering wildly and recklessly," but this seems contrary to the text’s meaning.

When the world loses the Dao, he cultivates virtue and retreats into seclusion.

**Annotation:** Even the affairs of Tang and Wu, if they accord with Heaven and respond to the people, are not without their proper place. Thus, "non-action yet nothing left undone" does not mean inaction.

**Subcommentary:** *Xián* (seclusion) is pronounced like *xián* (leisure). In times of chaos, he blends with the common and conceals his brilliance, cultivating virtue in obscurity to preserve his life’s Dao, dwelling in leisure and wandering in reclusion. This is what is meant by "adapting to presence or absence, acting or resting as the time demands."

After a thousand years, he wearies of the world and departs to become an immortal above.

**Annotation:** The utmost person exhausts the length of life and masters the transformations of principle. In life, he follows Heaven’s course; in death, he becomes one with things. Thus, it is said he wearies of the world and ascends as an immortal.

**Subcommentary:** The sage comprehends the non-duality of life and death and the unity of transformation. Thus, he fulfills the span of his years, whether long or short, and wearies of the world’s clamor to ascend in dissolution. Why single out the ascent at Mount Dinghu as the only path to immortality? The longevity of Anqi is said to span a thousand years.

He rides the white clouds to reach the Emperor’s realm.

**Annotation:** When qi disperses, there is nowhere it does not go.

**Subcommentary:** His spirit ascends, merging with the Great One, riding clouds and mounting qi to arrive at the realm of the Heavenly Emperor.

The three afflictions do not reach him, and his person remains free from misfortune. What humiliation could there be?

**Subcommentary:** The three afflictions are the earlier mentioned wealth, longevity, and many sons. Riding the Creator and coming and going, mounting transformation and wandering freely, the three afflictions are fundamentally empty, and the seven-foot body arises from non-being. What misfortune or humiliation could there be?

The border guard departed. Yao followed him, saying: "I beg to ask."

**Subcommentary:** Having heard enough, the border guard then left. Yao, now awakened to his error, sought an answer.

The border guard said: "Withdraw."

**Subcommentary:** Your doubts are resolved; you should quickly withdraw.

Yao governed the world, and Bo Cheng Zi Gao was established as a feudal lord. When Yao abdicated to Shun, and Shun to Yu, Bo Cheng Zi Gao resigned his lordship to farm.

**Subcommentary:** Bo Cheng Zi Gao—it is not known from where he came, but he was likely a man of the Dao. Yu went to see him, finding him plowing in the fields. Yu hastened to the downwind side, stood, and asked: "In the past, when Yao governed the world, you were established as a feudal lord. When Yao abdicated to Shun, and Shun to me, you resigned your lordship to farm. I venture to ask: what is the reason?"

**Subcommentary:** In the age of Yao and Shun, the throne was transmitted to the worthy; yet in the Xia dynasty, he retreated to farm in the wild. His conduct diverged so sharply—what was his intention?

Bo Cheng Zi Gao said: "In the past, when Yao governed the world, he did not reward, yet the people were encouraged; he did not punish, yet the people were in awe."

**Subcommentary:** Rewards and punishments are meant to manifest encouragement and awe. Yet Yao governed through non-action, and all things followed his transformation. Thus, the people did not wait for his commendation to exert themselves in goodness, nor did they require punishment to fear doing evil. This reveals his sagely illumination and virtue.

When you now reward and punish, the people lack benevolence. Virtue has thus declined, punishments have thus been established, and the chaos of later ages begins here.

**Subcommentary:** Even with rewards and punishments in full force, the people still lack benevolence. With the highest virtue in decline, penal laws proliferate. Thus, the chaos of future ages begins here.

Should you, Master, not depart? Let not my work be abandoned. He plowed steadily, heedless of all else.

**Annotation:** In the time of Yu, the Three Sages succeeded one another, their governance perfected and virtue complete. Yet as their achievements and beauty gradually receded, historical records left no trace, and even Confucius could not inquire into them. Thus, though Yu held the world, he did not partake in it—this was having yet not having. Examining the era, Yu was the most excellent; assessing the men, though three sages, they were as one with Yao. With no sage in the age, the world’s heart swiftly turned to Qi. Yet he who embodies perfect impartiality and occupies the right moment entrusts the world to the people, taking and giving without attachment. Thus, he does not seek what is lost nor refuse what is gained, but comes and goes with serene indifference. For this, he is neither praised by the upright nor blamed by the critical, and his name ranks among the Three Kings—no wonder. Zhuangzi uses this to reveal Yao’s flaws, for the flaw began with Yao and the breach was completed by Yu. How much worse for later ages without sages? He entrusts this distant account to Zigao, urging him to abandon governance, seeking to abolish sageliness and return to unity, to discard knowledge and attain tranquility. Yet in truth, this was never heard.

Zhuangzi’s words cannot be confined to a single interpretation. Some trace the Yellow Emperor’s teachings to Yao and Shun’s classics—how could he alone exalt Yao and belittle Yu? Thus, one must set aside his allusions and grasp his intent to abolish sageliness and discard knowledge.

**Subcommentary:** Why do you not depart? *Luo* means to abandon. *Lǚlǚ* describes the appearance of plowing. Bocheng addressed Yu as "Master." "Master, why do you not leave?" "Do not abandon my farming." Thus, he plowed with all his strength, no longer glancing back.

The Three Sages succeeded one another, with no distinction in excellence; only the purity or turbidity of their ages differed, hence their achievements varied. Guo’s annotation—"the flaw began with Yao and the breach was completed by Yu"—aims to show that having sages is inferior to having none, and action is not equal to non-action. Thus, he advances a lofty argument to clarify the abolition of sageliness and the rejection of knowledge.

In the Great Beginning, there was non-being, and non-being had no name.

**Annotation:** There was no being, thus nothing to name.

**Subcommentary:** *Tai* means great; *chu* means beginning. When qi first stirred, it was called the Great Beginning, for its vastness made it the origin of all things. At the Great Beginning, there was only non-being, not yet being. With being not yet arisen, where could it reside? Thus, there was non-being and no name.

From the arising of the One, there was the One, yet no form.

**Annotation:** The One is the beginning of being, the most wondrous. Being most wondrous, it had no physical principle or form. The arising of the One arises from the utmost One, not from non-being. Yet why does Zhuangzi repeatedly speak of non-being at the beginning? The beginning is that which has not yet been born but attains birth—the difficulty of attaining birth. Yet it neither relies on non-being above nor depends on knowledge below, but suddenly and spontaneously attains this birth. Why then strive for life after birth and lose its natural birth?

**Subcommentary:** The One corresponds to the Dao, having the name of the One but not the appearance of the myriad things. When things attain it to be born, it is called virtue.

**Annotation:** Non-being cannot generate things. To say "things attain it to be born" is to clarify that things are born of their own attainment. Allowing their self-attainment is what may be called virtue.

**Subcommentary:** Virtue means attainment, referring to this attainment. When things attain birth, they do not rely on externals nor depend on the self; neither non-being nor being, neither self nor other, they do not know how they are born—thus it is called virtue.

Before form, there were distinctions, and this was so without inquiry—this is called destiny.

**Subcommentary:** Though form had not yet taken shape, the essence to receive form already existed. Yet this essence’s length or brevity was without gap or inquiry—thus it is called destiny.

Stillness and movement give birth to things. When things are completed and the principle of life is established, this is called form.

**Subcommentary:** Stillness is tranquility. Yang moves, yin is still; their ascent and descent intermingle, distributing across the Three Powers and transforming to give birth to the myriad things. When things are completed and the principle of life is fully established, this is called form.

When form embodies spirit, each has its proper pattern—this is called nature.

**Annotation:** Virtue, form, nature, and destiny are names established through change, yet in their self-so, they are one.

**Subcommentary:** *Ti* means substance; *bao* means to preserve. Having received form and substance, they preserve their spirit. Form may be ugly or beautiful, spirit may be foolish or wise. Yet each follows its proper pattern, all different. Once the essence is fixed, it does not change—thus it is called nature.

When nature is cultivated and returns to virtue, virtue reaches the same as the beginning.

**Annotation:** Always self-attaining without action.

**Subcommentary:** Following this endowed nature and returning to the virtue of life’s beginning, when virtue reaches this point, it is the same as the Great Beginning.

Sameness is emptiness; emptiness is greatness.

**Annotation:** If not the same as the beginning and midway employing action, then what is held within is still something. With something, the virtue of nurturing is diminished.

**Subcommentary:** Sameness with the Great Beginning makes the mind empty and vast. With the mind empty and open, it can embrace greatness.

Harmonizing with the cries of birds,

**Annotation:** Speaking without intention to speak, harmonizing with the cries of birds.

**Subcommentary:** *Hui* means bird. With the mind empty and open, it returns to the true thing. Thus, its words harmonize with the cries of birds. The cries of birds have no intention of right or wrong; how could the sage’s words have attachment to love or hate?

Harmonizing with the cries, it unites with heaven and earth.

**Annotation:** Heaven and earth also move without intention.

**Subcommentary:** Words harmonizing with the cries of birds, virtue also harmonizes with heaven and earth. Heaven and earth have no intention in their covering and supporting; the sage has no intention in his words—thus he unites with heaven and earth.

Its harmony is seamless, as if foolish, as if dull.

**Annotation:** It harmonizes by sitting in forgetfulness, not by deliberate examination.

**Subcommentary:** *Jin* means to unite. The sage inwardly accords with the highest principle, outwardly follows the constant course of life, ever merging with the root—utterly without discord. Thus it is called seamless. Blending with the world’s currents, moving with the dust of myriad things, he appears foolish and dull.

Another interpretation: Harmonizing with the cries of birds and with heaven and earth—this too is seamless.

This is called profound virtue, aligning with the Great Compliance.

**Annotation:** The virtue is profound, and that which it complies with is vast.

**Subcommentary:** Summing up the foregoing, it extols this flourishing excellence. Such a person may be said to possess the most profound virtue, thus aligning with the Great Beginning and complying with all under heaven.

Confucius asked Lao Dan: “There is one who governs the Way as if imitating others—affirming the unconfirmable, assenting to the unassentable.

**Annotation:** To imitate others by forcing the unconfirmable into confirmation, the unassentable into assent—this is to distort one’s nature and feelings.

**Subcommentary:** The master sought Lao Dan’s counsel on every matter. Speaking generally without precision, he said, “There is one.” In administering governance, he makes others emulate him, imposing his own standards upon things, causing them to lose their nature. Thus what he affirms, others may deny; what he assents to, others may dissent. And what others affirm or assent to may likewise differ for him.

A disputant once said: “Separating hardness and whiteness is like hanging them in the void.”

**Annotation:** This means it is lofty and manifest, easily seen.

**Subcommentary:** Hardness and whiteness refer to Gongsun Long’s *Discourse on the White Horse*. Kong Chuan and his followers rigidly upheld this doctrine, unmatched in their time. Now the disputant claims: “I can dissect the argument on hardness and whiteness, not entangling them, making the distinction as clear as the sun and moon suspended in the sky.” Thus Guo’s annotation says it is lofty and manifest, easily seen.

Can such a one be called a sage?

**Subcommentary:** This concludes the preceding question. Can such a person be considered a sage?

Lao Dan replied: “This is but a clerk exchanging skills, ensnaring the body, wearying the form, and exhausting the mind.

**Subcommentary:** *Xu* means mutual. Such a one exchanges and seizes with assertions and negations, binding himself with these skills, thus wearing out his body and alarming his mind. This answers the earlier question. Some texts write *zhi* (branch) instead of *ji* (skill), meaning that assertions and negations branch and diverge like leaves.

The hound trained to catch foxes grows anxious; the nimble monkey is brought down from the mountain forests.

**Annotation:** Both have lost their natural state.

**Subcommentary:** A *nuan ju* is a macaque. The hound that seizes foxes often suffers a broken neck in the hunt, and thus, no longer at ease, grows anxious. The monkey, dwelling in the mountains and roaming freely, is swift and agile—yet loses its natural abode. Some texts write *mao* (cat) instead of *li* (fox), referring to the bamboo rat.

I tell you what you cannot hear and speak of what you cannot utter. Of all things with heads and feet but without minds or ears, there are many.

**Annotation:** Heads and feet refer to beginnings and ends. Without minds or ears means they transform of themselves.

**Subcommentary:** *Ruò* and *ér* both mean “you.” Heads and feet signify beginnings and ends. The principle transcends speech, so it cannot be heard or spoken. Nor can it be known by the mind or heard by the ear—hence the phrase “without minds or ears.” All things with mechanisms but no true nature have beginnings and ends, thus they are many. None can be explained in words, nor fully grasped by the mind. Why then do you boast of the monkey’s skill or exalt distinctions as lofty as the sun and moon? If things imitate you, is this not excessive?

That which has form and that which is formless and shapeless—both cannot endure together.

**Annotation:** What has form is ever-changing and cannot coexist with the formless and shapeless.

Thus one who skillfully governs the Way does not cling to the old but follows the daily renewal of transformation.
