**Subcommentary:** That which has form is the body; the formless is the mind. You claim both mind and body endure, but in observing principle, I see they are entirely empty.

Its movement is rest; its death is life; its decline is rise. This is not its *suoyi*.

**Annotation:** Movement and rest, death and life, flourishing and decline, rise and fall—none have constancy. All arise naturally, not by any deliberate means. Thus, when released, they find their own accord.

**Subcommentary:** At times there is movement, at times rest; things die and are born; affairs rise and fall. These six states follow natural principle, yet their cause is unknown. How could they depend on human thought or imitative governance? Simply follow and comply—things will find their proper place.

Governance lies in the people,

**Annotation:** Not in the ruler’s self-assertion.

**Subcommentary:** Each person acts according to their nature, the heavenly mechanism unfolding of itself—not by the ruler’s instruction.

Forgetting things, forgetting heaven—this is called forgetting oneself.

**Annotation:** When things and heaven are both forgotten, what remains besides oneself?

**Subcommentary:** Not only are worldly affairs empty, but even heavenly principle is non-existent. When both affairs and principle are forgotten, one attains the ultimate of neither being nor non-being.

One who forgets oneself is said to enter into heaven.

**Annotation:** What one cannot forget is oneself. If even this is forgotten, what remains to be known? This is to be obscurely one with the natural.

**Subcommentary:** Entering means merging. The most difficult thing to forget is oneself, yet if even this can be forgotten, what in the world remains? Thus, when self and things are both forgotten, one merges obscurely with the Dao of nature.

Jiang Qiao Ao saw Ji Che and said: “The Lord of Lu said to Fan: ‘I beg to receive your instruction.’”

Refusing proved impossible, and having already imparted my counsel, I know not whether it strikes the mark—allow me to offer it for trial.

**Subcommentary:** *Offer* means to present. Jiang Qiao and Ji are surnames. Mian is Ji Che’s given name. These two worthies’ origins remain unknown, their records undetailed. The Lord of Lu refers to the Marquis of Lu, descendant of Bo Qin, though which duke is uncertain. When the Lord of Lu met Qiao, he requested instruction on governing the state. Though Qiao declined, he could not escape his lord’s command and thus expounded the Way of governance. At the time, leading the army, he feared his words might miss the mark and so dared to present what he had advised, testing it against the wisdom of the worthy. If the counsel proved unsuitable, he hoped for gentle correction.

I said to the Lord of Lu: “You must clothe yourself in reverence and frugality, promote those of public loyalty without partiality—then which of the people would dare not harmonize?”

**Subcommentary:** *Harmonize* is read as *gather*. *Partiality* means bias. *Which* means who. *Harmonize* means to unite. The Way of governance begins with embodying reverence and frugality, simplicity and restraint. Only then should one elevate those of impartial loyalty and upright integrity, selecting the worthy and dismissing the unfit to jointly govern the people. Thus, the borders will be secure, the realm tranquil, the people singing and striking the earth—who would dare not be at peace?

Ji Che laughed heartily and said: “If one follows your words, then in terms of the virtue of emperors and kings, it is like the mantis raising its arms in anger to block a chariot’s wheels—it will surely fail the task.”

**Annotation:** Clothing oneself in reverence and frugality is not frugality for frugality’s sake; promoting public loyalty is not loyalty for loyalty’s sake. Thus, though free of partiality, this is still insufficient to bear the burden of correcting deceit.

**Subcommentary:** *Heartily* describes the act of laughing while leaning forward. To be reverent and restrained, to promote public loyalty—these are all contrived sentiments, not the forgetfulness of the bland. To take such words as the virtue of one who faces south is no different from the mantis raising its arms to oppose a chariot’s wheels. Using the small to imitate the great, it cannot bear the task. Moreover, such an approach places oneself in peril, like an observation tower—

**Annotation:** All this is to place oneself on high, visible like a tower or terrace.

**Subcommentary:** Public frugality and public loyalty, being unable to forget the bland, merely serve to display oneself and dazzle the crowd. Once elevated to a precarious height, one will inevitably meet with ruin like a chariot’s collapse—just as a towering terrace, though visited by travelers, will not stand long. Many things will come—

**Annotation:** This is to compel things beyond their natural allotment, forcing them to multiply and attach themselves.

**Subcommentary:** The terrace stands high, and people compete to gaze upon it, their steps multiplying as they gather. The crowd rushes to its edges—

**Annotation:** Raising their feet to advance, they do not rest in their proper place.

**Subcommentary:** Dazzling things unsettles them, so they do not remain in their allotted place. Thus, many lift their feet to advance, standing on tiptoe.

Jiang Qiao, startled, said: “I am utterly confounded by your words.”

**Subcommentary:** *Startled* describes the appearance of shock. *Confounded* means to see nothing. Hearing such lofty discourse, he was suddenly alarmed, pondering without comprehension—hence his bewilderment.

“Nevertheless, I wish to hear the essence of your teaching.”

**Subcommentary:** *Teaching* means instruction. What I previously set forth was deeply contrary to principle. I wish to hear a single word that might serve as a model.

Ji Che said: “When the Great Sage governs the world, he sways the people’s hearts, shaping customs and transforming habits. He eradicates their harmful intentions and advances their solitary aspirations, as if by nature’s own doing, so that the people do not know why it is so.

**Annotation:** Each great aspiration has its own inclinations; they cannot be made uniform. Thus, following their natural sway, he sways them—yet though swayed, it is not by force. Following their natural drift, he drifts with them—yet though drifted, it is not by action. Thus, their harmful intentions naturally vanish, their solitary aspirations naturally advance. Customs are transformed, habits altered, all-pervasive and inescapable. They tread their nature and act of themselves, unaware of the cause, all saying, ‘It is simply our nature.’ *All* means every one.

**Subcommentary:** When the Sage governs the world, he greatly accords with the natural tendencies of living things. Riding their natural sway, he establishes laws; following their natural drift, he shapes teachings. Thus, though teachings are established, their traces are not apparent; though customs are transformed, the people do not know it. He eradicates their harmful intentions and advances their solitary aspirations. Unmoved by things, they act as if by nature’s own doing; following their nature, they do not know why it is so. *All* means every one.

If this is so, how could it be like Yao and Shun’s teaching of the people, revering them as elder brothers?

**Annotation:** *Revering* means holding in the highest esteem. He refuses to excessively praise Yao and Shun or defer to them as elder brothers.

**Subcommentary:** *Revering* means holding in the highest esteem. If one governs the people by the previous method, the realm will be as pure as antiquity, all things attaining their nature. Why must one uniquely revere Yao and Shun, deferring to them as elder brothers? This is to say that the customs of yielding and deference do not surpass those of Tang and Yu.

One desires to equal virtue, and the heart abides.

**Annotation:** *Abides* means not chasing after externals. If the heart does not abide, virtue will not be equal.

**Subcommentary:** *Abides* means to be settled. When the heart chases after externals, it clashes with things; when empty, tranquil, and settled, the myriad conditions become one. The sameness or difference of conditions lies in the stillness or disturbance of the heart. Thus, to desire to equal Yao and Shun in virtue, one must first settle the heart.

Zi Gong traveled south to Chu and, returning to Jin, passed by Hanyin. He saw an old man preparing his vegetable garden, digging a tunnel to enter the well, holding a jar to draw water and irrigate. He toiled greatly but achieved little.

**Subcommentary:** South of the water is called *yin*; growing vegetables is called a *garden*; the plots within are called *beds*.

The tunnel is an underground passage. *Huajiao* describes the appearance of exertion. *Zhangren* is a term of respect for an elder. Zi Gong traveled south into the lands of Jing and Chu, passing by the southern bank of the Han River, where he exchanged words with the elder. Their rising and falling tones and discourse are fully recorded in the text. Zhuangzi thus records these two worthies to illustrate the praise of Hundun.

Zi Gong said: "Here is a device that can irrigate a hundred vegetable beds in a single day. It requires little effort yet achieves much—would you not desire it?"

**Subcommentary:** *Xie* refers to machinery. Seeing the elder exert much effort for little result, Zi Gong taught him about mechanical devices, hoping to reduce labor while increasing efficiency. He offered his sincere advice, uncertain whether the elder would accept.

The gardener looked up and asked: "What is it like?"

Zi Gong replied: "Carve wood into a mechanism, heavy at the rear and light at the front. It draws water as if pulling, swift as boiling water—its name is the *shado*."

**Subcommentary:** The *ji* is a pivot. Drawing water with it is like pulling, its speed like bubbling water. Light at the front and heavy at the rear, it is what is now called the well-sweep.

The gardener flushed with anger, his expression turning to scornful laughter: "I have heard from my teacher that those who possess mechanical devices must have mechanical affairs, and those who have mechanical affairs must have a mechanical heart. When a mechanical heart resides in the breast, purity and whiteness are incomplete. When purity and whiteness are incomplete, the spirit is unsettled. One whose spirit is unsettled is not borne by the Dao. I am not ignorant of such things—I am ashamed to do them."

**Commentary:** What is used in its proper time is true completeness. This man, seeking to cultivate completeness, clings to oneness and upholds antiquity, yet loses his original simplicity.

**Subcommentary:** Those who possess mechanical devices must have mechanical tasks, and those who have mechanical tasks must have a mechanical mind. When a mechanical mind resides in the breast, pure whiteness is not fully realized. When pure whiteness is not fully realized, the spirit hangs in uncertainty, unsettled between life and death. One who is unsettled is not borne by the ultimate Dao, and thus I am ashamed to act thus. This man has not yet embodied true cultivation, so he clings to oneness and guards whiteness.

Zi Gong was abashed, his head bowed, unable to respond.

**Subcommentary:** *Man* describes the appearance of shame. Having failed in his words, he did not know how to answer.

After a while, the gardener asked: "What are you doing here?"

**Commentary:** *You jian* means a brief moment. *Xi* means "what." He asked Zi Gong: Whose disciple are you? What do you study?

Zi Gong replied: "I am a disciple of Confucius."

The gardener said: "Are you not that one who, with vast learning, compares himself to the sages, flatters and fawns to surpass the multitude, and strums a lone zither to sing mournful songs, selling your reputation throughout the world?"

**Subcommentary:** *Yu yu* refers to flattery. You boast of your broad learning and vast knowledge, comparing yourself to the sages. You twist your words with flattery to surpass ordinary people. You sit alone, strumming and singing, modulating your voice with sorrowful deceit. Clinging to the teachings of the sages, you sell your reputation, traveling through the states and journeying across the world.

"You should forget your spirit and qi, cast aside your form and bones—only then might you approach it."

**Commentary:** Without forgetting, without casting aside, there is no way to approach it.

**Subcommentary:** *Ji* means "near." You must forget your spirit and qi, abandon your body and form. Only when both body and heart are forgotten can you draw near to the Dao. Yet you cannot even govern yourself—how can you presume to govern the world? Be on your way and do not hinder my work."

**Subcommentary:** *Er* means "you." *Fa* means "to lack." Each thing governs itself, and thus the world is ordered. To govern others with oneself leads only to great disorder. With your virtue, Zi Gong, you are not yet fit to govern yourself—how could you answer the summons of the world? You should hasten on your way and not neglect my work.

Zi Gong shrank back, his color drained, feeling small and ill at ease. He walked thirty *li* before recovering.

**Subcommentary:** *Beizou* describes a momentary change in expression. *Xuxu* describes the appearance of self-doubt. Rebuked thus, his countenance lost its composure. Only after walking thirty *li* did he return to normal.

His disciples asked: "Who was that man just now? Why did you, Master, change your expression and lose your color upon seeing him, remaining unsettled for the rest of the day?"

**Subcommentary:** *Fan* means "to return." Zi Gong’s disciples referred to him as their Master. They asked: What art does that man practice, that upon seeing him, you, Master, lost your usual composure, your spirit unsettled for the entire day? The disciples, puzzled, thus questioned him.

Zi Gong replied: "At first, I thought there was only one man in the world—"

**Commentary:** He meant Confucius.

"—but I did not know there was another such man."

**Subcommentary:** Before, I received teachings believing that in the world, only my Master was peerless. Now, having met this elder, I see his virtue is even more profound and distant. Thus, I was momentarily abashed and could not regain my composure. Though I have not yet discerned the true from the false, I truly believed him to be as worthy as Confucius.

"I have heard from my Master that in affairs, one seeks what is fitting; in achievements, one seeks completion. Where little effort yields great results—that is the Way of the sage."

**Commentary:** The Way of the sage is simply to employ the hearts of the people.

**Subcommentary:** In affairs, what is timely is fitting; in achievements, what is accomplished is complete. Thus, where little effort yields great results, it is the mechanism of timely fitting and complete achievement. Zi Gong, confused by what he had heard before, took this to be the Way of the sage. But now it is not so. One who holds to the Dao has complete virtue; one with complete virtue has complete form; one with complete form has complete spirit. One with complete spirit—that is the Way of the sage. Entrusting life to walk alongside the people, not knowing where it leads, vast and perfectly complete!"

"Those who pursue profit, schemes, and cunning must forget the hearts of others.

**Commentary:** This is the Way of the sage-king, not that of ordinary people.

Zi Gong, hearing this discourse on borrowed cultivation, was convinced, yet he did not understand how the purely unblemished align with the world.

**Subcommentary:** Now, if the Venerable One had questioned me, it would not be thus. One who holds to the Dao suffers no lack in virtue; one with complete virtue suffers no harm in form; one with complete form attains undivided spirit. One with complete spirit entrusts progress to human inquiry, entrusts life to the world, and though walking alongside all things, knows not where it leads—dim and profound, beyond measure. Thus, their conduct is pure and harmonious, their virtue and power perfectly complete, and their hearts cannot be swayed by profit, schemes, or cunning. This is the Way of the sage, not the borrowed cultivation of mere practice.

Zi Gong, failing to comprehend, rashly applied what he had heard. As for such a person—their will does not pursue what it does not aspire to; their heart does not act where it does not incline. Though the world praises them and they attain what they deem right, they remain unmoved; though the world condemns them and they lose what they deem right, they remain untroubled. The world’s praise or blame neither benefits nor harms them—this is one of complete virtue.

I am but one tossed by the winds and waves.

**Commentary:** These are the followers of Song Rongzi, yet they do not attain complete virtue. Zi Gong’s confusion in this man is like Liezi’s intoxication with Ji Xian.

**Subcommentary:** Their demeanor is carefree and unconcerned, their manner free from intent. The Venerable One’s aspirations are pure and simple, unburdened by schemes, his heart content with few desires, unconcerned with action. Though the whole world praises him and extols his virtue, knowing it brings no benefit, he does not so much as glance; though the whole world condemns him and his reputation is ruined, perceiving it brings no harm, he does not accept it. Unmoved by praise or blame, he may be called one of complete virtue. Yet the nature of water, though clear, stirs into waves when wind arises; my heart, unsettled, is like those waves—hence, I am called one tossed by the winds and waves.

As Guo’s commentary states, these are the followers of Song Rongzi, yet they do not attain complete virtue. Zi Gong’s confusion in this man is like Liezi’s intoxication with Ji Xian.

Returning to Lu, he told Confucius. Confucius said: That man was one who borrowed the cultivation of Hun Dun’s guard.

**Commentary:** As he turned his back on the present and faced antiquity, shunning worldly affairs, it was clear he was not truly Hun Dun.

**Subcommentary:** Zi Gong, traveling from Lu to Chu, returned to Lu and reported the matter to Confucius. Now, *hun dun* means "undifferentiated." Since he turned his back on the present and faced antiquity, it is said he was not truly so.

He recognized one aspect but not the other.

**Commentary:** He merely recognized the simplicity of cultivating antiquity and embracing purity, yet he did not understand the ease of adapting to the times and responding to things.

**Subcommentary:** Recognizing one aspect means clinging to antiquity without change. Not recognizing the other means failing to adapt to the present and adjust to circumstances.

He cultivated his inner self but not his outer.

**Commentary:** The true Hun Dun does not cultivate at all—how could he treat his inner self as distinct and cultivate it alone?

**Subcommentary:** Embracing the Dao and guarding simplicity is cultivating the inner; unable to adapt to the times and respond to change is not cultivating the outer.

One who is clear-minded and enters simplicity, who practices non-action and returns to purity, who embodies nature and holds fast to spirit, and thus wanders amidst the world of men—would you be truly astonished?

**Commentary:** This is the true Hun Dun, who moves with the world yet does not lose himself, thus blending into the common without distinction—how could this make you astonished?

**Subcommentary:** One whose mind is clear and attains the essence of simplicity, who practices non-action and returns to the source of purity, who awakens to true nature and holds fast to its essence, and thus wanders amidst the clamor of the world—should this be like rivers and seas among the people, forests and marshes among the myriad things, where birds and beasts are not startled, how could men be astonished? Yet to say "would you be truly astonished" is to clarify that one should not be astonished.

Moreover, as for the arts of Hun Dun, how could you and I be sufficient to understand them?

**Commentary:** To him, it is his way; to us, it is ours. Hun Dun is profoundly the same—who can understand it? What can be understood is merely the understanding of its descriptions.

**Subcommentary:** Hun Dun is without intent, surpassing all wisdom and thought. Even if sages and worthies were to appear in the world, how could they suffice to understand it? Its obscurity and profundity transcend the bounds of sentiment and intention.

Zhun Mang, traveling east to the Great Abyss, encountered Yuan Feng on the shores of the Eastern Sea.

**Subcommentary:** *Zhun* means "pure"; *mang* means "vast." *Yuan* is a small wind, or else a great whirlwind. *Bin* means "shore"; the *Great Abyss* is the sea. Zhun Mang and Yuan Feng are both allegorical figures. Zhuangzi employed these two to illustrate the great Dao, thus setting them as guest and host, meeting on the sea’s edge.

Yuan Feng said: Where are you going?

**Subcommentary:** *Xi* means "what"; *zhi* means "to go." He inquired of Zhun Mang where he was traveling.

He said: To the Great Abyss.

**Subcommentary:** He wished to go to the Eastern Sea.

Yuan Feng said: What for?

**Subcommentary:** He asked what he sought there.

He said: The Great Abyss, as a thing, receives all without filling, draws from all without exhausting—I shall wander there.

**Subcommentary:** The great sea is vast and profound, its depths unfathomable. A hundred rivers flow into it without overflowing; the Tail Conduit drains it without drying. This is an analogy for the supreme principle, whose meaning is likewise. Thus, though he spoke of traveling to the azure depths, in truth, he was wandering in the great Dao.

Yuan Feng said: Do you have no regard for the horizontal-eyed people? I wish to hear of sagely governance."

Yuan Feng, having perceived this intent, thereupon posed this question: "Does the Master truly have no concern for the black-headed people? I wish to hear of the methods of sagely transformation."

Zhun Mang said: "Sagely governance? Offices are established without losing their proper place; the capable are promoted without misjudging their talents.

**Subcommentary:** Commands are issued and offices set up, each attaining its fitting role; skills are selected and recommendations made without failing to match abilities. Knowing this, the world attains great peace, the constant norms are properly ordered, and the safeguard of sagely governance lies herein.

Act after fully perceiving the circumstances and proceed with what is to be done.

**Commentary:** All is followed and entrusted to them.

**Subcommentary:** Affairs are often discordant, undertakings manifold; thus, steps are taken at different times, and the pure and the decadent belong to different ages. Therefore, in governance, nothing precedes entrusting things to their own nature. Only after clearly seeing the circumstances and examining what is to be done, then following things as they are, can nothing be amiss.

Words and deeds arise of themselves, and the world is transformed.

**Commentary:** If things are made to follow one, they are not transformed.

**Subcommentary:** All actions taken and teachings spoken are entrusted to things themselves, not making things follow oneself. Thus, all living beings under heaven naturally follow transformation. With a wave of the hand or a glance, the people of the four directions all arrive together—this is called sagely governance.

**Commentary:** This means that with a gesture or a look, the people each attain their nature, for they are left to act of themselves.

**Subcommentary:** To move the hand or turn the gaze is to command with a gesture; thus, the four directions revere and submit, and the ten thousand states come to court. The efficacy of sagely governance is thus.

Some versions have "manifest" in place of "wave," meaning that with manifest commands, the four directions all submit. Here, there are three kinds of people: the sagely, the virtuous, and the spirit-like. The above concerns sagely governance; below, the virtuous and spirit-like are listed in order.

I wish to hear of the virtuous person.

**Subcommentary:** The preceding sagely governance was explained with broad strokes; the meaning of the virtuous person is what I deeply wish to hear.

He said: The virtuous person dwells without thought, moves without deliberation.

**Commentary:** Simply following nature.

**Subcommentary:** Profoundly attuned to the realm of the Dao, attaining what is without attainment—thus is called the virtuous person. The virtuous person concentrates the spirit and sits in solemn stillness, utterly without thought; even when responding to things and enacting transformation, there is never any scheming or planning. They harbor no right or wrong, beauty or ugliness.

**Commentary:** Having no right or wrong in the breast, they entrust all to the world.

**Subcommentary:** Embracing the Dao and holding to virtue, self and other are both forgotten—how could they harbor right and wrong, contain good and evil? Within the four seas, all rejoice in what is beneficial to all, all are at ease with what provides for all.

**Commentary:** Without a heart of self-interest.

**Subcommentary:** The virtuous person’s beneficence is vast and far-reaching, universally covering all beings. Thus, goods and benefits are shared equally by the four seas, and provision is given to the ten thousand people without distinction. This is the universal joy of heaven and earth, the peace of all under heaven. They are enlightened as if an infant who has lost its mother, disoriented as if a traveler who has lost the way.

**Subcommentary:** An infant who has lost its mother is bright with longing yet has nowhere to rely; a traveler who has lost the way is bewildered and has no place to turn. These two analogies illustrate the virtuous person.

Wealth and resources are abundant, yet they do not know whence they come; food and drink are sufficient, yet they do not know from where they arise—this is called the bearing of the virtuous person.

**Commentary:** Virtue is the expression of the spirit-like person, hence it is called bearing.

**Subcommentary:** Desires are few and limited to what is proper, thus wealth and resources are abundant; flavors are not sought, thus food and drink are sufficient; there is no seeking in life and destiny, thus they do not know from where things come. Summarizing the preceding meaning, this is called the bearing of the virtuous person.

I wish to hear of the spirit-like person.

**Commentary:** I wish to hear how they express it.

**Subcommentary:** Virtue is the path of the spirit-like person; I wish to hear how they express it.

He said: The supreme spirit-like person rides the light, and with form, perishes and vanishes.

**Commentary:** Riding the light means having no light.

**Subcommentary:** Rides means employs; light means wisdom. The highest spirit-like person employs wisdom to illuminate things. Though their light is like the sun and moon, it illuminates and then vanishes, withdrawing the body and dismissing cleverness, both heart and form are abandoned—thus, with form, they perish and vanish. This is called illuminating the vast.

**Commentary:** Without self and entrusting things to their own nature, empty and without anything harbored—this is not obstruction.

**Subcommentary:** Wisdom encompasses the ten thousand things, brightness surpasses the three luminaries; nothing is too obscure to be illuminated—is this not vast? Life is fully realized and emotions are exhausted; heaven and earth rejoice, and the ten thousand affairs vanish.

**Commentary:** When emotions are exhausted and life is fully realized, heaven and earth rejoice. When affairs do not hinder joy, this is having no affairs.

**Subcommentary:** Exhausting the utmost of nature and destiny, fully realizing the emotions of life and transformation—thus, dwelling between heaven and earth, they are never not carefree and joyful. Having penetrated the illusory emptiness of self and other, the ten thousand affairs vanish. The ten thousand things return to their emotions—this is called the mingling of darkness.

**Commentary:** Emotions return and darkness mingles without progression.

**Subcommentary:** Forgetting illumination yet illuminating, illumination rivals the three luminaries in brilliance; forgetting life yet living, life shares the joy of the two poles. Thus, they can observe the return of the ten thousand things to their origin, witness the four kinds of life returning to their destiny—therefore, chaos is undivided and darkness is one with the Dao.

Menwu Gui and Chizhang Manji observed the troops of King Wu.

**Subcommentary:** Men and Chizhang are surnames; Wugui and Manji are given names. Two thousand five hundred men make a *shi* (troop); *shi* means multitude. When King Wu attacked Zhou, his army crossed Meng Ford—at that time, the two men observed together.

Chizhang Manji said: "He does not compare to the Yu clan. Thus, he has encountered this calamity."

**Subcommentary:** Calamity means encounter. Yu Shun governed the age with yielding and deference; King Wu saved the world with shield and spear. Between yielding and shield, the difference is vast. Judging by this, they spoke of mutual incomparability.

The weapon of war is an inauspicious instrument, hence the disaster of slaughter and killing.

Menwu Gui said: "When the world is evenly governed, was it the Yu clan who governed it? Or was it governed only after chaos arose?"

**Commentary:** Both sages governed because of chaos—thus, yielding deference and the use of troops are merely matters of differing times, with no question of superiority between them.

**Subcommentary:** *Jun* means "even." If the world were at great peace and all things were in order, why would there be need for Yu Shun to establish laws and govern? It was only because Yao’s years were drawing to a close and his virtue was waning day by day that he yielded to Chonghua, entrusting him with the task of ordering the realm.

Chizhang Manji said: "That the world be evenly governed is the wish—why then calculate with the Yu clan in mind?"

**Commentary:** When governance is even, each wish is fulfilled—why then deliberate on the virtue of the Yu clan and push them forward as rulers? Xu Wugui’s words are correct.

**Subcommentary:** When the realm is clear and harmonious, and each aspiration is fulfilled, why deliberate on the virtue of the Yu clan and push them forward as rulers? This is to comprehend Wugui’s words and acknowledge their reason. The Yu clan were medicine for sores.

**Commentary:** The world was all at rest from wounds and chaos, hence they sought the medicine of the Yu clan.

**Subcommentary:** *Yang* means "head sore." When the body suffers wounds, one seeks a physician to heal them—just as when the world encounters turmoil, a sage is needed to govern it. Thus, without illness there is no physician, and without chaos there is no sage. To place a wig on a bald head, to seek a physician when ill.

**Subcommentary:** When the hair is thick as clouds, there is no need to apply a wig; when one is fortunate enough to be free of illness, why borrow a physician? Thus, when the world is clear and at peace, there is no need for a great sage. These two lines summarize the two preceding matters.

A filial son holds medicine to tend to his compassionate father, his countenance haggard—yet the sage feels shame at this.

**Commentary:** Those who govern the world do not do so for glory.

**Subcommentary:** *Cao* means "to hold"; *xiu* means "to tend." *Qiaoran* describes a withered appearance. Just as a filial son tending to his compassionate father does not boast of his merit, so too does a sage rescuing the world from disaster not take pride in glory. Such deeds are done out of necessity, hence the shame.

In an age of utmost virtue, worthies are not esteemed.

**Commentary:** The worthy occupy their proper place—this is not esteeming them.

**Subcommentary:** The unworthy and the worthy each occupy their proper place—this is not esteeming them to distinguish the worthy.

Abilities are not employed.

**Commentary:** The able act of themselves—this is not employing them.

**Subcommentary:** The clumsy and the skilled each follow their nature without boasting or striving—this is not esteeming or employing them.

The ruler is like the tip of a branch.

**Commentary:** He stands above things yet does not elevate himself.

**Subcommentary:** The ruler, dwelling above the people, is tranquil and empty, forgetting the self—like the tip of a high tree’s branch, without thought of glory or nobility.

The people are like wild deer.

**Commentary:** They are free and self-content.

**Subcommentary:** With the ruler practicing non-action, the people below are also pure and simple—like wild deer, free from the rites of kingship.

Upright yet unaware of it as righteousness, loving one another yet unaware of it as benevolence.

**Subcommentary:** Their hearts are straight and do not incline toward evil—how would they know of the righteousness that judges right and wrong? Following Heaven’s principle, they are mutually affectionate—how would they know of the benevolence of partial love?

Sincere yet unaware of it as loyalty, fitting yet unaware of it as trust.

**Commentary:** They follow their nature spontaneously, not through knowledge.

**Subcommentary:** Following their nature, they are sincere—unaware that this sincerity is loyalty. Acting in accord with principle, they are fitting—unaware that this fittingness is trust.

Moving like insects and employing one another, yet not taking it as a favor.

**Commentary:** They use their spontaneous movement, hence they move without gratitude.

**Subcommentary:** *Ci* means "to receive a favor." Creatures that move like insects—these are the refined and spirited kinds—employ one another, which is naturally fitting. Like the limbs and trunk, or the ears and eyes, with no intention of creation, how could there be a sense of receiving a favor? Governing things through non-action is likewise so.

Thus, conduct has no trace.

**Commentary:** The ruler enables their spontaneous conduct, hence there is no advancement.

**Subcommentary:** With the ruler and people pure and simple, above and below in harmony, they move following their nature—hence there is no nearness to record.

Affairs leave no transmission.

**Commentary:** Each remains within their proper place, hence there is no teaching transmitted to others.

**Subcommentary:** Like the head and feet, each has its office—remaining within their proper place, they do not transmit or learn from one another. With no nearness to record, affairs also vanish.

A filial son does not flatter his parents; a loyal minister does not fawn upon his ruler—this is the height of being a minister and son.

**Subcommentary:** To serve one’s parents well is filial piety. *Yu* means "false"; *chan* means "to deceive." To seek others not through uprightness is called *chan*. As a minister and son, serving father and ruler without deceit or flattery, exhausting loyalty and filial piety—this is the height of the minister’s and son’s virtue.

If he assents to whatever his parents say and approves whatever they do, the world calls him an unworthy son. If he assents to whatever his ruler says and approves whatever he does, the world calls him an unworthy minister. Yet how do we know this must necessarily be so?

**Commentary:** This is simply going against custom to follow one’s ruler and parents—hence custom calls them unworthy. Yet we do not know where the utmost correctness truly lies.

**Subcommentary:** *Buxiao* means "unlike." Whatever the ruler or father says or does, he follows without discerning good or bad, without the slightest intention of remonstrance—hence in the eyes of the world, he is truly unworthy. Yet we do not know where the true principle lies.

If one assents to what the world calls assent and approves what it calls good, one is not called a flattering or fawning person. Then is custom truly more strict toward parents and more reverent toward rulers?

**Commentary:** It is said that custom does not revere rulers and parents to the point of following custom—yet custom does not call this fawning. This makes clear that reverence is insufficient to subdue things; what subdues things lies rather in following custom.

Thus the sage never stands apart from the world, but always waxes and wanes with the times. When in an age of emperors, he is an emperor; when in an age of kings, he is a king—how could he turn his back on custom to impose his own way?

**Subcommentary:** *Yan* means "to teach." This clarifies that defiance and compliance are not fixed. When the world approves of goodness, remonstrance is right. Yet to defy custom and comply with one’s parents is called flattery, while to defy one’s parents and comply with custom—is this not fawning obsequiousness? Moreover, with both opposition and compliance, right and wrong appear, yet once opposition and compliance are emptied, we do not know where true principle lies. To defy one’s parents and comply with custom—can this be called reverence for rulers and parents? When one calls oneself a guide to others, they bristle with anger; when one calls oneself a flatterer of others, they frown in displeasure.

**Commentary:** The world ultimately takes majority agreement as correctness, so when called a flatterer, one shows anger and refuses to accept it. Yet all one’s life one guides others, all one’s life one flatters others—without inquiring into principle, merely seeking mutual approval.

**Subcommentary:** *Bo* and *fu* both describe an agitated appearance. *Dao* means "to lead," referring to flattery used to ingratiate oneself with rulers and parents. The people of the world, when called flatterers, show anger and reject the label, yet all their lives they engage in flattery. The whole world is like this. To assemble metaphors and adorn words is to gather a crowd, yet this beginning and end, root and branch, do not incur blame.

**Commentary:** To assemble metaphors and adorn words should incur the charge of flattery, yet the world again uses this to win people and gather crowds—this too is following custom, yet they are never seen as guilty.

**Subcommentary:** One who can assemble metaphors and embellish empty words draws people to compete for his favor, thus gathering a crowd. Able to preserve consistency from beginning to end, from root to branch, the crowd follows him, so no mutual blame arises. *Pi* originally had a variant meaning "to assemble jade tablets," referring to matching *gui* and *bi* jades. To drape robes and skirts, display colors, alter one’s appearance to ingratiate oneself with the age—yet not to call this flattery; to join the crowd, to blend right and wrong, yet not to call oneself one of the multitude—this is the height of folly.

**Commentary:** The world is utterly foolish, so one cannot but follow it.

**Subcommentary:** The Yellow Emperor draped robes and skirts to bring order to the world. Upper garments and lower skirts symbolize Heaven and Earth; red and purple hues are woven into patterns. Using such adornments, altering one’s appearance to ingratiate oneself with the age, the shallow and false do not call this flattery, but instead fawn upon their rulers. To join the crowd of vulgar people, to exchange judgments, to blend right and wrong, yet to consider oneself distinct from the multitude—this is the height of foolishness. One who knows his own folly is not utterly foolish; one who knows his own confusion is not utterly confused. The utterly confused never awaken in their lifetime; the utterly foolish never gain wisdom in their lifetime.

**Commentary:** That sages share the Dao yet emperors and kings take different paths is truly because the world’s confusion cannot be dispelled—so one follows and accords with it.

**Subcommentary:** *Jie* means "awakening"; *ling* means "wisdom." One who knows his own folly and confusion is a sage. Following and according with it, his folly is not confusion. The utterly foolish and confused are the vulgar, whose hearts are narrow and base, who meet circumstances and generate delusion, thus passing their whole lives without awakening. If three walk together and one is confused, the destination may still be reached, for the confused are few; if two are confused, effort is wasted and the destination is not reached, for the confused prevail. Yet now the whole world is confused. Though I have aspirations, they cannot be realized. Is this not lamentable?

**Commentary:** The whole world is confused, so though I seek the perfect Dao, it cannot be attained. Thus Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu merely followed the times.

**Subcommentary:** *Shi* means "to go"; *zhi* means "to reach"; *huo* means "delusion"; *qi* means "to seek." If three walk together and one loses the way, the destination may still be reached, for few are deluded and many are clear; if two are deluded, the spirit labors in vain and the destination is not reached, for delusion prevails over clarity. Now the whole world is deluded. Though Zhuangzi seeks the perfect Dao, there is no way to attain it—how sorrowful! Great music does not enter the ears of the village,

**Commentary:** It is not what the alleyways esteem.

**Subcommentary:** The *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* songs provoke uproarious laughter.

**Commentary:** When vulgar people hear sentimental tunes, they laugh in unison.

**Subcommentary:** Great music refers to the *Xian Chi* and *Da Shao* melodies, not what the back alleys and lanes hear. The *Zhe Yang* and *Huang Hua* are likely ancient popular tunes, coarse and vulgar, so they provoke laughter and animated expressions, with everyone laughing in unison. Formerly, Marquis Wen of Wei listened to ancient music and fell asleep in delight; when he heard the new sounds of Zheng and Wei, he rejoiced—this is the same phenomenon. Thus lofty words do not lodge in the hearts of the multitude,

**Commentary:** They do not take them to heart.

The discourse of utmost subtlety transcends the vulgar realm—this is what is called "lofty words." Such words are fitting only for the treasuries of sages and worthies; how could they lodge within the minds of the multitude? Just as grand music does not enter the ears of alleyways, so too do lofty words find no resting place in the hearts of the common. The supreme words remain unspoken, for the blindness of custom prevails.

**Commentary:** This is why the world has never heeded the sage and always follows its own inclinations.

**Subcommentary:** *To emerge* means to become manifest. The words of the supreme Way are bland and flavorless, never reaching the ears of back alleys—how much less could they lodge in the hearts of the multitude? Yet the words of the vulgar, adorned with embellished and deceptive phrases, are like the *Zhe Yang* tunes, pleasing to many listeners. Since common sayings dominate the thoroughfares, the supreme words remain hidden and obscured. Thus the *Qi Wu Lun* states, "Words are concealed in luxuriant ornament." With both delusions at play, one cannot reach the intended destination.

**Commentary:** Each has its own grounds for belief, and so they know not where to go.

**Subcommentary:** *Heels* refer to the feet. Those who lose their way take north for south; once both delusions arise, their steps falter, and they cannot advance. Even if one person sought to proceed alone, how could they attain their former clarity? This further explains the previous confusion. Now, with the whole world deluded, though I may have aspirations, how could they be realized?

**Subcommentary:** If two people falter in their steps, their destination is already difficult to reach—how much more so when the whole world is lost? Thus, though one may harbor a seeking heart, it is surely unattainable. This explains the earlier lament, "Is this not sorrowful?" The depth of deception warrants such emphasis. To know it is unattainable yet still force it is yet another delusion; therefore, it is better to release it and not press further.

**Commentary:** Align with it and become one with it.

**Subcommentary:** *Release* means to let go. Since the delusion runs deep and is difficult to dispel in haste, to insist on correction is yet another folly. Better to let go and not press, so that self and others may find peace. If not pressed, who then shares in the worry?

**Commentary:** Allow them to find their own timely harmony, without forcing understanding, and all will live without worry in this world.

**Subcommentary:** *Share* means to join. If one lets things resolve their own confusion and abandons the urge to press, then both self and others wander freely, and worry vanishes—who then remains to share it?

A leper gives birth in the dead of night, hastily seizes a torch to examine the child, and anxiously fears it will resemble himself.

**Commentary:** *Leper* refers to an evil person. It means that no one in the world wishes to be wicked; some are compelled by harsh servitude, others lose their nature through delusion. Yet the deluded may reflect and return, and the wicked may think to reform. Thus, I practice non-action, and the world transforms itself.

**Subcommentary:** *Leper* refers to one afflicted with ugliness and disease. *Hastily* means quickly; *anxiously* describes a state of urgency. It speaks of an ugly person who gives birth at midnight, swiftly takes up a torch to inspect the child, and in a flurry of emotion fears it will resemble them. Even one so grotesquely ugly still hopes for change, desiring to abandon ugliness for beauty. How much more should the deluded, weary of their confusion, yearn for awakening? Release it and do not press, and naturally, there will be no worry or weariness.

A hundred-year-old tree is felled and carved into a sacrificial vessel, adorned with blue and yellow patterns. Yet its offcuts lie discarded in the ditch. Compared to the sacrificial vessel, the offcuts in the ditch differ in beauty and ugliness, yet in the loss of their original nature, they are one.

**Subcommentary:** *Sacrificial vessel* refers to a vessel shaped like an ox, used in rituals, called a *xi zun*. *Differ* means distinction. Once carved into the shape of an ox and further embellished with blue and yellow patterns, one piece is discarded in the ditch, unused. Comparing these two fragments, beauty and ugliness diverge, yet in the loss of their original nature, they are the same. This sets up the analogy.

Jie and Zeng, Shi and their like differ in conduct and righteousness, yet in the loss of their nature, they are equal.

**Subcommentary:** This draws the parallel. Jie’s tyranny and cruelty, Zeng and Shi’s practice of benevolence and righteousness—though their good and evil diverge, in the loss of their true nature, they are the same.

Moreover, there are five ways in which the original nature is lost:

**Subcommentary:** The ways in which delusion leads to the loss of nature are manifold, but in essence, there are five.

First, the five colors confuse the eyes, rendering them unclear.

**Subcommentary:** The five colors are blue, yellow, red, white, and black. The common people indulge in their pursuit, and these colors confuse the eyes, preventing them from seeing the truth—hence, *unclear*.

Second, the five sounds confuse the ears, rendering them unperceptive.

**Subcommentary:** The five sounds are *gong*, *shang*, *jiao*, *zhi*, and *yu*. Indulgence in vulgar sounds prevents one from hearing the Way—hence, *unperceptive*.

Third, the five odors assail the nose, obstructing and wounding the inner passages.

**Subcommentary:** The five odors are rank, scorched, fragrant, rotten, and putrid. *Obstruct* means blockage, referring to a state of congestion. It speaks of the nose indulging in the five odors, leading to blockage and inner injury. External texts refer to this as *odors*. Thus, the *Yi Jing* says, "Its fragrance is like orchid"; the *Daoist Canon* speaks of the five fragrances, and the *Xi Sheng Jing* says, "Fragrance and flavor fill the body."

Fourth, the five flavors muddy the mouth, causing illness and loss of taste.

**Subcommentary:** The five flavors are sour, bitter, sweet, acrid, and salty. *Illness* means affliction; *loss* means deprivation. Indulgence in the five flavors pollutes the mouth’s root, leading to disease from excess salt and bitterness, and the tongue losing its sense of taste—hence, *illness and loss*.

Fifth, preferences and aversions agitate the heart, causing the nature to become flighty.

**Subcommentary:** *Preferences* means to pursue; *agitate* means to disturb. Following the heart’s desires, one pursues; opposing them, one rejects. This disturbs the heart, causing the natural nature to race without rest, becoming light, restless, and agitated—hence, *flighty*.

These five are all harms to life.

**Subcommentary:** This summarizes the five preceding matters, all of which are blades that sever life and axes that harm it—great calamities to living beings.

Yet Yang Zhu and Mo Di, striving apart from the forked path, deemed themselves to have attained the Way—this is not what I call attainment.

**Subcommentary:** *Striving apart* describes the exertion of force. Yang Zhu and Mo Di, each flaunting their own abilities, harmed their nature and life, taking this as attainment. But since it contravenes the principle of naturalness, it is not the attainment recognized by Master Zhuang.

Is attainment found in confinement? Then the turtledove and magpie in their cage may also be said to have attained it.

**Subcommentary:** Those bound by benevolence, righteousness, ritual, and law do not follow their true nature. Having falsified their nature, they encounter hardship. If this hardship is deemed attainment, how does it differ from the turtledove or magpie in its cage, mistaking captivity for contentment?

Moreover, pursuing and rejecting sounds and colors clogs the inner self, while caps of skin and heron plumes, sashes and long robes constrain the outer form.

**Subcommentary:** *Caps of skin* are made from animal hide. The *heron* is a bird resembling a duck, with green plumage, found in Yulin. Its iridescent feathers adorn caps, hence *heron-plumed caps*. Such caps were worn by those versed in celestial patterns. *Sashes* are inserted like jade tablets; *sashes* are also called *insertions*. *Fen* denotes substance, and *shen* refers to the great belt. *Long robes* are formal court attire. These vain and artificial men make pursuit and rejection their trade, so that the inner treasury is choked with the kindling of sensory dust, while their outer form is bound by robes and sashes. Turning their backs on the Dao of non-action, they violate their natural nature, taking this as attainment—how does it differ from the turtledove or magpie?

Within, the inner self is blocked and brimming like a wattle fence; without, layer upon layer of snares encircle them. Gazing about in their snares, they deem themselves to have attained it—then the convict with arms bound and fingers twisted, or the tiger and leopard trapped in their sacks and cages, may also be said to have attained it.

**Subcommentary:** *Blocked* means obstructed; *brimming* means full. *Wattle fence* is a hedge. *Snares* are cords. *Gazing about* describes their appearance. Since pursuit and rejection obstruct and fill the inner treasury, it is like a wattle fence; sashes and belts bind the outer form, likened to cords. Having fallen into such ruin, if they still deem themselves to have attained it, how does it differ from the convict with arms bound and fingers twisted by the cords? Or like the tiger and leopard ensnared in sacks and cages, suffering distress and hardship beyond measure—if they mistake this for attainment, how does it differ?

**#37** *The "Omissions and Errors" notes that Zhang Junfang’s edition includes the character *crime* after *mutual*.

**#38** Originally *huá* (華), emended to *è* (萼) following the *Siku* and Zhejiang Bureau editions; the subcommentary below matches this.

**#39** The *Siku* and Zhejiang Bureau editions write *fǒu* (缶) for *chuí* (垂).

**#40** Emended from *lìng* (令) to *huì* (会) following Zhao’s edition.

**#41** The eight characters *guī yì chā yě wǔ chā sǔn yóu* (珪亦插也捂插笋犹) are garbled in meaning; following Guo Qingfan’s citation, they are corrected to *chā yě. Zhì, yóu guī, wèi chā* (插也。质，犹珪，谓插), seven characters in total.

**Annotations and Subcommentary on the Southern Florescence Scripture of the True Classic**
**Volume Fifteen**
**Guo Xiang of Henan, Annotation**
**Subcommentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of Xihua, Tang Dynasty**
**Outer Chapters: "The Dao of Heaven" (Thirteen)**

The Dao of Heaven revolves without accumulation, thus all things are completed.
**[Subcommentary]** *Revolves* means moves, turns. *Accumulation* means stagnation, hoarding. The Dao of Heaven turns and revolves, nurturing all living beings, illuminating them with sun and moon, moistening them with rain and dew, stirring and shaping them without stagnation or hoarding. Thus the four seasons cycle, and the myriad things are born and completed.

The Dao of the Emperor revolves without accumulation, thus the world submits.
**[Subcommentary]** The king models himself on Heaven and Earth, governing all beings, dispersing without hoarding, bestowing transformation without limit. Thus the six directions unite in submission, and the eight regions offer allegiance.

The Dao of the Sage revolves without accumulation, thus all within the seas obeys.
**[Annotation]** These three all indulge the nature of things without entanglement or stagnation.
**[Subcommentary]** The Dao of the Sage is the Way of the mysterious sage and unadorned king. Responding to circumstances, he establishes teachings and institutes laws, providing a vessel for the wise and deliverance without end. His Dao aligns with Heaven, his virtue matches the Emperor’s. Though his actions vary, there are thus two Ways—of Emperor and Sage. Yet in employing wisdom to save the age, he likewise accumulates nothing. His compassion is vast and boundless, thus all within the seas obeys.

Those enlightened by Heaven and attuned to the Sage, whose virtue of Emperor and King pervades the six directions and opens the four gates—let them act of themselves, and all will be obscurely still.
**[Annotation]** Allowing them to act of themselves, though the six directions pervade and the four gates open, stillness remains unharmed.
**[Subcommentary]** The *six directions* refer to the four quarters, above and below. The *four gates* are spring, autumn, winter, and summer. Only by illuminating the effortless Dao of Heaven, penetrating the Sage’s mind free of care, pervading the six directions with life and transformation, and following the four seasons in action—only thus, ruling over the ten thousand chariots, can one be called the virtue of Emperor and King. Allowing things to move of themselves, concealing brilliance and obscuring advancement, one remains as if dimly attuned. Movement does not disturb stillness, thus all is still.

The stillness of the Sage is not because stillness is good, and thus he is still.
**[Annotation]** If stillness were deemed good, there would be times of movement.
**[Subcommentary]** The Sage’s emptiness and stillness are like a withered tree in form, like dead ashes in mind—he does not know stillness *as* stillness. If stillness were considered good and he acted with intent to be still, then there would indeed be times of movement.

Nothing suffices to disturb his mind, thus he is still.
**[Annotation]** This is self-possession.
**[Subcommentary]** His wondrous essence mirrors the Two Modes yet is non-being; all realms are empty. Thus he moves amid the ten thousand changes without disturbance, not through disciplined effort to attain stillness.

When water is still, it clearly reflects beard and brows, its level surface serving as a standard—even the great craftsman takes it as his model.
**[Subcommentary]** Water, when moving, flows in waves; when still, it becomes limpid. Suspended as a mirror, it illuminates without partiality, thus it clearly reflects beard and brows, pure and centered. Correcting all crookedness, it serves as a standard. Even the most skilled craftsman must rely on water to find levelness. Thus the *Lao Scripture* says, "The highest good is like water." This illustrates the preceding meaning.

If still water is so clear, how much more the spirit? The Sage’s mind is still—it is the mirror of Heaven and Earth, the looking-glass of the myriad things.
**[Annotation]** Possessing the instrument and allowing it to act of itself, what it illuminates is without obscurity.
**[Subcommentary]** The Sage’s virtue aligns with the Two Modes, his wisdom encompasses the myriad things—how can he be compared to the insentient water? If still water clearly reflects the temples, how much more the spirit of the Sage’s still mind? Thus it is fitting that he mirrors the subtleties of Heaven and Earth and reflects the mysterious traces of the myriad things. This concludes the analogy.

Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, solitude, non-action—these are the level of Heaven and Earth and the utmost of the Dao and virtue.
**[Annotation]** All that is not level or not utmost arises from action.
**[Subcommentary]** Emptiness, stillness, tranquility, solitude, non-action—these four are different names for the same reality. Their excellence is praised, thus they bear these four names. Heaven and Earth take them as level, the Dao and virtue employ them as utmost.

Thus Emperors, Kings, and Sages rest in them.
**[Annotation]** They never move.
**[Subcommentary]** Ceasing thought, they rest in stillness. Resting, they are empty; empty, they are full. Fullness is principle.
**[Annotation]** *Principle* means pattern.
**[Subcommentary]** Having ceased thought and rested, they naturally align with emptiness; aligning with emptiness, they unite with true reality. Uniting with the true Dao, they attain the principle of nature.

Empty, then still; still, then moving; moving, then attaining.
**[Annotation]** Not losing that by which one moves.
**[Subcommentary]** Principle is empty and still; stillness can move—thus one attains.

Still, then non-action; in non-action, those who bear responsibility fulfill their duties.
**[Annotation]** In non-action, the myriad talents and beings each bear their duties and naturally fulfill their responsibilities.

Thus it is said: "How majestic were Shun and Yu, who possessed the world yet did not engage with it"—this is what is meant.

**[Subcommentary]** To bear responsibility is the role of ministers, for each subordinate has their appointed duties. When the emperor and king employ wisdom yet remain tranquil in non-action, their ministers fulfill their offices, each attending to their concerns. Thus, the sovereign remains in non-action while ministers attend to affairs, so that the crown hangs low before the eyes, yet does not interfere. In non-action, one is serene and at ease; in such ease, no worry or trouble can take hold, and longevity is attained.

**[Annotation]** *Yu yu* describes a demeanor of leisurely self-possession.

**[Subcommentary]** *Yu yu* expresses a bearing of ease and joy. Those who act are entangled in circumstances, and worldly burdens thus ensnare the mind; those who rest in non-action and self-possession find no place for anxiety in their thoughts. Serene and joyful, they attain long life.

For emptiness, stillness, tranquility, and non-action are the root of the myriad things.

**[Annotation]** Tracing their origin, all things arise from non-action.

**[Subcommentary]** These four qualities are the foundation of all things, so they are reiterated here to conclude with their excellence.

Illuminating this and facing south, one becomes a ruler like Yao; illuminating this and facing north, one becomes a minister like Shun.

**[Subcommentary]** In the beauty of yielding and deference, none surpass the era of Tang; in the flourishing of ruler and minister, none precede Yao and Shun. Thus, these two sovereigns exemplify the four virtues. Though their positions differ—one facing south, the other north—they attain the same perfection.

Embodying this in a superior position, one attains the virtue of emperors, kings, and the Son of Heaven; embodying this in a subordinate position, one follows the Way of the profound sage and unadorned king.

**[Annotation]** These are the heights of non-action.

**[Subcommentary]** Those who possess the Way yet lack its rank, drawing the world to them without holding office—this is what is meant by the unadorned king’s self-valuing. Applying this non-action to govern from above is the virtue of the Son of Heaven, Emperor Yao; applying this emptiness and tranquility to serve below is the Way of the profound sage and unadorned king. Those who possess the Way but lack its rank—such as the profound sage and unadorned king who value themselves—are exemplified by Laozi and Confucius.

Retreating to dwell in seclusion and wander freely by rivers and seas, scholars of the mountains and forests submit to them.

**[Subcommentary]** *Retreating* refers to withdrawing into obscurity and concealment. Applying this Way in retreat, one may wander and dine amidst mountains and waters, at ease and joyful. Thus, all reclusive scholars submit to them—such as those like Xu You and Chao Fu.

Applying this to advance and govern the world, one achieves great merit, renowned fame, and the unity of all under heaven.

**[Annotation]** This is the next level.

Thus, in retreat, they resemble those like Xu You and Chao Fu; in advancement, they resemble those like Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou.

How vast is the substance of non-action! What in the world cannot be accomplished through it? Therefore, if the sovereign does not undertake the duties of the chief minister, then Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou remain tranquil in their offices; if the chief minister does not execute the tasks of the hundred officials, then the hundred officials remain tranquil in their governance; if the hundred officials do not impose their affairs upon the myriad people, then the people remain tranquil and secure in their occupations; if the myriad people do not alter their respective abilities, then the distinctions of self and other in the world remain tranquil and self-possessed. Thus, from the Son of Heaven down to the common people, extending even to insects, who can achieve anything through action?

Therefore, the more one embodies non-action, the more exalted one becomes.

**[Subcommentary]** *Advancing* refers to emerging into prominence and assuming office. Those who embody the wondrous substance of non-action while descending to engage with the world can govern the people with benevolence and longevity, magnify perfect virtue in the sagely court, manifest unfathomable merit and fame, and display the achievements of the great ministers. Thus, all under heaven is unified, sharing the same standards and script; in utmost goodness and beauty, who surpasses those like Yi Yin and the Duke of Zhou?

Still, they are sagely; moving, they are kingly.

**[Annotation]** When it is time to act, they act; when it is time to rest, they rest.

In non-action, they are exalted.

**[Annotation]** Naturally revered by all things.

**[Subcommentary]** In stillness, they attain the exaltation of the profound sage and unadorned king; in action, they hold the nobility of the nine-five sovereign. In non-action, they are exalted—emerging, they become the Son of Heaven; dwelling, they remain the unadorned lord. Thus, wherever the Way resides, who would not honor it?

In simplicity and plainness, none in the world can rival their beauty.

**[Annotation]** Only simplicity and plainness match the beauty of heaven.

**[Subcommentary]** For unadorned simplicity, non-action, and emptiness are truly the root of all things. Thus, in their exaltation, who can rival their beauty?

Those who comprehend the virtue of heaven and earth—this is called the great root and great origin, those who harmonize with heaven.

**[Annotation]** Heaven and earth take non-action as their virtue; thus, understanding their origin and root means no opposition to heaven and earth.

**[Subcommentary]** When the numinous mind is bright and still, the spirit’s illumination pure and unblemished, and one’s virtue aligns with the two powers, one can indeed serve as the master of all things, the root of the myriad existences, mysteriously uniting with the Dao of nature and harmonizing with heaven.

This is how one harmonizes and regulates all under heaven, and harmonizes with others.

**[Annotation]** Following heaven is how one responds to others; thus, when heavenly harmony is perfected, human harmony is complete.

**[Subcommentary]** *Harmonizing* means leveling; *regulating* means aligning. Without intention in response, like echo following sound, one levels all things and aligns with the feelings of the world, blending and advancing together. Thus, one harmonizes with others.

Those who harmonize with others are called human joy; those who harmonize with heaven are called heavenly joy.

**[Annotation]** When heavenly joy is attained, human joy is fulfilled.

**[Subcommentary]** Descending to blend with the world, one delights in the joys of the human realm; ascending to unite with nature, one rejoices in the joy of the heavenly Dao.

Zhuangzi said: "O my master! O my master! You blend the myriad things yet are not cruel."

**[Annotation]** Changing and intermingling, thus it is called a stew. This is sagely, not my master’s cruelty.

**[Subcommentary]** *Sagely* means refined; *cruel* means violent. Zhuangzi took the natural supreme Dao as his master, repeating this to extol its virtue.

The Dao I take as my master nurtures and sustains all living beings. Even if it orders the myriad things, it harbors no intent of violence or anger. Thus, when autumn’s frosts cause withering and decay, none resent it. This makes clear that though it severs and divides, it is not by judgment.

Its blessings extend through ten thousand generations yet it is not called benevolent.
**[Annotation]** Benevolence is but the name for partial love; without love, there is nothing to call transformation.
**[Subcommentary]** Benevolence is the advance of partial love. The great Dao opens and closes heaven and earth, creating and transforming all beings. Its boundless kindness is impartial, thus it is not called benevolent.

It endures since high antiquity yet is not called long-lived.
**[Annotation]** Longevity is but the name for distant duration; without duration, there is nothing to call long-lived.
**[Subcommentary]** How could it merely endure since high antiquity? It existed even before the Lord of Heaven. Since it neither perishes nor arises, how could it be called short-lived or long-lived? As Guo’s annotation says, longevity is but the name for distant duration.

It covers and bears heaven and earth, carves and shapes the myriad forms yet is not called skillful.
**[Annotation]** Skillfulness is but the name for what is exquisitely made; all things are so of themselves, thus there is nothing to call skillful.
**[Subcommentary]** Riding the two powers to cover and bear, taking the myriad things to carve and shape—yet the two powers take generation and transformation as their function, and the myriad things take spontaneity as their use. Since generation and transformation do not rely on anything else, and carving and shaping do not depend on others, each thing employs its abilities, and each person follows its nature. Thus, the names of craft and clumsiness vanish. As Guo’s annotation says, skillfulness is but the name for what is exquisitely made.

This is called heavenly joy.
**[Annotation]** Forgetting joy, joy is complete.
**[Subcommentary]** Wherever one finds contentment, heavenly joy is formed.

Thus it is said: Those who know heavenly joy, in life follow the movement of heaven, in death merge with the transformations of things.
**[Subcommentary]** Knowing that heavenly joy is beyond sorrow and joy, one understands life and death. Without life or death, in life one moves with heaven’s dispensation, in death one blends with the changes of the myriad things.

At rest, they share the virtue of yin; in motion, they ride the waves of yang.
**[Subcommentary]** Their wondrous root is empty and still, so they equal yin in its tranquility; responding and acting in the world, they merge with the flowing waves of great yang.

Thus, those who know heavenly joy harbor no resentment from heaven, no blame from others, no burdens from things, no reproach from spirits.
**[Subcommentary]** Their virtue harmonizes with heaven, so they incur no heavenly resentment; their conduct accords with the world, so they suffer no human blame; they are darkly one with things, so things do not burden them; they owe nothing to the seen or unseen, so how could spirits reproach them?

Thus it is said: In movement, they are like heaven; in stillness, they are like earth.
**[Annotation]** Though movement and stillness differ, their lack of intent is one.
**[Subcommentary]** Heaven and earth summarize the meaning of movement and stillness without intent.

With a single mind settled, they rule all under heaven. Their spirits bring no misfortune, their souls know no fatigue.
**[Annotation]** Always without intent, thus they rule all under heaven without weariness or illness.
**[Subcommentary]** When realm and wisdom merge, it is called "one." Things cannot disturb it, thus it is called "settled." Precisely because it is settled in the one mind, it can rule the myriad states. Since there is no reproach from spirits, what misfortune could arise? Moving yet ever still, thus the soul does not grow weary.

With a single mind settled, the myriad things submit.
**[Subcommentary]** A single mind congealed and still is like dead ashes, yet stillness governs activity, so the myriad things return and submit.

This means using emptiness and stillness to extend through heaven and earth, to penetrate the myriad things—this is called heavenly joy.
**[Annotation]** When my mind is ever still, the minds of the myriad things are open to it. Open, they submit; closed, they rebel.
**[Subcommentary]** Why does a single mind settled make the myriad things submit? It is simply that using the wisdom of emptiness and stillness, one traces the principles of the two powers, comprehends the feelings of the myriad things, and turns with their changes without ever failing to be fitting. Thus, it is called heavenly joy.

Heavenly joy is the heart-mind of the sage, by which they nurture all under heaven.
**[Annotation]** What does the heart-mind of the sage use to nurture all under heaven? Heavenly joy.
**[Subcommentary]** The reason the sage descends to walk the same path as the common and harmonizes with the supreme joy of heaven and earth is precisely to nurture and sustain all living beings.

The virtue of emperors and kings takes heaven and earth as its model, the Dao and its power as its master, and non-action as its constant.
**[Subcommentary]** The ruler models themselves on heaven and earth, thus they cover and bear without intent; they take the Dao and its power as their master, thus they generate without possessing; though they undergo a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, they always remain non-active. Such abundant virtue is what made Yao a true lord.

Through non-action, they employ all under heaven with ease.
**[Annotation]** Ease refers to leisure.
Through action, they are employed by all under heaven yet remain insufficient.
**[Annotation]** Insufficiency refers to the anxious desire to be used by things. Desiring to be used by things, they can be made subjects. Yet when they become subjects, they too have ease.
**[Subcommentary]** Insufficiency is an expression of eagerness. Ease refers to leisure. When the lord practices non-action, their wisdom shines broadly, governing the realm with leisure to spare. When ministers act, their concerns are narrow and inferior, each attending to their duties, serving the lord without rest, yet still fearing insufficiency. Thus, non-action and action follow different paths of labor and rest. This is why the ancients valued non-action.

When those above practice non-action, those below also practice non-action—this means those below share the same virtue as those above. When those below share the same virtue as those above, they do not serve as subjects.
When those below act, those above also act—this means those above share the same path as those below. When those above share the same path as those below, they do not serve as lords.
**[Annotation]** The craftsman does not act in carving wood but acts in using the axe; the lord does not act in attending to affairs but acts in employing ministers. Ministers can attend to affairs, and lords can employ ministers; axes can carve wood, and craftsmen can use axes. Each fulfills their abilities, and thus the principle of heaven is spontaneous, not a matter of action.

If the lord takes up the affairs of ministers, he is no longer a lord; if ministers wield the lord’s authority, they are no longer ministers. Thus, when each attends to their own duties, the principle of non-action reaches its perfection in both above and below.

**[Annotation]** Non-action is the virtue of the ruler; action is the way of the minister. If both above and below practice non-action, ministers usurp the ruler’s virtue; if both above and below act, the ruler encroaches upon the minister’s way. When the ruler encroaches upon the minister’s way, he is no longer a lord; when ministers usurp the ruler’s virtue, how can they be called ministers? Thereupon, above and below become confused, lord and minister transgress their bounds, and having deviated from the natural order, disaster inevitably follows. Thus, the teaching of non-action must not be left unexamined.

Non-action belongs to the ruler. The ancients prized non-action. Guo’s commentary on this passage is most eloquent and reasoned. The one above must practice non-action to employ all under heaven, while the one below must act to be employed by all under heaven—this is an unchanging Dao.

**[Annotation]** The teaching of non-action must not be left unexamined. For the one who employs all under heaven, there is indeed an act of employing. Yet, attaining this act, one moves in accordance with their nature, and thus it is called non-action. Now, those who are employed by all under heaven also attain this naturally. But those below attend to affairs, so even when Yao or Yu served as ministers, they were still called men of action. Thus, in relation to above and below, the lord is quiescent while the minister is active; in comparison to past and present, Yao and Shun practiced non-action while Tang and Wu had affairs to attend to. Yet each acted according to their nature, and the mysterious workings of heaven’s mechanism were spontaneously manifest—then in ancient and modern times, above and below, who truly acted?

**[Annotation]** One who occupies the position above as lord must invariably practice non-action and entrust matters to others, employing the talents of all under heaven. One who dwells below as minister must attend to affairs and act, fulfilling the duties of their office—thus all under heaven is transformed. This is the unchanging Dao of the hundred kings. Therefore, the ancient kings who ruled all under heaven, though their wisdom embraced heaven and earth, did not scheme for themselves.

**[Annotation]** This refers to the Three Sovereigns and Five Emperors, the pure and ancient lords. Their wisdom was luminous and penetrating, encompassing the two poles, yet they reigned with folded arms and practiced non-action, delegating matters to their ministers. The wise devised strategies, so they did not scheme for themselves.

Though their eloquence adorned the myriad things, they did not speak for themselves.

**[Annotation]** Their vast eloquence flowed like a river, adorning the myriad things, yet they entrusted governance to their ministers and never spoke on their own behalf.

Though their abilities exhausted all within the seas, they did not act for themselves.

**[Annotation]** Those above rest in their inability to practice non-action by taking up the duties of their ministers. If the lord prevents Gaosi from exercising his keen judgment or Hou Ji from carrying out his planting, then talents lose their proper roles and the lord becomes entangled in toil. Thus, with the crown’s tassels veiling his eyes, he entrusts all to the world, and all under heaven act according to their own nature—this is non-action that accomplishes everything, so both above and below practice non-action. Yet the non-action of the one above employs those below, while the non-action of those below is self-employment.

**[Annotation]** Though their talents and abilities surpassed all within the seas, they entrusted them to worthy assistants and did not interfere—what was there to do but remain in profound silence? Thus, the *Laozi* says, "This is called employing the strength of others." Heaven does not produce, yet the myriad things are transformed; earth does not grow, yet the myriad things are nurtured.

**[Annotation]** That is, they are so of themselves.

**[Annotation]** Heaven has no intention to produce, yet the myriad things are transformed and born; earth has no mind to grow, yet the myriad things mature and flourish. Thus, Guo’s commentary says, "This is called being so of itself."

The lord and king practice non-action, yet the achievements of all under heaven are accomplished.

**[Annotation]** Achievements are completed by others.

**[Annotation]** The king, in harmony with the two poles’ nurturing, follows the four seasons in bestowing governance, and entrusts the myriad things to act on their own—thus the achievements of all under heaven are accomplished. Therefore, it is said: none is more divine than heaven, none richer than earth, none greater than the lord and king.

**[Annotation]** The sun and moon alternate in brightness and obscurity, clouds and thunder, wind and rain, all providing shelter and nourishment beyond measure—thus none is more divine than heaven. It encompasses rivers and plains, contains mountains and streams, and bears all without end—thus none is richer than earth. Occupying the position of nine and five, wielding the might of ten thousand chariots, with the sun and moon shining upon them, one person governs all—none surpasses the lord and king in greatness of power and virtue. Thus, the *Laozi* says, "Within the realm, four are great, and the king is one of them." Therefore, it is said: the virtue of the lord and king matches heaven and earth.

**[Annotation]** It is the same as the non-action of heaven and earth.

**[Annotation]** *Pei* means to match. The virtue of the sage matches the non-action of heaven and earth. This is the Dao of riding heaven and earth, driving the myriad things, and employing the talents of the people.

**[Annotation]** Comprehending the lordless spontaneity of heaven’s sheltering and earth’s bearing, one thus rides and governs the two poles.
