None acted, yet all acted—this is non-action. Not knowing why it was so, yet it was so—this is naturalness. Thus, at that time, humans embraced the virtue of non-action, and things accorded with the Dao of naturalness.

When virtue further declined,
**[Annotation]** The reason virtue declined was that sages did not succeed one another. Those in power could not practice non-action but envied the achievements of non-action, thus governance became corrupt.
it reached the time of Suiren and Fuxi, who first ruled the world—hence they followed but were not unified.
**[Annotation]** The world had already lost unity; some matters could not be undone, so they were resolved without insistence, merely followed.
**[Subcommentary]** *Reached* means "arrived." In ancient times, people ate raw meat and drank blood, living like deer. Then Suiren first changed raw to cooked, and Fuxi tamed oxen and rode horses, established kitchens, drew the Eight Trigrams, and created writing. Imitating spiders, he wove fine nets. From this, cunning and deceit sprouted; desires gradually arose, eroding the heart of purity and scattering the Dao of non-action. Virtue declined, and thus began ruling the world—this is what is meant. They followed the people’s hearts but could not merge into *perfect unity*.

When virtue declined further,
it reached the time of Shennong and the Yellow Emperor, who first ruled the world—hence they brought peace but did not follow.
**[Annotation]** They found peace in what was peaceful, and that was all.
**[Subcommentary]** As virtue and governance further declined, corruption worsened. Thus, Shennong fought Gonggong, and the Yellow Emperor battled Chiyou—ominous forces did not cease, and warfare frequently arose. Therefore, they punished the violent and removed the cruel, offering solace to the people and questioning the guilty—merely seeking to pacify the world, they could not fully follow the natural course of living beings.

When virtue declined still further,
it reached the time of Tang and Yu, who first ruled the world, initiating the flow of governance and culture, dissipating purity and scattering simplicity.
**[Annotation]** Sages have no fixed intent; they allow the world to fulfill itself. Whether it becomes pure or coarse depends not on the sages. Sages can only allow the world to attain its own fulfillment—how could they make the world attain the sages? Thus, the achievements of emperors and kings change with the times, while the Dao of sages remains ever whole.
**[Subcommentary]** Tang Yao and Yu Shun stood at the end of the Five Emperors and initiated the governance of the Three Kings. They established the Five Constants to regulate the five phases, appointed officials to govern the people—yet the people grew cunning, the five phases waned, and their branches and streams divided, continuing to this day. Was this not the destruction of purity to create artifice, the scattering of simplicity to fabricate falsity?

They departed from the Dao to pursue goodness,
**[Annotation]** *Goodness* is a term for exceeding what is fitting; thus, there is goodness, but the Dao is not whole.
**[Subcommentary]** The Dao of emptiness and penetration forgets both good and evil. Now, imitating others and boasting of one’s name in pursuit of goodness departs from principle—hence it is called *departure*.

and practiced virtue through perilous conduct.
**[Annotation]** *Practice* means acting contrary to nature; thus, conduct is established, but virtue is not level.
**[Subcommentary]** *Perilous* means treacherous. Unable to follow nature and act genuinely, concealing their traces, they feigned conduct to gain fame. Yet fame is superficial, so inner virtue became endangered—how could it remain pure and level?

Then they abandoned nature and followed the heart.
**[Annotation]** To be driven by the heart is to lose nature.
**[Subcommentary]** Departing from the Dao of emptiness and penetration, discarding the virtue of purity and harmony, they then abandoned natural nature and followed the discriminating heart.

Heart contended with heart,
**[Annotation]** Each heart strove to be first in discernment, no longer following nature.
**[Subcommentary]** Each heart schemed against the other, competing in judgment, right and wrong, praise and blame—vying to be first in discernment.

and knowledge was insufficient to bring order to the world.
**[Annotation]** Forgetting knowledge and following nature—this is true order.
**[Subcommentary]** The heart clings to objects, knowledge discriminates without end—the six directions become obscured by dust, the eight wilds surge in turmoil. Thus, the four seasons lose their order, and the three luminaries blaze with comets.

Thus is the source of calamity and chaos—how could it suffice to bring order to the world? Thereafter, they adorned it with culture and augmented it with erudition. Culture extinguished substance, erudition drowned the heart.

**[Annotation]** Culture and erudition are but ornaments of the heart’s substance.
**[Subcommentary]** Having already set the heart to wield knowledge, which proved insufficient to order the world, they then relied on written culture to rectify the times and multiplied learning to save the age—unaware that substance is the root of culture, and that florid embellishment obscures plain essence; that erudition is but the branch of the heart, and that vast learning submerges the spirit’s clarity. Only by cutting off learning and discarding culture can one attain the beauty of non-action. Thereafter, the people became deluded and disordered, unable to return to their nature and feelings or recover their origin.

**[Annotation]** Origin refers to the root of nature and destiny.
**[Subcommentary]** Once florid culture has extinguished plain essence and vast learning has drowned the heart’s clarity, the people then fall into turmoil. How could they return to their tranquil nature or restore their original, natural state?

Alas! The heart’s knowledge and cultural erudition are the fault. From this perspective, the world has lost the Way, and the Way has lost the world. World and Way mutually destroy one another.

**[Annotation]** The Way, being without esteem, can thus preserve the world. Yet if the world preserves it, it esteems the Way—and in esteeming it, the Way is lost. The Way cannot prevent the world from esteeming it, nor can the world cease to esteem the Way. Thus, they mutually destroy one another.
**[Subcommentary]** *Sang* means to abandon. Observing the course of events, one knows that the frivolous, floating world has discarded the Way of non-action, just as the Way of non-action has transformed the world’s simplicity and harmony. Thus, world and Way mutually destroy one another. How could the person of the Way arise in the world, or the world arise in the Way?

**[Annotation]** If not esteemed, they would mutually arise.
**[Subcommentary]** Therefore, the sage who embraces the Way withdraws from the dust of the vulgar, unwilling to arise and govern the world. And how could the frivolous, deceitful world be moved by the sagely Way? The Way has no means to arise in the world, nor the world any means to arise in the Way. Though the sage does not dwell in the mountains and forests, his virtue is hidden.

**[Annotation]** The reason he does not hide now is due to his sentiment to arise. How could he arise? By lacking esteem.
**[Subcommentary]** In this degenerate age, the Way of non-action is no longer practiced. Even if the sage who embodies the Way were to descend into the world and mingle with the common, none would recognize him. Concealing his sagely virtue, he would go unrecognized and unused. Though dwelling in the marketplace, how would he differ from the mountains and forests? Hidden, yet not by his own choice.

**[Annotation]** If one hides oneself yet employs things, then Way and world mutually arise—what hiding is there?
**[Subcommentary]** The times are benighted and chaotic, so the sagely Way does not prevail. Is this because the sage conceals his light and hides his virtue? The so-called recluses of old did not crouch in concealment and refuse to be seen, nor did they seal their words and refuse to speak, nor hide their knowledge and never express it. The fault lies in the great error of the times.

**[Annotation]** None know to return to the One and cease striving, but instead pursue advancement to seek the One. The more they strive, the more they lose the One—this is the great error. Though one were to rise and clarify it, open one’s mouth to speak, or display knowledge to express it, how could mutual arising come about? It would only lead to mutual destruction.
**[Subcommentary]** *Miu* means false and deluded. They did not conceal their bodies and refuse to appear—though appearing, they did not disturb the common; they did not seal their words and refuse to speak—though speaking, they did not offend others.

Those who do not conceal their wisdom and refuse to express it—though they express it, they do not flaunt it—yet encounter false and deluded times, their fate meeting with misfortune, thus follow the world’s rise and fall, preserving themselves and keeping harm at bay. When the times align with their fate and they flourish throughout the world—

**[Annotation]** This is a time of tranquility and stillness.
Then they return to the One without proximity;
**[Annotation]** They return to and entrust themselves to the nature of things, and the nature of things unites of itself—thus there is no entanglement.

**[Subcommentary]** When the times align with the Dao and fate rests in clarity and peace, they spread virtue and magnify transformation, flourishing throughout the world. As each person returns to the One and every thing reverts to its root, self and other merge in darkness—thus there is no trace of striving.

When the times do not align with their fate and they are greatly constrained throughout the world—
**[Annotation]** This is a time when tranquility and stillness cannot be attained.
Then they deepen their roots and settle into the utmost stillness to await;
**[Annotation]** Though it be an age of affairs, the sage has never not been tranquil and still—thus they deepen their roots and settle into the utmost stillness, awaiting things to unfold of themselves. This is how the Dao is not lost.

**[Subcommentary]** When the times are without the Dao and fate meets with excess and disorder, their virtue and transformation do not spread, and they are greatly constrained throughout the world. Yet they firmly establish the root of spontaneity, preserve and settle into the utmost nature, arrange themselves and follow change, abide in constancy and await the end of the year—how could success or failure bring joy or sorrow to them? This is the Way of preserving the self.

**[Annotation]** There has never been a case where the self was preserved and the world did not flourish.

**[Subcommentary]** Abiding in hardship yet ever joyful, dwelling in peril yet at peace—entrusting themselves to the times’ flourishing or concealment, this may be called the Way of preserving the self.

The ancients who preserved their selves did not employ eloquence to adorn knowledge;
**[Annotation]** They entrusted themselves to their true knowledge alone.
**[Subcommentary]** The ancients valued reticence over eloquence, prized action over words—thus those who preserved their selves did not rely on florid speech to embellish or on discriminating cleverness to adorn petty wisdom.

Nor did they use knowledge to constrain the world;
**[Annotation]** This is the disposition of tranquility and simplicity.

**[Subcommentary]** "Exhaustion" refers to being bound and burdened. They did not indulge in the poison of knowledge to bring suffering upon the common people. Nor did they use knowledge to exhaust virtue.
**[Annotation]** They guarded their self-attainment alone.
**[Subcommentary]** Knowing the limits of their allotment, they did not allow boundlessness to burden their self-attainment. Uprightly abiding in their place, they fulfilled their nature—what more was there to do?

**[Annotation]** "Uprightly" describes a solitary and steadfast demeanor.
**[Subcommentary]** "Upright" means solitary. Living alone amid a chaotic world, dwelling in peril yet ever at peace, their movements did not disturb stillness. Constantly returning to their natural nature, following it in action—what else was there to do? This speaks of their non-action.

The Dao is fundamentally not a petty practice;
**[Annotation]** It roams the level path.
**[Subcommentary]** The great Dao is vast and unobstructed, encompassing all without constraint. Petty accomplishments conceal the Dao—thus it is fundamentally not a petty practice.

Virtue is fundamentally not a petty discernment;
**[Annotation]** It is utterly and greatly penetrating.
**[Subcommentary]** Those of supreme virtue, whose wisdom pervades the myriad things, do not fix their attention on right and wrong to make petty judgments. Petty discernment harms virtue; petty practice harms the Dao.

**[Subcommentary]** Petty discernment and petty knowledge diminish the profound and mysterious abundance of virtue; petty learning and petty practice injure and destroy the vast and unobstructed great Dao. Thus it is said: rectify the self and that is all. "Joy in wholeness" is called "attaining one’s aspiration."

**[Annotation]** Attaining one’s aspiration means being content in one’s heart alone, free from the emotions of sorrow and joy—this is the wholeness of joy.
**[Subcommentary]** When one’s own conduct aligns with the right Dao, all actions become unobstructed. Then, without compliance or resistance, forgetting sorrow and joy, every endeavor is fitting—this is the wholeness of joy. Only when joy is wholly complete does one’s nature and aspiration attain fulfillment.

What the ancients called "attaining one’s aspiration" did not refer to noble rank and emolument, but rather to having nothing to add to their joy.
**[Annotation]** Being complete within and sufficient.
**[Subcommentary]** "Add" means to augment.

Chariots are called *xuan*; crowns are called *mian*. The ancients were simple and unadorned, embodying the Dao in non-action. Their fulfillment of aspiration lay in tranquility and equanimity, and their joy was not tied to chariots and crowns. Their joy was already sufficient—how could it require augmentation?

What people today call "attaining one’s aspiration" refers to chariots and crowns.
**[Subcommentary]** In this degenerate age, most are frivolous and superficial, craving splendor and rank, seeking contentment in such things. Thus, they regard donning crowns and riding chariots as the fulfillment of aspiration. Yet chariots and crowns are not of one’s nature and destiny; they are transient things that come by chance—mere lodgings.
**[Subcommentary]** *Transient* means arriving unexpectedly. Chariots and crowns, glory and splendor, are external to the self. What comes by chance is not of one’s nature and destiny—it is but a temporary lodging, how could it endure? When lodged, its coming cannot be warded off; its going cannot be halted.
**[Annotation]** They are external things—gain and loss do not pertain to the self.
**[Subcommentary]** When the time comes by chance, one casually assumes chariots and crowns; when fate dictates their departure, one calmly relinquishes glory and splendor. Since there is no intent to control or resist, how could there be attachment to retention or fear of loss? Thus, one does not indulge one’s aspirations for chariots and crowns,
**[Annotation]** One remains serene and unperturbed, unaware of their presence as lodgings.
nor does one follow worldly trends in poverty and constraint,
**[Annotation]** One remains open and self-content, unaware of poverty’s presence.
**[Subcommentary]** *Indulge* means to extend; *follow* means to vie. The ancients understood that prosperity and adversity were matters of destiny, and that glory and decay were not of the self. Even if chariots and crowns came their way, they were not enough to extend their joy; even in humble poverty, they did not vie with the clamorous world. Their joy was the same in both,
**[Annotation]** *Both* refers to chariots and crowns, and to poverty and constraint.
**[Subcommentary]** Chariots and crowns, poverty and constraint—both are transient. If one delights in chariots and crowns, one must also rejoice in poverty and constraint, for both are mere lodgings and thus the same. Therefore, one is without sorrow.
**[Annotation]** Nor is there joy in delight.
**[Subcommentary]** Not delighting in chariots and crowns, not suffering in poverty and constraint—accepting transformation as it comes, this is why one is without sorrow. If one is displeased when the lodging departs, then from this we see that even in joy, one is not without distraction.
**[Annotation]** If one is displeased when the lodging departs, then when it arrives, one is distracted—this is to let the external alter the internal.
**[Subcommentary]** People today, with their shallow understanding, rejoice when things come by chance and grieve when they depart. How do they not know that both are transient, that coming and going are mere lodgings? Constant sorrow, constant joy—thus, though they may rejoice, their hearts are never free from distraction. Therefore, it is said: those who lose themselves in things and forfeit their nature to custom are called "the people of inverted priorities."
**[Annotation]** Seeking the external at the expense of the internal is the height of inversion.
**[Subcommentary]** Coming and going by chance, now grieving, now rejoicing—if one subordinates oneself to things, how is this not loss? Chariots and crowns, poverty and constraint—all belong to the dust of the world. If one follows worldly custom and loses one’s original nature, turning from truth and the Dao, the fault lies in misplaced priorities. What they take as security is truly inversion.

Variorum editions note that the Zhang Junfang edition includes the characters *zhi you* (之有) after *ming* (命). The Zhejiang Library and Siku editions render the four characters *shen daozhi ye* (甚倒置也) as *qi daozhi ye* (其倒置也).

**Annotations and Commentary on the Southern Florescence Perfected Scripture, Scroll Nineteen**
**Guo Xiang of Henan, Annotation**
**Cheng Xuanying of the Tang, Master of Western Florescence, Subcommentary**
**Outer Chapters, "Autumn Floods," Seventeenth**

When autumn floods arrive, the hundred streams pour into the River. The vastness of its currents swells so that between its banks and isles, oxen and horses cannot be distinguished.

**[Annotation]** This speaks of its breadth.
**[Subcommentary]** The River refers to Meng Ford. *Jing* means "to flow through." *Yu* means "bank," and *ya* means "edge." *Zhu* means "islet"—a place in water that may be inhabited is called an islet. Great waters arise in spring and flourish in autumn. In the white autumn, yin darkness grows fierce, and heavy rains prevail, so that in autumn the waters arrive.

Thereupon, all valleys and streams pour into the Yellow River. Its flowing currents fill to overflowing, its waters vast. Its banks stretch wide, its isles lie distant, so that when gazing across the water, one cannot tell ox from horse.

Then the River Lord rejoices, delighting in himself, believing all the world’s beauty to be contained within him.

**[Subcommentary]** The River Lord is the spirit of the River. His surname is Feng, his given name Yi. He was a native of Tongguan Township in Huayin and attained the Dao of water immortality. Since the River was so vast, he rejoiced in his grandeur, thinking all the world’s glory and splendor resided in himself.

Following the current eastward, he came to the Northern Sea. Facing east and gazing out, he saw no end to the water. Then the River Lord turned his countenance, looked toward Ruo across the vast expanse, and sighed: "There is a rustic saying: 'Having heard a hundred ways of the Dao, one thinks none can compare to oneself.' This describes me."

**[Subcommentary]** The Northern Sea is present-day Laizhou. *Wangyang* means "indistinct." Water and sunlight reflect one another, hence *wangyang*. Ruo is the spirit of the sea. The River Lord, following the current eastward, reached the great sea. Glancing back, he saw no end to the water. Only then did he turn his countenance, gazing up at the sea spirit Ruo, and with a sigh, voiced his lament in rustic words. Though the hundred streams are but one ten-thousandth of the whole, they are truly not enough to boast of—yet he had believed none could compare to himself. This describes the River Lord. Such is the talk of the countryside, not a universal truth.

Moreover, I have heard of those who slight Confucius’s learning and belittle Boyi’s righteousness. At first, I did not believe it. Now that I have seen the boundlessness of your realm, had I not come to your gate, I would have remained deluded. I would long have been ridiculed by those of great attainment.

**[Annotation]** Knowing one’s smallness and not presuming grandeur—this is the natural order of principle. There is no place for arrogance in such matters.
**[Subcommentary]** The world regards Confucius, who edited and fixed the Six Classics, as one of vast learning and broad knowledge, and Boyi, who yielded his kingdom and lived in purity, as one whose righteousness is weighty. Yet there are those of insight and eloquence who, in lofty discourse, dismiss Boyi’s righteousness as trivial and Confucius’s learning as meager. The River Lord had heard of this but did not believe it. Now, seeing the vastness of the great sea, its boundlessness impossible to fathom, he realizes that what he had heard before was not baseless. Had the River Lord not come to the gate of the sea spirit Ruo, his affairs would have been in grave peril. His vision was narrow and inferior, so he would long have been mocked by those of the great Dao.

The sea spirit Ruo said: "You cannot speak of the sea to a frog in a well—it is constrained by its dwelling. You cannot speak of ice to a summer insect—it is bound by its season. You cannot speak of the Dao to a narrow-minded scholar—he is shackled by his teachings."

**[Annotation]** All things that arise and find peace do so within their own limits.
**[Subcommentary]** The sea spirit Ruo, knowing the River Lord’s limitations, offers three analogies. The frog in the well, hearing of the great sea with its hundred-foot waves even in calm winds, refuses to believe it—it is constrained by its dwelling. The insect born in summer dies when autumn comes. Hearing of winter’s time, when water turns to ice and rain congeals into sleet, it refuses to believe—its heart is thick with summer’s time. The narrow-minded scholar, a man of rigid views, hearing of the all-pervading Dao—of transcending sagacity and abandoning cunning, of making the tip of a hair great and Mount Tai small, of making the short-lived equal to Pengzu—refuses to believe. He is bound by the teachings of names and rituals. The River Lord, never having reached the great river, never having met the sea spirit Ruo, prided himself on his grandeur—his case is the same.

Now that you have emerged from your narrow confines and beheld the great sea, you know your own inadequacy. You may now be spoken to of great principles.

**[Annotation]** Because he knows his place, he may be spoken to of principle.
**[Subcommentary]** The River Lord, riding the waters and following the current, surpassed the banks and isles. Meeting the sea spirit Ruo, he gazed upon the boundless abyss of the vast sea and belittled the pettiness of his own river. Having realized the limits of his dwelling, he may now be spoken to of the all-pervading great principle.

Of all the waters under heaven, none is greater than the sea. The ten thousand streams flow into it, yet it never fills—one does not know when it will cease. Its tail-gate drains it, yet it never empties—one does not know when this will end. It remains unchanged through spring and autumn, unmoved by flood or drought. Its surpassing of the flow of the Yangtze and Yellow River cannot be measured.

**[Subcommentary]** The *weilu* is the place where the sea’s waters drain. It lies east of the Azure Sea. There is a stone there, forty thousand *li* wide and forty thousand *li* thick, situated at the tail end of the hundred streams, serving as a barrier—hence it is called the *weilu*. When the sea’s waters pour over it, they scorch it, so it is also called the Scorched Sea. The *Classic of Mountains and Seas* says: "Yi shot down nine suns, which fell and became the Scorched Sea."

This discourse is fanciful and will not be discussed in detail here. In spring, the rains are scant; in autumn, they are abundant. Yao suffered floods, while Tang endured drought. Thus, the sea as a thing receives the flow of all rivers yet never fills; though the Scorched Sea drains it, it never empties. Through spring and autumn, its volume remains unchanged; in flood or drought, its rise and fall go unnoticed. In its vastness, it far surpasses the flow of the Yangtze and Yellow River—how could one speak of measuring its superiority or inferiority?

Yet I have never taken pride in this, for I compare my form to Heaven and Earth and receive my qi from yin and yang. I exist between Heaven and Earth as a mere pebble or twig upon a great mountain. Even as I recognize my own smallness, why should I take pride?

**[Annotation]** When one measures the capacity of all rivers against the Yellow River, and the Yellow River against the sea, and the sea against Heaven and Earth, each has its own measure.

This rhetoric seems to suggest that observing the great can clarify the small, but upon closer examination, it does not. What the world finds troubling is not levelness. Thus, those of great stature blithely dismiss the small as nothing, while those of small stature stubbornly declare the great to be utterly sufficient. This leads to boasting above and below, to self-doubt in looking up and down—such is the confusion of the people. To correct this confusion, nothing is better than first exhausting the differences between things and then following their inherent claims.

What is called "great" is utterly sufficient, so even an autumn hair cannot burden Heaven and Earth. What is called "small" has nothing in excess, so Heaven and Earth cannot surpass an autumn hair. Only then can the confused find their way back, each knowing its limit. Things rest in their allotted places, and those who wander freely use their natural steps to roam in the realm of self-contentment. This is how Zhuangzi gives voice to virtue.

If, as the confused claim, one were to constantly weigh small against great, the mutual overthrow would never end. If one gazes upon the great yet cannot be content with the small, or looks upon the small and takes pride in it, one will rush into the realm of victory and defeat, aiding the world’s people in their arrogance. How could this be in accord with Zhuangzi’s intent?

**[Subcommentary]** *Cun* means "to exist." *Xi* means "how." There is nothing greater than Heaven and Earth in covering and supporting the myriad things, nothing greater than yin and yang in setting boundaries and engendering transformation. Thus, when the Sea Spirit compares its form to Heaven and Earth, there is no rank in which to place it. To say it receives its dark essence from yin and yang is to treat it as one thing among yin and yang’s manifestations. Using things as metaphors, it is like a small stone or twig upon Mount Tai. Thus, the Sea Spirit, in the principle of Heaven, exists in scarcity. Each thing has its measure—how could it be cause for pride?

Consider the Four Seas within Heaven and Earth—are they not like a sunbeam’s gap in a great marsh? Consider the Central States within the seas—are they not like a grain of *ti* rice in a vast granary?

**[Subcommentary]** *Xunkong* refers to an ant’s nest. *Ti* is a grass resembling *pai*, but its grains are exceedingly fine. The Central States refer to the Nine Provinces. The Four Seas within Heaven and Earth, the Nine Provinces within the Four Seas—are they not like an ant’s hole in a great marsh, a grain of *ti* rice in a vast granary? Such is the disparity in their greatness and smallness.

The number of things is called "ten thousand," and humans are one among them. Humans gather in the Nine Provinces, where grain is grown and boats and carts travel—yet humans are but one among them. Compared to the ten thousand things, is this not like the tip of a hair on a horse’s body?

**[Annotation]** The distinction between small and great has its own gradations; they cannot be transgressed.

**[Subcommentary]** *Hao* means "to name." *Zu* means "multitude." The number of things is not limited to ten thousand, but in worldly speech, the ten thousand things are often mentioned. Humans are one thing among these ten thousand. The Nine Provinces are where people gather, where the hundred grains grow, where boats and carts travel—yet among the ten thousand things, humans are but one. Thus, comparing humans to the ten thousand things, the Nine Provinces to the cosmos, is no different from a single hair on a horse’s body. How could this be worth concern?

The connections of the Five Emperors, the struggles of the Two Kings, the worries of the benevolent, the labors of the capable—all are confined to this.

**[Annotation]** They do not extend beyond a single domain.

**[Subcommentary]** The Five Emperors passed the throne in succession, the Three Kings waged war in competition, the wise worried over the altars of soil and grain, the capable toiled in their duties. Though their endeavors differed, all were exhausted within the tip of a hair. Boyi refused the throne to make a name for himself; Confucius discoursed on the *Six Classics* to display his vast knowledge. In their self-pride, are they not like the River Spirit’s earlier boasting of its waters?

**[Annotation]** Things have their fixed domains; even the most knowledgeable cannot transcend them. Thus, the distinction between great and small is meant to clarify that the ultimate principle has no gradations.

**[Subcommentary]** Boyi declined the five ranks to establish his reputation; Confucius expounded on the *Six Classics* to demonstrate his erudition. Taking these lightly and priding oneself on them—how is this different from the River Spirit’s earlier boasting of its waters? This comprehensively unites the earlier metaphors and revisits the earlier point about belittling Confucius’s learning and Boyi’s righteousness.

The River Spirit said: "Then may I consider myself great as Heaven and Earth and small as the tip of a hair?"

**[Subcommentary]** In form, nothing is greater than Heaven and Earth; in substance, nothing is smaller than the tip of a hair. Thus, the extremes of great and small are used to show that allotted portions differ. The River Spirit presents what it has understood and inquires of the Sea Spirit.

Another interpretation: If sufficiency is considered great, then I may be greater than the Two Forces. If having nothing in excess is considered small, then I may be smaller than the tip of a hair.

The River Spirit, having grasped this, equalizes self and other to dispel its confusion and asks whether this is permissible.

The Sea Spirit of the Northern Sea said: "No."

For things, their measures are boundless.

**[Commentary]** Each thing has its own measure.

**[Subcommentary]** Having grasped the doubt, the answer is "no." The capacity of things differs according to their allotted portions; each receives what it is given and finds its proper measure. Yet with a thousand differences and ten thousand distinctions, their kinds are infinite. In their proper measure, there is neither great nor small—how could one arbitrarily impose what one knows and take it as fixed?

Time does not cease.

**[Commentary]** Death and life are both the movement of time.

**[Subcommentary]** Renewing without end.

Allotment is not constant.

**[Commentary]** Gain and loss are both allotment.

**[Subcommentary]** The allotted mandate one receives changes with time.

Beginning and end are not fixed.

**[Commentary]** Ever-renewing.

**[Subcommentary]** Though it ends only to begin again, it is never not new.

Thus, the great in wisdom observes both far and near, so the small is not deficient,

**[Commentary]** Each is self-sufficient.

**[Subcommentary]** The following explains the boundlessness of measure. With the wisdom of the great sage, one observes distant principles and examines nearby affairs. Thus, though the tip of a hair is small, in its own body it is self-sufficient, lacking nothing.

and the great is not excessive.

**[Commentary]** Nor does it have surplus.

**[Subcommentary]** Though Heaven and Earth are vast, in their own body they have no surplus, and thus are not sufficient to be considered excessive. Without excess, there is no boasting; without deficiency, there is no longing. Knowing measure is boundless,

**[Commentary]** Observing and examining, one knows that things both far and near, great and small, each have their measure.

**[Subcommentary]** With the wisdom of the great person, one knows the measure of things. Though great and small differ, each accords with its nature. Their names differ, and thus they are boundless. This concludes the previous point on the boundlessness of things’ measure.

Verifying the present by the past,

**[Commentary]** *Wu* means "to clarify." *Jin gu* means "past and present."

**[Subcommentary]** The following explains the ceaselessness of time. *Wu* means "to clarify." Having known that small and great are not truly small or great, one thereby clarifies that past and present are not truly past or present. Thus, though distant, one is not perplexed;

**[Commentary]** *Yao* means "long."

though brief, one is not divided.

**[Commentary]** *Rang* means "short."

**[Subcommentary]** *Yao* means "long," *rang* means "short." Having known that past and present are not truly past or present, one knows that long life and early death are not truly long or short. Thus, though one’s years and mandate extend long, one never wearies of life or seeks answers; though one’s allotted span is brief, one does not rejoice in or long for distant longevity. Following change and submitting to transformation, one has never not been oneself. Knowing time does not cease,

**[Commentary]** Clarifying past and present, one knows that transformation does not stop at death and life. Thus, one does not seek answers because of length nor stumble because of brevity.

**[Subcommentary]** This concludes the previous point on the ceaselessness of time.

Examining fullness and emptiness, one gains without delight and loses without sorrow.

**[Subcommentary]** The following explains the inconstancy of allotment. Since the Way of Heaven has fullness and emptiness, how could human affairs lack gain and loss? Thus, observing the changes of fullness and emptiness and understanding the principle of gain and loss, one may happen to gain—this is a matter of time, not cause for joy; one may happen to lose—this is a matter of mandate, not cause for grief. Knowing allotment is inconstant,

**[Commentary]** Observing the alternation of fullness and emptiness, one knows that allotment is not constant in gain. Thus, one can forget both sorrow and joy.

**[Subcommentary]** This concludes the previous point on the inconstancy of allotment.

Illuminating the level path,

**[Commentary]** Death and life are the proper Way of daily renewal.

**[Subcommentary]** The following explains the unfixedness of beginning and end. *Tan* means "level," *tu* means "path." Not taking death as death, not taking life as life, death and life are without barrier. Such is the illumination of the great, level, and equal Way. Thus, living, one does not rejoice; dying, one does not consider it a calamity.

**[Subcommentary]** For one who illuminates the level Way, life is not cause for joy, nor is death cause for ruin. Having penetrated the non-duality of death and life, what sorrow or joy could there be to discuss? Knowing beginning and end cannot be fixed,

**[Commentary]** Illuminating the daily renewal of beginning and end, one knows that the fixed cannot be grasped or retained. Thus, one traverses daily renewal without surprise, relinquishes the old without alarm, and the transformation of death and life is as one.

**[Subcommentary]** This concludes the previous point on the unfixedness of beginning and end.

Calculating what people know, it does not compare to what they do not know.

**[Commentary]** What is known has its limits.

**[Subcommentary]** Forced knowing departs from the real; not-knowing accords with the Way. By this calculation, one should indeed not compare.

The time of their life does not compare to the time before they were born.

**[Commentary]** The time of life has its years.

**[Subcommentary]** Before birth, there is no joy and thus no sorrow; after birth, there is attachment and thus aversion. To seek to exhaust the realm of the utmost great with the utmost small is to become confused and unable to attain oneself.

**[Commentary]** There is nothing better than to rest in one’s allotted portion.

**[Subcommentary]** The utmost small is wisdom; the utmost great is the realm. To seek the boundless realm of the great with the limited wisdom of the small—before the boundless realm is encompassed, the limited wisdom is already lost. Thus, one is confused for a lifetime, with no way to return to the root, losing oneself in longing for things and failing to attain oneself.

Thus, how could one know that the tip of a hair suffices to determine the limit of the finest? How could one know that Heaven and Earth suffice to exhaust the realm of the greatest?

**[Commentary]** Seeking the great with the small, one ultimately cannot attain it. Each resting in its allotted portion, both great and small are sufficient. If the tip of a hair did not seek the achievement of Heaven and Earth, then the surplus of the whole body would all be discarded things. If Heaven and Earth did not see themselves as greater than an autumn hair, then regarding their form and image, they would merely be self-sufficient. How then could one know the fineness of the fine or the greatness of the great?

**[Subcommentary]** The allotted portions of things each differ; though great and small are distinct, all find their proper measure.

If one seeks the great with the small, one becomes deluded and loses one’s nature; each resting in its allotted portion, both achieve the same freedom. Thus, though the tip of a hair is small, its nature may be called great; though the Two Modes are vast, they have no surplus that could be called small. From this perspective, how can the limit of the finest be definitively fixed in the tip of a hair, or the realm of the greatest be exhausted by Heaven and Earth?

The River Earl said: “Those who discuss such matters in the world all say: ‘The most refined has no form; the greatest cannot be encompassed.’ Is this a true reflection of reality?”

**[Subcommentary]** *True* means real. Common discourse has not yet distinguished right from wrong, asserting that the most refined and subtle lacks form and substance, while the most vast and boundless cannot be encircled. It does not know whether this principle is a matter of genuine insight or mere conjecture. The River Earl, not yet understanding, thus raises this doubt.

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: “One who views the great from the perspective of the small cannot exhaust it; one who views the small from the perspective of the great cannot clarify it.”

**[Commentary]** The eye’s vision has a fixed limit and cannot extend infinitely. Thus, regarding the great, there is always something it cannot exhaust; regarding the small, there is always something it cannot clarify. This is simply what the eye cannot reach. Both the refined and the vast are not nonexistent—how could one rashly claim that what has no form cannot be encompassed?

**[Subcommentary]** When a small form gazes upon a vast object, it can never fully grasp its vastness, hence it is said to be “unencircled.” When a vast object observes a small form, it cannot clearly discern its details, hence it is said to have “no form or substance.” These are merely limitations of the realm of existence—how could they represent the meaning of ultimate nonexistence? The refined is the subtlest of the small; the vast is the most expansive of the great—thus their conveniences differ.

**[Commentary]** Great and small differ, so their conveniences cannot be the same.

**[Subcommentary]** *Refined* means subtle and small; *vast* means expansive and great. To clarify that the smallest of the small and the greatest of the great, though differing in the qi they receive, do not depart from having form, the natural mechanism unfolds, each with its proper convenience. This is the condition of existence.

**[Commentary]** If there were no form and it could not be encompassed, there would be no such differing conveniences.

**[Subcommentary]** Since great and small differ, their conveniences also vary—thus we know this condition has not transcended the realm of existence. The refined and the coarse are bound to having form.

**[Commentary]** Where there is refinement and coarseness, there cannot be an absence of form.

**[Subcommentary]** When speaking of the refined and the coarse, one is always confined to the realm of form and name, never transcending the bounds of language and image. What has no form cannot be divided by calculation; what cannot be encompassed cannot be exhausted by calculation.

**[Subcommentary]** What has no form and cannot be encompassed is the Dao. The profound mystery of the supreme Dao is beyond mind and form, thus it cannot be distinguished by names or numbers, nor can it be exhausted by calculation. What can be discussed in words is the coarse aspect of things; what can be grasped by intention is the refined aspect of things. What cannot be discussed in words or grasped by intention does not pertain to refinement or coarseness.

**[Commentary]** It is merely nonexistence—what refinement or coarseness could there be? Words and intentions belong to existence, but what they express is nonexistence. Thus, to seek it beyond words and intentions is to enter the realm of no-words and no-intentions, and only then does one reach it.

**[Subcommentary]** What can be debated and discussed in words is the coarse principle of existing things; what can be attained by the mind’s intention is the refined subtlety of existing things. Yet what the spirit cannot express and the sage’s heart cannot fathom is the wondrous principle. To seek it beyond words and intentions—how could it be confined to the realm of refinement and coarseness?

Therefore, the conduct of the great person does not involve harming others.

**[Commentary]** The great person has no intentions but follows the movement of Heaven. With every step, they tread upon auspicious ground—how could they walk the path of harming others?

**[Subcommentary]** The great person responds to things as Heaven moves, acting without intention. Thus, they tread upon auspicious ground, speak words that benefit others, and never harm anyone. They do not excessively display benevolence and kindness.

**[Commentary]** They do no harm and do not boast of their kindness.

**[Subcommentary]** Their compassion is like the spring sun, yet they do not excessively display their benevolent actions. Their actions are not for profit.

**[Subcommentary]** They act in accordance with principle, and principle itself is free from harm.

**[Subcommentary]** They respond to the moment without confining their heart to benefiting others. They do not despise gatekeepers and servants.

**[Commentary]** They assign tasks according to ability, and the position is fitting—not because they despise them and thus place them in such roles.

**[Subcommentary]** They blend honor and disgrace, unite poverty and success, and thus do not consider guarding gates or serving as menial labor to be base. They do not contend over wealth and property.

**[Commentary]** Each is given their allotted share.

**[Subcommentary]** With few desires and contentment, they keep to their portion and do not covet, thus never contending over wealth and property. They do not excessively practice yielding and deference.

**[Commentary]** They simply act appropriately.

**[Subcommentary]** They follow their nature with humility and harmony, adapting to things without pretense, never forcing their conduct or embellishing their words with excessive deference. In their affairs, they do not rely on others.

**[Commentary]** Each is made to fulfill their own responsibilities.

**[Subcommentary]** Whether foolish or wise, they follow their nature; whether skilled or clumsy, they act according to their feelings, never borrowing from others or seeking tasks beyond their portion. They do not excessively consume through labor.

**[Commentary]** They are content with sufficiency.

**[Subcommentary]** They consume what is within their portion, being content with sufficiency, never excessively seeking or exhausting their mental and physical strength. They do not despise the greedy and corrupt.

**[Commentary]** Principle itself is free from desire.

**[Subcommentary]** They embody the profound Dao, thus having no passions or desires—not because they hypocritically value purity and despise corruption. Their conduct differs from the common.

**[Commentary]** They alone have no preferences, no aversions—this is why they differ from the common.

**[Subcommentary]** They harmonize with the world without being stained, having no preferences or aversions, yet remaining unstained amidst defilement—thus their conduct differs from the common.

They do not excessively deviate from the norm;
**[Commentary]** They follow principle and naturally differ.
**[Subcommentary]** Abiding in correctness and embodying the Dao, they do not indulge in perversity, yet greatly accord with all beings—thus they never deviate or differ.

Their actions follow the multitude;
**[Commentary]** They follow what the multitude does.
**[Subcommentary]** The perfected have no fixed intent, never insisting on their own way; thus in all their conduct, they strive to follow the multitude.

They do not despise the obsequious;
**[Commentary]** They are naturally upright.
**[Subcommentary]** Their nature is loyal and steadfast, never treading the crooked path—not because they first despise flattery and then become upright.

The world’s ranks and emoluments cannot serve as incentives, nor can punishments and disgrace serve as humiliations;
**[Commentary]** External affairs do not touch their hearts.
**[Subcommentary]** High office and generous stipends are deemed honorable by the world; execution and demotion are deemed shameful. Yet they perceive glory and decay as not pertaining to the self, and understand that success and failure have their seasons. What comes is not enough to spur them, nor what departs enough to shame them.

They know that right and wrong cannot be taken as fixed divisions, nor can the fine and the vast be taken as boundaries.
**[Commentary]** Thus they merge in profound sameness.
**[Subcommentary]** Each clings to right and wrong, so right and wrong cannot be fixed divisions; each deems itself great or small, so how can fine and vast have boundaries? This is what is meant by "heaven and earth" and "the tip of a hair."

It is said: The Dao-person is unheard of;
**[Commentary]** They let things be, and the nature of things flows freely—thus merit and fame return to things, and so they are unheard of.
**[Subcommentary]** The sage who embodies the Dao conceals brilliance and obscures traces, attributing success to things—thus no merit or fame can be heard of them. Hence the saying, "It is said."

The utmost virtue is not attained;
**[Commentary]** "Attainment" arises from loss; when nothing is lost, the name of "attainment" vanishes.
**[Subcommentary]** "Attainment" is the name for not losing. The one who reaches the ultimate level is equal in gain and loss—having nothing to lose, they also have nothing to attain. Thus the *Laozi* says, "The highest virtue is not virtuous."

The great person has no self.
**[Commentary]** They simply let things be.
**[Subcommentary]** The great sage responds to stimuli, adapting to things like water taking shape—thus they have no self.

This is the utmost of adhering to one’s portion.
**[Commentary]** Adhering to the utmost of one’s portion, they become obscure—only the utterly formless and unbounded can achieve this.
**[Subcommentary]** *Yue* means "to adhere"; *fen* means "limit." The great person benefits things, and though their paths are many, in essence, nothing precedes adhering to one’s portion. Like the eye seeing only what it can see, the ear hearing only what it can hear, knowing only what it can know, and limiting itself to its portion—this is the utmost of virtue.

The River Lord said: Beyond things, within things—where do the distinctions of noble and base arise? Where do the boundaries of small and great arise?
**[Subcommentary]** "Beyond things, within things" refers to the inner and outer of the nature of things. *Wu* means "where." The divisions of noble and base, the boundaries of small and great—do they lie within the nature of things, or beyond the portion of life? To what place do they extend?

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: Viewed through the Dao, things have no noble or base;
**[Commentary]** Each is sufficient in itself.
**[Subcommentary]** The Dao is the wondrous principle of emptiness and penetration; things are the cumbersome affairs of form and obstruction. Viewing the wondrous through the cumbersome yields great and small; viewing the cumbersome through the wondrous yields no noble or base.

Viewed through things, each deems itself noble and others base;
**[Commentary]** These trivial distinctions are what the Dao interweaves and equalizes.
**[Subcommentary]** The deluded emotions of things are inverted, confused by right and wrong. Each desires to be noble and deems others base; others likewise deem themselves noble and others base. With mutual delusion, it is called "each."

Viewed through custom, noble and base do not lie within oneself.
**[Commentary]** This is what is called inversion.
**[Subcommentary]** Glory and disgrace arise unpredictably, yet the vulgar are deluded by them. Thus what comes is deemed noble, and its attainment a blessing; what departs is deemed base, and its loss a humiliation. This is how honor and disgrace depend on external things—how can noble and base lie within oneself?

Viewed through differentiation, if you take what is great in each and deem it great, then nothing in the world is not great; if you take what is small in each and deem it small, then nothing in the world is not small. Knowing that heaven and earth are like a grain of rice, and the tip of a hair like a mountain, is to view through differentiation.
**[Commentary]** What is "great" is sufficient; what is "small" is without excess. Thus, following its sufficient nature to name it great, even the tip of a hair and a mountain cannot differ in name; following its lack of excess to call it small, even heaven and earth and a grain of rice cannot differ in designation. If one does not observe differentiation through this Dao, then distinctions multiply, the minute and subtle tilt against each other, and they cannot be exhaustively examined.
**[Subcommentary]** *Cha* means "distinction." If sufficiency is taken as great, then the tip of a hair and a mountain are equally great; if lack of excess is taken as small, then heaven and earth and a grain of rice are equally small. Thus, if you take the tip of a hair as great, nothing in the world is not great; if you take heaven and earth as small, nothing in the world is not small. Though there may be a thousand distinctions and ten thousand gradations, differing in measure, when viewed thus, the principle is evident.

Viewed through function, if you take what each possesses and deem it possessing, then nothing in the world does not possess; if you take what each lacks and deem it lacking, then nothing in the world does not lack. Knowing that east and west are opposites yet cannot be without each other, the division of function is determined.
**[Commentary]** All under heaven mutually regard each other as self and other, and both self and other desire to act for themselves—this is the opposition of east and west.

Yet though self and other stand as lips and teeth, they do not act for each other—yet when the lips perish, the teeth grow cold. Thus, when the other acts for itself, its aid to me is vast indeed. This is the very principle of opposition where neither can do without the other. Therefore, if we take their self-directed action and deny its function, then all functions under heaven are nullified; if we acknowledge their mutual indispensability and affirm its function, then all functions under heaven are realized.

Now, should one forget the function of self-directed action and dwell instead on the favor of mutual aid, the more diligently such favor is pursued, the more shallow and artificial it becomes. The world loses its proper work, and human nature overflows in chaos—thus, the division of function can never be settled.

**[Commentary]** East and west differ in direction and stand in opposition, yet without east, west cannot be established—this is their mutual indispensability. If we examine the body: the eyes see, the ears hear, the hands grasp, the feet walk; the five viscera, six bowels, four limbs, and hundred parts each possess their own function, all adhering to their fixed roles. How could the eyes see for the ears, or the feet walk for the hands? The function of mutual aid is thus rendered void. This is taking what each lacks and deeming it lacking—nothing in the world does not lack.

Yet if the feet cease to walk, the four limbs grow weary; if the eyes cease to see, the whole body is obstructed. Each part performs its own duty without intent to aid the other, yet the other’s function is naturally fulfilled. This is taking what each possesses and deeming it possessing—nothing in the world does not possess. Viewed thus, function exists, and each role is fixed.

Should one forget the function of self-directed action and dwell instead on the favor of mutual aid, self and other lose their nature, and right and wrong become confused—how could this align with Zhuangzi’s intent?

From the perspective of inclination: if we take what each affirms and affirm it, then nothing in the world is not affirmed; if we take what each denies and deny it, then nothing in the world is not denied. Knowing that Yao and Jie naturally oppose each other, the inclinations of their natures become evident.

**[Commentary]** All things are natural, thus nothing is not so; all things oppose each other, thus nothing is not opposed. If nothing is not opposed, then nothing is affirmed; if nothing is not so, then nothing is denied. He who affirms nothing and denies nothing is Yao; he who affirms and denies is Jie. Yet these two rulers each received their innate nature from heaven and cannot act for one another. Thus, observing Yao and Jie reveals the inclinations of all under heaven—it is evident that they cannot act for each other.

**[Commentary]** "So" means "thus." All things affirm themselves, thus nothing is not affirmed; all things oppose each other, thus nothing is not opposed. If nothing is not opposed, then nothing under heaven is affirmed; if nothing is not affirmed, then nothing under heaven is opposed. Therefore, observing the inclinations of things: if we take what each affirms and affirm it, then nothing in the world is not affirmed; if we take what each opposes and oppose it, then nothing in the world is not opposed.

The most extreme opposites under heaven are Yao and Jie. Thus, these two rulers illustrate the duality of affirmation and denial. Yao regarded non-action as right and desire as wrong; Jie regarded non-action as wrong and desire as right. Hence, it is said that Yao and Jie naturally oppose each other. From this, the inclinations and dispositions of all things under heaven can be seen.

Of old, Yao and Shun yielded and became emperors, while Zizhi yielded and perished.

**[Commentary]** Emperors of different eras, yielding and contending arose in different times. Yao, knowing the Mandate of Heaven had a successor, abdicated to Shun; Shun, knowing the dynastic succession would change, yielded to Yu. Tang and Yu were among the Five Emperors, hence it is said they "yielded and became emperors."

Zizhi was the chancellor of Yan. King Kuai was the ruler of Yan. Zizhi was the son-in-law of Su Qin. Su Qin’s younger brother, Su Dai, came from Qi to Yan and, citing the precedent of Yao yielding to Xu You, persuaded King Kuai to abdicate to Zizhi. Zizhi accepted, but the people resented his usurpation and refused to submit. After three years of chaos, King Xuan of Qi, following Su Dai’s counsel, sent troops to invade Yan. They killed King Kuai in the suburbs and executed Zizhi in the court, extinguishing the state of Yan. Was this not the consequence of emulating Yao and Shun’s yielding, bringing disaster to this extent?

Tang and Wu contended and became kings; the Duke of Bai contended and was destroyed.

**[Commentary]** Those who follow heaven and respond to the people to receive the world advance through the path of contention and yielding. Yet those who seek advancement lose the very means by which they advance—hence, they perish.

**[Commentary]** Tang of Yin overthrew Jie, and Wu of Zhou conquered Zhou, these two rulers both received the Mandate of Heaven. Thus, they brought peace to the six directions and all states came to pay homage, succeeding the Three Kings—hence it is said they "contended and became kings." Yet at times, force is required, as with Tang and Wu; at other times, yielding is called for, as with Yao and Shun. Thus, amidst endless change, one responds to circumstances without clinging to yielding or contending.

The Duke of Bai, named Sheng, was the grandson of King Ping of Chu and the son of Crown Prince Jian. King Ping, swayed by Fei Wuji’s words, took a daughter of Qin and estranged the crown prince, who fled to Zheng. There, he married a woman of Zheng and fathered Sheng. After the execution of his tutor Wu She, Wu Zixu fled to Wu, and Sheng followed, plowing with him in the fields. Later, the Chu minister Zixi welcomed Sheng back to the state and enfeoffed him at Bai, where he usurped the title of duke. Sheng, seeking vengeance for his father’s death at the hands of the people of Zheng, requested troops for retribution but was repeatedly denied. He then raised an army in rebellion. Chu sent the Viscount of Ye, Zigao, to suppress and destroy him—hence it is said the Duke of Bai "contended and was destroyed."

From this, it is clear that the rites of contention and yielding, the conduct of Yao and Jie, have their proper times—neither can be taken as constant.

**[Commentary]** Contention and yielding are the ways of martial and civil virtue. Yao and Jie represent affirmation and denial. When ordering heaven and earth, one values the civil and devalues the martial...

If one seeks to quell calamity and disorder, then the civil is devalued and the martial is prized. Thus, the Dao of civil and martial virtue has its times of honor and disgrace, just as the conduct of affirmation and denial has its moments of application and abandonment. Therefore, the rites of contention and yielding are honored in the eras of Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu, but despised in the times of Zhi and the Duke of Bai—they cannot be taken as constant.

A roof beam may batter down city walls, yet it cannot plug a rat hole: this speaks of differing implements. A fine steed like Qiji or Lüli may gallop a thousand *li* in a day, yet it is no match for a wildcat in catching mice: this speaks of differing skills. The owl snatches fleas at night and discerns the tip of a hair, yet by day it stares wide-eyed and fails to see a mountain: this speaks of differing natures.

**[Commentary]** If one employs each according to its difference, then the myriad things will all find their proper place.

Thus it is said: "Why insist on affirming only what one deems right and denying all else? Why insist on order alone and reject all disorder?" This is to fail to comprehend the principles of heaven and earth and the dispositions of the myriad things.

**[Commentary]** The principles of heaven and earth and the dispositions of the myriad things take attaining the self as right and losing the self as wrong, following one’s nature as order and losing harmony as disorder. Yet things have no fixed limits, the self has no constant fit, natures differ and conveniences vary—affirmation and denial have no fixed ground. If one insists on one’s own rightness, then others cannot be wrong: this is merely knowing the self and not seeing others. Thus, from the perspective of the Dao, there is no fixed position on affirmation and denial. Entrusting them to heaven and earth, letting both proceed freely, then the diverse directions and disparate kinds will all attain their due.

**[Commentary]** "Why insist" is an expression of incompleteness. To "insist" is to follow one’s own heart. Each thing follows its own heart, stubbornly clinging to bias—taking the self as right without knowing others deem it wrong, taking the self as ordered without knowing things deem it disordered. Thus, to insist on rightness is to fail to see that one’s own position may be wrong; to insist on order is to claim one’s own state is free of disorder. How can one know that order and disorder share a common source, that affirmation and denial have no fixed ground? For order and disorder share a common source: this is the principle of heaven and earth. Affirmation and denial have no fixed ground: this is the disposition of the myriad things. To align with this truth is what is meant by "failing to comprehend."

This is like insisting on heaven without earth, or on yin without yang—its impossibility is manifest.

**[Commentary]** Heaven and earth, yin and yang, exist in mutual opposition. If there were heaven without earth, the myriad things would not come to be; if there were yin without yang, living beings would not arise. Thus, to insist on rightness without wrong, or order without disorder, is clearly unworkable. Yet to persist in such speech without ceasing is either folly or deceit.

**[Commentary]** Heaven and earth, yin and yang, arise in mutual dependence; affirmation and denial, order and disorder, each contains the other. What, then, is to be discarded?

**[Commentary]** To speak thus without restraint is either the height of ignorance or deliberate falsehood.

The abdications of the Five Emperors and the successions of the Three Dynasties each differed. Those who missed their time or defied custom were called usurpers.

**[Commentary]** The Five Emperors and the Three Kings had distinct modes of abdication. The Three Dynasties—Xia, Yin, and Zhou—had distinct modes of succession. Some passed rule within the clan, others yielded to different lineages: hence "distinct abdications." Some succeeded father to son, others seized power by force: hence "distinct successions." Some acted too soon or too late, out of step with the times; others failed to win the people’s allegiance, defying human affairs. Thus, Zhi imitated Yao and Shun to cut off his line, and the Duke of Bai emulated Tang and Wu to bring about his own destruction—such cases are called usurpation.

Those who met their time and followed custom were called men of righteousness.

**[Commentary]** The ways of weapons and yielding differ, their use has its time, and they cannot be rigidly held. Yet when Tang and Wu took up arms, or Yao and Shun yielded, they aligned above with the Dao of heaven and below with the hearts of the people—such men are called righteous.

Silent now, River Lord! How could you know the gate of honor and disgrace, the house of small and great?

**[Commentary]** What the world honors may later be despised; what is deemed great in one age may be deemed small in another. Thus, following the advance of things, one cannot but differ—this is why the Five Emperors and Three Kings did not act alike.

**[Commentary]** The River Lord has yet to grasp the principle, so the Ocean Spirit rebukes him to forget words and fall silent. Do not waste breath! For small and great have no fixed ground, honor and disgrace no fixed gate; the dispositions of things are inverted, recklessly affirmed or denied. How, then, could you trace and know the gate of honor and disgrace, the house of small and great? This is to say you do not know.

The River Lord said: "Then what should I do? What should I not do? How should I decide what to accept or reject, what to pursue or abandon? In the end, what am I to do?"

The River Lord, though he has grasped the lofty principle, has yet to reach its ultimate purport, and so he further inquires to resolve his doubts, awaiting elucidation.

"I wish to dwell amidst the human world, to nurture and guard the Dao, to cultivate and refine the Way—what should I do, and what should I not do? As for declining and accepting, advancing and retreating, and the myriad affairs of things—how should they be handled? I humbly seek your instruction, that I may follow it all my life."

The Spirit of the Northern Sea replied: "Viewed through the Dao, what is noble and what is base—this is called 'reversal and recurrence.'

**[Annotation]** The Way of noble and base turns and follows in cycles.
**[Commentary]** 'Reversal and recurrence' means turning back and forth. For noble and base arise from deluded attachment. Now, when illumined by the principle of emptiness and penetration, what is noble reverts to base, and what is base reverts to noble—hence it is called 'reversal and recurrence.'

If you cling to your will, you will be greatly at odds with the Dao.
**[Annotation]** Self-clinging obstructs harmony with the Dao.
**[Commentary]** *Er* (而) means 'you.' The one who cultivates the Dao should act with abandon, yet you cling to your will, holding fast with pride—thus you are at odds with the principle of emptiness and penetration.

What is little and what is much—this is called 'alternation and application.'
**[Annotation]** Following its portion, what is applied is without constancy.
**[Commentary]** *Xie* (谢) means 'to replace'; *shi* (施) means 'to apply.' Things may gather the little to become much, or scatter the much to become little—thus application and alternation have no fixed constancy.

If you act with singleness, you will be at variance with the Dao.
**[Annotation]** Inability to follow change leads to disharmony with the Dao.
**[Commentary]** Alternation and application, whether much or little, adapt to the moment, following the transformations of opportunity—thus they harmonize with things. If you cling to singleness in action, you will be at odds with principle.

Majestic, like a state with its ruler, it is without private virtue;
**[Annotation]** It is merely impartial and fitting.
**[Commentary]** The one who embodies the Dao appears solemn, governing the myriad things with upright reverence, serving as a model for all. The myriad states look up to a single ruler, nurturing the people without partial virtue.

Vast, like a sacrifice with its altar, it is without private blessing;
**[Annotation]** What all under heaven together seek.
**[Commentary]** *Xuanxuan* (县县) describes a distant and extended appearance. Like the people’s sacrifice to the altar of the soil, the altar bestows no private blessing upon them.

Boundless, like the four directions without end, it is without cherished domain.
**[Annotation]** Boundless, without fixed abode.
**[Commentary]** *Fanfan* (泛泛) describes a pervasive and impartial appearance. The perfected one establishes his will with universal impartiality, aiding and saving all beings with equal and boundless love. It is like the east, west, south, and north—vast and without end, measureless as empty space—how could there be quarrels over boundaries or domains?

Embracing the myriad things, who bears and shelters them?
**[Annotation]** Sheltering and protecting all beings, returning them to their proper portion and acting with impartiality—how could they be supported and sheltered with partiality?
**[Commentary]** *Huai* (怀) means 'to embrace'; *shu* (孰) means 'who.' The great sage, with boundless compassion, embraces all beings, acting with impartiality—never with partial love. Who, then, would have the mind to rescue, receive, support, or shelter them?

This is called 'without direction.'
**[Annotation]** Without direction, thus it can take the directions of things as its direction.
**[Commentary]** Like a bright mirror or a deep valley, it responds to the hundred transformations without fixed direction.

The myriad things are as one—who is short, and who is long?
**[Annotation]** None is not complete.
**[Commentary]** The myriad things differ, yet their nurturing is one. The hare and the crane differ in length, yet their natures are equally complete.

The Dao has no end or beginning; things have death and life.
**[Annotation]** Death and life are but endless transformations—there is no end or beginning.
**[Commentary]** The Dao of emptiness and penetration has no end or beginning; clinging things deludedly calculate death and life. Thus the *Laozi* says: "Going before, one does not see its head; following after, one does not see its rear."

It does not rely on its completion;
**[Annotation]** Completion has no fixed place.
**[Commentary]** Things arise without direction, transcending and transforming alone—how could they depend on opposition to attain completion?

Now empty, now full, it does not abide in fixed form.
**[Annotation]** It does not take form as its abode, nor cling to it without change.
**[Commentary]** Like yin and yang, spring gives birth and autumn kills; fullness and emptiness transform, flourishing and falling follow the seasons—how could one cling to form or hold fast to name and position?

Years cannot be lifted away;
**[Annotation]** One wishes to lift them away, but cannot.
**[Commentary]** The length or brevity of years, the swiftness or slowness of time, arise from heavenly principle and do not depend on man. Thus, when they come, they cannot be lifted away to make them depart; when they depart, they cannot be stopped to make them stay. One should simply follow them—this is never not the self.

Time cannot be halted;
**[Annotation]** One wishes to halt it, but cannot.
**[Commentary]** Dissolution and growth, fullness and emptiness—at their end, they begin anew.
**[Annotation]** Transformation renews daily, never clinging to the old.
**[Commentary]** Yin dissolves and yang grows; summer is full and winter is empty. The sequence of qi cycles endlessly, ending and then beginning again. The Dao of perfect completion transforms daily, following principle without effort or intent.

This is how one speaks of the direction of great principle and discusses the principle of the myriad things.
**[Commentary]** The preceding discourse of the Spirit of the Northern Sea precisely speaks of the direction of great principle and discusses the mysterious principle of the myriad things.

Things come into being as if galloping, as if racing.
**[Annotation]** One should simply follow their use.
**[Commentary]** Arising and perishing, flowing and vanishing—ceaselessly moving, swift as racing or galloping. Thus one knows that a hundred years are but a fleeting moment—how could they be worth clinging to?

No movement without change, no time without shift.
**[Annotation]** Thus it cannot be clung to or held.
**[Commentary]** Flowing and changing, time shifting—swift as an arm’s turn, fleeting as a crack’s passage. Thus there is no movement without change, no time without shift."

What is to be done? What is not to be done? Things will naturally transform of themselves.
**[Annotation]** If one acts or refrains from acting in their midst, one disrupts their self-transformation.
**[Commentary]** The myriad things, though tangled and chaotic, all receive their nature from Heaven. At peace, they transform—each changing of itself. Why trouble oneself with deliberate choice between doing and not doing?

The River Spirit said: If this be so, then what value lies in the Dao?
**[Annotation]** Its value lies in self-transformation.
**[Commentary]** If doing and not doing were indistinguishable, then the principles of sage and commoner would be equal. Yet since one entrusts oneself to the spontaneity of transformation, why prize the supreme Dao?

The Spirit of the Northern Sea replied: One who knows the Dao must penetrate principle; one who penetrates principle must be clear about adaptability; one who is clear about adaptability does not allow things to harm oneself.
**[Annotation]** To know the Dao is to know one’s own incapacity. If one is incapable, how could one give birth to oneself? One is born naturally, and the four limbs, hundred members, five viscera, and spirit all form of themselves—without any deliberate intent after their formation.
One who penetrates this principle can cast off partial knowledge, relinquish the emotions that seek to prolong life, and ride change while responding with adaptability. Thus one does not allow externals to injure the inner self, and so remains perpetually whole.
**[Commentary]** One who knows the Dao of emptiness and penetration must also penetrate the profound reality of principle. One who penetrates the profound reality of principle must be clear about the adaptability of responding to things. Having grasped the boundlessness of adaptability and reality, one can rest in transformation and depart from contrivance. Death and life bring no change to oneself—how then could external things cause harm? This answers the River Spirit’s doubt and next clarifies the value of the supreme Dao.

One of utmost virtue cannot be burned by fire, drowned by water, harmed by cold or heat, or injured by birds or beasts.
**[Annotation]** Where the mind is at peace, danger cannot endanger; where intent is without obstruction, suffering cannot afflict.
**[Commentary]** One of utmost virtue is one who has attained the supreme Dao. Though blending light with the world and dwelling in the dust like others, one is not assailed by the four seasons or harmed by the three disasters. Having attained this within, externals cannot injure. This clarifies the value of understanding the Dao.

This does not mean one treats them lightly.
**[Annotation]** Though the mind is at peace, one does not allow them to be violated.
**[Commentary]** "Lightly" means to treat with disdain. That water and fire do not assail, and birds and beasts do not harm, arises from the mind’s peace—what injures cannot injure. Yet one neither avoids nor lightly provokes them.

It means discerning safety and danger,
**[Annotation]** Knowing they cannot be escaped.
**[Commentary]** That what injures cannot injure is precisely to discern safety and danger, to follow what cannot be escaped, and to dwell in constant ease.

Finding peace in fortune and misfortune,
**[Annotation]** Being at ease with what fate brings.
**[Commentary]** "Peace" means contentment. Misfortune is adversity; fortune is success. One of utmost virtue follows whatever comes, embodying the mandate of fortune and misfortune. Understanding that fortune and misfortune have no fixed gate, one’s joy is not in success or failure, yet one’s encounters are always at peace.

Being cautious in advance and retreat,
**[Annotation]** Discerning that advance and retreat are not one’s own.
**[Commentary]** Knowing that advance and retreat have no fixed rule, and that taking and relinquishing have their times, though one follows things in their changes, one always dwells in what is most fitting.

Nothing can harm one.
**[Annotation]** Not taking harm as harm, thus nothing can harm one.
**[Commentary]** Unified in safety and danger, obscured in fortune and misfortune, moving with transformation, thus things cannot injure. This summarizes the preceding meaning of being unharmed.

Thus it is said: Heaven is within, humans are without.
**[Annotation]** The natural is within, and what the natural follows is without. Thus the *Great Master* says: One who knows what Heaven and humans do has reached the utmost—clarifying that the distinction between inner and outer is not a matter of contrivance.
**[Commentary]** The nature of Heaven resides within the heart; what human affairs require lies in external dealings—neither is contrived. Entrusting oneself to spontaneity, thus things cannot harm.

Virtue lies in Heaven.
**[Annotation]** Indulging human knowledge leads to dissipation and loss of the original.
**[Commentary]** The beauty of utmost virtue lies in the natural. If one indulges human knowledge, the heavenly nature is dissipated.

Knowing the conduct of Heaven and humans, rooted in Heaven, abiding in attainment;
**[Annotation]** This natural knowledge acts without exceeding its bounds. Thus, though it moves externally, it is always rooted in Heaven and abides in attainment.
**[Commentary]** This is true knowledge. "Abiding" means dwelling. Acting in the world with true knowledge, though engaging with the myriad changes of things, one always takes the natural as the root, dwelling in emptiness without losing one’s nature—active yet tranquil.

Advancing and retreating, bending and stretching,
**[Annotation]** Responding to opportunities, one changes accordingly.
**[Commentary]** "Advancing and retreating" describes an unfixed manner. The perfected one responds to the world, following the rise and fall of things, now bending, now stretching—without fixed attachment. Meeting others in darkness, one adapts to the moment.

Returning to the essential and speaking of the ultimate.

Though knowledge extends to Heaven and Earth, and affairs encompass the myriad things, one never loses hold of the essential and ultimate—thus the Dao of Heaven and humanity remains whole.

**[Commentary]** Though mingling with the world of mortals, the mind remains ever serene and still, ever abiding in the pivotal essentials and returning to the root, reverting to the source. All speech arises from the ultimate emptiness; movement does not depart from tranquility, nor words from silence.

It is asked: What is Heaven? What is humanity?

**[Commentary]** As Hebo has yet to grasp the profound mystery, he raises this doubt, inquiring into the Dao of Heaven and humanity, hoping for an answer to follow.

The Lord of the Northern Sea said: "That oxen and horses have four feet is called Heaven; that a halter is placed on a horse’s head or a ring through an ox’s nose is called humanity."

**[Annotation]** In human life, can one do without yoking oxen or riding horses? And in yoking oxen or riding horses, can one do without piercing and haltering them? That oxen and horses do not refuse such piercing and haltering is because it is their inherent destiny. If it accords with Heaven’s mandate, then though it is entrusted to human affairs, its root lies in Heaven.

**[Commentary]** Now, oxen and horses receive their four legs from Heaven—this has nothing to do with human affairs, and so it is called Heaven.
