[Subcommentary] Not yet awakened to the fact that life arises from spontaneity and form from the workings of creation, he asked, *"If my body is not mine, then who possesses it?"*

Cheng replied, "It is the form bestowed by Heaven and Earth.
Life is not your own—it is the harmony bestowed by Heaven and Earth.
Nature and destiny are not your own—they are the compliance bestowed by Heaven and Earth."

[Annotation] If the body were yours to possess, then beauty and ugliness, life and death, would be subject to your control. Yet when qi flows eastward and gives rise to life, you cannot forbid it; when qi scatters and brings death, you cannot prevent it. Clearly, it gathers and forms of itself—it is not yours to possess.

[Subcommentary] *Bestowed* means gathered and formed. The yin and yang of Heaven and Earth, the gathering of hard and soft, harmonious and compliant qi—these constitute your body, nature, and destiny. Thus, when they gather, there is life; when they scatter, there is death. Since life and death, gathering and scattering do not depend on you, how can you claim your body as your own?

"Your descendants are not your own—they are the moltings bestowed by Heaven and Earth."

[Annotation] Qi gathers and sheds of itself, like a cicada’s molting.

[Subcommentary] Yin and yang gather, and thus there are descendants—transforming alone, like the shedding of a cicada’s skin.

"In walking, you know not where you go;
In dwelling, you know not what you hold;
In eating, you know not what you taste."

[Annotation] All arise spontaneously within you, hence you do not know.

[Subcommentary] Walking, dwelling, eating, tasting—all follow nature. Tracing their source, none knows whence they come. Who walks? Who dwells? Who eats? Who tastes? None knows the origin, yet all arise spontaneously.

"It is the strong yang qi of Heaven and Earth—how could you possess it?"

[Annotation] *Strong yang* refers to movement. This makes clear that the Dao may be used to relinquish the body and set the mind on life.

[Subcommentary] *Strong yang* means movement. *Hu* means "how." Body, nature, descendants—all are formed by the gathering of the moving qi of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang. How, then, could you claim to possess this body?

Confucius asked Lao Cong, "Today, at leisure, I dare to inquire about the perfection of talent and the Dao."

[Subcommentary] *At leisure* means at ease. Confucius studied under Laozi, and thus, during a moment of quiet repose, he questioned him about the profound Dao.

Lao Cong replied, "Purify your conduct through fasting, dredge your mind through emptiness, cleanse your spirit through clarity, and strike away your knowledge. The Dao—how recondite and difficult to speak of! I shall tell you its broad outlines."

[Subcommentary] *Dredging the mind* (疏沦) is like washing and rinsing. *Cleansing the spirit* (澡雪) is like purifying and refining. *Er* (而) means "you." *Striking away* (拾击) means shattering. *Yá* (崖) means division. If you wish to inquire about the Dao, you must first fast to escape the mind, be vigilant in reverence and sincerity, wash and rinse body and mind, purify and still the spirit and consciousness, shatter sagely wisdom, and sweep away emptiness and ease. Yet the profound Dao is obscure and dark, difficult to speak of in detail. I shall thus present its divisions and speak of it roughly.

The luminous arises from the obscure, the ordered from the formless, the spirit from the Dao.

[Annotation] All these illustrate its solitary generation, without reliance on anything else.

The physical form originates from essence.

[Annotation] All proceed from essence to the coarse.

[Subcommentary] *Lún* (伦) means principle. The bright and manifest arises from the obscure and dark; human order and activity emerge from the formless; the mind of spirit, wisdom, and consciousness arises from the profound Dao; and the realm of form, substance, and qi takes essence as its root. Yet all things generate one another through form, so creatures with nine orifices are born from the womb, while those with eight are born from eggs.

[Annotation] Though things generate one another through form, this too is natural. Thus, womb-born and egg-born creatures cannot exchange their modes of birth, demonstrating that spirit and qi cannot be manipulated.

[Subcommentary] The formless Dao can generate the formed, while formed things generate one another through form, substance, and qi. Thus, humans, with nine orifices, are womb-born, while birds and fish, with eight, are egg-born—all received naturally and cannot be altered. Its coming has no nearness, its going no boundary, no gate, no chamber, yet it is vast and all-pervading.

[Annotation] Those who follow their natural nature and wander the pathless way release their forms amid Heaven and Earth and lodge their spirits beyond the eight directions. Thus, without gate or chamber, it is vast and all-pervading, roaming the six directions and moving in harmony with transformation.

[Subcommentary] *Huáng* (皇) means great. Taking non-arrival as arrival, though it comes, it leaves no trace; taking non-departure as departure, though it goes, it has no boundary. Thus, it enters and exits without doors, comes and goes without edges, and so can be vast and reach the four directions, connecting all things. Those who encounter this have strong limbs, penetrating thoughts, keen ears and eyes, effortless application of the mind, and boundless responsiveness to things.

[Annotation] Those born and meeting this Dao have their heavenly nature preserved and their spirit settled.

[Subcommentary] *Yáo* (邀) means encounter. *Xùn* (徇) means penetration. Those who encounter the Dao and align with true principle have sound bodies, strong and healthy limbs, penetrating thoughts, sharp hearing and vision, a mindless mind that labors not, and a response without response that answers without fixed place.

Heaven cannot but be high, Earth cannot but be vast, the sun and moon cannot but move, and the myriad things cannot but flourish—this is the Dao.

[Annotation] All these cannot but be so naturally, not because the Dao compels them.

[Subcommentary] The Two Modes rely on the profound Dao for their height and breadth, the Three Luminaries depend on it for their movement, and the ten thousand things attain flourishing through it—such is the Dao’s power. Thus, the *Laozi* says: Heaven attains the One and becomes clear, Earth attains the One and becomes tranquil, the myriad things attain the One and live—this is what is meant.

Moreover, extensive study does not necessarily bring knowledge, eloquence does not necessarily bring wisdom—sages have already severed such notions.

[Annotation] They sever knowledge and wisdom, entrusting all to nature.

[Subcommentary] Broad study of the classics does not necessarily lead to true knowledge; grand eloquence and adorned words do not necessarily bring wisdom and illumination. Thus, the *Laozi* says: The good do not argue, the argumentative are not good; the knowing are not learned, the learned do not know. Sages have already severed and abandoned these.

As for that which, when augmented, is not increased, and when diminished, is not reduced—this is what sages preserve.

[Annotation] They simply preserve their proper allotment, thus having no use for knowledge and wisdom.

[Subcommentary] Broad knowledge and eloquence do not increase clarity; silence and facing the wall do not diminish it. This is what is called neither increasing nor decreasing, neither harming nor benefiting—sages’ wondrous embodiment, which they preserve and cherish.

Deep and still like the sea,

[Annotation] Its capacity is boundless.

[Subcommentary] Though its tail leaks, it is not exhausted; though a hundred rivers pour into it, it does not increase—profound, clear, deep, and vast, thus likened to the profound Dao.

Vast and towering, it ends yet begins again,

[Annotation] Those who move with transformation accumulate boundless eons—this may be called towering.

[Subcommentary] *Wēiwēi* (巍巍) means lofty and great. The Dao surpasses the Great One in remoteness and transcends the Two Modes in nearness, encompassing the boundless. Thus, it is praised as towering. Ending yet beginning again—this clarifies that it has no end or beginning, daily renewing in transformation, ungraspable in following or meeting.

It measures and sustains the myriad things without exhaustion.

[Annotation] It uses things without being enslaved by them, thus it is not exhausted.

Then the Dao of the noble person—is it external?

[Annotation] Each takes from themselves and is sufficient.

[Subcommentary] That which carries and sustains the myriad things, its capacity inexhaustible, pervading the boundless without depletion—this is the Dao of the noble person. It is not distant; it lies near, within the heart. Since it does not depend on external receipt, how could it be external?

The myriad things all turn to it for sustenance without exhaustion—this is the Dao.

[Annotation] It returns to using things, thus I am not exhausted. This clarifies that the Dao’s provision for things lies in not providing—by not providing, things attain themselves. Thus, it is said: this is the Dao.

This speaks of the Dao’s non-action; only non-action is worthy of being called the Dao.

The myriad beings, whether sentient or insentient, all receive this mysterious Dao; yet the mysterious workings subtly pervade all without ever being exhausted. Now, the Dao and things are neither one nor different, yet apart from the Dao there are no things—thus it is said: this is the Dao.

Within the Central Kingdom there is a kind of person who is neither yin nor yang,
[Annotation] Without partial designation.
dwelling between Heaven and Earth, simply being human,
[Annotation] Unrestrained and self-directed, content with whatever comes, utterly without fame or achievement.
[Subcommentary] The Central Kingdom—does this mean the Nine Provinces? The Dao observed by such a person is neither yin nor yang, neither soft nor hard, neither short nor long; thus it transcends the four propositions and leaves behind the hundred negations. Dwelling between Heaven and Earth, simply placed as human, without partiality—*zhi* (置) here may also be read as *zhi* (值), meaning that within the world, one encounters being human yet remains entirely unentangled.

They return to the Source.
[Annotation] Originally following the branches.
[Subcommentary] Free from partiality, simply placed as human, they can return to the root and revert to the Origin.

Viewed from the root, the living are but congealed things.
[Annotation] Merely gathered qi.
[Subcommentary] The root is the Dao. *Hāi-yī* (哈噫) means the gathering of qi. Observed from the Dao, the living are but things formed of congealed qi—how could they be worth cherishing? Though there be long life or early death, how great is the difference? This is but the discourse of a fleeting moment. How could it suffice to distinguish between Yao and Jie as right or wrong?
[Annotation] If even life and death are not truly distinct, how much less the difference between long life and early death?
[Subcommentary] Within a single lifetime, within a hundred years, whether long-lived or short-lived, how much difference is there? It is but the span of a moment, the discourse of an instant—how could it suffice to affirm Yao or condemn Jie and make distinctions between them?

Fruits and melons have their principles,
[Annotation] All things have their principles; one should simply follow them.
and though human relations are difficult, they have their proper order.
[Annotation] Human relations involve the changes of wisdom and cunning, hence their difficulty. Yet their wisdom and cunning naturally order themselves—one should simply follow and let them be.
[Subcommentary] Those on trees are called *guǒ* (果), those on the ground *guā* (瓜). Peaches, plums, gourds, and calabashes—whether born of wood or vine—all have their principles. Human life in the world is perilous and arduous, yet noble and base, honored and humble, follow one another in proper sequence. One should simply let them be, naturally aligning with the Dao, just as fruits and melons have their inherent principles.

The sage meets them without resistance,
[Annotation] Following whatever is encountered.
and passes beyond them without clinging.
[Annotation] Passing beyond what ought to be passed beyond.
[Subcommentary] Encountering eminence and rank, he does not resist; having passed beyond them, he does not linger.

Harmonizing and responding—this is virtue;
coinciding and responding—this is the Dao.
[Annotation] *Tiáo* (調) and *ǒu* (偶) mean harmonizing and coinciding.
[Subcommentary] Harmonizing with the myriad things and responding—this is supreme virtue; coinciding with circumstances and responding to the moment—this is the sagely Dao.

This is how emperors arise and kings emerge.
[Annotation] It is no more than this.
[Subcommentary] When emperors and kings arise, they respond to the myriad beings by harmonizing and coinciding with the times, meeting things as they come.

Human life between Heaven and Earth is like a white colt passing a chink—suddenly, it is gone.
[Annotation] Not worth cherishing.
[Subcommentary] The white colt is a swift steed, or else the sun. The chink is an opening. Human life in the world is but a fleeting moment, so pressing and brief—like a galloping steed passing a narrow gap, vanishing in an instant. How could it be worth mentioning?

All things surge forth in tumult;
all things drift and settle in stillness.

The terms "emergence" and "return" refer to transformation—nothing in the world remains unchanging.
[Annotation] "Surging forth" describes the appearance of life; "drifting and settling" depicts the state of death. All things in the world, without exception, arise from transformation and follow it into death. Having transformed into life, they transform again into death.
[Annotation] Both are transformations. Living beings lament this;
[Annotation] dead beings do not lament. Humankind grieves over it;
[Annotation] the dead do not grieve.
[Subcommentary] Life and death come and go, meeting in transformation. Entrusting this to the Creator, why cling to it? Thus, when death comes, living beings and humankind share in mourning, but those who are neither living nor of the same kind do not mourn or grieve. Release the bonds of nature, cast off its wrappings—
[Annotation] to be uniquely free.
[Subcommentary] *Jie* means to conceal; *guo* means to bind. People cling to right and wrong, rejoice in life and fear death, thus becoming bound by life and death. Now, having unified right and wrong and forgotten life and death, they naturally dissolve the fetters of nature.

In swirling, winding flux,
[Annotation] the intertwining of transformation—
the soul departs, and the body follows, thus returning to the Great Return.
[Annotation] Do not exert the mind between them.
[Subcommentary] "Swirling, winding" describes the state of dispersion. The soul ascends to Heaven, bones and flesh return to earth, spirit and qi scatter—freely following the flux, passing from being to non-being, this is the Great Return.

The formless takes form; form returns to the formless.
[Annotation] Only when formless does form truly arise; if one imposes form upon it, one ruins its form.
[Subcommentary] Before birth, humans inherently lack form, thus originating from the formless. Qi gathers to give rise to form; qi disperses to return to the formless. This is universally known.
[Annotation] Though known, people cannot allow it to take form naturally but instead impose form upon it, thus often ruining it. It is not the concern of those who have attained the Way.
[Annotation] Concern prevents attainment.
[Subcommentary] The transition from formless to form, and from form back to formlessness, is universally known. Yet this is but a mundane matter, not the true pursuit of those who have reached the ultimate. This is what the common people universally discuss.
[Annotation] Though they discuss it, they still cannot refrain from concern, thus failing to attain it.
[Subcommentary] The presence and absence of form, the coming and going of life and death—these are what the common people universally discuss. Those who have attained the Way do not discuss it;
[Annotation] only in effortless, unknowing awareness do they attain it. To discuss it is to fail to attain it.
[Subcommentary] The sagely ones, having forgotten words and grasped the principle, engage in no discussion. If they were to discuss it, they would not reach the Dao.

To perceive clearly is to miss the mark;
[Annotation] only upon hearing the ultimate does one truly encounter it.
[Subcommentary] *Zhi* means to meet or encounter. Those who close their wisdom and block their senses, merging obscurely with the mysterious principle—if they seek clarity, they will not attain the truth. Eloquence is inferior to silence. The Dao cannot be heard; hearing is inferior to blocking. This is called the Great Attainment.
[Annotation] In silence and blocking, there is nothing to pursue, thus the Great Attainment.
[Subcommentary] Excessive eloquence and adorned words distance one from the truth; forgetting words and abiding in stillness bring one closer to the mysterious Dao. Thus, the Dao cannot be sought through much hearing; seeking through hearing is inferior to blocking. Those who profoundly grasp this meaning may be said to have deeply attained the Great Principle.

Master Dongguo asked Zhuangzi: "Where does the so-called Dao reside?"
[Subcommentary] Dwelling in Dongguo, he was called Master Dongguo—teacher of Wuze, who was in turn the master of Dongguo Shunzi. He asked Zhuangzi: "Where does the all-pervading, empty Dao reside?"
Zhuangzi said: "It is nowhere absent."
[Subcommentary] The Dao is boundless; it is present everywhere.
Master Dongguo said: "Specify it, then it may be known."
[Annotation] He wished Zhuangzi to name its location.
[Subcommentary] The commentary states: He wished Zhuangzi to name its location.
Zhuangzi said: "It is in the ants."
He said: "Why so lowly?"
"It is in the millet stalks."
"Why even lower?"
"It is in the tiles and shards."
"Why still lower?"
"It is in excrement and urine."
Master Dongguo did not respond.
[Subcommentary] The Great Dao is nowhere absent, yet where it resides, it is nowhere to be found. Thus, it is present everywhere, undiscriminating of purity or filth. Master Dongguo, not grasping this subtlety, believed the Dao to be lofty and pure. When told it resided in tiles and shards, he already found it too base; hearing of excrement and urine, he grew indignant and did not respond.
Zhuangzi said: "Your question fundamentally misses the essence."
[Annotation] By naming its location, you speak of its manifestations, yet you still find fault with this—this is missing the essence.
[Subcommentary] The Dao is nowhere absent; how could it reside only in millet stalks? Your question fundamentally fails to reach the truth.

The question posed to the market inspector about treading on pigs to assess their fatness—each step lower reveals more.
[Annotation] *Xi* refers to large pigs. The market inspector treads on pigs to determine their fatness; the more he treads on the harder-to-fatten parts, the better he knows the key to the pig's fatness. Now, in seeking the Dao's abode, each inquiry into lower, baser places confirms all the more that the Dao does not escape from things.
[Subcommentary] *Zheng* is an official title, equivalent to today's market commissioner. *Huo* is a name. *Jian* refers to the market overseer, equivalent to today's butcher. *Xi* means pig. Now, when asking a butcher about the method of buying pigs, one is told: treading on the pig's thighs and legs—the harder-to-fatten parts—reveals the pig's fatness all the more. Why is this?

Where the lower, harder-to-fatten parts bear flesh, one knows full well the easier-to-fatten parts are thick with fat. Just so, where the Dao abides in lowly places like excrement and urine, it is clear that all pure and empty realms are equally pervaded.

You must not insist—nowhere does it escape from things.
[Annotation] If one insists that the Dao escapes from things, then the Dao is not all-encompassing. A Dao that is not all-encompassing is not truly the Dao.

[Subcommentary] *Wu* means "non-action" in the Way. The great Dao is vast and boundless, governing all without exception. You must not say that the ultimate Dao abandons things. If it were to escape from things, how could it be all-pervading? What holds true for the ultimate Dao also holds for grand teachings.

[Annotation] This clarifies that the Dao does not escape from things.

[Subcommentary] The ultimate Dao is principle; grand teachings are instruction. Since principle does not escape from things, instruction likewise is universally pervading and impartial. *Zhou*, *pian*, and *xian*—though their names differ, their essence is one, and their meaning is the same.

[Subcommentary] *Zhou* means all-pervading and complete; *xian* means all things possess the Dao. This further clarifies that the ultimate Dao does not escape from things. Though the three terms differ in name, in essence and principle they converge as one.

Once we wandered together in the Palace of Nothing-Whatsoever, harmonized in discussion, without end or limit.
[Annotation] If one wanders in what *is*, one cannot be all-pervading and complete. Only by harmonizing in discussion does one realize the Dao is present everywhere. Realizing the Dao is present everywhere, one can then roam boundlessly without attachment.

[Subcommentary] The Palace of Nothing-Whatsoever refers to the abode of the mysterious Dao—where not a single thing exists, hence "nothing-whatsoever." The three—*zhou*, *pian*, and *xian*—roam together in the realm of the ultimate Dao. Since their essential meaning is one, they harmonize in discussion, merging with the profound principle, thus without beginning or end.

Once we practiced non-action together—serene and still, vast and clear, harmonious and at ease.
[Annotation] All this arises from non-action.

[Subcommentary] This summarizes the three virtues of *zhou*, *pian*, and *xian*—their abundant power and flourishing virtue. Having roamed in the realm of the ultimate Dao and dwelled in the domain of non-action, they are thus tranquil and still, silent and clear, gentle and harmonious, spacious and at ease.

My will is now desolate,
[Annotation] Desolate, empty, and void.

[Subcommentary] The sage who attains the Dao merges with principle and the profound truth; his nature and will are vast and desolate.

I go nowhere yet do not know where I arrive.
[Annotation] If the will is desolate, then there is nowhere to go. Going nowhere, one goes yet does not know where one arrives. If there is somewhere to go, then before principle moves, the will has already arrived.

I depart and return yet do not know where I rest.
[Annotation] This is following the natural course.

[Subcommentary] Since the words are desolate, one comes and goes without return. Even if one does not go yet goes, does not come yet comes, there is ultimately no place of arrival or resting.

I have come and gone yet do not know where it ends.
[Annotation] One comes and goes not through knowledge, yet this does not mean one does not come and go. Coming and going are the constant principle of nature—can there be an end?

[Subcommentary] Even if one comes and goes with creation, lives and dies, follows change and submits to transformation, one does not know the beginning or end.

I wander in boundless vastness—great knowledge enters yet does not know where it ends.
[Annotation] Boundless vastness refers to emptiness and openness. Great knowledge, through this vast emptiness, freely knows the transformations—hence it does not know.

[Subcommentary] *Panghuang* means to roam freely; *feng hong* describes a vast and open appearance, referring to the merging of understanding. The person of great wisdom merges with the desolate and boundless principle, thus roaming freely and at ease, without limit.

The one who gives things their thingness has no boundary with things.
[Annotation] This clarifies that the one who gives things their thingness is not a thing—things are themselves things. Things are themselves things, hence they are obscure.

[Subcommentary] *Ji* means boundary. The one who gives things their thingness is the sage. The sage is obscurely one with the myriad things, thus having no boundary of self and other with things.

Yet things have boundaries—what are called the boundaries of things.
[Annotation] Things have boundaries, thus they cannot be obscurely one with each other—this is what is truly meant by boundaries.

[Subcommentary] The emotions of things discriminate and make endless choices, hence there are boundaries between self and other.

The boundary of no-boundary is the boundary that is no boundary.
[Annotation] The one without boundary, though called the one who gives things their thingness, merely clarifies that things are themselves things. The one who gives things their thingness is ultimately no thing—where is the boundary?

[Subcommentary] The boundary that is no boundary is the enlightened view of the sage; the no-boundary that is a boundary is the stagnant emotion of the vulgar. It is said: fullness and emptiness, decline and death—what is fullness and emptiness is not fullness and emptiness; what is decline and death is not decline and death; what is beginning and end is not beginning and end; what is accumulation and dispersal is not accumulation and dispersal.

[Annotation] Having clarified that the one who gives things their thingness is no thing, and that things cannot give themselves their thingness, then who is the doer? All is suddenly and spontaneously so.

[Subcommentary] Wealth and nobility are fullness; poverty and lowliness are emptiness. Old age and sickness are decline and death; beginning and end are root and branch. Coming to life is accumulation; death is dispersal. The one who gives things their thingness is not a thing—then who gives life to things? This clarifies that the one who gives and what is given are both not so. If things are not things, how can one speak of fullness and emptiness, decline and death? Thus it is known that what is called fullness and emptiness is not truly fullness and emptiness. As the *Western Ascension Scripture* says: "If one can understand this, what is affirmed is reversed and negated."

He and Gan of the He clan studied together with Old Dragon Ji under Shen Nong.
[Subcommentary] His surname was He, his given name Gan. Shen Nong here is not the Shen Nong of the Three Sovereigns but a later figure.

The two studied together under Old Dragon Ji. Old Dragon Ji was also a style name. Shen Nong leaned on his armrest with the door closed, napping in the daytime. He Gan thrust open the door at midday and entered, saying: "Old Dragon is dead."

[Subcommentary] *Yin* means to lean; *he* means to close. *Yao* means to open, also to push. Those who study the Dao concentrate their spirit and settle their minds, closing the door to lean on the armrest, guarding silence in stillness. When He Gan heard of his teacher’s death, he pushed open the door to announce it.

Shen Nong leaned on his staff and rose, then suddenly let go of the staff and laughed.

[Annotation] He rose and realized that death was not worth alarm, so he set down the staff and laughed.

[Subcommentary] *Pùrán* is the sound of the staff being set down. Shen Nong was startled by the news of Ji’s death, so he grasped his staff in alarm; then, reflecting that death was not cause for sorrow, he set it down and laughed.

He said: "Heaven knew my perversity, coarseness, arrogance, and carelessness, so it cast me aside and let him die. Alas, Master! You died without ever unleashing my wild words."

[Annotation] From Jian Wu downward, all took the ultimate words as madness and did not believe them. Thus, apart from Old Dragon’s disciples like Lian Shu, none were fit to speak with.

[Subcommentary] *Master* refers to Old Dragon Ji. He had the virtue of spontaneity, so he was called *Heaven*. *Wild words* are the ultimate words—beyond the comprehension of ordinary people, hence called *wild*. The teacher knew my stubbornness, vulgarity, arrogance, and inattention, so he abandoned our company and ceased in death. With the wise man gone, the ultimate words are cut off; no one remains to discourse on the profound or instruct me, to open my heart.

Yin Gang, upon hearing this, said: "Those who embody the Dao are what the noble ones of the world depend upon."

[Annotation] Those who embody the Dao are the masters of humanity. Yet in matters of the Dao, they have not attained even one ten-thousandth of the tip of an autumn hair.

[Annotation] The tip of an autumn hair is already minute, and they have not attained even one ten-thousandth of it. Yet they still know to conceal their wild words and die—how much more so for those who truly embody the Dao?

[Annotation] This makes clear that the ultimate Dao cannot be attained through words; it lies only in personal realization.

[Subcommentary] His surname was Na, his given name Gang; he was a recluse. *Depend* means to attach or rely upon. Upon hearing of Old Dragon Ji’s death, he offered this reflection: Those who embody the Dao are revered by the world; the worthy and noble attach themselves to them. Yet Old Dragon, in relation to the profound Dao, had not attained even one ten-thousandth of the tip of a hair. Even so, he knew to conceal his unbridled words and depart in accordance with fate—how much less would one of subtle awakening reveal his teachings? Thus, those who embody the Dao in profound mystery, who forget words and merge with principle, are exceedingly rare. It has no form to see, no sound to hear; in the discourse of men, it is called *obscure*—yet even so, to speak of the Dao is not the Dao.

[Annotation] That it is called *obscure* yet still not the Dao makes clear that the Dao is nameless.

[Subcommentary] The profound Dao is empty and vast, its wondrous essence beyond form and sound, beyond seeing and hearing. Thus, when scholars discuss it, they call it *obscure*—yet even this is not the true Dao.

Then Tai Qing asked Wu Qiong: "Do you know the Dao?"

Wu Qiong said: "I do not know."

He also asked Wu Wei.

Wu Wei said: "I know the Dao."

Tai Qing said: "In your knowing the Dao, is there a reckoning?"

Wu Wei said: "There is."

Tai Qing said: "What is this reckoning?"

[Subcommentary] Since you know the Dao, does it have a name or number? What is this reckoning? Please explain briefly.

Wu Wei said: "I know the Dao can be noble, can be base, can be gathered, can be dispersed—this is the reckoning by which I know the Dao."

[Subcommentary] Noble as an emperor, base as a servant; gathered as life, dispersed as death—its reckoning is boundless. This is but a rough explanation, meant to show that it is named yet not named, numbered yet not numbered.

Tai Qing then asked Wu Shi: "If this is so, then between Wu Qiong’s not knowing and Wu Wei’s knowing, which is right and which is wrong?"

[Subcommentary] The ultimate Dao is profoundly penetrating, serene and without action, unfathomable in its response, without end or beginning—hence the names *Wu Qiong* and *Wu Shi* are borrowed for it. Between Wu Qiong’s not knowing and Wu Wei’s knowing, which is right and which is wrong? Please judge their merits.

Wu Shi said: "Not knowing is deep; knowing is shallow. Not knowing is within; knowing is without."

[Subcommentary] Not knowing accords with principle, so it is profoundly abstruse and resides within; knowing deviates from the Dao, so it is coarse and shallow, and lies without.

Thereupon Tai Qing sighed in the midst of this and said: "Is not knowing then knowing? Is knowing then not knowing?"

Who knows the knowing of not-knowing?
[Annotation] To attain it is not through knowing, but through profound obscurity.
[Subcommentary] Tai Qing, grasping the middle Way, sighed in realization: not-knowing is true knowing. Who knows the knowing of not-knowing? This reveals how rare true knowing is.

Wu Shi said: The Dao cannot be heard; to hear it is not it. The Dao cannot be seen; to see it is not it. The Dao cannot be spoken; to speak it is not it.
[Annotation] Only by dwelling in the realm of neither hearing nor seeing does one reach it.
[Subcommentary] The Dao has no sound, so it cannot be heard by the ear—what the ear hears is not the Dao. The Dao has no form, so it cannot be seen by the eye—what the eye sees is not the Dao. The Dao has no name, so it cannot be spoken—what is spoken is not the Dao.

Know that what gives form to forms is itself formless.
[Annotation] Forms form themselves; what gives form to forms is ultimately no-thing.
[Subcommentary] That which gives form to the ten thousand things is itself not form—hence it is said that what gives form to forms is formless.

The Dao should not be named.
[Annotation] Though the Dao is named, it is ultimately no-thing, so the name cannot be fitting.
[Subcommentary] Names have no power to attain the Dao, and the Dao has no reality corresponding to names—thus to name the Dao is mistaken.

Wu Shi said: One who answers when asked about the Dao does not know the Dao. Even the one who asks about the Dao has not heard the Dao.
[Annotation] To ask is to not know; to answer when asked is not the Dao. Not to answer is not what the questioner can grasp, so even if asked, one ultimately does not hear it.
[Subcommentary] The Dao transcends names and words, so it cannot be questioned or answered. Thus, both asking and answering about the Dao show ignorance.

The Dao admits no questions; questions admit no answers.
[Annotation] This is the meaning of abandoning learning and teaching to return to naturalness.
[Subcommentary] One who embodies the Dao is beyond words—what questions or answers could there be? This passage further explains the preceding text.

To question where there is no question is to question emptiness.
[Annotation] This is what is meant by valuing emptiness.
[Subcommentary] *Qiong* means emptiness. To insist on questioning where there is no principle to question is to value emptiness.

To answer where there is no answer is to be without inwardness.
[Annotation] To feign existence where there is none is to be external.
[Subcommentary] To insist on answering where there is no principle to answer is to become estranged from truth.

One who meets the questioning of emptiness with the absence of inwardness—such a one outwardly does not observe the cosmos, inwardly does not know the Great Beginning.
[Subcommentary] *Yu* refers to the four directions of heaven and earth; *zhou* refers to past and future. The Great Beginning is the root of the Dao. One who meets the emptiness of questioning with a mind estranged from principle may be said to neither outwardly recognize the six directions and cosmos nor inwardly know the wondrous root of one’s own body.

Thus one does not pass beyond Kunlun, nor roam the Great Void.
[Annotation] As for those who wander the world, traverse the distant, and enter the profound obscurity—such a one does not answer, and that is all.
[Subcommentary] Kunlun is a mountain of great height; the Great Void is the profound principle. If one remains attached to names and words, still clinging to questions and answers, one has not yet traversed the heights or roamed the depths.

Guang Yao asked Wu You: Does the Master exist? Or does he not exist?
[Subcommentary] *Guang Yao* represents the power of discerning wisdom. *Wu You* is the realm of observation—wisdom can illuminate, hence the name *Guang Yao*; the realm is empty and quiescent, hence the name *Wu You*. Yet wisdom has brightness and dimness, while the realm has no depth or shallowness. Thus wisdom asks the realm: does it exist or not?

Guang Yao could not obtain an answer, yet when he examined its form and appearance, it was serene and empty. He gazed all day and saw nothing, listened and heard nothing, grasped and found nothing.
[Subcommentary] The wondrous realm is beyond sound and form, cutting off seeing and hearing—thus when one examines its appearance, it is only quiescence and emptiness.

Guang Yao said: It is perfect. Who can attain this?

I can attain "having" and "not-having," yet I cannot attain "not-not-having." How then could one reach this state?
[Annotation] This speaks to the meaning of cutting off all learning. When one severs attachment to the Dao, the learner returns to the root. Thus, the excellence of learning lies precisely in non-learning.
[Subcommentary] The luminous discernment of *Guang Yao* remains shallow—it can only grasp "not-having" by relinquishing "having," yet it cannot transcend both "having" and "not-having" together. Hence the sigh: how profound is "not-having"! Who could attain such mystery? Yet "not-having" does not merely negate "having"; it also negates "not-having," dissolving the four propositions and a hundred negations into utter absence. The word "not" in "not-having" leaves nothing un-negated—its expression is concise, yet its principle vast. Thus it is called "not." As for the question "how could one reach this?"—the realm of "not-having" exhausts principle and fulfills nature. Only those of profound virtue and superior attainment can embody it; shallow learners and petty wisdom have no means to arrive here.

The forger of hooks in the household of the Grand Marshal was eighty years old yet never missed by a hair’s breadth.
[Annotation] He grasped the weight of hammer and hook without the slightest deviation.
[Subcommentary] *Da Ma* was an official title, the Grand Marshal of Chu. *Chui* means to forge; *gou* refers to a belt hook. The Grand Marshal’s household had a craftsman who, from youth, excelled at forging hooks. Though he had reached eighty, his skill in hammering hooks grew ever more refined. His concentration was so single-minded that not even a hair’s breadth of error occurred. The hook here refers to a weighing hook, meaning he could judge the weight of hammer and hook with such precision that no deviation, however minute, escaped him.

The Grand Marshal asked: "Is your skill innate? Or have you attained the Way?"
[Subcommentary] The Marshal marveled that the old man’s forging grew more precise with age, suspecting his craft arose from some special method.

The craftsman replied: "I have my discipline. From the age of twenty, I devoted myself to forging hooks. I saw nothing else—nothing but hooks occupied my attention."
[Subcommentary] He had no other method, only steadfast devotion. From youth, he focused solely on this craft, observing nothing beyond hooks. Through long practice, it became his nature, and thus he reached such mastery.

That which is used arises from that which is not used, thereby prolonging its utility. How much more so for that which is never not used? What thing does not draw upon this principle?

[Annotation] With no attachments whatsoever, all things come in perfect response.
[Subcommentary] The reason he maintained his skill in forging hooks even into old age was that he relied on not directing his mind to observe other things. If even what is used borrows from what is not used to prolong its utility, how much more so for the sage who embodies the Dao—neither using nor not using, yet able to achieve great utility, from which all things draw sustenance? Is this not fitting?

Ran Qiu asked Confucius: "Could one know what existed before Heaven and Earth?"
Confucius replied: "Yes. The past is like the present."
[Annotation] Heaven and Earth have always existed; there was never a time when they did not.
[Subcommentary] Ran Qiu, a disciple of Confucius, raised the question to his teacher, inquiring whether the state before the existence of the Two Modes (Heaven and Earth) could be known. Since transformation renews daily, there is no present without the past, and the past is like the present—hence the answer that it could indeed be known.

Ran Qiu, having misunderstood the question, withdrew. The next day, he returned and said: "Yesterday, I asked whether one could know what existed before Heaven and Earth. You replied, 'Yes. The past is like the present.' Yesterday, I was enlightened; today, I am confused. May I ask what this means?"
[Subcommentary] He failed to grasp the intent of his question and left. Upon reconsidering the response, he returned to seek further clarification. Yesterday, his understanding was clear; today, it is obscured. He asks what accounts for this shift from clarity to confusion.

Confucius replied: "Yesterday’s clarity came because your spirit received it first.
[Annotation] With an empty mind awaiting instruction, the spirit receives.
Today’s confusion arises because you now seek with what is not spirit.
[Annotation] Striving to understand only leads to further obscurity.
[Subcommentary] Initially, he sought without comprehension, sharpening his spirit and applying his mind to receive, hence his clarity. Later, having grasped the answer, he no longer exerted his spirit but simply rested in natural truth, making no further inquiries—hence his confusion. "Seeking" here means not seeking at all.

There is no past, no present, no beginning, no end.
[Annotation] Not only does the nonexistent not transform into existence, but the existent also does not transform into nonexistence. Thus, as a thing, the nonexistent, though undergoing a thousand changes and ten thousand transformations, cannot become nonexistent even once. Because it cannot become nonexistent even once, there has never been a time when Heaven and Earth did not exist, and they endure eternally.
[Subcommentary] Since change renews daily, there is no beginning and no end, no past and no present—hence one knows there was never a time before Heaven and Earth.

Could there be descendants without ancestors?
[Annotation] This speaks of an unbroken lineage without end.
[Subcommentary] It means that descendants do not arise from one another, and the lineage has no limit. Heaven, Earth, and all things—none have an origin or a time when they did not exist.
"Could this be?"—meaning it cannot. Ran Qiu did not respond.

Confucius said: "Enough, there is no response." Not by life does life give rise to death. [Annotation] Death is but spontaneous transformation—it is not that life gives rise to this death. Not by death does death give rise to life. [Annotation] Life, too, is but spontaneous transformation. [Subcommentary] 已 means "to cease"; 未 means "nonexistent." Gathering and scattering, death and life—all are spontaneous transformations, daily renewed, never relying on anything else, never dependent upon one another. Thus one does not use life to give rise to this death, nor death to give rise to this life. Ran Qiu’s unanswered question—Confucius bids him cease and make no response, for the principle is exhausted here. What more is there to say?

Do death and life depend upon one another? [Annotation] They are self-sufficient in spontaneous transformation. Each has its own integral form. [Annotation] Death and life each constitute a complete form. [Subcommentary] Death is spontaneous transformation—how could it become another thing? Since death does not depend upon life, we know that life does not depend upon death. Death and life, gathering and scattering—each has its own integral form, and thus nothing depends upon anything else.

Is there a thing that existed before Heaven and Earth? That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. A thing cannot emerge prior to things—it is still a thing. Since it is still a thing, there is no end. [Annotation] Who could exist prior to things? If we take yin-yang as prior to things, yet yin-yang is itself what we call a thing. Who, then, existed prior to yin-yang? If we take spontaneity as prior, yet spontaneity is but the self-so of things. If we take the supreme Dao as prior, yet the supreme Dao is the utmost nothingness. Since it is nothingness, what could precede it? Then who existed prior to things? Yet there are still things, without end—this makes clear that things are spontaneous, not made to be so by anything else. [Subcommentary] That which gives rise to things is not itself a thing. Thus, not being a thing, it has no before or after. When a thing emerges, it is a thing, and there cannot be anything prior to this thing. How do we know this? Because it is still a thing. Extending this reasoning, there is ultimately nothing that existed prior to things. Then who existed prior to things? It is clear that things are spontaneous, and spontaneity has no end. Thus we know that Heaven, Earth, and the myriad things have existed from of old, without a time when they did not exist. The sage’s love for others never ends—this, too, is drawn from this principle. [Annotation] Drawing from the self-so, kindness flows through a hundred generations without ceasing. [Subcommentary] The sage who attains the Dao, in compassionate love and nurturing care, lets kindness flow through a hundred generations without end. This is because his virtue harmonizes with Heaven and Earth, and he subtly embodies spontaneity. Thus he empties himself toward others, forgets all in his nurturing, does not impose benevolence upon the myriad things, and treats all beings as straw dogs. All this is drawn from this principle.

Yan Yuan asked Confucius, saying: "I have once heard the Master say, 'Do not send off, do not welcome.' I venture to ask about its wandering." [Subcommentary] He requests the Master’s teaching. 将 means "to send off." The sage is like a mirror, neither sending off nor welcoming. Yan Hui, not yet understanding this principle, inquires of Confucius, asking about its source.

Confucius said: "The people of old externally transformed while internally remaining untransformed." [Annotation] They let the mind follow the form, and the form transformed of itself. [Subcommentary] The ancients were pure and simple, and many accorded with the Dao. Thus they could let their external forms follow things while their inner minds remained serene. "The people of today internally transform while externally remaining untransformed." [Annotation] They use the mind to manipulate the form. [Subcommentary] Internally, they are connected through conditions, ceaselessly transforming in ignorance; externally, their forms are perverse and cannot follow things. "Those who transform with things are one with the untransformed." [Annotation] Always without mind, thus one with the untransformed. Only one with the untransformed can transform with things. "At peace with transformation, at peace with non-transformation." [Annotation] Transformation and non-transformation are both entrusted to things—this is the absence of mind. [Subcommentary] 安 means "to entrust." The sage is without mind, flowing with things. Thus transformation and non-transformation are both entrusted to things, without distinction or deliberate intent. "At peace in following them, in harmony with them." [Annotation] Simply without mind, letting them transform of themselves—not sending off or welcoming to harmonize with them. [Subcommentary] 靡 means "to follow." The so-called entrusting of transformation and non-transformation means not opposing living beings but following and harmonizing with them. "Necessarily following them, yet not excessively so." [Annotation] Without sending off or welcoming, one is sufficient and stops. [Subcommentary] Though following things in harmony, one does not excessively bestow benevolence, each stopping at its proper place, without harm to self or other.

The park of Xiwei, the garden of the Yellow Emperor, the palace of Youyu, the chambers of Tang and Wu— [Annotation] These are the places where those without mind and entrusting transformation dwell. [Subcommentary] Xiwei, the Yellow Emperor, Youyu, Tang, and Wu were all sagely and enlightened kings. The way of being without mind and following things is the wandering park of Xiwei, the roaming garden of the Yellow Emperor, the virtue-nurturing palace of Youyu, the spirit-soothing chambers of Tang and Wu—these are where the many sages advance and dwell.

The gentleman, like the masters of the Ru and Mo schools, uses this to mutually destroy one another with right and wrong—how much more so the people of today! [Annotation] 聖 means "harmony." The masters of the Ru and Mo schools are the most difficult in the world to harmonize, yet one without mind can still harmonize with them—how much more so those who are near to it! [Subcommentary] 聖 means "harmony." The masters of the Ru and Mo schools ceaselessly refute one another with right and wrong—they are the most difficult in the world to harmonize. Yet the sage and gentleman can still follow and harmonize with them. How much more so the people of today, who are not masters of the Ru and Mo schools!

Following and transforming with them—is this not fitting?

The sage dwells among things without harming them.
**[Annotation]** Utmost compliance.
**[Subcommentary]** Abiding in the world with harmonious radiance, benefiting without harming—thus they do not injure.
One who does not harm things cannot be harmed by things.
**[Annotation]** This lies within me alone.
**[Subcommentary]** Like an empty boat or drifting tile, in perfect accord with the uncarved block, the uncarved block delights in being pushed—thus they dwell without harm.
Only one who harms nothing can truly meet and welcome others.
**[Annotation]** Without mind, one attains utmost compliance; with utmost compliance, one can transcend both meeting and welcoming, yet still surpass all acts of meeting and welcoming.
**[Subcommentary]** Only by peacefully accepting the uncarved nature of things, with no injury between self and other, can one engage with the world and illuminate the truth that there is no welcoming, yet all is welcomed.

Mountains and forests—
Meadows and wilds—
They make me joyful and glad.
**[Annotation]** Mountains, forests, meadows, and wilds are not superior to me, yet I delight in them—this is joy without cause.
Before the joy is complete, sorrow follows.
**[Annotation]** Joy without cause is also sorrow without cause.
Thus, what brings joy is hardly worth rejoicing over, and what brings sorrow is hardly worth grieving.
**[Subcommentary]** Clinging to fleeting emotions, forgetting life’s joys and sorrows, one suddenly gazes upon towering mountains and lush forests, upon sacred marshes and fertile lands, and is filled with admiration, deeming it bliss. Yet before the joy has faded, sorrow follows—emotions shift with circumstances, and joy and sorrow transform. This is joy without cause, sorrow without cause; thus, the world’s sorrows and joys are not worth reckoning.

When sorrow and joy come, I cannot resist them; when they depart, I cannot halt them.
Alas! The people of the world are but inns for things.
**[Annotation]** Unable to sit in forgetfulness and attain self-mastery, they become lodgings for sorrow and joy.
**[Subcommentary]** An inn is a guesthouse. The coming of poverty and success cannot be resisted; the departure of sorrow and joy cannot be stopped. Yet the common people, ignorant of this truth, are like inns where things lodge—mistaking the false for the real, how deeply lamentable!

One knows what one encounters but not what one does not encounter.
**[Annotation]** What one knows is what one encounters; what one does not know is what one does not encounter.
One can do what one is capable of but not what one is incapable of.
**[Annotation]** What one cannot do cannot be forced.
From this perspective, knowing and not knowing, being capable and incapable—control does not lie beyond me; it should be entrusted to nature.
**[Subcommentary]** Wisdom has its clarity and obscurity; ability has its skill and clumsiness—each is endowed by one’s inherent lot, and cannot be forced. Thus, what one’s lot brings, one knows; what it does not bring, one cannot know. What one’s nature allows, one can do; what it does not allow, one cannot. Like birds flying and fish swimming, spiders weaving webs and cicadas shedding shells—all follow their nature. Is this not their inherent way?
To be without knowledge or ability is something no person can avoid.
**[Annotation]** Each receives life according to their allotted portion.
**[Subcommentary]** Since one is not a sage, one’s wisdom cannot encompass all things. Thus, knowing and not knowing, being capable and incapable—each is bestowed differently at birth, with distinct mechanisms. Yet the common people stubbornly cling to what they cannot avoid.
To strive to avoid what no person can avoid—is this not also lamentable?
**[Subcommentary]** What no person can avoid are matters beyond one’s allotted wisdom and ability. Yet the petty and base cannot accept their lot, and so they strain their emotions, striving to stand alone—how foolish and deluded, how deeply pitiable!

The ultimate word transcends words; the ultimate act transcends acts.
**[Annotation]** All arise from self-mastery.
**[Subcommentary]** The ultimate principle’s words are beyond words—thus they are transcended. The ultimate principle’s acts are beyond acts—thus they are transcended.
To equal what knowledge knows is shallow indeed.
**[Annotation]** Those who rely on knowledge to attain understanding are merely learners—thus they are shallow.
**[Subcommentary]** Seeing the worthy and striving to equal them, imitating others to improve oneself, seeking principles through learning, pursuing the Dao through intellect—this is shallow and superficial. How can it be called profound knowledge?

*Commentary on the Southern Florescence True Scripture, Scroll Twenty-Four, concludes.*
