*Commentary and Subcommentary on the Southern Florescence True Scripture, Scroll Twenty-Five*
*Annotations by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Subcommentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of the Tang, Western Florescence School**
*Miscellaneous Chapters: "Gengsang Chu" (Twenty-Third)*

There was one named Gengsang Chu among the disciples of Lao Cong, who alone attained the Dao of Lao Cong.
**[Subcommentary]** His surname was Gengsang, his given name Chu—disciple of the Old Master, a recluse indeed. *Yi* (役) denotes a disciple; in ancient times, those who served their masters shared in their labors, undaunted by hardship or peril, hence the term *yi*. Yet the Old Master, being a great sage, had countless disciples. Among his followers, Gengsang Chu was the most eminent, thus it is said he "alone attained" the Way.

He dwelt in the north upon Mount Weilü. Those among his retainers who were artfully knowing departed from him; those among his concubines who were ostentatiously virtuous distanced themselves.
**[Annotation]** *Huaran* (画然) means "adorned with knowledge"; *xuran* (絮然) means "affected with virtue."
**[Subcommentary]** Mount Weilü is a mountain in the state of Lu. *Chen* (臣) refers to servants; *qie* (妾), to concubines. This speaks of how people treat benevolence and wisdom as servants and concubines, yet Master Gengsang cast aside both benevolence and wisdom in his dealings with the noble. Since Chu was a recluse dwelling in the mountain wilds, his nature was simple and unadorned, his heart disdaining superficial elegance. The men and women of the neighboring hills vied to serve as his retainers and concubines. Thus, those who *huaran* displayed their knowledge to flaunt their cleverness were expelled and sent away; those who *xuran* paraded their virtue to set themselves apart from others were made to keep their distance.

Those who were coarse and unrefined dwelt with him; those who were carefree and at ease served him.
**[Annotation]** *Yongzhong* (拥肿) means "uncouth"; *yangzhang* (鞅掌) means "self-content."
**[Subcommentary]** *Yongzhong* and *yangzhang* both describe the appearance of simplicity and self-contentment. Having cast off benevolence and wisdom, he returned to a state of tranquil authenticity. Thus, the unadorned and sincere dwelt with him, while those who followed their nature freely served him.

After three years, Weilü experienced a great harvest.

The people of Weilü said to one another: "When Master Gengsang first arrived, we were startled and found him strange."
**[Annotation]** They found him strange for abandoning knowledge and embracing simplicity.

"Now, when we reckon by the day, it seems insufficient; when we reckon by the year, there is surplus."
**[Annotation]** One who moves in harmony with the four seasons seeks no immediate gains.
**[Subcommentary]** *Darong* means "abundance." *Sa* describes a slight startle. After three years of his dwelling here, the mountains yielded great harvests, and the people of Weilü set aside their private ways, saying: "When Master Gengsang first came, we were slightly startled by him. At first, when we calculated by the day, the benefits seemed insufficient; but when we reckoned by the year, his achievements were more than enough. For the sage, in accord with the seasons, seeks no near-term gains—thus daily reckoning falls short—but embodies far-reaching virtue, so yearly reckoning yields surplus. Three years make a intercalary cycle, a minor completion of Heaven’s Way, hence after three years Weilü enjoyed great abundance. He must be a sage! Why do we not together honor him as our ancestral spirit, worship him as our earth deity, and venerate him as our grain god?"

The people said: "To *shu* is to admire; *ji* means 'near.' *Shi* means 'to preside.' This great worthy, Master Gengsang, so admires and draws near to the virtue of the sage—why do we not together honor him as our lord, presiding over the affairs of the southern face, establishing for him an earth shrine and grain altar, and raising a ancestral temple, with prayers and sacrifices according to ritual? Would this not be good?"

Master Gengsang heard this and turned to the south with an unsettled countenance. His disciples found this strange.

When he suddenly heard the people of Weilü propose to make him lord of the southern face, it ran counter to the Way of non-action, and so he was displeased. His disciples, not yet understanding this principle, were thus puzzled and found it strange.

Master Gengsang said: "Disciples, why do you find this strange in me? When the qi of spring stirs, the hundred grasses grow; when autumn’s proper moment arrives, the ten thousand treasures ripen. Do spring and autumn act with intent to bring this about? The Way of Heaven has already unfolded of itself."

For the vital qi of spring and autumn both accord with the natural Dao, and thus act without acting.

Spring’s growth and autumn’s fruition are the constant interplay of yin and yang; summer’s flourishing and winter’s storage are the unchanging pattern of things. Do spring and autumn then deliberately bestow their bounty upon the ten thousand treasures? The natural Way has already moved of itself, and so one forgets the virtue of their giving and having. Some texts write *treasures* as *ripening*, meaning the Two Modes take the ten thousand things as their treasure, and thus in autumn bring them to completion.

I have heard that the perfected person, dwelling in a humble chamber, lets the people roam wildly without knowing where to turn.

They simply go where they will, not by conscious direction.

The *environs* are walled on four sides, each a single *du*—this is called an “encircling *du*,” the so-called “square-zhang chamber.”  Like a corpse in stillness and emptiness, hence the term “dwelling as a corpse.”  Now, for the humble folk of Weilei to whisper and scheme, wishing to set me upon the ritual stands of the worthy—am I truly the one who marks the dipper’s handle?

[Annotation] He does not wish to be the world’s pointer.

[Exegesis] *Whisper and scheme* means to discuss in pairs.  The *zu* is the table for cutting meat; the *dou* is the vessel for holding dried meats—both are ritual implements.  The flock of dragons without a head is the maxim of the ancient sages; veiling virtue and nurturing tranquility is the track of later worthies.  Now these petty, fragmented commoners, murmuring in pairs and plotting together, wish to treat me as worthy, to honor me as master—this is to make me the world’s pointer.  How can this be called one who dwells in reclusion?  Therefore, I cannot let go of the words of the venerable Lao.

[Annotation] The *Biography of the Venerable Masters* says: “When merit is complete and affairs are settled, the hundred

A mere ditch of ordinary length cannot accommodate the turning of a great fish’s body, yet the minnow’s fins dictate its bounds; a hillock of a few paces’ height cannot conceal the bulk of a mighty beast, yet the ominous fox is deemed auspicious.

[Annotation] The disciple means that a great man must possess abundant emolument.

[Exegesis] Eight *chi* make a *xun*; twice a *xun* makes a *chang*. Six *chi* make a *bu*; seven *chi* make a *ren*. The *you* is a small fish with legs—this is no match for a leviathan. To *zhi* is to dominate. How can a ditch of such modest span accommodate the circling of a whale? Yet the puny *tongqi* fish is deemed splendid. A hillock of a few paces’ height cannot conceal a great beast, yet the malevolent fox is taken as a good omen. Thus we know that mighty beasts must dwell in deep mountains, and great men require ample emolument. Moreover, to honor the worthy and appoint the capable, to reward goodness and confer benefit—this has been the way since the time of Yao and Shun. How much more should the people of Weilei follow suit? Master, you too should heed this.

[Exegesis] To honor the noble and elevate the able, to employ the good first and grant them advantage—even the sage-kings Yao and Shun acted thus. How dare the common folk of Weilei deviate from the ancients’ example? You, Master, are a man of understanding; pray, listen and comply.

Gengsangzi said: Come here, young one. The beast that can swallow a carriage, once it leaves the mountain in its armor, cannot escape the snares and nets; the fish that can gulp a boat, once stranded and deprived of water, is tormented by ants. Thus birds and beasts do not tire of lofty heights, and fish and turtles do not tire of profound depths.

[Annotation] To distance oneself from profit and avoid harm is to preserve wholeness.

[Exegesis] That beast, vast enough to engulf a carriage, once solitary and parted from the mountain, cannot evade the peril of nets and traps. The fish that can swallow a boat, though its mass is no trifle, once cast adrift and bereft of water, is harmed by ants. Thus birds and beasts seek the high mountains, and fish and turtles the deep waters—do they do so out of love for the extraordinary? No, it is to preserve their bodies and avoid harm. If even birds and fish act thus, how much more should humans? For one who would preserve his embodied life, to conceal himself is to desire nothing so much as profound remoteness.

[Annotation] To entangle oneself in emolument is to be coarse and shallow.

[Exegesis] *Miao* means distant. The man who dwells in reclusion, who preserves his form and nurtures his life, must withdraw far from the dust of the world and plunge deep into mountain springs. To entangle oneself in emolument is to be coarse and shallow.

Moreover, what merit is there in praising those two? They are hardly worthy of exaltation.

[Annotation] The two are Yao and Shun.

[Exegesis] The two are Yao and Shun. The sagely ways of Tang and Yu are the root of disorder—how can they be worthy of praise? In their disputations, they would recklessly breach the walls to plant mugwort and brambles.

[Annotation] They would cause later generations to recklessly breach and sow disorder.

[Exegesis] They would cause later generations to recklessly breach and sow disorder. To *bian* is to distinguish. To establish the ways of Yao and Shun outside the nature of things, to teach and instruct people to emulate them, is like breaking through a fine wall to plant mugwort and brambles as a fence.

To comb one’s hair strand by strand, to count the grains of rice before cooking—

[Annotation] To fuss over the merest trifles.

[Exegesis] It is like selecting and combing each hair, measuring the grains of rice before cooking—such benefits are paltry, and the harm is greater still. How can such petty efforts suffice to save the world?

[Annotation] Only in undifferentiated unity, with nothing to manage or contrive, is there salvation.

[Exegesis] To imitate Yao and Shun, to whisper and scheme in private—this is but a minor path, how can it save the world? To exalt the worthy is for the people to contend;

[Annotation] To violate their nature in awaiting what they esteem.

To employ cunning is for the people to steal.

[Annotation] When authenticity is insufficient and cunning is employed to supplement it, falsehood arises. When falsehood is used to seek life, how can theft not follow?

[Exegesis] To contend. To exalt the worthy and appoint the capable, to employ cunning and reward goodness, is to incite strife and deceit, a hundred schemes of theft and fraud. The path of competition opens, and thus they harm one another.

These several things are insufficient to enrich the people. The people’s pursuit of profit is most ardent: sons kill fathers, ministers kill rulers, thieves rob in broad daylight, and burglars tunnel through walls at noon.

[Annotation] Without any further regard.

[Exegesis] These several things refer to exalting the worthy and employing cunning. Such teachings are superficial and cannot make the people sincere and generous. Yet the common folk’s hunger for profit stirs them deeply. Private grievances and resentments give rise to usurpation and regicide, endangering the altars of state. Thieves rob in broad daylight, attack cities, and tunnel through walls at noon.

I tell you, the root of great disorder must arise in the age of Yao and Shun, and its branches will endure for a thousand generations. A thousand generations hence, there will surely be men who devour one another.

[Annotation] Yao and Shun bequeathed their legacy, spreading false adornments to later ages, leading to this corruption.

[Exegesis] The yielding and deference of Tang and Yu gave rise to usurpation and rebellion. The root of disorder began with Yao and Shun, and its ills will persist for a thousand generations. The Yellow Turbans and Red Eyebrows are instances of men devouring one another.

Nanrong Qu sat up straight with a start and said: At my age, I am already advanced in years—how can I entrust my studies to attain such words?

[Exegesis] His surname was Nanrong, his given name Qu, a disciple of Gengsang. *Cu ran* describes his startled demeanor. Having heard these teachings, Nanrong Qu was filled with admiration. Thus, with alarm and reverence, he composed himself and earnestly sought further instruction: I am old, my spirit dim and dull—what learning should I rely upon to reach such words?

Gengsangzi said: Preserve your form whole,

[Annotation] To keep to the mean.

Hold fast to your life,

[Annotation] Not to grasp beyond the bounds of life.

And let not your thoughts and cares flutter restlessly. If you do this for three years, you may attain such words.

[Exegesis] Not chasing after external objects is what it means to preserve the form whole; abiding within one’s proper bounds is what it means to hold fast to life. Once one rectifies one’s bounds and preserves life whole, the spirit congeals and the form finds ease—thus one no longer enslaves the knowing mind to restless thoughts, nor pursues life with ceaseless striving. After three years of emptiness and stillness, one may then attain such words. These are Gengsangzi’s instructions to Nanrong.

Nanrong responded: The eyes and the form—I do not perceive them as distinct, yet the blind cannot see themselves; the ears and the form—I do not perceive them as distinct, yet the deaf cannot hear themselves; the heart-mind and the form—I do not perceive them as distinct, yet the mad cannot grasp themselves.

[Annotation] Eyes and eyes, ears and ears, heart-minds and heart-minds—their forms appear alike, yet their capacities differ. If there is such difference, one cannot forcibly imitate or emulate another.

[Exegesis] Those who are blind or deaf possess eyes and ears no different from those of ordinary people, yet the blind cannot see colors, and the deaf cannot hear sounds. The mad resemble the sane in appearance, yet the mad have lost their nature and cannot grasp themselves. Nanrong offers these three analogies to illustrate the body as a whole: his failure to comprehend the words of the supreme Dao differs not from blindness or deafness. Thus, the *Inner Chapters* state: not only the physical frame may be blind or deaf—so too may wisdom. The form and the form are also closed off,

[Annotation] There has never been a barrier.

Yet do things perhaps inquire of one another, desiring to seek each other yet unable to attain one another?

[Annotation] Though the two forms stand open, they cannot attain one another—there must be some separation between them.

[Exegesis] *Bi* means "open," *wen* means "separation." The blind and the sighted—both possess open apertures in their forms; seeing and not seeing—yet in things there arises a separation. The blind and deaf seek what lies between sight and hearing, but in the end cannot attain it, just as Nanrong seeks understanding and awakening yet has no means to reach it. Now I say to you: preserve your form whole, embrace your life, and let not your thoughts and cares flutter restlessly. Strive to hear the Dao and let it reach your ears.

[Annotation] Having heard too late, the forms are already divided—thus transformation is difficult.

[Exegesis] "Preserve your form whole, embrace your life"—as explained before. Reiterating what was asked to clarify the intent of the question.

Master Gengsang said: "My words are exhausted." He continued: The darting wasp cannot transform the bean caterpillar; the Yue chicken cannot brood the swan’s egg—only the Lu chicken can do so.

[Exegesis] The *benfeng* is the narrow-waisted wasp. *Huò* is the bean; *zhú* is the large green worm found in beans. The Yue chicken is the Jing chicken; the Lu chicken is the present-day Shu chicken. The narrow-waisted wasp can transform the mulberry worm into its own offspring, yet cannot transform the bean caterpillar. The Yue chicken, being small, cannot brood the swan’s egg; the Shu chicken, being large, certainly can. This means my talent is meager and cannot transform the great—what I have said exhausts the principle of the matter. Chickens and chickens—though their virtue is not different, some can and some cannot, for their talents are inherently great or small. Now my talent is small and insufficient to transform you. Why do you not go south to see Laozi?

[Exegesis] The chicken possesses five virtues: wearing a crest upon its head is propriety; having spurs upon its feet is righteousness; calling others when it finds food is benevolence; knowing the seasons is wisdom; facing an enemy and standing its ground is courage. Though the Lu and Yue chickens differ, their heavenly virtue is the same—thus some can and some cannot because their talents differ in size. I am like the Yue chicken, my talent too small to transform you. Why do you not journey south to seek a teacher and pay homage to the Old Master?

Nanrong Chu wrapped his provisions and, after seven days and seven nights, arrived at the place of Laozi.

[Exegesis] *Yíng* means "to wrap," "to carry." His reverence for the sage was fervent, ceaseless day and night, and after seven days he finally beheld the Old Master.

Laozi said: "Have you come from Chu?"

Nanrong Chu replied: "Yes."

[Exegesis] *Zì* means "from." The question: "Have you come from the place of Sang Chu?" Nanrong Zhao replied: "Yes"—a simple, respectful affirmation.

Laozi said: "Why have you come with so many people?"

[Annotation] He came bearing the weight of three words.

[Exegesis] *Xié* means "together." Laozi, being a sage, perceived his motive as clearly as a mirror. Yet he had not forgotten benevolence and righteousness, so he reproached him for coming with others. Clinging to the three words, he thus mocked him for coming with a crowd.

Nanrong Chu, startled, looked back behind him.

The exegesis states: *Jurán* describes a startled appearance. Not yet comprehending Laozi’s words, he suddenly heard mention of “coming with a crowd,” and so he glanced behind him, fearing there were many people.

Laozi said: “Do you not understand what I meant?”

The exegesis states: *Wèi* refers to the meaning of words. When I spoke of “coming together,” I was mocking you for bearing the weight of three words. That you looked behind you shows you did not grasp my meaning.

Nanrong Chu bowed his head in shame, then raised it and sighed, saying: “Just now I forgot my reply, and so lost my question.”

The exegesis states: *Fǔ* means to lower the head. Realizing his own dullness and failure to grasp the sage’s words, he bowed in humiliation, then raised his head and sighed to the heavens. His spirit wandered in confusion, his countenance flustered. Not only had he lost his composure, but he had also forfeited his chance to ask.

Laozi said: “What do you mean?”

The exegesis states: He asked what his words signified.

Nanrong Chu said: “Do you not know? People call me a fool. Do you know? It only brings sorrow upon my body.”

The exegesis states: *Zhū yú* means “utterly foolish,” an appearance of ignorance. If one remains mired in the dust of the world, one earns the name of a fool; but if one employs wisdom to engage with others, it only invites disaster to oneself. Since the harm lies within, he speaks of “sorrow upon my body.” Without benevolence, one harms others; with benevolence, one brings sorrow upon oneself. Without righteousness, one injures others; with righteousness, one brings sorrow upon oneself. How can I escape this? These three words are the afflictions that trouble me. I wish to ask through Chu.

The exegesis states: Benevolence is the path of universal love; righteousness is the work of perfecting others. Both are the teachings of the former sages, yet they are not the way to preserve oneself and avoid harm. Thus, without benevolence or righteousness, one harms others; but practicing benevolence and righteousness, one strays from the true and turns from the Dao. Not knowing how to govern the heart to escape this and cease harm, he entrusts these three words to Sang Chu as an intermediary, hoping to remain and listen to further instruction.

Laozi said: “Earlier, I saw the question in your brows and eyes, and so I understood you. Now your words confirm it. You are like one who, having lost his parents, frantically raises a pole to search for them in the sea. You are a lost man—bewildered, adrift.”

The exegesis states: *Guīguī* means petty and fragmented. Your heart is narrow and scattered, clinging to these three burdens like a child who has lost his parents, or like a monk raising a wooden staff to seek the ocean, hoping to fathom its depths—how could that be possible? You are one who has lost the true and forsaken the Dao, a drowning man, a fugitive. Where can you find refuge? You long to reach your nature and disposition, yet have no way in—how pitiful.

The exegesis states: Nanrong Zhao treads the path of the sages yet drowns in benevolence and righteousness. Though he desires to return to the origin and restore his true nature, the wounds have already formed, and there is no way in. The great sage, moved by compassion, finds this deeply lamentable.

Nanrong Chu asked to return to his lodging. There, he summoned what he loved and cast aside what he despised. After ten days of sorrowful reflection, he again sought out Laozi.

The exegesis states: Having lost his question, his mind wandered in confusion. He withdrew to his dwelling, spent ten days in contemplation, pursuing the Dao and virtue he cherished, and discarding the benevolence and righteousness he loathed. Yet he still could not grasp the Dao, so he grieved and, hoping for further instruction, returned to see Laozi.

Laozi said: “You have cleansed yourself—how thoroughly, how deeply! Yet within, there still lingers something foul, seeping out.”

The exegesis states: After returning home for ten days, he had washed away the five impurities and purified his accumulated grime. Yet when I observe your qi, though it is dense and profound, and though you have applied effort, it still leaks—this proves that the foulness is not yet fully expelled. That which is grasped externally cannot be seized in abundance, lest it strike within; that which is grasped internally cannot be seized in error, lest it strike without.

Here follows the translation:

---

The annotation states: *Jian* is the bolt of a lock. The ears and eyes belong to the external; the heart’s extension belongs to the internal. To preserve the body and embrace life, nothing compares to forgetting the heart’s extension and relinquishing the ears and eyes. If sounds and sights assail from without, then the heart’s extension becomes obstructed within; if desires and aversions are seized within, then the ears and eyes are lost without. Only when the lock is neither gained nor lost can one attain passage.

The exegesis states: *Huo* denotes being bound. *Jian* refers to closing. *Fan* means urgency. *Miu* means earnestness. When one employs the ears and eyes externally and is seized by sounds and sights, the spirit becomes closed and obstructed within. If one employs the heart’s intelligence internally and is led by desires and aversions, then the ears and eyes become closed and obstructed without. This is the mutual resonance of internal and external, the sign of the lock. Even if one uses the mind to restrain, grasps urgently with the hands, or earnestly clings, there is no way to attain it. Only when the spirit is settled within and the ears and eyes are still without does one accord with the Way of preserving life. Those who are seized externally and internally cannot be upheld by the Dao and virtue—how much less those who abandon the Dao and act recklessly?

The annotation states: Partial seizure is already impossible—how much more when both external and internal are seized? When the ears and eyes are dazzled without and the heart’s guard drifts within, even if one grasps urgently with the hands or clings earnestly, one cannot stop it.

The exegesis states: Partial attachment to one side already deviates from the principle of life—how much more when both internal and external are submerged in delusion, deepening the confusion? Even those who embrace the Dao and hold to virtue cannot uphold themselves—how much less those who scatter the profound Dao and indulge in such delusions, hoping to restrain them?

Nanrong Chu said: If a villager is ill, and another villager asks about it, the sick one can describe his illness—yet if he can still speak of his illness, he is not yet truly ill.

The exegesis states: When someone in the village is ill, and neighbors inquire, if the sick person can describe his symptoms, though ill, he is not yet gravely afflicted and may still be cured. This is like Nanrong, who, though foolish, can confess his faults and thus may be taught. But when Chu hears the great Dao, it is like taking medicine that worsens the illness.

The exegesis states: Medicine is for curing illness; when the illness is gone, the medicine is dissolved. Teaching is for awakening insight; when insight is awakened, teaching ceases. If one is not truly ill, the medicine does not dissolve; if the teaching remains and insight does not awaken, is this not like taking medicine that worsens the illness? Chu only wishes to hear the classic of preserving life.

The exegesis states: *Jing* means constancy. *Yi* means cessation. The teachings of the sages are manifold, and the gates of learning are not one. What I now seek is to preserve life; my heart’s intent rests solely upon this. If you would instruct me, I shall take it as my constant guide.

Laozi said: In the classic of preserving life, can you embrace the One?

The annotation states: Not departing from one’s nature.

The exegesis states: Guarding the true without duality.

Can you not lose it?

The annotation states: Returning to one’s own attainment.

The exegesis states: Attaining one’s own nature.

Can you know good and ill fortune without divination?

The annotation states: What accords is good; what transgresses is ill—no need for divination.

The exegesis states: Treading the Dao is good; pursuing things is ill. This principle is certain—why resort to divination?

Can you stop?

The annotation states: Stopping at one’s allotted portion.

The exegesis states: Not pursuing what lies beyond one’s portion.

Can you cease?

The annotation states: Not chasing past paths.

The exegesis states: Not pursuing what has passed.

Can you abandon others and seek within yourself?

The annotation states: Preserving the self without imitating others.

The exegesis states: *Zhu* means "in." Abandoning the mind that imitates others and pursuing the Dao within oneself.

Can you be supple?

The annotation states: Without lingering traces.

The exegesis states: Coming and going without attachment.

Can you be yielding?

The annotation states: Without obstruction.

The exegesis states: Accord with things without resistance.

Can you be like a child?

The exegesis states: Like a newborn babe.

A child may wail all day without hoarseness or strain, for harmony is perfect.

The annotation states: Letting the voice emerge naturally, not due to joy or anger.

The exegesis states: *Ya* means throat obstruction. *Geng* means voice breaking. Letting the qi issue forth in sound, the heart free of joy or anger, the child may cry all day without breaking or obstruction. Such pure harmony, such steadfastness, attains this state.

All day it grasps without the hand growing weary, for it shares in the power.

The annotation states: Letting the hand grasp naturally, not holding alone.

The exegesis states: *Zhao* means cramping. *Lao* means weariness. Because its harmony is one with the profound Dao and its utmost power.

All day it gazes without the eyes shifting, for its focus is not on externals.

The annotation states: Letting the eyes see naturally, not bound to sights.

The exegesis states: *Xuan* means movement. Letting the eyes see without the gaze shifting, not fixating on external dust.

It walks without knowing its destination.

The annotation states: Letting the feet walk naturally, without aim.

The exegesis states: *Zhi* means "to go." Like a boat untethered, though it moves, it has no fixed destination.

It dwells without knowing what it does.

The annotation states: Letting the body follow its own course.

The exegesis states: Serene and inactive, the utmost stillness.

It flows with things,

The annotation states: This is accordance.

The exegesis states: Engaging with things without resistance, bending and yielding.

and moves with their waves.

The annotation states: The waves of things are also its waves.

The exegesis states: Blending light and merging traces, moving with their waves.

This is the classic of preserving life.

The exegesis states: Summarizing the foregoing, completing the meaning.

Nanrong Chu said: Then is this the virtue of the perfected person?

The annotation states: If one can reform oneself and employ these words, one may yet be called the virtue of the perfected person.

The exegesis states: Following the aforementioned classic of preserving life and practicing it accords with the profound Dao.

Is this all there is to the virtue of the perfected person? No, it is not. This is what is called the thawing of ice and the melting of frost—

The annotation states: If one can achieve this, it is clear this does not arise of itself.

The exegesis states: Nanrong has long been constrained by benevolence and righteousness; only now, upon hearing the sagely teaching, does he begin to understand the preservation of life. It is like winter ice meeting the spring sun—his clinging, stagnant heart dissolves and scatters at this moment. This awakening comes through learning, not by natural spontaneity. If one can achieve this, it is clear it is not yet true.

This is Laozi’s answer to Yue’s question.

The perfected person shares in eating from the earth and delights together in heaven—

The annotation states: Without a heart of his own, he is one with all things.

The exegesis states: The perfected person, free of partiality, responds to things as they arise. Thus, he shares in the sustenance of all beings from the earth and delights in heaven together with the common folk. *Jiao* means "to share."

He does not use the gains and losses of others to disturb himself, nor does he conspire with them in strangeness, nor plot with them, nor act with them—

The exegesis states: *Lou* means "to disturb." The perfected person, with an empty heart, follows the world and moves with the waves of things. Thus, he puts an end to strange phenomena in the realm of ordinary life and severs scheming discourse among the masses. Since he does not treat affairs as affairs, how could gains and losses disturb him?

He comes and goes, drifting like a fish, moving like a startled deer.

This is called the classic of guarding life.

The exegesis states: Reiterating the preceding text to conclude its meaning.

It is asked: Can one truly reach this state?

The commentary notes: Does this mean one can attain this through mere words?

The exegesis states: Hearing these words, one may approach the ultimate.

Nanrong, dull of wit, pressed Laozi further.
Laozi replied: Not yet.
I have already told you: Can you be like an infant?

The commentary notes: This is not to say the words themselves are insufficient, but that those who merely hear and study them do not attain it on their own. If one does not reach it independently, then even hearing the ultimate words can only serve as a classic—how could one truly arrive? Thus, the learner does not attain, and the attainer does not learn.

The exegesis states: The phrase "can you" is an encouraging exhortation. Though these words are ultimate, they remain like the fish-trap and rabbit-snare. Since I have told you, you must receive them through study. Yet the learner does not attain, and the attainer does not learn—fish and trap differ in kind, hence the answer: "Not yet." This is Laozi’s further reply to Nanrong.

An infant moves without knowing what it does, walks without knowing where it goes. Its body is like the branch of a withered tree, and its heart is like dead ashes.

The exegesis states: Empty, tranquil, and serene, without emotion—like a withered tree that bears no blossoms, or dead ashes that cast no light. When both body and heart are doubly relinquished, how can its movements be known? This is the essence of guarding life.

Should one be thus, neither misfortune arrives nor fortune comes. With neither misfortune nor fortune, how can there be human calamity?

**Commentary:** Misfortune and fortune arise from loss and gain; human calamity stems from love and aversion. Now, like withered wood or dead ashes, utterly devoid of emotion, love and aversion, loss and gain have no means to arise.

**Exegesis:** Misfortune and fortune are born of gain and loss; human calamity arises from beauty and ugliness. Now, with form like withered wood and heart like dead ashes, gain and loss both forgotten, beauty and ugliness both relinquished—even the obscure cannot be blamed, so how can calamity enter? When the dwelling of power is tranquil and settled, it emits the radiance of Heaven.

**Commentary:** When the dwelling of virtue is serene and settled, what it emits is the radiance of Heaven, not human brilliance.

**Exegesis:** The body is the abode of spirit, hence the perfected person is called the dwelling of Dao and virtue. When the dwelling of virtue is peaceful, tranquil, and settled, the light it emits to illuminate things arises from the natural radiance of wisdom. That which emits the radiance of Heaven is seen by others as human,

**Commentary:** The radiance of Heaven emits of itself; thus, others see it as human, and things see it as things. Each sees itself and not the other, which is why it remains serene and settled.

**Exegesis:** The common and mediocre cannot fathom the sage; they see only one among the multitude, unaware of the distant illumination of Heaven’s radiance. Should there be one who cultivates, only then is there constancy.

**Commentary:** One who cultivates humanity attains self-mastery, hence remains perpetually serene.

**Exegesis:** *Heng* means constancy. Though principle severs learning, the Way still relies on seeking. Thus, those who truly cultivate can unite with the constancy of the congealed Dao. Those who are constant are sheltered by others and aided by Heaven.

**Commentary:** Being perpetually serene, one returns to dwell in one’s own abode and naturally receives assistance.

**Exegesis:** Those who embody constancy move in accord with auspicious convergence; they are sheltered by the people and blessed by the August Heaven—is this not fitting? Those sheltered by others are called Heaven’s people; those aided by Heaven are called Heaven’s son.

**Commentary:** When active, one is Heaven’s son; when at rest, one is Heaven’s people—both are capable. This is achieved through serenity and self-mastery, not through striving.

**Exegesis:** When active, one is sovereign; when at rest, one is a recluse—both attain this through embodying the Dao and constancy. The learner learns what cannot be learned; the doer does what cannot be done; the debater debates what cannot be debated.

**Commentary:** What can be done, though done, is not doing; what can be practiced, though practiced, is not learning; what can be said, though said, is not debating.

**Exegesis:** What lies within one’s portion, though done, is not doing—thus, though one learns, it is not learning; though one acts, it is not acting; though one debates, it is not debating. How could one then act beyond one’s portion or learn what cannot be learned? To know to stop at what cannot be known is perfection.

**Commentary:** What cannot be known cannot be forcibly known, hence stopping here is perfection.

**Exegesis:** Following what one can do and stopping at one’s portion—what cannot be known is not forcibly known. This is the ultimate subtlety of learning. Should there be one who does not abide by this, the balance of Heaven will ruin them.

**Commentary:** Though one may intend to act, acting will bring ruin; in the end, it cannot be done.

**Exegesis:** Should one harbor intentions beyond one’s portion, not taking what lies within as right, this is to ruin the natural nature. Prepare things to nurture form,

**Commentary:** Follow what is naturally prepared and accord with the completion of form.

**Exegesis:** *Jiang* means to accord. The great furnace of creation provides all things in full; one need only accord with the completion of form in seeking principle. Conceal without anticipation to give rise to the heart,

**Commentary:** The heart arises of itself, not through anticipation. *Yu* means conjecture and estimation.

**Exegesis:** The perfected person is without emotion; things move, and response follows. Embracing the wisdom of the sage, the heart arises in encounter with things, yet never premeditates or conjectures. Revere the inner to reach the outer,

**Commentary:** Principle reaches the outer of itself, not through revering the inner while neglecting the outer.

**Exegesis:** The inner is inner wisdom; the outer is external circumstances. Revering and honoring spiritual wisdom, one dares not lightly defile it. With wisdom congealed and tranquil, circumstances naturally become empty and open. Should the myriad evils arrive in this state, they are all of Heaven,

**Commentary:** The principles of Heaven inherently have exhaustion and passage.

and not of human,

**Commentary:** Acting to bring about evil is of human origin.

**Exegesis:** Though King Wen was imprisoned at Youli and Confucius was besieged at Kuang, their wisdom was not dim, nor were they not sages—yet they encountered such myriad evils and exhaustion. This was due to the timing and fate of Heaven, not human action. It is not enough to disturb completion.

**Commentary:** Accepting bitter fate, their completion remains undisturbed.

**Exegesis:** *Gu* means disorder. Embodying the Dao and uniting with truth, one accords with time and comprehends fate. Even when encountering myriad evils, it is not enough to disorder the heart of great completion. It cannot enter the numinous terrace.

**Commentary:** The numinous terrace is the heart; when clear and unobstructed, sorrow and restlessness cannot enter.

**Exegesis:** *Nei* means to enter. The numinous terrace is the heart. With the wondrous body empty and tranquil, worldly things cannot enter the numinous terrace. The numinous terrace has that which holds,

**Commentary:** That which holds means not being moved by things; in reality, it is not holding.

**Exegesis:** Only the heart that can hold is valued, yet one does not know how it holds. Yet it is not known what it holds,

**Commentary:** If one knew what it held, it would be holding.

and what cannot be held.

**Commentary:** To hold is to lose.

**Exegesis:** If one harbors the intention to hold, one strays far from it—hence, it cannot be done. Not seeing one’s sincerity and yet acting,

**Commentary:** This is reckless action.

each action is inappropriate.

Those whose actions do not arise from genuine sincerity—how could they ever be appropriate?

**Commentary:** Actions not rooted in one’s true sincerity cannot be fitting.

**Exegesis:** The preceding passage revealed the luminous wisdom of those who attain the Dao; what follows clarifies how those who lose their true nature err with deluded minds, straying into silence. *Sincerity* means reality. Without ever turning inward to reflect with true wisdom, one rashly acts from a deluded heart. Since the heart is not genuine, every action deviates from what is truly fitting. Karma enters and does not depart.

**Commentary:** Matters exceed one’s proper bounds.

**Exegesis:** *Karma* means affairs. Worldly affairs, tangled and chaotic, constantly enter the heart. Failing to discern what to reject or accept, one cannot let them go. Each time, one errs further.

**Commentary:** Only actions arising from genuine sincerity are deemed right.

**Exegesis:** Each time the heart acts deludedly, it chases after external objects, mistaking this for attainment—yet it only further loses its true nature. Those who do evil openly are punished by others; those who do evil in secret are punished by spirits.

**Exegesis:** Though humans and spirits differ in their visible and hidden paths, when it comes to acting with sincerity and treading truth, the Dao admits no separation. If one strays from one’s proper bounds and loses truth, retribution follows—resentment and response intertwine, leading to punishment. The cases of Zai Bo and Peng Sheng exemplify this. Only those who are clear about humans and clear about spirits can walk alone.

**Commentary:** With nothing to feel ashamed of in the seen or unseen, one walks alone without fear.

**Exegesis:** When the two paths of the seen and unseen are free of reproach, and one does not offend others, one can walk alone without fear. Those within their allotted bounds act without seeking fame.

**Commentary:** *Allotted bounds* means one’s proper share. Those who move within their bounds do not act for the sake of fame.

**Exegesis:** *Allotted bounds* means one’s share. *Without fame* is the Dao. Those who tread the Dao and act within their bounds do so without seeking advancement through fame. Those beyond their allotted bounds fix their minds on extravagant waste.

**Commentary:** Whether beneficial or not, they strive to diminish themselves for the sake of others.

**Exegesis:** *Extravagant waste* means ultimate ruin. Those who posture and act beyond their bounds, their minds wandering outside their proper share, achieve no true benefit and ultimately suffer loss. Those who act without seeking fame possess an inherent radiance.

**Commentary:** This radiance is innate and thus employed.

**Exegesis:** *Possess* means to employ. Those whose minds abide in the nameless Dao find their wisdom’s use growing ever more luminous. Those who fix their minds on extravagant waste are but merchants.

**Commentary:** Though they lack what they seek, they still borrow from others to trade.

**Exegesis:** Those who fix their minds on what lies beyond their bounds, striving for fame and profit while depleting their spirit and wisdom, are driven solely by reputation and gain—like merchants who buy high to sell. Others see their peril, yet they remain complacent.

**Commentary:** Those who pursue extravagance see their own downfall, yet still consider themselves secure.

**Exegesis:** *Peril* means danger. *Complacent* means at ease. Those who greedily grasp and seek beyond their bounds appear dangerous to others, yet they themselves feel secure—utter folly. Those who exhaust themselves with things are entered by things.

**Commentary:** *Exhaust* means to follow through to the end.

**Exegesis:** This refers to cessation. Those who harmonize with things, exhausting principle and fulfilling their nature, become a refuge for external things. Those who merely dabble with things cannot even contain themselves—how could they contain others?

**Commentary:** *Dabble* refers to those who act beyond their bounds and stumble. The stumbling cannot stand—how could they contain themselves? Unable to contain themselves, how could they contain others? If others are not contained, they depart.

**Exegesis:** Those who casually engage with others, clinging to superficiality, seeking profit and fame, their bodies already strained and their hearts restless—unable to contain themselves, how could they contain others? Those who cannot contain others have no intimacy; those with no intimacy are abandoned by all.

**Commentary:** If one cannot even contain oneself, then even the self is not one’s own—how could there be intimacy? Thus, all become others.

**Exegesis:** Narrow-mindedness precludes intimacy; without intimacy, all become others. With many adversaries and few allies, how can one hope for peace and security? No weapon is more reckless than the will—even the finest swords are inferior.

**Commentary:** What the will seizes burns like fire and congeals like ice—thus, it is more destructive than blades.

**Exegesis:** Weapons and blades are instruments of violence; *Mó Zōu* is an excellent sword. Yet nothing is more poisonously harmful than the heart. What the heart’s will pursues acts swiftly without haste—its harm surpasses even the finest swords. By comparison, armed conflict is inferior. No enemy is greater than yin and yang—there is no escape from them within heaven and earth.

**Exegesis:** *Enemy* means adversary. The heart’s gains and losses, joys and sorrows, wage war within the breast—its cold congeals like ice, its heat burns like fire. This is the enemy of yin and yang. Though one might flee a mighty foe, how can one escape when the battle arises within the heart? It is not that yin and yang harm one, but that the heart commands them.

**Commentary:** When the heart commands qi, yin and yang congeal in the five viscera, and their presence pervades everywhere—thus, there is no escape.

**Exegesis:** This is not that yin and yang harm people, but that the heart’s restlessness causes it. The Dao flows through both one’s allotted share and its completion—its fulfillment is also its ruin.

**Commentary:** Completion and ruin have no fixed share, yet the Dao flows through both.

**Exegesis:** All things receive qi according to their limits—beauty and ugliness, good and evil, are discerned by their allotted shares. What one calls completion, another calls ruin. The Dao flows through all, leaving nothing incomplete. What is detestable about one’s allotted share is that it is complete in itself.

**Commentary:** Not abiding by one’s share yet seeking completion is why one detests it.

**Exegesis:** Honor and disgrace, long life and early death, are bestowed by nature. Within one’s original share, one is already complete.

Those who stray beyond their allotted share to seek completion wander the realm of right and wrong, detesting the share they have received. What is detestable about completion is that it is already complete.

**Commentary:** One’s original share is not complete, yet one seeks completion—this is why completion is detestable. If one’s original share were inherently complete, how could it be detested?

**Exegesis:** To resent what nature has already bestowed is to fail to recognize that one was complete from the beginning. Thus, to depart and not return is to become a ghost.

**Commentary:** Failing to return and abide within one’s allotted share ensures that death is not far off.

**Exegesis:** To depart in delusion, blindly pursuing the realm of right and wrong without returning to one’s origin, is to hasten toward death—hence, one appears as a ghost. To depart and gain is called gaining death.

**Commentary:** Not departing brings no gain, yet this is how life is preserved.

**Exegesis:** To let the heart depart in pursuit of things, indulging desire and obtaining what it seeks, is to grasp the root of death and extinction. Extinction with substance is one with the ghostly.

**Commentary:** Having extinguished one’s nature, though one still lives, how is this different from a ghost?

**Exegesis:** To lose one’s original nature and cling to the body as real is to blur the distinction between death and the ghostly—thus, one becomes one with ghosts. It is by the formed that the formless is modeled and made definite.

**Commentary:** Though one has form, if one can remain vast and free of attachment, life is preserved and form stabilized.

**Exegesis:** *Xiang* means "to resemble." Though one has form, to resemble the formless is to recognize that form is not truly existent. To be vast and forget the self is to harmonize the spirit and stabilize the light. Does emergence have no source?

**Commentary:** It arises of itself, without a source.

To enter has no home.

**Commentary:** It perishes of itself, without a root.

**Exegesis:** Emergence is birth; entry is death. From nothing emerges something, yet something has no root or origin. From something returns nothing, yet nothing has no aperture. There is substance yet nowhere to reside; there is length yet no root or branch.

**Exegesis:** *Piao* means "branch" or "origin." Here, it follows the character’s reading. From nothing emerges something—this body is real, yet when one seeks its cause, there is nowhere it resides. From ancient times to the present, it is vast and long, yet when one traces past and present, there is no root or branch. There is emergence yet no aperture—what is real has substance.

**Commentary:** What emerges has substance, yet its emergence has no root or aperture.

**Exegesis:** What emerges without an aperture, when viewed superficially, seems to have substance, yet in truth, it does not. There is substance yet nowhere to reside—this is space.

**Commentary:** Space has four directions, above and below, yet these directions have no limit.

**Exegesis:** Space is the four directions, above and below. When things arise, they seem to have substance, yet when one seeks their place within space, there is nowhere they come from. If space is not so, how can there be a place? There is length yet no root or branch—this is time.

**Commentary:** Time has the length of past and present, yet this length has no end.

**Exegesis:** Time is past and present. The span of seasons is called past and present; when one traces the succession of ages, there is no root or branch. If time is not so, how can there be a root? There is life, there is death, there is emergence, there is entry—yet in emergence and entry, no form is seen.

**Commentary:** Life and death, emergence and entry, all arise of themselves, without cause—thus, no form is seen.

**Exegesis:** Emergence and entry arise from life and death. Though emergence and entry have names, when one exhaustively investigates their nature, there is no form of emergence or entry to be seen. This is called the Gate of Heaven.

**Commentary:** The Gate of Heaven is the collective name for the ten thousand things. To call it the Gate of Heaven is like calling it the Gate of Myriad Mysteries.

**Exegesis:** Heaven refers to the natural; the natural means having no cause. All things arise without source, their origins unfathomable—this is the gate of creation. The Gate of Heaven is nothingness, and the ten thousand things emerge from nothingness.

**Commentary:** Life and death, emergence and entry, all arise of themselves, without a doer. Though there is gathering and scattering, concealment and revelation—hence the names of emergence and entry—these are merely names; in truth, there is no emergence or entry. Where, then, is the gate? Thus, nothingness is the gate. If nothingness is the gate, then there is no gate.

**Exegesis:** The principle of nature, the gate of creation, has only a name and no reality. Yet all things emerge from this gate—hence, Guo’s commentary says "nothingness is the gate." If nothingness is the gate, then there is no gate. The existent cannot make existence exist.

**Commentary:** Before existence exists, what makes it exist? It must arise from itself—how can existence make existence exist?

**Exegesis:** Once existence exists, how can it make existence exist? Before existence exists, what gives rise to it? When one seeks the origin of existence, there is no existence. It must emerge from nothingness.

**Commentary:** This clarifies that existence cannot make existence exist but arises from itself—not that nothingness can make existence exist. If nothingness could make existence exist, what would nothingness be?

**Exegesis:** Whether existence has arisen or not, both are nothingness. That existence emerges from nothingness does not mean nothingness gives rise to existence. If nothingness could give rise to existence, what would nothingness be? Yet nothingness does not have a single nothingness.

**Commentary:** If there were a single nothingness, it would be absolute nothingness. If nothingness were absolute, then existence would arise of itself—this is clear.

**Exegesis:** Beyond all negations and affirmations, all is nothingness—hence, "a single nothingness."

The sage conceals himself herein.
**Commentary:** He allows things to arise of themselves, yet does not generate generation.
**Exegesis:** The sage of profound virtue, in dark union with the truth, conceals spirit and hides wisdom—herein he abides.

The ancients, their knowledge reached a point of utmost attainment.
**Exegesis:** The sages of primordial antiquity, those who attained the Dao, merged knowledge with reality—thus it was called "utmost."

How did it reach this point?
**Exegesis:** By what means did it attain this? What was done to reach it?

There were those who took "never yet having had things" as the utmost, the ultimate—nothing could be added to it.
**Exegesis:** This reveals the form and state of utmost attainment. Knowledge having reached its apex, all within observation is empty—thus they could employ all dharmas of existence while never having had a single thing. This may be called the most refined and subtle, the exhaustion of principle and the fulfillment of nature, the height of emptiness and wonder—nothing more could be added.

Next were those who took "having things" as their view,
**Exegesis:** Those below this, not having grasped true emptiness, regarded the ten thousand phenomena as "having things."

and who saw life as loss,
**Commentary:** Loss of its dispersion to gather into unity.
with death as return.
**Commentary:** Returning to fusion and fluidity.
**Exegesis:** Loss means deprivation. The common crowd takes life as gain and death as loss. Now, to reverse deluded sentiments, they take life as loss—for it is nothingness—and death as return, a return to emptiness and quiescence. Though not yet having exhausted the utmost wonder, they still equalize life and death.

Thus they made distinctions.
**Commentary:** Though they sought to equalize, distinctions remained.
**Exegesis:** Though they equalized life and death, they still perceived differences between life and death—thus distinctions arose from what is not.

Next were those who said: "First there was nothingness, then came life, and life swiftly turned to death."
They took nothingness as the head, life as the body, and death as the corpse.
Whoever knows the one who guards the unity of existence, nothingness, death, and life—I befriend him.
**Exegesis:** Those below this, their minds gradually aligning, first held nothingness, then from nothingness came life, and in an instant, this life perished. Thus they took nothingness as the head, life as the body, and death as the corpse. Whoever knows the non-duality of existence, nothingness, life, and death and cultivates this unity—Zhuangzi would befriend such a one, yet these are rare indeed.

Though these three differ, they belong to the same clan.
**Commentary:** Some take existence as nothingness, some unify existence, and some equalize distinctions—hence the three.
These three, though some exhaust and some do not, all can keep their breasts free of right and wrong—thus they are called the "public clan."
**Exegesis:** The three refer to taking nothingness as the head, life as the body, and death as the corpse. Within one body, these three differences arise, like the Chu royal house dividing one surname into three clans: the Zhaos, the Jings, and the Qu Yuans. The Zhaos wore caps, the Jings bore them, and the Jia clans were enfeoffed—though not one, they were all of the same lineage.
**Commentary:** Though these four belong to the public clan, they are no longer one—thus the three above are further differentiated.
**Exegesis:** Zhao, Qu, and Jing were the three surnames of the Chu royal clan. In ancient times, Qu Yuan served as the Grand Master of the Three Gates, overseeing the three clans and three surnames—these are they. The text here is abbreviated, hence it speaks only of Zhao and Jing. The royal scions, having grown and come of age, wore robes and bore caps. Each held rank and served in office, their surnames granted by their posts—thus the Jia clans. With achievements recorded, they were enfeoffed with land, their branches spreading—hence they were not one. Like the Dao dividing into existence, nothingness, life, and death, with different kinds and names, the text draws this analogy from within the clan.

Existence is a flaw,
**Commentary:** Merely the gathering of qi.
**Exegesis:** A flaw is a blemish. To call this formless thing "existence" is merely the gathering of qi into a blemish—nothing to be prized.

and yet it is said: "This shifts."
**Commentary:** Once distinctions are made, each takes what it takes as "this." "This" is not constant, hence it "shifts."
**Exegesis:** To divide is to scatter. The Dao has no "that" or "this," yet things have right and wrong. Right and wrong are not fixed, thus they scatter and shift without constancy. The state of this shifting is described below.

I have spoken of this shifting, yet it is not what is spoken.
**Commentary:** The shifting of "this" has already appeared before words.
**Exegesis:** Principles take form in right and wrong, hence they are sometimes spoken. Yet the shifting of right and wrong is not faithful to words.

Nevertheless, it cannot be known.
**Commentary:** If its shifting is not spoken, then its shifting cannot be known—thus it is tentatively spoken.
**Exegesis:** Though right and wrong do not arise from words, without words there would be no way to know right and wrong. Thus, tentatively speaking of right and wrong dispels right and wrong. If names did not rely on words, one would not know the absence of right and wrong in right and wrong.

The sacrificial victim’s limbs are complete—
they can be dismembered, yet cannot be dismembered.
**Commentary:** Each thing has its use.
**Exegesis:** The *la* sacrifice is the great offering. The limbs are the hundred parts of the body. *Gai* means complete, also referring to the ox’s hooves. During the *la* sacrifice, the sacrificial animals are most complete, their four limbs and five organs all arrayed. Once the rites conclude, they are dismembered—here, dismemberment is proper. Yet if the sacrifice is not yet complete, dismemberment would be improper—thus dismemberment is not always proper. This shows that right and wrong, "this" and "not-this," shift without constancy.

The observer of the chamber circles the ancestral temple,
then proceeds to the privy.
**Commentary:** The privy is where one retires.
**Exegesis:** The privy is the retiring place. Once the rites conclude, the officiants feast, the remaining offerings set within the chamber. The observer circles the ancestral temple, then proceeds to the privy.

After feasting for long, one must relieve oneself, so one retreats to the park to urinate. Feasting deems the ancestral temple proper, while urination deems the park proper—right and wrong shift without constancy, so what is truly fixed? The *la* sacrifice reveals that gathering and dispersal are not absolute; the observer of the chamber shows that places are not fixed. Neither admits of right or wrong. This is to illustrate the shifting of "this."

**Commentary:** The ancestral temple is for feasting and banquets; the privy is for retiring to relieve oneself. When one retires to relieve oneself, the propriety of the ancestral temple shifts to the privy. Thus, the shifting of right and wrong—now this, now that—who can keep it constant? Therefore, the perfected person rides these shifts and finds them equal.

Let us speak of the shifting of "this." Life is taken as the root.
**Commentary:** In the transformations of things, there is no moment that is not life—wherever there is life, that is the root.
**Exegesis:** Those who forget life and death are without "this" or "not-this," yet they cling to life and so grasp at "this." If one could relinquish life, where would "this" reside? Thus, the shifting of "this" takes life as its root.

Knowledge is taken as the teacher.
**Commentary:** Though what is known differs, each takes its own knowledge as teacher, thereby riding the shifts of right and wrong.
**Commentary:** To ride right and wrong is to be without right and wrong.
**Exegesis:** Following the mind that takes knowledge as teacher, the mind rides the function of right and wrong—how could one know that the teacher of knowledge, in its inversion of right and wrong, is without right and wrong?

There are indeed names and realities.
**Commentary:** The names and realities of things are indeed each self-possessed.
**Exegesis:** All things, in their multiplicity, are entirely illusory—like straw dogs and the ten thousand images, what names and realities do they truly have? Yet those who invert and misplace them insist there is a fixed order of names and realities.

Thus, one takes oneself as the measure.
**Commentary:** *Zhi* means master. Each thing deems itself right, sufficient to be the master of right and wrong.
**Exegesis:** *Zhi* means master. Deludedly grasping names and realities, one takes oneself as the master of names and realities and so contends over right and wrong.

This leads others to take one as their standard.
**Commentary:** All deem themselves right, so none communicate.
**Exegesis:** *Jie* means ultimate conduct. Having lost the thread of names and realities and clung to right and wrong, one causes the unenlightened to firmly grasp empty names as their standard of conduct.

Thus, one dies to repay one’s standard.
**Commentary:** What one guards is not truly relinquished.
**Exegesis:** Guarding right and wrong to perfect one’s conduct, one clings stubbornly and expects to die holding fast. Such a one deems action wise and inaction foolish, penetration illustrious and obstruction shameful.
**Commentary:** Unable to follow what one encounters and find peace in it.
**Exegesis:** Taking ostentation as wisdom and withdrawal as foolishness, penetration as honor and obstruction as disgrace—how could such a one unite honor and disgrace, obstruction and penetration?

The shifting of "this" belongs to the people of today.
**Commentary:** The people of remote antiquity were without "this" or "not-this"—what shifting could there be?
**Exegesis:** Those who stubbornly grasp names and realities, shifting and clinging to right and wrong, are the shallow and deceptive people of this degenerate age—how could they be the simple and honest men of high antiquity?

This is like the cicada and the young dove, identical in their identity.
**Commentary:** Identical in sharing what they deem identical.
**Exegesis:** The cicada and the young dove deem the bramble and the thorn proper. Their identity in this is not a penetrating vision—those who shift "this" are of this kind. The cicada is identical to the dove, the dove identical to the cicada—thus, identical in their identity.

If one treads on a stranger’s foot in the marketplace, one apologizes with an excuse of carelessness.
**Commentary:** Claiming one’s mistake was inadvertent to apologize.
**Exegesis:** *Ju* means to tread or trample. Trampling the foot of a stranger in the marketplace, one apologizes, saying one was haughty, reckless, and mistaken—it was not intentional.

If it is one’s elder brother, one merely coos in sympathy.
**Commentary:** Speaking softly to console, without apology.
**Exegesis:** Treading on one’s elder brother’s foot, one merely coos in sympathy, not shamed into speech.

If it is one’s parent, one says nothing at all.
**Commentary:** Clearly aware of the natural forbearance.
**Exegesis:** If a father treads on his son’s foot, he remains silent, without needless apology.

Thus, one knows that the exchange of words is empty and insincere. Therefore, it is said: The utmost ritual does not involve others.
**Commentary:** "Does not involve others" means seeing others as oneself. Seeing others as oneself precludes apologies—this is the utmost ritual.
**Exegesis:** From the perspective of both parties, seeing others as oneself means not deeming others external to oneself—what apology could there be? This is the utmost ritual.

The utmost rightness does not treat things as things.
**Commentary:** Each attains its proper place, so things are all oneself.
**Exegesis:** Abandoning both self and things, one subtly attains what is proper—not excluding things as external to oneself, what right or wrong could there be? This is the utmost rightness.

The utmost knowledge does not scheme.
**Commentary:** Knowledge that schemes afterward is not natural knowledge.
**Exegesis:** Illuminating by following one’s nature is not knowledge that schemes—this is the utmost knowledge.

The utmost benevolence has no partiality.
**Commentary:** Like the five viscera, which do not favor one another, yet benevolence is already utmost.
**Exegesis:** Like the hands and feet, which serve one another without conscious intent, yet the function of mutual aid is accomplished—how could there be partiality among them?

The utmost trust dispenses with metal.
**Commentary:** Metal and jade are but the substance of petty trust—utmost trust does away with them.
**Exegesis:** *Pi* means to dispense with. Metal and jade are but the substance of trust—utmost trust discards them.

Shatter the turbulence of the will, untie the knots of the heart, cast off the burdens of virtue, and open the blockages of the Way.
**Exegesis:** *Che* means to shatter. *Bo* means disorder. *Miu* means entanglement. These briefly set forth the terms, which are fully explained below.

Wealth, honor, prominence, dignity, fame, and profit—these six are the turbulence of the will.
**Exegesis:** Glory, wealth, abundance, loftiness, eminence, dignity, reputation, and gain—these six are the instruments that disorder the will.

Appearance, movement, complexion, speech, qi, and intent—these six are the entanglements of the heart.
**Exegesis:** Countenance, motion, facial expression, diction, qi-regulation, and emotion—these six bind and fetter the spirit of the heart. Some versions write *miu* as "delusion," meaning the delusions that ensnare the heart.

Aversion, desire, joy, anger, sorrow, and delight—these six are the burdens of virtue.
**Exegesis:** Hatred, craving, elation, wrath, grief, and pleasure—these six are the encumbrances that stifle virtue.

Rejection, pursuit, taking, giving, knowledge, and ability—these six are the blockages of the Way.
**Exegesis:** Discarding, following, demanding, bestowing, deliberation, and competence—these six obscure the true Way.

When these four sets of six are not stirred within the breast, one is upright; upright, one is still; still, one is luminous; luminous, one is empty; empty, one acts without acting yet accomplishes all.
**Commentary:** *Dang* means to stir.
**Exegesis:** When the afflictions of these four sets of six do not agitate the breast, the spirit of the heart is balanced and upright; upright, it attains tranquility; tranquil, it becomes radiant; radiant, it achieves emptiness; empty, it is serene and without action, yet responds to all things without limit.

The Way is what virtue reveres.
**Exegesis:** The Way is the method of cultivation; virtue is the method of engaging others. Valuing the person over the method, one reveres the Way.

Life is the radiance of virtue.
**Exegesis:** The great virtue of Heaven and Earth is to give life; thus, the generation and transformation of the myriad things are the luminous splendor of flourishing virtue.

Nature is the essence of life.
**Exegesis:** *Zhi* means root. The nature of spontaneity is the fundamental endowment of life.

The movement of nature is called *wei*.
**Commentary:** When nature moves of itself, it is called *wei*—this is true *wei*, not contrived action.
**Exegesis:** To move in accord with nature, to act within one’s allotted sphere, is *wei* without being *wei*—not contrived action.

Contrived action is called loss.
**Exegesis:** To be moved by external things, to act from deluded desires beyond one’s nature, is to lose the Way.

Knowing is contact; knowing is planning.
**Exegesis:** To engage with external things and strategize about affairs is called knowing.

What knowing does not know is like a sidelong glance.
**Commentary:** The eye’s ability to see is not knowing how to see and yet seeing; not knowing how to know and yet knowing—this is spontaneity. If one knows and then acts, that knowing is contrived.
**Exegesis:** *Ni* means to glance. The eye’s act of seeing does not know how it sees yet sees, seeing both brightness and darkness. The heart’s ability to know does not know how it knows yet knows, knowing both depth and shallowness. The eye cannot see what it cannot see, nor can the heart know what it cannot know—if there are limits, it is like a sidelong glance.

To act from necessity is called virtue.
**Commentary:** If one could refrain from acting yet acts, that is forced action—thus, one loses.
**Exegesis:** To act only when compelled, in harmony without premeditation, is to employ necessity—this is called flourishing virtue.

To act without self is called order.
**Commentary:** To act by imitating others is disorder.
**Exegesis:** To act in accord with nature, not abandoning the self to mimic others, is to align with right principle—thus, there is no disorder.

Names may oppose one another, yet realities accord.
**Commentary:** With the distinction of self and other, there is opposition; each attaining its reality, there is accord.
**Exegesis:** With the names of self and other, right and wrong, there is opposition; without the realities of self and other, right and wrong, there is accord in reality.

Yi was skilled at hitting the subtle yet clumsy at preventing others from praising him.
**Commentary:** Being skilled at hitting the mark naturally brings praise—this is the constant principle.
**Exegesis:** Yi was a master archer of antiquity. *Gong* means skill. Yi drew his bow and loosed his arrows, skillfully striking distant targets, mastering the subtleties of archery. Yet possessing such skill, he could not prevent himself from earning renown—praise was unavoidable!

The sage is skilled at Heaven yet clumsy at humanity.
**Commentary:** Following spontaneity is Heaven; acting with intention is humanity.
**Exegesis:** The preceding serves as analogy; this is the synthesis. The sage perfectly aligns with spontaneity, his merit equaling that of creation, yet the myriad beings go about their daily lives unaware—his subtlety is not displayed. As the earlier text says, "Making the world forget the self is difficult." Thus, to be skilled at Heaven and clumsy at humanity is possible only for the *quanren*.

One who is skilled at Heaven is clumsy at humanity—this is the *quanren*.
**Commentary:** To be skilled at Heaven is to be clumsy at humanity—this is the *quanren*, the *quanren* being the sage.
**Exegesis:** The *quanren*—the perfected person, the spirit person—harmonizes with spontaneity, excels at obscuring his traces, and benefits all generations without their awareness. Is this not the spirit person? The spirit person has no merit, hence his ability.

Only the creature can be creaturely; only the creature can be Heavenly.
**Commentary:** To return to and guard simplicity is to be Heavenly.
**Exegesis:** Birds fly and beasts run—this is being creaturely; spiders weave webs and bees form combs—this is being Heavenly. All are the workings of creation—how could they be the result of imitation?

Does the *quanren* despise Heaven? Does he despise the Heaven in others?
**Exegesis:** The *quanren* of perfect virtue, whose spiritual merit is unobtrusive, would he resent his own natural endowment and despise what others have received? Surely not—he simply follows and accords with spontaneity.

How much less would he distinguish between my Heaven and others’ humanity!
**Commentary:** To be utterly unaware and yet follow it—this is called being skilled at Heaven.
**Exegesis:** Whether Heaven or humanity, he does not perceive their difference—he simply follows them all.

You yourself abandon the distinctions between Heaven and humanity’s beauty and ugliness—yet Heaven and humanity still remain. Here, one may merge Heaven and humanity, no longer perceiving their difference.

*Wu* (吾) is the hypothetical self-reference of the discourse’s master.

A sparrow alights near Yi—Yi will surely take it, by force.
**Commentary:** Force seizes things, yet things must flee it.
**Exegesis:** Suppose a sparrow comes near Yi, who is skilled in archery—he will inevitably hit it. Thus, when one extinguishes ferocity, ferocity does not arise from virtue or wisdom; what is gained is little, what escapes is much. To govern the world by force is the same.

If one takes all under Heaven as Heaven’s cage, then no sparrow can escape.
**Commentary:** All things under Heaven have their own desires; when each obtains what it desires, where can escape lie?
**Exegesis:** The great Dao is vast and boundless, encompassing all—thus it is likened to a cage of Heaven and Earth. From this, we know that seizing things by force deeply contravenes the great workings of creation.

Therefore, Tang used a kitchen servant to enclose Yi Yin, and Duke Mu of Qin used five sheep hides to enclose Bai Li Xi.
**Exegesis:** Yi Yin was a dowry servant of the Youxin clan, skilled in seasoning the tripod; he carried a jade tripod to seek audience with Tang. Tang, recognizing his worth and following his nature, thus used the kitchen to enclose him. Bai Li Xi was enslaved among the Di; the Di people prized sheep hides, so Duke Mu of Qin ransomed him with five-colored sheep hides. It is also said: Bai Li Xi favored wearing robes of five-colored sheep hides, hence his title, "Grandee of the Five Rams." Both Tang the sagely and Mu the worthy, in their love of worthies, obtained these two men and employed them as fine ministers—all by following their original natures to enclose them.

Thus, there is nothing that cannot be enclosed by what one desires.

**Exegesis:** By following what one desires, there is nothing in the world that is difficult; to enclose by opposing one’s original nature—this has never been achieved. The maimed take pride in lavish adornment, yet externally, they invite neither praise nor blame.
**Annotation:** *Adornment* refers to what embellishes one’s appearance. The appearance of the mutilated is already marred; thus, they no longer hold beauty or ugliness in their hearts, and so they are cast aside.
**Exegesis:** *Maimed* refers to those who have suffered amputation. *Cast aside* means to discard. *Adornment* refers to finery, the embellishment of attire meant to enhance one’s bearing. For those whose forms are broken by mutilation, matters of praise or shame no longer reside in their hearts, and so they are discarded.
The convict laborer ascends heights without fear, having abandoned life and death.
**Annotation:** Having no attachment to life, he does not fear death.
**Exegesis:** *Convict laborer* refers to one bound in servitude. The son of a thousand golds values his own person, but the bondsman does not hold his life dear. Having no care for himself, he climbs perilous heights without dread.
To revert to one’s nature and yet forget others,
**Annotation:** Unaware of what others cherish.
**Exegesis:** *Forgiveness* (or *shame*, depending on the character) is read accordingly. To return to one’s original nature and complete it through such means is to refuse to imitate others, thus forsaking gratitude and repayment—this is to forget the way of human relations. It is like the hands and feet, which serve their functions in mutual reliance; do they express thanks for one another’s use? To forget others is thus to become one with Heaven.
**Annotation:** Without human sentiment, one naturally becomes a being of Heaven.
**Exegesis:** Following the nature of Heaven’s Dao, forgetting the sentiments of human ways, one thereby aligns with the principle of spontaneity.
Thus, those who are revered yet feel no joy, and those who are insulted yet feel no anger—only those in harmony with Heaven’s harmony are so.
**Annotation:** Even the mutilated and the convict laborer attain harmony with Heaven’s harmony—how much more so the natural harmony of Heaven itself?
**Exegesis:** In harmony with Heaven’s harmony, one forgets opposition and compliance; thus, reverence brings no joy, and insult brings no anger.
Anger that arises from non-anger is anger born of non-anger; action that arises from non-action is action born of non-action.
**Annotation:** This is the meaning of the non-existent giving rise to the existent, and non-action giving rise to action.
**Exegesis:** Those who produce anger or action do not do so from a state of non-anger or non-action; thus, they arise from non-anger and non-action. Therefore, know that action is rooted in non-action, and anger in non-anger. To embody this principle is to be insulted yet feel no anger.
To still the mind, calm the qi; to attain spirit, follow the heart—this is action. To be fitting, yield to necessity; the way of the sage lies in necessity.
**Annotation:** Calming the qi brings stillness; fulfilling the heart’s principle brings spiritual attainment; yielding to necessity ensures all actions are fitting. Thus, the sage takes this as the Dao—how could he seek non-action beyond the indistinct and evanescent?
**Exegesis:** *Yield* means to follow. To still the mind, one must regulate the will and qi; for spiritual transformation, nothing precedes following the heart’s essence. To harmonize within action and yet be fitting in principle, one must follow necessity. *Necessity* means responding only after being moved, acting within one’s proper role. Such examples are what the sage employs as the true Dao.
*Commentary and Exegesis on the True Scripture of Southern Florescence, Scroll Twenty-Five, Concludes*

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence Scripture*, Scroll Twenty-Six
Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan

**Tang Dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary**

**Miscellaneous Chapters, "Xu Wugui" Twenty-Four**

Xu Wugui, through Nü Shang, had an audience with Marquis Wu of Wei.

*Subcommentary:* His surname was Xu, his courtesy name Wugui—he was a recluse. Her surname was Nü, her given name Shang, a chief minister of Wei. Marquis Wu was the son of Marquis Wen and the eighth-generation descendant of Bi Wan. Wugui wished to admonish Marquis Wu, so he borrowed the minister’s position to gain an audience.

Marquis Wu greeted him, saying: "Master, you must be weary."

*Subcommentary:* Having long dwelled in the mountains and forests, enduring hardship and poverty, he had now deigned to lower himself and mingle among the vulgar. The marquis was inwardly delighted and offered words of consolation.
