Xu Wugui said: "I am weary on your account—what weariness have you for me? If you indulge your desires to excess, if you perpetuate your likes and dislikes, then the true nature of life and destiny will sicken. If you cast aside desires and temper your likes and dislikes, then your ears and eyes will sicken."

*Annotation:* Desires, likes, and dislikes—there is no fitting them, whether inwardly or outwardly.

*Subcommentary:* *Chu* means to discard; *xue* means to restrain. If your desires overflow and your likes and dislikes grow unchecked, the essence of life and spirit will be exhausted and afflicted. If you banish old desires and learn to set aside likes and dislikes, failing to accord with what is fitting, then your ears and eyes will sicken. Thus, I come to console you—what leisure do you have to weary me? I weary on your account—what weariness have you for me?

*Subcommentary:* This reiterates the preceding meaning.

Marquis Wu remained aloof and did not respond.

*Annotation:* He was displeased with his words.

*Subcommentary:* *Chao* means resentment. Since the words did not suit his disposition, he remained silent and did not answer.

After a while, Xu Wugui said: "I once told you—I read the signs in dogs."

*Subcommentary:* Sensing that Marquis Wu was displeased and sullen, he tested him with talk of dogs and horses, hoping to please his heart.

Those of the lowest quality stop when their bellies are full—this is the virtue of the wildcat.

*Subcommentary:* Clinging to their nature and will, they care only for a full stomach. In form and substance, their virtue is that of the fox or wildcat—dogs of the lowest rank.

Those of middling quality are like one gazing at the sun.

*Subcommentary:* Their spirit soars high, their gaze like one beholding the sun. In form and substance, they are as such—dogs of the middle rank.

Those of the highest quality seem to have forgotten themselves.

*Subcommentary:* They do not cling to their bodies. With settled and composed spirit, they seem to have lost themselves—dogs of the highest rank.

"I read the signs in dogs, yet this is not as good as reading the signs in horses."

*Subcommentary:* Dogs have three ranks, horses several grades, yet the skill in reading dogs does not surpass that in reading horses. Since Marquis Wu was crude and vulgar, Wugui used this to provoke his interest, hoping to please him and perhaps guide him toward the right path.

"I read the signs in horses: the straight ones meet the plumb line."

*Subcommentary:* This refers to the horse’s front teeth.

"The curved ones meet the hook."

*Subcommentary:* This refers to the horse’s neck.

"The square ones meet the carpenter’s square."

*Subcommentary:* This refers to the horse’s head.

"The round ones meet the compass."

*Subcommentary:* This refers to the horse’s eyes.

"These are the horses of a state."

*Subcommentary:* Those matching the above signs are the finest horses of a feudal lord’s domain.

"Yet they do not compare to the horses of the world. The horses of the world possess innate talent."

*Subcommentary:* Their virtue is naturally complete, requiring no training. These are the finest horses under heaven, fit for the Son of Heaven to ride.

"They seem anxious, as if lost; they seem to have forgotten themselves."

*Subcommentary:* Their eyes seem to glance about, as if troubled; their hooves move slowly, as if fleeing. Observing their spirit, they seem to have forgotten their bodies. Such is the quality of the Son of Heaven’s horses.

"Such horses surpass all others, leaving dust far behind—their origin is unknown."

*Subcommentary:* *Yi* means to surpass. Their gallop is swift, outpacing all other horses, as rapid as the wind, with dust left far behind. Since they are not trained, their source is unknown."

Marquis Wu was greatly pleased and laughed.

*Annotation:* How could the words of a true person be anything but fitting? They are only as good as what the thing itself desires.

*Subcommentary:* His words struck the right chord, so the marquis laughed with delight.

Xu Wugui departed. Nü Shang said: "Master, how did you alone manage to please our lord?"

*Subcommentary:* Having concluded their discussion, he took his leave. Nü Shang, surprised by the marquis’s joy, asked Wugui about it.

"The way I pleased our lord: broadly speaking, I spoke to him of the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*; narrowly speaking, I spoke to him of the *Golden Tablets* and *Six Strategies*."

*Subcommentary:* The *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*—the Six Classics. The *Golden Tablets* and *Six Strategies*—chapter names from the *Book of Zhou*, or perhaps secret teachings. One version writes *tao* instead, reading it as the military methods of the Grand Duke, referring to the *Six Strategies* of the Tiger, Leopard, Dragon, and Dog. *Heng* means distant; *zong* means near. Since Marquis Wu favored martial arts and disdained civil matters, Wugui treated military strategy as the near approach and the Six Classics as the distant one.

"Those who have served him with great merit are beyond counting, yet our lord has never once smiled. Now, master, how did you please our lord so that he is delighted like this?"

*Subcommentary:* Those who have served Marquis Wu with utmost loyalty, offering counsel on what is fitting or not, their achievements manifest—such men are beyond counting, yet our lord has never once opened his mouth to smile. What art did you employ to bring our lord such joy?

Xu Wugui said: "I simply told him of my reading of dogs and horses."

*Subcommentary:* Medicine, however cheap, is good if it cures the illness. Thus, he spoke directly of dogs and horses, saying nothing more.

Nü Shang said: "Is that so?"

*Subcommentary:* Did you truly only speak of dogs and horses? Surprised by the shallowness of his words, he asked this.

He said: "Have you not heard of the exiles of Yue?"

Far from his state for several days, he rejoices upon seeing those he knows—
*Annotation:* Each follows the inclinations of his own nature.
*Subcommentary:* Exiled far from his homeland, whether for transgressing the law or suffering harsh governance, he has barely bid farewell to his native soil when, after only a few days, he suddenly encounters an acquaintance—how could he not be overjoyed? This begins the analogy.

Far from his state for a month, he rejoices upon seeing those he once saw within the state—
*Subcommentary:* As the days and months pass, longing for home grows deeper. Though they may not be acquaintances, if he sees someone he once knew in his homeland, he greets them with delight.

After a full year, he rejoices even upon seeing someone who merely resembles a fellow countryman. Is it not true that the longer one is parted from others, the deeper the longing for them?
*Annotation:* When each attains what he desires, there is no longing; without longing, he forgets the very reason for his joy.
*Subcommentary:* After a year away from his state, the distance grows greater, so that even upon seeing someone who resembles a fellow villager, he is overjoyed. Is this not because, as separation from home lengthens, yearning only deepens? This is likened to Marquis Wu, whose nature delights in dogs and horses. Having long been estranged from matters of governance, he is like one far from home—suddenly hearing talk of such things brings him joy.

One who flees into the void, blocking the paths of moles and weasels with brambles and beams, treading upon emptiness, rejoices upon hearing the sound of footsteps in the hall. How much more, then, would he rejoice at the voices of brothers and kin drinking and laughing at his side?
*Annotation:* When one attains the utmost joy, great delight follows.
*Subcommentary:* *Zhu* means to block; *gen* means to tread; *tang* refers to the sound of footsteps. In times of turmoil and famine, one flees in desperation to an abandoned estate, where only reeds and wild grasses block the gates, and the paths of foxes and weasels lie before him. If, in the vast emptiness of the hall, he suddenly hears the sound of footsteps, he is already overjoyed—how much more would he rejoice at the voices of brothers and kin drinking and laughing beside him? This deepens the analogy.

For too long, no one has offered the words of a true person to awaken our lord at his side.
*Annotation:* This is why he has never once smiled. The words of a true person resonate with our lord’s nature; at first, he delights in them, but with time, he forgets them.
*Subcommentary:* Marquis Wu’s longing to hear of dogs and horses has endured for some time, like an exile growing ever more weary. After such prolonged hardship, he yearns for home. Yet now, when the true person speaks of the *Six Classics* or the military strategies of the Grand Duke, his words ring out at the lord’s side—this is not what he desires. This completes the earlier analogy.

When Xu Wugui met Marquis Wu, the marquis said: "Master, you dwell in the mountains and forests, eating taro and chestnuts, weary of onions and leeks. You have come to visit this lonely one—how long it has been! Are you now old? Do you crave the taste of wine and meat? Or does this lonely one possess some blessing for the altars of state?"

*Subcommentary:* *Gan* means to seek. Having long dwelled in the mountains, subsisting on vegetables and fruits, with age comes weariness—would he not seek richer flavors to sustain his declining years? Perhaps he comes to secure the ancestral temples through virtue.

Xu Wugui said: "Wugui was born in poverty and lowliness. I have never dared to partake of my lord’s wine and meat. I have come to offer you solace."

*Subcommentary:* Born in humble circumstances, content in the wilderness, how could I seek sustenance from your food and drink? That is not my purpose. I have come to offer you solace."

The ruler said: "Why? How would you offer solace to this lonely one?"

*Subcommentary:* *Why* means *for what reason*. He asks the purpose of his coming.

Xu Wugui said: "To ease the strain upon your spirit and form."

*Subcommentary:* Gluttony without restraint wearies the body and exhausts the spirit—thus I offer solace.

Marquis Wu said: "What do you mean?"

*Subcommentary:* He asks what these words intend.

Xu Wugui said: "The nurture of Heaven and Earth is one.

*Annotation:* They do not indulge the ruler without limit.

*Subcommentary:* The Two Modes of Heaven and Earth nourish all beings. Their sustenance is universal and impartial, never indulging a ruler’s excess. These are the words with which Xu Wugui offers solace.

One who ascends to high station cannot be called tall; one who dwells in lowliness cannot be called short. Yet you alone, as lord of ten thousand chariots, afflict an entire nation’s people to feed your ears, eyes, nose, and mouth.

*Annotation:* This violates the balance of Heaven and Earth.

*Subcommentary:* To rise to high rank as a nobleman is no cause to delight in it as a lasting state; to dwell in humble station as one of the common folk is no cause to suffer it as a permanent lack. Yet you alone boast of your ten-thousand-chariot might, oppressing the people of this land to demand sights, sounds, scents, and flavors for the indulgence of your senses. This defies the intent of Heaven and Earth—I cannot approve of it.

The spirit does not claim for itself.

*Annotation:* It is bestowed by things.

*Subcommentary:* *Claim* means *to take*. The sage-ruler and spirit-person treat all things equally, never demanding rich flavors for their own indulgence.

The spirit delights in harmony and detests deceit.

*Annotation:* To share with all things is harmony; to claim for oneself is deceit.

*Subcommentary:* The spirit-person delights in harmonizing with things and detests deceitful self-interest.

Deceit is a malady—thus I offer solace. Why does only my lord suffer from it?"

*Subcommentary:* Deceit is a private indulgence, a malady in principle. That you alone are afflicted—how grievous is your plight?

Marquis Wu said: "I have long wished to meet you. I desire to cherish the people, practice righteousness, and lay down arms—would this be acceptable?"

*Subcommentary:* He wishes to enact benevolent nurture and righteous correction, refining civil governance and stilling the weapons of war. With such a mode of rule, he asks whether it would be fitting.

Xu Wugui said: "It would not. To cherish the people is the beginning of harming them.

*Annotation:* The path of cherishing the people becomes what the people esteem. What is esteemed as cherishing is already false.

To practice righteousness and lay down arms is the root of raising arms.

*Annotation:* To practice righteousness is to make one’s name conspicuous; a conspicuous name invites competition, and competition leads to the loss of one’s true nature.

Father and son, ruler and minister, harboring feelings, deceive one another. Even if you wished to lay down arms, how could it be achieved?

*Subcommentary:* Partial benevolence, righteous correction, the stilling of arms, the refinement of culture—once these are made manifest, things will vie to emulate them. The harming of the people and the raising of arms begin here. If you proceed thus, it will surely fail.

*Annotation:* Only by acting from non-action can it succeed.

*Subcommentary:* *Proceed* means *to follow*. *Surely* means *nearly*. To follow this course is to nearly destroy the root of non-action, thus it will nearly fail.

All that perfects beauty is a vessel of evil.

*Annotation:* When beauty is perfected beforehand, falsity arises afterward. Thus, what perfects beauty is a vessel of evil.

*Subcommentary:* When good deeds are perfected in advance, their beauty becomes conspicuous, and things will vie to emulate them—thus it becomes an instrument of evil.

Though you practice benevolence and righteousness, you will nearly verge upon falsity.

*Annotation:* The people will judge it as false and will not accept it as genuine.

*Subcommentary:* *Nearly* means *close to*. When benevolence and righteousness are made manifest, all things lose their true nature—thus you verge upon the root of falsity.

Form inevitably gives rise to form.

*Annotation:* Where there is form, false form is inevitably produced.

*Subcommentary:* The paths of benevolence and righteousness both possess form. Thus, when one advances along them, false forms are inevitably produced in their wake.

Perfection inevitably invites attack.

*Annotation:* Perfection is conspicuous.

*Subcommentary:* When achievements and fame are perfected, they inevitably invite competition—thus they invite attack.

Change inevitably provokes external conflict.

*Annotation:* It loses its constant nature.

*Subcommentary:* When laws and institutions are created and the constant is altered, things will be harmed—thus external enemies arise, and affairs often lead to conflict.

You must not array ranks of cranes in the towering watchtowers,

*Annotation:* *Crane ranks* refers to the deployment of troops. *Towering watchtowers* are high towers.

nor station swift steeds in the palaces of the ancestral altars.

*Annotation:* Infantry are called *foot soldiers*.

Do not practice righteousness or cherish the people—also, do not deploy vast armies or gallop horses.

*Subcommentary:* *Crane ranks* refers to the deployment of troops, likening their formation to the ranks of cranes. *Towering watchtowers* are high towers, resplendent and lofty. *Ancestral altars* is the name of a palace. Do not set your mind on stilling arms through righteousness, nor deploy vast armies beneath the high towers or station swift steeds within the palace grounds.

Do not harbor resentment in your gains.

*Annotation:* If resentment lies within gain, it is lost.

*Subcommentary:* Do not conceal a resentful heart while grasping at gain.

Do not seek to outwit others,

*Annotation:* Preserve your simplicity, and each will have its own ability—thus there is balance.

*Subcommentary:* The greatest skill appears clumsy; each abides in simplicity. Do not use cunning to compete with others.

do not seek to outscheme others,

*Annotation:* Follow your true knowledge, and each will have its own strength—thus there is equality.

*Subcommentary:* Abandon calculation and follow your direct knowledge. Do not use schemes to outmaneuver others.

do not seek to outfight others.

*Annotation:* Respond to things with the Dao, and things will submit without the name of victory.

*Subcommentary:* First cultivate emptiness and tranquility, submitting others with the Dao. Do not seek to conquer others through warfare.

Those who kill others’ people, seize others’ lands, to nourish their own selfishness and their own spirits—how can one know which side is truly good in such a war?"

Where does the evil of victory lie?
*Annotation:* If one does not know what is truly good, then even conquest is not one’s own victory.
*Subcommentary:* To respond to Heaven and follow the people, even if one destroys the cruel and eliminates the rebellious, though a state may fall and lives be taken, one does not lose the people’s joyful hearts. But if one slays the people, seizes their lands, and acts with the intent to demand tribute, selfishly nourishing one’s own body and pleasing one’s own heart—though one may conquer the enemy and prevail over others, one does not know where this victory lies, nor in whom the good truly resides.

If you, O ruler, cannot cease, then cultivate the sincerity within your breast to respond to the feelings of Heaven and Earth, and do not disturb.
*Annotation:* If you cannot cease, then cultivate your own sincerity.
*Subcommentary:* Sincerity is reality. Disturbance is disorder. If affairs cannot be halted and governance is necessary, then cultivate the reality within your heart, respond to the life and death of the Two Modes, and do not trouble yourself with laws that disturb the common people.

The people have already escaped death—why would you, O ruler, need to employ the laying down of arms?
*Annotation:* When armor and weapons are not arrayed, it is not that they are laid down.
*Subcommentary:* In great accord with Heaven and Earth, transformation is enacted without intent. The people, having overcome cruelty, escape injury and death—why labor to devise laws for laying down arms?

The Yellow Emperor was about to visit Great Purity on Mount Jutci,
*Subcommentary:* The Yellow Emperor was Xuanyuan. *Great Purity* refers to the vastness and emptiness of the great Dao. It may also refer to *Great Purity*, an ancient perfected person. *Jutci* is the name of a mountain, located in the borderlands of Mi County in Yingyang, also called Mount Taipo.

A sage, long steeped in the profoundest principles, he sought to inquire into the mysterious Dao and thus journeyed to Mount Jutci. Fangming served as his charioteer, Changyu rode alongside, Zhangruo and Peng led the vanguard, while Kunhe and Guji followed in the rear carriage.
*Subcommentary:* Fangming, Guji, and the others were all names of individuals. Those on the right served as attendants, those on the left as charioteers. The vanguard rode ahead of the horses, while the rear carriage followed behind.

When they reached the wilds of Xiangcheng, the two and seven sages all became lost, with no one to ask for directions.
*Annotation:* The sages were named; names arise and things become confused. Though one may seek Great Purity, how can it be attained?
*Subcommentary:* *Directions* means the Way. Today’s Xuchang has a Xiangcheng County, located south of Mount Taipo, where the Yellow Emperor sought the Dao. From the Yellow Emperor up to Guji, there were in total seven sages. The annotation states: “The sages were named; names arise and things become confused. Though one may seek Great Purity, how can it be attained?” This annotation is apt; I now offer a further explanation.

They happened upon a boy herding horses and asked him for directions.
*Subcommentary:* The boy herding horses was an attained person. He herded horses by day and herded them still. By chance, they encountered the herdboy and thus inquired about the whereabouts of the Dao.

“Do you know of Mount Jutci?”
“Indeed,” he replied.
*Subcommentary:* *You* means “you.” *Indeed* means “yes.” They asked about the location of the mountain, and he answered that he knew it.

“Do you know where Great Purity resides?”
“Indeed,” he replied.
*Subcommentary:* *Resides* means “is located.” They again asked about the whereabouts of the Dao, and he answered that he knew the place.

The Yellow Emperor said, “How extraordinary, this little boy! Not only does he know of Mount Jutci, but he also knows where Great Purity resides. I beg to ask how to govern the world.”
*Subcommentary:* The Emperor marveled at the herdboy’s knowledge of the Dao’s whereabouts and thus asked how to order the realm.

The little boy said, “Governing the world is just like this—what more is there to do?”
*Annotation:* If each is as it is, then there is nothing to do; only with nothing to do can one govern the world.
*Subcommentary:* *What more* means “why.” *Like this* means “as such.” If one wishes to govern the world, it is like governing the self. Since the self is without action, what affairs are there for things? Thus the *Laozi* says, “I do nothing, and the people transform themselves.”

“From my youth, I have wandered within the Six Directions. Then I contracted a dizzying illness. An elder taught me, saying: ‘If you ride the chariot of the sun and wander the wilds of Xiangcheng…’”
*Annotation:* One wanders at sunrise and rests at sunset.
*Subcommentary:* *Within the Six Directions* refers to the dusty world. *Dizzying illness* means vertigo and confusion. I say: in my youth, I wandered the realm of the profound Dao, dwelling beyond the dust and grime, yet I suffered from dizziness and could not embody the true. Fortunately, a sage taught me to cultivate the Dao, acting by day and resting by night, riding the sun’s chariot to wander and thus dwell in ease, carefree in the world. Some versions have the character *chariot*, meaning to ride the sun’s renewal in transformation. Now that my illness has slightly improved, I will once more wander beyond the Six Directions. Governing the world is just like this—what more is there to do?”

“To govern the world, nothing surpasses self-abandonment; once self-abandoned, what can things constrain? Thus, I practice non-action, and the people transform of themselves.”

*Annotation:* *痊* means “to remove.” The illness of delusion has long since been dispelled; one wanders beyond the dust, the heart roaming outside things. Governing the body and governing the state—how are they different? Self and things merge in mutual accord, so there is nothing to be done.

The Yellow Emperor said: “To govern the world is truly not your affair.”

*Annotation:* Affairs arise from the people.

“Nevertheless, I ask how to govern the world.”

*Annotation:* Let the people find their own way—this is the essential Dao.

*Subcommentary:* To shepherd and nourish the common folk is not the sage’s true task. Though the principle is thus, he still requests the essential teaching.

*Small Lad declines to speak.*

*Subcommentary:* There is nothing to be said.

The Yellow Emperor asks again.

*Subcommentary:* Earnestly entreating the Small Lad.

The Small Lad said: “To govern the world—how is it different from herding horses? Simply remove what harms the horses, and that is all.”

*Annotation:* Horses are harmed by excess.

*Subcommentary:* What harms horses are matters beyond their proper measure. In cultivating the self, nothing comes before guarding one’s proper measure; thus, the art of herding horses can nurture the people. Since the question was earnest, I offer this answer in passing.”

The Yellow Emperor bowed twice, touching his forehead to the ground, and withdrew, calling him “Heavenly Master.”

The Master removes what exceeds nature, and the great spirit arrives.

*Subcommentary:* Suddenly awakening to the sage’s words, he cherishes body and mind, retreats from what lies beyond his measure, and attains the great spirit, aligning with the Dao of naturalness—this lies in our Master.

The man of knowledge finds no joy without the changes of thought and deliberation.

*Subcommentary:* In an age of peril and calamity, when misfortune strikes, the man of foresight thinks and deliberates; if not, he finds no joy.

The man of eloquence finds no joy without the order of discourse.

*Subcommentary:* Words flow like rivers, arguments turn like roasting spits; without the proper beginning for discourse, he finds no delight.

The man of discernment finds no joy without the thrust and parry of debate.

*Subcommentary:* The keen and perceptive man, if denied the exchange of host and guest, the clash of words, finds no joy.

All are confined by things.

*Annotation:* Unable to find fulfillment within, they seek joy in external things, and so may be confined.

Thus, each is confined by what brings him joy, and the myriad things come unbidden—not by force.

*Subcommentary:* These men, each with their biases, have yet to grasp the great norm; all are bounded by things.

The man who summons the age serves the court.

*Subcommentary:* He who recommends the loyal and gathers men of worth may take his place in the court.

The man of the common people honors office.

*Subcommentary:* Governing the four classes with balance and fairness, this man of keen judgment and defined role may honor his office.

The man of sinew and strength boasts of hardship.

*Subcommentary:* The stalwart hero, strong as a tiger, when hardship arises, devotes himself to saving the age.

The brave man rushes to peril.

*Subcommentary:* The martial and resolute man, roused to valor, sweeps away disaster.

The man of arms delights in war.

*Subcommentary:* He whose heart loves weapons and whose will dwells on blades delights in battle.

The ascetic cherishes his name.

*Subcommentary:* Living on little, clad in coarse cloth, his form gaunt, his mind fixed on rest, he dwells only on his reputation.

The man of laws expands governance.

*Subcommentary:* The man of punishments, attentive to statutes, punishing evil and encouraging good, governs broadly.

The man of ritual reveres appearance.

*Subcommentary:* In the refinements of ritual, he esteems dignified bearing.

The man of benevolence and righteousness values opportunity.

*Annotation:* Since men differ thus, he who encounters them must not alter his course.

*Subcommentary:* When the world offers occasion and the time presents opportunity, he practices benevolence and righteousness to establish his renown.

The farmer finds no harmony without the work of clearing fields; the merchant finds no harmony without the work of the marketplace.

*Annotation:* When their work is the same, they are in harmony.

*Subcommentary:* *Bi* means harmony. In ancient times, markets were held by the well, hence "marketplace." If they stray from their proper work, their hearts cannot be at peace.

The common people are encouraged by their daily tasks.

*Annotation:* When their work aligns with their aspirations, they are encouraged.

*Subcommentary:* The multitude, each with their duties, content from dawn to dusk, thus spur themselves on.

The hundred craftsmen take pride in the skill of their tools.

*Annotation:* Without their proper skill, they grow idle.

*Subcommentary:* *Zhuang* means flourishing. The hundred craftsmen, each with their tools, when they follow their nature, their work flourishes.

The greedy grow anxious when wealth does not accumulate.

*Annotation:* When things accord with their desires, they rejoice.

The boastful grow sorrowful when power does not stand out.

*Subcommentary:* *You* means extreme. The covetous man gathers wealth to suit his nature; the proud man borrows power to please his heart. If things run counter to their nature, sorrow and grief arise.

The followers of power and things delight in change.

*Annotation:* Power arises from changing circumstances.

*Subcommentary:* When disaster strikes, power becomes extreme; thus, those who wield power over things delight in calamity.

When the time offers use, they cannot be without action.

*Annotation:* Each of these men has their moment; when the time calls, they cannot restrain themselves. If the time does not come, though they wish to act, how can they?

Thus, nobility and baseness have no constancy.

*Subcommentary:* The men described above, meeting their fate, their hearts shifting with events, cannot be without action.

All follow in harmony with the seasons, not altering with change.

*Annotation:* Each man’s abilities have their limit, like the four seasons, which cannot be altered. Thus, when their time and things come, following their proper order, each has their use.

Therefore, following the seasons brings timely order; altering one’s nature fails to accord with things. To accord with things yet not be bound by them—how could this be destruction?

*Subcommentary:* *Bi* means sequence. Men’s actions have strengths and weaknesses; their use follows the time, their success has order, like the seasons’ heat and cold, unchanging in their course. "Not according with things" means not altering with things. To gallop one’s form and nature, sinking into the myriad things, never to return—how sad!

*Annotation:* Not holding to one skill but chasing the ten thousand directions for fleeting gain, some crawl back in the end—this is why it is sad.

*Subcommentary:* Racing mind and body, drowning in external things, until the end of life, never returning—so stubborn and foolish, deeply pitiable indeed!

Zhuangzi said: If an archer hits the mark without aiming, is he a good shot? Then all under heaven could be Yi—is that acceptable?

*Annotation:* Hitting without aiming means an accidental hit, not a good shot. If we call an accidental hit good shooting, then all under heaven could be called Yi—is that acceptable? It is not.

*Subcommentary:* *Qi* means the target.

If an archer hits a target without aiming and accidentally strikes something, and we call this good shooting—is that acceptable? Master Hui said: It is.

*Subcommentary:* This would mean all under heaven are Yi.

Zhuangzi said: There is no universal rightness in the world, yet each takes their own rightness as right—then all under heaven could be Yao. Is that acceptable?

*Annotation:* If we call an accidental hit Yi, then those who privately affirm their own views could also be called Yao.

Zhuangzi uses this to show that accidental hits are not Yi, and self-affirmation is not Yao.

*Subcommentary:* Each clings to their own rightness, so there is no universal rightness. Yet Yao, the sage, is right when contrasted with Jie. If each takes their own rightness as right, then all are sages—is that acceptable? It is not.

Master Hui said: It is.

*Subcommentary:* If each affirms their own rightness, then all under heaven are Yao—this is logically possible, yet Hui Shi, mired in sophistry, speaks without substance.

Zhuangzi said: Then if the Ru, Mo, Yang, and Bing—four schools—are joined with you, making five, which one is truly right?

*Annotation:* If all are Yao, why do these five mutually reject one another?

*Subcommentary:* Ru refers to Zheng Huan. Mo refers to Mo Di. Yang refers to Yang Zhu. Bing is the courtesy name of Gongsun Long. These four, along with Hui Shi, making five, each surpass others in wisdom, towering in eloquence, yet they dispute one another’s rightness—how can we determine who is correct? If all under heaven were Yao, why would these five still reject one another? Or are they like Lu Ju?

His disciple said: I have grasped the Master’s Dao! I can boil a cauldron in winter and make ice in summer.

*Subcommentary:* Lu Ju, a man of the early Zhou, claimed that in winter, one could take thousand-year-old dry ashes to kindle fire, instantly producing flames to heat a cauldron; in summer, one could boil water in an earthen jar, then suspend it in a well, and in moments, ice would form. Yet the deluded world, lost in self-affirmation, differs little from this.

Lu Ju said: This merely summons yang with yang and yin with yin—it is not what I call the Dao.

*Subcommentary:* Thousand-year ashes are yang, and fire is also yang—this is summoning yang with yang. The well is yin, and water is also yin—this is summoning yin with yin. Lu Ju’s words refute his disciple. I will show you the true Dao.

Then he tuned the se for demonstration. One he set in the hall, another in the chamber. When he plucked the *gong* note, the *gong* string resonated; when he plucked the *jiao* note, the *jiao* string resonated—their tones were in harmony.

*Annotation:* This, too, is summoning yang with yang, yet they stubbornly claim it as right.

*Subcommentary:* *Fei* means "to place." One se was placed in the hall, another in the chamber. When the *gong* or *jiao* string in the hall was plucked, the corresponding string in the chamber would vibrate in response, for the five notes and six pitches share the same sound. Yet this remains summoning yang with yang. If one were to adjust a single string so that it no longer aligned with the five notes—

*Annotation:* Changing it according to the tuning.

*Subcommentary:* If a string in the hall were retuned, the strings in the chamber would no longer respond, for their pitches would no longer match. Yet when that single string was plucked, all twenty-five strings would vibrate—

*Annotation:* Without sound, there would be no resonance; with sound, only harmony elicits response. Now, by altering this one string, all twenty-five strings change, for the tuning depends on tension and slack.

*Subcommentary:* The response was once limited to *gong* and *jiao*, but now all twenty-five strings resonate, for all whose pitches match will respond. Yet this differs not from sound itself, and the ruler of tones is already established.

*Annotation:* Lu Ju used this to boast to his disciple, but it is merely like responding to like—nothing uniquely his own.

*Subcommentary:* Beyond the laws of sound, there is no other art. Though the responses differ, all are governed by the five notes as their sovereign. Lacking any other defense, what is there to boast of? Is this not the same?

*Annotation:* Each of the five masters clings to his own views and deems them right, yet they differ not from Lu Ju’s boasting to his disciple, unable to surpass one another.

*Subcommentary:* Hui Shi’s words, each prizing his own rightness and striving to outdo others, are no different from Lu Ju’s—hence the question: *Is this not the same?*

Hui Shi said: Now the Confucians, Mohists, Yangists, and Bingists all engage me in debate, clashing with words and overpowering with voices, yet none has ever admitted my wrong—what do you make of this?

*Annotation:* "None has ever admitted my wrong" means each deems himself right. Hui Shi thus takes this as the ultimate achievement.

Zhuangzi said: There was a man of Qi who abandoned his child in Song, instructing the gatekeeper not to keep him whole—

*Annotation:* Casting him into a foreign land and entrusting him to a gatekeeper, he ensured the child would not leave unscathed.

*Subcommentary:* *Hūn* means "gatekeeper." The man of Qi discarded his child in Song and gave such an order—was this not his own rightness? When he sought his bronze bell, he bound it tightly—

*Annotation:* He reversed course, deeming the protection of the bell right, binding it for fear of damage.

When he sought his lost child, he never left the city—he left his kind behind.

*Annotation:* *Táng* means "lost." Having lost his child yet unable to search far, he abandoned his own kin, yet never deemed himself wrong. Human self-righteousness reaches such absurdity.

*Subcommentary:* *Xíng* is a small bell. *Táng* means "lost." Seeking a lost child yet never leaving the city; binding a bronze bell for fear of damage; valuing objects over children as unfilial—abandoning his kin yet still claiming rightness. There was a man of Chu who, while lodging, entrusted his child to a gatekeeper—

*Annotation:* Both were lodgers, unable to place themselves on high ground.

In the dead of night, when no one was about, he fought with the boatman, never leaving the bank yet already inciting resentment.

*Annotation:* *Cén* means "bank." Boarding another’s boat in the middle of the night, he had not yet left the shore before quarreling with its owner. The actions of these men of Qi and Chu were thus, yet they never deemed themselves wrong. How do the five masters’ self-righteousness differ from this?

*Subcommentary:* A man of Ying in Chu, while lodging as a guest near the riverbank, entrusted his child to a gatekeeper’s household. In the dead of night, when no one was about, he boarded another’s boat, and before the vessel had left the bank, he was already fighting with the boatman, forgetting kindness and instead breeding resentment—foolish and crude as this was, he still claimed rightness. Hui Shi and his followers are of this kind. *Cén* means "bank."

Zhuangzi, while attending a funeral, passed by Hui Shi’s grave. Turning to his followers, he said: A man of Ying daubed his nose with a fly’s-wing-thin layer of white clay, and had Carpenter Shi carve it away. Carpenter Shi swung his axe like the wind, listening as he struck—

*Annotation:* Eyes closed, hand unrestrained.

*Subcommentary:* Ying was the capital of Chu. The *Book of Han*’s "Biography of Yang Xiong" writes it as *Yǐng*, following this. The man of Ying was a plasterer. *È* is fine white clay; *màn* means "to smear." Zhuangzi, attending the burial of a close acquaintance, passed by Hui Shi’s grave and, reminiscing about the past, offered this analogy. With eyes closed and hand unrestrained, he struck by sound alone, and the axe’s mastery produced a wind-like rush. "Like a fly’s wing" describes its marvel. The clay was removed without harm to the nose, and the man of Ying stood unflinching.

When the Lord of Song Yuan heard of this, he summoned Carpenter Shi and said: Try it for me. Carpenter Shi replied: Your servant once could do it.

Though this I once could do, my material is long dead. Since the Master’s passing, I have had no material to work upon, no one with whom to speak.

The unflinching material and the partner who forgets words—without these, even the most wondrous stroke finds no use.

Carpenter Shi’s skill required an unmoving material; Zhuangzi’s wisdom still needed a partner who forgot words. When Huizi died, Zhuangzi lost his counterpart, and so the carpenter ceased his wind-like mastery, just as Zhuangzi stilled his subtle words by the Hao River.

When Guan Zhong fell ill, Duke Huan asked him: “Your illness has grown grave. If it should reach its final stage, to whom may I entrust the state?” Guan Zhong replied: “Whom does the Duke wish to appoint?” The Duke said: “Bao Shuya.” Guan Zhong said: “He will not do. He is a man of rigid integrity and noble character, but he does not associate with those beneath him, and once he hears of another’s fault, he remembers it for life. If he governs the state, he will offend the ruler above and alienate the people below. It will not be long before he incurs the Duke’s displeasure.” The Duke asked: “Then who is suitable?” Guan Zhong replied: “If there is no alternative, then Xi Peng will do. He is a man who forgets his rank above and disregards distinctions below. He feels shame before those who surpass the Yellow Emperor and pities those who fall short of himself. To distribute virtue is sagely; to distribute wealth is worthy. To rule with worthiness invites resistance; to yield with worthiness wins allegiance. In governing the state, he remains unaware of trifles; in managing his household, he overlooks faults. If there is no alternative, then Xi Peng will do.”

The King of Wu was sailing on the river when he ascended the Mountain of Monkeys. The troop of monkeys, seeing him, fled in terror and hid in the dense thickets. One monkey, however, lingered with leisurely bounds and daring leaps, displaying its skill before the king. The king shot at it, loosing arrows with swift precision, but the monkey caught them mid-flight. The king then ordered his attendants to shoot together, and the monkey perished clinging to a tree. The king turned to his friend Yan Buyi and said: “This monkey trusted in its cunning and relied on its agility to defy me, and so met its end. Take heed! Do not let your bearing make others proud.”

The monkey prided itself on its strength and skill, relied on its agility, and behaved arrogantly toward the king—thus it met its death. Alas, this cunning beast may serve as a warning to men: do not indulge in sensual pleasures or act with haughty pride in the world.

Yan Buyi returned home and studied under Dong Wu to uproot his vanity, renouncing music and shunning fame. After three years, the people of the state praised him.
*(Note: The character #30 is assumed to be "其" based on context.)*

South Count Zi Jing sat leaning on his armrest, gazing upward and sighing. Yan Chengzi entered and said: “Master, you are the most extraordinary of beings. Can the body truly be made like withered bones, the heart like dead ashes?”

Zi Jing replied: “Once I dwelled at the mouth of a mountain cave. At that time, when Lord Tian He caught sight of me, the people of Qi thrice celebrated it.
*(Note: The character #31 is assumed to be "之" based on context.)*

I must have preceded them, so they came to know me; I must have offered myself, so they came to treasure me.”

The commentary states: My reputation preceded me, thus allowing others to know me; I essentially sold myself to fame, so Tian He saw and emulated me. Had I not possessed it, how could they have known me? Had I not sold it, how could they have prized it?

The commentary further explains: If I had concealed my light and hidden my traces, possessing no reputation, how could the people of the world have known me? Had my name and worth not been esteemed, how could they have seen and emulated me? It is only because I could not erase my traces or conceal my beginnings that I became something constantly prized by others. Alas!

I grieve for those who lose themselves—
*(Commentary: "Lose" here means to forfeit or abandon.)*
Zi Qi laments the people of the world who discard their own Way to admire others.

Yet I also grieve for those who grieve for others—
*(Commentary: The Way admits no gain or loss, while beings are subject to sorrow and joy; thus, grieving for those who lose themselves is also lamentable.)*

And I further grieve for those who grieve for the grief of others—ever more distant with each passing day.
*(Commentary: Zi Qi knew that such grief could not save others but only harm oneself, so he chose not to grieve over grief. Thus, his sorrow gradually faded, leaving him serene and empty-minded, his form withered—hence the distance grows with time.)*
*(Commentary: The profound Way is empty and tranquil, without loss or joy. Therefore, grieving for those who lose themselves, as well as grieving for such grief—though varying in depth—all remain far from the Way and are thus lamentable. Grieving and grieving again, relinquishing and relinquishing once more, the teaching becomes manifest, and the mystery of mysteries is revealed, aligning with the myriad wonders. Hence, it is said to grow ever more distant.)*

When Confucius journeyed to Chu, the King of Chu offered him a feast. Sun Shu’ao held the goblet and stood, while Shi Nanyilaio received the wine and poured a libation, saying: “People of old—here, they would speak.”
*(Commentary: The ancients spoke only at gatherings.)*
*(Commentary: *Shang* refers to all wine vessels; here, it means the king feasted him with wine. A *jue* is also a wine vessel, holding one *sheng*. The ancients, before drinking, would first pour a libation. Shi Nanyilaio poured wine in offering and thus invoked the sage, wishing to discuss matters with Confucius at this moment.)*

Confucius said: “I have heard of speech without words—yet I have never spoken it.
*(Commentary: The sage speaks no words; what he utters are merely the words of the common people, hence ‘speech without words.’ If one takes speech as non-speech, then even when words leave the mouth, it is as if they have never been spoken.)*

Here, I shall speak it.”
*(Commentary: Now, I shall speak of the unspeakable at this moment.)*
*(Commentary: Principle as teaching is wordless; teaching as principle has never been spoken. Thus, the sage subtly embodies this truth, and in the end, it is said: ‘speaking yet never having spoken.’ Confucius, responding to Shi Nanyilaio’s request, thus spoke of the unspeakable at this moment.)*

Shi Nanyilaio juggled his balls to resolve the conflict between two families, while Sun Shu’ao slept peacefully, holding a feather fan, and the people of Ying laid down their weapons.
*(Commentary: These two masters settled disputes through silence, remaining tranquil and unperturbed, and the military strife dissolved of its own accord.)*
*(Commentary: His surname was Xiong, his given name Yiliao, a worthy and brave man of Chu, known for his silence. Dwelling south of the market, he was called Master of the South Market. When Bai Gong Sheng plotted rebellion and sought to kill the prime minister, Zi Xi, Sima Zi Qi said: ‘Xiong Yiliao is a brave warrior; if we obtain him, he could oppose five hundred men.’ Thus, they sent an envoy to summon him. Yiliao was juggling balls up and down in play, not speaking to the envoy. The envoy then brandished a sword at him, yet Yiliao showed no fear. Though he did not comply with the command, he also said nothing else. Without Yiliao, Bai Gong’s plans failed, hence ‘resolving the conflict between two families.’ His surname was Sun, his given name Shu’ao, prime minister of Chu, renowned for his virtuous counsel. Ying was the capital of Chu. *Tou* means to cease. Shu’ao, deeply learned and profoundly wise, slept peacefully and roamed freely, embodying principle without words, holding a feather fan in contentment. Thus, enemy states did not invade, and he repelled threats a thousand *li* away. The people of Chu lived in peace, cultivating civil virtue and setting aside military strategies. These two masters’ achievements are thus extolled, showing they were worthy to converse with Confucius and praise the profound Way.)*

“I wish I had a beak three feet long.”
*(Commentary: If one’s words are not one’s own, then even a lifetime of speech is as if never spoken. Thus, a beak three feet long is not long enough; for ordinary people, closing the mouth is not the same as not speaking.)*
*(Commentary: *Hui* means mouth. If one’s words are fitting, then this is no different from silence. Even if my beak were three feet long, how would it differ from a closed mouth? Hence, I wish for one.)*

That is called the Way of the un-Way.
*(Commentary: That refers to the two masters.)*
*(Commentary: That refers to the principle expounded. The un-Way as Way means it is neither the Way nor not the Way.)*

This is called the eloquence of the unspoken.
*(Commentary: This refers to Confucius.)*
*(Commentary: This refers to the teaching expounded. Speaking without speaking means it is neither speech nor not speech. Zi Xuan comments: ‘This refers to Confucius’—this annotation is crude and misses the mark. The un-Way and unspoken delve into the subtle and hidden, exhausting principle and fulfilling nature—how could the two masters have attained this? If one praises their peaceful sleep and ball-juggling as settling disputes through silence, then silence and speech are worlds apart—why would Confucius wish for a beak three feet long? Thus, it cannot be so. Moreover, this chapter profoundly discusses the ultimate mystery; judging by its flow, it has little to do with Sun and Xiong’s clarity.)*

Virtue encompasses all that the Way unifies.
*(Commentary: Though the Way’s manifestations are boundless, its great return lies solely in self-attainment—hence, it is one.)*

And words rest where knowledge cannot reach—this is perfection.

*(Annotation: Words that exceed their proper measure fall short of perfection.)*

*(Exegesis: The celestial realm of the ultimate Dao, the domain of profound mystery—even the sagely mind cannot fathom it, nor can the divine tongue articulate it. To seek truth through words and knowledge is to stray far indeed. Thus, what virtue unifies and words affirm lies solely in the singular mystery of the Dao. That which the Dao unifies, virtue cannot equal.)*

*(Annotation: Each attains it for themselves; they do not share it, yet the Dao remains one.)*

*(Exegesis: The singular Dao is empty and profound, boundless in its expanse, while virtue, though graded, cannot fully encompass it. Some texts read "同" as "equal," meaning virtue, though varying in excellence, cannot equal the Dao. This clarifies the earlier phrase, "that which the Dao unifies." What knowledge cannot know, discourse cannot exhaust.)*

*(Annotation: It lies not beyond its bounds, hence cannot be exhausted.)*

*(Exegesis: Knowledge pertains to the subtle Dao—what transcends names and words—thus, no argument or explanation can fully grasp it. This elucidates the earlier "what knowledge cannot know." To claim the names of Confucians and Mohists while acting thus is disastrous.)*

*(Annotation: Confucians and Mohists seek to equal what cannot be equaled, to exhaust what cannot be exhausted—hence, disaster.)*

*(Exegesis: Those who cling to right and wrong, adopting the names of Confucians and Mohists, invite calamity. Thus, the sea does not refuse the eastward flow—this is the height of greatness.)*

*(Annotation: Its greatness lies in accepting all without refusal.)*

*(Exegesis: A hundred rivers rush ceaselessly eastward, yet the vast sea receives them without hesitation. This speaks of the Eastern Sea, yet its vastness is supreme. The sage embraces heaven and earth, bestowing blessings upon all under heaven, yet none know his name.)*

*(Annotation: All is entrusted to spontaneity.)*

*(Exegesis: The earlier analogy of the sea is now matched. The sage’s virtue harmonizes with the two poles, thus embracing heaven and earth; his benevolence extends without limit, thus blessing all under heaven; he achieves yet does not dwell, thus none know who he is; he ascribes merit to others, thus none recognize his lineage. Therefore, in life he bears no rank.)*

*(Annotation: Possessing yet not possessing.)*

*(In death he receives no posthumous title.)*

*(Annotation: Posthumous titles honor merit, but merit does not reside in the self—thus, though titled, it is not his own.)*

*(Exegesis: In life, one holds rank and title; in death, a posthumous name is fixed to reflect their deeds. The sage, however, ascribes merit to others in life, so in death, no title befits him. In truth, he accumulates nothing.)*

*(Annotation: He lets all things be content.)*

*(Exegesis: Though possessing wealth and virtue, he disperses it all among others. His name is not established.)*

*(Annotation: Merit is not his own, so the name returns to things.)*

*(Exegesis: Names reflect reality; if reality is not accumulated, where can the name reside? This is called the Great Person.)*

*(Annotation: To act and claim possession is petty.)*

*(Exegesis: Summarizing the foregoing: one who forgets names and titles may be called a person of great virtue. A dog is not good because it barks well; a person is not worthy because they speak well.)*

*(Annotation: Worthiness arises from nature, not from words.)*

*(Exegesis: "Good" here means "fond of." A dog need not bark, nor a worthy person speak excessively—how much less so for the great. To be great is not enough to be called great, much less to be virtuous.)*

*(Annotation: Only spontaneity is virtue.)*

*(Exegesis: A compassionate heart is called great; harmony with the profound Dao is called virtue. To seek greatness with intent is already contrary to principle—how much more so to act with emotion for virtue. Greatness is complete, yet nothing surpasses heaven and earth. What do they seek to be so perfectly complete?)*

*(Annotation: Heaven and earth are complete in greatness, not through seeking.)*

*(Exegesis: "Complete" means fully endowed. The two poles cover and sustain, nurturing without intent; the four seasons proceed in order, generating and completing the myriad things. What method do they employ to ensure all is complete? One who knows completeness seeks nothing, loses nothing, discards nothing, and does not let things alter the self.)*

*(Annotation: One who knows their own completeness does not grasp at things, hence seeks nothing, loses nothing, discards nothing.)*

*(Exegesis: One who embodies the principle of natural vastness and finds all things inherently complete can remain indifferent between self and others, thus neither taking nor grasping, neither losing nor forfeiting, neither verifying nor attaining, and does not let external things seize the heart. Returning to the self without exhaustion.)*

*(Annotation: Returning to guard one’s own principle, one’s principle naturally flows.)*

*(Exegesis: Only through vast completeness can one align with the ultimate principle. Thus, returning to the root and reverting to the origin, one meets the subtlety of their own being without end. Following the ancient without friction.)*

*(Annotation: Following one’s constant nature to its natural end is not a matter of polishing.)*

*(Exegesis: "Following" means compliance. Complying with the nature of things without intentional alteration—why would one polish or adorn it? This is the sincerity of the Great Person.)*

*(Annotation: Not acting yet attaining—this is called sincerity.)*

*(Exegesis: "Sincerity" means reality. Returning to the root and reverting to the origin, following the myriad things—this is the true virtue of the great sage. Ziqí had eight sons; he arrayed them before him and summoned Jiufang Yin, saying: "Examine my sons for me—who is most auspicious?")*

*(Exegesis: Ziqí was the Minister of War of Chu. "Arrayed" means arranged in order. "诸" means "於" (before). Jiufang is the surname; Yin is the given name. "孰" means "who." "Auspicious" means good. Jiufang Yin was skilled in physiognomy. He arranged the sons before the courtyard and commanded Yin to examine them, asking which of the eight was most fortunate.)*

Jiufang Yin said, "Kun is the most auspicious."
*(Exegesis: Kun was the name of one son. Among the eight sons, Kun was the most virtuous and good.)*

Ziqí started in joy and asked, "How so?"
*(Exegesis: *Quran* denotes a look of surprise and delight. Hearing his son was auspicious, his expression showed astonishment and joy, and he asked what his auspicious appearance was like.)*

Jiufang Yin replied, "Kun will share the ruler’s table for the rest of his life."

Ziqí’s face fell as tears welled up, and he said, "Why must my son come to such an extreme?"
*(Exegesis: *Suoran* describes tears flowing. Jiufang Yin’s insight was shallow, taking meat-eating as auspicious, while Ziqí’s discernment was profound and subtle, knowing it was not truly fortunate. Thus, he pitied the extremity of misfortune and wept in sorrow.)*

Jiufang Yin said, "To share the ruler’s table brings favor to three clans—how much more to parents! Now that you weep upon hearing this, you reject good fortune. The son is auspicious, but the father is not."
*(Exegesis: The three clans refer to the father’s clan, the mother’s clan, and the wife’s clan. *Yu* means to resist. To share the ruler’s table is honor, wealth, and nobility, with blessings extending to the three clans—how could it be limited to parents alone? The son enjoys good fortune, yet the father weeps in response—this is rejecting virtue. Ziqí said, "Yin, how could you understand this and call Kun auspicious? It is merely about wine and meat entering the mouth and nose—how could you know their origin? I have never herded sheep, yet a ewe is born in the southwest corner; I have never hunted, yet a quail appears in the southeast. If this is not strange, what is?" *(Annotation: What is strange arises from the unexpected.)* *(Exegesis: *Zang* means sheep. The southwest corner is the *wei* position, the place of sheep; the southeast corner is the *chen* position, the place of quail—hence the mention of a ewe being born. Sheep require herding, and quail are obtained through hunting. If wealth and nobility depend on merit, how could Kun, whose deeds are unknown, share the ruler’s table? This is no different from having a sheep without herding or obtaining a quail without hunting. Without herding or hunting, how could it not be strange? What I share with my companions is wandering in the realm of Heaven and Earth. *(Annotation: Without purpose.)* I wander with them in joy beneath Heaven; I wander with them in sustenance upon Earth. *(Annotation: Following whatever is encountered in Heaven and Earth.)* *Yao* means to encounter. *(Exegesis: *Yao* means encounter. Heaven and Earth are without intent. Ziqí embodied the Dao, emptying himself and following things, content within his nature. He roamed between Heaven and Earth, finding fulfillment in whatever he encountered, needing no pleasure, and whatever he passed through became sustenance—how could it depend on rich flavors? I do not engage with them in affairs, nor in schemes, nor in strangeness. *(Annotation: *Guai* means anomaly. Following nature and acting spontaneously, free and unconstrained.)* *(Exegesis: Forgetting things, he does not engage in affairs; forgetting wisdom, he does not scheme; following the constant, he does not regard anything as strange. I ride the sincerity of Heaven and Earth without clashing with things. *(Annotation: This is not acting.)* *(Exegesis: *Cheng* means reality. Riding the true Way of the Two Modes, he follows the myriad things in carefree wandering, never clashing or disturbing them. I go along with them in ease without letting affairs dictate what is fitting. *(Annotation: This is following without discrimination.)* *(Exegesis: *Wei yi* means to go along freely. With no division between mind and environment, he moves with things in harmony. If affairs are not truly affairs, how could they dictate what is fitting? Now, there is a worldly recompense. *(Annotation: One who acts for things is repaid by them. I do not act for merit, yet I am repaid—why?)* *(Exegesis: Rewarding merit and virtue is the way of the world. If one embodies the Dao and follows things without seeking merit or fame, why would one need recompense? Whenever there are strange omens, there must be strange conduct. Alas, this is not the fault of my son or me—it is Heaven’s doing. *(Annotation: Now, with no strange conduct yet strange omens, it must be fate.)* *(Exegesis: *Dai* means peril; *ji* means near. Strange conduct must bring strange omens. Now, my son has no strange conduct yet faces strange omens—this peril must be Heaven-sent calamity, not his fault. That is why I weep. *(Annotation: What happens due to action can be avoided by not acting. What comes without action cannot be helped—hence the tears.)* *(Exegesis: If the fault were his, he might amend it. Since it is Heaven’s decree, he weeps.)* Before long, Kun was sent as an envoy to Yan. Bandits seized him on the road. Selling him whole would be difficult, but cutting off his foot would make it easier. *(Annotation: Keeping him whole risked escape, so maiming him made sale easier.)* *(Exegesis: *Wu ji he* means a brief moment. The state of Chu sent Kun as an envoy to Yan, but on the road, he was captured by bandits and enslaved. Selling him whole risked escape, making it hard to guard him, but cutting off his foot removed that concern, making sale easier.)* Thus, they cut off his foot and sold him in Qi, where he happened to serve as a street warden for Qu Gong and ended his life eating meat. *(Exegesis: Qu Gong was a wealthy man in Qi who served as a street warden. After Kun’s foot was cut off, he was sold to a wealthy merchant in Qi, where he oversaw the street and ate meat for the rest of his life.)*

The character *qu* (渠) is also written as *tu* (术), which states: Qu Gong was a butcher. Kun was sold to a butcher’s household, where he jointly oversaw the craft of slaughter, and thus ate meat for the rest of his life.

Nie Que encountered Xu You and asked, “Where are you going?”
*(Annotation: Nie Que met Xu You and inquired where he intended to go.)*
Xu You replied, “I am fleeing from Yao.”
*(Annotation: He answered that he sought to escape Emperor Yao.)*
Nie Que asked, “What do you mean?”
*(Annotation: He questioned the reason.)*
Xu You said, “Yao is so excessively benevolent that I fear he will become a laughingstock to the world. In later generations, men may even devour one another.”
*(Annotation: The root of contention lies in benevolence.)*
*(Annotation: *Xuxu* (畜畜) describes the flourishing of such conduct. The practice of partial, biased benevolence deviates from the virtue of pure harmony. I fear that those within the realm who have lost the Dao will grow even more dissolute than the degenerate ages of old. As they follow in Yao’s footsteps, the people will suffer famine, granaries will empty, and the people will inevitably turn to cannibalism. Thus, I flee.)*

“The people are not difficult to gather: cherish them, and they draw near; benefit them, and they come; praise them, and they are encouraged; impose what they detest, and they scatter.”
*(Annotation: The people grow close when cherished, come when benefited, are encouraged by praise, and disperse when confronted with what they loathe. Thus, the assembly and dispersal of the common folk are not difficult.)*

“Love and benefit arise from benevolence and righteousness. Few abandon benevolence and righteousness, while many exploit them. The practice of benevolence and righteousness is inherently insincere.”
*(Annotation: Once benevolence and righteousness are practiced, pretense follows.)*
*(Annotation: To benefit all beings, nurture all creatures, and gather the masses through merit—nothing precedes benevolence and righteousness. Yet those who truly embody benevolence and righteousness from within are few, while many feign saintly traces to pursue fame and profit. Thus, those who practice benevolence and righteousness do so with artificial nature and false sentiment, lacking sincerity.)*

“Moreover, they become tools for the greedy and rapacious.”
*(Annotation: When benevolence and righteousness are visible, the poor will borrow these tools to achieve their aims.)*
*(Annotation: *Qi* (器) refers to saintly traces. Those who are avaricious for fame and profit, more treacherous than birds and beasts, must borrow benevolence and righteousness as their instruments.)*

“Thus, the judgments of one man bring profit to the world.”
*(Annotation: If benevolence and righteousness arose from genuine sentiment, their judgments would not be confined to one man.)*
*(Annotation: Those who covet glory and profit, wielding benevolence and righteousness, impose their judgments upon the world. Without the traces of sages, how could this be so?)*

“It is like a single blade: if the myriad things, in their myriad forms, are cut by one measure, harm will follow.”
*(Annotation: *Mi* (覕) means to cut. If the myriad things, in their myriad forms, are severed by a single blade, injury will result.)*
*(Annotation: *Mi* means to cut. If one man’s rule subdues the world, it is like a single knife cutting the myriad things—harm will be widespread.)*

“Yao knew that the worthy benefit the world but did not realize they also harm it. Only those who stand beyond worthiness understand this.”
*(Annotation: To stand beyond worthiness is to prevent its pretense.)*
*(Annotation: The traces of sages may benefit one age, but in ten thousand generations, they will surely spawn harm. Only those who forget and transcend the worthy and the sage grasp this subtlety.)*

There are those who are *nuan shu* (暖姝), those who are *ru xu* (濡需), and those who are *juan lou* (卷娄).
*(Annotation: These are briefly outlined below for explanation.)*

The *nuan shu* are those who study the words of a single master, delighting privately in their *nuan nuan shu shu* self-satisfaction, believing they have attained sufficiency. Yet they do not know that nothing has truly been grasped.
*(Annotation: When intent is exhausted in form and teaching, how could they know of my solitary transformation in the profound and obscure realm?)*
*(Annotation: *Nuan shu* describes self-satisfaction. Those of limited learning, content with their meager knowledge, believe they have plumbed the subtlest mysteries. Yet what they have learned amounts to nothing—this is what is meant by *nuan shu*, summarizing the preceding point.)*

Thus, they are called *nuan shu*.

The *ru xu* are like lice on a pig: they select sparse bristles, believing them to be vast palaces and grand parks. They take the curves of hooves and the spaces between teats and thighs as secure chambers and advantageous dwellings, unaware that one morning, the butcher will roll up his sleeves, spread straw, and wield fire and smoke—whereupon they and the pig will burn together.
*(Annotation: *Ru xu* describes arrogance. The pig is the host. The lice, dwelling on the pig’s body, choose sparse, long bristles to fashion into vast palaces and gardens. The gaps between hooves and the spaces beside teats and thighs become warm and convenient abodes. Yet how would they know the butcher will suddenly seize fire and smoke, roll up his sleeves, spread straw, and slaughter them—so that they and the pig burn together?)*

Those who indulge in sensual desires among the ignorant masses differ not from the lice on the pig, reveling in their *ru xu* arrogance. Here they advance with their domain, there they retreat with their domain. *(Annotation: "Domain" refers to boundaries or realms.)* The lice perish when the pig dies; men rise and fall with their circumstances, hence the term "advancing and retreating with their domain." Such are the so-called *ru xu*.

*(Commentary:)* Those lacking the talent to adapt to change or transcend the world, yet clinging to fleeting comforts, are no different from the lice on the pig.

*(Annotation:)* The "hunched one" is Shun. Mutton does not seek ants, but ants seek mutton—for mutton is rank. Shun possessed a rank virtue, and the people delighted in him. *(Annotation: "Hunched one" describes a stooped posture, shoulders bowed and back curved in humility. Mutton, being rank, does not seek ants, yet ants flock to it. Shun’s virtuous conduct did not seek the people, yet the people rejoiced in him. Thus, mutton is likened to Shun, and ants to the people.)* Hence, thrice he fled to establish new settlements, and at Deng’s ruins, a hundred thousand households gathered. *(Annotation: To evade his son Dan Zhu and avoid the crowds, Shun fled thrice, yet the people, drawn by his virtue, followed in numbers reaching a hundred thousand, forming cities wherever he dwelled. Dengxu is a place name.)* Yao, hearing of Shun’s worthiness, raised him from barren land, hoping to receive his beneficent influence. *(Annotation: "Barren land" refers to soil devoid of vegetation. Yao, recognizing Shun’s sagely virtue, wed him to his daughters E Huang and Nü Ying, and elevated him to succeed his throne, yielding the realm to him. Though dwelling in desolate lands and enduring hardships, he awaited the neighboring states to emulate his example, that the common people might receive his grace.)* Yet when Shun was raised from that barren land, his years had grown long, his senses had dimmed, and he could not retire—such was the "hunched one."

*(Commentary:)* The sage’s form differs not from that of ordinary men, thus his ears and eyes may weaken, yet his spirit remains whole from beginning to end. If sageliness were absent in youth, and declined with age, would the sage’s sagacity not vanish in a single morning?

*(Annotation:)* Having ascended the throne as the Son of Heaven, his power spanning the realm, he pitied the common people and grieved for the masses. Thus, in his advanced age, his senses waned, and he found no respite, unable to return home. Hunched and weary, body and spirit exhausted—such was the "hunched one."

Therefore, the divine man detests the multitude’s arrival, *(Commentary: The multitude comes of its own accord, not because he seeks them.)* *(Annotation: Thrice he fled to escape them, for he loathed their presence.)* for where crowds gather, there is no harmony, and where there is no harmony, there is no benefit. *(Commentary: It is clear that Shun’s acquisition of the realm was a matter of necessity, not of seeking advantage through alliances.)* *(Annotation: "Harmony" here means accord. Where crowds assemble, discord arises, and discord brings no benefit.)* Thus, he held nothing too dear, nothing too distant, embracing virtue and warming harmony to align with the world—this is the true man.

*(Annotation: "Warming" means to nurture. The unfathomable divine man regards all with impartiality, upholding harmony—such is the true sage.)* To ants, he abandoned cunning; to fish, he acted wisely; to sheep, he forsook intent. *(Commentary: To the people, he bestowed grace; to Shun, he brought toil.)* *(Annotation: He did not emulate mutton’s virtue, hence to ants he abandoned cunning; he did not teach through rank conduct, hence to sheep he forsook intent. Having forsaken benevolence and righteousness, he aligned with the supreme Dao, neither clinging nor drowning, forgetting all in the rivers and lakes—thus to fish he acted wisely. This critiques Shun’s rank virtue, hence these words.)*

With the eye, he saw the eye; with the ear, he heard the ear; with the heart, he returned to the heart. *(Commentary: These three—eye, ear, and heart—remain present, yet without their usual functions.)* *(Annotation: Seeing only what the eye perceives, hearing only what the ear hears, knowing only what the heart knows, not pursuing what lies beyond one’s bounds but abiding within them—such is the way of the true man.)* In this state, his equilibrium was as a plumb line, *(Commentary: He had not yet transcended the plumb line to achieve self-equilibrium.)* *(Annotation: The plumb line is mindless yet straightens all things; the sage is detached yet impartial.)* and his transformations followed the natural order. *(Commentary: He had not yet erased his traces to achieve profound unity.)* *(Annotation: "Followed" means to comply. Dwelling in the world, he harmonized his light, adapting to myriad changes, greatly complying with the people, never opposing the few.)*

The true men of old treated all with the Dao of Heaven, *(Commentary: Abiding in non-action to await action, action thus succeeds.)* *(Annotation: The above explanation describes the ancient true man, who employed the natural Dao, emptying his heart to await all things.)* not imposing human affairs upon Heaven. *(Commentary: Seeking non-action through action only deepens chaos.)* *(Annotation: He did not employ human affairs to disrupt Heaven’s wisdom.)*

The true men of old gained life through it, lost it through death; gained death through it, lost it through life. *(Commentary: Life and death, gain and loss, each follows its circumstances. In life, it may be gain; in death, it may be loss—nothing is constant.)* *(Annotation: From the perspective of life, life is gain; from the perspective of death, life is loss. Since life and death are uncertain, to whom do gain and loss truly belong? Alas, it cannot be known. Thus, he merged life and death, unified gain and loss—hence he is called the true man.)*

Medicines—some are aconite, some platycodon, some chicken droppings, some pig’s droppings—at their proper time, they become sovereign remedies. What more need be said? *(Commentary: When needed, even the lowly is invaluable; out of season, even the noble is worthless. Value and worthlessness depend on timing—who can claim constancy?)* *(Annotation: Aconite treats wind impediment.)*

Knotweed root treats heart and abdominal blood disorders. "Chicken droppings" refers to *Glechoma longituba*, which when ingested prolongs life. "Pig’s droppings" is the root of *Polyporus umbellatus*, resembling pig feces, and treats wasting-thirst. These are all humble medicines. "Sovereign" means ruler. Medicines know no nobility or baseness—what cures is good; when medicine and illness match, it becomes the ruler. Even sight, hearing, grasping, and knowing—all have their times of use and concealment, their seasons of flourishing and decline. Thus, what the times deem worthy becomes sovereign; talent unsuited to the age becomes a subject. This is the inevitable way of things—how could it ever be fully spoken?

King Goujian, with three thousand men in armor, took refuge on Mount Kuaiji. *(Annotation: Goujian was the king of Yue. Kuaiji is a mountain name. Yue, devastated by Wu’s armies, retreated in distress and took refuge on Mount Kuaiji.)* Only Minister Zhong knew how to preserve a state on the brink of ruin, yet only he failed to foresee the sorrow that would befall himself. *(Annotation: Zhong was a grandee of Yue. At the time, Goujian suffered a crushing defeat, left with only three thousand soldiers, and fled to Mount Kuaiji—annihilation seemed imminent. Yet Zhong, with his deep schemes and foresight, discerned how ruin could be averted. He then feigned submission to Wu, and after twenty-two years, Yue destroyed Wu. As the saying goes: "When the cunning hare dies, the good hound is stewed; when the enemy state falls, the loyal minister perishes." Such is the way of things. After the conquest of Wu, Fan Li left Yue and wandered the rivers and seas, changing his name and concealing his brilliance—this was the later Tao Zhu Gong. Minister Zhong did not leave, and was executed by Goujian. He knew how a ruined state could be saved, but not how his own sorrow—death—was inevitable. The character *zhong* may also be written as 種, to be read accordingly.)*

Thus it is said: The crow’s eye has its proper use; the crane’s step has its measure—when parted, there is sorrow. *(Annotation: Each serves its time and purpose, yet none can be all things at all times. Thus, there are times of loss, and times of sorrow. *Jie* means to depart.)* *(Annotation: The owl’s eye is dim by day but sharp by night—it suits the night but not the day. The crane’s legs are long by nature—it can be long but not short. Such limitations bring sorrow when parted from their proper use, just as Zhong excelled at preserving the state but failed to secure his own fate.)*

Thus it is said: When the wind passes over the river, it diminishes it; when the sun passes over the river, it diminishes it. *(Annotation: All things with form naturally burden one another; only that which is beyond form cannot be worn away.)* *(Annotation: Wind and sun are *qi*; the river has form and substance. All things with form and *qi* cannot be without burden. When wind and sun act upon the river, there must be loss—yet relying on its source, the river does not perceive it. This is like Wu, after conquering Yue, executing its meritorious ministers who, trusting in their past achievements, failed to foresee their doom. Thus, things that benefit one another must also harm one another.)* It is said: The wind and sun merely guard the river, yet the river deems itself untouched. *(Annotation: It is already diminished, yet does not realize it. It relies on its source.)* *(Annotation: It does not perceive the loss because it relies on its source.)* *(Annotation: *Shi* means to rely; *ying* means to diminish. The wind and sun guard the river, diminishing it without its awareness, for it relies on its source.)*

Thus, water guards earth steadfastly; a shadow guards its person steadfastly; a thing guards its counterpart steadfastly. *(Annotation: Without intent, it abides by its nature—this is steadfastness.)* *(Annotation: *Shen* means stability. Water is not secure without earth; a shadow is not visible without a person; a thing does not exist without its creator. Thus, the three guard one another and deem themselves secure. Yet the old does not remain, existence and extinction do not cease. Yesterday’s thing is already transformed today. The hidden boat in the mountain—fools do not perceive this principle.)*

Thus, the eye’s clarity is perilous; the ear’s acuity is perilous; the heart’s pursuit is perilous. *(Annotation: Intent leads to boundlessness—hence peril.)* *(Annotation: *Xun* means to pursue. If the eye seeks the clarity of Li Zhu, the ear the acuity of Shi Kuang, and the heart the boundless knowledge of sages, can peril be avoided?)* All ability stored in the organs is perilous; once peril is formed, it cannot be remedied in time. *(Annotation: Thus, it is noble to be without ability and follow nature.)* *(Annotation: Those who wield discriminating wisdom from their organs and boast of their abilities will surely meet danger. Even if they succeed, they cannot turn back in time to repent.)*

Disaster’s growth gathers here. *(Annotation: *Cui* means to gather. If one cannot forget knowledge, disaster’s growth will be manifold.)* *(Annotation: *Zi* means abundance; *cui* means to gather. Those who serve their organs and display their abilities will see calamities and misfortunes multiply and accumulate.)* Its reversal follows from merit. *(Annotation: Returning to guard one’s nature, merit does not arise and thus is perfected.)* *(Annotation: Those who boast of their abilities and invite ruin do so because they do not retreat after success.)* Its fruition waits upon time. *(Annotation: Haste yields no fruition.)* *(Annotation: Sincere success is followed by self-praise. The heart that waits endures.)* To regard this as one’s treasure—is it not sorrowful? *(Annotation: "One’s treasure" refers to possessing knowledge and ability.)* *(Annotation: The deluded, clinging to their abilities, succeed and remain obstinate. How sorrowful!)*

Thus, the destruction of states and the slaughter of people never cease. *(Annotation: All are disasters of possessing a self.)*

The covetous, claiming lands as their great treasure, seize them by unrighteous means—states shattered, families ruined, countless common folk harmed without end. This is the failure to inquire.

*(Annotation: Not inquiring into the source of calamity stems from self-attachment; one must cultivate the heart to avert disaster.)*

*(Annotation: The world has its wise—these are its tortoise-shell mirrors. Not inquiring into the causes of ruin and misfortune, clinging only to hatred of poverty and lowliness, is the height of folly.)*

Thus, the foot treads upon the earth, and though it treads, it relies on what it does not tread to walk far.

*(Annotation: "Treads" and "tramples" both mean to step upon. The foot’s ability to walk depends on the earth it stands on, yet it must also rely on untrodden ground to proceed; without such space, it cannot move steadily or travel far. This is an analogy.)*

So too with human knowledge: though little, it depends on what it does not know to be called knowledge.

*(Annotation: Only by forgetting heaven and earth, relinquishing the myriad things, can one comprehend even the wing of a cicada—how much less can one know the Way of Heaven while still clinging to a self?)*

*(Annotation: Knowledge has its brightness and obscurity; ability has its limits. Each abiding in its measure, all things wander freely.
