Thus, the earth, though trodden, moves by what is untrodden; the heart, though knowing, illuminates by what it does not know. This is the principle of dwelling in stillness and nurturing tranquility. As the *Laozi* says: "Existence is for benefit; non-existence is for function." This aligns with the analogy.)*

To know the Great Unity, the Great Yin, the Great Eye, the Great Equality, the Great Square, the Great Faithfulness, the Great Constancy—this is perfection.

*(Annotation: Here, a brief outline of those who know the seven great principles, who may be said to have reached the ultimate. The following text explicates their meanings one by one.)*

The Great Unity unifies all.

*(Annotation: The Dao.)*

*(Annotation: One is the number of yang. The Great Unity is Heaven, which unites and generates the myriad things, hence "unifies.")*

The Great Yin dissolves all.

*(Annotation: Employing what lies within its bounds, the myriad affairs encounter no obstruction.)*

*(Annotation: The Great Yin is Earth, which, without intent, bears and sustains all things without division.)*

The Great Eye sees all.

*(Annotation: Letting the myriad things reveal themselves is itself the Great Eye.)*

*(Annotation: Each seeing what it sees is called the Great Eye.)*

The Great Equality follows all.

*(Annotation: Following the inherent nature of each, allowing all to attain their own, is the Great Equality.)*

*(Annotation: "Follows" means to accord. The Great Equality is the full sufficiency of each thing’s nature, all equally balanced.)*

The Great Square embodies all.

*(Annotation: Embodying so that each attains its proper place, all directions are thus encompassed—this is the Great Square.)*

*(Annotation: The forms of the myriad things each have their methods, like spiders weaving webs. To comprehend this is to embody the Great Square.)*

The Great Faithfulness fulfills all.

*(Annotation: What is ordained must be fulfilled without deviation—this is the Great Faithfulness.)*

*(Annotation: "Faithfulness" means reality; "fulfills" means to reach. Following and entrusting each to its own reality is the Great Faithfulness.)*

The Great Constancy upholds all.

*(Annotation: The true, unperturbed, is naturally constant; thus, upholding it with the Great Constancy is not to uphold at all.)*

*(Annotation: Each thing, empty in its essence, upheld and employed—its principle is emptiness.)*

All possess Heaven.

*(Annotation: No thing is without its natural endowment.)*

*(Annotation: None of the seven great principles above exist apart from the natural.)*

Following, there is illumination.

*(Annotation: Following brings clarity; no action is required.)*

*(Annotation: "Following" means to accord. Simply accord with the natural, and wisdom illuminates of itself.)*

In darkness, there is a pivot.

*(Annotation: The ultimate principle has its limit; when one darkly attains it, one grasps its essential pivot.)*

*(Annotation: The profound and obscure principle has its own pivot and mechanism, employed without deliberate effort.)*

In the beginning, there is the Other.

*(Annotation: What begins with the Other is the Other; thus, I transmit but do not create.)*

*(Annotation: What begins with the Other is the Other; thus, I transmit but do not create.)*

Thus, to dissolve it is to resemble one who does not dissolve.

*(Annotation: Dissolving by entrusting to the Other, the Other dissolves itself; dissolving without effort thus resembles not dissolving.)*

*(Annotation: The dissolution comes from following the Other’s teaching—beware of partial attainment becoming one’s nature, hence it does not resemble dissolution.)*

To know it is to resemble one who does not know.

*(Annotation: Illuminating the Other’s knowing.)*

*(Annotation: Able to forget one’s knowledge, thus resembling one who does not know.)*

Not knowing, and only then knowing it.

*(Annotation: If I do not know, the Other’s knowing acts of itself; when the Other’s knowing acts of itself, none under Heaven fail to know.)*

*(Annotation: Knowing by not knowing—thus, not knowing and only then knowing is true knowledge.)*

To inquire into it cannot be bounded,

*(Annotation: Responding to things appropriately, without fixed method.)*

Yet it cannot be unbounded.

*(Annotation: Each according to its measure.)*

Though tangled, there is reality.

*(Annotation: Though the myriad things are tangled and disparate, each thing has its own reality.)*

*(Annotation: "Tangled" means disparate. The myriad things, though chaotic and tangled, when governed as one, become the resource of the real Dao.)*

Ancient and modern do not replace one another.

*(Annotation: Each has its own cause and cannot substitute for the other.)*

The ancient abides in the ancient—it does not extend from ancient times to the present. The present persists in the present—it does not arise from the present to generate the ancient. Each thing has its own nature, and thus they do not replace one another.

Nor can they be diminished,
*(Annotation: Each should fully realize its own measure.)*

*(Annotation: Time does not come and go; the law does not shift or trade. How could the present rely on the ancient? Can this not be called a great upheaval and collapse?)*

*(Annotation: To collapse and then elevate—there is a great limit.)*

*(Annotation: As in the questions above, the Way is vast and boundless. How could it not be said to illuminate the subtle principle while collapsing concrete arguments?)*

Why not ask this very question? Why remain so perplexed?
*(Annotation: If one asks about this great collapse, then things have their ultimate measure. Thus, the principle of forgetting oneself and responding to things can be known—why remain so bewildered?)*

*(Annotation: Why—what? The ignorant, like wanderers in the night, why do they not inquire of the sage? Yet when they weaken and lose their way, becoming so confused and distressed—what is the reason for this?)*

To resolve confusion with the unconfused is to return to the unconfused—this is the ultimate unconfused state.
*(Annotation: Confusion cannot be resolved, so the ultimate unconfused state is the height of folly. Thus, the sage follows and responds to things, which is why the traces of emperors and kings differ, adapting their names to the age.)*

*(Annotation: The sage’s wisdom is unconfused, yet it is confused by worldly emotions. Using the words of sagely wisdom to clarify worldly confusion, forgetting attainment and returning to the root, reverting to the true source—yet one cannot grasp the meaning beyond words and clings to sagely traces, valuing and esteeming explicit teachings, taking the unconfused as the greatest. This is to aspire to the unconfused—how can it truly dispel confusion? This is yet another departure from the unconfused.)*

*End of the Twenty-Sixth Scroll of the Commentary and Subcommentary on the True Scripture of Nanhua.*

#43 The character "之" is amended to "立" following Guo Fan’s cited text. #44 Guo Qingfan’s cited text writes "摽" as "摽," the same below. #45 Wang Xiaoyu supplements the character "自" after "悦" in accordance with the main text. #46 The *Quewu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, which includes the two characters "长毛" after "鬣." #47 The *Siku* edition and Zhejiang Book Bureau edition both write "墟" as "虚." #48 Zhao’s edition omits the character "耳." #49 The Shide Hall edition writes "也" as "之," while Zhao’s edition omits "也." #50 The *Quewu* cites Zhang Junfang’s edition, which writes "之" as "人." #51 The *Siku* edition and Zhejiang Book Bureau edition both write "乎" as "夫." #52 The *Siku* edition and Zhejiang Book Bureau edition both write "谓" as "请." #53 The character "成" is amended to "伐" following Guo Qingfan’s cited text and the meaning of the passage. #54 Zhao’s edition writes "不亦" as "亦不."

*Commentary and Subcommentary on the True Scripture of Nanhua, Scroll Twenty-Seven*
*Annotations by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Commentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of the Tang, on the "Miscellaneous Chapters: Zeyang" (Chapter Twenty-Five) of the *Zhuangzi***

Zeyang traveled in Chu. **[Commentary]** His surname was Peng, his given name Yang, and his courtesy name Zeyang; he was a man of Lu. He served various feudal lords and later entered Chu, intending to serve King Wen of Chu. Yijie spoke of him to the king, but the king did not grant him an audience. **[Commentary]** His surname was Yi, his given name Jie; he was a minister of Chu. Zeyang wished to serve Chu, so he relied on Yijie to speak of him to the king. Since the king was noble and esteemed, he had not yet granted an audience. Yijie’s recommendation had not yet succeeded, so he left court and returned home.

Yijie departed. Pengyang saw Wang Guo and said, “Why do you not speak of me to the king?” **[Commentary]** Wang Guo was a worthy grandee of Chu. *Tan* means to praise or speak of; some texts also write it as *yantan* (discourse). Previously, relying on Yijie, he had not obtained an audience with the king; later, he entreated Wang Guo, hoping he would recommend him. Wang Guo said, “I am not equal to Gong Yuexiu.” **[Commentary]** *Ruo* means “like.” Gong Yuexiu was the sobriquet of a recluse. Wang Guo, a worthy man, disapproved of Pengyang’s haste and greed for glory, so he extolled the recluse to curb his eagerness for advancement.

Pengyang said, “What does Gong Yuexiu do?” **[Commentary]** *Xi* means “what.” Since he had praised Gong Yuexiu, Pengyang claimed not to know, so he asked what he did, hoping to learn the reason. [Wang Guo] said, “In winter, he spears turtles alone in the river; in summer, he rests in the mountain groves. If someone passes by and asks, he says, ‘This is my home.’” **[Annotation]** This is said to curb Pengyang’s eagerness for advancement. **[Commentary]** *Du* means to stab; *fan* means the side or a dense forest. In the depths of winter, he stabs turtles by the riverbank to roam freely; in the height of summer, he retreats to rest in the dense woods to find comfort. With no worldly attachments, he points to the mountainside and calls it his dwelling. This briefly describes Yuexiu’s conduct.

“If Yijie has already failed, how much more so I? I am even less capable than Yijie. Now, as for Yijie’s character: he lacks virtue but possesses cunning. He does not trust himself but uses his cleverness to mystify his connections, firmly entangling himself in the realm of wealth and honor.” **[Annotation]** This says that I am not as fond of wealth and honor as Yijie, who cultivates connections and exhausts his form and intent, relying on his knowledge to curry favor with superiors. **[Commentary]** *Leiming* means to be lost or submerged. It says that Yijie’s connections are steadfast, his intent fixed on glory; he is deluded and confused, his heart greedy for wealth and honor. He truly lacks true virtue but possesses worldly knowledge; he cannot follow the Dao with emptiness and tranquility but instead relies on his cunning to seek favor. Repeatedly acting thus, even he cannot succeed—how much less can I, who clings to foolishness, recommend him? This is Wang Guo’s modest speech.

“He does not aid others with virtue but instead harms them.” **[Annotation]** If he advances recklessly, his virtue is shallow, and his reputation is diminished. **[Commentary]** *Xiao* means to damage or ruin. It says that if Zeyang relies on me to speak of him to the king, this will only ruin his reputation and conduct, not benefit his great virtue.

“The frozen borrow clothes from spring; the scorched turn to winter’s cold wind.” **[Annotation]** This says that I follow the seasons’ gifts and cannot rush to Pengyang’s aid. **[Commentary]** Those who suffer from cold are warmed by clothing; those afflicted by heat are revived by water. They await the warmth of spring to thaw the frost or the cold wind of winter to relieve the heat. Though this departs from human affairs, it accords with the seasons. The man who treads the Way and understands principle embodies no immediate kindness; his refusal to advance Pengyang follows the same principle.

“As for the King of Chu’s character: his form is august and stern. In punishing offenses, he is as unforgiving as a tiger. If not for a flattering man of upright virtue, who could sway him?” **[Commentary]** His bearing commands the majesty of one who faces south; his dignity rests upon the power of a thousand chariots. His wrath is fierce, like a ravening tiger; in punishing and humiliating the people, he grants no pardon. If not for a great flatterer, none could serve him. How could a man who treads uprightness and embodies virtue bend his will to serve such a ruler?

Thus the sage—when impoverished—makes his household forget their poverty.
**[Annotation]** Serene and desireless, he finds joy in what befalls him, not prizing extravagance but honoring the Dao and virtue. Thus his family does not recognize poverty as suffering.
**[Commentary]** Yu-kou dwelt in Zheng, Lao Lai in Chu; though their wives drew the crossbow in straitened circumstances, their joy remained within. If worthy scholars can do this, how much more the true sage—such is his resolve in poverty.

When prosperous, he makes kings and dukes forget their ranks and emoluments, transforming them to humility.
**[Annotation]** Lightly regarding rank and emolument while esteeming the Dao and virtue, he sits in profound forgetfulness, unaware of the honor upon him. Thus he makes kings and dukes lose what they once held high.
**[Commentary]** Concealing brilliance is poverty; manifesting traces is prosperity. Duke Ai befriended Confucius; the Yellow Emperor crawled to Guangchengzi. In each case, where the Dao was present, reverence followed, unbound by rank. Thus they could make kings of ten thousand chariots and lords of the five orders transform their lofty hearts into humble conduct.

Toward things, he delights in harmony with them.
**[Annotation]** He does not suffer on their account.
**[Commentary]** Moving through the world, he engages with things impartially; all he encounters brings contentment, so he is never without joy.

Toward others, he rejoices in their free flow while preserving himself.
**[Annotation]** Others flow freely without losing himself.
**[Commentary]** Though he mingles in the world without obstruction, he does not lose himself in others. His movement does not disturb stillness, and he ever guards his true nature.

Thus, though he may not speak, he fills others with harmony.
**[Annotation]** Each attains self-realization—this is the harmony of drinking. What need is there for words?
**[Commentary]** Sheltering all beings, he merges obscurely with the vast heavens. The Dao of central harmony is realized in every heart; they depart with fullness, without need of verbal instruction.

Standing alongside others, he transforms them.
**[Annotation]** They gaze upon his influence and yield to it.
**[Commentary]** Blending light with the dust, he stands among them; each returns to their true nature—this is transformation.

The proper order of father and son—there they return to dwell.
**[Annotation]** He causes fathers to be fathers and sons to be sons, each returning to their place.
**[Commentary]** Though he mingles high and low, the natural order remains unharmed. Thus fathers and sons, rulers and ministers, each occupy their proper station, without confusion—is this not fitting?

Yet there is no gap in what he bestows.
**[Annotation]** His bestowal aligns with the virtue of heaven and earth, thus it is unceasing and unwavering.
**[Commentary]** All his acts of grace follow the sequence of the four seasons, ever unhurried and composed, his movement and stillness undivided.

So distant is he from the hearts of others.
**[Commentary]** The sage’s use of the heart, as described above, reveals his purity, loftiness, and profound remoteness.

Thus it is said: await Gongyue Xiu.
**[Annotation]** He wishes him to abandon the King of Chu and follow Xiu, that the wind of tranquility may still his restless heart.
**[Commentary]** This is the summation. The sage comprehends the intricate and entangled.
**[Annotation]** This is what is called "mysterious penetration."
**[Commentary]** The sage of the Dao, transcending all bonds, understands that the realm of things is illusory—how could he be fettered by the world’s net? Though Xiu has not yet fully attained the Dao, he is cited here as an example.

All things share one body.
**[Annotation]** Without inner or outer, all are equally illumined.
**[Commentary]** His wisdom encompasses all things, he exhausts principle and fulfills nature. Self and other are not two, thus all merge into one body.

Yet he does not know why it is so—it is his nature.
**[Annotation]** That which is naturally so without knowing why—what else could it be but nature?
**[Commentary]** Capacity and object respond, realm and wisdom merge; he does not know how it is so, nor can he distinguish the reason. Thus he accords with true nature.

Returning to the mandate, he moves and acts, taking heaven as his teacher.
**[Annotation]** He moves of himself, acts of himself, yet none fail to return to the mandate and take their natural state as teacher.
**[Commentary]** Returning to the root, he reverts to the original mandate. Though he moves and acts in accord with things, his movement and stillness are without intent, harmonizing with heaven and earth—thus he takes the two powers as his teacher.

Others then follow and name him.
**[Annotation]** This is not seeking fame by pursuing lofty traces. Moving in accord with nature, his traces are naturally lofty, so others cannot diminish his name.
**[Commentary]** *Ming* means "name." The sage who embodies the Dao has no name, but because his pure dust may be admired, others follow and name him.

Worrying through knowledge, his conduct lasts but a brief moment. When it must cease, what then?
**[Annotation]** Acting through knowledge brings a succession of worries.
**[Commentary]** Using knowledge to engage with things breeds cares and distractions; the spirit is easily swayed, conduct lasts but a moment. With clinging thoughts and anxieties, when will there be rest?

Even if it were Yu the Great, there would be no remedy.

One born beautiful—others provide him a mirror. If not told, he does not know his beauty surpasses others.
**[Annotation]** *Jian* means "mirror." A mirror reflects without partiality, thus people admire it. Now, does the mirror know it is mirroring when it mirrors? Born to reflect, others call it a mirror. If people did not tell one another, none would know its beauty surpasses others. This is like the sage—others give him a name.
**[Commentary]** *Jian* means "mirror." *Gao* means "to tell." Born bright and illuminating, it reflects things impartially; people admire it, thus it is called a mirror. If people did not tell one another, the mirror would have no name. This begins the analogy.

Whether he knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, his delight never ends.
**[Annotation]** The mirror’s delight lies in its lack of feeling. Whether one knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, it reflects upon approach—thus its delight never ends.

If the mirror’s reflection depended on hearing and knowing, then it would cease at times.
**[Commentary]** *Yi* means "to cease." The mirror’s illumination of things lies in its lack of feeling; it reflects foe and kin alike, ever impartially. Were it to reflect only when hearing and knowing occur, and not otherwise, its function would be subject to interruption—sometimes active, sometimes idle. How then could its illumination endure? Only because its reflection is unceasing does it earn people’s admiration. And people’s admiration for it never ends, for it is its nature.
**[Annotation]** If it were not its nature to reflect, how could its illumination endure?

The mirror’s capacity to reflect arises naturally; people’s admiration for it follows the workings of creation. Since it does not feign its nature, its reflection is endless. The sage’s love for others is such that people bestow a name upon him. Were they not told, none would know of his love for others.
**[Annotation]** The sage’s love is like the mirror’s reflection.
Yet his deeds benefit all things, so people give him a name. If they did not tell one another, none would know of his love for others.
**[Commentary]** The sage’s grace extends to all living beings, his kindness flows through ten thousand generations. Beings bear his virtue, and people give him a name, passing it on through speech, so that a fine title arises. Without this, how could the name of sage exist? Whether he knows or does not know, hears or does not hear, his love for others never ends.
**[Annotation]** He regards the people as straw dogs, yet the Dao accords with loving others—thus his love is without end. If his love depended on hearing and knowing, then it would wane at times.
**[Commentary]** The sage’s virtue is vast and boundless, his treatment of things impartial. He nurtures all living beings, regards the people as straw dogs—how could he wait for knowledge or hearing before loving them? Only because his compassion is without bias does his virtue never end. This completes the analogy.

People’s contentment with him never ends, for it is their nature.
**[Annotation]** What accords with one’s nature can endure.
**[Commentary]** *An* means "settled." At rest, he shares the virtue of yin; in motion, he moves with the waves of yang. Thus he is without intention in movement or stillness. Therefore, though thunder splits mountains, he remains steadfast; though great winds shake the sea, he is not startled. This is following one’s true nature. If one feigns nature and falsifies feeling, then one will be moved at times. Thus Wang Bi said: "If one does not accord with one’s nature in feeling, how can one long maintain one’s aspirations?"

Returning to one’s old state and old home, one feels a surge of joy.
**[Annotation]** If returning to the familiar brings such joy, how much more so returning to one’s nature?
**[Commentary]** The state and home are metaphors for one’s true nature. One who loses his homeland in youth and wanders in a foreign land feels joy upon gazing back at his native place. How much more so one who has long strayed from the Dao, pursuing the superficial for ages—now returning to the origin, one feels a surge of joy. Even if hills and woods have grown tangled,
**[Annotation]** *Min* means "to join."
with only one in ten recognizing the place, one still feels joy. How much more so when one sees what one has seen and hears what one has heard?
**[Annotation]** Seeing what one has seen before, hearing what one has heard before, one still feels joy—how much more so when one embodies one’s nature?
**[Commentary]** *Min* means "to join." In an old state and home, long abandoned, hills may be rugged, woods overgrown. Of ten visitors, nine recognize it; seeing what they once saw, hearing what they once heard, they feel a surge of joy. How much more so one who has long strayed from the Dao, drowning in the cycle of life and death—suddenly returning to the origin, meeting the true source, returning to the realm of profound mystery, beholding the realm of the supreme Dao. The joy this brings—how could it be easily described?

It is like a tower seventy feet high, suspended in the midst of a crowd.
**[Annotation]** What the crowd is accustomed to, though perilous, seems familiar—how much more so the sage, who is without peril.
**[Commentary]** Seven feet make a *ren*. A tower seven *ren* high is perilously suspended, yet when many people climb it, they feel no fear. Habit shapes nature, so they remain at ease. How much more so when one attains the true—where would one not be at peace?

Ran Xiangshi grasped its center and followed what was already complete.

**[Annotation]** Ran Xiangshi was an ancient sage-king who dwelled in emptiness and followed things, allowing them to complete themselves.

**[Commentary]** Ran Xiangshi was an emperor of non-action prior to the Three Sovereigns. The "ring" is the emptiness at the center. The ancient sage-kings attained the Dao of true emptiness and embodied the wondrousness of the ring’s center. Thus, their Way harmonized with all beings, blending and completing the myriad things. With things, they had no end and no beginning, no moment and no time.

**[Annotation]** Suddenly, they went along with them.

**[Commentary]** "No beginning" means no past; "no end" means no future; "no moment and no time" means no present. Embracing transformation and merging with change, they went along with things—thus, the three times ceased to exist. One who daily transforms with things is the one who does not transform.

**[Annotation]** Daily transforming with things, they were constantly without self; being constantly without self, they were constantly unchanging.

**[Commentary]** Following daily renewal and transforming with things, they moved yet remained quiescent. Thus, they congealed in the singular Dao, abiding in stillness without change. How could they ever abandon this?

**[Annotation]** Why not try relinquishing what one does?

**[Commentary]** *He* means "how." Those who embody emptiness are profoundly attuned to the Creator. Though myriad changes occur, they go along with transformation—how could they ever briefly part from it?

One who models oneself on Heaven yet fails to model oneself on Heaven—

**[Annotation]** Only by modeling nothing does one truly model Heaven.

**[Commentary]** *Shi* means "to emulate"; *Heaven* refers to nature. The great Creator fashions things, moving in accordance with their nature. If one acts with deliberate emulation, one deviates from nature—thus failing to model it. How can one who follows things in all their pursuits regard this as a proper endeavor?

**[Annotation]** Though modeling Heaven, one is still not free from pursuit—how could this be worth regarding as an affair? Modeling Heaven is still insufficient to be called an affair—how much less so if one does not model it?

**[Commentary]** *Xun* means "to chase" or "to seek." One who deliberately emulates creation and goes along with things does not follow their original nature—how could this suffice as the cultivation of one’s affairs? Still possessing something to seek, this is pursuit. If even modeling has something to be called pursuit, how much more so when one abandons oneself to chase things?

The sage has never had Heaven, never had man, never had a beginning, never had things.

**[Commentary]** The sage who attains the center penetrates the ultimate principle, thus transcending both man and Heaven, forgetting both self and things. If there is said to be no end, how could there ever be a beginning? Following nature and harmonizing with the Dao, they no longer model Heaven. They move in step with the world without ceasing; their conduct is complete yet not stagnant—how do they harmonize with it?

**[Annotation]** Only by being utterly without does one obscurely harmonize.

**[Commentary]** *Ti* means "to cease" or "to block." Blending with human affairs, they move in step with the world, engaging with things and adapting to the times without ever ceasing or lacking. Though they fully experience the world’s fortunes and misfortunes, they are never blocked. Whatever they encounter flows freely. Without deliberate emulation, they naturally harmonize with the Dao—how could one imitate this in order to align? The true is inherently ungraspable.

Tang entrusted governance to his minister, the Gatekeeper Yin Deng, who transmitted it for him.

**[Annotation]** He entrusted it to the hundred officials and did not intervene.

**[Commentary]** His surname was Men, his given name Yin. Here, *Gatekeeper* is an official title; his surname was Deng, his given name Heng. The sage-king Tang, forgetting concerns and following things, thus obtained a worthy minister to manage affairs. Though serving as a teacher and mentor, he remained serene and composed, refraining from action.

Following the teacher without confinement—

**[Annotation]** Allowing them to gather naturally, not confining them; letting them disperse naturally, not releasing them.

**[Commentary]** *Cong* means "to allow"; *you* means "to gather." Being empty and inactive, he entrusted the teacher, never accumulating achievements for himself. Attaining this following of completion, he entrusted governance to the minister—

**[Annotation]** The attendants of the chariot-keeper also followed the natural course of things. Tang obtained them, so his name was lent to things while his merit lay not in himself.

**[Commentary]** The worthy minister, receiving the commission, followed things to completion. Attributing merit to the chariot-keeper, his name did not reside in himself. This name and method were in surplus, attaining their dual manifestation.

**[Annotation]** Names and methods are merely traces of the past, not what is truly sufficient. Thus, it is said: one who is effortlessly without intention entrusts governance to the various ministers, so their names and traces are both manifested in them.

**[Commentary]** *Yingran* means "without intention"; *xian* means "to manifest." The name of completing things and the method of sagely traces both belong to the teacher, not to the sage. Thus, the two matters of name and method are both manifested in them. Effortlessly at ease, their merit is accomplished without claim.

Confucius exhausted his thoughts to serve as their mentor.

**[Annotation]** Confucius said: "What thought? What worry?" Thoughts are already exhausted. If there were the slightest lingering thought, how could one remain still and unmoving, responding endlessly to stimuli, aiding the natural course of the myriad things?

**[Commentary]** *Fu* means "to assist"; *jin* means "to exhaust." The sage Confucius, forgetting concerns and exhausting thoughts, thus opened and transformed the multitude, assisting their natural endowment. If the slightest intention remained, how could he sit in forgetfulness and respond to stimuli?

Rong Chengshi said: "Remove the days, and there are no years."

**[Annotation]** The reason we have years and retain days is because of life and death. If there were no life and no death, the reckoning of years and days would be removed.

**[Commentary]** Rong Cheng was an ancient sage-king. Years and days are merely names for the seasons. Reckoning time in years and days arises from life and death. When life and death cease, years and days are removed.

There is no inside, no outside.

**[Annotation]** Without self and other, there is no inside or outside.

**[Commentary]** *Inside* is the self; *outside* is things. Reckoning life and death gives rise to inside and outside. When years and days are dispelled, where can self and things reside?

Wei Ying and Tian Hou Mou made a covenant, but Tian Hou Mou betrayed it. Wei Ying grew enraged and was about to send an assassin after him.

**[Commentary]** Ying was the name of King Hui of Wei. Tian Hou was Duke Wei of Qi, named Mou, son of Duke Huan and descendant of Tian Heng, hence called Tian Hou. The two states of Qi and Wei had sworn an oath and formed an alliance, vowing not to invade one another. Soon after the alliance, Duke Wei betrayed it, so the Marquis of Wei flew into a rage and was about to dispatch an assassin to kill him. Their alliance had been made in the twenty-sixth year of Duke Wei of Qi and the eighth year of King Hui of Wei.

Xishou, hearing of this, deemed it shameful and said: "You are a lord of ten thousand chariots, yet you would follow the path of a commoner in seeking vengeance."

**[Commentary]** Xishou was an official title, akin to the modern "Tiger Warriors." A grandson of the ducal house, named Yan, held this office. A feudal state with ten thousand war chariots was called a "lord." A *commoner* refers to a man and woman paired without official rank. *Following vengeance* means to exact retribution. A ruler who lets anger rule him will bring corpses and bloodshed; now you would send a commoner alone to assassinate in vengeance—this is no deed for a lord of ten thousand chariots, and thus it is shameful.

Yan requested two hundred thousand armored troops to attack Qi on his lord’s behalf, capturing its people and seizing its cattle and horses.

**[Commentary]** General Sun Yan requested the authority to receive the battle-axe and lead two hundred thousand armored soldiers to attack Qi’s cities, certain of victory. Thereupon, he would plunder the populace, bind their cattle and horses, and distribute rewards to the soldiers for their merits.

He would cause the Qi lord’s inner heat to erupt upon his back, then uproot his state. After Ji fled, he would strike his back and break his spine.

**[Commentary]** Ji, surnamed Tian, was a Qi general. *Strike* and *break* mean to beat. With the state destroyed and its people lost, resentment and anger would fester in the heart, causing heat to accumulate and abscesses to erupt upon the back. Once the state was overthrown and its ruler and generals captured, he would strike their backs, break their spines, and return in triumph. Was this not gratifying?

Jizi, hearing of this, deemed it shameful and said: "To build a city wall seventy feet high, only to tear it down once it reaches that height—this is the toil that convict laborers lament."

**[Commentary]** Ji was a surname; in ancient times, it was a term of...

Xi was a worthy minister of Wei. *Xumi* refers to convict laborers. Jizi, who embraced the Dao, opposed military campaigns; when Xishou requested troops, he advanced in shame to remonstrate. A city wall of seventy feet requires no small effort—once completed, to destroy it without cause is the very suffering of convict laborers. This is the analogy he drew. Now, for seven years no war has arisen: this is the foundation of Your Majesty’s reign. Yan is a disturber of order and must not be heeded.

**[Commentary]** For seven years, weapons have lain still; the martial has been laid aside in favor of culture and governance—this is the great foundation of a true king. Yet Xishou now sows chaos; his counsel must not be followed.

Huazi, hearing this, deemed it disgraceful and said: “He who speaks well of attacking Qi is a disturber of order; he who speaks well of not attacking is also a disturber of order; and he who calls both the advocate of attack and the advocate of non-attack disturbers of order is yet another disturber of order.”

**[Commentary]** Hua was his surname; *zi* is a title of virtue. He, too, was a worthy minister of Wei. He who speaks skillfully in favor of attacking Qi—meaning to stir up weapons and war—is a disturber of order, namely Gongsun Yan. He who speaks skillfully against attacking seeks to preserve the king’s great foundation and surpass his enemies, yet harbors expectations and thus remains a disturber of order—this is Jizi. As for him who declares both the advocate of attack and the advocate of non-attack to be disturbers of order, he has not yet forgotten words or put the Dao into practice, still clinging to right and wrong in his heart, and thus has not escaped being a disturber of order—this is Huazi speaking of himself.

The ruler said: “Then what should be done?”

**[Commentary]** Huazi’s teachings ran deep, and the king could not fathom their intent, so he asked what the meaning was and what course to follow.

He replied: “Your Majesty should seek only the Dao.”

**[Commentary]** The Dao is clear, empty, and serene, transcending both things and self. Thus he urged the king to seek it, that his desires might grow few, his steps sure upon the Way, and strife vanish of itself.

Master Hui, hearing this, went to see Dai Jinren.

**[Commentary]** Dai Jinren was a worthy man of Liang. His surname was Dai, and his style Jinren. Master Hui, having heard Huazi’s pure words, feared the king of Wei might not yet awaken, so he brought in Dai Jinren to resolve his doubts.

Dai Jinren said: “There is a creature called the snail—do you know it?”

“Yes,” the king replied.

**[Annotation]** The snail is most minute, yet bears two horns.

**[Commentary]** The snail is an insect resembling a small spiral shell; commonly called the “yellow calf,” it is also known as the snail, and has four horns. “Do you know it?” “Yes,” the king of Wei answered, “I recognize it.”

On the snail’s left horn is a kingdom called Chushi, and on its right horn a kingdom called Manshi. From time to time, they war over territory, leaving tens of thousands of corpses in their wake. The victor pursues the vanquished for fifteen days before returning.

**[Annotation]** If one truly knew that what they contend over is as trifling as this, there would be no strife under heaven.

**[Commentary]** On the snail’s two horns, two states exist. Manshi and Chushi wage war again and again, inflicting no small slaughter, and their advances and retreats consume much time. This is the analogy he drew.

The king said: “Alas!”

Is this mere empty talk?

**[Annotation]** The words spoken are so strange and far removed from human nature that the king sighs in doubt, suspecting they are not true.

The guest said: "Allow me to prove their truth to Your Majesty. Do you believe that the four directions and the realms above and below have limits?"

**[Annotation]** The guest tests the king’s understanding: Are the four directions and the realms above and below bounded or not?

This principle applies to all things, and now it is being demonstrated to the Marquis of Wei.

The king said: "They are without limit."

**[Annotation]** The Marquis of Wei answers: The four directions and the realms above and below are boundless.

The guest said: "If one’s mind roams through the boundless and then returns to the lands of men—those within the reach of human footsteps—do they seem to exist or not?"

**[Annotation]** The lands where human footsteps reach are called "the lands of men," referring to the world within the four seas today.

"Exist" means to be present; "not" means to be absent. If the mind wanders through the infinite and then compares it to the Nine Provinces, the difference in scale is such that they seem as if they exist and yet do not.

The king said: "So it is."

**[Annotation]** Today, we consider the four seas vast, but when measured against the boundless, they seem as if they exist and yet do not.

**[Annotation]** "So it is" means the king acknowledges that the guest’s words are not false.

The guest said: "Within the lands of men lies Wei; within Wei lies Liang; within Liang lies Your Majesty. Does Your Majesty differ from the kingdom of Manshi?"

**[Annotation]** Formerly in Hedong, the state was called Wei. When Wei was pressed by the mighty Qin, its capital was moved to Liang. Since Liang arose from Wei, it is said that within Wei lies Liang.

"Differ" means to be distinct. Your Majesty’s kingdom is but one among the Six Directions. When comparing scale, it seems as if it exists and yet does not. What difference is there between you and Manshi? This completes the analogy.

The king said: "There is no difference."

**[Annotation]** Your Majesty and Manshi are both finite things. Being finite, neither great nor small can be measured against the infinite. Even heaven and earth, though vast, are as nothing within the boundless—how much less Wei, Liang within it, and Your Majesty within Liang, that they should be worth contending over?

**[Annotation]** The king realizes that what he contends over is no different from the struggle on the snail’s horns.

The guest departed, and the king stood lost in thought, as if something had slipped away.

**[Annotation]** He mourns the pettiness of what he contends over.

**[Annotation]** *Changran* describes a look of regret. When the man from Jin finished speaking and left, the king, recognizing his own folly, stood in sorrowful regret, his heart heavy as if something were lost.

After the guest left, Huizi came to see the king. The king said: "That guest is a great man—even a sage is not his equal."

**[Annotation]** "Sage" refers to Yao and Shun. The principles expounded by the man from Jin are so vast and profound that even the deeds of Yao and Shun cannot compare.

Huizi said: "When one blows into a pipe, there is a deep sound; but when one blows across the ring of a sword, there is only a faint whistle. Yao and Shun are praised by men; yet to speak of Yao and Shun before Dai Jinren is like that faint whistle."

**[Annotation]** It is scarcely worth hearing.

**[Annotation]** *Xiao* is a deep sound; *xuè* is a faint one. Blowing into a bamboo pipe produces a deep sound, but blowing across a sword’s ring yields only a faint one. Yao of Tang is praised by the world, yet to extol such virtues before Jinren is no different from the faint whistle of a sword’s ring—scarcely worth hearing.

When Confucius traveled to Chu, he lodged at the home of a wine-seller by Ant Mound.

**[Annotation]** Ant Mound is the name of a mound. The wine-seller was a family that sold wine, and their home was at the foot of the mound, hence the name.

When Master Kong journeyed to Chu as an envoy, he rested by the roadside at the home of a wine-seller.

His neighbor had a household of husband, wife, servants, and concubines who climbed to the top of the mound. Zilu said: "What is this bustling crowd doing?"

**[Annotation]** *Ji* means high; *jiji* describes a throng. When Confucius traveled as an envoy, his disciples were many, and their horses and carriages made an imposing sight. Thus, the neighbors—men and women alike—gathered atop the wine-seller’s mound to watch Master Kong. Unfamiliar with them, Zilu asked in surprise.

Confucius said: "They are the servants of a sage."

**[Annotation]** In ancient times, virtuous gentlemen were all called sages, so Confucius referred to Yiliao of Shounan as a sage. He meant that the crowd of servants and concubines climbing the mound were the retainers of Yiliao of Shounan.

"He buries himself among the people,"

**[Annotation]** He lives as one with the common folk.

"and hides himself at the margins."

**[Annotation]** He does not seek glory in advancement nor wither in retreat.

**[Annotation]** He mingles with the dust and mud, living as one with the common people, concealing his virtue—thus, he buries himself among the people. Neither seeking glory in advancement nor withering in retreat, he hides himself at the margins.

"His fame fades,"

**[Annotation]** He diminishes his name.

"yet his aspirations are boundless,"

**[Annotation]** His plans are for life itself.

**[Annotation]** "Fame" refers to reputation; "fades" means to vanish. Unconcerned with honor or disgrace, he effaces his name. Immersed in the ultimate Dao, his heart is infinite.

"Though his mouth speaks, his heart never speaks,"

**[Annotation]** All his words are those of the world.

**[Annotation]** His mouth responds to the world, but his heart remains serene—thus, though he speaks, his heart does not.

"and though he lives among men, his heart disdains to join them."

**[Annotation]** He lives differently from the world.

**[Annotation]** His Dao is at odds with the俗, so he opposes the world. Free from worldly burdens, his heart does not align with others—both his actions and his heart are distinct.

"He is one who sinks on dry land,"

**[Annotation]** A hermit among men, like one who sinks without water.

**[Annotation]** Serene and detached, he is like one who sinks without water—this is called sinking on dry land.

Is this not the Market South’s Yi Liao?

**[Annotation]** His surname was Xiong, his courtesy name Yi Liao, and as he dwelt south of the market, he was called Market South Yi Liao.

Zilu requested to go and summon him.

**[Annotation]** You heard that Yi Liao, a worthy who sinks on dry land, was there, and asked to go to his dwelling to summon him.

Confucius said: "Enough.

**[Annotation]** *Yi* means "stop."

He will certainly not come—best to cease and not pursue it. He knows that I am aware of him,

**[Annotation]** *Zhuo* means "clear."

and knowing that I am bound for Chu, he takes it for certain that I will urge the King of Chu to summon him. Thus he will take me for a flatterer.

**[Annotation]** *Bi* refers to Yi Liao. *Zhuo* means "clear." He knows that I clearly recognize Yi Liao as a worthy who sinks on dry land, and that upon reaching Chu, I will surely recommend him to the king. If so, he will regard me as a sycophant.

One such as this would feel shame even to hear the words of a flatterer—how much more to meet him in person?

**[Annotation]** A man who sinks on dry land follows his nature with utter sincerity. To him, even hearing the words of a devious flatterer brings shame—how much more to see his person with his own eyes?

Then why assume he remains here?

**[Annotation]** Better to leave him be and follow his will.

**[Annotation]** *Er* means "you." *Cun* means "to be present." Long concealed in shadow and silent, he must have fled long ago—why do you still summon him as if he were here?

Zilu went to see, and his dwelling was empty.

**[Annotation]** He had indeed fled.

**[Annotation]** Zhong You lacked discernment and did not heed his master’s words. He went to Yi Liao’s home, hoping to behold such great virtue. But as his refusal of office was so resolute, Yi Liao had already fled, leaving his house vacant.

The Warden of Changwu asked Zilao: "When governing, do not act recklessly; when ordering the people, do not act carelessly."

**[Annotation]** *Lǔmǎng* and *mièliè* mean "rash and incomplete," failing to fulfill one’s proper role.

**[Annotation]** Changwu was a place named for its tall parasol trees. *Feng ren* refers to the warden who guarded its borders. Zilao was a disciple of Confucius, surnamed Qin, a minister of Song. *Wei zheng* means "to enact transformation." *Zhi min* means "to govern."

Rashness means acting without mindfulness. Carelessness means treating matters lightly. The people are the foundation of the state, and when the foundation is firm, the state is at peace. One must attend to nurturing the people with care and must not lightly disturb them. The Warden was a man of the Dao, and thus he admonished Zilao.

Formerly, when I cultivated grain, if I plowed rashly, the harvest repaid me with rashness; if I weeded carelessly, the harvest repaid me with carelessness.

**[Annotation]** *Wei he* means "to plant grain." *Yun* means "to pull weeds." If the plowing is shallow and the hoeing incomplete, when autumn comes, the fine grain will be sparse—all due to negligence, and thus the governance is repaid in kind.

The next year, I changed my methods, deepened the plowing, and tended the fields thoroughly.

**[Annotation]** Fulfilling one’s proper role to the utmost is the perfection of non-action.

The grain flourished and multiplied, and I was sated for the entire year.

**[Annotation]** *Bian* means "to change." *Geng* means "to cultivate." *Liang* means "to weed." Last year’s harvest was meager, and hunger prevailed. This year, I altered my methods and plowed deeply. With deep plowing and diligent hoeing, the grain stalks grew lush. The kernels ripened abundantly, and the year’s bounty was sufficient—thus it was fitting.

Zhuangzi heard of this and said: Nowadays, when people cultivate their bodies and order their minds, many resemble what the Warden described.

**[Annotation]** People of this age are frivolous and superficial, chasing after desires without rest. When it comes to ordering body and mind, they are like what the Warden spoke of.

Zhuang Zhou heard this and expounded upon it: They flee from Heaven, depart from their nature, extinguish their emotions, and lose their spirit—all for the sake of pursuing the many.

**[Annotation]** Fleeing, departing, extinguishing, and losing are all caused by pursuing the many. If each were to reach its extreme, where would there be rest?

**[Annotation]** To escape the principles of nature, scatter one’s pure and harmonious nature, extinguish one’s true emotions, and lose the way of nurturing the spirit—all this stems from chasing after what lies beyond one’s proper role and being entangled in action.

Thus, those who are rash with their nature give rise to the calamities of desire and aversion, which assail the nature like reeds.

**[Annotation]** Sparrows and reeds harm millet and sorghum; desires and aversions injure the true nature.

**[Annotation]** *Jiu wei* are reeds. The heart’s desires and aversions often breed misfortune. Just as reeds harm millet and sorghum, desires and aversions wound the true nature—all because of rashness and superficiality.

When the reeds first sprout, they may yet support my form.

**[Annotation]** When they spread and grow, the spirit and qi flow freely.

**[Annotation]** *Jian jia* are also reeds. When noxious weeds first sprout, they are easy to remove, but once they spread and grow lush, they inevitably harm the millet and sorghum. Likewise, when desires first arise, they are easy to restrain, but once one is submerged in them, vigilance must begin in the subtlest signs. Thus Laozi said, "Their ends are not easily planned."

They creep and uproot my nature.

**[Annotation]** Desires and aversions draw out the nature beyond its proper bounds.

**[Annotation]** *Xun* means "to draw." *Zhuo* means "to uproot." When desires and aversions entice the heart, they uproot the true nature, drawing it beyond its proper bounds.

They burst forth in sores and ulcers, indiscriminate in their eruption—boils, scabies, abscesses, internal heat, and turbid essence.

**[Annotation]** This is the retribution for rashness.

Thus, those who cultivate their nature must not fail to align with their proper measure.

**[Annotation]** *Kui lou* are cold sores. *Piao ju* are hot, toxic swellings. *Yong* are a type of abscess. *Sou gao* refers to turbid urine and seminal loss. Indulging in sensory pleasures and drowning in sights and sounds, the spirit becomes confused and the body weakened. Diseases erupt without regard for place.

Bo Ju studied under Lao Cong and said: I request to travel throughout the world.

**[Annotation]** Bo was his surname; Ju, his given name. A scholar who embraced the Dao, he was a disciple of Laozi. He requested to journey through the world to observe customs and examine the conditions of things.

Lao Cong said: Desist. The world is the same as this.

**[Annotation]** Laozi stopped him and refused his request, saying that the conditions of things in the world were no different from here.

He asked again, and Lao Cong said: Where will you begin?

**[Annotation]** With repeated and earnest requests, he persisted. Laozi then asked where he intended to go first.

He said: I will begin in Qi.

**[Annotation]** Bo Ju was from Lu, near Qi. The people of Qi were without the Dao, so he wished to go there first.

When he arrived in Qi, he saw a man who had been executed. He pushed and straightened the body, removed his court robes, and draped them over the corpse.

**[Annotation]** He traveled to Qi to observe its customs and suddenly saw a criminal who had been put to death. He pushed and straightened the body, then removed his court robes to cover it.

He cried out to Heaven and wept, saying: You! You! The world suffers great calamities, and you alone have been the first to encounter them. They say: Do not steal. Do not kill.

**[Annotation]** Killing is a great calamity—referring to the matters below. Since great calamities exist, even if one is warned not to do such things, how can they be avoided?

**[Annotation]** *Li* means "to encounter." *Zai* means "disaster." He cried out to Heaven, weeping in sorrow for the man’s unjust suffering, and thus repeated, "You! You!" Stealing and killing are great disasters in the world—why was this man the first to suffer them? The details of these great calamities are listed below.

**[Annotation]** Another interpretation: The so-called executed man was a court official. He was forcibly pushed to take the court robes, enmeshed in the net of the law to ensnare the people. Thus, he cried out to Heaven and wept, making clear that the disaster arose from this. The preemptive net is described below.

When honor and disgrace are established, one then sees what ails the world.

**[Annotation]** When each attains what is proper, there is no honor or disgrace. When gains and losses are in turmoil, honor and disgrace arise. Once honor and disgrace are established, one boasts of what is called disgrace and strives for what is called honor.

Amidst the scramble for vainglory, what else but affliction?
**[Annotation]** Chariots and caps mark honor; execution and shame mark disgrace. To scramble and grasp for these—what else but affliction?

Wealth and goods accumulate, then one sees what men contend for.
**[Annotation]** If contentment were deemed riches, what would there be to contend for?
**[Annotation]** Treasures pile up, and the race for them begins.

Now, to establish what afflicts men, to amass what they contend for, to exhaust and entrap their bodies without respite—can one hope to avoid reaching this state?
**[Annotation]** When superiors have their preferences, inferiors cannot remain at ease in their proper stations.
**[Annotation]** Rewarding with chariots and caps, enticing with pearls and jades, the masses are thus set into a ceaseless scramble. How then can each be made to abide in their proper station?

The rulers of old held that success lay with the people, and failure lay with themselves.
**[Annotation]** If the ruler committed no failure, the people would naturally succeed.
**[Annotation]** Attributing merit to others, they held that success lay with the people; bearing the inauspicious fate of the state, they held that failure lay with themselves.

They held that rectitude lay with the people, and crookedness lay with themselves.
**[Annotation]** If the ruler committed no crookedness, the people would naturally be rectified.
**[Annotation]** Governing through non-action and entrusting matters to things, rectitude lay with the people; drawing blame to themselves and taking responsibility, crookedness lay with themselves.

Thus, if any form lost its proper form, they would withdraw and take the blame upon themselves.
**[Annotation]** Why would the forms and natures of things be lost? All stem from the ruler’s interference, leading to such calamities—hence, they took the blame upon themselves.
**[Annotation]** Each person receives qi differently and is endowed with distinct capacities. If each were allowed to exercise their abilities, all things would find their proper place. If any being lost its place and its form and nature were harmed, they would draw the fault to themselves and withdraw to take responsibility. This was the way of Tang of Yin.

Now, it is not so.
**[Annotation]** The pace differs with the times, and the purity of the age has changed. Thus, those who drive things today no longer act in this manner.

They conceal the nature of things and delude the ignorant.
**[Annotation]** To return to one’s nature is concealment; to employ one’s nature is manifestation. Thus, when things are made manifest, all recognize them.
**[Annotation]** The laws and statutes they enact all run counter to the nature of things. They hide the names of offenses, leaving the foolish unaware—hence, the multitude of transgressions.

They make great difficulties and punish those who dare not comply.
**[Annotation]** When things are made easy, all dare to comply.
**[Annotation]** Since the laws are difficult to determine and hard to follow, those who inevitably violate them are punished.

They impose heavy burdens and penalize those who cannot bear them.
**[Annotation]** If the burdens were light, all could bear them.

They set distant paths and condemn those who do not arrive.
**[Annotation]** If the distance matched their strength, all would arrive.
**[Annotation]** To demand completion of heavy tasks from those of weak strength, or to punish those who arrive late when the journey is long and the deadline short—both are impossible.

When the people know their strength is exhausted, they resort to deceit to continue.
**[Annotation]** To evade punishment.
**[Annotation]** When wisdom and strength are exhausted yet punishment is unavoidable, fear of punishment drives them to resort to deceit.

Deceit emerges daily, so how can the officers and people not be deceitful?
**[Annotation]** When the ruler daily fosters deceit, how can the officers and people preserve their authenticity?
**[Annotation]** The wind of cunning and deceit arises daily, and falsehoods multiply like weeds—where then can one find truth?

When strength is insufficient, there is deceit; when knowledge is insufficient, there is fraud; when wealth is insufficient, there is theft. To whom can one justly assign blame for the acts of theft and fraud?
**[Annotation]** Blame lies with those above.
**[Annotation]** When wisdom and strength are exhausted, deceit and fraud inevitably arise; when taxes and levies grow ever more urgent, greed and theft inevitably follow. All stem from the ruler’s lack of virtue and the proliferation of laws. If one could forget attachments, relinquish self-interest, and not prize treasures, then blame would lie with those above—how could the common people be at fault?

Qu Boyu, at sixty years of age, underwent sixty transformations.
**[Annotation]** He was also able to follow the world without being bound by self and other.
**[Annotation]** His surname was Qu, given name Ai, courtesy name Boyu—a worthy minister of Wei. His abundant virtue and lofty wisdom illuminated the empty truths, enabling him to renew himself daily and change with each passing year.

Never did he not begin with what was deemed right only to end by condemning it as wrong.
**[Annotation]** Flowing with things and expanding freely, such are the changes in the sentiments of things.
**[Annotation]** At the start of the year, he called it right; by the year’s end, he called it wrong. Within a single year, right and wrong emerged in constant flux—thus, what was right at the beginning was ultimately condemned as wrong.

He did not know whether what is now deemed right is not the wrong of fifty-nine years past.
**[Annotation]** The changes in the sentiments of things have no end.
**[Annotation]** Thus, he transformed into the new and deemed it right; the old having passed, he deemed it wrong. Therefore, last year’s wrong became this year’s right, and this year’s right would become next year’s wrong. Those who cling to right and wrong, who stagnate in the new and cling to the old, are the ones who invert the proper order.

Thus, the Master of Rong Cheng said: "Remove the days, and there are no years." Qu Ai understood this, hence he transformed with things.

All things have life, yet none see their root; they emerge, yet none see their gate.
**[Annotation]** Without root or gate, suddenly and naturally arising—hence, none see them.

Only those who have no life and no emergence can perceive their gate and fathom their root.
**[Annotation]** They arise with change, their life without root or origin; they emerge with transformation, their emergence without gate or door. Since it is said there is no root or gate, it is known there is no life or emergence. If life and emergence have no gate, how can one model the years?

All men honor the knowledge of what they know, yet none know to rely on the knowledge of what they do not know before attaining knowledge—can this not be called great doubt?
**[Annotation]** What I do not know, there are those among things who know it. Thus, employing the knowledge of things, there is nothing one does not know.

Alone relying on my own knowledge, how meager is what I know! Now, if one does not rely on things to know yet exalts one’s own knowledge, then things will not inform me—how could this not be great doubt?

**[Annotation]** What is known is worldly knowledge; what is unknown is true knowledge. The common crowd all honors discriminating knowledge, sharpens their passions in grasping and rejecting, yet none can depend on their discriminating wisdom to illumine the true source—truly, they are people of great delusion. Enough! Enough! And nowhere to flee.

**[Commentary]** If one cannot employ that, then one’s body has no place to lodge.

**[Annotation]** *Yi* means "to cease." Those who sharpen their passions in grasping and rejecting would do better to rest; they will inevitably encounter misfortune, with no place to escape their form. Is this what is meant by "so it is" and "is it so"?

**[Commentary]** Those who claim it is so—yet the world does not agree.

**[Annotation]** Each affirms what they affirm, each approves what they approve; opposing one another, who is right and who is wrong?

Confucius questioned the Grand Scribe Da Tao, Bo Changqian, and Xi Wei:

**[Annotation]** *Taishi* is an official title. The three below are all names of scribal officials. The matters he questioned are listed in sequence below.

He said: "Duke Ling of Wei indulged in wine and drowned in pleasure, neglecting the governance of his state; he devoted himself to hunting and archery, ignoring the affairs of the feudal lords. For what reason was he called 'Ling'—the Illustrious Duke?"

**[Annotation]** *Bi* refers to a great net. *Yi* means shooting with an arrow tied to a cord. Such vulgar and reckless rulers indulge in lewd music and wine, hunt birds and beasts, neglect state governance, and fail to attend the assemblies and diplomatic exchanges of the feudal lords. You, as scribal officials, must determine their posthumous titles—how can one so devoid of the Way be called *Ling*—the Illustrious?

Da Tao replied: "It is so precisely because it is so."

**[Commentary]** *Ling* is the posthumous title for one without the Way.

**[Annotation]** According to the *Posthumous Titles* of the Duke of Zhou: "One who is chaotic yet unharmed is called *Ling*." *Ling* is thus the title for one without the Way. This is because his lack of the Way led to his being titled *Ling*—hence, "it is so precisely because it is so."

Bo Changqian said: "Duke Ling had three wives, with whom he bathed together in the same vessel."

**[Commentary]** Men and women bathing together—this is without propriety.

"Officer Shi Qiu presented himself for service, bearing the ritual gifts, and the Duke grasped the silk and supported him with his arms."

**[Commentary]** Using *qiu* (loach) as a skewer for the ritual gifts was a labor of service, so the Duke grasped the silk and supported him to prevent the completion of the ritual—this is why he was deemed respectful and virtuous. The *bi* (silk) were the gifts for the officer.

**[Annotation]** *Lan* refers to a bathing vessel. His surname was Shi, his given name Qiu—he was a worthy minister of Wei. *Bi* means silk. Furthermore, the *Posthumous Titles* states: "One whose virtue is keenly perceptive is called *Ling*." Though he allowed men and women to bathe together, he also presented worthy men for service. When the Duke saw that Shi Qiu was a good minister, he was deeply ashamed and remorseful. He sent someone to grasp the silk and support him with his arms, comforting and escorting him away to prevent the completion of the ritual. Such reverence for the worthy is the mark of an enlightened ruler—thus he was titled *Ling*, for *Ling* is the title for one with the Way. His negligence was extreme, yet his respect for the worthy was so solemn—this is why he was called Duke Ling.

**[Commentary]** He sought to use his reverence for the worthy to compensate for his private indulgences. *Ling* has two meanings, and cannot be called purely good—hence Confucius questioned it.

**[Annotation]** Though his impropriety in bathing with women was extreme, upon seeing a worthy man, he suddenly displayed solemn respect. This was taken as evidence of the Way, and so he was titled *Ling*.

Xi Wei said: "When Duke Ling died, divination for burial in the ancestral tomb was inauspicious, but divination for burial at Shaqiu was auspicious. After digging several *ren* deep, they found a stone outer coffin. Washing it and examining it, they saw an inscription that read: *‘Not relying on his son, Duke Ling will seize and bury him here.’* Duke Ling had been *Ling* for a long time indeed!"

**[Commentary]** *Son* refers to Kuai Kui. The inscription meant: *‘Not relying on his son, Duke Ling will seize this place from you.’* All things have their predetermined fate, so future events may be known. Thus, whatever one must do, one cannot but do; whatever one must not do, one cannot do. Yet fools believe it lies within their own power—is this not delusion? How could those two understand this?"

**[Commentary]** They merely recognized what had already come to pass, not that what had come to pass arose from spontaneity.

**[Annotation]** Shaqiu is a place name, located north of the Meng Ford of the Yellow River. *Son* refers to Kuai Kui. This is to clarify that posthumous titles are determined before any sign appears, not subject to the fluctuations of human sentiment. Thus, the stone outer coffin at Shaqiu bore its inscription beforehand. How could it rely on Kuai Kui before the Duke could seize the burial site? How could Shi and Changqian possibly comprehend this?

Lesser Knowledge asked Grand Master Tiao:

**[Annotation]** One whose wisdom is narrow and inferior is called *Lesser Knowledge*. *Grand* means great; *Master* means upright.

Grand Master Tiao embodied the vastness of the Dao and the greatness of virtue, impartial and selfless, further harmonizing and aligning all things—hence the name *Grand Master Tiao*. Here, a hypothetical interlocutor is introduced to discuss the principles of the Way.

The interlocutor asked: "What are the words of the village and hamlet?"

**[Annotation]** In ancient times, ten households formed a *qiu*, and twenty households a *li*. Customs differed between villages and hamlets, so this dialogue is posed to elucidate the matter.

Grand Master Tiao replied: "The words of the village and hamlet amalgamate the customs of ten clans and a hundred names."

**[Annotation]** Gathering the customs of ten clans and the names of a hundred individuals, they are synthesized to form a shared custom. This unites differences into sameness and disperses sameness into differences. Now, if one points to the hundred parts of a horse yet fails to grasp the horse itself, it is only when the horse stands before us, its hundred parts assembled, that we call it a horse.

**[Annotation]** Just as the words of the village and hamlet are gathered to form a custom—uniting differences into sameness—so too does one who teaches adapt to circumstances and guide beings, dispersing sameness into differences. It is like pointing to the hundred parts of a horse—head, tail, waist, and spine—none of which alone constitute the horse; this is dispersing sameness into differences. Yet when the horse stands tethered before us, this is uniting differences into sameness.

Thus, hills and mountains accumulate the lowly to become lofty; rivers and streams converge waters to become vast; the great person unites all to become impartial.

**[Annotation]** To be without self-interest in the world is to unify the customs of all under heaven.

**[Annotation]** Piling earth and stone forms hills and mountains; gathering rivulets creates rivers and seas. Likewise, the sage, without fixed intent, adapts teachings to beings, thereby uniting the eight directions, harmonizing all under heaven, so that Chinese and barbarians alike tread the same path, and near and far know no partiality.

Therefore, what enters from without has a master yet is not grasped;

**[Annotation]** *From without* means that the sage’s teachings enter from outside and emerge from within, following the inclinations of beings. Thus, though presiding as master, there is nothing held fast.

what issues from within has rectitude yet is not resisted.

**[Annotation]** What enters from without is the transformation wrought by the great person; what issues from within is the nature of beings and things. Each nature attains its proper state, so the people do not act contrary to their hearts. Transformation is utterly impartial, so the master holds nothing fast. Thus, villages and hamlets are united with all under heaven, the myriad things are made one, and all differences are leveled.

**[Annotation]** *From within* also means that the black-haired people and all beings possess their proper natures. Following their hearts, they receive the imperial wind, and since it accords with their inclinations, they comply without resistance.

The four seasons have distinct qi, yet Heaven does not bestow them, and so the year is complete;

**[Annotation]** The distinct qi arise of themselves; thus, they endure perpetually. If they were bestowed by Heaven yet originally absent, they would at times cease.

**[Annotation]** *Bestow* means to grant. Spring’s warmth, summer’s heat, autumn’s coolness, and winter’s cold arise from nature, so the year’s sequence is complete. If it were as though Heaven granted them, they would at times cease.

The five offices have distinct duties, yet the ruler does not favor them, and so the state is well-governed;

**[Annotation]** The distinct duties arise from their inherent capacities; thus, they are entrusted with them, not favored by partiality.

**[Annotation]** The *five offices* refer to the ancient system of establishing offices based on the five phases. The spring and autumn offices each have their responsibilities. The ruler, in profound stillness, entrusts them without partiality, so the realm within the four seas is clear and tranquil, and the state is at peace.

The civil and martial virtues of the great person are not bestowed, and so their power is complete;

**[Annotation]** The civil is inherently civil, the martial inherently martial; they are not bestowed by the great person. If they were granted and thus capable, they would at times be lacking. This is not only true of civil and martial virtues—all natures are thus.

**[Annotation]** Civil ministers and martial generals are appointed according to their talents and entrusted with their duties; they are not granted by the sage. Impartial toward all things, the Dao and its power are thus perfectly complete.

The myriad things have distinct principles, yet the Dao is not partial, and so it is nameless.

**[Annotation]** The multitude of beings differ, each following its distinct nature—some dwell in nests, others in caves; some walk the earth, others fly through the sky. Yet nurturing and poisoning them, all attain self-sufficiency. Each thing fulfills its principle, so the Dao has no merit.

Nameless, it is without action; without action, yet there is nothing it does not do.

**[Annotation]** Names are limited by reality, so it is without action; realities act of themselves, so there is nothing it does not do.

**[Annotation]** Merit returns to things, so it is called *without action*; not clinging to this action, yet there is nothing it does not do.

Time has its endings and beginnings; the world undergoes transformations.

**[Annotation]** Thus, those without fixed intent follow along.

**[Annotation]** *Time* refers to the four seasons cycling in succession. *World* refers to human affairs, shifting and changing without constancy.

Fortune and misfortune flow ceaselessly;

**[Annotation]** Flowing and reversing.

**[Annotation]** *Flowing ceaselessly* describes their movement. The qi of Heaven’s seasons—cold and heat—pass and do not remain constant. Human fortunes and misfortunes—how could they long endure? Thus, the *Laozi* states: "Misfortune is where fortune leans; fortune is where misfortune lurks."

There are times when what seems contrary is fitting;

**[Annotation]** What is perverse here may be fitting there.

**[Annotation]** *Contrary* means perverse. The inclinations of beings have no fixed standard. What is perverse here may be fitting there, so those who comprehend the Dao do not cling to opposition or compliance.

Each clings to its own perspective;

**[Annotation]** Each trusts in what it deems right and cannot depart from it.

**[Annotation]** *Clings* means pursues. *Perspective* means orientation. With right and wrong entangled, each clings to its own view, so their orientations differ.

where there is rectitude, there is also deviation.

**[Annotation]** What is rectified here may deviate there.

**[Annotation]** What is rectified here may be deviant there. This clarifies that the inclinations of beings are inverted, differing in orientation.

Compared to a great marsh, all its hundred materials are measured;

**[Annotation]** No timber is discarded.

**[Annotation]** *Compared* means likened. *Measured* means assessed. In a vast marsh, the forests are abundant. Each timber is assessed for its use—none is discarded.

The great person selects things in the same way. Observe the great mountain: trees and stones share the same foundation.

**[Annotation]** Uniting the different as one.

**[Annotation]** *Foundation* means base. Stones may be large or small, trees coarse or fine, yet together they form the mountain’s base—this is uniting the different as one. This is called the discourse of the village.

**[Annotation]** If it holds true in a village, it may be known throughout the world.

**[Annotation]** This summarizes the preceding meaning.

Lesser Knowledge said: Then is calling it the *Dao* sufficient?

**[Annotation]** To name it the *Dao*—does this name for the *Dao* fall short of the principle? Desiring to clarify that the supreme *Dao* is nameless, he raises this question.

Grand Duke Diao said: Not so. Now, the count of things does not stop at ten thousand, yet we call them the "ten thousand things" because we name and refer to them by their greatest number.

**[Annotation]** Things with number do not stop at ten thousand—how much less can the numberless *Dao* be deemed sufficient?

**[Annotation]** *Limit* means boundary. *Name* means to speak. Things with form are boundless, yet when people speak of them, they limit them to "ten thousand things," taking the greatest measure as their term. It is like the subtle principle of the empty *Dao*, which is originally nameless; by its function, we forcibly name it the *Dao*, yet the name falls short of the principle.

Thus, heaven and earth are the greatest of forms; yin and yang are the greatest of *qi*; the *Dao* is their commonality.

**[Annotation]** Things are made to flow freely; what flows freely through things is without partiality, and so we forcibly call it the *Dao*.

**[Annotation]** Heaven covers and earth bears; yin and yang engender and nurture—thus, they are the greatest among forms and *qi*. The *Dao* of heaven can flow through the ten thousand things, sustaining and nourishing all life, bestowing transformation without partiality—thus, it is called the common.

To name and refer to it by its greatness is permissible,

**[Annotation]** What is called the *Dao* that can be spoken of.

**[Annotation]** The great *Dao* flows through things, giving life and transforming the myriad beings. Speaking of its origin, it is truly nameless; by its function, naming it is permissible.

but once it has a name, can it still be compared? Once a name exists, how can it be likened to what is nameless?

**[Annotation]** The name already exists—how then can it be compared to what admits no comparison?

**[Annotation]** By its function, the name *Dao* already exists; one cannot compare this named thing to the principle of the nameless. In such comparison, the distance grows vast.

Thus, to debate it in this way is like comparing dogs and horses—it falls far short.

**[Annotation]** The debate of names does not reach far; thus, the *Dao* is still deemed insufficient. It must reside in the realm of the nameless and wordless to attain it. Though it has a name, nothing can compare to it.

**[Annotation]** To compare it solely to a single beast like a dog or horse is not only to differ in size but also to distinguish in worth. Now, to compare the named *Dao* to the nameless principle is not only to differ in refinement and coarseness but also to diverge in depth—thus, it falls far short.

Lesser Knowledge said: Within the four directions, encompassing the six directions, from whence do the ten thousand things arise?

**[Annotation]** This question implies that the *Dao* is capable of generating them.

**[Annotation]** Within the six directions, between heaven and earth, from where do the myriad beings—both moving and still—arise? Lesser Knowledge raises this question to discern their origin.

Grand Duke Diao said: Yin and yang illuminate and cover each other, govern each other; the four seasons replace, engender, and destroy each other.

**[Annotation]** All this occurs of itself, not from nothing.

**[Annotation]** The three luminaries illuminate one another, the two forces cover each other, wind and rain govern each other, heat and cold replace each other, spring and summer engender, autumn and winter destroy—how does this relate to intention? It is the natural principle of things.

Desire and aversion, approach and withdrawal arise from this; the union of female and male is ever thus.

**[Annotation]** All these affairs—movement and rest, advance and retreat—ultimately arise from the mutual illumination of yin and yang and the replacement of the four seasons.

**[Annotation]** *Arise* describes the emergence. *Ever* means constant. When things are favorable, they approach with desire; when adverse, they withdraw with aversion. Beings within the transformations of yin and yang harbor such intentions, opening and closing, uniting and parting—this is their constant way.

Safety and danger alternate, fortune and misfortune engender each other, urgency and ease rub against each other, gathering and scattering complete the process.

**[Annotation]** When encountering prosperity, there is safety; when meeting adversity, there is danger. Danger becomes misfortune, safety becomes fortune. Ease brings longevity, urgency brings early death. Scattering leads to death, gathering leads to life. All these outcomes arise from the mutual friction of creation—like the four seasons changing and transforming, how do they relate to intention?

These are the names and realities that can be recorded, the essences that can be noted.

**[Annotation]** Beyond this lies the natural. As for the causes of the natural, who knows their origin?

**[Annotation]** *Noted* means recorded. Within yin and yang, between heaven and earth, there are realities and names—thus, they can be outlined and recorded. Even if subtle, they can still be spoken of and noted. But when it comes to the profound and wondrous principle, transcending form and name, it cannot be sought through words or images.

Following the sequence of their mutual ordering, the arising of their mutual employment, exhaustion returns to the beginning, the end returns to the start. These are the properties of things.

**[Annotation]** All are the properties of things, occurring naturally—not that anything is capable of making them so.

**[Annotation]** The four seasons cycle, mutually ordering one another; the five phases move, driving one another in turn. When things reach their limit, they return; when they end, they begin anew. The properties of things are exhausted in this.

What words can express, what knowledge can reach, extends only to the limits of things.
