**[Annotation]** Beyond things, nothing more exists—thus, words and knowledge do not surpass the limits of things.

**[Annotation]** The true principle is profound and wondrous, beyond words and knowledge.

If one relies on verbal explanation, employs knowledge, or engages in thought, the Dao may be exhausted only in the realm of existing things, yet it fundamentally cannot reach the boundless and profound境. Those who perceive the Dao do not follow what ceases nor trace what arises.

**[Annotation]** Arising and ceasing occur of themselves—nothing is to be traced or followed.

This is where discussion must halt.

**[Annotation]** Since all is self-so, there is nothing left to discuss.

**[Annotation]** *睹* means "to see." *随* means "to pursue." Those who perceive the Dao—persons of profound awakening—concentrate their spirit beyond things, silently illuminating the center of all. They embody the ten thousand conditions as boundless, the four kinds of life as non-existent. How could they cling to things or trace the origins of arising and ceasing? This is what is meant by "words fail at the Dao" and "discussion comes to rest."

The Lesser Knower said: Jizhen’s "non-action" and Jiezi’s "occasional agency"—which of these two doctrines aligns with true nature, and which is partial in its principle?

**[Annotation]** Jizhen said: "The Dao does nothing." Jiezi said: "The Dao occasionally acts." "Occasional agency" means it has the power to move things.

**[Annotation]** Jizhen and Jiezi were both worthy men of Qi who frequented the Jixia Academy. The passage invokes these two worthies to clarify the principle. *莫* means "none." *使* means "to act." Jizhen took non-action as the Dao, while Jiezi held that the Dao has the power to act upon things. Each adhered to one side, neither offering a comprehensive account. The Lesser Knower now raises this question to determine which is correct or flawed in relation to pure nature and the wondrous principle.

Taigong Tiao said: The crowing of roosters and the barking of dogs are what people know. Yet even one of great knowledge cannot describe in words how they transform of themselves, nor can they anticipate in thought what they will do next.

**[Annotation]** Things have their own nature—this is not something agency can achieve.

From this perspective, Jizhen’s words are correct.

**[Annotation]** What the eye sees and the ear hears—roosters crowing and dogs barking—arise from the transformations of creation, known equally by the foolish and the wise. Thus, even the greatest sages and most profound knowers cannot fathom in thought what they do, nor can they describe in words how they come to be. Their crowing and barking occur naturally—how could the Dao have made them so? Knowing this, Jiezi’s words do not accord with principle.

Analyzing this further: refinement reaches the point of having no peer, and greatness reaches the point of being unencompassable.

**[Annotation]** All occur not through agency but of themselves.

**[Annotation]** Even if one takes the most refined things—those without pattern or order—and the coarsest things—those too vast to measure—and analyzes them through this principle, not a single phenomenon fails to be a spontaneous transformation.

"Occasional agency" and "non-action" remain bound to things and ultimately become errors.

**[Annotation]** Things have their mutual agency, yet all occur of themselves. Thus, "non-action" is not separate from things.

All things, in their manifold forms, pass away through non-action.

**[Annotation]** Not aligning with the Dao, they remain bound to things; clinging to one side, they ultimately become afflictions.

"Occasional agency" is substantive.

**[Annotation]** It acts of itself.

**[Annotation]** It clings to action.

"Non-action" is empty.

**[Annotation]** It does not act.

**[Annotation]** It is submerged in nothingness.

Having name and reality is where things reside.

**[Annotation]** This refers to the locus of name and reality.

Having no name and no reality is the emptiness within things.

**[Annotation]** Where things reside, their reality is utterly empty.

**[Annotation]** If one’s nature clings to existence, then wherever one is becomes a thing. If one’s nature embraces nothingness, then wherever one is becomes emptiness. Thus, existence and nothingness lie in the mind, not in the external world.

What can be spoken or conceived—speaking of it only increases its distance.

**[Annotation]** Therefore, one must seek it beyond words and thoughts to reach it.

**[Annotation]** What can be explained in words or grasped in thought grows ever more distant from the Dao. Thus, one must seek it beyond words and thoughts to reach it.

What has not yet arisen cannot be prevented.

**[Annotation]** It arises suddenly of itself—control does not lie with me, and I cannot forbid it.

What has already died cannot be obstructed.

**[Annotation]** It dies suddenly of itself—I cannot oppose it.

**[Annotation]** *忌* means "to forbid." *阻* means "to hinder." It arises suddenly—one cannot forbid it. It dies suddenly—what obstruction can there be? One should simply follow change and yield to transformation, finding peace wherever one is. *阻* may also be written as *沮*, meaning "resentment." Dying in accord with the natural order, one does not resent loss.

Death and life are not distant—their principle cannot be seen.

**[Annotation]** They are near, within the body, yet one cannot see their self-so nature and thus desires to grieve over them.

**[Annotation]** The gathering and dispersal of toil and rest occur within a single body. Their principle is obscure and dark—foolish people do not see it.

"Occasional agency" and "non-action" are the assumptions of doubt.

**[Annotation]** These two are what the world most doubts.

**[Annotation]** The dual attachments to existence and nothingness do not reside in the minds of those who have attained. Only those of doubtful nature, clinging to one side, engage in such discussions.

Observing its root, its going has no end. Seeking its end, its coming has no limit. Without end and without limit—words are exhausted, yet it shares the same principle as things.

**[Annotation]** The principle of things is boundless; thus, knowing that words are boundless, one then shares the same principle as things.

**[Annotation]** The root is the past. The end is the future. The past has gone, and transformations are endless—one cannot fathom their origin or grasp them in thought. Even if one were to expound at length on nothingness, clinging to one side, one would remain bound to things. Thus, it shares the same principle as things.

"Occasional agency" and "non-action" are the root of words, and they share the same beginning and end as things.

**[Annotation]** It is always non-action that makes things act of themselves.

**[Annotation]** *本* means "beginning." Those who cling to one side as the root remain bound to beginnings and ends, sharing the same start as things. Thus, they depart from things.

The Dao cannot be possessed as "having," nor can "having" be devoid of it.

**[Annotation]** The Dao cannot make things "have," yet what has existence is always self-so.

**[Annotation]** The supreme Dao is unceasing, neither having nor lacking. Thus, to cling to either "having" or "lacking" is equally inadmissible.

The name "Dao" is a borrowed term for its functioning.

**[Annotation]** It is that by which things proceed, hence the borrowed name "Dao."

**[Annotation]** The Dao is vast and nameless; "Dao" is a forced designation. This borrowed name and teaching are set in motion to enact it.

"Occasional agency" and "non-action" are but one corner of things—how could they suffice for the great Dao?

**[Annotation]** From one corner, the rest may be inferred.

**[Annotation]** *Hu* means "how." *Fang* means "Dao." "Occasional agency" and "non-action" have not yet ascended to the realm of emptiness and subtlety; they remain but one thing among the vulgar, a partial and biased view. How could such a person attain the profound mystery or speak of the great Dao?

If words sufficed, then speaking all day would exhaust the Dao.

**[Annotation]** To seek the Dao beyond words and meaning is sufficient.

If words did not suffice, then speaking all day would exhaust only things.

**[Annotation]** To be unable to forget words and preserve meaning is insufficient.

**[Annotation]** *Zu* means "complete and all-pervading." *Buzu* means "partial and obstructed." If one can forget words and grasp the principle, then speech is as though unspoken, fully aligning with the mysterious Dao. But if one clings to words without fathoming the principle, one strays from the Dao of emptiness and penetration, exhausting only obstructed things.

The Dao is the ultimate of things; neither speech nor silence can bear its weight.

**[Annotation]** The Dao of heaven is the ultimate of things, always self-so without agency, neither in speech nor in silence.

**[Annotation]** At the ultimate of Dao and things, it is neither Dao nor thing; thus, neither speech nor silence can fully bear it.

Beyond speech, beyond silence—discourse has its limits.

**[Annotation]** Its limit lies in self-so, not in speech or silence to discuss it.

**[Annotation]** Silence is not silence; discourse is not discourse. Only by seeking beyond the four propositions can one enter the gate of manifold mysteries.

*Commentary and Annotations on the True Scripture of Nanhua, Scroll Twenty-Seven, Concluded*

**Scroll Twenty-Eight of the *Annotations and Commentaries on the True Scripture of Nanhua***
*Guo Xiang of Henan, Annotator*
*Master Cheng Xuanying of the Western Flower [Monastery] of the Tang, Commentator*

**Miscellaneous Chapters: External Things, Twenty-Six**

External things cannot be made certain.
**[Commentary]** Those who fix their minds with obstinacy deem things certain.
Human affairs and external things are tangled in myriad threads; only by abiding in the great compliance can one achieve emptiness and penetration wherever one goes. If one opposes things with clinging attachment, one will inevitably encounter calamity.
Thus, Long Feng was executed, Bi Gan was slain, Jizi feigned madness, Elai perished, and Jie and Zhou met their ruin.
**[Annotation]** Both good and evil in their governance cannot be made certain.
**[Commentary]** Long Feng and Bi Gan have already been explained in the *Outer Chapters*.
Jizi was the younger uncle of King Zhou of Yin. When his loyal remonstrance went unheeded, he feared Zhou’s harm and feigned madness, yet in the end, he could not escape execution.
Elai was Zhou’s sycophantic minister, who devoted himself entirely to Zhou and thus perished with him.
No ruler fails to desire loyalty from their ministers, yet loyalty is not necessarily trusted. Thus, Wu Yun was cast into the river, and Chang Hong died in Shu, his blood preserved for three years before transforming into jade.
**[Annotation]** The utmost of sincerity.
**[Commentary]** Jade is a precious stone.
Zixu and Chang Hong have already been expounded in the *Outer Chapters*.
As for being "cast into the river," Wu Yun remonstrated with Fuchai, who killed him, flayed his skin to make a bag shaped like an owl, filled it with Zixu’s corpse, and set it afloat on the river—hence, "cast into the river."
Chang Hong, slandered and exiled to Shu, resented his loyalty being met with slander, so he disemboweled himself and died. The people of Shu, moved by his devotion, preserved his blood in a casket, and after three years, it transformed into jade—a testament to the utmost of sincerity.
No parent fails to desire filial piety from their children, yet filial piety is not necessarily cherished. Thus, Xiaoji grieved, and Zeng Shen sorrowed.
**[Annotation]** Therefore, the perfected person responds to things without preconceived intent, adapting only to what is fitting.
**[Commentary]** Xiaoji was the son of Gaozong of Yin. He suffered at the hands of his stepmother and died of sorrow.
Zeng Shen was supremely filial, yet his parents despised him, often beating him nearly to death—hence his weeping.
The bond between parent and child is of heavenly nature, and the duty between ruler and minister is of grave weight. Yet even the utmost loyalty and filial piety may not be loved or understood—how much less can the myriad paths of worldly affairs be made certain?
One should only hold loyalty in the heart, harmonizing self and other, to preserve the body and distance oneself from harm.

When wood rubs against wood, it ignites; when metal is kept near fire, it melts.
**[Commentary]** Wood generates fire, and fire overcomes metal—this is the natural principle of the five phases. Thus, when wood is rubbed against wood, fire is born; when metal is guarded by fire, it melts. Therefore, those who cling obstinately to external things with sincere fixation will meet with the ruin of melting away.
When yin and yang move in disorder, heaven and earth are greatly shaken. Then there are thunder and lightning, fire within water, and the great locust tree is burned.
**[Annotation]** This is what is meant by "moving in disorder."
**[Commentary]** Fire within water is lightning. The burning of the great locust tree is the strike of thunderbolts. When yin and yang are in chaos, defying the five phases, thunder and lightning erupt in fury, startling the myriad things. When people deviate from harmonious qi, their ruin follows likewise.

Excessive sorrow traps one in a double predicament with no escape.
**[Annotation]** If one cannot forget form, one will be ensnared by joy and sorrow wherever form leads, with no fitting course left or right.
**[Commentary]** Unable to empty the mind and forget form, one’s heart becomes obstinate and fixed. Thus, one’s emotions race between the two realms of honor and disgrace, sinking into the dual snares of sorrow and joy, with no refuge from form.

The *chen* and *dun* cannot be completed.
**[Annotation]** The more one clings, the greater the difficulty in every situation, and one knows not where to stand—hence, they cannot be completed.
**[Commentary]** *Chen* and *dun* mean trepidation. Unable to forget emotions and relinquish attachment, one exhausts the body with anxiety and care, yet ultimately achieves nothing.

If the heart hangs suspended between heaven and earth,
**[Annotation]** What it aspires to is lofty and vast.
**[Commentary]** When the heart pursues worldly affairs, it becomes lofty and distant, racing after things and traversing the cosmos.
It is restless and sunk in gloom,
**[Annotation]** Not level, peaceful, and smooth.
**[Commentary]** When desires are fulfilled, one is consoled; when they are thwarted, one is benighted and oppressed. Encountering circumstances, one sinks into them; touching things, one is obstructed. Since this is not clarity and peace, how can it be level and smooth?

When profit and harm grind against each other, they generate abundant fire.
**[Annotation]** This is due to internal heat.
**[Commentary]** Where there is profit, there is harm—like the cicada and the magpie. Entangled between profit and harm, the heart within is constantly heated, generating fire in abundance.
The harmony of the multitude is burned.
**[Annotation]** When the multitude forgets profit, there is harmony; if profit and harm linger in the heart, their harmony is burned.
**[Commentary]** *Burned* means scorched. The multitude refers to the common people, who cannot abide in their allotted place without action but instead race after profit and harm. Their internal heat is like fire, scorching the flame of their harmonious nature.
The moon is surely no match for fire.
**[Annotation]** What is great and dim is burdened by many encumbrances; what is small and bright knows its place.

**[Commentary]** Though the moon is vast and its light full, though fire is small it shines brightly. This illustrates how one with grand ambitions and many desires is not equal to one who humbly guards their allotted place. Thus there comes a state of *tuìrán* where the Dao is exhausted.

**[Annotation]** Only in *tuìrán*—free from self-importance, forgetting the body and attaining self-mastery—does the Dao reach its fullness.

**[Commentary]** *Tuìrán* describes a bearing of ease and unconcern. When one forgets profit and harm, remains indifferent and unassuming, the profound principles of the Dao are fully realized in this.

Zhuang Zhou, being poor, went to borrow grain from the Marquis of the River.

**[Commentary]** The Marquis of the River was Duke Wen of Wei. Zhuangzi, lofty and pure, did not engage in worldly affairs, and as his family was impoverished, he came to borrow grain. The Marquis said, "Very well. When I receive the taxes from my fief, I will lend you three hundred pieces of gold—will that suffice?"

**[Commentary]** *Nuò* means assent. Copper and iron were also called *jin*; this was not gold. He would wait until year’s end, when he collected the people’s taxes and the tribute from his fief, before lending it.

Zhuang Zhou, his face flushed with anger, replied, "On my way here yesterday, I heard someone calling from the road. I looked and saw a carp in the rut of a wagon wheel. I asked it, ‘Carp, what are you doing here?’ It answered, ‘I am a wave-minister of the Eastern Sea. Might you have a dou or sheng of water to keep me alive?’"

**[Commentary]** A wave-minister, a small servant of the tides, trapped in a wheel rut—could you spare some water to save me?

"I said, ‘Very well. I am about to travel south to persuade the kings of Wu and Yue to dam the Western River and bring its waters to meet you—will that do?’"

**[Commentary]** The Western River is the Shu River. Though many rivers flow north, only the Shu River comes from the west, hence it is called the Western River.

The carp, its face flushed with anger, replied, "I have lost my usual element and have nowhere to dwell. A dou or sheng of water would suffice to keep me alive, yet you speak of this! You would do better to seek me now in the market of dried fish."

**[Annotation]** This shows that what accords with principle need not be grand; if it does not, even the grand is of no use.

**[Commentary]** *Suǒ* means to seek; *sì* means market. A carp accustomed to the sea, now deprived of its usual home, could be saved by a mere dou or sheng of water—yet you speak of damming the Western River, which is no help at all. If you cannot save me even for a moment, you might as well find me in the dried-fish market. This illustrates that matters, great or small, depend on timeliness and appropriateness; if they do not meet the moment, even the grand is of no use.

Lord Ren of Ren made a great hook with a thick black rope, using fifty castrated oxen as bait.

**[Commentary]** Ren was the name of a state; this was a lord of Ren. *Jù* means great; *zī* means black rope; *jiè* means castrated ox; *ěr* means the meat on a hook. Having made a great hook, he used a thick rope and hung fifty oxen as bait.

He squatted on Mount Kuaiji and cast his line into the Eastern Sea.

**[Commentary]** Though he made a great hook, a year passed without catching a fish. *Dūn* means to crouch; *jù* means to sit, perched on the mountain. He fished day after day, yet after a year had caught nothing. Then a great fish took the bait, dragging the huge hook down, plunging deep and thrashing its fins, raising waves like mountains. The sea churned violently, its roar matching that of ghosts and spirits, its dreadful power extending a thousand *li*.

**[Commentary]** After a year, a great fish swallowed the hook. It pulled the hook down, plunging in alarm, thrashing its head and tail, flaring its scales and fins, raising white waves like mountains, vast enough to touch the sun.

Lord Ren caught this fish, cut it into strips, and dried it. From the Zhe River eastward and from Cangwu northward, there was none who did not feast on this fish.

**[Commentary]** This fish was a sea spirit. The Zhe is the Zhe River. Cangwu is a mountain in the far south, where Shun was buried. The sea spirit’s flesh was abundant, and when dried into jerky, it fed all from the Five Ridges northward and the Three Xiang eastward.

Yet later, those of shallow talent and glib speech were all astonished and spread the news.

**[Commentary]** In the declining years of the age, those with frivolous minds and shallow learning, who recited words without embracing the profound Dao, heard of the great fish and were amazed, telling one another. Some texts write *quǎn* (shallow) as *quán* (measured). *Quán* means limited.

For one who lifts a slender pole and hurries to irrigation ditches, guarding minnows and carp, catching a great fish is difficult indeed.

**[Commentary]** *Lěi* means a thin rope; *ní* and *fù* are small fish. Carrying a slender pole and hurrying to irrigation channels, one may catch minnows and carp, but catching a great fish is difficult.

For one who adorns trivial words to seek lofty office, attaining great understanding is also far off.

**[Commentary]** *Gān* means to seek; *xiàn* means high. Those who cultivate minor conduct and pride themselves on their words, seeking high reputation and fame, will never fully grasp the supreme Dao. Some texts write *xiàn* (high) without the heart radical, as the ancient character for *xuán* (suspended) often omitted it.

Thus, those who have never heard of the customs of the Ren clan cannot govern the world, for they are far from it.

**[Annotation]** This shows that as aspirations differ, so too do the means of governing the world—great and small each have their proper place.

**[Commentary]** The ways of the human world are ever-changing, now level, now perilous. Without a mind vast and empty, one cannot navigate order and chaos. Those who pride themselves on reputation and adorn their conduct are far from it.

The Confucians used *Odes* and *Rites* to rob graves. A great Confucian announced, "The east is stirring—how goes the matter?"

**[Commentary]** A great Confucian, a learned scholar, refers to a senior academician. *Lú* means to transmit words from above to below; *chuán* means to pass on. "The east is stirring" means dawn is breaking, urging them to rise. The Confucian disciples, robbing graves as thieves, feared the coming light and hurriedly asked how the matter was proceeding.

A lesser Confucian replied, "The skirt and jacket are not yet untied—there is a pearl in the mouth."

The lesser Confucian was a disciple. The dead man’s skirt and jacket had not yet been untied; feeling inside his mouth, they knew there was a precious pearl. The *Odes* indeed contains this verse: “The green, green wheat grows on the hillside slope. While living, he gave no alms—why part with the pearl in death?” **[Commentary]** This is a lost poem, long since excised. Noblemen were often buried with pearls in their mouths, so the verse “The green, green wheat” was recited to mock them. Seizing his temples, pressing his cheeks, the Confucians used a metal mallet to strike his jaw, carefully prying apart his cheeks to avoid damaging the pearl within.

**[Annotation]** *Odes* and *Rites* are the vestiges of the former kings. If the person is unworthy, the Dao cannot operate in vain. Thus, even Confucians may use them for villainy, proving that vestiges cannot be relied upon.

**[Commentary]** *Jiē* means to grasp; *yè* means to press; *huì* means the mouth; *kòng* means to strike. Grasping his temples and striking his mouth with an iron mallet, they feared harming the pearl, so they gently separated his cheeks. Thus, Tian Heng exploited benevolence and righteousness to usurp power, while the Confucian scholars recited *Odes* and *Rites* to rob graves. From this, we see that the sagely vestiges cannot be trusted.

The disciple of Lao Laizi went out to gather firewood and encountered Confucius. Returning, he reported to his master, **[Commentary]** Lao Laizi was a worthy recluse of Chu, who often lived in seclusion on Mount Meng. The King of Chu, knowing his worth, sent envoys to summon him as minister. His wife, returning from gathering firewood, saw carriage tracks before their door. Asking the reason, Lao Laizi said, “The King of Chu has summoned me as minister.” His wife replied, “Those who accept from others must be controlled by them. You cannot control others.” She then left him. Lao Laizi followed, carrying his wife on his back, and fled south of the Yangtze, where none knew their whereabouts. The one who went out for firewood was gathering kindling. After seeing Confucius, he returned to inform his master.

**[Commentary]** “There is a man over there, tall above and short below, his shoulders hunched and his ears set back, his gaze as if managing the Four Seas. I do not know whose son he is.” **[Annotation]** Tall above and short below. His ears were set back and sloped upward. His gaze was vacant, as if managing others’ affairs.

**[Commentary]** *Xiū* means tall; *qū* means short; *mò* means the shoulders. The man he saw was tall above and short below, his shoulders hunched, his ears set back, his gaze lofty and distant, his demeanor hurried, as if managing the world. Unsure of his lineage, the disciple asked out of curiosity.

Lao Laizi said, “That is Qiu. Summon him.” **[Commentary]** Qiu is Kong Qiu of Lu; you should call him here.

Confucius arrived. Lao Laizi said, “Qiu, discard your bodily pride and your cultivated wisdom—only then can you be a gentleman.” **[Annotation]** This means Confucius could abandon form and forsake knowledge, thus becoming a gentleman.

**[Commentary]** *Gōng* means the body. When Confucius arrived, Lao Laizi spoke first, urging him to cast off bodily adornment and forget cultivated wisdom—only then could he be a gentleman.

Confucius bowed and withdrew, **[Annotation]** accepting his words.

**[Commentary]** Respectfully receiving his teaching, he bowed and retreated. With a startled expression, he changed his countenance and asked, “Can my work be advanced?” **[Annotation]** He posed the question to make Lao Laizi clarify that it could not be advanced.

**[Commentary]** *Cùrán* means a startled appearance. Confucius asked whether the work of sagely vestiges and conduct could be cultivated and put to use in the world.

Lao Laizi said, “To spare the harm of one age but alarm the calamities of ten thousand ages—**[Annotation]** If one acts for one age, the vestiges will bring calamity for ten thousand ages, so it cannot be taken lightly.

**[Commentary]** Sagely wisdom and benevolence save the harm of one age, but when later generations grasp them for villainy, they become the disasters of ten thousand ages. Those who arrogantly rely on sagely vestiges are like Tian Heng. Some interpret *jīng* as “to cause,” meaning to make later generations ceaselessly pursue them—also implying the meaning of relentless striving—if you stubbornly cling to poverty and lowliness, **[Commentary]** Stubbornly adhering to sagely vestiges, manipulating them at will, and straying from one’s original nature leads to poverty and distress. Have you lost your strategy and fallen short? **[Annotation]** If one simply follows them, the people’s nature will not be violated, and there will be no affairs beyond their reach.

**[Commentary]** Losing one’s original nature and neglecting the boundaries of life, one falls short of the true Dao. Kindness that delights in arrogance is a lifelong disgrace. **[Annotation]** Those who are kind and delighted are unkind when not delighted. Yet kindness cannot last forever, so a single act of kindness becomes a lifelong disgrace.

**[Commentary]** Those who take delight in kindness cannot extend it universally, so arrogance and disdain abound. Thus, using kindness to win people only breeds resentment, resulting in lifelong disgrace. The conduct of the common people may be advanced, **[Annotation]** If it is easy to advance, one must not forget kindness.

They attract one another with fame and bind one another with concealment. **[Annotation]** *Yǐn* means to gather; this refers to advancement.

**[Commentary]** The natures of the supremely wise and the utterly foolish are difficult to change, but the common people are easily swayed. Thus, hearing of Yao’s virtue, they are drawn by fame; hearing of Jie’s evil, they conceal themselves in hiding. Rather than praising Yao and condemning Jie, it is better to forget both and close off what you praise. **[Annotation]** To close is to block.

**[Commentary]** Praising Yao’s good Dao and condemning Jie’s evil conduct leads to ceaseless striving. Losing one’s nature is common, so it is better to forget both good and evil, block praise and blame, and preserve the nature of things. To turn back is to invite harm; to act is to invite deviation. **[Annotation]** Following it preserves wholeness; stillness preserves correctness.

**[Commentary]** Turning against the nature of things brings only harm; disturbing the mind leads only to deviation.

The sage proceeds with deliberation to initiate affairs, thereby ensuring success in every endeavor.
**[Annotation]** Affairs do not stray from their root, thus his achievements are ever accomplished.
**[Commentary]** With unhurried composure, the sage acts without premeditation, responding to the moment to undertake his work. Ever at ease, never opposing the nature of things, his success is ever assured.

Why then does he bear it to the end with such self-importance?
**[Annotation]** Self-importance cannot be borne, thus he abandons it and does not claim it.
**[Commentary]** *Naihe*—how could it be? How could one cling to the traces of benevolence and righteousness, disturbing the minds of all things, carrying the burden of solemn dignity to the end of one’s days? These are the words with which Lao Lai reproved Confucius.

In the dead of night, the Lord of Song Yuan dreamed of a man with disheveled hair peering through the side gate.
**[Commentary]** The Lord of Song, posthumously titled Yuan, was the ruler of Song. *A* refers to a curved or side chamber, meaning the gate of a side or curved room.
The man said: "I come from Zailu Deep. I was sent by the Clear River as an emissary to the River Lord, when the fisherman Yu Ju caught me."
**[Commentary]** *Zi* means "from." Zailu is the name of a deep pool by the river. His surname was Yu, his given name Ju, and he was a fisherman.
The Lord Yuan awoke and had the dream interpreted. The diviner said: "This is a spirit turtle."
The Lord said: "Is there a fisherman named Yu Ju?"
His attendants replied: "There is."
The Lord said: "Summon Yu Ju to court."
**[Commentary]** *Ming* means "to summon." He ordered Yu Ju to attend court to inquire about his catch.
The next day, Yu Ju appeared at court.

The Lord said: "What did you catch in your fishing?"
Yu Ju replied: "In my net, I caught a white turtle, five feet in circumference."
The Lord said: "Present this turtle to me."
When the turtle arrived, the Lord wavered twice—first wishing to kill it, then wishing to spare it. His mind uncertain, he divined with it, and the oracle said: "Killing the turtle for divination will bring good fortune."
**[Commentary]** *Uncertainty lingered in his heart; whether to kill or spare it, he hesitated again and again. Only after determining that killing it would be auspicious did he proceed to carve the turtle for divination.*

He then carved the turtle, drilling seventy-two times without a single miscalculation.
**[Commentary]** *From beginning to end, he drilled seventy-two times, and in every instance, his calculations of fortune and misfortune were never amiss.*

Confucius said: "The spirit turtle could appear in a dream to Lord Yuan, yet could not evade Yu Ju’s net. It could foresee seventy-two divinations without error, yet could not escape the disaster of having its entrails carved out. Thus, knowledge has its limitations, and even the divine has its insufficiencies."
**[Annotation]** *Such is the insufficiency of divine knowledge. Only those who dwell in stillness, abiding in what they can do without seeking beyond, remain whole.*
**[Commentary]** *Divine wisdom is not to be relied upon. Therefore, the perfected person in the world forgets form and spirit, intellect and thought, becoming like a withered tree in its barrenness, equal to the dead in its stillness. Entrusting all things to the workings of creation, even the great sage Confucius thus reflected upon it.*

*Though one possesses supreme knowledge, a multitude of counselors surpasses it.*
**[Annotation]** *Do not rely on one’s own knowledge but employ the counsel of many.*
*Fish do not fear nets but fear pelicans.*
**[Annotation]** *Nets are without intent, and thus they catch fish.*
**[Commentary]** *Nets, being without intent, catch fish—this illustrates how the sage, being without partiality, gathers the world to himself.*

*Discard petty knowledge, and great knowledge becomes clear.*
**[Annotation]** *Petty knowledge is self-serving; great knowledge responds to things.*
**[Commentary]** *Petty knowledge clings to preferences in the mind; great knowledge is without distinction. Abandoning the emotions of separation and contention, one attains impartiality, and thus great knowledge shines forth.*

*Discard goodness, and one becomes naturally good.*
**[Annotation]** *Discard goodness, and there is nothing to admire in goodness. With nothing to admire, goodness arises spontaneously without artifice.*
**[Commentary]** *Abandoning the petty heart of self-importance and merging with the great goodness of nature, as the earlier text says: "Departing from the Way to pursue goodness is perilous; acting with virtue is treacherous." The *Laozi* also states: "When all under heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness has already arisen."*

*An infant is born without a teacher yet learns to speak, for it dwells among those who can speak.*
**[Annotation]** *Naturally and without practice, it acquires this ability—not by striving to imitate others.*
**[Commentary]** *The nature of an infant does not depend on teachers or craftsmen. As it gradually grows, it naturally learns to speak—not through deliberate study, but by dwelling among its parents, following its innate nature, and speaking spontaneously. Thus, we know that the myriad things in the world do not arise from acquired knowledge or learned skill.*

Hui Shi said to Zhuangzi: "Your words are useless."
**[Commentary]** *Zhuangzi was a man of comprehensive understanding. His vision embraced both emptiness and fullness, and his words were vast and profound. Yet they did not align with the common mind, so Hui Shi mocked them as useless.*

Zhuangzi said: "Only when one understands the useless can one begin to speak of the useful."
**[Commentary]** *What is useful is like a prematurely severed life; what is useless preserves its wholeness. Thus, only when one understands the useless can one discuss the useful.*

"The earth is neither narrow nor small, yet what man uses is only enough to stand upon. If, however, one were to dig away the earth beside one’s feet down to the Yellow Springs, would it still be of use?"
Hui Shi said: "It would be useless."
**[Commentary]** *To dig away. Within the six directions, nothing is vaster than the earth, yet what man uses is no more than the space to stand. If, beyond the space for one’s feet, one were to dig down to the Yellow Springs, one would tremble and be unable to move. Thus, we know that what is useful depends on what is useless for its success.*

Zhuangzi said: "Then the usefulness of the useless is indeed clear."
**[Annotation]** *The sage responds from within, acting in accord with the moment; what is expressed outwardly flows from the unfolding of circumstances. When circumstances unfold, affairs are resolved; when the outer is clear, the inner is employed—such is the principle of mutual necessity.*
**[Commentary]** *If one stands only where one’s feet fit, one cannot walk. Only with additional space can one move and use one’s feet. The principle of the useless is thus made clear, as the *Laozi* says: "Existence is the means of advantage; non-existence is the means of use."*

Zhuangzi said: "If a man is capable of wandering, how could he not wander? If a man is incapable of wandering, how could he wander?"
**[Annotation]** *What one’s nature is capable of, one cannot but do; what one’s nature is incapable of, one cannot force. Thus, the sage does not impose restrictions, and all things attain their proper place without knowing how they do so.*
**[Commentary]** *People are endowed with different natures and employ them in different ways. Some respond to words like an echo; others cannot distinguish beans from wheat. Thus, what one’s nature is capable of, one cannot but follow; what it is incapable of, one cannot force. Each abides by its portion, and nothing is lost. But those who indulge in aimless wandering or cling to resolute detachment—alas! Are these the tasks of one of utmost knowledge and profound virtue?*

**[Annotation]** *Without utmost depth, none can bear such aspirations or trust in such extraordinary abilities.*
**[Commentary]** *To drift and flee without return, to be resolute and unyielding—these are the ways of the utmost foolishness and baseness. How could they be the tasks of one of perfect wisdom and deep virtue? This is Zhuangzi’s meaning.*

*To fall and not recover, to rush like fire and not look back—*
**[Annotation]** *What people desire, they pursue without regard for right or wrong, even unto death.*
**[Commentary]** *The deluded and ignorant cling stubbornly to their ways. Though their homes be destroyed and their bodies ruined, they do not turn back. Chasing after things with the urgency of fire, they do not look back. Such is the result of aimless wandering and resolute detachment."*

Though they may serve as ruler and minister to one another, this is but a matter of the times; when the age changes, they need not hold one another in contempt.
**[Annotation]** This is the great equality and sameness.
**[Commentary]** Those favored by the times become rulers, while those whose talents do not match the age become ministers—like Shun and Yu, who in turn served as ruler and minister. Thus, when the world undergoes transformation, one cannot despise the other for being ruler or minister. Those who drift and flee know nothing of this. Hence it is said: *The perfected person does not cling to conduct.*
**[Annotation]** They follow whatever they encounter, thus moving with transformation.
**[Commentary]** As the world rises and falls, they move accordingly, and so the enlightened never stagnate. To honor the past and disparage the present is the way of scholars.
**[Annotation]** The past is not inherently noble, nor the present inherently base; yet scholars honor the past and disparage the present, losing sight of the source.
**[Commentary]** The customs of each age differ, as do the purity and decadence of their times. The affairs of past and present are not the same, yet to value the past and demean the present is to stray far from true discernment—merely a narrow view of learning, not the clarity of understanding. If we observe the present age through the lens of the rulers of old, such as the sovereigns before the Three August Ones, who could avoid being swept away?
**[Annotation]** To follow the times and adapt to things is to achieve perfect harmony.
**[Commentary]** If we govern the present with the ways of the distant past, the contrast between purity and decadence will be stark—who could avoid being tossed about and losing their nature? This is the flaw of honoring the past and disparaging the present. Only the perfected person can wander through the world without bias,
**[Annotation]** Responding to affairs as they arise, wherever they may be, is correctness.
and follow others without losing themselves.
**[Annotation]** Fundamentally, there is no self—what is there to lose?
They do not study teachings,
**[Annotation]** Teachings arise from the nature of things, hence they are not learned.
nor do they adhere to intent.
**[Annotation]** Intent arises naturally, so to follow and employ it is to allow all things to fulfill their own nature.
**[Commentary]** Only those of utmost virtue can adapt to the times and transform with things, not through learned intention but through the fullness of their inherent nature. As for "not adhering to intent," it means embracing the intent of teachings to guide their nature, yet their true Way is originally complete and does not rely on those teachings.

The eye that penetrates is called clarity; the ear that penetrates is called acuity; the nose that penetrates is called discernment of scents; the mouth that penetrates is called savor; the mind that penetrates is called understanding; understanding that penetrates is called virtue.
**[Commentary]** *Penetrates* means to be unobstructed. *Discernment of scents* refers to pungent and foul odors. When the six senses are free of blockage, their clarity and acuity are not swayed by externals, thus becoming virtue.

The Way does not favor obstruction; obstruction leads to choking, and choking, if unchecked, leads to trampling.
**[Annotation]** When what should flow is blocked, principles cannot be released and instead trample one another.
Then harm arises in abundance.
**[Annotation]** *Arises* means to emerge.

All things with awareness rely on breath,
**[Annotation]** Those with roots and life lack awareness and do not rely on breath.
**[Commentary]** Heaven endows the six senses, and none can be dispensed with. The ear hears, the eye sees, the nose smells, the mind knows—these are their proper functions, and though employed, they incur no fault. Yet if the eye is drawn to the allure of mulberry groves, the ear to the lewd sounds of Pu, the nose to the excess of orchid and musk, or the mind to boundless desires, then Heaven’s principle is extinguished—how can this be called penetration? Thus, when the six senses are thoroughly unobstructed, the breath flows freely, and the principle of life is preserved. If this is not so, it is not Heaven’s fault.
**[Annotation]** *So* means proper. Breath does not depend on awareness; it is through awareness that one loses propriety, and losing propriety leads to obstruction. Thus, awareness relies on breath, but breath does not rely on awareness. Yet the use of desire is controlled by the person—it is not an inevitable sign.
**[Commentary]** *So* means proper. Some indulge their six senses, chasing after external objects; others block their orifices, harming the boundary of life. Both extremes fail to accord with principle—these are the faults of human nature, not the blame of Heaven. Heaven bores through them day and night without ceasing,
**[Annotation]** The principle of flow has a constant motion.
**[Commentary]** *Ceasing* means stopping. The principle of nature bores through all things, from day to night, never halting. Yet people, in turn, block their apertures.
**[Annotation]** Without emotion, following Heaven, the apertures open.
**[Commentary]** *Apertures* are openings. Ordinary people, contrary to Heaven’s principle, obstruct their sensory orifices, drowning in stagnation.

The womb has layered chambers,
**[Annotation]** *Chambers* are empty spaces.
**[Commentary]** *Chambers* means emptiness. The human abdomen is hollow, allowing it to contain the stomach, and the stomach is hollow, allowing the passage of qi and fluids.

The mind has the wandering of Heaven.
**[Annotation]** *Wandering* means to be unbound.
**[Commentary]** Because it is empty, the natural Way wanders within it.

A room without emptiness leaves no space for mother and daughter-in-law to avoid quarreling;
**[Annotation]** A place of contention.
**[Commentary]** Without emptiness, a room cannot accommodate, so mother and daughter-in-law contend, and hierarchy is lost.

A mind without the wandering of Heaven leaves the six apertures in conflict.
**[Annotation]** *Conflict* means opposition.
**[Commentary]** *Apertures* are openings. *Conflict* means opposition. If the natural Way does not wander in the mind, the six senses oppose it, failing to follow principle.

The great forests and mountains are beneficial to people, yet even the spiritually attuned cannot prevail.
**[Annotation]** The principle of nature finds expression through things.
**[Commentary]** The principle of nature finds expression through things.

Virtue overflows into fame,
**[Annotation]** When fame is high, profit runs deep; thus, those who cultivate virtue exceed what is proper.
**[Commentary]** *Overflows* means excess. The Five Virtues of benevolence and righteousness are over-practiced because of the pursuit of fame and competition.

Fame overflows into violence,
**[Annotation]** To restrain violence is to make one’s fame surpass one’s virtue.

The violent inflict harm. Fame is the vessel of the scholar; when fame exceeds its proper measure, men inevitably turn to mutual destruction. As the *Inner Chapters* state: "Fame is that by which men grind against one another."

Plans are scrutinized in haste,
**[Annotation]** *Xuan* means urgency; only in urgency are plans examined.
**[Commentary]** *Ji* means to investigate. *Shei* means urgency. Only in matters of pressing difficulty are strategies weighed.

Does knowledge arise from affairs?
**[Annotation]** When one proceeds calmly, knowledge is of no use.
**[Commentary]** If one deploys the mind’s knowledge to venture beyond its bounds, strife inevitably follows.

Obstruction arises from clinging,
**[Annotation]** *Chai* means blockage.
**[Commentary]** *Chai* means blockage. *Shou* means grasping. When emotions are rigidly fixed, one’s achievements fail to flow.

Official duties are fulfilled through accommodating the many.
**[Annotation]** What the many deem fitting is not uniform; thus, official duties are established.
**[Commentary]** The establishment of offices and the ordering of affairs must accord with what the people find convenient. If one acts contrary to this, calamity and disorder arise.

When spring rains fall in season, grasses and trees burst forth in vigorous growth, and the plow and hoe begin their work.
**[Annotation]** The arising of all things has its cause.
**[Commentary]** *Diao* refers to implements like the plowshare. *Nou* means the hoe. In the season of verdant spring, when timely rains descend, all grasses and trees sprout and grow. Thus, farmers begin to prepare their tools. This illustrates acting in accord with the season, not opposing the nature of things.

More than half of the grasses and trees that reach maturity do so without men knowing why.
**[Annotation]** Affairs proceed from principle, and thus one remains unaware.
**[Commentary]** *Zhi* means to grow. Once the plow and hoe are prepared, weeds and reeds are cleared away. By good fortune, the spring days arrive, and hoeing ceases as growth begins. This is entirely due to the season’s influence and cannot be measured by human sentiment. Thus, we know that the establishment of laws and teachings must follow the times.

Stillness can remedy illness,
**[Annotation]** This does not mean one is not ill.
**[Commentary]** For those afflicted with restlessness and agitation, tranquility may serve as a cure.

Trimming the temples can restore youth,
**[Annotation]** This does not mean one does not age.
**[Commentary]** *Zì* refers to trimming the hair at the temples. *Cǐ* describes the appearance. The countenance of decline and old age may be refreshed through such grooming.

How could this bring an end to haste?
**[Annotation]** This does not mean one is not hasty.

**[Commentary]** *Jù* means swiftness. For those whose nature is hasty and pressed, tranquility may serve to restrain it. Nevertheless, such measures are the tasks of the toiling—those at ease have never once paused to inquire after them.

**[Annotation]** If such is the case, there remains toil, and thus those at ease transcend it without regard.

**[Commentary]** To still haste with calm, to cure agitation with stillness—these are but remedial expedients, the concerns of lesser minds and the burdens of those who exhaust their spirit and intellect. How could they be the heart of one who embodies the Dao, a person of leisure, untroubled and unafflicted? Their bearing is lofty, their disposition noble; they have never once deigned to glance at such matters.

The sage startles the world, yet the *shenren* has never once paused to inquire;
**[Annotation]** The *shenren* is the sage—"sage" describes their outward manifestation, "spirit" their inner nature.
**[Commentary]** *Jīng* means to astonish. "Spirit" is the name for the unfathomable; "sage" is the title of one who leaves traces. Because they bestow teachings and move others, they do not deign to inquire.

The worthy startles the age, yet the sage has never once paused to inquire;
**[Commentary]** The worthy realizes emptiness; the sage illuminates all. Gazing from the profound to the shallow, they do not inquire.

The noble person startles the state, yet the worthy has never once paused to inquire;
**[Commentary]** Why should the noble person alarm the feudal lords’ domains? The worthy, having attained what they possess, do not inquire.

The petty person conforms to the times, yet the noble person has never once paused to inquire.
**[Annotation]** Each advances in their own way; high and low occupy their proper stations.
**[Commentary]** The petty person of the world, who merely adapts to the moment—like the followers of Tian Dan—is of no worth. Thus, the refined and noble disdain them without a glance.

In the Yan Gate, when a kinsman died, one who excelled in mourning was appointed as the official leader. Half of his fellow townsmen mourned themselves to death.
**[Annotation]** To feign grief for reward is far from true filial piety—this is the excess of exalting the worthy.
**[Commentary]** *Shùmén* (束门) is also written as *yínmén* (寅门), read according to the character. The filial piety of the Eastern Gate arose from the heart, its sorrow manifest in outward appearance. The Lord of Song, admiring his utmost devotion, ennobled him and appointed him minister. When the villagers heard that he had been honored for his filiality, they forced wails and feigned grief, distorting their nature and falsifying their emotions. As a result, half of them perished.

Yao offered the empire to Xu You, but Xu You fled from it; Tang offered it to Wu Guang, and Wu Guang raged against him.

**[Annotation]** Yao, knowing Xu You’s worthiness, abdicated the throne to him. Xu You declined with a mere "wash my ears" and fled to Mount Ji. Tang offered the throne to Wu Guang, but Wu Guang refused, reviling and raging, then retreated deep into the forest. These men followed their innate nature, disdaining rank and emolument, without the least pretense or desire for fame.

When Ji Tuo heard of this, he led his disciples to squat by the waters of his home. The feudal lords came to offer condolences, and for three years, Shen Tu Di drowned himself in the river.

**[Annotation]** The turbulence of the waves harmed his nature, leading to this extremity.

**[Annotation]** Shen Tu Di and Ji Tuo were both recluses. Hearing that Tang had offered the throne to Wu Guang, Ji Tuo feared it might fall to him next, so he and his disciples crouched by the water. The feudal lords, admiring his integrity, came to console him, fearing he might drown himself. Shen Tu Di, hearing of this, envied their lofty reputation and threw himself into the Yellow River, drowning to death. The turbulence of the waves undid his nature, bringing him to this end.

The *quan* is what one uses to catch fish, but once the fish is caught, the *quan* is forgotten; the snare is what one uses to catch hares, but once the hare is caught, the snare is forgotten.

**[Annotation]** The *quan* is a fish trap made of bamboo, hence the character includes the bamboo radical. Some versions use the grass radical, referring to *sunquan*, an aromatic herb used as bait—placing the fragrant herb among reeds and brushwood to lure fish. The snare is a rabbit net, also called a rabbit noose, used to bind the hare’s legs, hence the name. These two examples serve as metaphors.

Words are what one uses to convey meaning, but once the meaning is grasped, the words are forgotten.

**[Annotation]** This is the synthesis of the analogy. *Meaning* refers to the subtle principle. Just as fish and hares are caught by means of the *quan* and snare, yet the *quan* and snare are not themselves fish or hares, so too does the profound principle rely on words for expression, though words are not the principle itself. Once the fish and hare are obtained, the *quan* and snare are forgotten; once the profound principle is understood, names and words fall away. How might I find one who has forgotten words, that I might speak with him?

**[Annotation]** When the two sages reach the state of no-mind, they are entirely without speech.

**[Annotation]** To forget words and grasp the principle is to perceive the Dao with a single glance—such people are rare indeed, hence this difficulty.

*Commentary and Annotations on the Southern Florescence True Scripture*, Scroll Twenty-Eight, concludes.

**Cheng Xuanying’s Subcommentary on the "Miscellaneous Chapters" of the *Zhuangzi*: "Parables" (Chapter Twenty-Seven)**

**Nineteen Parables**
*[Annotation]* When entrusted to others, nine out of ten words are believed.
*[Subcommentary]* *Yu* (寓) means "to entrust." The world’s people, deluded and suspicious, grow doubtful upon hearing the Way spoken by oneself. Yet when the same words are entrusted to others, nine out of ten are believed. Thus, figures like Hong Meng, Cloud General, Jian Wu, and Lian Shu are all parables.

**Seventeen Weighty Words**
*[Annotation]* What the world esteems is believed seven out of ten times.
*[Subcommentary]* *Zhongyan* (重言) refers to elders and village elders held in esteem. Even the words of old men are believed seven out of ten times.

**Goblet Words Emerge Daily, Harmonized with Heaven’s Boundary**
*[Annotation]* A goblet, when full, tilts; when empty, it rights itself—it does not hold fast. Applied to words, they follow things and adapt to change, yielding to what comes. Thus, they "emerge daily." "Emerge daily" means daily renewal; daily renewal exhausts the share of the natural, and when the natural’s share is exhausted, harmony is achieved.
*[Subcommentary]* A *zhi* (卮) is a wine vessel. "Emerge daily" means daily renewal. *Tianni* (天倪) is the share of the natural. *He* (和) means "to harmonize." A goblet tilts when full and rights itself when empty; empty or full, it follows the object, tilting or righting as others will. Words without intent are *zhi* words—thus, they do not speak. Words without attachment to tilting or righting accord with the natural’s share.

*Alternative interpretation:* *Zhi* (卮) means "to prop up." Propped-up words lack precision, hence they are called *zhi* words.

**Nineteen Parables Rely on External Discourse**
*[Annotation]* Words spoken by oneself are often rejected by the vulgar, so one borrows from others. Figures like Jian Wu and Lian Shu are those from whom one borrows.
*[Subcommentary]* *Jie* (藉) means "to borrow" or "to entrust to others." The phrase "nine out of ten words" refers to borrowing others’ voices to expound.

**A Father Does Not Act as His Son’s Matchmaker**
A father’s praise of his son is not as credible as that of a non-father.
*[Annotation]* A father’s praise of his son is often disbelieved, yet there are times when it is believed. However, it is invariably met with habitual suspicion, so one borrows external discourse.
*[Subcommentary]* *Mei* (媒) means "to bring together." When a father speaks of his son, people often disbelieve him; when another praises him, belief is more common.

**It Is Not My Fault, but the Fault of Others**
*[Annotation]* Though one may be trustworthy, those who harbor habitual doubt still do not accept it. Entrusting it to others, however, they believe. Such is the burden of how people listen.
*[Subcommentary]* *Wu* (吾) refers to the father. It is not that the father’s praise of his son is untrue, but that listeners groundlessly grow suspicious, making disbelief their fault.

**Agreement with Oneself Is Affirmed; Disagreement Is Rejected**
*[Annotation]* They mutually condemn one another.
*[Subcommentary]* The vulgar, inverted in their judgments, arbitrarily approve or condemn. What aligns with their own views is affirmed as right; what differs is rejected as wrong.

**Affirming What Aligns with Oneself, Condemning What Differs**
*[Annotation]* In matters of sameness and difference, two parties dispute their choices, yet both differ from the undebated third. Thus, they alone trust what they affirm. How could this be done without borrowing from others?
*[Subcommentary]* Clinging to sameness and difference, they falsely perceive right and wrong. When sameness and difference are empty, right and wrong vanish.

**Seventeen Weighty Words Serve to Conclude Speech—These Are the Venerable Elders**
*[Annotation]* Because they are venerable elders, the vulgar collectively esteem them. Even if their words do not rely on others, seven out of ten are still believed.
*[Subcommentary]* *Qiai* (耆艾) is a term for the long-lived. Speaking for oneself, without borrowing from others, one is esteemed as an elder and thus believed. Such is the delusion of the common world.

**One May Be Senior in Years, Yet Without the Warp and Weft of Root and Branch to Merit the Title of Venerable Elder**
*[Annotation]* One may precede others in age, but without root or branch to offer, one is not truly senior. *Qi* (期) means "to await."
*[Subcommentary]* *Qi* (期) means "to await." *Jing* (经) refers to the vertical (warp), *wei* (纬) to the horizontal (weft). This describes one who merely occupies a senior position by age yet lacks wisdom of root and branch. Thus, though treated with the respect due a venerable elder, this has nothing to do with moral precedence.

**One Who Has Nothing to Offer Others Has No Human Way; One Without the Human Way Is Merely a Worn-Out Person**
*[Annotation]* They are merely long-worn people, yet the vulgar readily believe them. Such is the world’s folly in clinging to habit.
*[Subcommentary]* Without ritual propriety to lead others, one lacks the Way of human relations—merely a worn-out person. Yet they are esteemed for this.

**Goblet Words Emerge Daily, Harmonized with Heaven’s Boundary, Flowing Without End, Thus Exhausting the Years**
*[Annotation]* The natural has its share, but right and wrong have no master. Without a master, they flow without end—who can settle them? Thus, one remains open and unattached, following as things come, allowing each to fulfill its natural lifespan.
*[Subcommentary]* *Manyan* (曼衍) means "without intent." Following the daily renewal of change, harmonizing with the natural’s share, one thus flows with the myriad things, meeting them without intent. This is how one exhausts the years of creation’s span and attains the farthest reaches of life’s longevity.

**Without Words, There Is Equality**
*[Subcommentary]* Principle resides in wordlessness; to speak is to deviate. Thus, to remain utterly wordless is to let things equalize themselves.

**Equality and Words Are Not Equal**
*[Subcommentary]* *Qi* (齐) means "without words." Wordlessness and words are not one, hence they are not equal.

**Words and Equality Are Not Equal**
*[Annotation]* Entrusting words to things and employing them as needed, right and wrong naturally equalize themselves. If one cannot establish words in accord with things to equalize them, then I and the myriad things are again unequal.

Thus it is said: "Without words." *[Annotation]* What they speak of are their own words; though there are words, I ultimately remain wordless. *[Subcommentary]* To use words to dispel words is an endless endeavor—even if one were to heap a hundred refutations, it would still not attain the subtlety. Only by concentrating one’s illumination on the sage, where wisdom merges with movement and stillness, and where action and silence share the same essence, can one achieve wordlessness in speech and speech in wordlessness. How then could there be a distinction between words and wordlessness, or between equality and inequality? Thus it is said: "Words are without words." "Words are without words"—throughout a lifetime of speaking, one has never truly spoken; *[Annotation]* Though they issue from my mouth, they are still their words. Throughout a lifetime of silence, one has never truly been silent. *[Annotation]* Judging by what issues from my mouth. *[Subcommentary]* This further explains the meaning of "words without words."

There are causes by which things are acceptable, and causes by which they are not; there are causes by which things are so, and causes by which they are not. *[Subcommentary]* Each clings to their own views, hence there is what is acceptable and what is so. When self and other are both empty, what is acceptable and what is so vanish. How is it so? It is so in being so. How is it not so? It is not so in not being so. How is it acceptable? It is acceptable in being acceptable. How is it unacceptable? It is unacceptable in being unacceptable. *[Annotation]* "Cause" (自) means "to arise from." From the bias of self and other, there arises what is acceptable and what is not. *[Subcommentary]* "How" (恶乎) means "in what." When self and other are both empty and all things are illusory, where is there room for what is acceptable or unacceptable? Where is there room for what is so or not so? Pursuing this to its end, what is so and what is acceptable naturally cease. This further explains the meaning of "there are causes by which things are so and acceptable."

Things inherently have what they deem so, things inherently have what they deem acceptable; *[Annotation]* Each is natural, each is acceptable in itself. There is nothing that is not so, nothing that is not acceptable. *[Annotation]* Speaking in general terms, there is nothing that is acceptable or unacceptable—yet this is the ultimate reach of what is acceptable and unacceptable. *[Subcommentary]* Among the things of the vulgar world, there are those who invert right and wrong, insisting on what is not so as so, and on what is unacceptable as acceptable. Without the daily-renewing words of the wine vessel, harmonizing with the natural boundary of heaven, who could endure for long? *[Annotation]* Only those whose words adapt to things and follow their natural allotment can avoid premature decline. *[Subcommentary]* Unless one follows the ceaseless transformations of each day and comprehends the principle of natural spontaneity, who can attain the Way of long life and enduring vision? This is the ultimate attainment of those who grasp it.

All things are seeds, succeeding one another in different forms. *[Annotation]* Though they transform and replace one another, their *qi* is originally one. *[Subcommentary]* "Succeed" (禅) means "to replace." All things, receiving their endowment from creation, share the same *qi* yet differ in form. They flow ceaselessly, replacing one another in succession. Beginning and end are like a ring; *[Annotation]* What is a beginning today was already an end yesterday. *[Subcommentary]* The transformations of things are like a circle—death and birth, end and beginning, follow one another in turn. This describes the state of succession and replacement. None can grasp their order; *[Annotation]* The principle is thus of itself—hence none can grasp it. *[Subcommentary]* "Order" (伦) means "principle." Seeking the Way of transformation, one ultimately finds no principle to attain. This is called the "harmony of heaven" (天均). The harmony of heaven is the "boundary of heaven" (天倪). *[Annotation]* Is harmony and equality arbitrary? They are all the natural allotment of heaven. *[Subcommentary]* "Harmony" (均) means "equality." This summarizes the preceding chapter, stating that the Way of natural equality is the Way of harmonious equality, also called the "natural allotment."

Zhuangzi said to Huizi: "Confucius, at sixty years of age, underwent sixty transformations." *[Annotation]* He moved with the times. *[Subcommentary]* As the flow never ceases and renewal is unending, his years advanced to sixty while he transformed with each year. Now, Zhuangzi and Huizi often met to discuss the profound Dao, so he cited Confucius from afar to illustrate the method of transformation. What he initially deemed right, he later deemed wrong; *[Annotation]* As the times change, so do customs. One who rides things to roam the mind—how is he different from the vulgar?

The present "right" is not the wrong of fifty-nine years ago—yet who knows if today’s "right" will not become next year’s "wrong"? *[Annotation]* Change never ceases; rightness cannot be constant. *[Subcommentary]* A person’s lifespan is reckoned by the years, yet the years themselves are not fixed—how then can reckoning be certain? Thus what was right last year is wrong this year. From this we know that this year’s right was last year’s wrong, and this year’s wrong will be next year’s right. Therefore the Master of Rongcheng said: "Remove the days, and there are no years." Huizi said: "Confucius exerted his will and employed his knowledge." *[Annotation]* He meant that Confucius exerted his will and employed his knowledge to attain understanding, rather than allowing things to transform of themselves. This shows that Huizi fell short of the sage’s far-reaching resonance. *[Subcommentary]* "Employed" means "put to use." Huizi, not having grasped the Way, conjectured about Confucius, saying that he roused his will and diligently practiced, applying his mind to study the Dao, and thus attained his wisdom—not that he naturally entrusted himself to transformation. Zhuangzi said: "Confucius has moved beyond that, yet he has never spoken of it." *[Annotation]* He moved beyond transformation as something self-so, not something achieved by knowledge or effort; thus he followed the times and entrusted himself to things without contriving words. *[Subcommentary]* "Moved beyond" means "replaced." "Yet" refers to you. "Never" means "not at all."

Nipha had long since replaced the laboring mind of devotion—you ought to awaken your spirit anew and cease your reckless words.

Confucius said: “One receives one’s endowment from the Great Root and revives the spirit to live.”
*[Annotation]* If one employs one’s talents and knowledge without reviving the root-spirit, life is lost.
*[Subcommentary]* All people receive their talents and wisdom from the wondrous root of the Great Dao and return to the spirit-mandate to fulfill their life’s course—how could they labor their wills and employ their minds, going against the Creator’s work? This is Zhuangzi recounting Confucius’ words to rebuke Huizi.

When he intoned, it accorded with the pitch-pipes; when he spoke, it matched the standards.
*[Annotation]* Intoning arises from the pitch-pipes; speech issues from the standards. Yet pitch-pipes and standards are what the multitude creates—sages merely employ them. Thus nothing fails to accord, yet he never spoke of them, never acted upon them.
*[Subcommentary]* *Intoning* means sound. *Accorded* means matched. The sage Nipha, in virtue harmonizing with yin and yang, made his tones resonate with the bell-pitches and his teachings align with the models.

Profit and duty lay before him, yet likes and dislikes, right and wrong merely served the mouths of others.
*[Annotation]* *Served* means employed. I have no words of my own—what I speak merely employs the mouths of others. The display of likes and dislikes, right and wrong, profit and duty never issued from my own mouth.
*[Subcommentary]* Benevolence and duty, profit and harm, likes and dislikes, right and wrong—these respond to the opportunities before him, expounded in due time. Though words issue from his mouth, they follow what is before him, which is to employ the mouths of others.

Thus he made people submit with their hearts and dare not stand in opposition, settling what settles the world.
*[Annotation]* The mouth expresses the heart. Having employed the mouths of others, he employs their hearts. I follow the hearts of others, so their hearts trust—who would dare stand in opposition? I settle the world by relying on its self-settling—what more is there to do?
*[Subcommentary]* Adapting to what suits the multitude, he employs their hearts and minds. Teaching follows things, and things submit in turn, like grass bending to the wind, daring not stand in opposition. Following their inherent stillness, he settles them according to their nature—thus he settles what settles the world.

“Enough, enough! I shall never reach his level.”
*[Annotation]* Riding along with things, nothing fails to reach.
*[Subcommentary]* *Enough* means stop. *His* refers to Confucius. Repeatedly admonishing Huizi to cease speaking, [Zhuangzi says,] “We are too shallow to attain his level.” This is Zhuangzi’s praise of Nipha’s words.

Master Zeng took office twice, and his heart transformed twice.
*[Subcommentary]* His surname was Zeng, given name Shen, a disciple of Confucius. The meaning of “took office twice” is explained below.

He said: “When I took office while my parents were alive, three *fu* brought me joy; later, when I took office after their passing, three thousand *zhong* did not suffice—I grieved in my heart.”
*[Annotation]* *Sufficed* means reached.
*[Subcommentary]* Six *dou* and four *sheng* make one *fu*; six *hu* and four *dou* make one *zhong*. *Sufficed* means reached. Zeng Shen, being most filial, sought office to provide for his parents. Thus, when he first took office while his parents were alive, though his salary was meager, he rejoiced; later, after their passing, though his salary was great, he grieved. This is what is meant by “transformed twice”—his heart changed between sorrow and joy because he could no longer provide for his parents.

His disciples asked Confucius: “Can one say that Shen is free from fault in this?”
*[Annotation]* *Fault* means entanglement. They mean that Shen took office for his parents’ sake and was not entangled by salary.
*[Subcommentary]* *Entanglement* means attachment. Among the disciples, none are named—this must refer to one of the Four Categories or Ten Worthies. Zeng Shen, being benevolent and filial, sought office to provide for his parents. Though his heart changed between sorrow and joy, he should be free from fault. The disciples, doubting this, asked Confucius.

[Confucius] said: “He was already entangled.”
*[Annotation]* Entangled by salary to provide for them. One free from entanglement—could he feel sorrow?
*[Annotation]* Providing for parents is fitting, regardless of means. If one could be free from entanglement, one would not weigh high or low in mind but remain peaceful and joyful, fulfilling the proper expression of care.

*[Subcommentary]* The filial son serves his parents with the aim of suiting them, regardless of the salary’s size. He fulfills the expression of care, and thus there are those who, though hired laborers, are called filial sons, while others, though having taken office three times, are still deemed unfilial. Since Shen’s heart held sorrow and joy, was he not entangled by salary? Only one free from entanglement would feel no sorrow or joy.

He regarded three *fu* and three thousand *zhong* as observing sparrows and mosquitoes passing before him.
*[Annotation]* *He* refers to one free from entanglement. One free from entanglement regards honor and salary as mosquitoes, sparrows, or flies passing before him—how could there be sorrow or joy in between?
*[Subcommentary]* *He* refers to one free from entanglement. Sparrows are large, likened to a thousand *zhong*; mosquitoes and flies are small, likened to three *fu*. One who has attained the Dao is free from attachment to salary—whether a thousand *zhong* or three *fu*, he does not perceive more or less. Like sparrows, mosquitoes, or flies flying past before him, they pass by and that is all—how could he be entangled?

Yan Cheng Ziyou said to Dongguo Zijing: “Since I heard your words, after one year I became rustic,
*[Annotation]* Detached from external advantages.
*[Subcommentary]* Living east of the outer wall, he was called Dongguo—this is the same Nan Guo Ziqi from the “Equalizing Things” chapter. Ziyou was Ziqi’s disciple. *Rustic* means unrefined. Having heard the Dao for a year, his learning was not yet mature, but he gradually became simple, shedding superficiality.

after two years I followed,
*[Annotation]* Did not act on his own.
*[Subcommentary]* Submitted to custom.

after three years I penetrated,
*[Annotation]* Penetrated self and others.
*[Subcommentary]* Did not cling to circumstances.

after four years I became one with things,
*[Annotation]* United with things.
*[Subcommentary]* United with things.

after five years they came to me...”

after six years the spirits entered,
*[Annotation]* Transcended the bodily form.
*[Subcommentary]* Spirit harmonized with principle and things.

after seven years Heaven was perfected,
*[Annotation]* Nothing left to do.
*[Subcommentary]* Accorded with nature’s completion.

after eight years I knew not death, knew not life,
*[Annotation]* Whatever encountered was fitting and at peace.
*[Subcommentary]* Wisdom obscured the Maker of Things, spirit merged with nature—thus he perceived no difference between death and life, gathering and dispersal.

after nine years the Great Mystery.
*[Annotation]* Mystery means excellence. Good and evil became the same, so nowhere was not darkness.
This speaks of long hearing the Dao, knowing the spontaneity of Heaven’s pipes, until suddenly self-forgetting, whereupon defilements daily fell away to the point of exhaustion.
*[Subcommentary]* Mystery means subtlety. Having heard the Dao for days on end, the heart of learning gradually took hold, enabling him to transcend the four propositions, cut off the hundred negations, reach the ultimate of profound darkness, exhaust the myriad mysteries, and attain vast illumination—hence it is called “great.”

Principled life is activity—death.
*[Annotation]* To live while acting is to lose one’s life.
*[Subcommentary]* Dwelling in the human way, sunk in activity, is to return to death and extinction.

I urge you, sir, because your death has a cause.
*[Annotation]* Cause means reason. Death comes from activity; activity comes from prizing one’s life.
Now what I urge you about is that your death arises from prizing it.
*[Subcommentary]* Sir means impartiality. Cause means reason. That which leads human life into the realm of death is still prizing one’s life, unable to be impartial—hence the exhortation.

Yet life is yang—it has no cause.
*[Annotation]* Life’s yang, proceeding by leaving no traces and doing nothing, suddenly arises alone—it has no reason.
*[Subcommentary]* Moved by yang qi, this life comes to be; since it has no reason to follow, it is not worth prizing.

Is it truly so?
*[Subcommentary]* Truly means certainty. Yang qi generates things—this is certainly so.

Where is it fitting? Where is it not fitting?
*[Annotation]* Yet it is truly so, hence there is nowhere it is fitting and nowhere it is not fitting—only then is it everywhere fitting, and everywhere fitting is arrival.
*[Subcommentary]* Qi gathers to form life—life is not worth rejoicing over; qi disperses to form death—death is not worth grieving over. Since life and death are equal, joy and sorrow vanish. Thus where is it fitting? Where is it not fitting? Everywhere is fitting.

Heaven has its celestial reckonings, earth has its human settlements—where should I seek them?
*[Annotation]* All are self-sufficient.
*[Subcommentary]* The stars’ reckonings and celestial patterns adorn Heaven; the nine provinces and four extremities are where humans and things depend—within creation, all is already complete in me. Where should I seek them outside?

No one knows its end—how can it be without destiny?
*[Annotation]* Principle must end of itself, not through knowing—if not destiny, what is it?
*[Subcommentary]* Heaven and earth’s day and night, humans and things’ life and death—tracing their roots, no one knows beginning or end. Timing comes and goes—if not destiny, what is it? To say it is without destiny is to speak of its having destiny.

No one knows its beginning—how can it have destiny?
*[Annotation]* Not knowing why it is so yet it is so—this is called destiny. It seems as if there were intention, hence the name of destiny is again set aside to clarify its spontaneity, and only then is the principle of destiny complete.
*[Subcommentary]* Death goes, life comes, like spring, autumn, winter, summer—since there is no beginning or end, how can it be destiny? To say it has destiny is to speak of its having no destiny. This again sets aside destiny.

There is that to which it responds—how can it be without spirits?
*[Annotation]* Principle must have a response, as if there were numinous spirits to bring it about.
*[Subcommentary]* Spirits mean numinous awareness. The ears and eyes respond to sounds and colors, the heart-mind responds to things—this is like echo and shadow. How can there be no numen? To say it is without spirits is to speak of its having them.

There is nothing to which it responds—how can it have spirits?
*[Annotation]* Principle responds of itself; response does not come from anything else—thus although it responds, there is no numen.
*[Subcommentary]* When a person sleeps, they do not know external things; though they have eyes and ears, they do not respond to colors and sounds. If there were numen, how could it not respond? To say it has spirits is to speak of its having none. This again sets aside its having them.

The Penumbra asked the Shadow:
“Earlier you were bowing, now you are looking up; earlier your hair was tied up, now it is loose; earlier you were sitting, now you are standing; earlier you were walking, now you are still—why?”
*[Subcommentary]* Penumbra is the faint darkness outside the shadow. This is a parable. “You” means “you.” Bowing means lowering the head. Tied up means binding the hair. Your sitting and standing, walking and stopping, follow only the form—judging by this, you must exist because of the form. The principle does not wait—its subtlety is not yet clear. This question and answer are set forth to reveal solitary transformation.

The Shadow replied: "It moves of itself—why ask at all?"
*[Annotation]* Its movement is spontaneous, with nothing to prompt inquiry.
*[Subcommentary]* "Of itself" describes effortless, unthinking motion. "Why" means "for what reason." The Shadow answers: My movement is without intent, serene and self-content, requiring nothing, arising through solitary transformation. You know nothing of this—why trouble me with questions? I have these movements yet do not know their cause.
*[Annotation]* It is spontaneous, thus its cause is unknown.
*[Subcommentary]* "I" means "me." All my movements and stillness follow the Creator, yet I do not know their origin. None can fathom how they arise—how could they depend on anything? I am like the cicada’s husk, the snake’s sloughed skin—resembling them yet not the same.
*[Annotation]* The shadow resembles form yet is not form.
*[Subcommentary]* The cicada’s husk is its cast shell; the snake’s slough is its shed skin. When a grub transforms into a cicada, or a snake emerges from its skin, neither is aware of the change.
