The grub perishes before, the cicada appears after—yet the cicada does not arise *from* the grub, nor does it wait upon the grub to come into being. The same principle applies to the snake’s skin. Thus we know that all the myriad existences do not depend on one another but arise through solitary transformation, all called "self-so." Therefore the Shadow says: My dependence is like the snake’s slough or the cicada’s husk—seeming to rely on form yet in truth not dependent on it. Fire and sunlight are my gathering; darkness and night are my succession.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Layering" (屯) means gathering; "succession" (代) means passing away. When there is fire or sunlight, the shadow gathers; when night or darkness comes, the shadow fades. If the shadow were truly dependent on form, it would not rely on fire or sunlight. Yet in darkness, form exists without shadow—thus we know the shadow does not depend on form, and the principle of solitary transformation is manifest. Why then does it seem to have dependence?

**[Subcommentary]**
What the shadow seems to depend upon is fire and sunlight. Yet if the mind had no form, fire and sunlight could not produce a shadow—thus the shadow does not truly depend on them either. How then could one claim it has dependence?

**[Annotation]**
Pushing this to its limit, what we now call "dependence" ultimately leads to "non-dependence," and the principle of solitary transformation is revealed.

**[Subcommentary]**
Moreover, what has dependence is form. Without fire or sunlight, form cannot produce a shadow—thus the shadow does not depend on form. Since form arises without fire or sunlight, how could the shadow’s arising depend on form? Using fire and sunlight as an analogy, we see clearly that the shadow does not depend on form. If even form and shadow do not depend on one another, how much less do other things? Thus we know all the myriad dharmas arise through solitary transformation.

When that (form) comes, I (the shadow) come with it; when that goes, I go with it; when that grows bright, I grow bright with it. Yet what question is there in brightness?

**[Annotation]**
It simply moves with brightness of its own accord—following along, coming and going without intention, beyond all questioning.

**[Subcommentary]**
"That" refers to form. "Brightness" describes its movement. Coming and going, movement and stillness—form and shadow occur simultaneously, yet without mutual dependence, all relying on solitary transformation. The principle of solitary transformation is wondrous beyond all names and words; questions and answers about it are already complete.

Yang Ziju traveled south to Pei, while Lao Dan journeyed west to Qin. They met by chance in the outskirts and encountered each other in Liang.

**[Subcommentary]**
His surname was Yang, given name Zhu, courtesy name Ziju. "Traveled" (之) means went. Pei was Pengcheng, now Xuzhou. "Met by chance" (邀) means encountered. Liang was now Bianzhou. Yang Zhu was heading south, Laozi traveling west—they chanced upon each other in the lands of Liang and Song, meeting in the wilds where Laozi spoke to him.

Midway, Laozi looked up to heaven and sighed: "At first I thought you could be taught, but now I see you cannot."

**[Subcommentary]**
When they first met, he believed Yang had the heart of the Dao; now seeing his arrogance, he knew him untrainable. Displeased by his divergence from the common way, he lamented.

Yang Ziju did not answer.

**[Subcommentary]**
Aware of his own faults, he fell silent in shame.

Upon reaching the inn, he brought water for washing, a towel and comb, removed his shoes outside the door, and advanced on his knees.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Washing" (盥) means cleansing; "comb" (栉) means to arrange. Arriving at the lodging, he entered the guest quarters. There he brought water to rinse and wash, took up towel and comb, crawled forward on his knees, and bowed in utmost reverence—his thighs trembling as he sought instruction, hoping to receive correction.

He said: "Earlier, your disciple wished to ask you, but you were traveling without pause, so I dared not. Now there is pause—may I ask what my fault was?"

**[Subcommentary]**
Rebuked before, he wished to inquire of his error, but the master was traveling without respite. Now, having reached the inn with leisure, he hoped to hear the reason for the rebuke, to aid his future conduct.

Laozi said: "Your haughty glare—with whom could you dwell?"

**[Annotation]**
"Haughty glare" describes domineering arrogance. People will fear and distance themselves.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Haughty glare" (睢睢盱盱) describes restless aggression and overbearing pride. "You" (而) means "you." With such domineering force and ostentatious display, all will shrink from you—who would dwell with you?

"The purest white appears sullied; the greatest virtue seems insufficient."

**[Subcommentary]**
Those who are incorruptibly pure seem as if stained; those of perfect virtue appear lacking. This is Laozi quoting the *Daodejing* to admonish Ziju.

Yang Ziju’s expression changed abruptly, and he said: "I respectfully receive your teaching."

**[Subcommentary]**
"Abruptly" (蹴然) means with startled shame. Having received the master’s instruction, his alarm deepened—he bowed in reverence, humbly accepting the command.

When he had gone before, the innkeeper had welcomed and escorted him; the master of the house held the mat, his wife the towel and comb. The seated guests avoided his seat, and the fire-tender shrank from the hearth.

**[Annotation]**
His bearing set him apart, so all shrank from him in awe.

**[Subcommentary]**
"Escorted" (将) means sent off. The master of the house (家公) refers to the innkeeper. "Fire-tender" (炀) means one who tends the flame. When Yang Zhu first went to Pei, he conducted himself with imposing dignity. Arriving at the inn, the host welcomed and saw him off; the master of the house held the mat, his wife the comb and towel. Those already seated fled his seat, and the fire-tender dared not approach the hearth—his power over others reached such extremes.

On his return, the innkeeper vied with him for a seat.

**[Annotation]**
This was because he had shed his arrogance.

**[Subcommentary]**
Returning from Pei, having received the master’s teaching, he cast off his ostentation and pride, blending his traces with the dust and harmonizing his light with the world. Thus the innkeeper now competed with him for a seat.

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture, Scroll Twenty-Nine, Concluded*

#8 Guo Qingfan’s cited text emends 是 to 义. #9 Zhao Lianyi’s edition renders 也 as 化. #10 The Shidetang edition omits the character 而. #11 Zhao Lianyi’s edition writes 观 as 鹳. The *Quewu* concurs; Zhang Junfang notes: “鹳雀 is written as 观乌雀.” #12 The *Quewu*, citing Zhang Junfang’s edition, adds the character 私 beneath 其. #13 Guo Qingfan’s cited text emends 也 to 而. #14 Guo Qingfan’s cited text emends 其 to 有. #15 The Siku edition writes 影 as 景, and the same applies below. #16 The character 摄 is supplied following the *Chengshu* and the *Quewu*, which cites Zhang Junfang’s edition. #17 The Zhejiang Bureau edition writes 叟 as 搜. #18 The character 无 is supplied following Guo’s commentary and the *Quewu*, which cites Zhang Junfang’s edition. #19 The original reads 去, likely an error; here corrected following Guo Qingfan’s cited text. #20 The original reads 昆, likely an error; here corrected in accordance with the context and Guo Qingfan’s cited text. #21 The original reads 司; here corrected in accordance with the context and Guo Qingfan’s cited text.

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence Perfect Scripture, Scroll Thirty*
*Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Commentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of the Tang, Western Florescence School**
*Miscellaneous Chapters, "Yielding the Throne" Twenty-Eighth*

When Yao yielded the realm to Xu You, Xu You declined. He then yielded it to Zizhou Zhifu, who replied: "That you would make me Son of Heaven is acceptable. Nevertheless, I presently suffer from a malady of profound care; I am just now attending to it and have no leisure to govern the realm."

*Commentary:*
The deeds of Yao and Xu You are fully recorded in the *Inner Chapters*. His surname was Zi, his given name Zhou, and his courtesy name Zhifu—a man who embraced the Dao, a recluse. Yao, knowing his worth, offered him the imperial throne. "That I should be emperor would indeed be fitting," he said, hence his words "is acceptable." *You* means "profound"; *you* means "toil." He declared: "I am mired in depths of care, my heart burdened with toil. I am now cultivating myself, hoping to align with the Dao, and have no spare moment to order the myriad affairs." The realm is the weightiest of all things, yet he would not let it harm his life—how much less would he allow other things to do so?

*Commentary:*
To ascend to the ninefold dignity, to wield the might of ten thousand chariots, is the highest honor among men—yet he would not let such glory and eminence impair his livelihood. How then could other external things trouble his mind? Only one who takes no account of the realm is fit to be entrusted with it.

*Commentary:*
One who forgets the realm takes no thought of it; only such a person may be entrusted with its governance.

Shun yielded the realm to Zizhou Zhibo, who replied: "I presently suffer from a malady of profound care; I am just now attending to it and have no leisure to govern the realm."

*Commentary:*
The deeds of Shun are fully set forth in the *Inner Chapters*. Zhibo is the same as Zhifu.

Thus the realm is a vessel of great weight, yet he would not exchange his life for it—this is how those who possess the Dao differ from the common run.

*Commentary:*
The throne of the emperor is a vessel of the greatest weight, yet he would not let such honor rob him of his life. Without the Dao, who could act thus? This is how he differs from the conduct of the vulgar.

Shun yielded the realm to Shan Juan, who replied: "I stand amid the cosmos. In winter I wear furs and pelts; in summer, fine linen. In spring I plow and sow, my body sufficient for labor; in autumn I reap and gather, my person sufficient for rest and sustenance."

Sun rises, and I rise to work; sun sets, and I rest. I roam at ease between Heaven and Earth, my heart content. Why should I take the realm for myself?

*Commentary:*
His surname was Shan, given name Juan, a recluse. Dwelling within the Six Directions, in harmony with the Four Seasons, he found his place between Heaven and Earth, wandering free beyond the dust and grime. The Dao was within him, and so he had no use for the realm. Alas, you do not know me! Thus he refused. Then he departed and entered the deep mountains, and none knew his whereabouts.

*Commentary:*
The ancients, in their simplicity, called the emperor "son." He lamented that Shun did not recognize the purity of the wild.

Shun yielded the realm to his friend, the farmer of Shihu. The farmer of Shihu said: "How toilsome is the lord’s conduct! A man of unyielding strength!"

*Commentary:*
The character *hu* may also be written as *hu*, and is read accordingly. Shihu is a place name. *Nong* means "person," as people in the south still call a man *nong*. This was Shun’s friend. *Bao* means "firm." He said that Shun’s will was resolute, his strength exerted to the utmost, his back bent with labor, never able to rest. For all this toil, he now offers the realm—thus he refused. He deemed Shun’s virtue not yet perfected. Then, his wife bearing their child on her head, the husband shouldering their load, they entered the sea and never returned.

*Commentary:*
The ancients carried burdens on their heads, a custom still seen among the Koreans. Believing Shun’s transformative virtue not yet supreme, they took their wife and child and left, never to tread his land again. They entered the islands of the great sea and departed, never to return.

King Tai of the Great Clan dwelt in Bin. The Di tribes attacked him...

The *Subcommentary* states: Danfu was the father of King Ji and the grandfather of King Wen. *Na* was the name of a place. The Di tribes were the Xianyun. As the state bordered the Rong and Di barbarians, it suffered their attacks. Danfu offered them furs and silks, but they refused; he offered them dogs and horses, but they refused; he offered them pearls and jades, but they refused—for what the Di tribes sought was land. Danfu then said: “To dwell in a man’s elder brother’s land and kill his younger brother, to dwell in a man’s father’s land and kill his son—this I cannot bear. All of you, strive to remain here. What difference is there between serving as my subjects and serving the Di tribes?”

The *Subcommentary* states: *Shi* means “to offer.” *Mian* means “to exert oneself.” *Xi* means “how.” The Di tribes were greedy and cruel, their intent fixed on the land. Unwilling to inflict harm or slaughter, Danfu urged his people to remain. Moreover, he had heard that one must not harm what one nourishes for the sake of what nourishes it. Thereupon, he took up his staff and departed. The people followed in a continuous stream, and thus a state was established beneath Mount Qi.

The *Subcommentary* states: *Yong yang* refers to the land, and *suo yang* to the common people. The land is originally used to nourish the people, but now men kill the people to preserve the land—this is unacceptable. Having leaned on his staff and left, the people followed in succession, and thus a state was founded at Qiyang.

This Danfu, the Grand King, could indeed be called one who honored life. Those who honor life, though noble and wealthy, do not harm their bodies for the sake of nourishment; though poor and lowly, they do not burden their forms for the sake of profit. Yet men of the present age who occupy high office and exalted rank all fear losing them. Seeing profit, they lightly cast aside their lives—are they not deluded?

The *Subcommentary* states: In this chaotic age of deceit and shallowness, men’s hearts are frivolous. They pursue carriages and caps at the cost of their lives, chase wealth and profit to the ruin of their persons, unaware of what is light and what is heavy—deeply mired in confusion.

The people of Yue assassinated their ruler for three generations. Prince Sou, fearing this, fled into the cinnabar caves. When Yue was left without a ruler, the people sought Prince Sou and found him in the cinnabar caves. Prince Sou refused to emerge, so the people of Yue smoked him out with mugwort. They then bore him forth in a jade carriage.

The *Subcommentary* states: *Sou* was the prince’s name. The cinnabar caves were caverns in the southern mountains. The jade carriage was the ruler’s chariot. Some texts write *wang* (“king”) instead of *yu* (“jade”), to be read according to the character—this refers to the jade imperial chariot. The people of Yue had repeatedly assassinated their rulers, so the prince, seized with terror, fled into the caves. When they summoned him and he would not emerge, they smoked him out with mugwort. Having entreated him to become their ruler, they bore him forth in the jade imperial chariot.

Prince Sou grasped the carriage rope and mounted, then looked up to heaven and cried: “Rulership! Rulership! Can you truly not spare me?” Prince Sou did not hate being a ruler—he hated the calamities that came with rulership. Such a man as Prince Sou could indeed be called one who did not harm his life for the sake of the state. This was precisely what the people of Yue desired in a ruler.

The *Subcommentary* states: *Yuan* means “to pull.” *Sui* refers to the rope on a carriage. Unable to escape, he sighed deeply as he mounted the chariot. He did not hate being a ruler—he feared the disasters it would bring. As he valued life over rank, he could be compelled to become a ruler.

Han and Wei contended over disputed territory. Master Hua Zi visited Marquis Zhao of Han, who wore a troubled expression.

The *Subcommentary* states: Marquis Zhao was the ruler of Han. Master Hua was a worthy man of Wei. As Han and Wei were neighbors, they fought over border lands. With weapons drawn and victory uncertain, the marquis was anxious and fearful, hence his troubled expression.

Master Hua Zi said: “Suppose now that the world inscribed a decree before you, which read: ‘If you seize it with your left hand, your right hand will be severed; if you seize it with your right hand, your left hand will be severed. Yet whoever seizes it shall possess the world.’ Would you seize it?”

The *Subcommentary* states: *Ming* means “inscription.” *Jue* means “to grasp.” *Fei* means “to sever.” Suppose an inscription were placed before you: if you took it with your left hand, your right hand would be cut off; if you took it with your right hand, your left hand would be cut off. Yet whoever took it would gain the world—would you take it? This analogy was offered as a question to the Marquis of Han.

Marquis Zhao said: “I would not seize it.”

The *Subcommentary* states: He replied that he could not sever both arms to gain the world.

Master Hua Zi said: “Excellent. From this we may observe that two arms are weightier than the world, and the body is weightier than two arms. How much lighter is Han than the world!

The *Subcommentary* states: *Zi* means “from.” Observing this, we see that the body is weightier than two arms, and two arms are weightier than the world. The world, in turn, is weightier than Han—the difference in weight between Han and the world is vast.

What you now contend over is even lighter than Han. Yet you stubbornly grieve, harming your life and troubling your spirit over what you may not obtain—are you not deluded?”

The *Subcommentary* states: What they contended over was mere borderland, thus even lighter than Han. Yet the marquis stubbornly grieved, harming his form and injuring his nature, fearing he might not gain it—was he not deluded?

Marquis Zhao said: “Well said! Many have instructed me, but never have I heard such words.”

Master Zihua could indeed be called one who understood the weight of things.

*The Subcommentary* states: He suddenly awakened to these words, marveling at their wonder.

The Lord of Lu, hearing that Yan He was a man who had attained the Dao, sent an envoy bearing gifts to approach him first.

*The Subcommentary* states: The Lord of Lu was Duke Ai of Lu, though some say it was Duke Ding. Yan, whose given name was He, was a man of Lu and a recluse. The *bi* were silk offerings. Having heard that Yan He had attained the Dao of purity and integrity, the duke wished to appoint him as minister, so he dispatched an envoy bearing silk to convey his intent.

Yan He dwelt in a humble lane, wearing coarse hempen cloth and tending cattle himself.

*The Subcommentary* states: *Ju* cloth was made from ramie. *Fan* means “to feed.” Living in a crude and narrow alley, clad in rough and shabby cloth, he personally fed the cattle—this sufficiently showed his poverty and frugality.

When the envoy of the Lord of Lu arrived, Yan He received him himself. The envoy asked: “Is this the home of Yan He?” Yan He replied: “This is indeed He’s home.” When the envoy presented the gifts, Yan He responded: “I fear the messenger may have misheard and thus incur blame. It would be better to verify.”

*The Subcommentary* states: *Yi* means “to give.” Unwilling to accept the gifts, he fabricated this excuse to deceive the envoy. The envoy returned to confirm, then came back to seek him, but by then it was too late. Thus, one like Yan He truly despised wealth and honor.

Therefore it is said: The true essence of the Dao is for cultivating the self; its remnants may be used to govern the state; its dregs, like dirt and straw, may be used to govern the world. From this we see that the achievements of emperors and kings are but the leftover tasks of sages—these are not the means to preserve the body and nourish life.

*The Subcommentary* states: *Xu* means “remnants.” *Tu* means “dung,” and *ju* means “straw.” One who employs the true Dao to sustain the self must regard governing the state as a residual matter, and ruling the world as no more than dirt and straw. Yet the gentlemen of this vulgar age often endanger their bodies and abandon their lives in pursuit of things—is this not lamentable?

Whenever the sage acts, he must examine both his purpose and his means.

*The Subcommentary* states: *Xun* means “to pursue.” He observes where the people of the world are headed and what the common folk are doing, then acts in response.

Now suppose there were a man here who used the Pearl of Marquis Sui to shoot at a sparrow a thousand *ren* high—surely the world would laugh at him. Why? Because what he employed was weighty, while what he sought was light. How much more so is life itself, which is far weightier than the Pearl of Marquis Sui!

*The Subcommentary* states: The state of Sui lay near the Pu River, which produced precious pearls—these were the gems carried by the spirit-snake in repayment of kindness, obtained by the Marquis of Sui, hence called the Pearl of Marquis Sui. The sparrow flew a thousand *ren* high; to shoot at it with such a pearl was to seek something light with something weighty. To harm life in pursuit of things follows the same principle.

Master Liezi was poor, and his countenance bore the hue of hunger. A guest mentioned this to Ziyang of Zheng, saying: “Lie Yukou is a man of the Dao, yet he dwells in your state in poverty. Might this not suggest that you, my lord, do not esteem scholars?”

*The Subcommentary* states: Ziyang was the minister of Zheng. Yukou was a man of Zheng, a man of the Dao who lived in poverty. The guest, speaking in veiled terms, reproached Ziyang for not valuing worthy scholars.

Ziyang of Zheng immediately ordered an official to send him grain. When Master Liezi saw the messenger, he bowed twice and declined.

*The Subcommentary* states: He commanded the official in charge of the granary to give him grain. Yukou, being of lofty integrity, declined the offer with thanks.

The messenger departed, and when Master Liezi entered his home, his wife struck her breast and said: “I have heard that the wives and children of men of the Dao all live in ease and joy. Yet here you are with the look of hunger. If you had accepted the food the master sent, you would not have suffered so. Is this not fate?”

*The Subcommentary* states: Having refused the grain, she lamented their destined poverty, beating her breast and reproaching her husband’s error. Thus it is clear that the wife of Liezi fell far short of the wife of Laolai.

Master Liezi laughed and said to her: “The lord did not know me of his own accord. Because someone spoke of me, he sent me grain; and if he were to blame me, it would again be on the basis of someone’s words. This is why I did not accept it.” In the end, the people indeed rose in revolt and killed Ziyang.

*The Subcommentary* states: Ziyang was harsh and cruel, and many resented him. When one of his attendants accidentally broke his bow, fearing punishment, he incited the people—who were already chasing a mad dog—to kill Ziyang.

King Zhao of Chu lost his state, and the butcher Shuo fled with him.

*The Subcommentary* states: King Zhao, whose given name was Zhen, was the son of King Ping. When Wu She and Wu Shang were executed by King Ping, Wu Zixu fled to Wu and tilled the fields. Later, in the reign of King Helü of Wu, he requested troops to attack Chu, breached the capital of Ying to avenge his father, and forced King Zhao into desperate flight—first to Sui, then to Zheng. A butcher named Shuo accompanied the king in his flight. The reason for his flight is explained below.

When King Zhao returned to his state, he wished to reward those who had followed him, including the butcher Shuo. The butcher Shuo said: “When the great king lost his state, I lost my butcher’s trade. Now that the great king has returned, I have returned to my butcher’s trade. My rank and salary have been restored—what reward is there to give?”

The king said: “Insist that he accept.” The butcher Shuo replied: “When the great king lost his state, it was not my fault, so I dared not accept punishment. Now that the great king has returned, it is not my merit, so I dare not claim reward.”

The king said: “Let me see him.” The butcher Shuo replied: “According to the laws of Chu, only those who have rendered great merit and received heavy rewards may be granted an audience. My wisdom is insufficient to preserve the state, and my courage is insufficient to die in battle against the enemy. When the Wu army entered Ying, I fled in fear of danger to avoid the enemy—it was not that I deliberately followed the great king. Now if the great king wishes to set aside the law and break the covenant to see me, this is not what I wish to be heard of in the world.”

King Zhuang of Chu then addressed Minister Si of the Marshal’s Office: “The butcher Shuo dwells in lowly circumstances yet sets forth principles of the highest order. You must extend to him an invitation to the rank of the Three Standards.”

(Note: The Three Standards denote the Three Dukes. Some texts write “gui” [jade tablets], for the Three Ministers all hold gui, hence the Three Ministers are called gui.)

Butcher Shuo replied: “The rank of the Three Standards—I know it is nobler than my butcher’s stall; the salary of ten thousand bushels—I know it is richer than my butcher’s profit. Yet how could I covet rank and salary and thereby cause my lord to bear the reputation of reckless bestowal? I dare not accept. I wish only to return to my butcher’s stall.” Thereupon he declined the offer.

Yuan Xian dwelt in Lu, in a walled hut of one rod square, thatched with living grass. The door of woven mugwort was incomplete, its hinge made of mulberry wood. A single room had a window of broken jars, patched with coarse cloth. Rain leaked through above, moisture seeped below, yet he sat upright and plucked the zither.

(Note: Yuan Xian was a disciple of Confucius, surnamed Yuan, given name Si, style Xian. A walled space of one rod on each side is called a “walled hut,” like a room of one square zhang. Covering a roof with grass is called “thatching.” Coarse cloth is called “he.” “Upright” means proper. Yuan Xian was poor, his room no more than a walled hut, thatched with grass, its hinge of mulberry wood, its door of mugwort. A broken jar served as a window. Husband and wife each occupied one room; when rain came, the floor grew damp, yet he played the zither for his own delight, knowing fate and content in poverty—this was his way.)

Zi Gong rode a grand horse, his inner robe deep blue and his outer robe white, his high carriage too wide for the lane, as he went to visit Yuan Xian.

(Note: Zi Gong was a disciple of Confucius, named Ci, skilled in speech and fond of splendor. His carriage canopy was white silk lined with deep blue, his horse and carriage so tall and broad that the lane could not accommodate them.)

Yuan Xian wore a hat of birch bark and slippers of untanned leather, leaned on a staff of bramble, and answered the door himself.

(Note: “Slippers” means worn shoes. He made his hat from birch bark, used a bramble staff, and, having no servant, answered the door himself.)

Zi Gong said: “Alas! Master, what ails you?”

Yuan Xian replied: “I have heard that to lack wealth is called poverty, while to study yet fail to practice is called ailment. Now I am poor, not ailing.”

Zi Gong stepped back, his face flushed with shame.

(Note: “Alas” is an exclamation of surprise. “Stepped back” describes his retreating manner. Confronted with frugality after extravagance, he felt ashamed.)

Yuan Xian smiled and said: “To act in hope of worldly favor, to make friends through cliques, to study for others’ sake, to teach for one’s own gain, to use benevolence and righteousness as a cloak for wickedness, to adorn oneself with carriages and horses—these are things I cannot bear to do.”

(Note: “Wickedness” means deceit. “Adorn” means embellishment. To chase worldly trends, to curry favor with cliques, to seek fame through study, to profit from teaching, to feign benevolence and righteousness for deceit, to flaunt carriages and horses—these are things a gentleman finds shameful and cannot bear to do.)

When Master Zeng dwelt in Wei, his padded robe had no outer layer, his complexion was rough and chapped, his hands and feet calloused.

(Note: His robe was stuffed with hemp, with no outer covering. “Rough and chapped” means weathered. Constant labor left his hands and feet calloused.)

For three days he did not light a fire, for ten years he did not make new clothes. When he straightened his hat, its cord snapped; when he grasped his lapel, his elbow showed; when he put on his shoes, the heels split.

(Note: Living in humble integrity, his household was impoverished. For three days he did not cook, for ten years he did not sew. The cord of his hat broke when he adjusted it; his sleeve tore when he grasped his lapel; his shoes split when he put them on.)

Yet as he dragged his hem and sang the *Odes of Shang*, his voice filled heaven and earth, as if issuing from metal and stone. The Son of Heaven could not make him a subject, nor could the feudal lords make him a friend.

(Note: His singing of the *Odes of Shang* was resonant and forceful, its meaning profound and vast, harmonizing with heaven and earth. His voice was pure and clear, attuned to metal and stone. His noble character transcended worldly rank, so the Son of Heaven could not employ him, nor the feudal lords befriend him.)

Thus, he who nurtures his will forgets his form; he who nurtures his form forgets profit; he who attains the Dao forgets his mind.

The scholar who guards his health does not harm his life for profit; the one who attains the Dao forgets the art of knowing through the mind.

Confucius said to Yan Hui, "Come here. Your family is poor and your station low—why do you not enter official service?"
Yan Hui replied, "I do not wish to serve. Beyond the outer wall, I have fifty *mu* of fields, enough to provide gruel and porridge; within the wall, ten *mu*, enough to yield silk and hemp. Playing the zither suffices for my amusement, and what I have learned of your Dao is enough for my joy. I do not wish to serve."
Confucius’s expression changed solemnly as he said, "Excellent is Hui’s resolve! I have heard that he who knows contentment does not burden himself with profit, and he who truly possesses himself is not dismayed by loss. He whose conduct is cultivated within feels no shame at lacking rank. I have long recited these words, but only now, through Hui, do I see them realized—this is my gain."

Prince Mou of Zhongshan said to Zhanzi, "Though my body dwells by rivers and seas, my heart lingers beneath the gates of Wei—what is to be done?"
Zhanzi replied, "Value life. When life is valued, profit becomes light."
Prince Mou of Zhongshan said, "Though I know this, I cannot overcome myself."
Zhanzi said, "If you cannot overcome yourself, then follow your nature—why should the spirit resent it? He who cannot overcome himself yet forcibly resists is doubly wounded. Such a doubly wounded man belongs not to the company of the long-lived."
Wei Mou was the son of a lord of ten thousand chariots; that he could withdraw to caves and cliffs was more difficult than for a commoner. Though he had not yet attained the Dao, he may be said to have grasped its intent.

Confucius was stranded between Chen and Cai, going seven days without cooked food. His gruel was made of wild greens without grain, his complexion wan and weary, yet he strummed the zither and sang in his chamber.
As Yan Hui picked vegetables, Zilu and Zigong said to one another, "The Master was twice exiled from Lu, his traces erased in Wei, his tree felled in Song, reduced to hardship in Shang and Zhou, besieged in Chen and Cai. Those who would kill him incur no blame; those who would trample him face no prohibition. Yet he never ceases his zither and song—can a gentleman be so shameless?"
Yan Hui could not respond and went in to tell Confucius. Confucius pushed aside the zither and sighed deeply, saying, "You and Ci are petty men. Summon them, and I will speak to them."
Zilu and Zigong entered.

Zilu said, "In such straits, one may truly be called destitute."
Confucius replied, "What words are these? The gentleman who is at one with the Dao is called 'at one'; he who is cut off from the Dao is called 'destitute.' Now I, Qiu, embrace the Dao of humaneness and rightness, yet encounter the calamities of a disordered age—how can I be called destitute? Thus, I look within and am not cut off from the Dao; I face adversity and do not lose my virtue. When the bitter cold arrives and frost and snow descend, it is then I know the flourishing of the pine and cypress. The straits of Chen and Cai—are they not a blessing for me?"

Confucius then crisply turned back to his zither and resumed his strumming and song, while Zilu, roused, took up his shield and danced. Zigong said, "I knew not the height of heaven nor the depth of earth! The ancients who attained the Dao found joy in adversity and joy in prosperity. What they rejoiced in was not adversity or prosperity, but the presence of virtue and power. Thus, adversity and prosperity are but the sequence of cold and heat, wind and rain."

For Xu You found delight by the Ying River, and Gong Bo found fulfillment on Qiu Peak. When Shun offered the world to his friend, the Northerner Wuze, Wuze said, "How strange is this ruler’s conduct! Dwelling in the furrows of the fields, yet frequenting Yao’s gate. Not content with this, he now seeks to sully me with his shameful conduct. I am ashamed to see him."

Thus he cast himself into the Clear and Cold Abyss.

Confucius said: "The scholar whose will is set upon benevolence will sacrifice his life to transform others, but will not seek survival at the cost of benevolence." Those whose aspirations soar toward purity and transcendence, whose lofty conduct distances them from the world, stand apart from those who drown their lives in the pursuit of profit—such is the distinction ordained by heaven and earth.

The man of the north was named Wuze, a friend of Shun. *Hou* means "ruler." The raised part of a field is called a *mu*; the furrow is called a *quan*. The Clear and Cold Abyss lies within the borders of Xie County in Nanyang. Shun tilled the land at Mount Li, grew up among the furrows, and frequented the gates of Yao, receiving Yao’s abdication—were his deeds not thus? Yet he sought to smear me with his shameful conduct. Overcome with humiliation, Wuze cast himself into the Clear and Cold Abyss.

When Tang was about to strike down Jie, he consulted Bian Sui, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who, then, is fit for it?" Bian Sui replied, "I do not know." Tang then consulted Wu Guang, who said, "This is not my affair." Tang asked, "Who, then, is fit for it?"

Wu Guang replied, "I do not know." Tang asked, "What of Yi Yin?" Wu Guang said, "He is strong and enduring, able to bear disgrace—beyond that, I know nothing."

[Commentary] Bian was the surname, Sui the given name; Wu was the surname, Guang the given name. Both were men who embraced the Dao, recluses. Tang, recognizing their worth, consulted them on his plans. Since such matters were not the business of recluses, they answered that they did not know. Yi was the surname, Yin the given name, Zhi the courtesy name—a worthy man who aided the age. *Ren* means "to endure"; *gou* means "disgrace." To halt the use of arms, one requires a man of great strength; to slay a ruler, one needs a man who can bear shame. As for his other abilities, I know nothing of them.

Thereupon, Tang and Yi Yin plotted to strike down Jie, and succeeded. Tang then offered the throne to Bian Sui, who declined, saying: "When you plotted against Jie, you consulted me—you must have thought me a villain. Now that you have defeated Jie and offer me the throne, you must think me greedy. I live in an age of chaos, and a man without the Way has twice sought to smear me with his shameful conduct. I cannot bear to hear such things again." He then cast himself into the Chou River and died.

[Commentary] *Man* means "to smear." The Chou River lies within the borders of Yingchuan Prefecture. The character is also written as *tong*.

Tang then offered the throne to Wu Guang, saying: "The wise devise the plan, the martial carry it out, and the benevolent take the throne—this is the Way of antiquity."

"Why do you not take the throne yourself?" Wu Guang declined, saying: "To depose a ruler is not righteous; to kill the people is not benevolent. Others bear the hardship, while I enjoy the gain—this is not integrity."

[Commentary] *Enjoy* means "to receive." *Depose a ruler* refers to the banishment of Jie. *Kill the people* refers to the warfare. *Others bear the hardship* means suffering execution. *I enjoy the gain* means receiving emoluments. I have heard it said: one who does not act righteously does not accept its emoluments; in an age without the Way, one does not tread its soil—how much less would I accept such an honor? I cannot bear to witness this any longer." He then carried a stone and drowned himself in the Lu River.

[Annotation] An old account says: "Those like Bian Sui and Wu Guang regarded the world as beyond the six directions, something others could not comprehend." This is mistaken. One who treats the world lightly cannot hold anything in esteem; if nothing is held in esteem, there is no cause for which to die. To regard the world as beyond the six directions is to leave it to the likes of Yao, Shun, Tang, and Wu. Detached and unencumbered, they drift with the multitude, unconcerned with gain or loss—why would they cast themselves away? If these two men are to be praised, it is for their pursuit of fame and admiration of loftiness, not for placing the world beyond their concern.

[Commentary] The Lu River lies within the borders of Beiping Prefecture in Liaoxi. When the Zhou arose, there were two gentlemen dwelling in Guzhu, named Boyi and Shuqi. The two said to each other: "We have heard there is a man in the west who seems to possess the Way. Let us go and observe him."

[Commentary] Guzhu was a state in Liaoxi. Boyi and Shuqi, brothers who yielded their right to the throne, heard that King Wen possessed the Way, so they went to observe him. The deeds of Boyi and Shuqi have already been explained in the *Outer Chapters*. When they reached Qiyang, King Wu heard of them and sent Shu Dan to meet them. He made a covenant with them, saying: "I will raise your rank two grades and appoint you to an official post." They smeared the covenant with sacrificial blood and buried it.

[Commentary] Qiyang is the southern side of Mount Qi, where King Wen established his capital—now Fufeng. The Duke of Zhou, named Dan, was King Wu’s younger brother, hence called Shu Dan. At that time, King Wen had already passed, and King Wu had ascended the throne. Preparing to strike down Zhou, he sought to win over worthy men, so he sent the Duke of Zhou to make a covenant with them, promising to raise their emoluments two grades and appoint them to an official rank. They smeared the covenant with sacrificial blood and buried it beneath the altar. The two men looked at each other and laughed, saying: "Hah! How strange! This is not what we call the Way."

In ancient times, when Shennong ruled the world, his seasonal sacrifices were performed with utmost reverence yet without prayers for blessings. In his dealings with the people, he was loyal and trustworthy, governing to perfection without seeking anything in return.

When joy governed the administration, it was true governance; when joy governed the order, it was true order. He did not complete himself through others’ ruin, nor exalt himself through others’ lowliness, nor profit himself through the opportunities of the age.

Now, seeing the chaos of Yin, Zhou hastily established its rule. Those above schemed while those below traded in bribes; they relied on military force to preserve their might, slaughtered sacrificial animals to swear covenants as pledges of trust, flaunted their conduct to please the masses, and resorted to killing and warfare to seize advantage—this is but replacing one form of chaos with another.

I have heard that the scholars of old, when encountering an age of order, did not shirk their duties; when facing an age of disorder, they did not cling to mere survival. Today, the world is in turmoil, and Zhou’s virtue has declined. To align myself with Zhou would only sully my conduct—better to withdraw and preserve my integrity.

The two men journeyed north to Mount Shouyang, where they ultimately starved to death. As for Boyi and Shuqi, when it came to wealth and rank, if it could be avoided, they would never rely upon it. With lofty principles and unyielding conduct, they rejoiced in their own resolve, refusing to serve the world—such was the integrity of these two scholars.

The overarching intent of this passage is to inspire a spirit of noble yielding and distant retreat. Those touched by this ethos—even the greedy and grasping, who ride the celestial thoroughfares and enter the imperial courts—may yet sigh in mid-journey, let alone ordinary men. Thus, the likes of Yi and Xu are worthy to stand alongside Hou Ji and Yi Yin, to be compared with Yi and Lü.

Those who dwell in mountain valleys yet magnify the world—though they may not all become sagely ministers, are they not still loftier than those mired in dust and grime? Their deeds may be difficult to emulate, yet their influence is less prone to corruption, and thus worthy of transmission.

It is asked: Where does the true value of Yi and Xu lie?
It is said: The flaw of Xu You lies in leading men to feign yielding in pursuit of advancement, culminating in the likes of Zihuai. The legacy of Boyi, however, emboldens tyrannical rulers to unleash their poison without fear of resistance. The flaw of Yi and Lü lies in emboldening the world’s greedy and ambitious to dare usurpation and rebellion. Only the sage leaves no trace, and thus incurs no flaw.

If Yi and Lü are deemed the sage’s path of advancement, then Boyi and Shuqi are also the sage’s trace. If Boyi and Shuqi are not the sage’s trace, then the deeds of Yi and Lü are likewise not those of a sage.

The sage follows the natural course of things, leaving no trace. Thus, the so-called sage is one who fundamentally leaves no trace—things attain their trace, and when a trace is attained, the name "sage" is forcibly applied. Therefore, the sage is but the name for one who leaves no trace.
