*Annotations to the Nan Hua True Scripture*, Scroll Thirty-One
Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan

**Exegesis by Tang Dynasty Master Cheng Xuanying of Xihua on the Miscellaneous Chapters**
*Chapter Twenty-Nine: "Robber Zhi"*

Confucius was a friend of Liuxia Ji. Liuxia Ji’s younger brother was named Dao Wei. Robber Zhi led a band of nine thousand men, rampaging across the world, invading and oppressing the feudal lords. They broke into chambers and pried open doors, drove off people’s oxen and horses, and seized their wives and daughters. Greed made them forget their kin; they paid no heed to parents or brothers and did not offer sacrifices to their ancestors. Wherever they passed, the great states fortified their cities, the small states took refuge in their strongholds, and the myriad people suffered under them.

**[Exegesis]**
His surname was Zhan, given name Qin, courtesy name Ji. He received his fief at Liuxia, hence he was called Liuxia Ji. It is also said that he dwelled beneath a willow tree, and thus took it as his sobriquet. Zhan Qin lived during the reign of Duke Zhuang of Lu, over a hundred years after Confucius—yet they are spoken of as friends, for this is a parable.

Zhi was the name of Qin’s younger brother, who was ever a great robber, hence the name Robber Zhi. They tunneled through chambers and loosed door pivots to seize people’s oxen and horses. Some versions write this as *kong* (empty) or *qu* (drive).

A *bao* was a small walled town. The harm he wrought was so vast that the common folk were utterly afflicted.

Confucius said to Liuxia Ji: “As a father, one must be able to instruct one’s son; as an elder brother, one must be able to teach one’s younger brother. If a father cannot admonish his son, nor an elder brother teach his younger brother, then the bond of father and son, elder and younger brother, is worthless. Now, sir, you are a man of talent in this age, yet your younger brother is Robber Zhi, a scourge upon the world, and you have not been able to teach him. I am secretly ashamed for you. Allow me to go and persuade him on your behalf.”

Liuxia Ji replied: “You say that a father must be able to instruct his son, and an elder brother must be able to teach his younger brother. But if a son will not heed his father’s admonitions, nor a younger brother accept his elder brother’s teachings, what can even your eloquence accomplish? Moreover, Zhi is such a man: his mind surges like a spring, his thoughts scatter like the whirlwind. His strength suffices to repel foes, his eloquence suffices to gloss over wrongs. He is pleased when his will is followed, enraged when it is crossed, and easily provoked by words. You must not go.”

Confucius would not listen. Yan Hui drove the carriage, and Zigong stood at his right. They went to see Robber Zhi, who was then resting his troops on the southern slope of Mount Tai, mincing human livers to eat.

**[Exegesis]**
*Bū* means “to eat.” Zigong verified the carriage, standing at its right.

Confucius alighted and stepped forward. He addressed the herald, saying: “I, Kong Qiu of Lu, have heard of the general’s lofty virtue and come with respect to bow twice before the herald.” The herald went in to announce him. When Robber Zhi heard this, he flew into a great rage. His eyes blazed like stars, his hair bristled to lift his cap. He said: “Is this not that crafty, deceitful man Kong Qiu of Lu? Tell him this: You fabricate words and invent phrases, falsely invoking Kings Wen and Wu. You wear a cap like a tree’s branches and gird yourself with the flanks of a dead ox. You spout a torrent of specious arguments, eating without tilling, clothing yourself without weaving. You flap your lips and wag your tongue, stirring up right and wrong to delude the lords of the world, so that scholars everywhere abandon their roots and recklessly perform filial piety and brotherly respect in hopes of attaining enfeoffment and riches. You have traveled endlessly to seek office, and Jie Yu mocked you with his song of the phoenix. You have forsaken your origins and lingered in vain pursuits, and Shi Jin ridiculed you with his metaphor of the straw dog. Your crimes are grave and weighty. Flee at once, or I shall add your liver to my evening meal.”

Confucius sent word again: “I am fortunate to be counted a friend of your elder brother. I wish only to gaze upon the hem of your tent.”

**[Exegesis]**
He meant: “I am most fortunate to be a friend of your worthy elder brother. I dare not look directly upon your countenance but wish only to tread beneath the edge of your tent.” Some versions write this as *qí* (footprint). *Qí* means the mark of a footstep. “To tread in your footsteps” is like saying “to look upon your feet.”

The herald relayed this message. Robber Zhi said: “Let him come forward.” Confucius hastened forward, stepped back from his mat, and bowed twice to Robber Zhi. Robber Zhi was enraged. He stretched out his legs, gripped his sword, glared fiercely, and roared like a nursing tiger: “Come closer, Qiu. If your words please me, you shall live; if they cross me, you shall die.”

Confucius said: “I have heard that there are three virtues in the world: To be born and grow tall, surpassingly handsome and peerless, so that young and old, high and low, all delight in seeing you—this is the highest virtue. To comprehend the workings of Heaven and Earth and distinguish all things—this is the middle virtue. To be fierce, resolute, and bold, gathering troops and leading armies—this is the lowest virtue. Whoever possesses even one of these virtues is fit to face south and call himself ‘Solitary.’ Now, General, you possess all three: your body stands eight feet and two inches tall, your face and eyes radiate light, your lips are as bright as cinnabar, your teeth are as even as rows of cowrie shells, your voice rings like the Yellow Bell, yet you are called Robber Zhi. I am secretly ashamed for you and urge you to reconsider.”

The Yellow Bell is one of the six pitch-pipes. If you, General, are willing to heed my counsel, I shall journey south to Wu and Yue, north to Qi and Lu, east to Song and Wei, and west to Jin and Chu, to have a great city of several hundred *li* built for you, with a settlement of hundreds of thousands of households, and to honor you as a feudal lord. Together with the world, we shall begin anew, disband your troops, rest your soldiers, gather and nurture your brothers, and jointly worship our ancestors. This is the conduct of a sage and a man of talent, and the wish of all under Heaven.

Robber Zhi retorted: "Come forward, Qiu! Those who can be swayed by profit or admonished by words are but the foolish and vulgar masses. As for my towering stature and striking beauty, which delight all who see me—these are the legacy of my parents’ virtue. Though you do not praise me, do I not know myself? Moreover, I have heard that those who flatter others to their faces are also wont to slander them behind their backs. Now you tell me of great cities and teeming multitudes—this is but to entice me with profit and treat me as a commoner to be herded. How could such a thing endure?

A great city cannot last forever. The greatest of cities is none other than the realm itself. Yao and Shun ruled all under Heaven, yet their descendants had not even a foothold to call their own. Tang and Wu ascended as Son of Heaven, yet their posterity was cut off and extinguished. Was this not because the profit was too great?

Furthermore, I have heard that in ancient times, beasts were many and men were few. Thus, the people dwelled in nests to avoid them, gathering acorns by day and roosting in trees by night. They were called the people of the Nest-Builder. In those days, the people knew not clothing; they piled up firewood in summer and warmed themselves by it in winter. They were called the people who knew how to live. In the age of Shennong, they lay at ease and rose content, knowing only their mothers and not their fathers, dwelling among the elk and deer. They tilled the soil to eat and wove to clothe themselves, harboring no thought of harming one another. This was the height of perfect virtue. Yet even the Yellow Emperor could not uphold such virtue: he fought Chiyou on the plains of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao and Shun arose and established a multitude of ministers.

Tang exiled his lord—[exiled Jie to Nanchao]—while King Wu killed Zhou—[the battle at Chaoge]. Thereafter, the strong oppressed the weak, and the many tyrannized the few. Since the time of Tang and Wu, all have been men of disorder—[their conquests and usurpations, Tang and Wu most egregious]. Now you cultivate the Way of Wen and Wu, wielding the world’s discourse to instruct later generations—[Confucius modeled himself on Wen and Wu, expounding on benevolence and righteousness to teach posterity]. Clad in sewn robes and narrow sashes, you utter artful words and feign virtuous conduct to delude the lords of the world, seeking only wealth and rank. No thief is greater than you. Why does the world not call you "Robber Qiu" and instead call me "Robber Zhi"?

You used honeyed words to persuade Zilu to follow you, making him remove his towering cap and lay aside his long sword to receive your teachings. The world all says that Confucius can quell violence and forbid wrongdoing—[the towering cap and long sword were the attire of the brave]. Once he submitted to your teachings, he cast them aside. In the end, Zilu sought to kill the lord of Wei but failed, and his body was minced upon the eastern gate of Wei. This was the result of your inadequate instruction—[Zhong You’s hatred of evil ran deep; his attempt to kill the Wei lord, Ju Ji, failed, and he was hacked to pieces. Robber Zhi thus mocked him].

Do you consider yourself a man of talent and a sage? Yet you were twice exiled from Lu, your traces erased in Wei, impoverished in Qi, besieged in Chen and Cai, and found no refuge in the world. You taught Zilu to meet this fate—unable to preserve himself above or benefit others below. Is your Way truly worthy of esteem?

Of those the world exalts, none surpasses the Yellow Emperor, yet even he could not uphold perfect virtue. He fought on the plains of Zhuolu, and blood flowed for a hundred *li*. Yao was unfilial—[he did not pass the throne to his son, Dan Zhu]. Shun was undutiful—[his father despised him]. Yu was afflicted with hemiplegia—[his toil in governing the waters, enduring wind and rain, left him with a paralyzed half-body]. Tang exiled his lord, King Wu slew Zhou, and King Wen was imprisoned at Youli—[Youli, a prison of Yin. King Wen suffered Zhou’s calamity, confined for nearly seven years before escaping]. These six—[the Yellow Emperor, Yao, Shun, Yu, Tang, and King Wen]—are those the world reveres. Yet upon examination, all were deluded by profit, violently distorting their true natures. Their conduct was deeply shameful—[these six, coveting the throne, strayed from the true Way and acted contrary to nature, thus deserving shame].

The world calls the worthies Boyi and Shuqi. Boyi and Shuqi—[the two]—renounced the rulership of Guzhu and starved to death on Mount Shouyang, their flesh and bones left unburied. Bao Jiao adorned his conduct to condemn the age and died embracing a tree—[the two perished on the mountain, leaving no descendants to bury them. His surname was Bao, given name Jiao, a recluse of the Zhou era. He refined his conduct to criticize the world, maintaining integrity and purity. He carried firewood and gathered faggots, subsisting on acorns, leaving no heirs. He would not serve the Son of Heaven nor befriend the feudal lords. When Zigong encountered him, he said: "I have heard that one who opposes a ruler’s governance should not tread upon his land, and one who defiles his lord should not accept his benefits. Now you tread upon this land and eat its bounty—is this permissible?" Bao Jiao replied: "I have heard that the steadfast scholar values advancement and scorns retreat, while the worthy feels shame easily and disdains death." He then embraced a tree and withered where he stood]. Shentu Di remonstrated but was not heeded; he carried a stone and cast himself into the river, where he was devoured by fish and turtles—[Shentu drowned himself; this was explained in an earlier passage. That he "remonstrated but was not heeded" lacks clear evidence; Cui’s commentary, though extensive, offers no definitive explanation].

Jie Zitui was the very model of loyalty: he cut flesh from his thigh to feed Duke Wen. Later, the duke betrayed him, and Zitui, enraged, departed and burned to death embracing a tree—[Duke Wen of Jin, Chong’er, fled the calamity of Li Ji and wandered abroad. On the road, starving, Zitui cut flesh from his thigh to feed him. Three days after the duke’s return, he rewarded his followers but forgot Zitui. Zitui composed the *Song of the Dragon and Serpent* and wrote it upon the duke’s gate, then fled in anger. The duke later felt remorse and pursued Zitui to Mount Jie. Zitui hid, so the duke set fire to the mountain, hoping he would flee. When the flames reached him, Zitui embraced a tree and burned to death]. Weisheng arranged to meet a woman beneath a bridge. When she did not come, the waters rose, but he would not leave. He embraced a bridge pillar and drowned.

These six—[Boyi, Shuqi, Bao Jiao, Shentu Di, Jie Zitui, and Weisheng]—differed not from dismembered dogs, drifting swine, or beggars clutching gourds. All pursued fame and scorned death, heedless of nurturing life’s root—[these six, failing to align with the profound Way, feigned conduct to stand apart from the world, seeking reputation to transmit to later ages. How do they differ from a dog torn apart, a pig adrift in the water, or a destitute man begging with a gourd? Such figures are not worthy of mention, yet the conduct of these six is no different. All valued fame over life, neglecting to return to the root and nourish their allotted span]. Some texts write "swine" as "death" and "run" as "beg"—read according to the character.

"Zuo shi" means "swine." Those whom the world calls loyal ministers—none surpass Prince Bigan and Wu Zixu. Zixu drowned in the river, Bigan had his heart carved out; these two, the world calls loyal ministers, yet in the end they were mocked by all under heaven.

From the perspective of one who has attained the Dao, even Zixu and Bigan are not worthy of esteem. What Confucius tells me—if he speaks of ghostly matters, I cannot know them; if he speaks of human affairs, it goes no further than this, all of which I have heard and understood. Now I tell you of human nature: the eye desires to see beauty, the ear to hear sound, the mouth to savor flavor, and the will to reach fulfillment.

Human life spans a hundred years at its longest, eighty in middle age, sixty at its shortest. Subtracting days lost to illness, emaciation, death, mourning, and sorrow, the time one opens their mouth to laugh amounts to no more than four or five days in a month. Heaven and earth are without end, but human death comes at its appointed time. Clutching this finite vessel and entrusting it to the boundless, one passes in an instant—no different from a swift steed galloping past a crack in the wall.

Those who cannot delight their will and nurture their allotted span are not those who comprehend the Dao. What Confucius says is all that I reject. Hurry, leave, and return—do not speak of it again. Your Way is frantic and insatiable, a craft of deceit and pretense, incapable of preserving truth. What is there to discuss?

Confucius bowed twice, hastened away, exited the gate, mounted his carriage, and three times lost hold of the reins. His eyes stared blankly, seeing nothing; his complexion was ashen, like the dead. Leaning against the crossbar, he hung his head, unable to catch his breath.

Upon returning to the eastern gate of Lu, he encountered Liuxia Ji. Liuxia Ji said, "Lately, you have been absent for several days, and your carriage bears signs of travel. Might you have gone to see Zhi?" Confucius looked to the sky and sighed, "Yes."

Liuxia Ji asked, "Did Zhi perhaps offend you as I warned before?" Confucius replied, "He did. I am what one might call one who moxibusts without illness—running to stroke a tiger’s head, braiding its whiskers, nearly escaping the tiger’s jaws."

Zizhang asked Mangou De, "Why not practice virtuous conduct?" Mangou De replied, "One without shame grows rich; one who speaks much gains prominence. The greatest of fame and profit lies in shamelessness and glibness. Thus, when one observes reputation and calculates profit, sincerity is truly the way."

If one abandons fame and profit, it runs counter to the heart. Therefore, the conduct of a scholar cannot go a single day without such pursuits.

Mangou De said, "The shameless grow wealthy, the voluble gain renown. The greatest of fame and profit nearly rests in shamelessness and glibness. Thus, when one observes reputation and calculates profit, glibness is truly the way."

If one abandons fame and profit, turning inward to the heart, then the conduct of a scholar embraces their Heavenly nature.

To embrace is to hold fast; Heavenly refers to the natural. The scholar who cultivates the Dao, establishing conduct and renouncing fame and profit, goes against the common heart, yet by holding fast to Heavenly truth, they align with the profound and mysterious Way.

Zizhang said: "In ancient times, Jie and Zhou were honored as Sons of Heaven, possessing all under Heaven. Yet if one were to say to a hoarder or thief, 'Your conduct is like Jie and Zhou’s,' they would flush with shame and harbor resentment—such is the disdain of petty men. Confucius and Mo Di, though impoverished commoners, if one were to say to a prime minister, 'Your conduct is like Confucius and Mo Di’s,' they would alter their expression and demeanor, declaring themselves unworthy—such is the true nobility of the scholar."

Jie, Zhou, Confucius, and Mo Di have all been discussed earlier. *Zang* refers to slaves; *ju* refers to thieves, the petty men of banditry. To compare a gentleman to a slave is to provoke shame and defiance; to compare a prime minister to a commoner is to elicit a change in countenance and joyful humility.

Thus, one knows that what is noble lies in conduct, not in rank. Therefore, though one may hold the power of the Son of Heaven, this does not necessarily make one noble; though one may be impoverished as a commoner, this does not necessarily make one base. The distinction between noble and base rests in the goodness or evil of one’s conduct.

This further explicates the preceding meaning. *Man Goude* said: “Petty thieves are imprisoned, while great thieves become feudal lords—yet at the gates of such lords, righteous scholars still dwell.” In ancient times, Duke Huan of Qi, Xiaobai, killed his elder brother and took his sister-in-law, yet Guan Zhong served as his minister. Tian Chengzi once murdered his lord and usurped the state, yet Confucius accepted his gifts. In speech, they are condemned as base; in action, they are deferred to—thus, the true sentiments of words and deeds wage war within the breast. Is this not perverse?

*Bei* means contrary; *fu* means perverse. Duke Huan of Qi, named Xiaobai, killed his elder brother, Zifu, and took his sister-in-law. Guan Zhong, a worthy man, served and aided him, ultimately uniting the feudal lords nine times and rectifying all under Heaven. Tian Chengzi murdered Duke Jian of Qi, yet Confucius, having bathed and dressed in court robes, accepted his worn silk. To kill one’s elder brother and take one’s sister-in-law, to murder one’s lord and usurp the state—no greater evil exists in human relations. Yet Yiwu served as minister, and the Master accepted his gifts. In speech, they are deemed vile and base; in conduct, they are humbly served. Is this not a war within the heart, a contradiction between words and deeds? Thus, the *Book* says: “Who is evil? Who is good? The successful become the head; the unsuccessful, the tail.”

The successful are made leaders and served; the unsuccessful are made tails and reviled. By this reasoning, it is only success or failure that matters, not whether one’s conduct is virtuous or not—thus, one cannot truly know who is good or evil. The *Book* cited has been lost to the fires, and no copies remain.

Zizhang said: “If one does not act with virtue, then kinship and estrangement will lack principle, noble and base will lack righteousness, elder and younger will lack order. How, then, can the Five Bonds and Six Positions be distinguished?”

*Qi* means kinship; *lun* means principle. The Five Bonds refer to grandfather, father, self, son, and grandson—or the Five Phases: Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, Earth—and the Five Virtues: benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and trust. The Six Positions refer to ruler and minister, father and son, husband and wife—or father, mother, elder brother, younger brother, husband, and wife. Zizhang said: “If one does not practice the conduct of benevolence and righteousness, then kinship and estrangement will lack principle, noble and base will lack righteousness, elder and younger will lack order, and the Five Bonds and Six Positions will have no means of distinction.”

*Man Goude* said: “Yao killed his eldest son; Shun exiled his younger brother of the same mother—where is the principle in kinship and estrangement?” Yao deposed his eldest son, Dan Zhu, denying him the throne—some say he killed him. Shun enfeoffed his younger brother, Xiang, in the state of Youbi, commanding the officials of all under Heaven to govern his land and collect his tribute—thus, it is called exile. In deposing a son and exiling a brother, where is the principle of kinship and estrangement? “Tang exiled Jie; King Wu killed Zhou—where is the righteousness in noble and base?” King Tang of Yin exiled the Xia tyrant Jie to Nanchao; King Wu of Zhou killed the Yin tyrant Zhou at Jijun—where is the righteousness in the distinction between ruler and minister, noble and base? “King Ji was the rightful heir, yet the Duke of Zhou killed his elder brother—where is the order in elder and younger?” King Ji was the youngest son of King Tai, father of King Wen. Taibo and Zhongyong yielded the throne and did not claim it, so the younger son, Jili, was made the rightful heir. The Duke of Zhou’s elder brothers, Guan and Cai, wept as they were executed—thus, it is said he killed them. In deposing the rightful heir and establishing a younger son, in a younger brother killing his elder brother—where is the order in seniority and rank? “The Confucians speak with hypocritical words; the Mohists practice universal love—how, then, can the Five Bonds and Six Positions be distinguished?” The Confucians often speak grandly, fabricating names and ranks; the Mohists practice impartial love, universal and without partiality—how can the Five Bonds and Six Positions be distinguished?

“Moreover, you rectify for the sake of reputation; I rectify for the sake of profit. In truth, neither reputation nor profit accords with principle or reflects the Dao.” *Jian* means clarity, perception. What Zizhang pursues is rectitude for the sake of reputation; what *Goude* pursues is rectitude for the sake of profit. Yet both paths of reputation and profit are not truly real—they violate the highest principle and fail to perceive the profound Dao.

“I daily debate with you before *Wu Yue*: the petty man dies for wealth; the gentleman dies for reputation. Though the emotions they alter and the natures they change differ, when it comes to abandoning what they do and dying for what they do not do, they are the same.” *Song* means to discourse; *yue* means a covenant. To abandon what one does is to forsake the self; to die for what one does not do is to pursue externals. To die for profit is called petty; to die for reputation is called noble—yet though reputation and profit differ, what they die for is the same.

Zizhang and *Goude* both discussed the profound words of non-action and the principle of effortless harmony, deepening their bond of mutual understanding. Thus it is said: “For the petty man to practice non-action is to turn back and die for Heaven; for the gentleman to practice non-action is to follow Heaven’s principle.” *Er* means “you.” Neither pursuing profit nor dying for reputation, one can follow one’s nature and return to the root, uniting with the Dao of spontaneity.

“Whether crooked or straight, assist and reach Heaven’s extremity; face the four directions and ebb and flow with the seasons.” *Xiang* means to assist. Without questioning crooked or straight, follow the Dao of spontaneity, observe the four directions, and move with the waxing and waning of the seasons. “Whether right or wrong, grasp the revolving mechanism; stand alone in intent and wander with the Dao.” *Paihuai* means to transform one’s intent. *Yuanji* means the center of the ring. Grasp the Dao of the revolving center to respond to right and wrong; employ the mind of solitary transformation to fulfill one’s intent—thus can one darkly comprehend the principle of emptiness and penetration, transforming without end.

Do not act with contrivance, nor establish virtue with deliberation, lest you lose what you seek to accomplish. The *Commentary* states: What you seek to accomplish is your true nature. Do not turn your will toward the conduct of sagely traces; do not perfect your heart in the learning of benevolence and righteousness. Abandoning the self to imitate others, you will lose your true nature.

Do not pursue wealth, nor strive for success, lest you forsake your Heavenly nature. The *Commentary* states: Do not rush toward wealth and honor, nor be consumed by the pursuit of success. To rush and strive is to turn away from the nature of spontaneity. Bi Gan’s heart was carved out, and Wu Zixu’s eyes were gouged—these were the calamities of loyalty. The *Commentary* states: Bi Gan remonstrated with King Zhou, who said, “I have heard that the heart of a sage has seven apertures,” and so he cut open Bi Gan’s heart to examine it. Wu Zixu remonstrated with King Fuchai, who killed him. Wu Zixu said, “After my death, gouge out my eyes and hang them on the eastern gate of Wu to witness Yue’s destruction of Wu.” These were all cases of utmost loyalty meeting with disaster.

Zhigong testified against his father, and Weisheng drowned—these were the perils of trustworthiness. The *Commentary* states: Zhigong’s father stole a sheep, and his son bore witness against him. Weisheng had arranged to meet a woman, and when she did not come, he held onto a bridge pillar and drowned. These were all cases of upholding trustworthiness leading to misfortune. Baozi stood upright until he withered, and Crown Prince Shen did not defend himself—these were the harms of integrity. The *Commentary* states: Bao Jiao was incorruptibly upright; when Zigong mocked him, he embraced a tree and stood until he withered and died. Crown Prince Shen was the eldest son of Duke Xian of Jin. When he was slandered by Lady Li, he was falsely accused and did not defend himself, hanging himself in the end.

Confucius did not see his mother, and Kuang Zhang did not see his father—these were the failures of righteousness. The *Commentary* states: Confucius was engrossed in sagely traces, traveling through states to answer summons. When his mother was on her deathbed, Confucius did not see her. Kuang Zhang, a man of Qi, remonstrated with his father, who did not heed him. Hated by his father, he traveled to another city, where he was so absorbed in studying benevolence and righteousness that he forgot to return. When his father was on his deathbed, Kuang Zhang did not see him. These were all cases of being submerged in benevolence and righteousness, leading to such faults.

These are the traditions of the upper ages and the talk of later generations, by which those who would be scholars rectify their words and verify their conduct—yet they still suffer calamity and encounter misfortune. The *Annotation* states: This chapter speaks of valuing conduct, which leads to artificiality, and esteeming scholars, which leads to pretense. Thus, one must despise conduct and belittle scholars to preserve one’s inner integrity; only then can conduct be lofty and scholars esteemed. The *Commentary* states: From Bi Gan to Kuang Zhang, all suffered disaster for their loyalty, trustworthiness, integrity, and uprightness. These are the traditions handed down from ancient times and the talk of later generations. Thus, those who are loyal and sincere, incorruptible and trustworthy—rectifying their words to remonstrate with their lords and verifying their conduct to serve their rulers—all encounter misfortune and suffer calamity. Those who would follow the Dao must be deeply cautious.

Wu Zu asked Zhi He: “There has never been a person who did not seek fame and pursue profit. The wealthy attract followers; followers humble themselves, and the humble are esteemed. To be humbled and esteemed is the Dao of long life, bodily ease, and joyful contentment. Yet you alone have no such intention. Is your wisdom insufficient? Or do you know but lack the strength to act? Or do you deliberately reject it without forgetting?” The *Commentary* states: Wu Zu refers to those who are insatiably greedy. Zhi He refers to one who embodies the Dao of harmony, a person of integrity who knows his limits. The two are set in contrast to illustrate the fortunes and misfortunes of greed and integrity.

Wu Zu said: “No one in the world fails to seek fame and pursue profit. The wealthy attract followers; followers humble themselves and esteem them. To be humbled and esteemed brings joy to one’s nature, aligns with one’s disposition, and ensures bodily ease and longevity. Do you truly have no desire for wealth and honor? Is it that you know contentment and do not seek them? Or do you know but lack the strength to act, so you deliberately reject them without forgetting the desire for honor and gain?”

Zhi He replied: “Now, these people—those born in the same era and dwelling in the same village as oneself—consider themselves transcendent, surpassing the world. Yet they are without principle or rectitude, merely observing the times and distinguishing right from wrong, conforming to custom. The *Commentary* states: These people refer to the wealthy. The vulgar are those without wisdom, whose greed for profit is intense. Those born in the same era and dwelling in the same village as the wealthy consider themselves transcendent, surpassing the world—how much more so those who enjoy wealth and honor themselves. These are foolish people without inner guidance, who do not follow the right path. They do not perceive the eras of past and present, nor discern the boundaries of right and wrong, but compete with the dust of the world, shifting with its currents. How can they recognize the outcomes of fortune and misfortune?

They abandon what is most weighty and forsake what is most noble, all for the sake of their pursuits. How far this is from the Dao of long life, bodily ease, and joyful contentment! The *Commentary* states: What is most weighty is life; what is most noble is the Dao. The vulgar abandon life and turn their backs on the Dao, acting in this way in all things. How distant they are from the Dao of long life!

The pain of sorrow and the ease of joy are not reflected in the body; the fear of alarm and the delight of happiness are not reflected in the heart. The *Commentary* states: Sorrow and joy, fear and delight are all external matters, unable to illuminate the sage’s form or penetrate the heart’s spirit. Yet the foolish act upon them blindly. They know what they do but not why they do it. Thus, though they may be honored as Son of Heaven and possess all under Heaven, they cannot escape misfortune.”

The *Commentary* states: "To act" is to engage in deliberate action; "the reason for acting" is non-action. They know only how to act through deliberate action but do not understand that the source of action lies in non-action. Such people, though they may hold the reins of ten thousand affairs and command the wealth of the four seas, cannot escape the misfortunes of alarm and dread.

Wu Zu said: Wealth, for men, is advantageous in every way. It exhausts beauty and exhausts power—what even the perfected cannot attain, what the worthy cannot match.
The *Commentary* states: To exhaust all the world’s goodness and beauty, to command all human might and influence—what is this if not wealth and nobility? Thus, even those of utmost virtue and the wisest sages cannot surpass it.

They wield the bravery and strength of others to bolster their own might, they grasp the wisdom and schemes of others to sharpen their own discernment, they rely on the virtue of others to adorn their own excellence. Though they do not rule a state, their stern authority rivals that of a sovereign or father.
The *Commentary* states: The wealthy and noble attract many to their side. Thus, the brave defend them, the wise counsel them, the virtuous assist them. Though they do not govern a realm, their majesty and severity are like those of a ruler or father—all this is brought about by the power of wealth.

Moreover, the allure of music, beauty, fine flavors, and power over men—these delight the heart without need of learning, and the body finds ease in them without need of imitation.
The *Commentary* states: The ear delights in sound, the eye in beauty, the mouth in rich flavors, and the heart in authority and influence—these please the mind without instruction, and the body finds comfort in them without following any model. Such is the nature of man.

Desire and aversion, avoidance and pursuit—these do not wait upon a teacher. This is the nature of man. Though all under heaven may reject me, who can refuse them?
The *Commentary* states: To pursue what one desires and avoid what one dislikes is the common nature of all beings. It does not require a teacher to know this. Though the world may oppose Wu Zu, who alone would dispute or reject this?

Zhi He said: The actions of the wise move in accord with the people, never transgressing their measure. Thus, contentment brings no strife, and non-action yields no seeking.
The *Commentary* states: The wise, with empty hearts, respond to things. Thus, their conduct and movements take the people’s hearts as their own. The people follow them, never transgressing the proper measure. Their minds are perfectly at ease, so they do not contend. They act without deliberate effort, so they neither seek nor perceive.

Those who lack contentment seek it, contending in all four directions yet never deeming themselves greedy. Those with surplus renounce it, casting aside the world yet never deeming themselves modest.
The *Commentary* states: The four directions are the four quarters of the earth. The distinction between the common and the sage lies in greed and modesty. Thus, they vie for the four quarters, racing across the eight wilds, never recognizing their own rapacity. They abandon the throne of the Son of Heaven, declining the ninefold dignity, yet never recognizing their own restraint. The truth of modesty and greed does not come from external pressure—it is a reflection of one’s inner measure.
The *Commentary* states: To reflect is to illuminate. The fulfillment of one’s nature is not forced by external things. When one turns inward, each follows a different measure.

They may hold the position of Son of Heaven yet not use their nobility to intimidate others; they may possess all under heaven yet not use their wealth to toy with others. They weigh the harm, consider the consequences, and see it as injurious to their nature. Thus, they decline and do not accept—not to seek fame.
The *Commentary* states: Those who do not use their lofty status to dominate or their riches to amuse do so because they calculate the disasters and fear harm to their true nature. Thus, they decline the greatest treasure and do not accept it—not to pursue reputation.

Yao and Shun ruled as emperors and brought harmony, yet this was not out of benevolence toward the world, but to avoid allowing beauty to harm their lives. Shan Juan and Xu You were offered the throne yet refused it—not out of empty humility, but to avoid allowing affairs to harm themselves. All of them pursued what benefited them and declined what harmed them. Though the world calls them worthy, they did not act to cultivate fame.
The *Commentary* states: Harmony means peace. The governance of Yao and Shun brought peace to all under heaven—not out of a desire for benevolence, but to avoid allowing splendor to harm their lives. Shan Juan and Xu You were offered the throne yet refused it—not out of false humility, but to avoid allowing worldly affairs to harm themselves. All pursued the benefit of long life and declined the harm of usurpation and strife. Thus, the world calls them worthy, and they may be said to have had this mind of avoiding harm—but they had no intention of seeking fame.

Wu Zu said: If one clings to reputation, tortures the body, rejects sweetness, and practices austerity to preserve life, one is no different from one who suffers chronic illness and endless hardship yet does not die.
The *Commentary* states: If one stubbornly seeks to cultivate reputation, torments the body, rejects sweetness, and practices strict restraint to preserve life, how is this different from one who endures long illness and unending hardship, living as if already dead?

These are the words of Wu Zu, challenging Zhi He.

Zhi He said: Balance brings fortune, while excess brings harm—this is true of all things, and wealth is the most extreme case.
The *Commentary* states: Balance brings blessings, while excess invites disaster—this is the natural principle of heaven. All things are thus, but wealth is the most extreme.

Now, the rich man’s ears are filled with the sounds of bells, drums, pipes, and flutes; his mouth savors the flavors of fine meats and rich wines, stirring his mind and causing him to neglect his duties. This may be called disorder.
The *Commentary* states: To savor is to find satisfaction. Pipes and flutes are types of bamboo instruments. The wealthy indulge their passions without restraint: their mouths delight in rich wines, their ears in music, their choices clouding their minds and disturbing their senses. Their natures grow dull, their duties forgotten, and they remain unaware—is this not disorder?

Engulfed in pent-up qi, it is as if one carries a heavy burden while ascending a slope—this may be called suffering.
The *Commentary* states: Pent-up qi is akin to frustration and vexation. When greed and desire grow excessive, toil and exhaustion ensue, the heart becomes stifled, and one sinks into resentment—like climbing a steep incline with a weight upon one’s back. Such weariness—is this not suffering indeed?

Craving wealth brings only consolation, craving power brings only depletion; in stillness one drowns, in bodily ease one seethes—this may be called affliction.
The *Commentary* states: Coveting treasures to soothe the heart, scheming for authority to exhaust the mind; in quiet repose the body sinks into torpor, in physical comfort resentment arises. Whether in motion or stillness, such hardship—is this not affliction?

Driven by the desire for wealth and profit, one’s ears are filled like a wall, yet one does not know to retreat; clinging to pent-up qi without release—this may be called disgrace.
The *Commentary* states: A wall is a barrier. The craving for wealth and profit is like an insatiable abyss, akin to a wall built ever higher. The heart seethes with frustration, greed unrelenting, blind to danger—is this not shameful?

Wealth accumulates yet goes unused, clung to without release; the heart brims with vexation, the pursuit of more unceasing—this may be called sorrow.
The *Commentary* states: Vexation is distress. Hoarded yet not spent, pent-up yet not resolved, greed knows no limit, and the heart overflows with turmoil. Upon reflection—is this not sorrow?

Within, one fears the threat of plunderers; without, one dreads the harm of bandits. Doors are barred and towers fortified, one dares not venture out alone—this may be called fear.
The *Commentary* states: Fear is terror. To seek is to demand. "A man without guilt may yet be condemned for the jade he carries." Thus, at home one trembles at the thought of thieves, abroad one quakes before the threat of robbers. Gates are sealed, watchtowers erected, every entry and exit guarded, every coming and going fraught with dread—daring not walk alone. Such hardship—is this not fear?

These six—disorder, suffering, affliction, disgrace, sorrow, and fear—are the greatest harms under heaven. Yet one forgets them and fails to examine them; when calamity strikes, one exhausts one’s nature and squanders one’s wealth, and even a single day of carefree simplicity can no longer be regained.
The *Commentary* states: The six are disorder, suffering, affliction, disgrace, sorrow, and fear. To exhaust is to deplete. The greatest harms under heaven are forgotten and unexamined; when bandits suddenly strike, life hangs by a thread, a lifetime of greed undone in an instant, all wealth and treasures gone in a moment. Could one ever return to a day of humble poverty? Thus, when one looks for fame, it is nowhere to be seen; when one seeks profit, it cannot be found. Yet the mind remains entangled, still contending for these—is this not delusion?
The *Annotation* states: This chapter speaks of how those who know contentment are ever content.
The *Commentary* states: Entangled is to be ensnared. When bandits strike, one’s very body is no longer one’s own. In such a moment, where is fame or profit to be found? Yet the common folk, so utterly inverted, remain ensnared by fame and profit, their hearts set on contention. By this measure—is this not the height of delusion?

The *Southern Florescence Canon: Annotated and Subcommented* (Volume Thirty-Two)
*Annotations by Guo Xiang of Henan*
*Subcommentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of the Western Florescence, Tang Dynasty*

**Miscellaneous Chapters: "Discourse on Swords" (Chapter Thirty)**

In former times, King Wen of Zhao delighted in swords. Over three thousand swordsmen, lodging as retainers, thronged his gates, clashing day and night before him. Each year, more than a hundred perished or were wounded—yet his passion knew no satiation. Thus it continued for three years, until the state declined and the feudal lords plotted against him.

*Subcommentary:* King Hui of Zhao, named He, was the son of King Wuling. Fond of swordsmen, he maintained three thousand retainers, his desire insatiable. As his state weakened, the feudal lords, perceiving his lack of the Way, conspired together, intending to attack.

The crown prince, Kui, grew anxious and offered a reward to his attendants: "Whoever can persuade the king to abandon his fondness for swordsmen shall receive a thousand gold pieces." His attendants replied, "Zhuangzi would be capable of this."

*Subcommentary:* Kui was the name of the Zhao crown prince. Distressed by his father’s obsession with warfare, he sought to offer a thousand gold pieces to recruit a persuasive scholar. Zhuangzi, being a great worthy, would surely be able to halt the king’s passion for swords.

The crown prince then sent an emissary bearing a thousand gold pieces to present to Zhuangzi. Zhuangzi declined the gift but accompanied the emissary to see the crown prince, asking, "What instruction does the crown prince have for Zhou, and why grant him a thousand gold pieces?" The crown prince replied, "I have heard that you, Master, are enlightened and sagely. I humbly offer this thousand gold as provisions for your attendants. Since you have declined, how dare I speak further?"

*Subcommentary:* "What matter do you wish to instruct me in, that you grant a thousand gold pieces?" Since the sum was substantial, he inquired. The crown prince said, "Having heard of Zhuangzi’s wisdom and sagacity, I present this thousand gold to serve as provisions for your retinue."

Zhuangzi said, "I have heard that what the crown prince wishes to employ me for is to end the king’s fondness for swords. If I were to persuade the king against his will and fail to satisfy the crown prince, I would face execution. How then could I concern myself with gold? But if I were to persuade the king and satisfy the crown prince, what in the state of Zhao could I not obtain?" The crown prince said, "Indeed. What my father sees are only swordsmen."

Zhuangzi replied, "Very well. I am skilled in the sword." The crown prince said, "Yet the swordsmen my father favors all have disheveled hair, bristling sideburns, and drooping caps; their cords are coarse, their robes short in the back. They glare fiercely and speak with difficulty—yet the king delights in them. If you, Master, were to appear before the king in Confucian garb, the matter would surely go awry."

*Subcommentary:* Their hair was wild as withered grass, their sideburns bristling; their iron caps drooped to obscure their faces. Their cords were of coarse hemp, their robes short in the back for ease in combat. With glaring eyes and fierce expressions, their voices were harsh and grating—such was the appearance and attire of these swordsmen.

Zhuangzi said, "Permit me to prepare the attire of a swordsman." After three days of preparation, he was presented to the crown prince, who then accompanied him to see the king. The king, bare blade in hand, awaited him.

Zhuangzi entered the palace gates without haste and did not bow upon seeing the king.

*Subcommentary:* One who is self-possessed harbors no fear within, and thus does not rush.

The king said, "What instruction do you wish to offer me, that the crown prince has spoken for you first?"

*Subcommentary:* "What method do you intend to use to admonish me, that the crown prince has already spoken to me on your behalf?"

Zhuangzi replied, "I have heard that Your Majesty delights in swords, and so I have come to present myself as a swordsman." The king asked, "What ability does your sword possess to restrain others?" Zhuangzi said, "My sword can slay one man every ten paces and traverse a thousand *li* without hindrance." The king, greatly pleased, exclaimed, "There would be none in the world to rival you!"

*Subcommentary:* His sword could kill a man every ten paces and travel a thousand *li* without pause—so swift and sharp was it that none could withstand it.

Zhuangzi said, "The art of the sword lies in presenting emptiness, opening with advantage, responding after the opponent moves, and arriving first. I wish to demonstrate this." The king said, "Master, rest and retire to your lodgings. I shall issue the command and arrange a contest to invite you."

*Subcommentary:* His words were pure and far-reaching, moving the king’s heart. Thus, the king bade him rest and retire to his quarters, awaiting the arrangement of a sword contest before summoning him.

The king then assembled swordsmen for seven days. Over sixty were killed or wounded, and five or six remained. These were ordered to present their swords at the foot of the palace steps, and Zhuangzi was summoned. The king said, "Today, let us test the swordsmen and have them engage in combat."

*Subcommentary:* *Dun* means "to sever." The king wished to array the swordsmen and have them compete to determine superiority.

Zhuangzi said, "I have long awaited this."

*Subcommentary:* He had long yearned for this opportunity and requested an early trial.

The king asked, "What length of weapon does the Master wield?" Zhuangzi replied, "Any weapon I am given will suffice."

*Subcommentary:* *Yu* means "to employ." The king, recognizing Zhuangzi’s skill in swordplay, thus inquired. "Yet I possess three swords, any of which Your Majesty may employ. Permit me to describe them before demonstrating."

The king said, "I wish to hear of the three swords." Zhuangzi replied, "There is the sword of the Son of Heaven, the sword of the feudal lords, and the sword of the commoner."

The king asked, "What is the sword of the Son of Heaven like?" Zhuangzi said, "The sword of the Son of Heaven has its point forged from Yanxi and Stone Fortress, its edge from Mount Tai of Qi."

*Subcommentary:* The *feng* is the tip of the sword; the *e* is its blade. Yanxi lies in the state of Yan; Stone Fortress is a mountain beyond the frontier. These northern lands form the sword’s point. Mount Tai of Qi, in the east, serves as its blade.

"Its spine is formed by Jin and Wei, its guard by Zhou and Song."

*Subcommentary:* The *tan* is the guard. Jin and Wei, being near Zhao, form the spine. Zhou and Song, lying to the south, serve as the guard.

"The states of Han and Wei form its hilt."

*Subcommentary:* The *jia* is the handle. The states of Han and Wei lie to the west of Zhao, thus serving as the handle.

"It encompasses the Four Barbarians and enfolds the Four Seasons."

*Subcommentary:* It embraces the Four Barbarians with virtue and power, and accords with the Four Seasons in generation and transformation.

"Its blade is tempered by the Bohai Sea, its belt girded by Mount Chang."

*Subcommentary:* The Bohai Sea is Cangzhou. Mount Chang is the Northern Marchmount. Within the workings of creation, mountains and seas stabilize the land.

"It is ordered by the Five Phases, judged by punishment and virtue."

*Subcommentary:* The Five Phases are Metal, Wood, Water, Fire, and Earth. Punishment refers to penal law; virtue, to moral transformation. By these Five Phases, the realm is governed; by punishment and virtue, all living things are guided.

"It is opened by yin and yang, sustained by spring and summer, and put into motion by autumn and winter."

*Subcommentary:* Yin and yang initiate; spring and summer uphold; autumn and winter enforce severity—such is the natural Dao.

"This sword, when thrust forward, knows no obstacle; when raised, nothing lies above it; when pressed down, nothing lies below it; when swung, nothing lies beside it. Above, it cleaves the floating clouds; below, it severs the earth’s foundations. Once this sword is employed, it rectifies the feudal lords, and all under heaven submits."

*Subcommentary:* When the sword is the Dao, nothing can contain it, for it extends without bound above, below, and on all sides. Floating clouds and earth’s foundations are but trifling matters. Since its work is that of creation itself, none dare resist. Such is the sword of the Son of Heaven."

King Wen, dazed and disoriented,

*Subcommentary:* One of limited capacity, upon hearing great truths, cannot grasp them—thus he grows dazed, as if crossing the sea, losing all sense of direction, much like King Hui of Wei upon hearing the *shao* music.

asked, "What of the sword of the feudal lords?"

Zhuangzi replied, "The sword of the feudal lords has its point forged from the wise and brave, its edge from the pure and incorruptible, its spine from the worthy and good, its guard from the loyal and sagely, and its hilt from the bold and eminent.

"This sword, too, when thrust forward, knows no obstacle; when raised, nothing lies above it; when pressed down, nothing lies below it; when swung, nothing lies beside it. Above, it models the round heavens to follow the Three Luminaries; below, it models the square earth to follow the Four Seasons; within, it harmonizes the people’s will to pacify the Four Quarters."

*Subcommentary:* The Four Quarters are the four directions. To emulate heaven and earth and comprehend the nature of all things—this is what sets the feudal lords apart. If one wields this sword to govern the state, none under heaven can withstand it. Once employed, it strikes like thunder, and within the four borders, none fail to submit and heed the ruler’s command. Such is the sword of the feudal lords."

*Subcommentary:* The *Yijing* associates the *Zhen* hexagram with the feudal lords, hence thunder symbolizes their authority.

The king asked, "What of the sword of the commoner?"

Zhuangzi replied, "The sword of the commoner is wielded by men with disheveled hair, bristling sideburns, slouching caps, tassels dangling, and short-backed robes. They glare fiercely and speak harshly, clashing before one another, slashing at necks above and piercing livers and lungs below. This sword of the commoner differs not from a cockfight—one day’s combat, and a life is lost. It serves no purpose in the affairs of state. Now, though Your Majesty occupies the throne of the Son of Heaven, you delight in the sword of the commoner. I humbly deem this unworthy of you."

*Subcommentary:* Zhuangzi’s eloquence surpasses all in ancient and modern times, and thus he persuades the King of Zhao to abandon his preference, guiding him toward the true essence of his teaching.

The king then led him up to the hall. The royal chef presented the feast, and the king circled him thrice.

*Subcommentary:* "Circled" means to encircle. The king, recognizing his own error, was deeply ashamed and remorseful. He commanded Zhuangzi to ascend the hall to express his contrition, circling the feast three times without being able to sit calmly—his breath grew labored and his heart heavy. How could he possibly eat?

Zhuangzi said: "May Your Majesty sit composed and steady your qi. The matter of the sword has now been resolved."

Thereupon, the king did not leave his palace for three months, and the swordsmen all died of resentment in their quarters.

*Subcommentary:* Having received no further rewards, they perished in bitterness.

*End of the thirty-second fascicle of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Zhu Shu

2. The Kōzan-ji edition includes the character "之" above "三剑."
3. In the Kōzan-ji edition, "魏" is written as "衛," consistent below.
4. In the Zhao Lianyi edition, "賢良" is written as "堅聖"; in the Shi De Tang edition and Zhao edition, "忠聖" is written as "忠勝"; in the Siku edition, "忠聖" is written as "忠直"; in the Siku edition, "豪桀" is written as "豪傑."

*Beginning of the thirty-third fascicle of the* Nan Hua Zhen Jing Zhu Shu
*Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Commentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of Xihua on the Miscellaneous Chapters: "The Fisherman," Chapter Thirty**

Confucius wandered through the forest of black canopies and rested, seated upon the Apricot Altar. His disciples read aloud, while Confucius plucked the zither and sang, the melody not yet half-finished.

*Subcommentary:* *Zi* (缁) means black. The Master traveled the world, expounding the *Book of Songs* and the *Book of Documents*. At times, by the riverside, he would rest amid the forest’s whispers. The woods were lush and dense, their foliage blocking the sun, casting deep shade, their hanging branches like curtains—hence the name, the Forest of Black Canopies. A *tan* (坛) is an elevated place in the marsh. As apricot trees grew there in abundance, it was called the Apricot Altar. The zither embodies harmony, capable of harmonizing the heart and nurturing the nature—thus he played it.

There was a fisherman who descended from his boat and approached. His temples and brows were white as frost, his hair unbound, his sleeves swaying as he walked. He ascended the plain, stopping at the shore, his left hand resting on his knee, his right hand cradling his chin as he listened. When the song ended,

*Subcommentary:* The fisherman was Fan Li, minister to the King of Yue. Having aided King Goujian in defeating Wu, he boarded a small boat and roamed the Three Rivers and Five Lakes, changing his name to the Fisherman—this was the man encountered here. Later, he crossed the sea to Qi, where he was called Master Yayi; in Lu, he was known as Master White Jade; in Tao, he became Lord Zhu. Concealing his brilliance and obscuring his traces, he adapted to the times, even sending a letter to Minister Zhong. *Yu* (揄) means to wave; *mei* (袂), the sleeve. *Yuan* (原) refers to high, level ground; *ju* (距), to arrive. Hair and brows white as snow mark the visage of the long-lived; unbound hair and no cap, the bearing of a rustic. From afar, he gazed upon the plain, waving his sleeves as he walked. Reaching the high shore, he moored his boat, propped his chin, and clasped his knees, listening to the zither and song. Then he beckoned to Zilu and Zigong, and both responded.

The stranger pointed at Confucius and asked, “What manner of man is he?”

*Subcommentary:* He inquired as to Confucius’s rank and title.

Zilu replied, “A gentleman of Lu.”

*Subcommentary:* He answered that he was a worthy gentleman of the state of Lu.

The stranger asked of his lineage. Zilu replied, “The lineage of Kong.”

*Subcommentary:* When asked of his clan, he answered that his surname was Kong.

The stranger said, “And what does this Kong practice?”

*Subcommentary:* He further asked by what methods or arts the Kong lineage cultivated itself.

Zilu did not answer, but Zigong replied, “The Kong lineage follows loyalty and trust as its nature, embodies benevolence and righteousness in action, refines ritual and music, selects and orders human relationships. Above, it is loyal to the rulers of the age; below, it transforms the common people. Its aim is to benefit all under heaven—this is what the Kong lineage practices.”

*Subcommentary:* Following its nature with humility and harmony, it treads the path of the sages, refines ritual and music, selects and orders human relationships, serves the ruler with sincerity, and brings transformation to the people. Its intent is to benefit all beings—such is the heart of the Kong lineage.

The stranger asked again, “Is he a lord with lands?”

Zigong said, “No.”

Is he an advisor to kings and lords?

Zigong said, “No.”

*Subcommentary:* Is he a lord enfeoffed with land and rank? Or is he an advisor to kings and lords, a minister or chancellor? To all these, the answer was no. The stranger laughed and turned away, saying as he went, “Benevolent, to be sure—but I fear he will not escape harm to himself. His heart labors and his form toils, endangering his true nature. Alas! How far removed he is from the Dao.”

*Subcommentary:* To labor the heart and toil the form, endangering one’s true nature—such is the path of those who practice partial benevolence. They stray ever farther from the root, becoming ever more distant from the mysterious Dao. Thus he laughed in hesitation, sighing in lament.

Zigong returned and reported this to Confucius. Confucius pushed aside his zither and rose, saying, “He must be a sage.” He then went down to seek him. By the marsh’s edge, the stranger was just then using a pole to guide his boat. Turning, he saw Confucius and stood facing him. Confucius retreated, then advanced again, bowing twice.

*Subcommentary:* *Ná* means to guide. Retreating and then advancing again was a gesture of reverence.

The stranger asked, “What do you seek?”

Confucius replied, “A short while ago, sir, you left behind some parting words. I, Qiu, am unworthy and did not grasp their meaning. I have waited humbly in your wake, hoping to hear even the sound of your cough or sigh, that I might receive your instruction to the end and be aided thereby.”

*Subcommentary:* *Nǎng* means “earlier.” *Xùyán* means “remaining discourse.” *Sòng* means “to complete.” *Xiāng* means “to assist.” Earlier, the gentleman left behind some refined discourse. I, Qiu, am dull and did not understand its import. I waited humbly in your wake, hoping to catch even the sound of your voice, that I might receive your words in full and be aided in my inadequacy.

The stranger said, “Ah! How earnest is your love of learning!”

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying, “From my youth I have cultivated learning, and now, at sixty-nine years of age, I have yet to hear the ultimate teaching. How dare I not remain open in heart?”

*Subcommentary:* *Xī* is an exclamation of laughter. From my youth I have studied benevolence and righteousness, yet even now, in old age, I have not heard the ultimate Dao. Thus I remain reverent, humble, and open in heart.

The stranger said, “Like attracts like, and sound responds to sound—this is the principle of heaven. I shall set forth what I possess and examine what you practice.”

*Subcommentary:* When the tiger roars, the wind stirs; when the dragon rises, clouds gather—this is the natural principle, and so it must be. Thus the Fisherman, a great worthy, and Zhongni, the ultimate sage, were drawn together, like responding to like. Therefore, I shall expound the Dao of the world beyond and examine the affairs you cultivate within the world.

“What you practice concerns human affairs. When the Son of Heaven, the feudal lords, the great officers, and the common people—these four ranks—each maintains its proper place, governance is excellent. But when these four ranks depart from their stations, no disorder is greater. When officials attend to their duties and people concern themselves with their tasks, there is no encroachment.”

*Subcommentary:* *Líng* means “disorder.” Human affairs are manifold, but none are more essential than these four ranks. When each maintains its station, teaching and governance flourish. But when superiors and inferiors overstep, no disorder is greater. Thus, when the hundred officials each fulfill their duties and the common people attend to their work without encroachment, this is the unchanging Dao.

“When fields lie fallow and houses leak, when clothing and food are insufficient, when taxes and levies are unrelenting, when wives and concubines are discordant, when elders and juniors lack order—these are the concerns of the common people.”

*Subcommentary:* When fields lie barren and houses leak, when taxes are incessant and fail to correspond, when wives and concubines lose their proper order and elders and juniors lack sequence—these are the afflictions of the common people.

“Inability to fulfill one’s duties, failure to govern official matters, conduct that is not pure, subordinates who are negligent, failure to achieve merit, inability to maintain rank and emolument—these are the concerns of the great officers.”

*Subcommentary:* Inability to fulfill one’s duties, failure to manage affairs, the people’s neglect, the four occupations’ indolence—these are the concerns of the great officers.

“Lack of loyal ministers in the court, the state’s confusion and disorder, artisans’ lack of skill, tribute that is not fine, falling behind in the spring and autumn audiences, disobedience to the Son of Heaven—these are the concerns of the feudal lords.”

*Subcommentary:* Disloyal ministers, failure to present tribute, falling behind in the spring and autumn assemblies, disobedience to the Son of Heaven—these are the concerns of the five ranks of lords.

“When yin and yang are not in harmony, when cold and heat are untimely, harming the myriad things; when feudal lords are violent and disorderly, seizing and attacking one another, harming the people; when ritual and music lack moderation, resources are exhausted, human relationships are not ordered, and the hundred clans are licentious—these are the concerns of the Son of Heaven’s officials.”

*Subcommentary:* *Rǎng* means “to remove.” When yin and yang are not regulated and the seasons deviate, when weapons and warfare arise repeatedly and the myriad things are cut short, these are the concerns of the Three Dukes and Nine Ministers.

“Now, you possess neither the authority of the Son of Heaven’s officials and feudal lords above, nor the office of a great minister with its duties below. Yet you presume to adorn ritual and music, select and order human relationships, and transform the common people. Is this not excessively meddlesome?”

*Subcommentary:* Lacking the position of the Son of Heaven or feudal lords above, or of ministers and chancellors below, yet presuming to adorn ritual and music, select and order human relationships, and transform the common people—this is the conduct of one who meddles excessively.

“Moreover, people have eight faults, and affairs have four perils—these cannot but be examined. To attend to affairs that are not one’s own is called *zǒng*.”

*Subcommentary:* *Zǒng* means “indiscriminate.” To force knowledge of matters that are not one’s own is called meddling.

“To advance where one is not heeded is called *nìng*.”

*Subcommentary:* To force the offering of loyal words when they are not heeded is called flattery.

“To guide speech by currying favor is called *chǎn*.”

*Subcommentary:* To hope to align with another’s intentions and guide their speech is called sycophancy.

“To speak without distinguishing right from wrong is called *yú*.”

*Subcommentary:* To comply indiscriminately without distinguishing right from wrong is called obsequiousness.

“To delight in speaking of others’ faults is called *chán*.”

“To hear of others’ faults and delight in exposing their failures is called *chán*.”

*Subcommentary:* To hear of others’ faults and take pleasure in broadcasting their failures.

“To sever friendships and estrange kin is called *zéi*.”

*Subcommentary:* When others share bonds of kinship or friendship, to cleave and divide them is called destructive harm.

“To praise falsely and slander others in order to ruin the virtuous is called *tè*.”

*Subcommentary:* Those close to oneself, though wicked, are praised; those distant, though good, are slandered. Through such deceit and malice, delighting in harming others—this is the mark of a treacherous person.

“To make no distinction between good and evil, accommodating both sides with an agreeable countenance, and stealthily advancing one’s own desires is called *xiǎn*.”

*Subcommentary:* *Fǒu* means “evil.” Embracing both good and evil without discrimination, maintaining a pleasant demeanor, and surreptitiously promoting one’s own wishes—following and flattering accordingly—this is the mark of a deceitful and perverse person.

These eight flaws externally confuse others and internally harm oneself. The noble person does not befriend such people, nor does the enlightened ruler employ them.

*Subcommentary:* Externally, they bewilder and mislead the common people; internally, they bring ruin to themselves. Thus, the noble person does not take them as friends, and the enlightened ruler does not make them ministers.

As for the four perils:

“To delight in managing great affairs, altering and disrupting the constant order to seek merit and fame is called *tāo*.”

*Subcommentary:* Watching for moments of danger and stability, scheming over great affairs, seizing opportunities for change to establish merit and fame—this is the mark of an intrusive and reckless person.

“To monopolize knowledge and arrogate authority, encroaching upon others and acting self-righteously is called *greed*.”

*Subcommentary:* To arrogate all matters to oneself and domineer over others is called greed.

“To persist in error without correction, and to grow more obstinate upon hearing admonition is called *hěn*.”

*Subcommentary:* To cling to faults without reform, and to become even more stubborn upon hearing counsel—this is the mark of a cruel and obstinate person.

“To approve only what aligns with oneself, and to reject even the good when it differs from oneself is called *jīn*.”

*Subcommentary:* What aligns with oneself, though evil, is deemed good; what differs, though good, is deemed evil—this is the mark of an arrogant and boastful person.

These are the four perils. Only by eliminating the eight flaws and avoiding the four perils can one begin to be taught.

Confucius sighed deeply, bowed twice, and rose, saying: “I was twice exiled from Lu, had my traces erased in Wei, was forced to fell a tree in Song, and was besieged between Chen and Cai. I do not know what wrong I committed to incur these four slanders—why was this?”

*Subcommentary:* *Qiǎorán* describes a look of shame and trepidation. *Lí* means “to encounter.” Having committed no fault yet suffering these four slanders, he had not yet grasped the earlier teaching, hence this doubt.

The guest’s expression turned somber as he replied: “How deeply you resist understanding! There was a man who feared his shadow and loathed his footprints, and so ran to escape them. The more he lifted his feet, the more footprints he left; the faster he ran, the more his shadow clung to him. Believing himself still too slow, he ran without rest until he collapsed and died. He did not realize that by standing in the shade he could have stilled his shadow, and by remaining still he could have ceased his footprints—how foolish he was!

You scrutinize the space between benevolence and righteousness, examine the boundaries of sameness and difference, observe the changes between movement and stillness, measure the limits of giving and receiving, weigh the inclinations of likes and dislikes, and harmonize the moderation of joy and anger—yet you have nearly failed to escape. To carefully cultivate oneself, guard one’s true nature, and return all things to others is to be free from entanglement.

*Subcommentary:* To linger in the space between benevolence and righteousness to attract disciples, to watch for opportunities in the boundaries of sameness and difference, to observe changes in movement and stillness in hopes of luck, to measure the limits of giving and receiving in pursuit of merit and fame, to cling stubbornly to likes and dislikes, to regulate joy and anger as a means to the Way, to instruct others while priding oneself on one’s nature—this is nearly inescapable.

If you diligently cultivate yourself and cautiously preserve your true nature, returning all things to others, then you will be free from burdens.

*Subcommentary:* To carefully tend to one’s body and preserve one’s true nature, returning all merit and fame to others, is to achieve wholeness in both self and things, hence free from harm.

Now, instead of cultivating yourself, you seek it in others—is this not misplaced?”

*Annotation:* To fail to cultivate oneself and seek it in others—is this not estrangement?

Confucius, again abashed, asked: “May I ask what is meant by *the true*?”

The guest replied: “The true is the utmost of essence and sincerity. Without essence and sincerity, one cannot move others.

*Subcommentary:* The true is not false, essence is not adulterated, sincerity is not feigned. Thus, those who feign emotions and falsify their nature cannot move others.

Therefore, forced weeping, though sorrowful, is not mournful; forced anger, though severe, is not awe-inspiring; forced affection, though smiling, is not harmonious. True sorrow is soundless yet mournful, true anger is unexpressed yet awe-inspiring, true affection is unsmiling yet harmonious. When the true resides within, the spirit moves without—this is why the true is prized.

Applied to human affairs, serving parents yields filial devotion, serving rulers yields loyalty, drinking yields joy, and mourning yields grief.

*Subcommentary:* The Way is present in all things, and all things are pervaded by it. Thus, when applied to human relationships, these four arise. The meanings of these four are elaborated below.

Loyalty takes merit as its essence, drinking takes joy as its essence, mourning takes grief as its essence, and serving parents takes suitability as its essence. The beauty of merit’s completion cannot be confined to a single form.

*Subcommentary:* *Zhēn* is the trunk of affairs. Thus, merit is taken as its essence. Drinking dissolves and uplifts the nature, hence joy is its essence. Since merit lies in its beauty, its manifestations cannot be uniform.

Serving parents takes suitability as its essence, without regard for the means; drinking takes joy as its essence, without selecting the instruments; mourning takes grief as its essence, without concern for ritual.

*Subcommentary:* This reiterates the meanings of the four above.

Ritual is what the worldly create; the true is what one receives from Heaven, naturally and unalterably.

*Subcommentary:* Ritual’s refinements are created by the worldly; true nature is bestowed by the great simplicity, naturally and unchangeably so.”

Thus the sage models himself on Heaven and values the true, unbound by worldly conventions.

*Subcommentary:* He emulates the natural and treasures the true Dao, hence he is not constrained by vulgar rituals.

The foolish do the opposite. Unable to model themselves on Heaven, they fret over human affairs; ignorant of the value of the true, they mindlessly conform to worldly changes—thus they are never content.

*Subcommentary:* *Fret* means to worry. *Mindlessly* describes a slavish demeanor. Deluded fools, contrary to the sage’s path, cannot emulate the natural to attain harmony, nor value virtue and power to roam freely. Instead, they drown in worldly affairs, vexed by cares, mired in the dust of clamor, and insatiably chasing things—hence their hearts are ever unsatisfied. Alas! That you were so early steeped in human artifice and so late to hear of the great Dao.

Confucius bowed twice and rose, saying: “Today I have been so fortunate as to meet you—like a blessing from Heaven. You do not disdain to treat me as a servant and instruct me in person. May I ask where you dwell? I would follow you to receive your teaching and complete my study of the great Dao.”

*Subcommentary:* Overjoyed, Confucius sighed in gratitude, as if ascending to Heaven upon meeting the fisherman. He was certain that the man would not scorn to instruct him, and resolved to serve him as a disciple, receiving his personal guidance. He asked where he lived, intending to study the great Dao to its end.

The stranger said: “I have heard that those who can journey with you, take them to the subtle Dao; those who cannot, do not know the Dao—beware of taking them, lest you bring harm upon yourself.”

*Subcommentary:* *Journey* means to progress from delusion to enlightenment. The *subtle Dao* is the true root. *Know* means to discern. If you meet a person of superior wisdom, you may speak to them of the subtle root; if you encounter one of lesser capacity, do not speak to them of the profound ultimate. Observe their capacity and adapt your teaching—only then will you avoid fault.

“Strive on! I leave you now, I leave you now.” With that, he poled his boat away, gliding among the green reeds.

*Subcommentary:* He exhorted Confucius to exert himself. The boat threaded through the upper reaches of the reeds. The repeated “I leave you” was an earnest admonition.

Yan Yuan turned the carriage, and Zilu handed him the reins, but Confucius did not look back. He waited until the water’s ripples stilled and the sound of the oars faded before daring to board.

*Subcommentary:* Having met an extraordinary man who revealed the ultimate Dao to him, Confucius gazed after him with ever-deepening reverence, his heart filled with both joy and awe. Though his disciples offered the reins, he did not glance at them. Only when the boat was far off, the waves calmed, and the sound of the oars vanished did he dare to mount the carriage.

Zilu stepped beside the carriage and asked: “I have long served you, yet never have I seen you meet another with such deference. Kings of ten thousand chariots and lords of a thousand chariots, when they meet you, do not fail to observe proper courtly etiquette—yet you still bear yourself with a certain haughtiness. Now this fisherman stands before you with his oar, and you bow like a chime-stone, answering his words with repeated bows. Is this not excessive? We disciples all find it strange—how has this fisherman earned such treatment?”

*Subcommentary:* The Son of Heaven commands ten thousand chariots; the feudal lords, a thousand. *Courtly etiquette* means to stand opposite. They stand in the courtyard, facing each other with equal rites, their ranks and dignity matched, without any lowering of status. When Confucius met the Son of Heaven or feudal lords, he still maintained a certain haughtiness; yet upon meeting this fisherman, he bowed deeply, humbling himself, and responded to his words with repeated bows. The fisherman’s majesty was such that it elicited this response. Confucius revered the Dao beyond the world, while Zilu was a man of the world—hence his astonishment and his question from beside the carriage.

Confucius leaned on the crossbar and sighed: “You are truly hard to transform, You! You have been steeped in ritual and propriety for so long, yet your crude and vulgar heart has not yet left you.

*Subcommentary:* He had long been immersed in ritual and propriety—hence Confucius sighed, leaning on the crossbar, lamenting his stubbornness.

Come, let me tell you. To meet an elder without respect is to lack ritual; to meet a worthy without reverence is to lack benevolence. If he were not a perfected person, he could not humble himself before others. If one does not humble oneself with utmost sincerity, one cannot attain the true—thus one harms oneself. Alas! There is no greater calamity for a person than to lack benevolence—and you alone possess it to the full.

*Subcommentary:* He summoned Zilu to come forward and approach. To meet an elder without respect is to fail in ritual propriety; to meet one who is noble without reverence is to lack a benevolent heart. If one is not a person of utmost virtue, one cannot make others feel at ease in one’s humility. If one’s humility is not perfectly sincere, one cannot reach the profound ultimate. To be untransformed and unloving is to lay the foundation for disaster. Alas for Zilu—he alone embodies this failing to the fullest.

Moreover, the Dao is that by which the myriad things proceed. All things that lose it die; those that attain it live. In affairs, to go against it is to fail; to follow it is to succeed. Thus, wherever the Dao resides, the sage reveres it. Now, as for this fisherman and the Dao—he may be said to possess it. How could I dare not revere him?”

*Commentary:* This chapter speaks of one who, though not of the rivers and seas, can humble himself before those of the rivers and seas. Was Confucius’ openness to instruction limited to this fisherman alone? He would roam the six directions, penetrating all without exception. Even the crawling creatures could fully express their hearts to him, and he would exhaust principle and convey destiny—this is indeed the way of the perfected person.

*Subcommentary:* *Proceed* means to follow. *All things* means the multitude. The Dao gives birth to the myriad things—hence it is called the Dao. Thus we know that all things follow the Dao to live. Those who follow it live and succeed; those who go against it die and fail. Regardless of a thing’s worth, where the Dao resides, it is revered. Since this fisherman embodied the Dao, how could Confucius not revere him?

This concludes the thirty-third scroll of the *Annotations and Subcommentary on the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*. In the *Missing Errors*, Zhang Junfang’s edition has *交* as *皎*; the *Siku* edition concurs.

#2 Guo Qingfan emends the text, changing *tuo* 拓 to *tuo* 托.
#3 In the *Missing Errors*, Zhang Junfang’s edition has *dai* 待 as *shi* 侍.
#4 The Kōzan-ji edition has *you* 忧 as *chu* 处.
#5 The Kōzan-ji edition has *ting* 廷 as *chao* 朝.
#6 The Kōzan-ji edition includes the character *yi* 亦 after *bu* 不.
#7 Originally *zong* 总; here following the *Siku* edition, emended to *zong* 总.
#8 The subcommentary here is missing; now restored following the original *Chengshu* text.
#9 Liu Wendian’s *Corrections and Emendations* has *ju* 举 as *yu* 誉.
#10 The Kōzan-ji edition omits the character *shen* 身 after *li* 离.
