#11 This passage in the Kōzan-ji edition reads: “Now, not cultivating the self but seeking it in others.”
#12 The Kōzan-ji edition has *bei* 悲 as *ji* 疾.
#13 Also, *weifa* 未发 is rendered as *buyan* 不严.
#14 Also, *wei* 未 is rendered as *bu* 不.
#15 The phrase *sishi* 四事 is restored from the preceding text and Guo Qingfan’s citation.
#16 The Kōzan-ji edition includes the character *qi* 其 after *lun* 论.
#17 The Kōzan-ji edition includes the character *wei* 为 after *bu* 不.
#18 The Kōzan-ji edition has *xian* 贤 as *gui* 贵.
#19 Originally *yin* 因; here following the *Siku* edition, emended to *gu* 固.

This concludes the thirty-fourth scroll of the *Annotations and Subcommentary on the True Scripture of Southern Florescence*.
Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan.

Tang dynasty Master of Western Florescence, Cheng Xuanying’s *Subcommentary*
*Miscellaneous Chapters: Lie Yukou*, Chapter Thirty-Two

When Lie Yukou journeyed to Qi, he turned back midway and encountered Bohun Maoren.

**Subcommentary:** Bohun was a worthy gentleman of Chu, known as Bohun Maoren, a recluse. Having studied under Master Huanzi, Yukou also served Bohun. As he set out for Qi, traveling the Way of transformation, he startled himself with the shallowness of his progress and returned mid-journey. There he chanced upon Maoren, who asked him the reason.

Bohun Maoren said: By what Way have you turned back?

**Subcommentary:** *Fang* means "Way." *Xi* means "what." By what Way did you travel? To what destination did you go? He inquired into the cause of his turning back midway.

Yukou said: I was startled.

**Subcommentary:** Recognizing his own inadequacy, he turned back in alarm. This briefly answers the preceding question.

Maoren said: Why were you startled?

**Subcommentary:** He again asked Yukou what matter had provoked his alarm.

Yukou said: I once sought food among ten broth-sellers,

**Annotation:** Households that sold broth.

and five of them served me first.

**Annotation:** This showed their respect for him.

**Subcommentary:** *Kui* means "to offer." *Ten broth-sellers* refers to ten households selling broth. As Liezi traveled thirsty, he sought drink among ten inns selling beverages, and five of them offered him refreshment first. Observing their deference, he was seized by alarm, for he had not yet attained effortless oneness. Thus he turned back in fear.

Bohun Maoren said: If this is so, then why did you startle yourself?

**Subcommentary:** He pressed further to uncover the cause of his alarm, hoping he would confess his error.

Yukou said: My inner sincerity was not yet dissolved,

**Annotation:** He outwardly adorned himself with self-importance.

**Subcommentary:** He realized that his inner wisdom had not yet attained effortless clarity. Being revered by others, he was startled into returning.

My demeanor schemed to shine,

**Annotation:** His conduct was obsequious and ostentatious.

and with outward appearances I overawed others’ hearts.

**Annotation:** His inner substance was insufficient to command respect.

**Subcommentary:** *Mou* describes obsequiousness. *Zhen* means "to subdue." His manner was fawning, his movements radiant. Using such outward appearances, he overawed others.

This caused people to slight the venerable and esteemed,

**Annotation:** Had his authority arisen from inner power, it would have deepened others’ reverence for the aged.

and to court the very source of their troubles.

**Annotation:** When one moves others with outward beauty, disorder arises.

**Subcommentary:** *Zheng* means "disorder." Failing to merge with the world and equalize with dust, he became a standard for others. This led them to revere him while slighting elders, and he feared that calamity and disorder would soon arise. The broth-sellers dealt only in goods for sustenance, with no great profit. Their gains were meager, their influence slight, and yet they acted thus.

**Annotation:** With little influence and scant profit, they had no need to seek favor from others.

How much more so for a lord of ten thousand chariots?

**Subcommentary:** *Te* means "only." *Ying* means "profit." The broth-sellers dealt only in food and drink, with modest earnings. Their profit was meager, their influence light, yet they still revered him and hastened to offer him broth. How much more so for a ruler, whose power is vast and profit abundant—should not people hasten to honor him?

I exhaust myself for the state and expend my knowledge in affairs. He would entrust me with tasks and measure me by my achievements. This is why I was startled.

**Subcommentary:** A ruler of men oversees all matters of state and commands authority across the four seas. Thus he wearies himself for the realm and exhausts his mind in worldly affairs, thirsting for worthy men to relieve his burdens. He would surely entrust me with duties and test me by my accomplishments, leading me to lose my inner truth in pursuit of the external and forget authenticity in favor of pretense. The cause of my alarm is fully set forth here.

Bohun Maoren said: Excellent is your observation!

**Subcommentary:** You have examined yourself and discerned gain and loss. I commend your self-awareness, hence I say "excellent."

If you abide in yourself, others will safeguard you.

**Annotation:** If one does not abandon form, one will naturally be safeguarded wherever one is. *Safeguard* means to gather and protect.

**Subcommentary:** *Bao* means "to guard." If you settle into yourself without forgetting your person, yet still display your form and power, others will be drawn to you. Disciples will seek instruction, gathering to protect you.

Before long, he went to Yukou’s dwelling, and the sandals outside the door were piled high.

**Subcommentary:** *Before long* means "after little time." In a brief moment, Bohun visited Yukou’s abode and saw sandals discarded outside the door. Barefoot, Yukou had ascended the hall, and many had come to seek instruction.

Bohun Maoren stood facing north, leaning firmly on his staff and propping his chin upon it. He stood among them for a time, then departed without speaking.

**Subcommentary:** *Dun* means "firm." Leaning on his staff and resting his chin upon it, he listened to their discourse. He stood among them for a long while, then departed in wordless silence.

The attendant informed Liezi, who grasped his sandals and ran barefoot. Reaching the gate, he said: Since you have come, Master, have you no medicine to dispense?

**Subcommentary:** The *attendant* refers to the one who received guests. Hearing that his teacher and friend had stood among them without speaking before departing, Yukou was filled with awe and shame. Without pausing to don his sandals, he ran barefoot to the gate and turned back, saying: Since you have come, noble one, I hoped you might apply the needle and moxa, yet you have not once opened your medicine case before leaving. His sincere thirst for instruction prompted this earnest plea.

Maoren said: It is done. I had already told you that others would safeguard you, and indeed they have safeguarded you.

**Subcommentary:** "Done" means "stop." I had already told you before that others would safeguard you, yet you could not conceal your light and hide your traces, so you were inevitably sought out by others. Now I see your disciples filling the room—my earlier words to you were surely not empty. Cease your entreaties; spare yourself the trouble of further speech. It is not that you can make others safeguard you, but that you cannot prevent others from safeguarding you.

**Commentary:** When one acts with equanimity and transforms, there is no stirring, no seeking. Without stirring or seeking, there is no mutual safeguarding.

**Subcommentary:** When one displays traces outwardly, others will safeguard them. Yet if one has not forgotten virtue, one cannot be without self-preservation. Why then provoke or preemptively display distinction?

**Commentary:** To bestow favors before others act is to bestow without cause; preemption is distinction.

**Subcommentary:** "You" refers to Yukou. Why must self and others be forgotten before there is no need for others to stir one? If there must be a stimulus to provoke response, there is no need to preemptively display distinction or bestow favors before others act. If there must be a stimulus, one’s fundamental nature is shaken—this is meaningless.

**Commentary:** If there must be a stimulus, then one moves with fundamental nature.

**Subcommentary:** "Shaken" means "moved." If there must be compulsion before rising, one follows fundamental nature, responding while erasing traces and concealing beginnings—what is there to praise? Those who wander with you offer no true counsel; their petty words are all poison to others.

**Commentary:** Petty and clever words that deceive others are called "petty words."

**Subcommentary:** Those who share your path and understanding indulge only in frivolous, clever speech, flattering others—all of it like turtledove’s poison. How could they use the Way to instruct you? None awaken, none comprehend—how could any discern and inform another?

The cunning labor, the wise fret; the incapable seek nothing. Sated, they roam, drifting like an untethered boat—empty, they wander.

**Commentary:** Only the sage is truly incapable. From those below to the crawling insects, none forget their abilities to rely on the multitude.

**Subcommentary:** Things do nothing, yet one wearies oneself with cleverness and knowledge. Only the sage drifts without attachment, the mind forgotten, like an empty boat, following fate in carefree ease.

A man of Zheng named Huan chanted and studied in the land of Qiu. After three years, Huan became a Confucian.

**Commentary:** "Chanted" means recitation. "Qiu" is a place name. "Zhi" means "just."

**Subcommentary:** "Chanted" means reciting and reading. Qiu is a place name. "Zhi" means "just." A man of Zheng named Huan studied in the land of Qiu; after three years, he mastered the Confucian Way. His influence moistened nine li, his virtue extended to three clans, and he made his younger brother a Mohist.

**Commentary:** The three clans are father’s, mother’s, and wife’s. He enabled his brother to succeed in Mohist teachings.

Confucians and Mohists debated, and their father sided with Di.

**Commentary:** Di was Huan’s younger brother.

**Subcommentary:** Di was Huan’s younger brother. Confucians follow the statutes of Wen and Wu, tracing their lineage to Yao and Shun, yet they are stubborn and loquacious. Mohists emulate the Way of Yu, valuing frugality and generosity. Confucians and Mohists diverge in path and aspiration, each clinging to right and wrong, debating fiercely. The father, siding with the younger son, aided Di.

After ten years, Huan took his own life. His father dreamed of him, saying: "The one who made your son a Mohist was your son. Why did you not once look upon his virtue? He has already become the fruit of the autumn cypress."

**Commentary:** Huan resented his father for aiding his brother, so in grief and indignation, he took his own life. In death, he appeared in a dream, saying: "I transformed myself into a Confucian and transformed my brother into a Mohist. My brother, transformed by me, could not follow me. I, a virtuous teacher, resented this to the point of death—my sincerity was such that I became the fruit of the autumn cypress."

**Subcommentary:** "He" means "why not." The autumn cypress is a sturdy tree. The father aided Di, and Huan resented him. After ten years, in grief and indignation, he took his own life, appearing in a dream to reproach his father: "The one who made your son a Mohist was my doing. Why did you not recognize me as a virtuous teacher and instead ally with my brother? My resentment was so great that I transformed into the fruit of the autumn cypress, growing on my grave." Some texts use "垠" (grave), saying: "Why did you not look upon my grave, where I have transformed into an autumn cypress bearing fruit?"

The Creator’s recompense to man does not repay the man but repays the man’s Heaven.

**Commentary:** From here onward are Zhuangzi’s words. The recompense lies in the accumulation of practice, repaying one’s nature, not one’s actions. Thus, the effort of study and practice perfects one’s nature—how could it be for the sake of action?

**Subcommentary:** The Creator is the great furnace of nature, yet the Creator is no-thing, able to transform all things—hence the name "Creator." The wisdom and ability of things are endowed by transformation, not acquired through study. Thus, study and practice assist the natural Way, repaying one’s Heavenly nature, not human effort. We know that Di had a Mohist nature, not acquired from Huan. Huan’s claim to have taught him was mistaken.

It was his nature that enabled him.

**Commentary:** He had that nature, so he was made to practice it.

**Subcommentary:** Di originally possessed a Mohist nature, so he became a Mohist. If one’s nature lacked it from the start, study would never succeed. This is not only true of Mo Di—all things are thus.

People consider themselves distinct from others and despise their kin.

Those who take credit to belittle others do not spare even their kin, while those who forget themselves to follow their inherent nature maintain proper order between noble and base.

**Subcommentary:** Huan, relying on his own accumulated learning, considered himself distinct from ordinary people, thus despising his kin and scorning his father. How deeply deluded people become to reach such a state! The well-drawers of Qi fought one another over water. Hence it is said: the world today is full of Huans.

**Commentary:** Digging wells serves to channel springs; chanting serves to channel nature. Without springs, there would be nothing to dig; without nature, nothing to chant. Yet the world forgets the naturalness of springs and nature, recognizing only the superficial work of digging and chanting. They then claim possession with pride—is this not delusion?

**Subcommentary:** The earth holds springs, and each person has their nature—this is Heaven. Digging to form wells and studying to master arts—this is human effort. Alas, how profoundly the world is deluded! They know only the superficial tasks of digging and learning, failing to awaken to the naturalness of springs and nature, yet boasting of these as their own achievements. Thus, the world is filled with followers of Huan. When the people of Qi dug a well and travelers came to draw water, the well’s owner seized them by the hair to stop them. Zhuangzi heard of this and used it as an analogy.

From this, those of virtue come to know ignorance, while those who embody the Dao remain untouched.

**Commentary:** Observing Huan’s errors in learning, the father simply let things be as they were, knowing without interference.

**Subcommentary:** Seeing Huan’s delusion, believing himself truly virtuous, from then on he forgot knowledge and let things take their course, no longer boasting of himself. How much more so for one who embodies the Dao—would they regard such efforts as their own?

In ancient times, this was called "the punishment of fleeing from Heaven."

**Commentary:** Those who claim Heaven’s natural abilities as their own achievements flee from Heaven, and thus punishment befalls them.

**Subcommentary:** Not recognizing that things are naturally as they are, and boasting of them as personal achievements, is to flee from Heaven’s principle. Having violated the workings of creation, punishment inevitably follows.

The sage finds peace in what is naturally peaceful and does not impose peace where it is not;

**Commentary:** The sage is neither at peace nor not at peace, but follows the hearts of the people.

**Subcommentary:** To find peace is to follow. Following the nature of all beings, not forcing things to conform to oneself, and not imposing what is absent in their nature—this is what makes one a sage.

The multitude finds peace in what is not naturally peaceful and does not find peace in what is.

**Commentary:** Their sense of peace differs from others, which is why they are the multitude.

**Subcommentary:** They learn what they cannot, finding peace in what is not naturally peaceful; they do not find peace in their inherent nature, failing to rest in what is naturally peaceful.

Zhuangzi said: "Knowing the Dao is easy; refraining from speech is difficult."

**Subcommentary:** The profound Dao is obscure and formless, beyond words and images. To comprehend it is easy, but to forget speech is truly hard.

To know and not speak is to reach Heaven; to know and speak is to remain among men.

**Subcommentary:** Profoundly awakening to the mysterious Dao, with no method to express it, one attains the realm of nature. Though one may know the ultimate, as long as words and distinctions remain, one has not departed from the human realm.

The people of old were Heavenly and not human.

**Commentary:** Knowing yet aligning with Heaven and Earth, they never spoke to lead others, responding only to their inherent limits.

**Subcommentary:** The true persons of antiquity, those who knew the Dao, were naturally pure and free from human emotions.

Zhu Hanman studied dragon-slaying under Zhi Liyi, exhausting a thousand gold fortune. After three years, his skill was perfected, yet he had no use for his craft.

**Commentary:** What matters is suitability; there is no value in distant or impractical efforts.

**Subcommentary:** His surname was Zhu, given name Hanman. His teacher’s surname was Zhi, given name Liyi. He spent his entire fortune learning the art of slaying dragons. After three years of devoted study, his technique was mastered, yet his skill was ultimately useless. Dragon-slaying is a rare pursuit in the world. This illustrates that in navigating human affairs, what matters is appropriateness. If one’s actions do not align with the moment, even great efforts are of no benefit.

The sage takes what must not be as not necessary, thus having no conflict;

**Commentary:** Though a principle may be inevitable, to treat it as not necessary is the height of harmony. How could conflict arise?

**Subcommentary:** One who has attained the Dao follows the inclinations of things. Though a principle may be inevitable, they do not cling to it, and thus avoid contention.

The multitude takes what is not necessary as necessary, thus creating much conflict;

**Commentary:** Though a principle may not be inevitable, to insist on it as necessary leads each to cling to their own views, breeding discord.

**Subcommentary:** The common people stubbornly hold to their delusions. Though a principle may not be inevitable, they insist on it as such, clashing with the nature of things and creating much discord.

Following conflict, they act with demands.

**Commentary:** When each follows their nature, they are sufficient, and sufficiency leaves no room for demands.

**Subcommentary:** With hearts full of greed and desire, they indulge in rigid attachments.

Conflict, when relied upon, leads to ruin.

**Commentary:** When used out of necessity, with tranquility as the highest aim, it does not lead to ruin.

**Subcommentary:** Failing to follow the great harmony of destiny and instead delighting in discord with the nature of things brings one close to losing what is truly precious.

The knowledge of petty men does not extend beyond gift-bearing and letter-writing.

**Commentary:** Gift-bearing to bestow, letter-writing to inquire—these are the pursuits of small minds.

**Subcommentary:** Petty men are like commoners. *Baoju* refers to fragrant herbs; *gandu* refers to bamboo slips. Plucking fragrant herbs to give as gifts or breaking bamboo slips to send letters—these are trivial matters of the world, not what a true person should deign to do.

They waste their spirit on the shallow and narrow.

**Commentary:** Obsessed with trivial matters, their gains are meager.

**Subcommentary:** Indulging in gift-giving and inquiries, they exhaust their spirit on lame and shallow pursuits, unable to roam the vast and distant.

Those who seek to universally aid and guide all things yet leave their forms hollow and empty—such people are lost amid the cosmos, their bodies burdened, unaware of the Great Beginning.

**Commentary:** The knowledge of petty men, though they aspire to universally aid and guide all things, traverses emptiness and roams afar. Their ambitions are vast, but their spirits are exhausted, their forms encumbered—thus they become bewildered and lose the proper attainment.

**Subcommentary:** With shallow understanding, they yet desire to universally aid all beings and guide all lives, hoping to empty their forms and merge with the mysterious Dao of the Great Unity—this is ultimately impossible. Such people are deluded by past and present, their bodies burdened by the six directions; how can they illuminate and comprehend the wondrous principle of the Great Beginning?

The perfected person, however, returns their spirit to the Beginningless and finds contentment in slumber within the land of Nothing-Whatsoever.

**Subcommentary:** The Beginningless is the wondrous root; the land of Nothing-Whatsoever is the realm of the Dao. The person of utmost virtue, though ever in motion, remains perpetually still. Even while universally aiding and guiding all things, their spirit congeals in the Beginningless—thus they harmonize their light with the world and constantly repose in the homeland of the Dao.

Water flows without form, issuing forth into the Great Purity.

**Commentary:** Placidly non-active, it follows the natural course.

**Subcommentary:** Without obstruction, it accords with things like flowing water, adapting to change with the times, not clinging to form or trace. Traces do not depart from the root, so though responsive to movement, it constantly issues forth into the utmost of the Great Purity.

Alas! Your knowledge resides in the tip of a hair,

**Commentary:** What their knowledge attains is minute.

Yet you know not the Great Tranquility.

**Commentary:** They attain the Great Tranquility by following their nature.

**Subcommentary:** Gift-bearing and letter-writing—how do these differ from the tip of a hair? To wield wisdom in such a way is deeply lamentable. With shallow and meager spirit, how could they know the Dao of utmost stillness?

A man of Song named Cao Shang was sent by the King of Song as an envoy to Qin. When he first went, he received several chariots; the King of Qin was pleased with him and added a hundred more chariots. **Subcommentary:** His surname was Cao, given name Shang, a man of Song. Sent by King Yan of Song as envoy to Qin, he responded aptly, and the King of Qin favored him, bestowing upon him a hundred chariots. A *cheng* refers to a team of four horses.

Returning to Song, he saw Zhuangzi and said: "To dwell in a wretched alley, hard-pressed and weaving sandals, with a withered neck and sallow face—this is what I am poor at. But to awaken a ruler of ten thousand chariots and follow in a train of a hundred chariots—this is what I excel at." **Subcommentary:** *Jiong* means distress. To speak of poverty and hardship, weaving sandals to sustain oneself, with a gaunt neck and emaciated face—at such a time, this is what I am poor at. Yet with a single mission to mighty Qin, I so startled the King of Qin that he bestowed a hundred chariots—this is the strength of my cunning. Thus he boasted to Zhuangzi.

Zhuangzi said: "The King of Qin, when ill, summoned physicians. Those who lanced boils and drained abscesses received one chariot; those who licked his hemorrhoids received five chariots. The baser the treatment, the more chariots they received. Did you, perchance, treat his hemorrhoids? How else could you have received so many chariots? Begone!"

**Commentary:** Only by serving the lowly can one’s merits become great; only with great merits can one’s emoluments become weighty. Thus those who are lofty, distant, and serene in their indifference abandon worldly honors.

**Subcommentary:** *Yong* refers to an itching, inflamed, and poisonous swelling. *Zhi* refers to the disease of anal fistula. Master Zhuang, with his transcendent spirit and keen insight, aspired to purity and loftiness. Here, he unleashed his extraordinary eloquence to rebuke Cao Shang. As Guo’s annotation states: *Only by serving the lowly can one’s merits become great; only with great merits can one’s emoluments become weighty. Those who are lofty, distant, and serene in their indifference abandon worldly honors.*

Duke Ai of Lu asked Yan He: “I regard Confucius as the pillar of integrity—will the state then be free of disorder?”
**Subcommentary:** Confucius possessed the virtue of loyal integrity and the power to govern. If appointed as chief minister, the afflictions of the state of Lu would surely be cured.

Yan He replied: “Confucius is perilously close to ruin.”
**Commentary:** *Ji* means peril. The perfected person finds peace in the stillness of the people. But if one becomes a pillar of integrity, one leaves behind a lofty legacy for ten thousand generations, inciting competition over the Seven Teachings and embellishing superficial adornments. The people will then be imperiled, and the perfected person will have no means of finding peace.
**Subcommentary:** *Dai* means near. *Ji* means peril. To lead the people by the example of integrity is to cause them to lose their nature—how then could Confucius find peace? Soon they will be adorning feathers and painting patterns,
**Commentary:** Whenever the phrase *fang qie* (“soon they will”) appears, it refers to later generations. Those who engage in such adornment and painting are not true to their nature.
**Subcommentary:** If Confucius were to serve as chief minister in the court of Lu, future generations would chase after his example, embellishing their conduct and losing their true nature.

They would engage in florid rhetoric, taking fragmentation as their guiding principle,
**Commentary:** This would cause later generations, in their pursuit of governance, to lack substance while their intentions and inclinations proliferate wildly.
**Subcommentary:** Once the sage’s traces are manifest, those who follow in governance and service will employ artifice and florid words, splitting streams and dividing currents as their guiding principle.

They would suppress their nature to observe the people, yet remain unaware of their own lack of sincerity,
**Commentary:** Later rulers, admiring Confucius’ distant path, would forcibly suppress their nature and act with hypocrisy in governing the people. As superiors and subordinates imitate one another, they would no longer recognize their own falsity.
**Subcommentary:** Later rulers, admiring Confucius’ distant path, would forcibly restrain their nature to govern the people. As superiors and subordinates imitate one another, they would deceive the common folk, unaware of their own lack of sincerity.

Using these embellished and false traces to instruct the black-haired masses, they would receive them in their hearts and wield them with their spirits, severing their true nature. How could one who governs the people in this way be worthy of praise? What suffices to govern the people is to receive it in the heart and wield it with the spirit.
**Commentary:** If one governs the people in this way, later generations would not merely follow outwardly but would receive and employ it with their hearts and spirits, unable to return to the self-possession of their inherent nature.
**Subcommentary:** Those later generations would not merely follow outwardly but would receive and employ it with their hearts and spirits, unable to recover their true nature. How could one who governs the people in this way find peace?

Are they suitable for you?
**Commentary:** *Bi* refers to the people; *ru* refers to Duke Ai. The people and you each have what is suitable for yourselves. To imitate one another is to lose the true. This is the very evidence we see today.
**Subcommentary:** *Bi* refers to the people; *ru* refers to Duke Ai. The people and you each have what is suitable for yourselves. What is suitable for you cannot be given to the people.

Should I provide nourishment for them?
**Commentary:** Imitating them is not the way to nurture oneself.
**Subcommentary:** *Yu* means “I”; *yi* means “nourishment.” The nourishment of the people and myself differ—like fish and birds, their rising and sinking are not the same. If you were to apply your own nourishment to others, both would be lost.

To err in this way would be acceptable.

To follow the traces of steadfast integrity in error is fundamentally unacceptable. Now, if we cause the people to abandon their true nature and study falsity, this is no way to guide them. Considering the generations to come, it would be better to cease such efforts.

**Commentary:** The question does not refer to the present time.

**Subcommentary:** To forsake one’s true nature and study false methods cannot serve to instruct the common folk. Fearing disorder in later ages, it is better to desist.

It is difficult to govern.

**Commentary:** To govern is to foster falsity, so the sage does not govern.

**Subcommentary:** To abandon oneself and imitate others—this the sage does not do.

To bestow upon others yet not forget is not the spontaneous distribution of Heaven.

**Commentary:** To distribute while keeping account is not the way of the straw dogs of the ten thousand things.

**Subcommentary:** The Two Modes spontaneously generate the ten thousand things—how could they value favor?

Merchants are held in contempt,

**Commentary:** How much more so scholars and gentlemen?

**Subcommentary:** Those who bestow seeking repayment are even despised by merchants—how much more so gentlemen and scholars?

Even if, for the sake of affairs, they are accorded rank, the spirit disregards them.

**Commentary:** Though one must acknowledge their acts of kindness in worldly matters, their failure to forget renders them insignificant in the eyes of the spirit.

This is the great disposition of the common people.

**Subcommentary:** To bestow yet not forget does not accord with the Way of Heaven. Though one must acknowledge their acts of kindness in worldly affairs, their demand for repayment causes the spirit to dismiss them lightly—such is the nature of the common people.

What governs these affairs is human nature and emotion. External punishments are metal and wood;

**Commentary:** Metal refers to blades, saws, axes, and halberds; wood refers to rods, cudgels, stocks, and fetters.

Internal punishments are movement and transgression.

**Commentary:** When one is still and appropriate, there are no punishments, internal or external.

When petty men incur external punishments, metal and wood interrogate them;

**Subcommentary:** *Xiao* means the dark of night. *Li* means to entangle. *Xun* means to question. Those benighted and deluded, ensnared in the net of law, suffer the punishments of cangues, fetters, axes, and halberds.

When they incur internal punishments, yin and yang consume them.

**Commentary:** To move beyond one’s proper measure is to injure the inner nature and qi, just as metal and wood interrogate externally.

**Subcommentary:** If one does not cease transgressing, then internally, cold and heat congeal, and yin and yang erode them.

Only the true person can escape both internal and external punishments.

**Commentary:** Unless one is a true person, none can halt at their proper measure. Thus, all inevitably suffer internal or external punishments—only the degree varies.

**Subcommentary:** With a heart like dead ashes, the inner spirit is not disturbed; with a form like withered wood, the outer self is not bound by fetters. Only the true person achieves this.

Confucius said: The human heart is more treacherous than mountains and rivers, harder to know than Heaven. Heaven at least has its seasons—spring, autumn, winter, summer—and its fixed times of dawn and dusk. But humans possess thick appearances and deep emotions.

**Subcommentary:** The human heart is harder to know than mountains and rivers, more inscrutable than the azure sky. The depth of its deceptions is set forth below.

Thus, some appear sincere yet are insincere; some seem timid yet are unworthy;

**Subcommentary:** *Yuan* means genuine. *Bu xiao* means unseemly. Some have the appearance of sincerity yet harbor frivolous hearts; others possess true worth yet seem unworthy.

Some appear compliant yet are distant;

**Subcommentary:** *Huai* means urgency. Some appear compliant and hasty yet their hearts grasp principle.

Some seem steadfast yet are lax; some seem relaxed yet are sharp.

**Commentary:** Human emotions and appearances often reverse in this way.

**Subcommentary:** *Man* means lax. *Han* means urgent. Some appear steadfast yet are truly scattered; others seem relaxed yet are inwardly sharp.

Thus, those who approach righteousness as if parched may flee it as if scorched.

**Commentary:** It is not that there are no traces—only that they are hard to discern.

**Subcommentary:** Some pursue righteousness as if thirsting for water, yet abandon it as if fleeing fire. Though difficult to discern, their traces are not entirely absent. Proof is provided below.

Therefore, the gentleman sends them far to observe their loyalty, brings them near to observe their reverence,

**Subcommentary:** Sending them far reveals loyalty or treachery; a single step shows respect or disdain.

Assigns them complex tasks to observe their ability,

**Subcommentary:** Overwhelming them with duties tests their competence.

Suddenly questions them to observe their knowledge,

**Subcommentary:** Abrupt questions and immediate responses reveal their sincerity and wisdom.

Sets urgent deadlines to observe their trustworthiness,

**Subcommentary:** Sudden appointments test their reliability.

Entrusts them with wealth to observe their benevolence,

**Subcommentary:** The benevolent are not greedy.

Warns them of danger to observe their integrity,

**Subcommentary:** Warning of peril reveals their steadfastness.

Intoxicates them with wine to observe their propriety, mingles them with others to observe their demeanor.

**Subcommentary:** The perfected cannot be confused by wine; their principles remain unshaken. Even when men and women dwell together, their chastity does not waver.

When all nine tests are complete, the unworthy are exposed.

**Subcommentary:** The gentleman is easy to discern; the unworthy are hard to fathom. Yet by examining their conduct, observing their paths, and scrutinizing their contentment, even through indirect means, one may come to know them.

Zheng Kaofu, upon his first appointment, bent low; upon his second, stooped; upon his third, bowed deeply. He walked along the wall, and who would dare act improperly toward him?

**Commentary:** No one would dare insult him with unruly conduct.

**Subcommentary:** *Kao* means accomplished; *fu* means great. One of accomplished virtue who walks the upright path is called Zheng Kaofu—Confucius’ ancestor, a grandee of Song. A scholar receives one appointment, a grandee two, and a minister three. Bent, stooped, and bowing deeply, his reverence was extreme. So humble and retiring, who would dare insult him with unruly conduct?

But there are those who, upon their first appointment, strut like Lü Ju; upon their second, dance atop their carriage; upon their third, call others "uncle." Who would align with such as Tang Xu?

**Commentary:** *Erfu* refers to the common man. *Tang* refers to Yao; *Xu* refers to Xu You. It speaks of how the common man compares to Kaofu—who could align with the deeds of Tang and Xu?

**Subcommentary:** *Erfu* is the vulgar man. *Zhufu* means uncles. The common man, eager for rank and eminence, upon his first appointment flaunts like Lü Ju; upon his second, seizes the carriage strap and dances; upon his third, proudly names his uncles. Yet Kaofu’s humility and the common man’s arrogance differ so greatly—how could their measure and worth be compared? Who could match the effortless virtue of Yao and Xu You, who yielded the throne in non-action?

No thief is greater than virtue with intent.
**Commentary:** Virtue pursued with intent is not true virtue. True virtue arises spontaneously, unknowing of its own power.

**Subcommentary:** To scheme and strain the mind in pursuit of virtue is the gravest harm. Yet the mind has its lashes—
**Commentary:** To follow the mind in virtue may yet be tolerable; but to bind the mind to the space between the brows is already excessive pretense. And if it has eyes yet turns inward, turning inward leads to ruin.
**Commentary:** To probe and pry into the obscure, making depth one’s aim, is to ruin both mind and endeavor.

**Subcommentary:** To enslave the mind, exhausting spirit in the space between the eyes and lashes, chasing thoughts without cease—this is the path to grave peril.

Five baleful virtues exist, and the central virtue is chief among them.
**Subcommentary:** These are the heart, ears, eyes, tongue, and nose—the five roots. Disaster arises from these virtues, hence they are called baleful. Of the five roots, the chief disaster lies in the central virtue, the heart without emptiness. What is the central virtue? The central virtue is to cherish one’s own preferences and revile what one does not do.
**Commentary:** To condemn. To esteem oneself and reject others invites many attacks, making it the chief of baleful traits. If the center harbors no self-cherishing, then it freely affirms what all things affirm. Each affirmation remains untainted, and the world will eagerly submit to it.

**Subcommentary:** To condemn. To take what the heart cherishes as right and revile what differs from oneself—this is to regard the heart’s self-affirmation as virtue, hence called the central virtue.

There are eight extremes of ruin, three certainties of success, and six bodily palaces.
**Subcommentary:** The eight extremes and three certainties pertain to ruin and success, just as the body has six palaces—detailed below.

Handsome beard, great stature, robust build, radiant beauty, courage, and daring—eight traits that surpass others, yet through them one meets ruin.
**Commentary:** Ruin in servitude. Yet the world is never ruined by its shortcomings, but ever by its strengths.

**Subcommentary:** *Mei* means flattering charm; *ran*, the whiskers and sideburns; *chang*, height; *da*, girth; *zhuang*, strength; *li*, splendor; *yong*, ferocity; *gan*, bold decisiveness.

Possessing these eight traits, surpassing ordinary people, one is burdened with many servile tasks and thus falls into poverty and hardship.

Dependence, infirmity, and timidity—three traits inferior to others—yet through them one attains success.
**Commentary:** *Yuánxún* refers to one who leans on things to walk. *Yǎnyǎng* describes one unable to bend and grasp. *Kùnwèi* denotes one who is cowardly and weak. Since these three are unfit for active service, they are instead employed in auxiliary roles, hence their certain success.
**Subcommentary:** *Xún* means compliance—relying on others and following them, unable to stand alone. *Yǎnyǎng* describes one who holds their head high and cannot stoop to take hold of things. *Kùnwèi* refers to distress and fear. Possessing these three traits, inferior to ordinary people, one nevertheless attains success wherever they go.

Wisdom that extends outward,
**Commentary:** Extending outward harms the inner self by its boundlessness.
**Subcommentary:** Relying on one’s intelligence to illuminate things, one connects outwardly with the dusty world.

Bravery that stirs action breeds resentment,
**Commentary:** Only timidity and stillness truly preserve the self.
**Subcommentary:** Vigor and restlessness inevitably invite enmity.

Benevolence and righteousness invite many reproaches,
**Commentary:** The world expects universal love, yet love cannot be all-encompassing—hence the many reproaches.
**Subcommentary:** Benevolence and righteousness, being incomplete, must incur many demands.

Those who grasp the essence of life are *kuǐ*,
**Commentary:** *Kuǐrán* describes a state of great tranquility and release.
Those who grasp knowledge are *xiāo*;
**Commentary:** *Xiāo* means dissolution and dispersal.
**Subcommentary:** The commentary states: *Xiāo* is dissolution and dispersal; *kuǐ* is tranquility and release. At the summit of enlightenment, the true nature shines in emptiness, *kuǐrán* suspended in liberation, free from attachment.

Those who grasp the great mandate follow,
**Commentary:** They merge indistinguishably with transformation.
**Subcommentary:** The *great mandate* refers to great longevity. Even one like Pengzu, blessed with long life, follows and yields to it, never wearying of its duration or deeming it a burden.

Those who grasp the small mandate encounter,
**Commentary:** They awaken only when resting at the proper juncture.
**Subcommentary:** The *small mandate* refers to short lifespan. *Encounter* means to meet. Like a child who dies young, one meets their fate without distress.

There was a man who gained an audience with the King of Song and was granted ten chariots. With these ten chariots, he grew arrogant and relegated Zhuangzi to a lower rank.
**Subcommentary:** *Xī* means to grant; *hòu* means to place after. During the reign of King Xiang of Song, a mediocre man traveled to Song and deceived the king with empty words, receiving ten chariots in reward. Using these, he flaunted his superiority, pushing Zhuangzi behind him and boasting of his precedence.

Zhuangzi said: By the river lived a poor family who wove reed mats for a living. Their son dived into the depths and found a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. His father said to him: Bring a stone and smash it! For a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces must lie in the ninefold abyss beneath the chin of a black dragon. That you could obtain it means you must have encountered the dragon while it slept. Had the black dragon been awake, what trace of you would remain?
**Subcommentary:** *Wěi* refers to reeds; *xiāo* to mugwort. The poor family wove mats from reeds and mugwort to sell for food. *Duàn* means to hammer. *Lí* is the black dragon, beneath whose chin lies a pearl worth a thousand gold pieces. This parable mocks the man who gained the chariots. The depths of the state of Song are not merely a ninefold abyss; the ferocity of the King of Song surpasses even that of a black dragon. That you could obtain the chariots means you must have encountered him while he slept. Had the King of Song been awake, you would have been ground to powder.
**Commentary:** To acquire wealth and honor, one must align with the people’s expectations. If one clings to strange doctrines, rides the celestial thoroughfare, and ensnares the ruler’s heart, a wise lord will not accept it. Thus, if there is praise, there must be testing. If one does not betray the people’s trust and is universally acclaimed as meeting the hopes of all, this is how the Three Dynasties conducted themselves with uprightness.
**Subcommentary:** Those who harbor loyalty and sincerity to move their ruler will receive extraordinary rewards. But those who employ devious methods, flatter the ruler with clever words, and seek fortune through luck will display arrogance and disdain. How is this different from encountering a sleeping black dragon and obtaining a pearl? The rest is explained in the commentary.

Someone once sought to employ Zhuangzi.

**Subcommentary:** This is a parable, for the surname and clan of the one extending the invitation are not specified, hence the use of "someone."

Zhuangzi responded to the messenger, saying: "Have you seen the sacrificial ox? The ox is fed for three days beforehand to be used in the ancestral temple sacrifices. Clothed in embroidered brocade and fed with fine grass and beans, when it is led into the grand temple, though it might wish to be a lone calf, could it ever be so?"

**Commentary:** Those who delight in life fear the sacrificial fate and decline such appointments. The skull, hearing of life, knits its brows in dismay—such is the difference in feelings between life and death, each fitting in its own way.

**Subcommentary:** *Chu* refers to grass, and *shu* to beans. Though the sacrificial ox is richly nourished, when the day of sacrifice arrives, it cannot become a lone calf. How much more so for those who feed on official stipends, who often meet early deaths, while those who retreat in noble seclusion fully preserve their lives? Zhuangzi, lofty and pure, mocked the pursuit of fame and profit.

When Zhuangzi was about to die, his disciples wished to give him a lavish burial. Zhuangzi said: "I take heaven and earth as my inner and outer coffins, the sun and moon as my paired jades, the stars and constellations as my pearls and beads, and the myriad things as my funeral gifts. Are my burial rites not already complete? What more could be added?"

**Subcommentary:** Zhuangzi, profoundly attuned to the mysterious Dao, regarded his body as a temporary lodging. Thus, he took heaven and earth as his coffins, the two primal forces as his crucible, the stars and constellations as his pearls and beads, and the three luminaries as his transformations—his funeral provisions were fully prepared. For his disciples to insist on a lavish burial was deeply contrary to the workings of creation.

The disciples said: "We fear that crows and kites will feed on you, Master."

Zhuangzi replied: "Above, crows and kites will feed on me; below, ants will feed on me. To take from one to give to the other—how partial is that!"

**Subcommentary:** *Yuan* refers to the kite. The disciples, bearing the deep kindness of their teacher, wished to bury him lavishly to avoid the crows and kites, yet they did not realize that a lavish burial would only expose him to ants. Their affection led them to partiality in their choices.

"To use imbalance to create balance—such balance is not true balance."

**Commentary:** To impose one’s own sense of balance upon the myriad things is not as good as allowing the myriad things to find their own balance.

**Subcommentary:** Without partiality in giving or taking, entrusting all to impartiality—this is true balance. But if one applies one’s own thoughts to balance the myriad things, the moment one sets one’s mind to it, imbalance arises.

"To use the unconvincing to convince—such convincing is not truly convincing."

**Commentary:** *Zheng* means "response." Not following the natural responses of the myriad things but instead imposing one’s own views upon them will inevitably lead to discord.

**Subcommentary:** The sage, without preconceived intent, responds to stimuli—this is true responsiveness. If one responds with a preconceived mind, one cannot truly respond. *Zheng* means "response."

"The enlightened are but servants of things."

**Commentary:** Those who cling to their own views are often used by things—how can they use things?

**Subcommentary:** Those who flaunt their enlightenment and respond to affairs with their emotions are driven and used by things—how can they use others?

"Only the spiritually attuned can truly respond."

**Commentary:** Only by entrusting oneself to the spirit can one reach the utmost, thus responding without fail.

**Subcommentary:** The spiritually attuned, without preconceived intent and unmoving in stillness, can respond to all without exception.

"That the enlightened cannot surpass the spiritually attuned has long been so."

**Commentary:** The reach of enlightenment does not extend beyond the physical form. Yet when one attains perfect compliance, there is no distance too far or depth too profound—all things find their own fulfillment.

**Subcommentary:** Enlightenment involves responding to affairs with a preconceived mind, driven and used by things. The spiritually attuned, without preconceived intent, respond to stimuli without limitation. Having a mind cannot compare to being without one; responding with intent cannot compare to responding without intent—this is readily apparent.

"Yet the foolish rely on their own views to influence others, their achievements external—is this not lamentable?"

**Commentary:** When one attains perfect compliance, one’s actions arise from others yet remain hidden within things. But if one clings to one’s own views and insists on being right, though one may wish to influence others, one’s achievements remain external.

**Subcommentary:** Those who respond without attachment act without claiming credit, achieving success without dwelling on it. The foolish, however, cling to their own usefulness, appropriating others’ achievements as their own. Though they may wish to boast, their achievements remain external. Such delusion is deeply lamentable.

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence True Scripture, Scroll Thirty-Four, Concluded.*

Thus, the *Nei Wai* editions reverse the order to "inner and outer." The character *xùn* in the *Siku* edition is rendered as a lacuna. The *Que Wu* cites the Jiangnan Ancient Repository edition, where *shùn* ("comply") is written as *shèn* ("cautious"). Wang Xiaoyu supplements the character *zhēng* ("sign") based on context. The original *xīn* ("heart") is emended to *jù* ("possess") following Guo Qingfan’s citation and contextual meaning. The particle *fú* ("now") in the main text and commentary should be moved below *ér* ("yet"), as amended. The original *lěi* ("burden") is a scribal error; it is corrected to *yì* ("differ") in accordance with the main text and Guo Qingfan’s citation. The original *gēn* ("follow") is suspected to be erroneous and is amended to *jié* ("eyelashes") following the commentary, the *Siku* edition, and the *Shi Wen*, with consistency maintained below. The character *qiè* ("timid") is supplied based on context and Guo Qingfan’s citation. The *Daozang* edition writes *xiāo* ("resemble") as *xiāo* ("dissolve"). The original *rén* ("person") is suspected to be erroneous and is amended to *jiǔ* ("long") following context and Guo Qingfan’s citation. The original *fēn* ("divide") is suspected to be corrupt and is amended to *jiè* ("interpose") based on context and Guo Qingfan’s citation. The original *nǐ* ("imitate") is incorrect and is amended to *jì* ("sacrifice") following context and Guo Qingfan’s citation. The *Siku* edition reads, "its achievements lie without." Guo Qingfan’s citation emends *wàng* ("forget") to *wàng* ("delusion").

*Annotations to the Southern Florescence True Scripture, Scroll Thirty-Five*
*Commentary by Guo Xiang of Henan*

**Subcommentary by Master Cheng Xuanying of the Tang, Western Florescence**
*Miscellaneous Chapters: "The World" (Chapter Thirty-Three)*

The governance and arts of the world are manifold, each claiming its active methods cannot be surpassed.

*[Annotation]*
If one acts through *having* (有為), it is true action; if it is true action, there is no falsity—what more could be added?

*[Subcommentary]*
*Fāng* (方) means the Dao. From Zhuanxu down to Yao and Shun, the arts of governance and methods of rule were numerous. All followed the nature of existing things, aligning with their inherent tendencies, allowing the myriad beings to grow and move without imposing external distinctions. Thus, though they taught, it was as if they did not teach; though they acted, it was as if they did not act.

Where, then, does the so-called *Dao*-art of antiquity reside?

*[Subcommentary]*
The *Dao*-art practiced by the Three Sovereigns of high antiquity—following things, letting transformations unfold, pure and without contrivance—where is this method to be found? This hypothetical question illuminates a profound principle.

It is said: There is nowhere it is not.

*[Subcommentary]*
The answer: The wondrous Dao of non-action exists everywhere. From ancient times to the present, there is no place it does not pervade.

It is asked: By what means does the numinous descend? By what means does illumination emerge?

*[Annotation]*
The numinous and illumination descend and emerge in response to affairs.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Shén* (神) is the name for the wondrous; *míng* (明) signifies all-pervading wisdom. If the empty and penetrating sagely Dao has existed from ancient times to the present, why would those numinous beings need to manifest this luminous wisdom, establishing rites and music to guide the world?

The sagely arise from something; kings achieve through something.

*[Subcommentary]*
The empty and congealed wondrous Dao gives birth to things in response to their resonance. The sagely emperors and enlightened kings descend and manifest their traces to accomplish their works—how could this be in vain?

All originate from the One.

*[Annotation]*
If things each return to their root and embrace the One, with no adornment on the outside, this is how the sagely and kingly arise and achieve.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Yuán* (原) means root; *yī* (一) is the Dao. Though they descend in spirit to engage with things, blending their light and harmonizing their manifestations, they respond to things without departing from true constancy, embracing the One and returning to the root.

Not departing from the source is called the *heavenly person*.
Not departing from the essence is called the *numinous person*.
Not departing from the real is called the *perfected person*.
Taking heaven as their source, virtue as their root, and the Dao as their gate, foreseeing transformations, they are called *sages*.

*[Annotation]*
These four names refer to one and the same person; they differ only in how they are described.

*[Subcommentary]*
Merging with the source and uniting with the root is called *natural*. Pure and unadulterated is called *numinous*. Unwavering and uncontrived is called *perfected*. Taking the natural as their source, supreme virtue as their root, and the wondrous Dao as their gate, observing signs and adapting to things’ transformations, they are called *sages*. The four types above are but one; they are named differently according to their functions.

Taking benevolence as kindness, righteousness as principle, ritual as conduct, and music as harmony, suffused with compassion and kindness, they are called *noble persons*.

*[Annotation]*
These four names denote coarse traces, which worthy and noble persons embrace.

*[Subcommentary]*
Dispensing the seven virtues as grace, applying righteousness and principle to correct wrongs, employing ritual propriety as the foundation of conduct, and moving with music to harmonize the nature—radiating compassion across the nine provinces, fanning the winds of benevolence in all eight directions, like orchids and irises whose fragrance perfumes near and far—this may be called worthy.

Taking law as division, names as markers, verification as confirmation, and investigation as decision—such are the numbers one, two, three, and four.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Jī* (稽) means to examine; *cāo* (參) means to grasp. Law defines divisions, names mark reality, verification confirms conduct, and investigation decides ability. The numbers one, two, three, and four correspond to names, laws, and the like.

Officials rank one another by these, taking affairs as their constant.

*[Subcommentary]*
From Yao and Shun onward, the hundred officials were established. Using these four methods, they ranked one another in order. The duties of ruler and minister became their norm—what is called the constant principles of human relations.

Taking clothing and food as their primary concern, multiplying, rearing, and storing,

*[Subcommentary]*
Of affairs that cannot be abandoned, farming and weaving are foremost; of the sagely, clothing and food are indispensable. Thus, the state takes the people as its foundation, and the people take food as their heaven. Therefore, multiplying, nurturing life, accumulating, and storing are all methods of nourishing the people.

Caring for the elderly, the weak, the orphaned, and the widowed—all are provided for. This is the governance of the people.

*[Annotation]*
Since the governance of the people is thus, the sagely and worthy do not oppose it.

The people of antiquity were truly complete.

*[Annotation]*
The people of antiquity refer to these four types.

*[Subcommentary]*
Caring for the elderly, pitying the weak, compassionating the orphaned, and aiding the widowed—from the Five Emperors onward, all have practiced this.

They matched the numinous and bright, purified heaven and earth, nurtured the myriad things, and harmonized the world.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Pèi* (配) means to join. The sagely emperors, without intent, followed the nature of things. Thus, they could unite with the wondrous principle of the numinous and bright, align with the purity of heaven and earth, nurture the common people within the realm, and harmonize the myriad beings under heaven.

Their blessings extended to the hundred clans. Illuminating the root numbers, they connected to the branch measures.

*[Annotation]*
When the root numbers are illuminated, the branches do not depart.

*[Subcommentary]*
The root numbers are benevolence and righteousness; the branch measures are names and laws. The sagely heart, compassionate and nurturing, overflows with grace toward the common people. Thus, they illuminate benevolence and righteousness to exalt the root and connect to names and laws to rescue the branches.

The six directions and four openings, the great and small, the refined and coarse—their movements are nowhere absent.

*[Annotation]*
This is what it means to be complete.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Bì* (辟) means method. Great as the two modes (yin and yang), small as the myriad things, refined as spirit and wisdom, coarse as form and image—they roam through the six directions, transform in accord with the four seasons, moving with the moment, nowhere absent.

As for their illumination within numbers and measures, the old laws and transmitted records of historians still abound.

The manifestations within numbers and measures that can be made evident, though many remain, are already coarse and external.

*[Subcommentary]*
The *Annals* (*Chunqiu*) and *Book of Documents* (*Shangshu*) are both ancient histories. "Numbers and measures" refer to benevolence, righteousness, laws, and names. What has been handed down from antiquity and remains manifest in the world—historical records and transmitted texts—still abound. As for those found in the *Odes*, *Documents*, *Rites*, and *Music*, scholars of Zou and Lu, the girdled gentlemen, are largely able to elucidate them.

*[Annotation]*
They can elucidate their traces, but how could these be the essence of the traces?

*[Subcommentary]*
Zou is the name of a city; Lu, the name of a state. *Jin* (搢) refers to the tablet, or to insert; *shen* (绅), the sash. *Xiansheng* (先生) are the Confucian scholars. This says that benevolence, righteousness, names, and laws, as laid out in the *Six Classics*, are made clear by the scholars of Zou and Lu, men of the Confucian garb. The *Odes* convey the will, the *Documents* convey affairs, the *Rites* convey conduct, the *Music* conveys harmony, the *Changes* conveys yin and yang, and the *Annals* conveys names and distinctions.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Dao* (道) means to reach or to penetrate. The *Odes* convey emotions and intentions, the *Documents* convey worldly affairs, the *Rites* convey the conduct of the heart, the *Music* conveys harmony and ease, the *Changes* clarify hexagrams and omens, penetrating yin and yang, and the *Annals* praise and blame, fixing names and distinctions. These principles, scattered throughout the world and established in the Middle Kingdom, are at times expounded and conveyed by the schools of the Hundred Masters.

*[Annotation]*
They all convey the traces of the ancients, yet even these cannot always be upheld.

*[Subcommentary]*
The traces of the *Six Classics* are scattered throughout the realm, but the reach of their transformative influence does not extend beyond the central lands. The Hundred Schools and various masters, vaguely following the Five Virtues, occasionally expound upon them, yet cannot achieve great unity. When the world falls into great disorder,

*[Annotation]*
it is because they employ the traces without a unifying principle.

*[Subcommentary]*
Clinging to the traces of the past, they cannot attain peace. When the sagely and worthy remain obscure,

*[Annotation]*
to elucidate their traces is no easy task.

*[Subcommentary]*
They conceal their brilliance and hide their traces. When the Dao and virtue are not unified,

*[Annotation]*
the Hundred Schools force their interpretations.

*[Subcommentary]*
Their teachings and methods are manifold. People of the world each grasp one part,

*[Annotation]*
each believing in their own partial view and unable to embrace the whole.

*[Subcommentary]*
Scholars throughout the realm are each bound to their own attachments, grasping but a single art—how could they achieve vast comprehension? They examine and take delight in their own preferences.

*[Annotation]*
The sage unifies the great sentiments of the people and thereby establishes systems, so the people entrust their sentiments to what is unified and forget their own likes and dislikes, thus attaining harmony with their age in tranquil indifference. In disorder, the reverse occurs: people indulge their immediate preferences, households apply their own codes, so states adopt different policies and households follow distinct customs.

*[Subcommentary]*
Unable to attain tranquil indifference and emptiness, they instead employ their minds to scrutinize, following their own inclinations to devise teachings. It is like the ear, eye, nose, and mouth, each possessing its own clarity yet unable to communicate with one another.

*[Subcommentary]*
The eye can see colors but cannot hear sounds; the nose can smell fragrances but cannot discern tastes. Each has its own function and thus cannot communicate. It is like the various arts of the Hundred Schools, each possessing its own strength and at times serving a purpose.

*[Annotation]*
Their strengths differ and cannot be constantly employed.

*[Subcommentary]*
The Five Virtues of the *Six Classics* and the various teachings of the Hundred Schools each have their strengths in saving the world, yet since they do not align with the Dao, they are at times discarded, like the nose and mouth that cannot always communicate. Nevertheless, they are not comprehensive or all-encompassing—these are the scholars of one corner.

*[Annotation]*
Thus, they are not sufficient for full responsibility.

*[Subcommentary]*
Though each possesses its own strength, they cannot achieve thorough comprehension or universal reach. These are the biased scholars, the people of partiality, not those of rounded penetration and harmonious adaptability. They divide the beauty of Heaven and Earth, dissect the principles of the myriad things,

*[Annotation]*
each employing but one corner, thus dividing and dissecting.

*[Subcommentary]*
The people of one corner, each clinging to their biases, though they establish their methods, cannot unite with the Dao. Thus, they scatter the pure harmony of the Two Modes and sever the empty penetration of the myriad things. Examining the wholeness of the ancients, few can embody the beauty of Heaven and Earth or match the countenance of spirit and illumination.

*[Annotation]*
How much less can those of one corner?

*[Subcommentary]*
Observing the ancient people of complete virtue, they could still embody the nurturing of the Two Modes and match the countenance of spirit and illumination—how much less can the people of one corner? Therefore, the Way of inner sageliness and outer kingship grows dim and unclear, pent up and unexpressed.

*[Annotation]*
This is because the complete person is rarely encountered.

*[Subcommentary]*
The mysterious sage and the uncrowned king represent inner sageliness; the soaring dragon at the ninth-five, outer kingship. Yet when the Hundred Schools arose in competition, each prizing their own views, right and wrong became confused, and disputes between self and other proliferated. Thus, the Way of withdrawal and engagement grew dark and obstructed, pent up and unexpressed. People of the world each followed their own desires to devise their own methods. Alas! The Hundred Schools have gone forth and do not return—they will surely not unite.

*[Subcommentary]*
What the heart desires, it grasps and enacts, taking these desires as methods. Once set upon things, they never return to the root—how could they attain unity with principle? Having strayed from the nature of things, this is deeply lamentable. Later scholars, unfortunately, do not witness the purity of Heaven and Earth or the great body of the ancients.

*[Annotation]*
The great body, when each returns to the root and embraces the One, is the purity of Heaven and Earth.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Xing* (幸) means to encounter. The purity of Heaven and Earth is non-action; the great body of the ancients is simplicity. This says that people of later ages, living in this decadent era, do not witness the Way of non-action or encounter the age of simplicity. The arts of the Dao will be torn asunder throughout the world.

*[Annotation]*
Torn asunder means divided.

The corruptions of the Dao arts led each to champion their own methods. Some, by making things their master, caused things to depart from their nature and submit to external control, thus losing both nature and destiny.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Torn asunder" means divided. Confucians, Mohists, Logicians, and Legalists each raced forward, each prizing their own views, all following their own inclinations. The Dao arts became tangled and conflicting, mutually deceiving and outdoing one another, leaving the common people with no place to set their hearts. The division of the One Nature truly arose from this.

They did not indulge in extravagance for later generations, nor did they lavish upon the myriad things, nor did they shine through the measures and standards.

*[Annotation]*
Diligence and frugality lead to exhaustion, hence they did not shine.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Extravagance" means excess. "Lavish" means adornment. "Shine" means clarity. Teaching later generations, they did not permit luxury; in their dealings with things and self, they were utterly frugal, never indulging in ornate splendor. Having strayed from the nature of things, their teachings and methods could not prevail, and thus the classical rites of the former kings did not become manifest in the world.

They used the carpenter’s line to correct themselves.

*[Annotation]*
"Correct" means to discipline.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Correct" means to discipline. They used benevolence and righteousness as the carpenter’s line to discipline and refine their aspirations and conduct.

And prepared for the world’s emergencies.

*[Annotation]*
Acting with frugality leaves wealth in surplus, hence emergencies are provided for.

*[Subcommentary]*
"World’s emergencies" refer to the disasters of the Nine Suns, Hundred and Six, water, and fire. Through diligence, frugality, and moderation in use, they stored and accumulated wealth to prepare for the world’s calamities and urgent difficulties.

There were aspects of the Dao arts of antiquity present in this. Mo Di and Qin Guli heard of this trend and delighted in it, carrying it to excess, making themselves its greatest exemplars.

*[Annotation]*
They no longer measured what the multitude could bear.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Exemplars" means to follow. The Dao arts of antiquity—Yu’s governance of the floods, his diligence, frugality, and emaciation—left traces still present, hence it is said there were aspects present in this. Qin, by surname, styled Guli, was a disciple of Mo Di. Mo Di and Guli, by nature fond of diligence and frugality, hearing of Yu’s teachings, deeply delighted in and loved them. They devoted themselves to this Way, acting with excessive hardship, conforming only to themselves, unable to extend their teachings to others.

They composed *Against Music* and titled it *Moderation in Use*. In life, they did not sing; in death, they wore no mourning.

*[Subcommentary]*
*Against Music* and *Moderation in Use* are two chapter titles in the *Mozi*. "In life, they did not sing" is why they opposed music; "in death, they wore no mourning" is why they advocated moderation in use—meaning they had no funeral garments, shrouds, coffins, or outer coffins, expressing their extreme frugality and惜费.

Mozi universally loved and benefited all, opposing warfare among states.

*[Annotation]*
When things are insufficient, deficiency is deemed correct. Now, Mozi commands the people to all be diligent and frugal, each having surplus, hence he opposes conflict.

*[Subcommentary]*
Universally loving and benefiting all beings, he made each self-sufficient, hence eliminating strife and deeming conflict wrong.

His Way did not involve anger.

*[Annotation]*
He merely disciplined himself.

*[Subcommentary]*
Disciplining himself with diligence and frugality, he did not resent or grow angry at things.

He also loved learning and was broadly knowledgeable, without distinction.

*[Annotation]*
Having already taken himself as correct, he wished all things to be the same as himself.

*[Subcommentary]*
Mozi also loved learning, mastering the ancient classics. Having already practiced diligence and frugality himself, he wished others to be the same.

He did not align with the former kings, destroying the rites and music of antiquity.

*[Annotation]*
The former kings allowed their multitude of differences to flourish, then harmonized them so all were satisfied without knowing why.

*[Subcommentary]*
Rites involve gradations of refinement and restraint; music involves bells, drums, feathers, and plumes. Deeming them extravagant and luxurious, he destroyed and abandoned them.

The Yellow Emperor had *Xianchi*, Yao had *Great Chapter*, Shun had *Great Shao*, Yu had *Great Xia*, Tang had *Great Hu*, King Wen had the music of the *Biyong*, and King Wu and the Duke of Zhou composed *Wu*.

*[Subcommentary]*
The above are the names of the music of the Five Emperors and Three Kings.

The mourning rites of antiquity had ceremonies for the noble and base, ranks for the high and low. The Son of Heaven had seven layers of inner and outer coffins, the feudal lords five, the great officers three, and the officers two.

*[Subcommentary]*
From the Son of Heaven down to the common people, all had their ceremonies and laws, each with their own gradations—these were the rites of antiquity.

Now, Mozi alone did not sing in life and wore no mourning in death, using a paulownia coffin three inches thick without an outer coffin as his model. Teaching others in this way, he risked not loving them.

With this as his own practice, he surely did not love himself.

*[Annotation]*
All things love by exerting their strength and following their nature. Now, taking frugality as the model and carrying it to excess is, though one may wish to enrich the world, precisely what is not love.

*[Subcommentary]*
Following in Yu’s footsteps, he was frugal to excess. Above, this departed from the Three Kings; below, it ran counter to the myriad people. Thus, in life and death, he toiled in hardship, unable to nurture external things. His form and countenance withered—this could not be called love for his own person.

This is the ruin of Mozi’s Way.

*[Annotation]*
It is simply not the Dao and virtue.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Ruin" means "nothingness." Mo Di’s nature inclined toward the ideas of Yi Yin and Laozi.

Yet though he sang, it was not singing; though he wept, it was not weeping; though he rejoiced, it was not joy—was this truly akin to others?

*[Annotation]*
Though he alone formed the Mohist school, he did not resemble the feelings of the myriad things.

*[Subcommentary]*
To sing in life and weep in death is the constant principle of human relations; to mourn in misfortune and rejoice in good fortune is the great sentiment of the world. Now, he reversed these—thus, he was not merely different.

In life, he toiled; in death, he was meager. His Way was greatly parched.

*[Annotation]*
"Parched" means "without moisture."

*[Subcommentary]*
"Parched" means "without moisture." In life, he wearied body and mind; in death, his burial resources were scant. His Way was dry and without moisture.

He caused people to worry, caused people to grieve. His conduct was difficult to sustain. I fear it cannot be the Way of the sage.

*[Annotation]*
The sage’s Way delights and thereby moves the people. When the people attain what their natures delight in, they are pleased, and when they are pleased, the world has no difficulties.

*[Subcommentary]*
The sage’s Way wins the hearts of the hundred clans. Now, he caused things to worry and grieve, made his conduct difficult to endure, and left no moisture—thus, it cannot be used to teach the world.

He opposed the hearts of the world, and the world could not bear it. Though Mozi alone could endure it, what could he do about the world? Separated from the world, he was far from kingship.

*[Annotation]*
One who would be king must unite the world’s hearts and go forth with things.

*[Subcommentary]*
To rule the world, one must empty the heart and forget the self, greatly following the multitudes. Now, he destroyed the laws of the august kings and opposed the nature of the black-haired people—was he not far from ruling things?

Mozi spoke of the Way, saying: In ancient times, Yu dammed the floodwaters, dredged the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers, and opened the way to the four barbarians and the nine provinces. The great rivers numbered three hundred, their tributaries three thousand, and the smaller ones were beyond count.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Dammed" means "blocked." In ancient times, Yao suffered the flood and commanded Yu to regulate the waters. He set up blockages and embankments, dredged the rivers and streams, rescuing from the disaster of the hundred and six, and sowing the nine grains.

Yu personally wielded the basket and spade, nine times traversing the rivers of the world.

*[Subcommentary]*
The basket was a vessel for carrying earth; the spade, a tool for digging. Yu grasped the spade to dig the earth, carried the basket to bear the soil, and toiled in person to guide the rivers and plains. Thus, boats and oars came and went, and the nine provinces exchanged goods.

*[Alternative explanation]*
In ancient times, characters were few: *di* 涤 was used for *dang* 荡 ("to scour"), and *chuan* 川 for *yuan* 原 ("plains"). "Nine times" means the nine directions.

*[Another version]*
The character was originally written as *jiu* 鸠 ("to gather"), meaning to gather and dredge the rivers and valleys to guide the Yangtze and Yellow Rivers.

His calves had no flesh, his shins no hair. He washed in heavy rain and combed his hair in fierce winds, establishing the ten thousand states. Yu was a great sage, and his physical toil for the world was like this.

*[Annotation]*
Mozi saw only Yu’s physical toil but did not perceive the harmony of his nature.

*[Subcommentary]*
In dredging the hundred rivers and establishing the ten thousand states, hearing of Qi’s birth, he had no time for a brief visit. Passing his gate three times, he could not see his son. He relied on torrential rain to wash his hair and fierce winds to comb it. Constantly toiling and laboring, his form and countenance were worn and haggard, so that his calves and thighs had no flesh, and his knees and shins no hair. Yu’s Way was sagely, yet he himself endured hardship—how much more should we, the ordinary and mediocre, toil without ceasing?

Thus, later Mohists wore coarse garments of fur and hemp, and sandals of wood and grass. Day and night they did not rest, taking self-imposed suffering as their ultimate principle.

*[Annotation]*
They took self-imposed suffering as the perfect method of principle.

*[Subcommentary]*
Coarse garments of fur and hemp, wooden sandals and grass shoes—these were frugal. Working day and night without rest—this was exertion. Using these to impose suffering on themselves was the ultimate subtlety of principle.

They said: If one cannot be like this, it is not Yu’s Way and is insufficient to be called Mohist.

*[Annotation]*
To hold to this Way when it is not the time is what makes one Mohist.

*[Subcommentary]*
The Mohists were Yu’s distant descendants. Thus, those who could not endure hardship and departed from Yu’s Way could not be called Mohist.

Xiangli Qin’s disciples, the followers of Wu Hou, the southern Mohists Ku Huo and Ji Chi, Deng Lingzi and their like—all recited the *Mo Jing* but differed in their deviations and deceptions, calling one another "heterodox Mohists."

*[Annotation]*
Since each held to their own views, there was no communication anywhere. Thus, within Mohism, they further distinguished themselves from one another.

*[Subcommentary]*
Xiangli, named Qin, was a Mohist master of the south. Ku Huo, Wu Hou, and their like were all Mohist scholars. "Deviations" means "differences." Though they all recited the *Mo Jing*, they further differed from one another, calling each other "heterodox Mohists."

They criticized one another with debates on the hard and white, the same and different; they responded to one another with arguments of the odd and even, the matched and unmatched. They took the *juzi* as sages.

*[Annotation]*
The *juzi* was most able to distinguish what was right and perfect his conduct.

*[Subcommentary]*
"Criticized" means "slandered." *Ju* means "great." Singular arguments were called *qi* (odd); paired debates were called *ou* (even). *Wu* means "order." Deng Lingzi and his followers practiced Mohist techniques, stubbornly holding to the hard and white, each flaunting their abilities, merging differences into sameness, and splitting sameness into differences.

Some sang alone with few in harmony; others took turns as guest and host, exchanging words. They slandered one another with debates on being and non-being, right and wrong; they responded with disordered arguments. Those most diligent and frugal were hailed as sages. All wished to serve as their *shi*—

*[Annotation]*
*Shi* means "master."

—hoping to become their successors. Even now, their disputes remain unresolved.

*[Annotation]*
They desired to inherit the legacy of the *juzi*.

*[Subcommentary]*
All longed to be the master-teacher, hoping to transmit their teachings to posterity. Yet their contentious battles over victory and defeat could never be settled.

The intentions of Mo Di and Qin Guli were sound—

*[Annotation]*
Their aim was to avoid extravagance and prepare for the world’s emergencies; this is why they were correct.

—but their conduct was wrong.

*[Annotation]*
They carried it too far.

*[Subcommentary]*
Their intent was to save others, which was right; but their excessive frugality was wrong. They would have later Mohists necessarily torment themselves, advancing only by emaciating their calves and wearing away their body hair.

This is the height of disorder—

*[Annotation]*
No disorder is greater than acting against things and harming one’s nature.

—and the lowest form of governance.

*[Annotation]*
The highest governance follows the multitude and accords with nature; the Mohists do the opposite, hence they are the lowest.

*[Subcommentary]*
The Dao of Mozi goes against things and harms nature, making it the lowest art of governance and the foremost cause of chaos.
