Yet Mozi was truly one who loved the world—

*[Annotation]*
For he genuinely revered the sage-kings and did not act contrary to them, though his teachings could not be followed.

—his pursuit was unrelenting.

*[Annotation]*
Without equal.

Even when withered and gaunt, he did not abandon it.

*[Annotation]*
This is what made his love genuine.

*[Subcommentary]*
In all the world, only he loved frugality. Seeking his like, he could find none. Though so emaciated, he never ceased, for his nature was truly devoted—not feigned. He was a man of talent indeed!

*[Annotation]*
He was not a man of virtue.

*[Subcommentary]*
Alas! Though he acted against things and harmed nature, truly not a sage, he was still a man of talent, diligent and frugal, who sought to save the world.

Unburdened by custom, unadorned by things, uncompromising with others, unopposed to the multitude—

*[Annotation]*
*Zhi* means "to oppose."

*[Subcommentary]*
Free from the burdens of custom, unfeigning toward things, unyielding to others, uncontentious with the crowd, he stood by his name and conduct to nurture the common people.

He wished for the world’s peace to preserve lives, ceasing only when all—self and others—had enough.

*[Annotation]*
He dared not hope for surplus.

With this, he purified his heart. In this lay an ancient art of the Dao.

*[Subcommentary]*
Ever desiring the world’s tranquility to save the black-haired people, frugal in both self and others, knowing contentment—with this teaching, he purified his heart. An ancient art of the Dao resided in this, passed down without cease.

Song Jian and Yin Wen heard of his spirit and delighted in it.

*[Subcommentary]*
Song, named Jian; Yin, named Wen—both were men of King Xuan of Qi’s time, who studied together at Jixia. Song wrote one chapter, Yin two, both taking the common people as their teachers and naming their teachings accordingly. Their natures aligned with his teachings, so they heard of his spirit and rejoiced.

They fashioned the *Huashan* cap as their emblem—

*[Annotation]*
The Huashan cap is even above and below.

[Subcommentary]
Huashan’s form is like a sheer cliff, even above and below. Song and Yin, aspiring to lofty purity, fashioned it into a cap to mark their distinctive virtue.

They engaged with the myriad things, beginning with *separate enclosures*—

[Annotation]
Not desiring mutual encroachment.

[Subcommentary]
*Enclosures* means boundaries. *Beginning* means foundation. In establishing their teachings to respond to the world, they distinguished the ten thousand existences, taking this as their root.

The bearing of the heart they named *the heart’s conduct*—

[Subcommentary]
*Named* means designated. In speech and utterance, they always let the heart’s bearing embrace the myriad things, calling this receptivity *the heart’s conduct*.

With harmony they joined in joy, with regulation they harmonized the world—

[Annotation]
Forcibly harmonizing with their Way to bring union, adjusting to create peace.

They requested to establish this as the master—

[Annotation]
The two masters requested that one who embodied this be made the master of things.

[Subcommentary]
With this teaching they harmonized and regulated the Four Seas, hoping to unite all in joyful accord, establishing such a person as the master of things.

They endured insult without shame—

[Annotation]
Their urgency lay in saving the people.

They rescued the people from strife, forbade attack and stilled weapons, saving the world from war—

[Annotation]
This is what is meant by harmonizing and regulating.

[Subcommentary]
*Stilled* means ceased. Preventing aggression and halting warfare, their intent lay in reconciliation, forbidding combat. Even if mocked and humiliated, they took no offense, their purpose being to save the world—this was why.

With this they traversed the world, persuading above and instructing below. Though the world did not accept it, they clamored insistently without ceasing—

[Annotation]
This is the principle of harmonizing and regulating.

[Subcommentary]
With this teaching they transformed the Nine Provinces, persuading rulers above and instructing the common people below. Though the world rejected it, they pressed on with vehement exhortation, never abandoning their cause.

Thus it is said: above and below found them wearisome, yet they forced themselves forward—

[Annotation]
This is what is meant by enduring insult without shame.

[Subcommentary]
Though all found them contemptible, they still pressed forward to exhort others—this is what is meant by bearing humiliation without shame.

Yet in this, they did too much for others and too little for themselves—

[Annotation]
Not waiting for others to transform naturally but forcibly consoling them, their burden was too heavy.

[Subcommentary]
Those who attain the Dao and the sages respond only after being moved, first cultivating themselves before others. Now, by constantly pressing others and enduring rejection without cease, they exhausted themselves—was this not doing too little for themselves?

They said: We request only to set aside five *sheng* of rice—this is enough.

[Annotation]
This clarifies how little they did for themselves.

The master feared not being full, while the disciples, though hungry, never forgot the world—

[Annotation]
Song Jian and Yin Wen called the common people *master* and referred to themselves as *disciples*.

[Subcommentary]
Song and Yin called the black-haired people *master* and themselves *disciples*, putting others before themselves.

Their advance was unobstructed, their intent lying in diligence and frugality. Setting aside five *sheng* of rice for a day’s meal, they feared only the people’s hunger, not their own starvation. Never forgetting the world, they took this as their heart, diligently and frugally nourishing the common people. Following this method, they toiled day and night without rest.

Day and night they did not rest, saying: We must surely bring life!

[Annotation]
They meant that the people would repay them.

How towering were these saviors of the world!

[Annotation]
The bearing of one who thrusts aside all with lofty grandeur.

[Subcommentary]
*Towering* describes their lofty bearing. Their strength endured hardship as they aided and rescued the black-haired people. Though not yet aligned with the Dao, they could be called saviors of the world.

They said: The noble person does not engage in petty scrutiny—

[Annotation]
They devoted themselves to magnanimity.

[Subcommentary]
The worthy and noble person, forgiving and tolerant, never employs a mind of acceptance and rejection to scrutinize things.

Nor does he lend himself to things—

[Annotation]
He must exert his own strength.

[Subcommentary]
He establishes himself and seeks within, not relying on things to achieve fame.

They held that what brought no benefit to the world was better left unilluminated—

[Annotation]
This is why they were saviors of the world.

[Subcommentary]
*Left* means ceased. With toil of heart and strain of body, they contravened the Dao and opposed things. Since this brought no benefit to the world, it was better to cease than to proceed.

They took forbidding attack and stilling weapons as external—

[Subcommentary]
For the benefit of others, an external practice.

And taking desires to be few and shallow as internal—

[Subcommentary]
For self-benefit, an internal practice.

Their teachings, whether grand or fine, coarse or refined, extended only to this point and no further—

[Annotation]
They had not yet traversed emptiness or ventured into vastness.

[Subcommentary]
Benefiting self and others, internal and external practices—though differing in scale and varying in refinement, their guiding principles and essentials went no further than this.

Impartial yet not partisan, easygoing yet without bias, decisive yet without a fixed master—

[Annotation]
Each followed its own course.

[Subcommentary]
Impartial yet not partisan, level yet without partiality, deciding by principle without a fixed arbiter—this is what is meant by *law*, which lies herein.

They pursued things without duality—

[Annotation]
Things attained their proper pursuit, hence unity.

[Subcommentary]
Their intent lay in the pursuit of principle, not divided in regard to things.

Without regard for deliberation, without reliance on knowledge, without choosing among things, they proceeded with them all—

[Subcommentary]
Following principle and applying the law, they did not look ahead or behind, deciding with uprightness and without fear or deliberation. They did not employ knowledge or scheme beyond the law. Adhering to the law, they proceeded rigorously without selection.

An ancient art of the Dao resided in this—

[Subcommentary]
From the Five Emperors onward, there were those who governed by law as their art. Thus, traces worthy of esteem still remain in the world.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao heard of their spirit and delighted in it.

[Subcommentary]
By surname Peng, named Meng; by surname Tian, named Pian; by surname Shen, named Dao—all were recluses of Qi, who together frequented the Jixia Academy and each composed several chapters. Their natures accorded with the law, thus they heard of this spirit and delighted in it.

They took the equalization of the myriad things as their foremost principle, saying: Heaven can cover them but cannot bear them; Earth can bear them but cannot cover them; the great Dao can encompass them but cannot discriminate among them. Knowing that the myriad things each have what they can and cannot do, they said: selection is never all-encompassing.

[Annotation]
Only when all are employed is it complete.

[Subcommentary]
Heaven covers and Earth bears, each having its capacity; the great Dao embraces all yet does not discriminate. Thus, knowing the myriad things have their "can" and "cannot," one should follow their inherent dispositions and simply accord with them. If one seeks to select, it will inevitably be incomplete.

Teaching does not reach them;

[Annotation]
Only when one follows their nature does it attain.

The Dao leaves nothing behind.

[Subcommentary]
The myriad things differ, each endowed with distinct natures. To teach one with what belongs to another is far from the ultimate. But if one follows the profoundest Dao, then all things attain themselves without loss.

Therefore, Shen Dao discarded knowledge and abandoned the self, following only what could not be avoided. He refined and sifted things to establish his principle of the Dao.

[Annotation]
Refining and sifting mean letting things take their course.

[Subcommentary]
Refining and sifting mean selecting and tempering. Ceasing deliberation and discarding knowledge, forgetting the body and abandoning the self, responding only when compelled by circumstance, acting only upon stimulus—selecting and tempering right and wrong, deciding and judging according to the law—Shen Dao adhered to this as his principle of the Dao.

He said: to know what one does not know is to slight knowledge and then nearly harm it.

[Annotation]
This refers to shallow knowledge that does not entrust itself to spontaneity, thus slighting it and nearly causing harm.

[Subcommentary]
Knowledge has what it does not know, hence it is slight; though slight, it has not yet been entirely forgotten, thus it still nearly harms principle.

Unsteady and irresolute, he mocked the world’s esteem for worthies.

[Annotation]
Refusing to take up responsibility himself, he entrusted it to the multitude; if each of the multitude can act on their own, then there is no need to esteem worthies.

[Subcommentary]
Unsteady and irresolute: following things and according with circumstances, without fixed application. Each thing attains itself, without esteem for worthies or the capable, hence he mocked them.

Unrestrained and unprincipled, he denounced the world’s great sages.

[Annotation]
He sought to obliterate his traces so that things would not be ensnared.

[Subcommentary]
Indulgent and unconstrained, without the virtuous conduct of benevolence and righteousness, forgetting and leaving behind established traces, he thus denounced the sages of the world.

Crude and abrupt, yet pliable with things,

[Annotation]
Though the Legalist school was subtle, it remained crude and abrupt, thus not yet perfectly merged.

[Subcommentary]
Crude and abrupt: flogging and beating. Abrupt: carrying out punishments. Pliable: transforming. Again able to beat and punish, yet following the times, he could transform with things without rigidity.

Abandoning right and wrong, merely to avoid trouble,

[Subcommentary]
Not rigidly adhering to right and wrong, merely avoiding the affairs of the age.

Without relying on knowledge or deliberation, unaware of before or after,

[Annotation]
Unable to know right from wrong or before from after, he closed his eyes and indulged his nature, merely avoiding the troubles of the moment.

[Subcommentary]
Not following the heart’s inclinations, not employing knowledge or deliberation, nor looking ahead or behind—straightening his nature to accord with circumstances, he simply acted broadly, following things alone.

He remained towering and unmoved.

[Annotation]
Entrusting himself to his nature, standing alone.

[Subcommentary]
Towering and unmoved: a state of stillness. Though dwelling among the vulgar and mingling with the dust, he remained towering and independent.

Pushed, then he moved; pulled, then he went.

[Annotation]
This is what is meant by following what cannot be avoided.

[Subcommentary]
Pushed and pulled, following what cannot be avoided, responding only to stimulus, not initiating.

Like the whirling of a gust of wind, like the spinning of a feather, like the turning of a millstone—whole and without fault, in movement and stillness without transgression, never once incurring blame.

[Subcommentary]
Turning: grinding. Like the whirling of a gust of wind, the spinning of a falling feather, the turning of a millstone. These three are without intention, thus they remain whole and complete. Therefore, they are without right or wrong, without blame or transgression, without emotion, entrusting themselves to things—hence their steadfastness.

Is this not because—

[Subcommentary]
Posing a hypothetical question to reveal his capacity.

—things without knowledge have no trouble from establishing the self, no burden from employing knowledge, and in movement and stillness do not depart from principle, thus they live out their lives without praise.

[Annotation]
Trouble arises from praise, and praise arises from establishing.

[Subcommentary]
All things are mired in attachment to the self, establishing merit and fame, employing the heart’s knowledge and drowning in external realms. But the millstone and the like—acting or resting as things dictate, without intention, always abiding in the wondrous principle—cut off trouble and burden, thus fulfilling their Heaven-appointed destiny without blame or praise.

Hence it is said: to reach the state of things without knowledge is all; there is no use for worthies and sages.

[Annotation]
Only the sage can then discard knowledge and precedent, following Heaven’s principle. Thus, the foolish and the wise each occupy their proper place, the noble and the base each attain their rightful position, the worthy and the unworthy each follow their nature. To say there is no use for worthies and sages is not to know the Dao.

A clod of earth does not lose the Dao.

[Annotation]
It is joyful to discard knowledge like a clod of earth.

This is also said of ordinary things in general—none can attain the Dao, for the Dao does not pervade things.

[Subcommentary]
Esteeming the absence of knowledge, one’s nature becomes like tile and stone; rejecting worthies and sages, one is as benighted as one who wanders in darkness. Thus, like a clod of earth, one is said to attain principle. Such were the confusions of Shen Dao.

The eminent and powerful mocked him together, saying: The Dao of Shen Dao is not the conduct of the living but the principle of the dead.

The annotation states: To discard knowledge and follow one’s nature is to allow the spirit’s illumination to shine through—this is how one praises the sage. Yet to say that a clod of earth does not lose the Dao, that man should be like a clod of earth—how is this not death? This is why the eminent and powerful mocked him.

The subcommentary explains: The sage who attains the Dao illuminates all things without intent, their virtue harmonizing with the Two Modes and their clarity equaling the Three Luminaries. Yet to take a clod of earth as the Dao—how does this differ from death? Devoid of spiritual efficacy, it is not the conduct of the living. Thus, the learned and discerning, the profound and eminent, recognizing its deviation from principle, derided it as absurd.

The annotation adds: Failing to accord with the supreme Dao, it becomes strange and monstrous.

The subcommentary continues: Those who do not accord with the supreme Dao become precisely that—strange and monstrous. Tian Pian was likewise misguided, having studied under Peng Meng yet received no true teaching.

The annotation states: He attained the Dao of self-reliance.

The subcommentary explains: Tian Pian and Shen Dao, disciples of Peng Meng, indulged in unrestrained abandon, receiving no instruction. Peng Meng’s master said: The Daoist of old reached the point of neither affirming nor denying anything.

The annotation states: This is what is meant by "taking the equality of the ten thousand things as foremost."

The wind blew fiercely—how could one speak against it?

The annotation states: The sound stirred by the wind.

The subcommentary explains: *Huòrán* describes swiftness. The Daoist of old, emptying the heart and forgetting the self, took heaven and earth as their measure, no longer distinguishing right from wrong. Their influence, like the wind, passed swiftly—how could one cling to their sagely traces or fix them in words? They constantly opposed others, gathering no admiration,

The annotation states: Not conforming to popular expectations.

The subcommentary explains: Unable to fully align with the multitude, they often defied human sentiment, nor could they earn the veneration of the people.

yet were not exempt from the bluntness of the turtle’s cut.

The annotation states: Though they established laws, their edges were as dull as a turtle’s severed limb.

The subcommentary explains: *Yuánduàn* describes the lack of sharp edges. Though they enacted laws and spread transformation, they failed to fully equalize the ten thousand things, thus remaining subject to such bluntness.

What they called the Dao was not the Dao, and what they deemed correct was not free from error.

The annotation states: *Wěi* means "correct."

The subcommentary explains: *Wěi* means "correct." What Shen Dao called the Dao was not the true Dao, and what he claimed as correct was incorrect, hence not free from error.

Peng Meng, Tian Pian, and Shen Dao did not know the Dao.

The annotation states: The Dao is present in all things, yet to say that a clod of earth does not lose the Dao is to show ignorance.

The subcommentary explains: Though they practiced emptiness and forgetting, taking non-intention as the Dao, they failed to achieve perfect illumination—thus, they did not know it.

Nevertheless, in general, they had once heard of it.

The annotation states: They simply did not reach it.

The subcommentary explains: Though Peng Meng and his followers did not embody the truth, their aspirations were lofty. They possessed a rough outline, learning from one another, and had some basis—not mere arbitrary conjecture. Thus, they had once heard of it.

Taking the root as refined, the material as coarse,

The subcommentary explains: The root is non-being; the material is being. Employing non-being is subtle, the Dao refined; employing being is practical, the material coarse.

and accumulation as insufficient,

The annotation states: Entrusting it to the world, one finds abundance.

The subcommentary explains: Greed and hoarding leave the heart forever unsatisfied. Knowing contentment and stopping at one’s allotted share, one remains clear, pure, and empty, independent and self-sufficient in spirit. The Dao is omnipresent—such has been the case since antiquity.

Guan Yin and Lao Dan heard of their teachings and delighted in them.

The subcommentary explains: His surname was Yin, given name Xi, courtesy name Gongdu. During the reign of King Ping of Zhou, he served as the magistrate of Hangu Pass, hence known as Guan Yin. His surname was Li, given name Er, courtesy name Boyang, with the alternate name Lao Dan—Laozi, the teacher of Yin Xi.

Master and disciple echoed one another, their principles in harmony. Thus, they rejoiced in the teachings of non-action.

They established it upon constant non-being and being,

The annotation states: What can non-being and being establish? Establishing them upon constant non-being and being clarifies that things establish themselves.

and took the Great Unity as their foundation.

The annotation states: From heaven and earth to the myriad things, each attains its own nature without adornment—is this not taking the Great Unity as their foundation?

The subcommentary explains: *Tai* denotes vastness; *yi* signifies oneness. The great Dao is boundless, encompassing all things, uniting them into one—hence the term *Taiyi*.

In establishing their teachings, they always took the constancy of non-being as their principle, awakening to its essence and taking the empty pervasiveness of the Great Unity as their foundation. This was their preference for frugality, which wearied their physical forms—it could not be taught to others, nor did it harm their Daoist arts.

They took gentleness, weakness, humility, and deference as their outward conduct, and emptiness and non-destruction of the ten thousand things as their substance.

The subcommentary explains: Outward conduct refers to external actions. They took softness, weakness, humility, and harmony as their external wisdom, and empty kindness and all-encompassing clarity as their internal virtue.

Guan Yin said: Within oneself, one holds nothing,

The annotation states: Things come, and one responds; responding without retention, thus merit follows things away.

The subcommentary explains: Not claiming merit, one attributes success to things—this is how one cultivates oneself.

while the forms of things manifest themselves.

The annotation states: Not asserting oneself but entrusting things, thus the forms of things each manifest clearly.

The subcommentary explains: Entrusting things without claiming merit, their natures and forms each manifest clearly.

Their movement is like water, their stillness like a mirror, their response like an echo.

The annotation states: They are constantly without emotion.

The subcommentary explains: Moving like flowing water, still like a hanging mirror, their response to stimuli swift as an echo—movement and stillness are without intent, their spiritual efficacy thus rapid.

Vague as if vanished, silent as if pure, those who harmonize with them find harmony, while those who grasp them lose.

The annotation states: Those who constantly preserve wholeness know not what they have gained.

The subcommentary explains: *Wù* means "faint," *wáng* means "nonexistent." The Dao is neither being nor nonbeing, neither pure nor turbid—thus it seems faintly vanished, yet its essence is not nonexistent; still and silent as if pure. Those who align with it, disregarding purity or turbidity, harmonize with the shallow perceptions of the common world. Yet if one takes this purity, emptiness, and nothingness as virtue, one loses the Dao.

It never precedes others but always follows them.

The subcommentary explains: Harmonizing without leading.

Lao Dan said: "Know the masculine, yet guard the feminine, and be a ravine for the world; know the white, yet guard the blackened, and be a valley for the world."

The annotation states: When things each guard their own place, they remain still and silent—what need is there for the masculine or the white? Are not the masculine and the white those who esteem victory and self-display? To esteem victory and self-display—is this not to pursue knowledge beyond one’s bounds and endanger one’s life? Thus the ancients did not follow boundless knowledge but guarded what was within their own bounds, and so their natures remained whole. When their natures were whole, only then could they extend to the world; when they could extend to the world, only then did all return to them as to a ravine or valley.

The subcommentary explains: Heroes and outstanding figures advance with restlessness and thus shorten their years; the feminine and the humble retreat in stillness and thus endure. Therefore, one abandons the glory of brilliance and self-display and embraces the humility of concealing one’s light—this is the pivotal mechanism of studying the Dao, and thus one becomes a ravine or valley for the world. Both ravines and valleys are watercourses, though ravines are small and valleys large, hence the repetition.

While others all seek to be first, I alone take the rear.

The annotation states: Not contending with the myriad things, one is then willingly elevated by the world without resentment, thus placing oneself behind.

The subcommentary explains: Common people all esteem victory and strive to be first, yet the great sage alone humbly remains behind, as the *Dao Jing* says: "Place oneself behind, and one finds oneself in front."

It is called bearing the world’s disgrace.

The annotation states: The feminine, the humiliated, the lowly—these are what the world calls disgrace.

The subcommentary explains: Retreating and placing oneself behind, one elevates others first—this is to bear disgrace.

While others all seek the substantial,

The annotation states: They know only being as useful, not knowing nonbeing as function.

The subcommentary explains: They covet material wealth.

I alone take the empty.

The annotation states: Guarding emptiness and tranquility to await the many substantial things.

The subcommentary explains: Guarding emptiness and stillness.

Having no hoarding, thus having surplus.

The annotation states: Entrusting things to guard themselves, one does not fear scarcity.

The subcommentary explains: *Cáng* means "to accumulate." Knowing contentment and guarding one’s bounds, one disperses without accumulating, thus having surplus.

Abiding in independence, thus having surplus.

The annotation states: This is what is meant by "standing alone and self-sufficient."

The subcommentary explains: *Kuīrán* means "independent." It speaks of purity and self-restraint, which are rare among things—only the sage remains without intent.

In conducting oneself, one moves slowly and without waste.

The annotation states: Acting according to what benefits the people, following the four seasons to bring things to completion, always in accord with the principle of the Dao, thus without haste or waste.

The subcommentary explains: *Fèi* means "loss." The one who has attained the Dao does not bestow petty favors; they eat from simple fields and stand in unborrowed gardens, at ease and unhurried, never harming themselves for the sake of things. This is how they conduct themselves and nurture their being.

Acting without contrivance, one laughs at craftiness.

The annotation states: Craftiness is contrivance, which harms the self-completion of the spiritual vessel. Thus the one who acts without contrivance follows things’ spontaneous arising and allows their spontaneous completion—each thing attains its own ability. Even a spider can spin its web, so every person has their own abilities; there is no need to value Gongshu.

The subcommentary explains: Moving in accord with one’s nature, simple and without contrivance, one scorns the cunning and falsity of common people.

While others all seek fortune, I alone bend to preserve wholeness.

The annotation states: Entrusting oneself to the ultimate principle, one remains constantly whole—thus one seeks no fortune, for fortune is already sufficient.

It is called merely avoiding blame.

The annotation states: Following things, thus things cannot blame one.

The subcommentary explains: *Jiù* means "misfortune." Common people, deluded and obstinate in their actions, know only to seek fortune and cannot consider misfortune. Only the great sage, with an empty mind, follows things with flexibility, preserving the way of life and thus avoiding calamity.

Taking profundity as the root,

The annotation states: The principle is rooted in the ultimate of the Great Beginning—it cannot be called shallow.

taking restraint as the guiding principle,

The annotation states: Avoiding excess and extravagance.

The subcommentary explains: Taking profound mystery as the root of virtue, taking frugality and restraint as the guiding principles of conduct.

It is said: What is rigid will break,

The annotation states: In perfect compliance, even metal and stone are not rigid; in opposition, even water and vapor cannot be altered. Perfect compliance preserves, opposition destroys—this is the correct principle.

what is sharp will be blunted.

The annotation states: Advancing restlessly without bounds is sharpness.

The subcommentary explains: Breaking the rigid conduct of strength, blunting the sharpness of greed—thus the *Dao Jing* says: "Blunt its sharpness."

Always being magnanimous toward things,

The annotation states: When each guards their own place, there is naturally room for all.

not diminishing others,

The annotation states: Preserving their nature.

The subcommentary explains: Retreating and being humble, thus magnanimous toward things; knowing contentment and guarding one’s bounds, thus not encroaching upon others.

this may be called the ultimate.

Guan Yin and Lao Dan—were they not the vast and true persons of antiquity?

The subcommentary explains: Guan Yin and Laozi, great sages of antiquity, plumbed the subtlest mysteries and merged with the true and the Dao. Their teachings were vast and boundless, their principles broad and profoundly mysterious. Zhuangzi was nearly their equal, hence this sigh.

Still and silent, without form; transforming without constancy,

The annotation states: Following things.

The subcommentary explains: The wondrous source is formless, thus still and silent; its traces follow things’ transformations, thus without constancy.

death and life together with it, heaven and earth in unison with it, the spirits and the bright in accord with it.

The annotation states: Following transformations.

The subcommentary explains: Taking death and life as day and night, thus uniting the two poles; turning with the workings of creation, thus journeying together with the spirits and the bright.

Vast and boundless—where does it go? Fleeting and swift—where does it proceed?

The annotation states: Without intention or direction.

The subcommentary explains: Entrusting itself to nature’s transformations, drifting with the boundless and the fleeting, roaming carefree; having no attachment to going or staying, it follows fate wherever it leads.

All things are encompassed, yet none can serve as its refuge.

The annotation states: Thus it remains wherever placed.

The subcommentary explains: Embracing the myriad things, enfolding the cosmos, never departing from the Dao—where could it return to its root?

Among the arts of the Dao in antiquity, there were those who dwelt in this. Zhuang Zhou heard of their teachings and delighted in them. With far-reaching discourse, vast and unbounded words, and speech without limits or boundaries, he gave free rein to his thoughts without constraint, never revealing his intent through partiality.

The annotation states: Not eager to make others perceive his meaning.

The subcommentary explains: *Miù* means empty; *yōu*, distant; *huāngtáng*, vast and boundless; *zìzòng*, unrestrained. *Jī* means uneven. Yet Zhuangzi, born to respond to the world, inwardly merged with the mysterious Dao. Thus he could expound teachings of emptiness, depth, and vastness, uttering words without end or thread, following the moment without bias, harmonizing his qi with the world, never standing apart.

He saw the world as sunk in turbidity, unfit for solemn speech.

The annotation states: Burdened by forms and names, they take solemn speech for madness and do not believe it—hence he did not engage them.

The subcommentary explains: *Zhuāngyǔ* means grand discourse. The common people of the world, mired in darkness and murk, all drown in petty distinctions—one cannot speak grand words to them.

He used *zhīyán* for ceaseless unfolding, *zhòngyán* for truth, and *yùyán* for breadth.

The subcommentary explains: *Zhīyán* is indeterminate; *mànyǎn*, without fixed intent. *Zhòng* refers to venerable elders. *Yù* means to lodge. A *zhī* vessel tips when full and rights itself when empty—thus it serves as a metaphor for perfect speech. The words of the aged, embodying much truth, and the principles lodged in others, profound and vast—such are the followers of Hong Meng, Yun Jiang, and Hai Ruo.

Alone he communed with the spirit of heaven and earth, yet did not look down upon the myriad things.

The annotation states: His words reached the ultimate principle, rightly ordering the nature and destiny of all things.

The subcommentary explains: *Áoniè* means arrogance. Embracing the wisdom of true essence and wielding the unfathomable spirit, he dwelt within the world, coming and going with birth and death. Humble and yielding to things, he was never arrogant.

He did not reproach right or wrong,

The annotation states: Having no right or wrong of his own, he let things follow their course.

to dwell among the common world.

The annotation states: Moving among things in form.

The subcommentary explains: *Qiǎn* means to blame. With no fixed right or wrong, it cannot be exhaustively reproached—thus he could ride the waves of the world and abide in the dust.

His writings, though magnificent and far-reaching, remained unharmed by contradiction.

The annotation states: Returning to harmony with things, thus unharmed.

The subcommentary explains: *Guīwěi* means grand and majestic; *liánfān*, harmonious and blended. Zhuangzi’s writings, though lofty and profound, still touched upon the common—thus they harmonized with things without harm.

His words, though uneven, were strange and wondrous to behold.

The annotation states: Not merely addressing the affairs of the time, hence uneven.

The subcommentary explains: *Cēncī* means now empty, now full—his words were not uniform. *Chùguǐ* means witty and playful. Though his parables and allusions spanned different eras, their humor and wit were most engaging.

His fullness could not be exhausted,

The annotation states: Abounding in all things.

The subcommentary explains: *Yǐ* means to cease. His writings, with their lucid words and far-reaching principles, embraced all things without limit—thus they could not be brought to an end.

Above, he roamed with the Creator, and below, he befriended those beyond death and life, without beginning or end.

The subcommentary explains: Riding transformations in carefree wandering, he befriended nature itself—thus he could merge life and death, darkening the distinction between beginning and end. From the subtle root to the coarse traces, his words descended to the lowest.

In regard to the root, his teachings were vast and expansive, profound and unrestrained; in regard to the source, they may be called fitting and ascending.

The subcommentary explains: *Pì* means to open; *hóng*, vast; *hóng*, also vast; *sì*, to extend; *suì*, to reach. Speaking of the ultimate root, his teachings were deep and vast, extending and opening without bound. The true source was attuned and ascended to the mysterious Dao.

Yet though he responded to transformations and untangled things,

The subcommentary explains: Though Zhuangzi’s writings were strange and wondrous, they responded to the changes of the moment and untangled the affairs of things—none surpassed them.

their principles were inexhaustible, their coming undiscarded.

The subcommentary explains: *Tuì* means to shed. The mysterious principles were empty and profound, responding without end; yet when the moment came to move him, he never shed or abandoned it.

Vast and obscure—who has fully grasped them?

The annotation states: Zhuangzi consistently spoke with a level mind, no different when speaking of himself than of others. Examining his words, they are vast and flowing—like Yu’s reverent reception of great counsel, what fault could lie here?

The subcommentary explains: *Mángmèi* means dark and deep. Zhuangzi’s writings were profound and distant, vast and obscure, beyond sight or hearing. If one seeks them through words and images, their depths remain unfathomed.

Hui Shi was versatile in many arts; his writings filled five carts. His Way was errant and mixed, his words often missing the mark.

The subcommentary explains: *Chuǎn* means divergent; *bó*, tangled. With many arts and five carts of writings, his principles were scattered and impure, his words eloquent but often off the mark.

In his reflections on things,

The subcommentary explains: His mind roamed the myriad things, examining and debating them.

he said: "That which is greatest and without outside is called the Great One..."

That which is smallest and without inside is called the Small One.

The subcommentary explains: Encompassing all without outside is called great; entering into the spaceless is called small. Though great and small bear different names, in principle they return to the undivided—hence they are called One. Without thickness, it cannot be accumulated, yet its vastness spans a thousand *li*.

The subcommentary explains: In principle, it is so subtle that it cannot be grasped; transcending form and color, how could it have thickness? Thus it cannot be accumulated or piled up. Not only does it not exist, it also does not not-exist—being and non-being give rise to one another, hence its vastness spans a thousand *li*. Heaven and earth are base; mountains and marshes are level.

The subcommentary explains: By common perception, heaven is high and earth is low, mountains tower and marshes lie below. Yet viewed through the Dao, mountains and marshes are equal in levelness, heaven and earth are one. The *Qi Wu* chapter says, "Nothing is greater than an autumn hair, yet Mount Tai is small"—this is its meaning. The sun is at once at its zenith and slanting; things are at once born and dying.

The subcommentary explains: *Nì* means slanted. Those in the west call it "zenith," while those in the east call it "slanting"—thus there is no true zenith or slant. It is like life and death: the living take death as death, while the dead take life as death. Since the sun’s zenith and slant are not distinct, so too are life and death without difference. That the great same differs from the small same is called the small same-and-different.

The subcommentary explains: Common perception distinguishes sameness and difference—this is the small same-and-different. That the myriad things are wholly the same and wholly different is called the great same-and-different.

The subcommentary explains: Life and death alternate, cold and heat succeed one another; forms and natures differ, yet in principle they are without distinction. The southern region is without limit yet has a limit.

The subcommentary explains: Knowing the four directions are without limit, one meets with things. Form does not exhaust form; color does not exhaust color—form and color exhaust one another. Knowledge does not exhaust knowledge; things do not exhaust things—exhaustion and things exhaust one another. Only because it is without thickness can it not be accumulated. Speaking only of the southern region is to illustrate one corner—from which the other three may be known. Today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday.

The subcommentary explains: Gazing from the present to the past, one has the present; gazing from the past to the present, one has the past. Yet if the present is not truly present, how can there be a past? If the past is not truly past, how can there be a present? Since there is neither past nor present, it may be said that today I go to Yue, yet I arrived yesterday. Linked rings can be unlinked.

The subcommentary explains: Rings interlock through their empty spaces, not through the rings themselves. Thus two rings pass through emptiness without penetrating one another, each turning freely—hence they can be unlinked. I know the center of the world: it is north of Yan and south of Yue.

The subcommentary explains: Yan and Yue are two states, far apart; common perception clings to directions, each claiming its own. Thus north of Yan and south of Yue may be called the world’s center. Embracing the myriad things with universal love, heaven and earth are one body.

The subcommentary explains: The myriad things and I are one—hence I embrace them with love. The Two Modes and I arise together—hence we are of one body. Hui Shi took this as the greatest principle, observing the world and enlightening debaters with it.

The subcommentary explains: Hui Shi used this principle, considering it supreme, and illuminated the world, instructing debaters with it. The world’s debaters delighted in it together.

The subcommentary explains: Sharing the same love and resonating in nature, the debaters of the world took joy in studying it. Eggs have feathers.

The subcommentary explains: Being and non-being are both names returning to emptiness. Common perception clings to appearances, saying eggs have no feathers—but since names are empty, they may be said to have feathers. A chicken has three feet.

The subcommentary explains: Numbers arise from emptiness and nothingness; from nothingness they proceed to being, and names are established. Thus two and three ultimately lack real substance—hence a chicken’s two feet may be called three. Since this is so for a chicken’s feet, it may be seen in all things. Ying possesses the world.

The subcommentary explains: Ying was the capital of Chu, seventy *li* north of Jiangling. All things have their place, each with its four directions—thus north of Yan and south of Yue may be called the world’s center. The state of Chu, with Ying as its capital, spanned a thousand *li*—why could it not be called the world? A dog can be called a sheep.

The subcommentary explains: Names have no power to grasp things; things have no reality corresponding to names. Names and realities are not fixed—hence a dog may be called a sheep. The people of Zheng call uncut jade *pú*; the people of Zhou call an uncured rat *pú*—thus form resides in things, while names reside in people. Horses lay eggs.

The subcommentary explains: Birth from wombs, eggs, or transformation—common perception distinguishes them, but viewed through the Dao, they are not different. Since a crow’s egg has feathers, why could a beast’s womb not be called an egg? A tadpole has a tail.

The subcommentary explains: The people of Chu call a toad a *dīngzǐ*. That toads have no tails is known to all—this is common perception, not the ultimate principle. Viewed through the Dao, nothing is without being, and since non-being may still be called "without," why could non-having not be called a tail? Fire is not hot.

The subcommentary explains: Fire is hot and water is cold—this arises from common perception. Viewed through principle, they are neither cold nor hot. Why? In the south there is a fire-eating beast, and sages enter water without getting wet. By this reasoning, they are fundamentally neither cold nor hot. It is like a staff striking the body, yet pain arises in the person—the person feels pain, but the staff does not. So too fire touches the body, yet heat arises in the person—the person feels heat, but fire does not. Mountains have mouths.

The subcommentary explains: Mountains originally have no names—mountain names come from the mouths of people.

In mountains it is thus, and the myriad phenomena are all the same.

The wheel does not tread upon the earth.
The subcommentary explains: When a chariot moves, its wheels turn without cease. The track ahead has already passed, and the path behind has yet to arrive—between past and future, there is no moment of treading. Thus, though the wheel rolls on, it never truly touches the ground. As the *Zhao Lun* says: "The whirling storm levels mountains yet remains still; rivers rush forth yet do not flow. The wild horse gallops yet does not move; the sun and moon traverse the heavens yet do not revolve." What is strange in this? What is strange in this?

The eye does not see.
The subcommentary explains: For the eye to see an object, it must depend on conditions. Since conditions are inherently empty, the eye cannot truly see.

The finger does not reach, yet reaching is unceasing.
The subcommentary explains: When a finger points to an object, it is not the finger itself—thus, the finger does not reach. Yet without the eye, the finger attains the object—thus, reaching is unceasing.

The tortoise is longer than the snake.
The subcommentary explains: In comparing length, there is no inherent long or short. To say the snake is long and the tortoise short is merely the stagnant perception of things. To dispel this delusion, it is said the tortoise is longer than the snake.

The carpenter’s square is not square, and the compass cannot make a circle.
The subcommentary explains: The compass draws circles and the square makes right angles—this has been so for ages. Yet names are not fixed, and square and circle have no true essence; thus, they cannot do so.

The mortise does not encircle the tenon.
The subcommentary explains: The mortise is the hollow; the tenon is the wood that fits into it. When the tenon enters the mortise, the wood passes through the empty space without obstruction—thus, it does not encircle. This is like the principle that interlocking rings can be separated.

The shadow of a flying bird has never moved.
The subcommentary explains: The past has already vanished, the future has yet to come—beyond past and future, there is no moment of flight. Only the bird and its shadow remain utterly still. Thus, all things in the world are fundamentally quiescent. As the *Zhao Lun* says: "The four images race like the wind, the celestial sphere turns like lightning—grasp the subtlest meaning, and though they shift, they do not change." This is what is meant by "things do not move."

The speeding arrow has a time when it neither moves nor stops.
The subcommentary explains: The *zú* is the tip of the arrow. Though its flight is swift, it does not escape the three times—no different from the wheel’s motion or the bird’s shadow. Since it neither treads nor moves, how can the arrow be said to stop or go? It is like a sharp blade cutting three strands of silk—within it, there are past, future, and present.

A dog is not a hound.
The subcommentary explains: Dog and hound are two names for one thing. Since names are empty, a dog is not a hound. Dog and hound share the same essence but differ in designation. When name and reality align, one calls it a dog, another a hound; when they diverge, one calls it a dog, distinct from a hound. As *Mozi* says: "A dog is a hound, yet a dog is not a hound."

A yellow horse and a black ox make three.
The subcommentary explains: Form is not color, and color is not form. Thus, one horse and one ox make two; add the horse’s color, and they become three. Say "yellow horse," "black ox," and "yellow-black"—form becomes three. It is like one and speech making two, and two with one making three.

A white dog is black.
The subcommentary explains: Names and designations are unreal; form and color are empty. To counter clinging perception, it is said the white is black.

A lone colt has never had a mother.

A one-foot staff, halved each day, will never be exhausted in ten thousand generations.
The subcommentary explains: *Chuí* is a staff; *qǔ* means to break. Someone asks: A one-foot staff, halved this morning, will leave five inches by evening. Within two days, the staff should be exhausted. This is plainly evident—how can it not be exhausted? The answer: Names correspond to reality, and reality to names. Thus, seeking things by name, they cannot be hidden. If one clings to the name "one-foot staff" and takes from it each time, how can there be an end? But if one breaks it at five inches, the name is violated—it is then called "half a foot," which is not the meaning of "one foot." The debaters align this with Hui Shi’s argument, remaining inexhaustible for a lifetime.

Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, disciples of the debaters,
The subcommentary explains: Huan Tuan and Gongsun Long, both from Zhao, were masters of debate who lodged in the household of Lord Pingyuan. Gongsun Long wrote the *On Guarding Whiteness*, which circulates in the world. Using the above staff argument, they echoed and harmonized with one another, spending their years thus, never reaching an end.

They adorn the human mind and alter human intent,
The subcommentary explains: Indulging in such profound debates, they embellish the human mind and, with refined words, change human understanding.

Able to triumph over others’ mouths, but not to subdue their hearts—this is the debaters’ enclosure.
The subcommentary explains: Their arguments surpass things, so they can triumph over others’ mouths; their words do not accord with principle, so they cannot subdue others’ hearts. Thus, the debaters make this their preserve.
Another explanation: *Yòu* means "boundary." Hui Shi’s words do not align with principle; what they expound is confined to this limit.

Hui Shi said: With his knowledge and others’ debates, he alone created wonders with the world’s debaters—this was his foundation.
The subcommentary explains: *Tè* means "alone"; the character may also be written as *jiāng* ("to lead"). *Guài* means "strange"; *dǐ* means "essence." Hui Shi used discriminating knowledge to engage in debate, leading himself to stand apart from the world. Though his arguments were myriad, their essence did not surpass this.

Yet Hui Shi’s eloquence, he himself deemed most worthy,
The subcommentary explains: *Rán* means "thus." Hui Shi’s understanding of principle was second only to Zhuangzi, and his eloquence he considered superior to all. How could he be like those who merely debate?

Saying: "Heaven and earth are as vast as Zhuangzi!"

Hui Shi possessed grandeur in his five arts.
The subcommentary explains: *Zhuāng* means "great"; *wèi* means "the Dao/Way." He claimed that heaven and earth, born alongside me, were not great enough to be called so. His intent lay in heroic brilliance, surpassing the world and outshining others. Lacking humility and gentleness, he thus lacked the true Dao. Yet in speaking of his strength, he was uniquely mighty.

In the south there was an extraordinary man named Huang Liao, who asked why heaven and earth neither fell nor sank, and what caused wind, rain, and thunder.
The subcommentary explains: Dwelling in the south, surnamed Huang and named Liao, he did not conform to the common and stood apart from others, a wandering scholar beyond the mundane. Having heard of Hui Shi’s keen eloquence, he came to pose questions: how the two primal forces endured, and from what origins wind, rain, and thunder arose in their movements.

Hui Shi did not decline but responded, did not ponder but answered.
The subcommentary explains: With heroic spirit and unrestrained eloquence, he thus replied without refusal and answered without deliberation.

He expounded on the myriad things in all their aspects, speaking without cease, exhaustively and without end, yet still deemed it too little, adding the strange to augment it.
The subcommentary explains: He exhaustively expounded on the origins of the myriad things, explaining the causes of the two primal forces and thunder, never resting. Yet he still found it too brief, so he added the bizarre to display his talent.

Taking contrarian views as truth and desiring to surpass others in fame, he thus could not harmonize with the multitude.
The subcommentary explains: He took views contrary to human nature as the true Dao, always seeking to surpass all things and stand above the crowd, his heart set on reputation. Thus he could not find accord with the world.

Weak in virtue, strong in things, his path was obscure.
The subcommentary explains: *Tú* means "path." His virtue was exceedingly weak, yet his grasp of things was extreme. He claimed his path was profoundly secluded.

Viewed from the Dao of heaven and earth, Hui Shi’s abilities were like the toil of a single mosquito or midge—what use were they to things?
The subcommentary explains: *Yóu* means "from"; *yōng* means "use." From the Dao of the two primal forces’ generation and completion, Hui Shi’s power to transform things differed not from a mosquito or midge flying in the void, flapping its wings in clamor—merely exhausting itself. What could be said of it? His words on benefiting things were thus rendered useless.

To fill but one measure might yet be called daily more noble; how near he was to the Dao!
The subcommentary explains: *Jī* means "near." Hui Shi’s eloquence, though not vast in expounding principle, might yet fill one measure among the myriad things. Yet he sought to sharpen his passion for the noble Dao, adorning his intent to approach truth. Judged sincerely, this was truly not possible.

Hui Shi could not find peace in this, scattering himself among the myriad things without surfeit, and in the end gained fame for his eloquence.
The subcommentary explains: *Zú* means "end." He could not employ this profound Dao to bring himself peace, instead dissipating his spirit in lofty discourse on the myriad things. In the end, he had no Dao to preserve, gaining only the name of a debater.

Alas! Hui Shi’s talent overflowed yet found no outlet, chasing the myriad things without return—like pursuing an echo for its sound, or racing one’s shadow in a contest of speed. How lamentable!

Formerly, before I had perused the *Zhuangzi*, I once heard debaters contend over the meaning of "the foot-long staff" and "the linked rings," all claiming these were words of Master Zhuang, and thus classed Master Zhuang among the sophists. Examining this chapter’s critique of the various masters, however, when it reaches this passage, it states that his Dao is contradictory and discordant, his words miss the mark—thus I realized how hearsay on the roads harms truth. I too believed these were discourses without governance of the state or attainment of truth, mere useless talk.

Yet the sons of the rich and noble, like all who indulge in play, may grow weary of canonical words, yet still be able to distinguish names and analyze principles, thereby expressing their qi and ordering their thoughts. Flowing into later ages, if they keep their natures from depravity, is this not still more worthy than those who gamble and play chess? Thus I preserve these words without further judgment, leaving them to those who delight in such matters.

The subcommentary explains: *Dài* means "to let loose." How grievous that Hui Shi, though talented, lacked the Dao, letting his eloquence run wild without grasping the true source, racing after the ends of the myriad things and unable to return to the wondrous root. For in attaining principle, nothing surpasses forgetting knowledge; in returning to the source, nothing exceeds stilling debate. Yet Hui Shi toiled his mind and artifice in pursuit of the Dao, pouring forth his unadorned truth like a flooding river—how is this different from one who seeks to escape an echo by amplifying its sound, or flees a shadow by hastening his steps? With such prodigious talent, how deeply lamentable!

The *Nanhua Zhenjing Zhu Shu*, Scroll Thirty-Five, concludes. #1 The *Siku* edition emends *zuò* to *suǒ*.

#2 The character *zhě* is amended to *míng* ("name") following the Zhao Jianyi edition and the *Siku* edition. #3 The original *cāo* is suspected to be erroneous and is amended to *cān* ("to participate") following the *Siku* edition. #4 The Kōzan-ji edition omits the two characters *wéi yì* ("as intent"). #5 Wang Xiaoyu follows Wang Shumin’s suggestion that *mò* ("end") should be *dù* ("measure"). #6 The *Siku* edition renders *pì* identically as *pì*. #7 The Shide Tang edition reads *bǎi yī* as *yǒu* ("there is"). #8 Wang Xiaoyu amends *cháng* ("constant") to *cháng* ("once"). #9 The *Siku* edition renders *gù* ("therefore") as *ér* ("and"). #10 The *Siku* edition renders *xún* ("to follow") as *shùn* ("to comply"). #11 The character *wù* ("thing") is suspected to be missing and is supplied following the *Siku* edition and the Zhejiang Bureau edition. #12 The original *jūn* ("lord") is amended to *sān* ("three") following the main text and Guo Qingfan’s citation. #13 The two characters *Zhái xìng* ("Zhai’s nature") are supplied following the main text and Guo Qingfan’s citation. #14 The *Siku* edition adds the character *zhě* ("one who") below *xī* ("formerly"). #15 The *Quēwù* cites the Jiangnan Ancient Repository edition and the Li edition, both reading *zá* ("miscellaneous") as *dí* ("to cleanse"). #16 The *Siku* edition transposes the characters *fēng* ("wind") and *yǔ* ("rain"). #17 The Kōzan-ji edition adds the character *zhě* ("one who") below *hào* ("to favor"). #18 The character *shǒu* ("head") is supplied following Wang Xiaoyu’s collation notes. #19 Wang Xiaoyu follows the Zhao edition in amending *yì* ("also") to *bì* ("necessarily"). #20 Guo Qingfan’s citation amends *yì* ("different") to *wàn* ("ten thousand"). #21 The original *yòu* ("again") was *hòu* ("after"), and the original *yān* ("how") was *yě* ("also"); both are amended following the *Siku* edition. #22 *Bǎi* ("cypress") is suspected to be a graphic error for *pāi* ("to clap"); it is corrected following the *Siku* edition. #23 The *Siku* edition renders *jù* ("to gather") as *jiàn* ("to see"). #24 Wang Xiaoyu follows the Song edition in amending *lǐ* ("principle") to *mái* ("to bury"). #25 The Kōzan-ji edition omits the character *róng* ("appearance"). #26 The *Siku* edition renders *jì* ("stillness") as *zī* ("this"). #27 The Zhao Jianyi edition renders *tǎng* ("perhaps") as *dǎng* ("party"). #28 The character *liǎng* ("both") is amended to *ér* ("and") following the *Siku* edition. #29 The *Siku* edition renders *tiáo* ("to harmonize") as *chóu* ("dense"). #30 The character *yì* ("also") is amended to *bài* ("to bow") following the *Siku* edition. #31 The Kōzan-ji edition omits the character *yě* ("also"). #32 The *Siku* edition omits the character *xià* ("below"). #33 The character *zhào* ("to commence") is supplied from the preceding subcommentary. #34 The original *zhòng* ("heavy") is suspected to be erroneous and is amended to *dòng* ("to move") following the main text and Guo Qingfan’s citation. #35 The original *rèn* ("to appoint") is incoherent and is amended to *zhù* ("to dwell") following the preceding text and Guo Qingfan’s citation.
